comment: We have been struggling to find good Thai food in Singapore, but this place really hit the spot. The flavours are bold and fresh. Green papaya salad is as close to authentic as you can get. I really enjoyed this place and would recommend it highly.

address: 262 Middle Rd Elias Building Sunshine Plaza Singapore 188989 Singapore
comment: This is our local take out spot. Menu is a hybrid Thai / Chinese offering. Spice level is high just as in Thailand so be clear when ordering if this is not for you. Prices are reasonable and serving size meets western standards. Our favorite is the soft shell crab.

address: 262 Middle Rd Elias Building Sunshine Plaza Singapore 188989 Singapore
comment: Our local Thai kitchen ... Love this place for both eat in and take out.  Menu is clear and the staff are mostly friendly and helpful which is not the norm in singapore! Highly recommend the phad seeyu (kway teow) and the phad thai

Found this venue walking around through the mall starving before finally giving in with the aroma coming from the kitchen that lingered out the hallway is what caught my attention. Pros:-Food are reasonable to its extent. They have several combo meals.-Friendly/Happy Service-Great Food & Great Soju-K-Pop Music playing the background makes it a great atmosphere. Cons:-Bathroom isn't located within the restaurant.  -The restaurant is kinda hard to find inside the mall somewhere. LOL!Will I be back! Hell yeah.... Lines aren't long. Makes it for quicker faster service! Loves it. And the co-workers actually take the time to get to know you. Gotta love great conversations, and asking tips on whats there to see in Singapore and night life and such.

Thanks to the K-Wave in Singapore, Korean food seems to be popping up everywhere in Singapore. This local chain does decent, localized Korean food. If you like something trendy and can have non-stop Korean music blasting at your ear when you dine, you at the right place. On a pricier side, but combo meals make it slightly more shareable if you are a small eater.Seafood tofu soup (Hae Mul Soon Du Bu) is quite bland, but pan cheon (appetizers) can be refilled. Pretty yummy side dishes.If your Korean though and looking for a place to remind you of home cooked food, this is not the right place to look for as it will be too gimmicky and impression-based Seoul.

If you're looking for great service, you've come to the right place! I have to give kudos to the ladies who served our table because she was definitely accommodating to our requests - like having our army stew 'super, duper, extra spicy'. They were extremely attentive and I never had to ask for a refill of my iced barley tea, which is definitely a plus point for me because their cups are rather tiny, and I would hate being a bother who keeps asking for a refill. We got a Signature Combo where for 2 pax, you get one appetizer, one signature dish and one dessert from a selection on their menu. We were quite torn between having the Spicy Rice Cakes or the Pancake/Kimchi Pancake, but went for the first in the end - which we kinda regretted because the fish wasn't as awesome as we imagined it to be. This was I guess the let downer in the entire experience. I definitely loved the Army Stew - we got the one with assorted meat, which was really super yummy! I love that it's served to the table still 'raw' so it's cooked table top on a gas stove which is really good for me and the partner because I like my noodles chewy while he likes it soft - it was the best of both worlds. The meet assortment was rather interesting because they had luncheon meat and sausages as well. It was the first time we were trying this dish, and we can't wait to go to Korea to try the real thing on a cold winter day some time soon! We had Patbingsoo for the dessert - nothing fancy though I would have preferred that it be yoghurt rather than ice cream (substituted because I think they ran out of yoghurt for the day already) - which I guess contributed to the lack the the extra star as well because the ice cream doesn't really go with the dessert as a whole. I would definitely come here to eat again, but I'll be ordering different appetizers next time around. Oh, speaking about appetizers - the tofu with spicy-ish sesame sauce in the 6 little bowls that they give you before your meal is quite awesome!

Very disappointed - very subpar Korean food. This place used to have snaking long lines for its stews, but now is much less popular, and I can unfortunately see why. I came here after seeing the long lines at Yoogane, thinking that Korean food can't exactly be bad right? I even ordered spicy kimchi stew ($12.90) because that's the basic Korean food that's literally impossible to get wrong right? Sadly no. It was a little too salty and tasted of MSG, not the usual pork stew or even tofu taste. The tofu was tough. It didn't even come with white rice. My friend ordered the set with jjajiangrice & dumplings. The dumplings tasted alright but overall average. The appetizers served with the meal were also very tiny plates & subpar. If you're looking for authentic Korean food, don't bother! You can get a good meal for less at so many other places, even the food court is better.

This would definitely rank as my 'between 1 and 2 star' restaurant. Quality of food isn't fantastic (I.e. Rice is dry and has a musky smell to it). Ordered their second combo set for $48.90 suitable for 2 pax but several of the items were pretty bad (EXCEPT their kimchi chigae and grilled salmon!). The beef bibimbap was really dry and tasteless, the beef in it was very dry as well, it was burnt even before we started stirring. Took 2 spoons of the bimbap and that was it. In addition, their 4 side dishes was also dry and somewhat stale, they have pre-prepared them, left it in the open before serving us (oh god). The kimchi chigae was a real redemption though! It was so nice. Tangy and sour, I'm sure they cooked it with real homemade kimchi. Appreciate that. It's quite additive btw. Grilled salmon was a good too. Hygiene wise the place was ok but I've got this impression it isn't clean either. The plates/spoons were slightly dirty, u can see some remnants still attached to them even after washing.I had to use the wet tissue to clean them before dining. Service wise, it was relatively good, staffs were friendly and smiley :) Maybe this restaurant is good for their army stew (as I see many people having that), I've yet tried it so can't comment. Anyhow, wouldn't go for the 2nd combo ever again haha. Army stew... Don't mind trying since their kimchi chigae proves to be awesome :)
Nice service, nice ambiance. If you're into Korean food, this is a good casual place to dine at.
Wonderful ambience for a Sunday morning brunch! Food was healthy and simple, yet elegantly prepared! Will definitely visit again!

Came here to enjoy a cup of coffee while waiting for my friend. The atmosphere is very cute and quiet. I really liked the atmosphere, and how spacious the cafe was. There's enough space between each table, so it didn't feel cramped at all. The food menu items look good, but it seemed like it was on the pricey end. I ordered a flat white, which was $5.90. It was smaller than I expected, and it didn't scream "great" to me. It wasn't bad, but I'm not sure if it's worth the price. However, if you want to cool down at a cafe with a nice atmosphere, this might be a nice cafe to stop by!
Pastas are great here. Portions are fairly large. Great atmosphere, enjoy sitting next to the windows. Their water is always infused and a refreshing treat in the heat.
Spacious with material interior design. Great menu but it's brand new so few people know the place yet. Visit before it gets too crowded.

address: 190 Middle Road #01-02 Fortune Centre Singapore 188979 Singapore
comment: Simple consistent food. Sets are mostly $4.70 and come with 2 soft boiled eggs and a drink. Mains include kaya toast (4 square pieces), French toast, soft bun or egg baguette.I've tried them all and they are worth the price. The kaya here is thick and I do ask for a little extra for my French toast sometimes.You get a bigger cup of tea when it's takeaway but often less thick.The eggs are always nicely done but.. They often take very long to be served!Staff are pleasant.

address: 190 Middle Road #01-02 Fortune Centre Singapore 188979 Singapore
comment: This little coffee and breakfast place has been here for more than 5 years. Run by a group of aunties who are always cheerful and efficient. The coffee is your traditional kopi tiam coffee, strong enough to stand a spoon in. The spanking new  ya  ku which opened up a couple of doors down can't match this kopi-o for strength and flavour or price.

Thai Gold Food is a Thai eatery that serves good and affordable food. Thai Gold Food is frequently compared to its neighbor Aroy-Dee and after trying both out, I still cannot contend which is better. Both are equally good so I guess it boils down to whichever is less crowded. The Phad Thai ($4) was simple and unpretentious. The rice noodles had a nice texture to it and the little bits of egg in it were so flavorful. It was fried well and fragrant. The serving was big and they were generous with the ingredients, which makes it a really value-for-money dish. I really liked the Green Curry with Chicken ($4) too, although it was a bit too spicy. It was fine when paired with white rice. The gravy was thick and delectable, unlike most other places that serve a watered down version of it. There were big juicy pieces of chicken in it too.

Along with a friend, i had a Sunday lunch at Thai Gold.The ambiance is a very basic.  Lol, I am not even sure it qualifies as ambiance.  But, we were just looking for some tasty food and we found it.The service was straight-forward.  They are not going to ask you how your day is going but they are going to make sure your order is taken and your food is brought out in a timely manner.The crispy calamari was very good.  Almost immediately, I polished this off.  It was crispy.  It did not have an oily flavor and the calamari was tender with a mild flavor.tinyurl.com/8mpsekwMy main was a chicken dish with lots of black pepper.  It was so flavorful.  The veggies were fresh and NOT over-cooked.  So, they helped cut through the black pepper.  I thought it made for a great lunch.tinyurl.com/8njrcfdMy friend had a vermicelli dish. It didn't look like much but she didn't seem to mind.  She joyfully ate it all.tinyurl.com/9psywwmWe shared some greens.  By this I mean, I had a bite and my friend ate the remaining.  These were perfectly cooked and quite flavourful.tinyurl.com/8s7wj9eOverall this is a basic restaurant with basic service and pretty good Thai food.  If you are in the neighbourhood and need lunch, I can give it a two thumbs up.

Sunshine Plaza is basically a shrine of good thai food. Three thai food restaurants line up in a row on one side of the Plaza. For me, Thai Gold is indeed king of the bunch. I've tried the Pad Thai here and the Pineapple Rice, and both are so worthy of coming back for more, especially for this price. In Thai Gold, you could easily get a hearty genuine thai meal for less than $8. My serving of Pineapple Rice cost no more than $5, and was filling enough for one. The rice was very well oiled and cooked, strategically filled with pineapple and topped with pork floss and cashew nuts. Very tasty, very fragrant. My counterpart today had the rice with fried garlic chicken, which was surprisingly amazing, and literally blew my mind with how crisp it was, and how rich the garlic taste was. The tenderness was also something I hadn't expected from a shop that serves out food as cheap and quick as this. One dampener for me is the thai iced tea, which looked good with its layers, but wasn't very 'together', even if it was very sweet and thick. In summary: great great value, good genuine thai food. I'd just come back from Bangkok a week ago and found that the tastes here were very familiar to those along the streets of Bangkok. Sawadikrap!!!
Food is tasty, ambience is dull and dark. Portion of the food is small. $5 for a plate of Basil pork rice + omelette. Does not sell any nice coffee.

address: 190 Middle Road Fortune Centre Singapore 188979 Singapore
comment: I've been here a number of times over the years and the standard is pretty consistent. I highly recommend the thunder tea rice, dragon roll, soba salad, rainbow salad and bibimbap. Most main items are around the $8-10 range.Not a place to linger and chat. Service is fairly quick and friendly. There is one kooky auntie who I adore

address: 190 Middle Road Fortune Centre Singapore 188979 Singapore
comment: There are tons of cuisines on the menu, all vegetarian, and a friendly staff who chats with you right through it :) The flavours are yummy! There's a store at the back for quirky food stuff if that's what you want to do after a full meal!

address: 190 Middle Road Fortune Centre Singapore 188979 Singapore
comment: I've always known Fortune Centre is laden with a lot of vegetarian option, perhaps due to it's proximity to the Guan Yin Temple nearby. I've walked past Fortune Centre multiple times, even went into it, but never had the chance to dine here cos there are so many options, I dont know which to choose from!So a colleague who frequents Fortune Centre finally gave me a quick orientation and we ended up at New Green Pasture. A mixture of a restaurant and grocery selling organic food, there is a wide selection of dishes to choose from, such as salads to mixed rice combos and other soup/noodle options.I had the Lei Cha set which is very refreshing yet filling. Using brown rice, the dish is even more nutritious. The Charcoal Noodles uses passionfruit to lift the taste of the dish and made it light and appetizing. Overall the dishes has a certain character and they taste great!

address: 190 Middle Road Fortune Centre Singapore 188979 Singapore
comment: The good: Some of the best vegetarian food I've ever tasted. Try the Sri Lanka rolls and soba salad. I'm a total meat lover but whenever I'm in the area I swing by. Refillable water which is a bonus for me, I know, it's the small things in life. They even have a cafe/grocery section. The bad: Not easy to find, as its on the 3rd floor of a somewhat vacant mall. The ugly: A lot of the shops surrounding the restaurant are "massage" places, so it really changes the vibe while eating.  I usually battle at least 2-3 winks on my way here.

address: 190 Middle Road Fortune Centre Singapore 188979 Singapore
comment: I recently tried the Rainbow Salad. This was refreshing and tasted fresh, with a zesty flavour. It was really like a rainbow, with vibrant colours from the variety of raw vegetables. A great dish. Try not to sit indoors near the kitchen though, as the smells wafting from the kitchen are rather strong. I sat outdoors and the smells still got to me. Perhaps I'll sit further inside, away from the kitchen the next time.

address: 91 Bencoolen St #01-18/10/20, Sunshine Plaza Singapore 189652 Singapore
comment: Maybe we were expecting a little too much? We went late on a weekday, near closing time. The service was brusque and the food, very average. Maybe worth another shot now that we know what it is like and try the food without the expectations :)

address: 91 Bencoolen St #01-18/10/20, Sunshine Plaza Singapore 189652 Singapore
comment: The restaurant was located between a Thai restaurant and an Ice cream outlet, at the first floor of the building. The restaurant was small and simple in decoration. It offered Thai cuisine in vegetarian style, which was seldom found in Singapore.Fried Kang Kong Salad 炸马来风光菜沙律 ($12)Deep fried crispy and light greens, served with a sweet sauce. It was light and crispy, none of the usual crunchy texture that was usually associated with kang kong. The sauce looked like curry but tasted quite sweet.Phap Thai 亁烧泰式细河粉 ($8)It was served with lime, raw bean sprouts, chopped peanuts and chilli flakes by the side. The noodles tend to stick together. It was lacking of the hei wok.Tom Kha Kai (Coconut Milk Soup) 东炎汤炖椰粒 ($8)I'm surprise that the coconut flesh was used in place of fish meat in this dish. Inside the coconut, there was also mushroom, carrot, and mock meat. The soup was not too spicy, and tasted quite milky.Olive Fried Rice 橄榄炒饭 ($8)It's quite tasty on its own, topped with cashew nut and meat floss. It was savoury while simple in look.Overall the food was delicious. Although we were the last customers of the day, the staffs did not pressure us to finish the food by 10pm. The staffs were friendly and made small talks.

Chili crab pasta ($17++= $20) - 4.5 starsHuge portion! Lots of fettuccine, and better still ample crab meat and even soft shell crab! Taste was spicy enough to make time perspire but for some reason the flavor was a tad lacking. Not enough for me to complain though.I love the decor here - the spacious minimalist interior and huge windows! Coming back for sure.

Crossings offers quality food in a casually nice ambiance, with all profits going to charity. Whenever a restaurant has an open kitchen, I know that they pride in the food they prepare, with nothing to hide. I was very satisfied with the items I ordered: The crabmeat fettuccine, mushroom soup, sweet potato crossings, and Americano.Taking a star away for the sweet potato fries which could have been more flavourful (or come with a side of sauce). Otherwise fantastic experience, will definitely return to try other items from the menu!

Went to Crossings Cafe for lunch to celebrate my dad's birthday.  Its a Saturday afternoon and it was crowded.  Luckily I made a reservation.We ordered the quesadillas and chicken wings for appetisers. The quesadillas were good, even though the fillings were distributed a little unevenly. Chicken wings were good too, with a very good crunch to them, but just slightly over-salty. For mains, we had the laksa, braised beef shin, chicken parmigiana and honey berry ribs. The laksa was surprisingly the best dish of the lot, although 12.90 for laksa is rather expensive. The parmigiana was tasty, but don't order it if you don't like your food deep fried. Some of the ends were almost charred. Almost. The beef shin was tagged to be the best dish of the lot, but unfortunately it was pretty ordinary,like stir fried beef at a zhichar stall. The honey Berry ribs were alright, although I couldn't taste the honey or Berry in the sauce. The ribs themselves were fall-odf-the-bone tender, but slightly underseasoned. Now all the food was served with impeccable timing. The appetisers were served first, and once they were done, all the mains came together..  Except the ribs. Unfortunately the waiter forgot to key in my order, and the ribs only arrived 15 minutes after everyone else had finished their mains. The waiter was of course apologetic,and I found it hard to lose my cool when scripture was hanging on the wall right in front of me. Overall, the food was good but somehow just missed the mark by a little bit. If it weren't for the forgotten order, I'd have given it 5 stars.

Been wanting to try out this place for about a month now after chancing upon reviews on Yelp and of course to aid social enterprises along the way. Came here after attending a visual art exhibition at Singapore Arts Museum (walkable distance) and since there were quite a number of space, we managed to get seated on a comfy sofa like chair. The waiter approached us checking whether we would want some iced water while we decide on our orders. It was a nice professional gesture from their end. After browsing through a one double sided menu, I decided to order the following.1) Wanted to order root beer but it was out of stock. Same with my friends' orders of Ginger beer.2) Decided to order Snapple's pink lemonade instead.3) Chilli crab pasta sounded good at that moment so decided to order that. They ran out of Fettuccine so I had to change the pasta to spaghetti instead. Verdict: pasta was warm when it was served, chewy and tender in terms of texture. The  deep fried soft shell crab were both delicious and crunchy (managed to get the ones with eggs) and the Crossings' own chilli crab claw meat sauce were flavorful and hint of spicy made the dish special. (definitely recommended)4) My friend ordered fish and chips. The fish batter was pretty good and the portion of the fish fillet was bigger than expected too. 5) Hazelnut molten cake with ice cream. The dish was warm when it arrived to our table. The chocolate was a little bitter but the cake was moist and soft. Combined with the vanilla ice cream, it is one of best lava cake in Singapore. Overall, price wise it was quite affordable and considering that profits will be directed to charities made this place a gem. The service was excellent too as they checked on the customers' needs quickly when customers raised their hands. As my friends and I left for this place, we were also greeted with a thanks. Will be back soon for more yummy goodies :)

Though waiting time can take a little longer but the food never disappoints. As a social enterprise, I am very impressed with the level of service delivered by servers who are challenged in different special ways. They are professional and extremely polite. The greatest I derive from dining at this place is the fact that not only do I get good food and good service, all profits are donated to charity! So as I enjoy a good meal, I am also able to contribute to the society. What more can I ask?There are many places that use the term social enterprise very loosely and patrons suffer either from high price (in the name of social cause and benefit) or bad food/service and we are expected to be understanding because the special needs or at-risk individuals are involved. That should not be the case. Quality and experience should not be compromised for the sake of social good. I fully support Crossings because they have created an environment that bring out the best in all the staff, regardless of their special needs and patrons are always well taken care of. Respect!

Nice cafe with a meaningful concept and tasty food. It is a social enterprise which hires disadvantaged people. I had aglio olio with mushroom and bacon whereas my friends had chilli crab pasta. We also shared sweet potato fries. The dishes were all well done and service was attentive. I would highly recommend checking out this cafe and contributing to society in a small way.

I always go cos I want to support this local social enterprise cafe. They hire kids with disabilities or are disenfranchised or marginalized. For this fact alone, I will go support them. But more importantly, I love their coffees as they are yums and come in nice mason jars. Additionally, their sweet potato fries are substantial for an appetizer and very yummy. Oh gosh. I am drooling.

Modest little social enterprise cafe on Waterloo street. Prompt service and cheap food. The ribs I had were a ribstickingly generous portion. Could've done with a stronger marinade. But the sweet potato fries were delicious. The spicy coriander fish was good. Decent slab of fish and the coriander paste was tasty and nicely calibrated. I like that the orange juice tasted fresh squeezed not concentrate. Place was bright and buzzy and there's free wifi. Good place to grab quick bite and I love the social enterprise driven nature. Go support support!

I had fish and chips, and honestly speaking, taste way better than your regular chain of fish and chips. Fish is breaded and the chips are those thicker fries. And suprisingly, very well fried and all the strands taste almost the same. Even the salad and the dressing harmonise well. The staffs are always ready to serve. Definitely coming back monthly!

address: 1 Rochor Canal Rd #B1-08/26, Sim Lim Square Singapore 188504 Singapore
comment: Came by the other day for a light lunch and it was a tasty experience. Tried out the spicy seafood stir fried keoy teo and it had nice wok hey along with bits of seafood, including shrimp, and scallops.There were chilis on the side for additional flavor too!The food court was air conditioned with numerous stalls. Seems like cash is preferred!

address: 1 Rochor Canal Rd #B1-08/26, Sim Lim Square Singapore 188504 Singapore
comment: There is an authentic Vietnamese outlet here and their beef noodle Pho is great.I won't say much for their spring roll which they served Chinese ones instead of authentic Vietnamese ones this time around

address: 1 Rochor Canal Rd #B1-08/26, Sim Lim Square Singapore 188504 Singapore
comment: Broadway Food Court is an ideal makan place for residents or employees of the local area surrounding Sim Lim. As a Lasalle student, this is an ideal place for a quick bite. Prices are moderate though can be lower for certain stalls.As the place recently finished renovations, the premises looks cleaner and more updated. Welcome to 2015, Broadway. The current problem with the place is the insufficient quantity of halal makan stalls. The only one that is qualified as halal is Indian * Pakistan Cuisine. The stall is run by an Indian man with, whom I believe is his mother, in the kitchen. I ordered the Butter Chicken with Naan, costing $7.50. There was an option to take Naan, but I wasn't sure if it was chargeable or complimentary. The food comes as 1 plate of naan and 1 boat of butter curry with the chicken inside it. The naan tasted fresh and excellent as it is cooked and prepared from dough on the spot. The butter curry tastes strong and feels rather sweet as well, though this is expected of butter. The chicken cutlets which are soaked in the curry are also savory and taste delicious. I decided to go for a mini taco kinda thing and wrapped pieces of naan with curry and chicken. Simply excellent. With that said, the price is a little steep but is justified by the taste and cost of ingredients. Broadway has finally upped its game but holds potential in the future by possibly adding more halal food.Definitely a place to go for now as a regular makan place, assuming you're not Muslim.

address: 1 Rochor Canal Rd #B1-08/26, Sim Lim Square Singapore 188504 Singapore
comment: It's difficult not to be engrossed with shopping in Sim Lim. But when your tummy grumbles, it's time to take a break and head on downstairs, to the food court.I did not need to go far just to grab something to eat. It was great that there was a food court down stairs. Even though it's small, they still have a lot of food stalls to choose from. Also, it's quite interesting that despite the lunch crowd, it does not seem crowded or overwhelming. I had the western meal and unlike the other western meals I've had in other food courts, this was a huge serving-definitely western-ish. After lunch, just walk upstairs and continue your tech shopping.I think everyone would agree that when shopping, it's great to know that there's a nearby food place to go to recharge.

address: 12 Queen Street #02-01, Hotel Royal @ Queens Singapore 188553 Singapore
comment: For this classmate gathering, Melvin decided to bring us to this chinese restaurant which was located at the second floor of the hotel. It was located near Bras Basah MRT Station (CC2). As it was a week day night, the restaurant was not crowded and we were showed to a private room for our dinner. The room was big with at least 4 tables. It was full glass window where one can have a good view of outside. As Melvin was a regular customer, he had done some  consulting with the chef about the menu. He decided on what was fresh and what was the chef's best dishes.We started the meal with Roasted Suckling Pig. Surprisingly it was served with the sweet sauce underneath. The skin was crispy and fatty part was simply melted in the mouth.Next we had double boiled soup. Inside the soup, there was shark's fin, dried scallop, whelk, ginseng, chicken,and chinese ham. The soup was very flavourful.For the fish dish, we had Baked fish with Cream Sauce. It was served with asparagus. The fish was simply melted in the mouth. Everyone agreed that it was the best dish of this meal.Next we had Stir Fried Scallop and Shimeji Mushroom with XO sauce. Tasted slightly spicy, the scallop was quite juicy.This was followed by the Crispy Roasted Chicken. It was served topped with crispy curry leaves, almond slices, sliced chilli, and savoury crispy bites. I like the savoury crispy bites which added another layer of taste to the roasted chicken.For the vegetable dish, we had Braised Abalone with seasonal vegetables. It was served with shiitake mushroom and spinach. The abalone was well flavoured here.For the carbohydrates, we had Lotus Leaf Rice. The glutinous rice flavoured with chicken, shiitake mushrooms, and chinese ham. The rice was not too mushy.Lastly for dessert, we had Hashima. It was served hot, with longan, red date, ginseng, and lotus seed. It did not taste too sweet. The lotus seed was well cooked and soft to bite. Hashima is made from the dried fatty tissue found near the fallopian tubes of true frogs. The version here was simply melted in the mouth.Overall the food was very good. Although I did not get to see the actual bill, but it was about $100 per person for this meal. Sounded expensive but it was expected considering the expensive items ordered. The staffs were friendly. Plates were replaced for every dish. The manager and even the chef also came over to check on our table. Guess Melvin was such a VIP here.

So happy to have come across Ginett - this is an excellent place to have weekend brunch that offers an affordable free flow option.  As long as you order a main dish, you can add on free flow mimosas (for 2 hours) for an extra $15, which I thought was a steal!  The servers are also really good about refills, even if your glass is not quite empty yet.  Don't expect the drink to be strong but you have more than enough time to drink your money's worth.  Food is reasonably priced - I ordered the bolognese and it was delicious.  I was here for my birthday and received a complimentary dessert and bottle of bubbly.  This was certainly a nice touch.  Can't wait to come back again!

Ambience 4. Food 4. Service 4. Value 4.  G Board u get to choose what cheese you want so that was good.  Only meat we did not like was the bologne.  Pate pastry was a miss both in taste and texture.  One thing though food does take a long time to come out so sticking to a 2 hr duration may be a little stretch.  200 days age steak came out good but perhaps just a tad under season.  Mush risotto was nice.  Not easy to achieve a nice texture.

This restaurant-bar strikes a very nice balance between pricing, decor and food. I enjoyed my evening here very much except that the service got slower and more distracted as the evening went on.Wine here is incredibly well priced - I would totally recommend popping in with friends to share a bottle (or two). When I was there, bottles started at $30 (!!!) and that made me a very happy customer. Also, despite the price tag, they were very decent bottles.The food here was quite good, the only thing I have to say is that French food is on the heavy side. The bone marrow was super generous - it came with 3 giant bones which you can scrape out deliciously onto toasted bread. The pork rilette was also yummy and went well with the pickled cornichons provided on the side. The mains are well priced as well, and while I liked my Kurobuta t-bone, it all became quite heavy. I was not a fan of their desserts though.I think this place would do great as a place for a drink and a bite! I will probably come back for the very reasonably priced drinks.

While I ordered the least expensive (strip loin) on the menu, it was riddled with fat and grissle.  Service on a second glass of wine took 15 minutes.  And I ordered it while my first glass was only half done.  Oysters on special were too small and hardly worth it.Having said that, the wine selection is very good and the appetizers, while over priced, look good, too.

My boyfriend and I came here for the Sunday brunch and experienced a disaster. Upon being seated, we were informed of a long list of items that were no longer available due to missing ingredients. Our server was clueless about the menu and how items were prepared when we inquired. After ordering, someone came over to tell us that they were out of heirloom tomatoes so they needed to modify the dish we ordered for regular tomatoes. I ordered an iced latte. They forgot to bring sugar or sweetners so after requesting it and waiting far too long with no action, I went to the bar and picked some up. After tasting it, the latte was way too strong and I requested a hot latte instead. The server asked several questions asking if it could be modified, I responded no, she finally took it away. Awhile later she arrived with the replacement, right before I drank from it, she came and took it away saying it was hot chocolate (a mistake). She later returned with what looked like the same drink (now barely hot) and I could finally consume my mediocre coffee. Then the food came out, I ordered the croque monsieur with fried eggs. It barely resembled any croque monsieur I've ever had. It was also extremely bland. I had to add salt and pepper to give it some flavor. We were then ignored forever, ran out of water and only got a refill when we asked for it. To make matters worse, a few hours later, as I prepared to head out for the evening, I got a horrible stomachache. My boyfriend had to run out to get me medicine and we spent the rest of our first day in Singapore in bed. This restaurant not only ruined our meal, but also our first of only three days in the city. With so many great places to eat in Singapore, DON'T GO HERE AND REGRET IT LIKE US!

I walked and sat at the bar with one bartender making a drink and another cleaning the coffee machine. I was not acknowledged or asked anything for ten minutes while the bartender and the the other worker clearly saw me and another couple. Service is lacking and should be avoided as it's clear they have their hands full. This was a Monday with maybe three tables seated by the way and a server on the floor.
Great bar! Super friendly bar staff, some reasonable drinks, great atmosphere! The food is okay, but overall a really lovely place to hang out and enjoy the space and open walls.

The food was reasonable. The Kang Kong was gorgeous with 5 star rating. Awesome sambal. The beef strips was also delicious and juicy and had wokhay. It got a 4 star from my family. The original reason we came to Rex was supposed to be for its chicken rice. This however was disappointing to half the people eating it's supposed to be the top 10 chicken rice. The chicken was good tasting but fairly dry. The rice can be a little more fragrant and the chili more viscous as it is a little dilute and thin. I would skip the chicken rice if I visited again and stuck to the Zi char.

100% best chicken rice that I had in Singapore. Chicken is tender, perfectly cooked, well-seasoned and delicious. I am usually wary of ordering chicken because many restaurants can overlook them. The aloe Vera jelly drink is really delicious. Return the wet napkins to the front if you don't want to pay for them. We liked the restaurant so much that we ate there twice during our vacation.

I've been here recently for dinner. The food is pretty good and the place is hygienic.I enjoyed the chicken rice, crispy sotong and longan juice.It's a great place for those who enjoy halal food and it's quiet affordable as well.A small suggestion, I certainly feel that they should mention the specialties to the new customers so that they may enjoy the food better

Consistently good halal zichar. The beef hor fun si chap is always a winner, as is the chicken rice. Other hot favourites are the crispy lemon chicken, fried baby squid (this one is addictive) and the ngoh hiang (it's made from chicken and my Malay friends adore it). The clam soup is pretty darned good even though the clams are from a can - watch out if you're on a date though. The soup's loaded with garlic

Value for money lunch sets even on weekends! Starting from $9.80++! Really fresh fish for the price! Waiters are attentive and helpful! Order via an iPad or call for service by the iPad as well! Easy to use menu ordering system. I ordered and the food came pretty quickly!

Traveling solo so this was dinner for one. Don't pity me, I don't mind. The outdoor seating is quite good - spacious, near a wide walkway so you can people watch without fear of trampling, and there is some kind of fan blowing down so it's cool (relatively speaking). You get what you pay for here: middle-price meals for middle-price quality and middle-price service. You can get better Japanese cuisine in the Intercontinental restaurant 100 meters away, but for 5X the cost. The menu offerings are quite good, just the execution isn't top notch.

Thought that the place was not crowded but turned out that most of the tables were under reservation. In the end we decided on the counter seats with a great view of the staffs grilling the sticks. Although we were sitting right in front of the grilling section, it was not smoky. While looking through the menu, we were served a complimentary side dish which was lightly dressed cabbage.Volcano Roll ($9.90++/ 4pcs)Sushi roll with avocado, crabmeat, and cucumber on top with spicy salmon, flying fish roe and homemade spicy mayonnaise sauceFelt the roll itself was rather bland without the mayonnaise sauce. The avocado, crab meat and salmon could barely be tasted.Bakudan Korokke ($8.90++)Homemade Egg Potato CroquetteIt looked like a deep fried ball when served. Cut it opened, one would be able to see the molten lava egg yolk flowing out smooothlng from inside. Potato salad enclosed the egg. Interesting dish by itself. No wonder it was recommended by the staff. Tsukune ($4.90++)Big Chicken Meatball with CheeseThe meatball were so juicy and crunchy that my partner thought we were having pork meatballs and could not believe that its chicken.Enoki Bacon ($3.90++)Bacon & Golden Mushroom with Garlic Soy SauceThe stick looked rather dry but it was juicy and crunchy.Eringi ($3.90++)Oyster Mushroom in Garlic ButterI like that the mushroom was lightly seasoned which one could still taste the actual flavour of the mushroom.We down the meal with green tea ($1++/ pax), which was refillable.

My friend recommended me to come here, but I feel disappointed with the food . All food is just normal and not very fresh (especially salmon ), the soya source and wasabi taste not good at all compare to Japan. Not good experience here.

I went to their new outlet at Icon Village.. Nice all you can eat a la carte buffet.. Best happy hour in CBD with $5 for mug of Sapporo draft (same price for a mug of tiger at lau pa sat!!)Yakitori, ramen, sushi, sashimi are all tastefully done. Even the salads are good with sesame dressings. very affordable prices and a very good option for a carb free meal.

I don't get the hype about this place. Food items are meh, with the exception of the tennis ball sized croquette that I would have given two years of my life span for. First things first, the ipad ordering system isn't intuitive at all. You can't easily find stuff you're looking for, because say.. A noodle item might not be listed under noodles, but under best sellers instead. When it's late 9pm and you're hungry and cannot find that item and you get angry.. HANGRY alert! Speaking of noodles. There was this spicy cold noodle thing that was terrible and tasteless. My dining companion had to douse the noodles with soy sauce, and it was still barely resuscitated. And the oyako don- chicken and egg both overcooked. Oh the travesty. Chicken soft bone was not soft at all, overly fried and hard. Gyozas were ok only, as were the skewers. On hindsight I should have just eaten 4 croquettes instead. There's a luscious onsen egg inside that's still cold, and oozes very silkily and sexily across your dish. Major points for that. And the draft Sapporo. Otherwise.. Nope, not going back.

This review is based on a dinner I had on 7 Oct 2014.Sumire is tucked in a corner of Bugis Junction, first floor next to Nandos.As usual, I ordered a mountain of assorted yakitori and these are the highlights:1. Aburi Avocado. Grilled avocado! What's not to like?2. Liver (Tare) Medium grilled pieces of liver with tare sauce. Could be a smidgen more raw.3. Toro Hatsu (Shio) Grilled little chicken hearts on a stick, sprinkled with salt. Perfect!Service was ok, exception was Dean. He was attentive and polite. More items on the menu I would like to try, definitely the giant fluffy croquette I saw on my neighbouring diner's table.I will be back!

I was here with a friend for dinner after work. There's nothing here that I didn't like! The food was good, every single item we ordered (we ordered mainly grilled food, but even the kaisen chirashi don was delish!). Although the crowd tend to be a little more loud and rowdy, there's sufficient privacy. Orders are mainly done on the iPad. Even so, the service staff were friendly and prompt (knowing that it's our first visit to the restaurant, one of the staff did an introduction to the menu to us). Definitely gonna go there again! :)

The place was packed on a Thursday night about an hour before closing. Idealite is located not too far from a MRT station. I had a herbal soup with the fixings, which paired really well with brown rice. This herbal soup is not bitter, but actually fragrant with lots of veggies and hard-boiled eggs. The soup can be easily shared with 3-4 people. I also had noodles in a pumpkin curry sauce topped with tofu. The noodles weren't heavy nor did I feel sluggish afterwards.Lots of beverage options at Idealite, hot and cold. I opted for a hot ginger citron tea even though it was hot and humid outside. The inside was nice and cool. Thank you for turning on the AC.Service was good. All the staff members spoke Singlish (Singapore English) and Chinese Mandarin. Restroom is a bit of a tight squeeze, literally, there was one small room. Sink is outside. I'd actually come back again just for the herbal soup!

Cheap and good kopitiam which offers a whole range of local cuisines. Fragrant braised chicken rice is very good but expensive if you want to buy the whole chicken. Rong kee stall at the end is my favourite for wonton noodles as they're old school and still use lard oil to flavour the dry noodles. The porridge stall serves fluffy Cantonese style chok. The sliced fish is good as well as the pork porridge. But I miss the raw fish platter they used to serve. And the boiled fish skin. They were both drenched in a savoury soya sesame sauce with spring onions and chilli padi. Shiok.At night the three shops are all taken over by zichar shops.
I tried the first dish of Singapore, the famous Bak Kut Teh , and this little place sold the best BKT.

This is my favorite stall in Food Junction/Bugis Junction.Sizzling hot food is a good thing.  This is certainly sizzling hot.  The staff is friendly and helpful.  This takes a tad longer than many of the other stalls.  But it is made fresh.  Plus, it is often busy.  But the wait is never really that long.I get the beef plate.  The portion is pretty decent.   It is super hot and comes on a plate that helps keep it hot.   It is pretty simply.  There is beef and rice along with the basic seasoning.  There is a side of rice and some soup.  It is all good.  For a quick dinner with no frills, this does the trick for me.tinyurl.com/8vftfjxFood Junction is very clean.  Even when busy, there tends to always be seats.  When you are carrying a tray with a hot sizzling platter, this is important.

address: 201 Victoria Street #01-13 Bugis Plus Singapore 188067 Singapore
comment: Another concept under the Paradise Group, Kung Fu Paradise is a semi-fast food concept selling local delights. They range from main local cuisine like the typical coffee shop fare, to western options like salads or baked rice, and even sandwiches or burgers. A great variety of choices, at an affordable price somewhere between actual fast food chains and more proper restaurants you can find in the mall. On a late Saturday afternoon, the store is not as packed as you would probably expect, which in a way is good news for diners since they get full attention from the service staff. The decor is bright and cheery with orange and black as its main theme, providing a warm and welcoming atmosphere to its diners. It is a set up perfect for a casual day out or when you just want to grab a quick bite. Cutlery, napkins and DIY order forms a all placed on the table to reduce the need for service staff. However, the staff are all polite and willing to help if you require any assistance.

address: 201 Victoria Street #01-13 Bugis Plus Singapore 188067 Singapore
comment: KungFu Paradise is kinda like a Hong Kong style cafe, serving up everyday dishes which are cheaper by restaurant standards, but expensive if you consider that you could prepare a number of dishes on your own.Still, definitely good if you're in the mood for something light or supper-like - the milo shaved ice I ordered came with oreo bits and tadpole jellies and was quite yummy and large. The chicken cutlet burger was cheap, but a tad oily and they put a huge amount of mayo on it which I scooped out.They have some sort of points redemption system going on where you can redeem points through a cardless system - just quote your IC # at the cashier for any paradise group restaurant and you'll get some rebates!

address: 201 Victoria Street #01-13 Bugis Plus Singapore 188067 Singapore
comment: Late night food! My first night in Singapore this was one of the only places still open so we went to grub after a loooooong flight. The menu and signs everywhere frequently remind you that there is no lard in anything :) The lava buns are a bit too salty for me. The lava eggs are delicious though. The noodle plate I had wasn't anything impressive but in a pinch I'd come back here.

address: 201 Victoria Street #01-13 Bugis Plus Singapore 188067 Singapore
comment: Not a top choice in my opinion to go to but cos it's under the Paradise Group, they serve the same Salt Yolk Custard bun as Canton Paradise. They have recently started to absorb both GST and Service Charge so what you see (on the menu), is what you pay. The food is just average for me but they do have quite a good Curry Baked Rice. The instant mee selection is alright, other HK cafes taste better.

address: 201 Victoria Street #01-13 Bugis Plus Singapore 188067 Singapore
comment: One of the latest additions to our already plentiful dining spots, Kungfu Paradise, brought to you by the Paradise group, is a HK 'char chan teng' style café that serves no pork or lard. A new addition at Bugis+, Kungfu Paradise makes itself more attractive to the supper crowd by staying open till 2am from Sundays to Thursday and till 3am on Fridays and Saturdays. The menu is simple, with a local twist on the items and priced very reasonably. There is a recommendation page on the menu to help you decide, from which I tried the "Kungfu Master Salad", "Kungfu Bumger" and was very satisfied.The only drawback is that there are no al fresco dining areas which means no smoking areas. And getting out to smoke is a hassle, considering there are no nearby exits.

Konkatsu set. Good nice cutlet with a shredded cabbage with a nice vinaigrette dressing and a cool potato salad on the side. Don't miss that small droplet of mustard at the edge of the plate. Great miso soup with onions carrots in it. I think the dessert that comes with it is ice cream.

Enjoyable space on the 2nd floor of Bugis Junction. I think the decor is suppose to be French, but there's also a bunch of mish-mash of things that had me guessing for a little bit. It was a comfortable, casual environment. Anyway, the menu has a pretty good offering of dishes, including escargot in garlic butter. The pork tonkatsu was moist but a little fatty for my liking. The panko crust was delicate and didn't leave you that oily mouth feel. The Tonteki pork steak was good too and pan-fried perfectly. The fatty parts had a nice char and the meat was tender and juicy. Usually, the Tonteki comes smothered in their "Original Tonkatsu Sauce" which I'm glad I asked for on the side because although it was tasty in a Worcestershire sauce kinda way, it would have overwhelmed the pork steak. Plenty of beer and wine selection to choose from. Didn't have room for dessert, but there is a large offering of it if you are so inclined to indulge in. The service was excellent throughout the dinner service, even more so than many other fancier places. There is a set lunch menu that changes daily. The entrees includes a "healthy salad and drink" it says. Great place to grab a meal, a drink, and/or dessert.

The food is probably overrated. I ordered a day carbonara spaghetti , hamburger steak and clam chowder soup. It taste regular and nothing really stood out. The spaghetti was good but too oily. Other than that, the restaurant renovation and atmosphere still quite acceptable

I came here by myself after work and sat at the bar counter (kinda awkward sitting in a table when all the other tables are pairs...). I like sitting on the counter though, you get to peek at one the cooks are doing through a glass pane.Like everyone said, the decor of this place is super cute and cozy, modeled after a small B&B or something. They also play this adorable jazzy french music in the background.I got the sizzling hamburg steak since that seems to be getting rave reviews. It's not bad for $19.90. Tasty and fills me up - it comes with fries and a bed of bean sprouts. Kinda reminds me of a glorified pepper lunch. It was served in an interesting manner too - The waiter will pour some sort of liquid on your egg and burger, and it would light up for awhile before she pours another liquid on top of it to put the fire out.After serving your meal, your waiter will give you a key which you will then take to the cashier to pay your bill and "check out" of this lovely B&B. cute eh?

This is a review of a Sunday lunch at Ma Maison in Bugis Junction.After a quick discussion of places to have lunch, we decided on Ma Maison.Upon arrival, we were quickly seated.  Throughout our meal, the service was prompt, professional, and polite.The ambiance is relatively basic but it is a step up from most of the other restaurants in Bugis Junction.The food ranged from average to very good.  However, only one dish made it beyond the average mark.Breaded Prawns - This was my favorite part of the meal.  I enjoyed the  breading.  The prawns had a very fresh flavour to them.  The presentation was very appealing.tinyurl.com/cy8fu65Chef's Pizza - This was a basic pizza.  It had some small shrimp and other general ingredients.  There was nothing that stood out about this pizza.  I am NOT saying this was a frozen microwave pizza.  It did remind me of one though.tinyurl.com/a2txw22Paella - My friend ordered the paella.  She enjoyed it.  I tried a bite or two.  The rice was dense.  It seemed to all hold together ok but it did not stand out to me.  Even with the fresh seafood, it seemed bland.  The presentation for this dish was nice.tinyurl.com/arcgp6dOverall, if you live or are shopping in the neightbourhood, this is a decent option for lunch.  The room is nice enough.  The service is solid.  While the food may not rock the world, it is good enough to make for an enjoyable lunch.

When you go to Ma Maison.. regardless of which branch you go to.. the service is always quite consistent.. a nice greeting... waiters/waitresses with initiative to take away your plates, fill up your water... Food is also quite consistent. Tried their famous breaded pork cutlet here and it's the same as the one at Clarke Quay Central. Their escargot is affordable and did not disappoint as well. So if you are around the area and you are looking for affordable french food, Ma Maison is it!

I am very late to the Ma Maison game thanks to general blurness on my part. Last year, while looking for places to eat on a Friday night at Liang Court, I stumbled across this strange French cottage-looking restaurant with tons of ladies waiting outside. Couldn't put two together and moved on. Earlier this year, after moving to my new workplace at Suntec, a friend suggested we have lunch at Ma Maison at Bugis Junction. When I walked in (once again, there was a line for lunch), everything clicked!I've only had the Ma Maison set meals with grilled steak, hamburg steak and tonkatsu because someone told they're really good at the hamburg. Why order anything else if a restaurant is great with it's grill right? All of those dishes have been fantastic, with the hamburg steak taking the cake no matter what sauce I've had it with. Plus if you're feeling thirsty, they have a good range of beers by the bottle and some very appetizing tarts that I've *yet* to try.What really rocks my boat however is the service. For Singapore standards, the Bugis outlet has some of the best service I've experienced in this country. From the usual embarrassing welcome you get at Japanese restaurants to accommodating substitutions, explaining sauces and keeping my water glass filled, the staff here get top marks. It's one of the few times I find myself saying, "boy do the Japanese know how to train their service staff right" because they all look happy and serve professionally. I do notice that the Japanese managers pay more attention to Japanese customers, but hey I would too if I was working in a foreign country and the "less attentive" level already exceeds most competitors. However, I would point out that service at the Parco Millenia restaurant is not great and borders on rude on occasion because, well you guessed it, there are no Japanese managers on site and the outlet seems severely understaffed. One can't have everything so I suggest sticking to Bugis Junction. Lastly, come early or past 1pm during lunchtime to avoid lining up for long. Forget dinner on Mondays (ladies happy hour) or Fridays if you're starving and don't want to wait.

Have you never had the hamburg steak? it's only the bestest, moistest, most tasty patty of beef you can find... but not between two buns. I guess I'd call it a mod-Japanese/Western dish, and this is pretty dang fantastic. Plus it comes with a sunny-side-up egg on top. And that sauce...I really should also tell you I had the company of the lovely ladies Kathryn B and Michelle L (now M) at lunch, and all I can do now is talk about this food... guess I'm not a very gracious dining companion eh?I think they'd agree that the food was pretty awesome, and the service deserves a good mention too - every staff member was available, without being intrusive, and for newbies, I guess the only odd thing was when one of the staff handed me a key as I asked for the bill. What do I do with this now? He told me to bring it to the cashier, and when I handed it over, it hit me - it's a kitschy form of "checking out" of the restaurant, and it completes the cottagey/B&B-themed experience.Decor aside (which really isn't bad), I'd go back for that hamburg...

Expect a queue when you come by Ma Maison after work on every day of the week. I waited about 10 minutes to get a table today, which wasn't too bad, considering that it was "Ladies Night" on Mondays. 20% off ala carte items - score!The decoration of the place is lovely. The lighting's a little dim, but it adds to the cosy atmosphere of the restaurant. I had the Gratin with Prawns and Scallops ($13.80), which was pretty good, but they were rather miserly with the actual prawns and scallops - there were only two pieces of each in the large bowl. My friend had the Fresh Greens salad ($6.90) with Japanese dressing - I wasn't too impressed with that. We ended the meal with a Strawberry Tart ($8.80) - the most popular out of at least five different flavours of tarts - and it was not bad. However, the tart base was almost like a very dry cake which I feel did not complement the texture of the strawberries.Ma Maison is known for their sincere approach to food, and it shows through their simple yet delicious dishes. Their prices are also very affordable, so you can try a number of dishes without breaking the bank. It's my go-to dining option at Bugis Junction!

First restaurant I've been to that offers a fusion of French-Japanese cuisine! Not what I expected at first, although I'm not sure what exactly I thought it would be.The ambiance is quaint, with French themed furniture and finishings. The soft lighting and wood interiors really set the tone of a small French cafe.We started off with the Escargot, served in the shell, with a garlic-buttery sauce, which was quite good. Followed these up with Camembert Cheese Fritters that were also really yummy, although I would have preferred a different sauce, the one we had oddly resembled Thai sweet chilli.The Beef Stroganoff served with Buttered rice and omelette was a bit disappointing despite my love of Japanese rice. The omelette threw me off a bit and overall the meal could do without.The desserts were the real treat here. We ordered the Banana Tart, Mixed Berry Tart and Blueberry Tart ($4.90).The Banana was by far the best with a layer of banana cream on the tart base, topped with chopped banana halves, dollops crème and walnuts. Not my favourite for lunch but highly recommended for a bit of light tea and dessert
Squid ink spaghetti and escargots were great! It's better if u make a reservation as the queue is always long. Waiting time was 15-35 minutes, and they will not seat u till all members are present.

Since the first time I been to this restaurant, I love it.  They have the two cuisine I like under one roof... french and japanese.  So far,  this is one restaurant that I have not been disappointed with the items I ordered and I haven't felt a dip in their services or quality.Some of my favorite items here are their scallop capaccio, escargot, french onion soup and their tonkatsu set meal.

Fresh fruit toppings, frozen yogurt made in the place. People are nice and welcoming. Definitely a good place for everyone with a sweet tooth.I do not put 5 stars as the flavour version does not taste very natural...

address: 80 Middle Road #01-01,, Hotel Intercontinental Singapore 188966 Singapore
comment: I was searching for the best unagi in town (Singapore). And, based on the recommendations, it came down to Chikuyotei vs. Mikuni.I decided to give Chikuyotei a try and it didn't disappoint me. Even though Chikuyotei is specialized in Edo style unagi but also has Mikawa style of Unagi (Histumabashi). My wife had Edo style and I had Mikawa style. The former one is steam first then grill with light sauce, while the later one is grill with smokey texture and taste. I can't comment on Mikuni unagi yet, however, Chikuyotei's unagi is as authentic as you can get. And  comparing with Yanagawa unagi (which it was my all time favorite), Chikuyotei's Hitsumabashi is on par with Yanagawa unagi. Highly recommend if you are crazy about unagi. Mikawa style unagi costs $80 for a lunch set and Edo style unagi starting price is $40 for a lunch set, both are 200g of unagi.

address: 80 Middle Road #01-01,, Hotel Intercontinental Singapore 188966 Singapore
comment: Excellent Japanese food. Loved the Unagi on rice, but also their sushi and sashimi preparations are excellent. Very pricy though.

address: 80 Middle Road #01-01,, Hotel Intercontinental Singapore 188966 Singapore
comment: Went in for lunch. Got the least expensive fixed price lunch. Was there the first day it opened after the renovation. Minimalistic decor so not sure what they renovated. Not very crowded. They sat me at the counter since I was dining alone. Strangely they have wait service at the counter. First course was flounder (3 thin slices) with salt and truffle oil. Two bites of peeled asparagus and a small piece of tomato. The flounder was heaven on earth! I could have eaten 10 more servings of that!! The second course was a salad. Very refreshing with flower petals, different lettuces, and a few other veggies. Next was the tempura. This was the best mushroom I ever had in my life, plus two pieces of fresh shrimp/prawns, and a pepper (which was good and crispy but I didn't eat).Next was a crab meatball in clear soup. The snow crab ball had a consistency that did not appeal to me so I didn't eat it after tasting it. But the smell and taste of the clear broth was incredible and I devoured every last drop and all the green floating in it.  This was another course I could have made a meal out of by ordering 10 of them!! The Tuna on rice ruined me forever. The tuna melted in my mouth. The rice was delicious that I ate the whole bowl. I asked the sushi chef the secret. He said the secret is red vinegar not white. He also said everything is imported, salt , sugar, rice, etc. I chatted with my sushi chef. He shared with me that the knives are sharpened every day and he showed me his name in Chinese on his knife. I watch him "garnish" a dish with the most delicate small flowers; he explained that they can also be put in soy sauce to add flavor.Service was ok. Some dishes came out too fast, I got my first dish before my drink, I was asked if I needed anything else and informed they were closing for lunch before my dessert came, and I had to ask for the check.

address: 80 Middle Road #01-01,, Hotel Intercontinental Singapore 188966 Singapore
comment: Had the lunch omakase twice. Both times exceptional. Sat at chefs counter, a total delight. The chef explained all of the dishes to us, including the origins of the fish. The chef stressed how the restaurant chooses fish only when they are in season. Presentation and service are both strong. Really liked how the omakase ends with a fresh Japanese melon.

address: 80 Middle Road #01-01,, Hotel Intercontinental Singapore 188966 Singapore
comment: We racked our brains for a good place to celebrate a birthday for my wife. Chikuyotei came to mind as we loved our last meal there some months ago, and I particularly love omakase as I'm always delighted by the unexpected flavors and combinations. Chikuyotei did not disappoint. The dishes were beautifully laid out, flavors were subtle or in your face depending on the course. It would not be just to rank each course individually. Rather the entire meal was a symphony of palate appealing delights. Seasonal dishes make repeat visits interesting. Adding to the food was the service and ambience, which was top notch. This place is highly recommended. Now if only it did not cost an arm, but then, you do get what you pay for.

address: 80 Middle Road #01-01,, Hotel Intercontinental Singapore 188966 Singapore
comment: High quality sushi in a high service environment. I came here in a Sunday night and was one of less than 10 people in the restaurant. The sushi was fresh and dessert delicious as well. Good for days when you want to treat yourself or host guests!

address: 80 Middle Road #01-01,, Hotel Intercontinental Singapore 188966 Singapore
comment: i have been following sushi chef anson wherever he went since 2006.his resume includes being a disciple of nogawa san and i first met him at the now defunct chiharu where he earned my loyal following.whenever a fresh shipment or interesting seasonal items comes in, he would alert me via sms.and whenever i feel like eating at chikuyotei i will sms him and he would advise me on the right day to visit.i seldom look at their menu these days as i will mostly leave it to him to plate me the best sashimi on offer and also count on him to arrange with the kitchen for other yummy cooked stuff.today we started with the japanese mini yam.steamed and served with sea salt.a simple pinch and the flesh detaches from the skin.then came the chef special sashimi: hirame, kanpachi, tai, awabi, kani legs, sanma and otoro.all amazingly fresh and skillfully sliced.next came the steamed japanese chestnuts.in season but a little too troublesome to eat.the stewed kagoshima wagyu beef with konnyaku jelly was full of flavour with a little spice from chilli flakes.the steamed hokkaido snow crab legs were really sweet and ergonomically sliced to make it easy to consume.the highlight for the cooked food was the hamachi kama.perfectly grilled cheek with juicily fresh flesh under it's nicely charred skin.kaki furai was next.perfectly plump oysters lightly breaded and deep fried to a golden brown and served with a thousand island dipping sauce.the unagi kabayaki is their specialty.live eel slaughtered when ordered and grilled by their unagi master, only one in singapore.the kurobuta pork belly was ever so lightly seasoned, grilled and served with mustard seed mustard.last but not least, a favourite with many, is anson's spicy tuna maki.painstakingly prepared and appreciated by all.slices of reverse spicy tuna maki resting above a bed of spicy tuna then sprinkled with roughly torn nori.

address: 80 Middle Road #01-01,, Hotel Intercontinental Singapore 188966 Singapore
comment: Consistent, sublime, creative food, delivered by wonderfully competent characters - make sure you sit by the sushi bar!!

Brotzeit is located outside Raffles City and across from Chijmes and the Raffles arcade which is under reno. It's an outdoor (but covered) Restaurant open till pretty late in the evening. As you can tell from th name Brotzeit is focused on German cuisine and serves a solid array of German beers...pilseners, wheat, darks, etc.For lunch, I tried three items on the Karneval menu...the chicken schnitzel sandwich, fish and chips and chicken strips. Both the chicken dishes were quite good with the chicken being quite tender and tasty. The fish dish which used sea bass was a little on the fishy side for me. The fries were perfectly prepared and pretty tasty too. I also snacked on one of Brotzeit' famous pretzels which was served warm and darn tasty as well. Service is pretty good and you are never rushed. A good place to kick back and chill after shopping at Raffles. I look forward to my next visit!

I was craving German food so I was delighted to find a restaurant directly across the street from my hotel! And it's a good one! The menu was extensive with lots to choose from and with the holidays approaching they had lots holiday inspired dishes. I ordered a glum wine, even though it felt like 100 degrees outside. Inside it was actually pretty cool, even in the section which would be considered outside seating. The fans keep it a pretty nice temperature. Only problem, your food cools quicker. I got the jagerschnitzel which was good. Different then I expected but still good. I was expecting it to still have all the breading with the mushroom sauce. It wasn't really breaded. The mash potatoes reminded me of my Oma's so that was great. I enjoyed eating here. I'd definitely eat here again. Their wurst dishes look amazing. And if you're a beer drinker there's a lot to choose from.

Great place to chill in the afternoon or evening or night or whenever! It is definitely quieter in the afternoon but that makes it nicer since it is also not too noisy for conversations. I did not really eat here (those cold plate platter does not count) but I would think the food quality should be more or less the same as other branches. How wrong can you go with bratwurst and sausages? Besides the beer options, there are wine and mocktail and other non-alcoholic drinks. If you are a light drinker or not that into beer, the mixed beer option is good. I like the Russ'n which is Weissbier mixed with lemonade. There are other fruit mixes which should make the drink equally sweet. So non-beer lovers rejoice when beer/alcohol drinker friends suggest going to Brotzeit, we have something to drink there besides coffee and tea and soda.

Good friends and I met for a nice Friday meal to kick start our weekend with good food and company! Between the 4 of us, we shared a platter and that's good. We each had a portion of everything. As expected, the pork knuckle was nicely deep-fried. The assorted sausages also tasted good. Generally, I personally preferred the chicken ones over the somewhat porky-tasting ones. The lighter ales are also my favourite! I like how drinking much light ale just gives me a light buzz. I also discovered another drink that I now LOVE - Jäger bomb!!! This is another dangerous drink as the sweetness of the mix gives you the deception that you can down a plenty without getting slosh! Ladies, know your limit, else boys will gleefully take advantage of that situation. :/

One word.  Lowenbrau beer on tap.  Was out of town and looking for a cold beer.  Patio seating in the front for prime people watching as they come in and out of the attached mall.  Bar in the back with many German beers on tap and in the bottle.

This Brotzeit location is the one I visit most frequently and was always very satisfied with the quality of the food. The service is a bit hit and miss here, the Vivo City location is a bit better there. Sometimes I just need a nice 'meal from home' and the dishes from Brotzeit are the ones that come closest except I cook myself.Pork Knuckle is pretty good, one of my favorite dishes however are the Nuremberger Sausages with Sauerkraut, mashed potato and potato salad.I find this to be excellent price/value compared to what they charge at Brauhaus at Suntec. Also, Brotzeit now had branches in other countries like Hong Kong and Vietnam. I tried them and the food here in Singapore has been the best so far. I guess sourcing the good ingredients is much easier here than elsewhere.One thing I do not like is that the kitchen closes pretty early. Recently I wanted to order something at 11 and it was impossible. However they told me that only AFTER ordering beverages. Fail!Enjoy ~~S

The place always looks lively when I walk past and I've always wanted to give it a try. And so I did. I met a couple of friends for dinner a few weeks back and ordered the vegetarian pizza (cos i'm on a budget and pork knuckle will kill my wallet). It ws pretty good. Never thought a german restaurant could serve decent pizza but they do and I definitely will go back for more!

Real German food and beer here.  Do not be in a hurry here.  Good wait staff that gets you what you need.  The White asparagus is to die for.  I really thought I was in Germany.  The schweinshaxn is just like I was in Germany.  I eat here three times in two days.  I wish there was one of these in Cleveland.

Every time I walk by this place - the energy is always buzzing - and the place looks fun and cool. I love the interior - the design's really modern and cool looking. The place is always full - so I usually just sit by the bar - since I can never get a table. The staff are really friendly, the bar looks cool and their drink options are amazing! I'm not a beer person - but even I found their beer and cider pretty okay.What I Love: Their Spicy Potato Wedges are yummmyyyy. I've also tried their Spatzle and Jägermeisters - which are really good! The Salon fillet was fresh and yummy too, the ambiance is really nice - and I usually just enjoy sitting there and soaking up all the energy and people-watching.What I Don't Love: Their prices are pretty steep. I had a couple of drinks with friends, each of us had a main, a tiny starter - and the bill came up to $238? The drinks are nice but for $15 a pop - you can't be chuggin' down much.
Good place to have some food and German beer.  Wide selection of (German) food for both the sausage lover and health conscious.

Went to Brotzeit last night.It was filled with people, tourist.Location is very good with good view.Beer was good. Properly served. Food was not awesome in term of taste.Portion wise is good.  Ordered the Sausages and Pork knuckles. I think the Pork Knuckle is good. I will come back for drinks.
I don't care what people say about mass-produced food. This place is my favorite place for sausages. Surprising fact: Cocktails are suitably strong.

Excellent brews, sort of weak vibe in terms of the mall plaza-like locale.Definitely a formidable choice if you are in the immediate area...  otherwise, consider your options. There are plenty of them.

I am from U.S.A. I went here on one of my first days back in Singapore after a long time. I love German food and the food was good. I lived in Germany for many years so I know German food pretty well. The service was most accommodating. My most memorable thought though was:  WOW...CHINESE DIRNDL GIRLS! And secondly, I was literally shocked at the price of beer. I later found out that it's pretty much that way all over Singapore. I was told that they lay heavy import duty on it to protect the one local beer, Tiger Beer. And even the Tiger beer is not that well priced. I will definitely go back next time in Singapore.
Great place to sit and watch the crowds go by. Saturday afternoon, good sausage, better beer. Service was friendly and timely. Enjoyed it and price was reasonable for Singapore.

Brotzeit loosing their touch? Just had the Chicken breast with mash potatoes. Verdict: Pretty close to terrible. Tasteless, with substandard appearance.  The salad covered pretty much everything on the plate, and the salad itself was covered with some horrible creamy instant sauce. Yuk. Staff indifferent about feedback.Instead of looking into international expansion the management should look into quality and coaching of their staff.Probably my last visit. Prices have reached a level that one can seriously look into booking a flight to Munich as a viable alternative. And get the real deal.

I can't say I know their mains very well, I almost never eat here. I had the pork knuckle once. It was okay.But!A platter of cold cuts and other meats, and sausages, and a lot, a lot of beer = FTW! It's one of the better places to drink in the main City Hall MRT area.

After two weeks of Asian food and being late in the evening, I tried this German restaurant below my hotel.  It's an outdoor eatery with very modern touches.  Lots of people ordered the schnitzel and seemed happy; the server had me try something that was saucey but not memorable.  The people next to me ordered a pork knuckle that looked great.  For a night of conversation with friends, it's a place you can get into easily and have a decent meal.

Stumbled upon this place across from Raffles Hotel after a very expensive Singapore Sling. The food was fantastic. One of my crew had lived I. Germany and another has a German born mother. My last name even means garlic in German so the standards were very high. My schweinhaxn was EXCELLENT.  THE spätzle was the real deal and the German potato salad tastes like my grandmothers. The beer on tap was delicious. What an amazing surprise in Southeast Asia!

My sister and I like to split a pork knuckle (crispy! porky!) between the two of us. I recently discovered their deep fried Camembert, which is also quite moreish. I know the point of Brotzeit is the drink, not the food, but they do make an effort--the lunch and tea sets are good value, and there are seasonal specials as well. I recently had something off their white asparagus menu that was quite commendable!

This is the first place I go when I get to Singapore. Drinking a proper liter of Paulaner dark really makes my day. The food here is also quite good. We have had a few birthday parties here, and they all went really well.

Thoroughly overrated I believe. Brotzeit offers your typical German fare with sausages, pork knuckle and sauerkraut. It seems like novelty in Singapore, but honestly you could go down to the butcher and have your own October fest at home, with better beer at least. Brotzeit serves house beer which is really poor and flat. I had 3 gulps solely to quench my thirst. The pork knuckle in general fascinates everyone but be warned, the meat is not tender but tough. It is only the skin that is probably enjoyable as it crackles with every bite. A place worth a try to silence the surrounding hype.

When its German food, you have to have pork knuckles; and they serve quite tasty ones here too. Servings are generous in size and grilled very well....so crispy. Cool place to hang out with colleagues after work, really enjoy the drinks and pork knuckles here.

the sausages were very well prepared, great taste.  they came with sauerkraut, which were also very good. and the beer was excellent, lots of good choices.  if you're looking for good german food and drinks in singapore, look no further.  i went with a couple co-workers after work.  my german co-worker was quite pleased with the food and drinks.  unfortunately we had to wait about an hour for a table, even though there were only 4-5 people in line in front of us.  the place was packed! which is always a good sign.  i guess it's worth the wait if you are craving german food.  it was slightly more expensive that expected though, but the quality of the food makes up for it.

address: 328 North Bridge Rd Raffles Hotel Singapore 188719 Singapore
comment: The seating is split between inside and outside in the raffles arcade. Both are very nice. Atmosphere is good. We ordered the original lobster roll with Salad and fries. We really loved the lobster roll. Richly filled with a lot of high quality lobster. It is  served in a thick slice of cut open sandwhich bread.The fries are good. Salad a bit small.All in all more than enough food.Service is good and quick. We enjoyed it.

address: 328 North Bridge Rd Raffles Hotel Singapore 188719 Singapore
comment: Only has instagramable environment Poor food qualityOverall the restaurant is Over priced n rated Ordered combo for 2. Lobster was not fresh n get cold very fast. Crab meat was shrinking from shell. Background music was very loud. Doesn't justify the price ($70 per pax) Will not go again any more. Completely waste of money n time.

address: 328 North Bridge Rd Raffles Hotel Singapore 188719 Singapore
comment: Lobster lovers, the second restaurant of the famed Burger & Lobster chain is here at the Raffles Hotel. You no longer need to make your way to the far east side of the island. In my opinion, the food is consistent and the lobster rolls are just as good, and the fries were hot. Prices are okay, S$28 for lobster roll itself, S$34 with the fries and salad.There are a couple of new items on the menu: The B&L Beast Burger (lobster + beef patty) and the Lobster Rosti... will most probably be back to try them out.

Awesome Singaporean food. Our MBA group came here for lunch, and the food was delicious! Staff service was excellent as well, I'm surprised to see very little reviews on this place.Food: Delicious, and cooked very well! I can't remember all of them, and no! I did not have the time to take pictures, since everyone including me - ate all the food in a hurry. Green Truffle Dumpling: Never in my life have I seen green steamed dumplings! I live in Houston, and I like to think we are diverse in Asian food. But Singapore has got us beat! The dumpling was sticky, fat, and delicious! The mushroom was so aromatic as well. Fried Rice: Didn't try it, however everyone else gobbled it up!Shrimp paste wrapped in fried bean curd skin: Crispy outside, steamy inside! Black Crab Chili Buns: My goodness, I crave these little guys! They're absolutely stunning and in a way they look exciting. They look like pure black buns in a muffin/cupcake cup. When you bite into it, you get this sweet flavor from the bun with a hint of spiciness from the stringy crab. It was silky smooth, and delicious.
