This is their signature dish, and would recommend everyone trying it. I even tried to find online recipes, however I cannot! Mango pudding: Delicious, it was almost like a mango cream/milk jello, with mango bits inside of it. It was sweet, cool, and refreshing.Service: Very quick, most of the folks at my table were not familiar with the dishes and they came by to explain to them. I also asked for serving spoons, and they promptly gave them to us as well. These guys are excellent and super attentive.Come to this restaurant, you won't regret it!

Price 2/5:If you are used to hawker center prices, you'll be shocked here. We paid:a) $12 for two pieces of won ton in the won ton soupb) $80 for the chili crab - varies depending on weight and market price (which the waiter said was a small one lol - but it was big)c) $36 for the chili spicy seafoodd) around $38 for two small pieces of cod fishTaste:a) 4/5 for wonton soup - wonton we're very flavorful but portion wise for $12 just not worth itb) 3/5 is what we came for but the big bowl is full of sweet sour soup (german sauer scharf Suppe) which was just too sweet to eat. The crab was freshc) 3/5 same as the chili crab but just less sweet and more spicy. It has octopus, shrimp and fish pieces. The portion for its price were also far too muchd) 5/5 I know it's expensive, BUT the cod fish was the best we had at that night. Nice sweet flavor of tender cod fish. Amazing! $38 is expensive but the experience was worth itWould we come again? Probably not, especially not for the chili crab. It was a one time experience. The price to value ratio is clearly not the best.

Beware: If you're not careful, they'll take advantage of you.It's our first time visiting Singapore. Overall, we had pleasant experiences at other restaurants.However, when we got to this one, we regret going.When we sat down at our table, they started bringing over tea, peanuts, pickles, and wipes -- and since we just sat down and hadn't even been offered the menu, we thought, okay, maybe this is all complimentary.After that, they handed us the menus and we proceeded to order.The food was okay. Nothing to rave about.The real issue came when we were handed the bill. We had ordered only 3 items. When we saw the bill, we had been charged for 7 items: including the previous items that we didn't even order bc they proceeded to serve them as we sat down. Our sense is that they guessed that we were tourists and took advantage of the situation.Therefore, we advise that first-time visitors be very careful. Especially for such an expensive restaurant with okay food, expenses can really add up.

Truly a Singaporean meal experience.  Restaurant is is a little secret hole in the wall with friendly service and wonderful food.  The chili crab, razor clams, tofu, local veggies and special sauce lobster with tiger beer gave us a wonderful taste of Singapore.  Yummy

I am excited that Red House Seafood Restaurant opens up another location at Prinsep and it is just 10 minute walk from my hotel during my Weekend in Singapore!The deco might not be at fancy as the location at Robertson Quay or the atmosphere might not be as buzzing at East Coast but I find this location a less touristy vibe and more down to earth!I like how our waiter told me I have more than enough food for the 2 of us and never push or upsell us to more expensive items! Unlike my last experience at No Signboard which was ultra touristy to the max!Wok-fried and Tossed in Black Pepper 黑胡椒螃蟹 was just finger licking delicious! The sauce was really balance without over powering the freshness taste of the crab. The crab is meaty and full of roe at the same time.... Sambal Kang Kong 叁岜应菜 recommended by our friendly waiter was full of fresh from the wok taste. Just a touch of spiciness from the sambal sauce.As stated, crab and seafood is not cheap but just worth having at least once whenever I am in town. Hopefully, that will be soon!

This was the most convenient location because one of my overseas colleague wanted to try our famous chilli crab and I was not confident to get seats without reservations at my usual Long Beach, Jumbo or No Signboard. We had no trouble walking in and getting a table straight away. In fact it was near empty at 6.45 so I was wondering if I had made a bad call to pick this place. Service was excellent and the staff were very attentive to anticipate our needs. Menu is fairly extensive and the captain was knowledgeable in his recommendation. We decided to have white pepper crab and the baby squid with a stir fry of baby Kai Lan in mince garlic. Serving portions seem small but it was just right for two eventually as we didn't have much leftovers.

I was visiting Singapore for a few days and at the top of my list was the famous chilli crab that Singapore is known for. My research pointed me towards Jumbos, No Signboard and Long Beach. A few others popped up here and there, including Red House. I didn't think much of this one, but when the day I decided to venture out to get my chilli crab fix turned out to be a stormy day filled with rainstorms, I had to choose the easiest to get to. Red House was a mere two blocks from my hotel so that was an easy choice.At 1:30PM, the restaurant was still filled with families, tourists and businessmen having lunch. Dim sum was apparently still available as most of the tables were eating that. I noticed one table next to me with the crab - and only two people. That made me feel a little bit better, as I wouldn't be the only one making a mess of myself during lunch. Chilli crab, to say the least, can get a bit messy.I ordered the smallest crab available, which was still over 2 lbs. An order of mandou was standard as well. The staff brought out everything I would need to conquer my crab - claws, crackers, water with lemon, wet naps and a bib. When it came, I knew there was NO WAY I was going to finish it. It was HUGE. And then I had a taste of that slightly spicy, very sweet tomato sauce and had to sigh. It was easily the best taste of my entire trip. I did not intend on finishing it - I swear. But before I knew it, the entire crab was gone. The staff was surprised, I could tell. They were watching me eat through the entire meal, which was fine as my water bowl and teapot was constantly replenished. This meal was not cheap - my crab alone was $60 USD. But so, so worth it. It was the perfect meal to end a 11 day foodie adventure.

Greatly underwhelming. Welcomed by two deeply non-motivated front staff with the older gentleman being borderline rude asking twice about reservations and making a great long scene looking for the (massively easy to spell, Japanese 4 word first-) name - when I pointed it out myself.We were 5 seated at a table for 10. We converged on one side of the table to get some conversation going.. must have looked kind of funny actually.The food: Soft shell crab: an oily sponge, please don't order.Chili crab: next to no crab meat, the worst sauce ever experienced in S'pore. Glutamate with some spices or colouring, it tasted so bland and awful we let nearly all of the dish go back. The buns we ordered were a disappointment, too.Tofu with mushrooms and greens: very niceBeef: actually the best dish (in a seafood restaurant)Waitstaff was very friendly and efficient but food and ambience subpar and way too expensive.

So disclosure is that I didn't ask my husband how much the bill was bc I didn't  want it to affect my feelings about this place. The service is a bit gruff and reminds me of Chinatown restaurants in ny. Which is fine if the food makes up for it. And it totally does! Razor clams that are huge with some amazing garlic noodle topping. And the crab! I didn't care that I got it all over my rings and my elbow and hair and clothes and face. If I wasn't so full I'd drink that sauce straight up. Had one fried bun which was so soft and hot and yummy. But mostly just ate crab like a savage with my teeth. Using the crackers when necessary. Sweet and slightly spicy and messy and sticky and delicious. My favorite Singapore dining experience of the trip. My friends had some steamed fish and it looked nice but I had no room left to try. They chose the Sri Lankan crab and not sure why but so much sweet meat. Love chili crab!

Dinner with a group of 10 last night. Amazing peppered crab entree and the squid trio starter was very nice. Great place for groups with lazy Susan style share plates. Seafood was fresh and delicious. Lots of flavors.This is not a fancy establishment but the food is good and the staff is attentive. It is also quite pricey as it is a bit of a tourist trap amongst the the riverside hotels.

There were several Red House Seafood locations but this was the closest to the hotel and highly recommended. My husband was looking forward to eating chili crab but was very disappointed. He said there was very little crab meat and the sauce was just not great. We also ordered asparagus and mushrooms which was also a disappointment. I also did not find the restaurant to be very clean and the service was lacking.

Had their black pepper crab and was this a new taste sensation. But they could have served a larger crab. My biggest knock on SG so far with their crabs is that they just are not that meaty. You can all make the best chilli sauce or whatever but if your work your fingers to the bone for very little meat, we not have a good time. Room and table was nice after I requested we move from the cramped waiter station when the place was practically empty.

Strictly a review for dim sum.I was pleasantly surprised with how delicious the dim sum is at this place. I ordered the truffled mushroom dumplings, the chili crab bao, and their bbq honey pork in pastry. My favorite by far was the truffled mushroom dumplings, they are extraordinary. So delicate and full of flavor.  If you love mushrooms and truffles, you'll be pleased. The chili crab bao were just okay.  A bit under-salted, not as flavorful as I expected.  I wish they would pay more attention to how they make these.  I used them as a taste test to determine whether I would return to try their chili crab, after tasting these I think I'll pass. The bbq pork in pastry was really good. The best I've had so far. Huge chunks of meat and the bbq sauce was not overwhelming. It was perfect. Service was great, prompt and attentive. Note, they do charge you for the tea and wet napkin even if you don't touch it. But it's only $1.80 so whatever... I pick my battles.

Latest outlet of the Red House restaurant. Some standard dishes done well - the Kang kong was crisp and well cooked and the sambal has bits of dried prawn. The deep fried grouper was very fresh and cooked beautifully. Crispy duck a bit dry although the herbal seasoning was well done. Service inconsistent tho. Think the staff is a bit green. But there was one waiter who was very on the ball. Offered warm water for the kids at the table and brought kids cutlery promptly.

Tasty and spendy sums up most of the sea food restaurants in the CBD. Red house did not disappoint. Black pepper crab was delicious at about S$50/kg. The surprise of the night was breaded crayfish. We initially thought that S$20/piece was a little inflated, but what came out on the plate looked like lobsters. The other highlight was a very drinkable bottle of white burgundy on special for S$65. The prices vary by the fresh catch of the day so you will be paid off by having a good chat with your server and making informed menu selections.Service was solid, short of hovering.Dinner with drinks for 2 all-in was S$250.

Food was good, crabs were delicious. However, this place is very expensive! 2 crabs and 1 beer cost almost $250. Don't come here unless are ready to spend lots of money.  They will charge you for side dishes or anything extra.Service was less than average. The servers were busy maintaining the restaurant or busy eating. They weren't interested in taking care of customers' dining needs. I didn't like that tips were added to the bill for a party of 2 already since we didn't get good service. The restaurant only had 2 table occupied and we were kept waiting for a while. 4 stars for food and minus 1 star for mediocre service.
They served authentic fresh chili crab. We love it. We ordered very good fried rice and fried tofu with seaweed.
Service was efficient and very friendly. We had the Chilli Crab with fried buns and it was delicious and plenty of meat on a 1kg crab (and 6 buns) for 2 people
Very nice seafood restaurant mainly visited by locals. The hotel guided us there. It's great!

So so.. I had Scottish chilli crab, cold dish, veggies & Spanish tofu. Cold dish and Spanish tofu is what I would recommend but the other 2 you can skip. The air con is way too cold and all the food got cold so quickly. Slightly on the pricey side, could easily get fresher and juicy crabs from zi char in SG.

The thosai here is the highlight: crisp-thin spread out on a silver platter. Servers walk around with four cans, each with a different kind of sauce: two curries, two yoghurt-based ones. The latter are thick, creamy, but lightly flavoured and tangy.As for the rice-based dishes, the store isn't stingy with the rice: it usually arrives in the shape of a mountain, with the other ingredients in generous portions.The feel of the restaurant is very old-school, simple and plain with no frills. That somehow adds to the authenticity of the experience, where one can enjoy great-tasting vegetarian cuisine without having to pay a lot or squeeze with crowds for seating.

This place is super no frills and it's about as Indian you can get. The menu is really simple, but they mostly sell Thosais, Pani Puris, an Chapatis. My Masala Thosai came out a little limp, but one the the sauces they provided really packed a punch. Would recommended coming here if you're in the vicinity and looking for a cheap bite.

Hidden all the way behind in the stalls under Ramen Champion, this is a strong contender with its neighbors. I ordered the special ramen which came with three thick slices of char siew and an egg swimming in broth that looks oily but is actually light in taste and does not leave you feeling thirsty afterwards. The fried chicken is also well done. You can choose to have thick or thin noodles, Japanese or Singapore level of saltiness and to add garlic or sesame seeds.

address: The Cathay 2 Handy Road, #B1-K2 to B1-07 Singapore 229233 Singapore
comment: When I heard about $1.60 for sushi, I was thinking whether it's a wise choice as I had experienced bad sushi for cheaper prices. Went to this outlet on a Sunday afternoon. Was expecting it to be crowded but amazingly our suspicions were wrong. We were seated quite quickly.Coming to an all you can eat sushi, I thought there was a price difference for the plate colors but it was $1.60 without gst. The ambience of this outlet was pretty nice. The seats were actually sofa seats and there was an iPad where you could order additional items which wasn't on the conveyor belt.I went with a group of 10 and we were divided to 6 and 4 each table. The food on the conveyor belt kept rotating and I tried some of the two piece sushi. Taste wise is pretty good. Chewy rice and ingredients are considered fresh.We also ordered a side of salmon sashimi and some of the group ordered rolls. It was pretty good. A sweet tooth person (referring to myself) won't go off without desserts. Tried the strawberry mochi. Was chewy and not as sweet as I thought it would be. I also tried the cheesecake. Couldn't resist the temptation of seeing it on the belt rotating three to five times when we were there. Price wise it was good. But the cheesecake wasn't as moist as it should be - what can you expect for $1.60. When we paid, we were given vouchers - a business tactic to get us back there again,  which can be used within 3 months of date of issue. Overall, I am very satisfied with the food. I'll probably give full star if the space was spacious and efficient staffs. Will be back again soon :)

address: The Cathay 2 Handy Road, #B1-K2 to B1-07 Singapore 229233 Singapore
comment: Lunch here yesterday. First time at nihon mura. Sushi varieties are really many to be choose from. The sushi are not bad, the cream puffs and chocolate eclair are good. The mochi is like tang yuan. Environment is nice. Met a looking sianz and sleepy sale person here but still alright for the service. Will be back here again.

address: The Cathay 2 Handy Road, #B1-K2 to B1-07 Singapore 229233 Singapore
comment: It is a no frill sushi place, the main draw is budget price. Even though for the price, it is good value for money compared the rest, to be honest not all food is consistent especially on freshness. My favorite is the grilled prawn and white chocolate cream puff that really worth for
Wonderful north-Indian cuisine. I have had my fair share of Indian food, but this one is very good.Every dish I tried today was top-notch.

Impressed with this place! They have buffet lunch and a la carte dinner, and buffet dinner on holidays. Live music starts at 8 pm every night.The Papdi Chaat (indian taco) was sooo delicious and my favorite with flavours of mint, yogurt, and tamarind.We got the Tandoori Milawat that has a few pieces of 4 kinds of tandoori grills - chicken tikka, fish tikka, prawn, and kebab. It was great to try different kinds.The Aloo Gobi (cauliflower and potatoes) was kind of mushy and could've tasted better.The Chicken Makhanwala (butter chicken) was perfect with the naan bread.If you like bread, the bread basket was perfect! Plain and garlic naan, roomali roti (thin chappati-yum!), and tandoori parantha (also yum!)We tried the Jal Jeera to drink and it was very different and not something I would recommend. Can't go wrong with the Mango Lassi though.Unfortunately we were disappointed with the service. It could've been much better for the price we pay. Servers didn't clear our table or refill our waters. Most were chatting and standing around.We went for dinner this time but would love to try the lunch buffet next time.

I had a splendid time at Shahi Maharani. In my context I feel that this place is lush and posh.I had Chicken Makhanwala, Palak Paneer and Bengali Fish Curry with my Garlic and Butter naan. They are flavorful and delicious. I would prolly order 1 gravy dish in future. I had so much gravy that added complexity to the naan. LOL!As I was sitting at my table, I noticed a lot of hot plate being served out. And I was intrigued by the smell and flavour that I had to just ask the service crew what it was. Tandoori Paneer, the crew explained to me it's cottage cheese and peppers laced with a creamy marinade. The service was excellent n warming.

Shahi MaharaniStaff seated us but did not bring menus until we asked. Failed! They are losing a star for lack of service.Salt lassi - goodLong cracker - good but a tad saltishAppetiser - Pakora - vegetable (it is actually white onions within)Garlic nann & plain nann & cherry naan (sweetish & surprisingly nice)Tikki masala chicken - Nice; a wet fish food for those who don't like their food too dryOkra - nice and crunchy with onionsGrilled prawns - sliced open and easy to cut - tastes good tooTandoori chicken - quite nice and tender Somehow the food was better when catered by a Friend. Probably it is because she knows what to order.Music was too loud and 2 of us ended up having headaches. At one point the mike went berserk. I would rather they do without the Indian music and singing.
It is known as one of the best restaurants in Singapore and definitely lives up to the reputation. The service is great and the food is even better. Try the kulfi sampler for sure!

This place offers a very good value for money weekday buffet promotion where 2 people can eat for ~S$35. Food is good and ambience is pleasant.Food is good overall but nothing extra ordinary with a standard north indian restaurant menu. Prices are a bit on the high side for the location but still affordable.
Loved the food and drinks here. Very authentic taste and great service. The best part is the live music. Great singers and good music. Must try.

This is an excellent choice for upscale Indian food in Singapore. Many choices but this is conveniently located to several hotels in the Raffles City mall between Fairmont and Swissotel.  There are cheaper places in town for sure but the service is excellent (probably rates outstanding), the food was great and there is some Indian entertainment during dinner. Great place for a low key business dinner or a dinner for it's own sake!  I will come back!

Solid Indian food.  Meats and all ingredients were fresh and delicious.  Service was friendly and attentive.  Only issue was the food wasn't spicy...waiter claimed our dishes were the spiciest on the menu but wasn't nearly as hot as a chicken vindaloo in London. So lost one star for that.

In for a nice fluffy Japanese Pancake?  this will satisfy your craving.  We had the banana, original and Apple.  Service is pretty good.  Got to say the coffee needs working on especially when it is about 7 a pop for a latte2.  Otherwise would be back again.

Im not surprised why no one bothered to write a review about this branch, cause the customer service sucks. We came here before when it wasn't crowded and got seated right away. The food wasn't the best but I will give it a 3 cause they are consistent with the flavor and quality. We are always in the Novena branch and didn't have any problem, even the supervisor or owner treat everyone accordingly. The problem with the Bugis branch was they let  a customer get seated and order food even the rest of the party were not present yet. The line was long and we were waiting already for 30min before telling us we need to wait 30 minutes more. I bluntly told them it was unfair for us who were waiting in line and they shouldnt have took the order when the clients weren't  presently seated altogether. The staff just smiling mockingly when I told them that they should've told us right away from the start so we shouldnt have wasted our  time waiting  for a while. There's  a lot restaurants in the area better than their  food; it's not worth the wait. I will go back to the Novena branch which is highly recommendable . I was going to inform the manager but got no time  so I hope someone in charge would see this review to  train their staff how to handle customer professionally. I will not recommend this branch to anyone and would never go back no matter how close it is to our house.

I had high expectations coming in so did feel a bit disappointing. But overall ambiance was great, a good place to work or have conversations . Food was decent. Did not try any drinks but there were lots of options.Enjoyed the salted egg onion rings which is a different take. The chicken nuggets are like one step up from McDonald's but their sauce is great. Mentaiko pasta lacked flavor.

It surprised me that this place served really good food with very good vibes of environment. The house red is only at $10 per glass, I would say reasonable in Singapore. Gyudon was good, but the salmon mentaiko don which I found it better. Nice place, good food, I will go again

It had been quite awhile since I last visited the place. The menu had changed alot from what I last had. Besides the bar bites, the place also offers brunch menu during the weekend. It was recommended that reservation had to be made as the place get crowded during weekends. The place was easy to find as it was just a street away from the MRT station.The place was decorated in dark industrial look way. Although there was no service charge on the bill, there was GST on the bill. Remember to help yourself to the ice water on the shelf.COFFEE BALLER ($8.50+)Macadamia Flavoured Espresso Ice Ball served with warm milkBeware of the hot milk when pouring into the glass. It was a refreshing drink to have and one could adjust the richness of the drink to own's taste.Katsuo Butter Sprouts ($12+)Brussel Sprouts, Katsuo Butter, Roasted AlmondsIt looks simple, but it was filled with sweet, juicy, and nutty texture.Mac & Cheese Refined ($10+)Emmental, Cheddar, Mozzarella Cheese, Crispy BreadcrumbsBest had it while it was still hot and moist, else it became quite hard and dry. It was a cheese lover's favourite.The Refinery Zhng Burger EVM ($18+)Crispy Double Chicken Cutlets, Slow-Grilled Brioche Burger Buns, Overdose of Signature Refinery Salted Egg Sauce, Served with Truffle Fries.This item was available only for 3 July. I got to know about it when I saw the picture of it on instagram the day before. The dish took quite awhile to arrive. The truffle fries smelt great with the truffle oil smell, and was dry and crispy. The chicken cutlet was big in size, but would be better if it was a bit more juicy and overflowed with more sauce. I like my burger juicy and dripping with sauce.The salted egg sauce that served with it, was thick and rich, more like a paste.Overall the food was not bad. The place was crowded but not too noisy.

The food here is Yums but the service leaves you wanting. Coffee here is just alright. I especially love the salted egg yolk custard sauce on onion rings. So awesome!What's not bad:- beef rice bowl. Tasty - fried cauliflower- big breakfast. Huge portions- mantou sliders. Also very generousThe poutine should definitely be improved. The sauce isn't saucy enough. And the cheese not squeaky or generous enough to be called a poutine. Don't put onions in the poutine please. It's just wrong! Very affordable.  Casual dining. Will be back for sure.
It's okay...Nothing to write home about. I like the place more than the food. If you work around the area, it's s nice place to hang out after work. If not, don't bother with the hike to the area.

I really, really, really wanted to like this place, I did.Unfortch, neh.I've walked past this place a few times, and the place was always crowded on a Friday night, with great decor, projecting the sort of cool hipster vibe, and with a cool name like The Refinery, I felt myself drawn to this place because I like to pretend I'm a hipster sometimes.Alas! I was so disappointed. Everything about this place is great except the food. I will not comment on the cocktail bar on top that is part of this set-up as I didn't drink that night. On hindsight, I ought to have drank to dull my senses.I had a multitude of items which were a hodgepodge of Japanese/local fusion, and I wasn't impressed. Would I come back? Not even if it was free.

The place is 10 mins walking distance from lavender mrt. There are crowd. The aircon is strong enuff and blowing on face. I like the truffle fries that comes with the burger. The salted egg yolk source is like a paste. I didn't find it special. It was served seperately in a small disposable plastic container. The plain water is free. It would taste better with slices of lemon in the water. Free one cannot complain. :)Katsuo Butter Sprout is nice with almond sprinkled on top. I like the taste as it is sweet and well cooked.

An ex-colonial mansion converted into a bar/restaurant, nested within 'lush greenery'. On top of Mount Emily. I like the concept as I felt secluded from the rest of the world - and pretty close to the stars in the sky.Location: The location is such a b*tch. It is almost inaccessible without a car but I am blessed with friends who don't mind ferrying me around.Ambience: Very laid-back vibe. You can come dressed down or up (friendly hang-out with friends whom you don't quite care about - shorts + tee + flip-flops or not-so-innocent hang-out with a date whom you are trying to impress - pretty dress / shirt + heels) - as it was pretty dark outdoors and so no one could judge your dressing. Problem I had was the tables were placed quite closely together ... and there weren't many people on a Fri night (maybe fewer than 4 tables were filled up in total) - and so you could literally listen into other people's conversations as it could be quite quiet up the hill. and my friends were quite wasted and sprouting a lot of embarrassing shit about me.Drinks: There's an 1-on-1 happy hour deal from Tues-Sat for house pours, wines and beers before 9PM. You could order your drinks and place them on tab before 9PM ... and the servers would only bring them out later when you want them (even after 9PM) - that was pretty sweet service. I had a bit too much to drink - and they cancelled my last two merlot without charging me - even sweeter.Food: Share a partial menu with sister restaurant, Wild Rocket next door - I think some of the food came out of Wild Rocket's kitchen. Mostly tapas style (so the mini fish-and-chips was really mini). Fish and chips was below mediocre - the 'fish fingers' were overly battered, with absolute lack of fish mince. BUT - its sarawak chicken curry shepherd's pie was so yummilious - one of the best Asian-Western fusion dish ever had. Curry + Mashed potato sounds like a great combination. Throw in the cheese - it might be a bit too over-the-top - but somehow Wild Rocket got all three (curry, mashed potato and cheese) together to awe my tastebuds.Overall - worth a visit, but I don't think I will be back here too soon ...

Many restaurants or cafes have sprouted in our local parks within last few years and one of them is Wild Oats. This is a place located in Punggol Park that serves casual-style local and western cuisine.For appetizers, the Otah Bruschetta $5.70 did not impress as it was just Otah paste smeared onto half-toasted white bread and so was the "You Tiao and Tao Pok" $4.50 shown below as the rojak sauce was meagre despite having asked for extra sauce.Would have thought that the chef's "deadly chilli sauce" for the Golden Chicken Wings ($7.50) would be a spicy killer but it was like mild Hainanese chilli sauce. The well-seasoned wings were crispy and tender, which can be independent from the sauce.For the mains, the Pan Fried Salmon (with mash) draped with creamy garlic sauce $14.90 fared better than the Sambal Balachan Fish Fillet (served with butter rice and coleslaw) $14.20 because the salmon was truly well cooked such that the juices were retained and slightly salted skin was crisp. For the latter, the sambal was neither fragrant nor fiery

Popped by here once for dinner, had the offal BKT so I couldn't comment on the ribs, but my offal was okay. The side dishes were okay too, nothing to shout about. The omelette however, was exceedingly oily, and we regretted ordering it. The atmosphere here is not AC, but it doesn't feel too hot. Soup is freeflow, drink as much as you like. Prices are slightly high, I'm looking at you, greasy omelette.

The dry mee sua picture caught my attention I hardly see dry mee sua in many noodle stalls. The coffee shop is spilt into two sections, separated by some pillars but you can order from either the noodle/coffee stalls section or from the bak kut teh side.I had the dry mee sua which was not as good as the one in Yan Kee over at BK Eating House (Boat Quay area). The mee sua was a bit more sticky and soggy. The sauce could also be better. At $3.50 it is the same price as Yan Kee but this seemed to have more ingredients. Besides mee sua, you could have the usual mee pok or mee kia and other noodle items. I also ordered bak kut teh as I wanted the soup. I chose the premium which came with long rib bones, instead of the usual chopped up shorter or smaller ribs/bones. The soup is of the clear peppery kind, with no herbal taste. It was good but I would not say mind blowing. As I hardly have BKT, I do not know much about it. It is pricey at $6 for just 3 ribs. The soup is refillable. Just ask the staff for a refill and they will come round with a kettle of soup to pour into your bowl.

Dryyyyyyyyyy, that's the only word I have for the pork, in soup or braised with the preserved vegetables.I love my bak kut teh in Singapore, dipping you tiao in the never ending refillable  black peppery soup, complete with salty vegetables and some braised meat/beancurd skin! I chanced upon this stall on my way to liang seah street to hunt for other food stalls. So my colleagues and I, 4 of us, decided to give this stall a try as it truly looks appealing!We ordered 2 bowls of the signature bak kut teh, 1 sliced pork soup, 1 pigs stomach soup, 1 preserved vegetables and braised pork, 2 bowls of you tiao and completed with rice and vermicelli. Total bill is slightly less than S$50, which I thought it's slightly on the high side for bak kut teh.The taste of the soup is not that peppery spicy, and I think it's good for tourist. This is easy drinking soup, and it's not too bad. Being a Singaporean myself, I prefer my bak kut teh to have stronger punch of the black and white pepper combination! The pig's stomach is great, and really cleaned properly with no nasty smell. I've a mixed feeling with the preserved vegetables with braised pork. It's well flavored, a hit on the salty side, and they used thick slices of pork belly to braise it with the vegetables. The skin of the pork belly is yummy, but the meat is dry, like really dry which I thought it's kind of weird on a pork belly. The pork ribs from the soup are also dry and tasteless, and I feel that there's a lack of fragrance in the soup, probably ties in with the lack of pepper and onion.Well, this is ok for me and it's probably somewhere I will bring friends traveling from states here to try. Local taste bud, not really.

address: Blk D, 1 Mcnally St #01-01 Singapore 187940 Singapore
comment: - Hipster café- Friendly Staff- Opened early for breakfast. We didn't get to hear but they live music as well- Some of the food options weren't available. - Student discount - Would recommend!

address: Blk D, 1 Mcnally St #01-01 Singapore 187940 Singapore
comment: For a college cafe, it's pretty great.  For a Singapore cafe, it's hipster vibes with OK drinks and food options.  The high ceilings, tucked away couches, and shared tables make it an easy place to grab a bite and relax, read, or work.  Service is pretty low-key with the order at the counter style service.  Music is medium volume during the day- looks like they can host live music or DJ events.  They take pretty much all forms of payment to accommodate accounts from all over the world- so that's a bonus.

address: Blk D, 1 Mcnally St #01-01 Singapore 187940 Singapore
comment: Food is ok average here but the biggest draw is the bouncy castle they have set up during the weekends. I love the part of the bouncy castle being INSIDE the aircon cafe where parents are chill over makan while the children have fun wasting their energy. They have ample parking and table seats so we don't feel bad just sitting there and nursing our drinks while waiting for the kids to come back to the table for water and more food. A definite come-to place for parents chillax and children playing time.

address: Blk D, 1 Mcnally St #01-01 Singapore 187940 Singapore
comment: A very cool place. High ceilings with lots of glass. It is definitely a comfortable place to go and relax over food and coffee. It's in the La Salle Art College Campus. I heard that this cafe recently introduced some Mexican dishes. I'm always a bit skeptical because there are VERY little options for Mexican in Singapore. I was surprised to find affordable prices but even more surprised to find such a hearty portion. I had the chipotle chicken taco and it was really good. Iced cafe latte: $5.5Chipotle chicken taco: $5.5Ambiance: modern, openRecommended: Yes! Try the Mexican.

address: Blk D, 1 Mcnally St #01-01 Singapore 187940 Singapore
comment: I always loved 15 Minutes and to see if close down was a sad moment as it was a great place to chill and hangout. However out with the old and in with the new. Overall atmosphere of this place was comfy and it has a very organic theme to the place. Plenty of seats and a stage for performances. Overall I loved the atmosphere. Food is not too bad as well, however I do have to point out I was here for lunch and all I had was the Dory Fish dipped with Beer Batter and the Carbonara. The Carbonara was lovely as it was not drowned in sauce like how a lot of places does it. It was however a little more to the dry side and I did wish for just a tiny bit more sauce. This fish was by far my favorite, golden crunch on the outside and moist on the inside. Definitely would recommend it.Will definitely come back here a second time and will update this review as I get to try out more of their food.

address: Blk D, 1 Mcnally St #01-01 Singapore 187940 Singapore
comment: On the outside, this cafe/restaurant looks great. Hip decor, nice touches and an overall comfy, cheery feel. The sort of place you would really want to hang out in with a bunch of friends.Which made me want to like it that much more.And which made my actual experience of it that much more disappointing. In short - the food was just no good.I went for lunch and had a grilled chicken with salad for $8.90. Sounded promising. The chicken was a chicken chop (thigh, whole piece) - and was just passable, and not very different from the sort of chicken chop you get from a western food stall in the hawker centre. It came with a small side salad that was lettuce greens and tomatoes. The chicken was covered with a cheesy (I think) sauce. It was just meh. I would not go back for this food.One other thing - when our food was served, my friend asked the wait staff what the sauce was (as it was not indicated on the menu). She just smiled and said she was "not sure". That was it. Not sure. Didn't bother to find out either.Nice try, won't go back. Sorry. A damn shame because I really, really liked the previous cafe that used to be at this location - 15 Minutes Cafe. I shall mourn its demise.

This is part of a chain of dim sum restaurants that are scattered around Singapore! This is the branch at Junction 8 and is located in the basement floor. For those who are spoiling for some good dim sum, this place is pretty good- their buns follow all the traditional "folds", have authentic flavor and their soup buns are a must have. We ordered the vegetarian dumplings, shrimp and veggie noodle, a cold beef sliced appetizer, 1 si gua shrimp soup dumpling, 1 regular soup dumpling, a round of garlic fried spinach, and shrimp fried rice. Food:1. Cold cut beef appetizer - The art of this beef is that it is marbled when you see it sliced and laid out so delicately in the thinnest slices and the marble is so intricate that it's a true delicacy hard to rival in anything I've seen in the US. the beef is well flavored and must be eaten cold as that what makes the marbled texture stay- eat this warm, and it will melt the marbled cartilage. I have attached a picture with a cup of tea next to it for comparison and it's remarkable how delicate the cut is. Not an oily dish, almost like a refreshing wet beef jerky if one were to describe the flavor. 2. Steamed vegetarian dumplings- 10 for 11.80$- For my vegetarian friends, this is the dish to get. The dumpling has various tofu and chives and vermicelli wrapped inside- it is flavorful and the green wrapping is a lovely color to see when they lift the lid off the steamer. 3. Steamed gourd and shrimp "soup" dumpling- 10 for 11$- if you're a soup bun fan, you want to try this version- it has the crunchy but yet tender soft si gua and the shrimp inside. The soup is a sweeter and more vegetable taste than its other famous typical counterpart, the vegetable and pork soup bun 4. Steamed vegetable and pork dumpling 10 for 10.30$- Gotta get the staple of soup buns if you're going to have good soup dumplings and a good dim sum set. There are the 13 folds that are described as the art of folding a true "delicacy" correctly that one will not find in American dim sum stores that usually just fold a dumpling minus the 13 folds. pick this up with chopsticks at the tip and put it into a soup spoon before eating. wait a min for it to cool or bite a small hole on top and drink the soup inside slowly as it will be hot. 5. Stir fried spinach /w garlic for 10.80$\- not over cooked and has the garlic flavor- still maintains the crisp and jade green flavor that spinach should have6. Fried rice w/ shrimp and eggs for 12.80$-  a truly rich and buttery fried rice that screams generous eggs, butter, and shrimp. highly recommend this is if you are a fan of fried rices- this is truly a must have.
Excellent Taiwan dishes.  From bun to dishes.  This is a well know and respectable chain restaurants from Taiwan.  They are very international.  Including LA

DTF is great, consistent high quality food and reasonable prices. I love their spicy dumplings, their xio long bao ( of course ) and their mushroom chilli noodles are sooo good. I'm giving it 4 stars because the service, while swift is also curt. I suppose that's understandable given the massive queues of hangry people waiting, there's little time for small talk and courtesy. They're not discourteous just curt. I guess that's singapore for you lol

Come for the dumplings. Each of the three outlets does a really nice job of quality of food - hence the locals willingness to stand in line for 30-40 minutes to get in.  The decor is nothing to get excited about.The service is quick, unfriendly, and to sum it up very Singaporean.  Eat here - or don't they don't need you business and they know it.  **see the line to get in.

You can't go wrong with Din Tai Fung for dependable dim sum and a good Chinese meal. Of course you have to eat the Xiao Long Baos here, and you have to find the fine line between eating it piping hot and not burning your tongue. There are many new-fangled versions of the Xiao Long Bao, but the traditional one is best.My other favourite dish here is the pork chop fried rice - the rice is really eggy here and the pork is savory and yummy.Gets really crowded on weekends - families patronize this outlet and queues can be lengthy, so avoid peak hours if you can!

The  Crab Meat and Pork Xiao Long Bao has holes on top therefore diluting the meat juice in the bao. The bao was bland and the crab meat was mushy. Hot and Sour soup needs flavoring. Taste like water more than broth. Disappointing.

DTF being DTF. Best dumplings, Xiao long bao ever. Too bad, the nearest location from my place is in LA. Therefore, I would eat at this place whenever I'm in Singapore. This branch in Junction 8 is conveniently located near MRT and bus terminal. The space is small and thus; waiting time is typically around 30-60mins. Be prepared to spend 2 hours on undoing the dining and waiting.

The xiao long bao at Din Tai Fung is the best value for money ones in Singapore! The skin is thin, the soup is super tasty and the pork is just succulent and yummy!!! I can literary eat a basket of ten just by myself without getting sick of it. Other recommended dishes include the xia ren cao fan (seafood fried rice), chicken soup, dan dan mian, drunken chicken as the starter, yam dumplings for dessert.This Bishan branch starts packing up very early for dinner especially on Sundays because it is a hot favourite for Chinese family dinners. Try to beat the queues by getting there before 6pm on Sundays or just join the queue because the wait is worth it anyway.

One of the good few places to eat the xiao long bao, it has two flavours, the crab/pork meat and the pork meat . However if you were to ask me frankly, I couldn't tell much of a difference. Even though the similar, they taste just as good and remember to go with the ginger sauce.Some of the details you might notice is the number of folds on the xiao long bao, it is supposed to have 18 folds and I can't be sure if you can request to change if it counts less or more than 18. It would be ridiculous though. The skin of the dumpling is thin but good enough to hold the soup and meat in it. It didn't stick on the wet cloth which is good.Service at the restaurant is good, the waitresses and waiters are responsive and willing to take the initiative.

My first thought: Great! A decent Chinese dim sum restaurant is finally making its way into the heartlands. The waitresses are pretty inefficient when it comes to taking orders and requests. Other than that, food is great! (just like the other DTF outlets) No need for long distance travel to crowded Orchard just to have good dim sum! P.s. Having said that, queues can get pretty long at dinner time and over the weekend. Try these! : Xiao Long Bao, oriental salad in special vinegar dressing, zha jiang mian

If you are in the suburbs and are at a loss on where/what to eat, always trust your fellow residents. Anywhere with a long line or plenty of diners is always a good indicator, especially if the diners are older. They are usually there for the food or cheap pricing, and not because the place looks hipster and the food looks instagram worthy.  I walked past Mata Thai several times and it was always packed with diners, especially during meal times. Located in a corner of a HDB block, it is fairly spacious as they also took up the space in front of the restaurant. I was there for a late lunch and it was a lull period with just 4 or 5 tables being occupied. More people came in shortly after me. I guessed when the food is good, people can eat round the clock in Singapore. The tom yam seafood soup was not fiery hot like other places, but it had a good balance of spicy and tang. It only came in 2 sizes - small and big. The small was sufficient to feed 2-3 persons if you also ordered other items.The basil chicken with rice and fried egg was a single person's portion and it was pretty good. It could do with more basil but I am quibbling here. The papaya salad was the special add on for that day and it was really nice. I am usually not a fan of papaya salad but this was refreshing and not overly spicy. The winner of the day was really the Thai iced milk tea. I loved how they let you mix it so you know it was made fresh on the spot. It tasted like those in Bangkok. Delicious. And for $1.50, it was quite a steal, especially when you have paid $1.60 for iced Milo at the coffee shop at the other end of the same HDB block a few hours ago.They take cash or NETS only.

Bishan is not my territory. I was trying to figure what to eat, without bejng stuck in a mall. Turned on Yelp! & Mata Thai came up with 1 decent review. Decided to be adventurous. We ordered Glass noodles salad, Tom Yum, minced chicken with basil & fried baby kai lan. All are very very average. Including the warm lemongrass drink. They were trying to push their $28 fish to us. Thank goodness we did not try.

address: 407 Ang Mo Kio Avenue 10 #01-759 Singapore 560407 Singapore
comment: Decent tasting thai food at reasonable prices, especially their lunch set at $4.80 nett with a drink. Their iced Thai milk tea tasted like cha tra mue :)

address: 407 Ang Mo Kio Avenue 10 #01-759 Singapore 560407 Singapore
comment: While the food maybe be ok their service is terrible. Got totally wrong order. Called them and was told to request refund via deliveroo. How does the deliveroo driver get it wrong?I cant eat a refund a few days later...the owner/the person who answered the call should be banned from the industry. Didnt even apologise just hang up. What a terrible person he is and he is in charge of food. Scary. Stay away please, sadly...stay away. Should be 0 star

address: Blk 124 Lor 1 Toa Payoh #01-459 Singapore 310124 Singapore
comment: Food are fresh and delicious, a bit like home cooked food. Their white bee Hoon is best among all others claim to be best like sembawang white bee Hoon. Theirs is wok fried no sauce.

address: Blk 124 Lor 1 Toa Payoh #01-459 Singapore 310124 Singapore
comment: You know the place that was really bad in business, went through a reality show and got popular? Yeah this is one of those extreme makeover food stores. But after they became popular the food quality got really dubious too. Came for their "famous" white bee hoon but was thoroughly disappointed. There was no line, but the portion of a $4 white bee hoon was pathetic. I could count the ingredients inside, a handful of noodles, 2 prawns, 1 slice of squid and 2 slices of pork. That was it. The chili condiment sauce tasted good, slightly on the sour side with a tangy twist. The most generous must be the portions of pork lard. Served lukewarm, and therefore altering the taste, making it greasy and hard to digest.Every time I taste this the food has been inconsistent, they need to do something before they need to go through round 2 of "bad business revival".

Two visits here over 4 day trip.Fish head curry was my favourite, so much flavour, fresh and lots of meat. Their home made sambal was probably the best sambal I've had so far.Will come again if we visit Singapore again

Food Pot, also known as Gu Ma Jia () refers to Auntie's house. The recipe and kitchen is helmed by  as she is affectionately called by all her nieces and nephews. The restaurant came about as "Gu Ma Jia" is often the family gathering spot for the entire extended family. It is not wonder the food is all so hearty and full of the warmth of home cooked food. And hearty food it was. The Assam Fish Head is a red snapper fish head carefully handpicked by the cooks every morning. Freshness guaranteed! The fish head is tender and succulent and sweet because it's so fresh. We all loved the Assam flavoring which is sour, spicy and tangy all in one.One of my favorite dish is the Butter Baked Salted Egg Sri Lanka Crabs (Seasonal Price). I love Sri Lankan crabs because they are huge and meaty! The crab is really well cooked because it was succulent and also juicy inside. I love the butter baked salted egg dry gravy and it goes so well with the creamy crab roe. Sinfully awesomeness. Would love more of that gravy though.All their dishes are well executed. Love it.

For full review with photos, please visit:myfrozenreminiscence.blo…For those who are celebrating early - Gu Ma Jia is offering 10% discount until 29 January when you dine in at the restaurant. For those who are still deciding where to have your CNY reunion lunch/dinner on 30 January (Thursday) - Gu Ma Jia has CNY 2014 Set Menu Promotions with four timings to choose from: 12.00 pm - 2.00 pm, 2.15pm - 4.15pm, 6.00 pm - 7.45 pm, and 8.00pm - 9.45 pm. The restaurant will be closed on 31 January (Friday) and 1 February (Saturday) but operations will resume on 2 February (Sunday) - a great day to makan before starting work on Monday, if you have to work on Monday.Gu Ma Jia is famously known for its signature dish - Assam Fish Head ($28). Many bloggers have praised the delicacy and even celebrities have visited the restaurant to have a taste of this delicious dish. YES! I bet you can finish two bowls of rice with just the gravy. The gravy wins hands down by having the balance of 4S. It was sweet, spicy, savory and sour. The sweetness of the gravy was very "fishy"... in a good way! I later found out that the natural sweetness of the gravy came from the fish! The fish was cooked in the gravy to perfection with its meat still moist and tender. (FYI: Many places steam the fish head and then pour the gravy over it.) *Apologies for the absence of photograph.Some people travel all the way here just for its Assam Fish Head. But Gu Ma Jia offers many other good delicious dishes.For full review with photos, please visit:myfrozenreminiscence.blo…

Don't let this place scare you as it has quite a typical dodgy look on the outside. It's only the second Korean restaurant located in a neighbourhood area in Upper Thomson. If you compare with Auntie Kim's which is just down the road then it's even more reasonably priced.  Inside, it's kind of eerie with dim lighting, slightly old school and a little crowded at dinner time. I've been here twice as I was introduced by a friend who's as passionate about food as I am. Also, with a large selection of food items, you can try new things everytime you go.Favorites:RamyunBBQ Short Beef RibsBulgogiJia Jang MyunRefillable appetisers (LOVE the super smooth potato salad and green veggies tossed in fragrant sauce)Personally not a big fan of Korean food but it would be nice to have it for once in awhile.

Singapore arguably has the most exciting food scene in the world and Indian cuisine isn't a struggle to find. The venue has become a fascination for visitors and locals alike seeking to taste their specialties. Their menu is extensive and all the classics are well prepared and cooked perfectly. We ordered the followings:THOSAIWas paper thin and crispy with a slightly sour note. It crumbled nicely in your mouth and was fun to eat. It was my least favorite dish however, I find myself reaching in for more after every bite. PRATAWe ordered plain to pair with our curry. It was flaky and great for sopping up the gravy. FISH HEAD CURRYWhile it may not sound appealing, it's by far one of the most memorable meals I've had in Singapore. The fish was tender bathing in an aromatic curry gravy with assorted vegetables served piping hot in a clay pot with a side of rice. Incredibly delicious and highly recommended! CHOCOLATE PRATACrispy with the chocolate sauce adding a nice sweetness to the fried Prata. A great dessert to finish up our meal with. While Indian restaurants are plentiful in Singapore, Casuarina is located off the beaten path and worth seeking!

Less crowded place so quick service no waiting time. I ordered a biriyani, portion is good taste is nice. Price also very reasonable. Restaurant crew also nice and helpful. Good for a quick lunch or dinner.

When people talk about Casuarina Curry, you go to Casuarina Road right? That's where I've been going for ages... but then they open a  branch in my neck of the woods!Hurrah for branches - now my drive is MUCH shorter, and I don't have to wait as long... if I time my visit right. Popped by with a bunch of friends (somehow a party of EIGHT wants to eat curry on a steamy sunday afternoon), and I was amazed by the speed of service! Plus the guy who took or order memorised everything we wanted, down tot the customisation of each prata and what curry we wanted.The mutton briyani is good stuff, and so was the murtabak. The "kosong" prata is still as crispy as ever!

address: Blk 51 Lorong 5 Toa Payoh #01-60 Toa Payoh, Singapore Singapore
comment: Love love love this place! Beef cooked to perfection. Chicken cutlet and chicken chop are delicious. The beef stew reminded me of how grandma used to cook it for me. Can't fault this place. Uncle and his staff are very friendly. For a Coffeeshop stall you can't ask for more. No where else can you find the potato ball.

address: Blk 51 Lorong 5 Toa Payoh #01-60 Toa Payoh, Singapore Singapore
comment: A decent neighborhood steak place. Black pepper Ribeye for $13. Served with a potato ball ( dry mashed potato, with a crispy outside). Does cook to your instructed meat temperature. And served on a hot plate too. Other popular items on the menu; black pepper chicken chop, fried chicken cutlet, Stewed beef with rice.

address: Blk 51 Lorong 5 Toa Payoh #01-60 Toa Payoh, Singapore Singapore
comment: My 2nd time here and my daughter and I had:1) Mushroom Soup - only ok... Can definitely skip this the next time2) Garlic Bread - lightly seasoned but surprisingly nice3) Coleslaw - very nice with raw onion slices for that extra zing!4) Chicken Cutlet - the batter is nicely seasoned and light. Can taste the chicken inside. Serving size is decent too 5) Black Pepper Sirloin - the slice is decent size and beautifully seasoned. It's served with their house special - potato ball. It's a deep-fried mash potato if you would have it. Nice side! Will return... :)

This is 1 of the stall with a long queue in this hawker center, so I decided to line up and try. Decided to get the roasted and bbq pork combo and they didn't disappoint! The sweet gravy pour on top will help digestion but I suggest to ask for it on the side so you can taste the meat without any sauce.

Just a stone throw away from Bishan MRT Station is the long-standing Happy Garden Seafood which is located within Kim San Leng(金山嶺) serving local tze char dishes.Come try out their recently launched Truffle dishes.  Truffle Oyster Omelette Signature Curry Fish Head Truffle Chicken Mid-wings Truffle Prawn Balls Caipo Tofu Yam Ring Stir-fried Kai Lan [PROMO] Quote [happy20] to enjoy 20% off when you dine at Happy Garden. Valid till 15 Aug 2019.

I have not tried the tze char dishes though the pictures do look good.I usually order the wu xiang stuff. Now that the wu xiang stall is no longer at the Food Republic in Wisma Atria, this is the only place I know which sells it. The selection is not huge and there is no price list so I have no idea if I am overcharged. The prices seemed ok so I have no complaints. For a century egg, a prawn fritter and beancurd, plus a side of fried been hoon, it came to $4.50. This is similar to Indian Rojak as you get to pick and choose the items you want. The items will be reheated via deep frying (double fried) so it can be quite greasy. If you have them to go, at least the oil will be absorbed by the paper. The chili has a strong raw garlic taste though it goes very well with the fried bee hoon and fried items.

Another cafe tucked away in a neighborhood. Ambience is whimsical and nice. The decor is pretty sweet, especially the clear roof ceiling at the back of the cafe, the fairy lights and the adobe walls. Came here twice on a weekend night and a morning. There was already a crowd so we had to queue a little. Tried their breakfast menus as well as their deserts. Both were good, but nothing great in my books. Price is reasonable of course due to the quiet location.I have to commend their staff, particularly a male staff wearing black frame glasses, couldn't get his name. Excellent service, always with a smile and cheery attitude! Also orders were quick.Would definitely come back again, likely shooting for non-peak times again.Not sure if we caught a one-off experience but the quick service was a plus.

Visited Wimbly Lu a couple of times has made me a fan of this place. Love the carbonara with bacon, the creamy white sauce taste homemade, poached egg is well-cooked, spaghetti is Q, portion is just right. Love the waffle with chocolate ice cream. The waffle may look simple and plain, but that's the beauty of it. It is perfectly crisp on the outside and soft and airy on the inside. Goes really well with a scoop of chocolate ice cream. One of the best waffle I've ever had.Love the hot chocolate (70% dark chocolate). Rich and creamy and taste like a bar of dark chocolate.  Love the chicken nuggets. Crispy on the outside and juicy and tender on the inside. Overall, service and ambience is good, menu is well categorized for easy ordering. Just hope that they show a list of food photos on the menu so that those who has not been there before, know what to expect and order from the menu.
We had the Ethel's Blackout Cake. Kinda Nice.

Love the ambience. Drinks were well made, specially like the iced chocolate and mocha drink. One of the staff was really friendly and nice. However, i find most of them pretty inexperienced. They had 4 choices for 'soup of the day' which really should be soups of the day. We had the mushroom soup and it was quite pleasant. Beef cottage pie was not available so we thought of going for more desserts since there was a rave about it here.Waffle is a must; come early for it so that waiting time won't be long. When asked what was "eton mess", the staff said "choc cake", and what was "blackout", she said "choc cake". Could have been a little more specific and professional in this. In the end she recommended the blackout which was a total disappointment because it's just a very moist chocolate cake.Price is on the high. For the service and the quantity of food (the $5 chicken nugget comes with literally 5 piece of chicken karaage), i will only return if i am seriously craving for waffles. Else, nah.

Until now, I still do not know why this place is so popular. Ironically, the desserts did not impress even though Wimbly Lu is famous for them.   The Hazelnut Butterscotch Blondie ($4.50) was too dry and chalky with rancid untoasted nuts though the butterscotch sauce was rich and sweet. I don't understand the logic of molten lava cakes  $6without ice cream or creme anglaise sauce but I know some do. The version here is very rich, dense and luckily not too sweet. However, the cake texture was still dry as compared to Domino's or Morgansfield.   The Chocolate Tofu Cake $6 did not taste anything of tofu but I guessed the ingredient blended into the mousse did help to give it a smooth, creamy texture. However, the biscuit base was stale and not crunchy as described by the staff.   With a crisp texture and some even noted a resemblance with cereal taste, the signature waffles with one scoop ice cream ($8.50) was the better ones that day. I wonder if the salted caramel ice cream came from Salted Caramel at Upp Thomson though. But it was too small a scoop for the size of the waffles.Mediocre Cheese Toast Melts which can be skipped Another recommended item was the Chocolate Root Beer Cake $6. Think layers of root-beer-infused ganache intersecting with chocolate sponge. I like chocolate and root beer. But the combination of both tasted strange.Blackout Cake $6Bottomline, a cafe that is simply over-rated. Perhaps it is crowded because the seats are limited. My companions were generous to comment that the ambience was good, for instance the settings such as the red bricks tiled wall and lightings. But I tend to ignore ambience and focus on the food. Given the substandard quality of the chocolate desserts, I would not fancy a return.

Love the space, reminded me a lot of NYC with the exposed brick wall, longish shop space, glass roof that lets the sun in.Coffee - much too weak. Can't taste the coffee at all.Brownie - like that it is rich and not sweet, but it was a tad dry.Truffles - nice to see them making them fresh in the shop. $2 each for assorted favors. But we didn't like any if the 3 favors that we tried (salted caramel, dark chocolate, bailey's). The chocolate taste is just not decadent enough and it doesn't feel like premium chocolate.I would go if I am in the area looking for a nice place to catch up with friends, but nothing to write home about.

There's a lovely conservatory-style area at the back of the café, preceded by a dim but cosy seating area facing an open kitchen/bakery and chocolate display cabinet.It was raining that day, and I actually suspect that they redecorate according to the season or occasion! My evidence: the staff were visibly buzzing around inside before they opened, and they could have been tweaking the decor! Also, I've seen pictures of the café filled with little hearts, all posted in February, as well as other similar pictures with Halloween lanterns. I'd be very impressed if they actually hung those raining clouds to reflect the weather outside! It really added a fantastic touch to Wimbly Lu's intimate and personal setting.To make sure that my friend and I were having a legitimate lunch and not just stuffing our faces with desserts instead of having a proper meal, we ordered a double seafood and cheese toasty ($6) which was so-so.Me made our next choice from having read other reviews and recommendations - waffle with salted caramel ice cream, plus a topping of maple syrup. ($8.50)This waffle was pretty much perfect, it really hit that criteria of a crisp exterior and fluffy insides. From what I've heard, every single waffle served is just as perfect! Talk about quality control.The salted caramel ice cream was delicious - flavourful but not sickeningly sweet. We definitely could have had a bigger scoop. The maple syrup was a good choice of topping as well.Now I'm no expert on sticky date pudding, as this was my first one ever. I've got to say that it was delightful! Warm, gooey, sweet, and addictive. I only got to taste dates in my last mouthful, though. I'm not sure if sticky date puddings have to taste strongly of dates.It would have made more sense for the dense, rich pudding to come with pouring cream or ice cream, but it didn't, so we ordered an addition scoop of honey cinnamon ice cream. ($3)The cinnamon taste was a little stronger than expected, which was a surprise, but a good one - like apple pie in ice cream form! There wasn't much taste of honey, it was probably used mainly to sweeten. The ice cream flavour didn't go that well with the pudding. However, the texture was perfect in my terms. Not too icy, yet not too heavy and gooey - somewhere among that blissful in between. We found ourselves craving more of that honey cinnamon ice cream!With service charge, the bill came to somewhere around $25 in total for the both of us, which is pretty reasonable for the great atmosphere and food. Wimbly Lu is definitely somewhere I'll return to for a relaxed dessert experience the next time I visit Singapore!

Wimbly Lu is all about chocolate. Period.A rising star in a little hideout, Jalan Riang, it's really not that difficult to find with the cute red and white vintage beetle parked right in front of the shop. You might actually have better luck locating the Cafe than an empty parking lot!My fave there gotta be their Rootbeer Cake.Who in the world will think that rootbeer infused chocolate cake would taste so good! With a scope of vanilla ice cream, the combination is just like a regular rootbeer float just that instead of drinking, you are actually eating it.The salted caramel truffle has a touch of chocolate bitterness that fuses with the sweet and salty caramel. Rich and tantalising, it's a really cool chocolate treat! If you can't get enough of the chocolate, try their chocolate molten lava cake. There's seriously more "molten chocolate" than cake in this dessert. Havent had the chance to try their savoury dishes but their desserts are definitely good enough for me. ;)

The ambiance is great.  Wimbly Lu  has a very pretty, serene vintage feel. However, the food ranged from average (at best) to disappointing. But we loved the ambiance so much that the food didn't really mattered all that much after awhile. I would recommend you stick with the "safer" choices then sit back, relax & enjoy the place. Read a book. It's a beautiful way to spend a lazy sunday afternoon :) The food (desserts) 1. Root beer cake - We saw many tables order this + It was highly instagramed + It was a chef's choice... so we went against our gut feeling (which was warning us that root-beer & chocolate will probably taste weird) and order it. Sadly, our guts were right! This tasted pretty strange! I am a fan of root beer and chocolate. But not both together. Lesson learnt. 2. Waffles with salted caramel ice cream & toffee sauce - Since we went for a risky choice with #1, we decided opt for a safer choice with the waffles which was not bad. Average. Safe. Expected. My only complain was the toffee sauce which tasted nothing like the sticky, rich brown toffee sauce I expected. This was a translucent, honey colored liquid which tasted more like a cheap syrup than toffee! The salted caramel ice cream was also more salty than I'd prefer. 3. Honey lemon - Ok4 Scones - A good safe choice. Served with cream and jam... just the way I like my scones :) Service - Great.

Nice place with good interior decor. It's a nice rustic look. However, the long waiting queue and cramped up seating arrangements is a put off. It seemed as those as they are squeezing as many pax in the restaurant with little room of comfortable space. Food wise, the waffles are really nice. But the rest of the desserts are unimpressionable.
Great dessert place, ordered the banoffee pie, carrot cake, blackout cake and molten lava cake. Highly recommend the banoffee pie. Cakes here are as good as you expect them to be.

"Just go for the desserts, skip the real food."That's what I heard about Wimbly Lu. Well what happened was we had dinner at Fat Cat, and then we hopped over to Wimbly for desserts! A friend on Instagram also recommended their Orange Flour-less Cake, and someone said their Waffles are good. My neighbour told me about their molten lava cake and smores pie, which is then what we ordered. Chocolate overload!The molten lava cake was not as sweet as I expected though, which is good. Still gave me a sugar high (ok perhaps it was the smores pie) but the chocolate quality is detectable to be better than average. With the smores pie, it is a layer of granola crushed bits, with a huge chunk of chocolate, and molten marshmellows. Super decadent. super sweet.The place itself is very whimsical and nice. I really liked the decor, especially the ceiling fairy lights and the adobe walls. It was quite packed on a Sunday night as people lined up to sit for some coffee and desserts. The noise level is a bit high, but that's expected.

Reasonably priced cafe food and great service. We ordered the following: waffles with salted caramel ice cream and maple syrup, truffle fries, banoffee pie and iced and hot honey lemon for beverages. My verdict: nothing worth mentioning except the banoffee pie was really good! Not overly sweet with generous amount of banana and the digestive crust was nicely salted, so all together was  pleasant!

I heard good things, so I went... and ehhh I think it was all right.First impressions are GREAT. It's a BEAUTIFUL shop - vintage VW Beetle out front, great shopfront, and stepping in, you see the dark brown brickwork, and the greenhouse-style roof at the back... it's pretty gorgeous.Menu-wise one should remember that this is a chocolate shop. I wouldn't look at anything else, especially if the store itself says so. I've had a friend rave about their spicy hot chocolate (and he's a dude, so it must be pretty good). I... liked it, but I didn't think it was all that.The gang and I had a raft of other desserts too, and I was particularly looking forward to the clafoutis - cherries in a chocolate tart? Heck Yeah! When it came though... it was kinda thin and dry; perhaps their interpretation was a little different?This spot gives me a "style over substance" feel, but when so many friends are in love with it, I'll have to give it another try. And hope they've fixed the clafoutis.

I love this place, they make the most awesome desserts. Try their home made ice cream with waffles, it's probably as good as it gets anywhere else in Singapore. There's also a great ambience to chill out with friends.However, on weekends, do note that if your party is small you may get shifted around as larger parties come in and they need you to give up your seat. Didn't happen to me but the waiter did give advance notice in case it happened.

Tucked away coffee shop in the Serangoon suburb.  All the locals hangout here on the weekend.  The chocolate, the cakes and the savouries are of superb quality.  They make a proper flatwhites which is hard to find in Singapore.  Service can get patchy as they get busy during the weekend.  They also showcase their decorating cakes which is very entertaining for children.  Recommended esp if you are in that area.

The interior reminded me of the castle of Edinburgh with the exposed brick walls and natural light from the ceiling. Very vintage and yet homey. There are little nooks and crannies to be explored such as the kids section under the stairs. I think it's the perfect corner to take off your inhibitions along with your shoes and sit cross legged on the mat. You can do that while enjoying a yummylicious dessert.There's quite a selection of sweets but Wimbly Lu place quite a large emphasis on their chocolates. Caught sight of the Root Beer Float Cake, which has a slice of moist chocolate fudge cake soaked in root beer and ice cream and good ol' choc fudge. It's a dessert in a dessert! I don't know why this didn't appear on my table but then again it's really lousy judgement on my part for letting S do the ordering. :P Heard that this is pretty awesome. I think it's only $6.50.Skip the mains, go for desserts straight.

Located at Jalan Riang, Wimbly Lu was certainly a hard place to find for someone who did not know the area well. It is perhaps easier to identify their adorably vintage signature car parked outside which is quite hard to miss. I was brought there by a friend who had raved about the place and their waffles.The place was not big but very cosy and comfortable, with quite a nice homely feel to it. We went there in the day but I was told by my friend that it was gorgeous at night with the lights and an open area so I would have to go again to witness it for myself. The staff were extremely pleasant with huge smiles and an ever-ready attitude, which made it a very delightful experience indeed. The happiness of the staff seemed to be rather infectious as it made me feel rather happy too despite the rain outside.I ordered a chicken baked rice which seemed to be more of an eastern take on chicken baked rice, without the creaminess that most baked rice dishes have. In fact, there was no sauce, and it was simply a slightly sweet chicken and mushroom rice, reminiscent of claypot rice, baked with a layer of cheese that was likely some form of cream cheese instead of the usual cheddar or mozarella. Although it was not the best baked rice I've had, it was quite an interesting take on chicken baked rice and went rather well together as a whole. We also had their famous waffles with cinnamon icecream, and though the ice-cream was far too grainy, the waffles were wonderfully fluffy on the outside and crispy on the inside.With the stellar service I received and yummy waffles, I would be more than glad to go back again to verify if it is indeed as lovely as my friend had described at night.

I dropped by Wimbly Lu one evening with the parents as I was craving some sort of a chocolate cake. As I live around the area, wimbly lu was probably the closest cafe for me to get a nice cup of coffee and cake. I have heard raving reviews about the place from some friends who have been there a couple of times. My parents were familiar with the area so we found the cafe quite easily. However, I believe it might be pretty difficult for most people to get there by foot as it is located in the private housing estate quite a distance from the nearest MRT station (Serangoon MRT). The cafe is easily identifiable by their signature red car parked outside. The decor of the place is lovely, and great attention is put into the display pieces and ornaments placed around. Walking in, antique looking shelves line the wall, giving the place a touch of vintage. The rustic red bricked wall on one side, coupled with the beautiful lighting gave the place a homely, yet romantic atmosphere. I had their Rootbeer cake, which essentially was a piece of dark chocolate cake infused with root beer, topped with a chocolate root beer syrup and served with vanilla ice-cream. The chocolate cake was alright, and I could taste the hint of root beer with each mouthful. However, the chocolate did not come through sufficiently, which was pretty disappointing as what can be worse in a chocolate cake than not tasting the chocolate. That said, the chocolate syrup was divine. The chocolate was thick, but not too heavy, and the root beer flavour combined with it brilliantly. The vanilla ice-cream was slightly icy, but otherwise went well with the cake. I also had a flat white, which was pretty good!The service at Wimbly Lu was brilliant. The service staff were attentive and patient, answering my questions about their various desserts. Overall, this cafe is a pretty awesome find and I will definitely be back to try more of their offerings (especially their waffles, which I heard is pretty good).

really good desserts at this small store in a surprisingly hipster part of serangoon - I live near the area and never knew this place even existed (except for all the posts floating about the blogosphere on this place and its cajun neighbour). I didn't really know what to expect, actually - I tried to come with tempered expectations in case it didn't actually live up to the hype - but came away liking it quite a bit.it's a small space (so be prepared to wait), but gorgeously furnished in kitschy retrovintage furnishings and what I feel is rather old-school american - which also leads me to ask: have you also noticed that hipster places in singapore take on a vintage persona from history that never quite happened to us? I feel like this place could fit in fantastically in seattle, but here seems a little like an isolated microcosm of american fifties-style coffee shops.and the food? pretty good, really. we had two waffles  - both of which came warm, crisp outside with soft insides. I think this ought to be a sure-order; it's a rather large portion as well. we also had a bread pudding - served with crème anglaise - as well as a still molten chocolate lava cake. I think the latter was more impressive - the chocolate was sufficiently darkwell-worth a return, and especially so after dinner at the fat cat.
Why do people queue to be squashed elbow to elbow next to strangers to eat waffles while listening to next table conversations. Totally pretentious. So hipster I can't breathe.

I dont think these reviews need to be too long? This place is fit for purpose as a neighbourhood coffee joint, and if I lived around the corner I'd probably drop in for a coffee ever so often. Otherwise, better for kids with its friendly pricing or only as a second best option.

The place is fine, but with the poor service staff, makes it all the more worse. Service staff stands around doing nothing most of the time, puts in more effort in looking at the mirror instead of trying to serve customers. Foods great, but service utterly sucks.

address: Blk 78C, Toa Payoh Central Singapore 313078 Singapore
comment: A classy stall in a coffeeshop. I tried their Peri-Peri Chicken with Spaghetti that was on promotion. Their version of peri-peri sauce should come with health warning! It was SPICY!!! Lucky I can take the spice and found it tasty with a lot of bite!! Very generous leg of chicken and their spaghetti was great company to the grilled chicken.My hubby ordered his usual pizza and THAT was also something to shout about. Something about the cheese they use that is very savory and fragrant. Very yummy indeed. That became his favourite!!!Will definitely return for pizzas and peri-peri grilled chicken!!

It seems like every coffee shop is trying to get a face-lift these days. After extensive renovations, PP 881 finally reopened with spanking new decor. While I like how clean the newer facade is, I nonetheless miss the old coffee shop style a little.The good dim sum stall is still there, and if you come in the morning you'll have to fight with the crowd. The zi char is also good, and has become a frequent haunt whenever I'm in the area. They get your orders mixed up occasionally though, so beware of that.Also must-try: the new claypot chicken rice stall. It's very affordable at S$4.50 for a pretty big bowl, and they cook the rice in the claypot from scratch instead of using already cooked rice.

The coffee stall in this coffee  shop has a hidden rule. If you have coins, you should put them on the counter instead of handing over to the cashier. That's according to the old woman at the coffee stall around 3.40 pm 31/03/2021. According to this old woman, if you don't do this, the coins would just 'drop'. Also refused to pass change to your hands, very weird. Either this or the old woman is mentally unstable. Doubt it's the later

Not a bad place for some cheap and good cheese baked rice or pasta! :) I loved my Japanese curry sauced baked rice with mushroom and salmon!!!! :) delish! Would totally have it again!
