I also got an oreo freeze which was def a great drink to wash down all that cheese! :) These cheesy snack platter is also a treat! The cheese fondue is bubbling non stop and the cheese has a sweet tangy taste to it! :)I would have to come back to Eighteen Chefs to checkout more of their offerings.Service : since it's a nett priced place, you would go up to the cashier to order and the waiter would serve the dishes to you.

I will like this place if I am a teenager. Decent food at affordable prices, and there is a student rate all day long, everyday. It is not a wonder then that it is packed on weekends, with a constant stream of customers waiting for a table. It is a mix of teenagers, families with young children and older parents (pioneer generation card holder also has special price) and a handful of adults on Sunday afternoon after 2pm. The staff is young and the service is enthusiastic, polite and prompt. They do try to fit everyone and so a few tables of diners were asked if they could swap tables to accommodate different group sizes. Generally everyone is considerate and fine with that. The cashier is a bit slow, and again everyone is understanding and not in a hurry. The cashier is also mindful of the students and different organizations discount available and will ask if any of us has that. That is quite rare as many restaurants do not even bother asking customers that. This is not a place for a quiet meal as the din from a full house is tremendous. Food is served quickly unless you ordered the baked rice/pasta then it will take a while. The pricing is generally affordable though I think there could be more than 4 mid wings for $3.80. Or maybe the presentation of 4 mid wings in a big bowl makes it look very little. I customized my baked rice with double cheese (regular mozzarella and nacho cheese) with spicy garlic (just a few slices of chili, so not spicy to me) and mushrooms  (sliced button mushrooms). I did not care for nacho cheese in rice so I will skip that next time. The wings are good, likewise for the cream of mushroom (sliced shiitake) soup and garlic bread.

At first, I was a tad disappointed that my favourite Thai Express place was gone (within a week!) and this chicken rice place took over instead. I was curious as there was such a long queue and all for chicken rice?If you just get a basic plate of chicken rice, it costs only $4.90, how affordable is that! Plus, it comes with a small bowl of chicken rice soup. We ordered the Tofu with Sweet Thai Sauce in addition to the chicken rice; not too bad I must say, the Tofu was soft on the outside and slightly crispy on the outside. I'm not a fan of the sweet thai sauce flavour but it complements the dish nicely.Something interesting to note is that the entire suite of staff from Thai Express was working the floor at Pratunam Chicken Rice. I wonder if it's the same boss or the new bosses took pity on the old staff (given the short notice of takeover) and hired them all. Food for thought.TIP: Come during odd hours to enjoy a peaceful meal as it can get quite noisy and crowded, especially on weekends!

Parking is now available at the residence "The Venues", right opposite the restaurant. Either that, or hope you get street parking right outside the restaurant. (Can be difficult during peak periods, so just park elsewhere and walk if possible)The parents wanted to get Turtle Soup for dinner, and while I'm not a huge fan (still sounds creepy to me), I love their Black Chicken soup! So herbal-y and flavourful, yum!They basically only serve two types of soups with rice (yam or white), so you find anything else here.Their chili is really good. Add vinegar to it for that extra kick.

The thought of eating turtle may be somewhat controversial or grotesque to some, but this was probably the best thing I ate the entire week I was in Singapore.  Ser Seng Herbs sells other things like black chicken (was so tempted to get), but their turtle soups are where it's at.You can choose between $15/$25/$35 bowls of soup, and you can also choose whether or not you would like to include turtle innards along with the skin and meat.  I chose to keep all three in my $25 soup for the full experience, and I was not disappointed whatsoever.  The meat was tender and the texture reminded me of pork.  Turtle doesn't taste fishy as I thought it would, but more like a typical red meat.  The skin is gelatinous and tastes like cartilage.  Innards are awesome, but that's because I'm biased and love innards/entrails.  Comes with a side of special hot sauce (add vinegar - good combo).  The hot soup was probably the most flavorful soup I've ever had in my life.  I don't care if its 90 degrees Fahrenheit and 100% humidity outside... good soup is acceptable in any kind of weather.The next time I'm in Singapore, this is my first stop.

For the adventurous gourmet who wouldn't mine gulping down a thick rich creamy essence of Turtle. Set Seng has the best tasting soup I have tasted in Asia.The turtles are farmed for human consumption in Indonesia, which supplies the produce to them. The soup is absolutely delicious and it is definitely worth a try without any prejudice. The texture of the meat taste like lean chicken.
Had to ask a taxi driver who then told us about this gem on McPherson.  Soup was delicious, rich, lots of turtle.  Also quite clean...had a A rating.

address: 531 Ang Mo Kio Ave 10 #01-2429 Happy Hawkers Coffeeshop Singapore 560531 Singapore
comment: As their name suggests, they focus on fish and chicken only, nothing else.Their fish and chips are really quite good, soft and buttery inside and crispy outside. Chicken is decent too (both grilled and crispy).It is one of those new-generation hawker stalls, so it's more expensive ($7-12). I think this is a little expensive given their narrow selection of meats - for example, Char-Grill Bar has similar prices, but they offer pork, lamb, beef, etc. By right focusing on only a few meats should help this place cut down on purchasing and storage cost, but I guess that doesn't translate to lower prices.Also, they charge $0.50 for takeaway (not sure why it costs so much, it comes in a plain paper box), and they aren't really very generous with their dips.Overall, the fish and chips may be worth an occasional splurge, i guess.

address: 531 Ang Mo Kio Ave 10 #01-2429 Happy Hawkers Coffeeshop Singapore 560531 Singapore
comment: I tried the two flavour fish chilli/salty eggTo my surprise is the salty egg flavour that tasted the best . Although I a chilli crab kind of guy. Everything is good except that you have to bring your own tissue because they don't provide any

address: 68 Serangoon Garden Way Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 555964 Singapore
comment: The unit that this restaurant occupies could be said to be cursed - in the past few years it's had on average more than one tenant per year, or something like that. The trend looks set to continue.I've never been a fan of steamed food. This place did nothing to change my disposition, as it had the blandest food I can ever remember eating. Even when I'm sick, food doesn't taste so bad (and yes, I used the sauces).So you can come here to eat if you want to feel virtuous. Or feel like torturing yourself.The food was really fresh, but then steaming as a form of cooking is not kind to bad produce - even fans of steamed food would not be able to take it.The sauces you can put on your food to make it more palatable are the standard ones you'd find in any steamboat place, with the addition of black pepper and "seafood" (which was a "Thai"-ish style sweet and sour chili sauce). But then what works with steamboat doesn't work here, since steamboat soup serves to flavour your food (in other words, stronger sauces are needed to make up for the bland-tasting food).Besides the disappointing food, the way this place does dining arrangements makes the experience annoying - you can only cook food one layer at a time, which makes it very slow. The whole experience was thus very slow and we took 1.5 hours to finish our meal. This is probably why they only have 2 dinner seatings - at 6pm and 8pm (good luck to you if you want to eat at other times).One of the few redeeming points here is that as your food is steamed, its drippings fall below to flavour what becomes porridge (which you end your meal with). The porridge wasn't bad, but it wasn't quite enough to redeem the meal.

address: 68 Serangoon Garden Way Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 555964 Singapore
comment: Very gimmicky way of eating. Not enjoyable at all. We much prefer old school steamboat.The food variety is also not interesting. And the condiments station not good either. Won't return.

address: 68 Serangoon Garden Way Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 555964 Singapore
comment: If you are looking for a new and unique restaurant and don't mind paying a bit more, you MUST try this place. Instead of the typical steam boat or mookata, Steam Box offers a healthier and better way to enjoy the ultra fresh seafood. I heard from one of the staff that they get their fresh seafood daily and even discard leftovers each day to ensure quality. So what's so interesting about this place? You select the items you want and pick from 1 of the 2 broth for the porridge. They will put the uncooked porridge ingredient in the pot below and tell you to start steaming the other items. The 'juice' from all the items will drip into the porridge making it even tastier. (I think the pork broth is better than the clam broth)That's not all, the steaming process takes just 2 minute for the barramundi (entire fish but sliced up nicely) and up to 6 minute for other items. The plates are color coded according to the time you need to set for the cooking. Steaming helps retain the flavour of each item really well. My favorite dishes are the barramundi, prawn, and the Chef Marinated Minced pork with premium salted fish. This is the current place that will provide you with a unique experience. I heard that you need to book at least 3 days in advance for a table during peak hours. I did a walk in at 8:15 on Friday and was to wait for 20 minute to get a table for 3. If you aren't the type to make reservation, you can go at a later timing. :)

address: Blk 92 Lorong 4 Toa Payoh #01-264 Singapore 310092 Singapore
comment: I'm surprised at how good the fish head curry is. My friend has told me about it ages ago but the location put me off (I'm an Orchard Road girl after all). Then I saw it when I was at the coffee shop for Kim Keat Hokkien Mee, and realized it was not so far from home after all. My favorite type of fish head curry was of the spicy tangy type from my childhood. Not sure where my dad bought it from and my memory was too fuzzy to remember where it was. But it was a Chinese stall specializing in fish head curry somewhere in Serangoon area. Anyway, that is my benchmark for an awesome curry. Ocean Curry Fish Head is very close to that remembered taste. The curry is slightly spicy and has a tang to it. Besides the fish head, there are the usual veg in it (eggplant, tomato and okra) plus chopped green chilies and the surprise - pineapple. For a half head portion, there is plenty of meat that the 2 of us barely finish it. The price is quite ok. We paid $31 for the fish head curry (portion for 2 - half head), a side of vegetables and 1 plate of rice. The stall also has a wide range of dishes for economy rice. All of them look very appetizing and fresh. They will be a good option to buy home when you are too lazy to cook for the family.

address: Blk 92 Lorong 4 Toa Payoh #01-264 Singapore 310092 Singapore
comment: Absolutely yummy goodness.  The restaurant is located in a larger shared space in the Toa Payoh neighborhood.  First you order the fish head curry you want.  It comes in small and large sizes depending on the number of people.  Yes I said fish head curry so all you are getting is the head of the fish.  Second there is a section where you can order small dishes as add-ons.  They various veggie dishes and I recommend the bean sprouts with salted fish and the sambal kangkong (aka water spinach or convolvulus).  You can also add rice to your meal.The side dishes came pretty quickly but the fish took a few minutes extra.  It was served in a clay pot boiling hot.  Wait a couple of minutes to let it cool down before digging.  I recommend the meat from the cheek.  That is best part of the whole fish.  It's been a long time since I had a good fish head curry and I am satisfied.

address: Blk 92 Lorong 4 Toa Payoh #01-264 Singapore 310092 Singapore
comment: $45 for 2... curry fishhead plus 3 side dishes..decent price... nothing fancy... good food...good for a family meal... easy parking.. n no waiting time..try it!!

address: Blk 92 Lorong 4 Toa Payoh #01-264 Singapore 310092 Singapore
comment: I'll be frank to say that the food is not cheap but the flavour is there. They are afterall famous for their curry fish head.I like the option to have a quick and a affordable meal if you just pick dishes to go with rice on a single plate. Alternatively, you can order dishes and rices in separate dishes. That may be more expensive but more communal as a family meal. Other than the fish curry, the other dishes are also done very nicely. So don't worry and just order what looks good, chances are, it'll taste good too! This is my go-to place for picking up dishes to supplement a home-cooked meal.

Great location.  Service was fast , considering only 8 people eating. Couldn't imagine if the place was full. Anyway the food was awful , all precooked frozen trash. It tasted freezer burned. I would avoid except to go and have a beer or drink. Nice location. Eat before you go, food is real bad.

We had came for a birthday dinner of about 20 pax. I would give credit for the excellent location and fair food, but the bad service more than negated everything. Besides having to pay for something as simple as ice water, they gave us a pile of tissue papers to serve our birthday cake (which was just over 6 inches btw), claiming that they had no more small plates available, full stop. When we requested to borrow their 'reserved' section of the restaurant for just a group picture because it was raining outside and we did not want to disturb the rest of the guests, we were flatly rejected with the claim that the guests might be arriving. We stayed till 10pm, but no one arrived at their 'reserved' section. This was tolerable until our balloons floated to the ceiling and we asked for their kind help to retrieve it. Guess what, their manager just replied and said that they were sorry and there's nothing they can do. As guests, we had to stand ourselves on their chairs and retrieved it with the help of our own umbrellas. Throughout the whole time, all the staff just stood by and watched without offering to help. This is when we decided to speak to the manager, but was told by the staff that there was no manager on duty. Clearly however, there was someone in charge who was in plain clothes. She had stood behind the bar the whole time watching the horrible service unfold with nothing but a smile on her face. When we had requested for their boss's namecard for feedback, she seemed more than happy to pass us the namecard without bothering to find out what the issue was. Horrible experience, all for paid service charge. Thank you Vava Bistro for letting us know how a restaurant should not be managed. I had originally intended to hold my corporate meetings at this establishment, but after this experience, no way would I allow my guests to be served in this manner.

Perfect Gem tucked away on a back street near my apartment! I have only ordered from this resto for delivery but it never failed me! The food is excellent and authentic and what I really appreciate is that they are willing to make some dishes vegetarian! which is a big plus for us. My goto favourites are - Green curry chicken - Thai style morning glory - Paneang Curry - yellow Ginger chicken - Tom sap (SPICY!!!) - Tom Ka I would recommend them to infact add some vegetarian dishes to their menu, I am sure there are many like us who would be encouraged with veggie choices. Compliments to the chef.

Siam Society is a great place if you are craving for some westernized Siam food (food kinda lack some spice, but still taste good regardless). During my visit, I ordered Tom Kha soup (large size) and Thai butter prawn. The thai butter prawn's sauce is really to die for. Taste wise it's not authentic, but the sauce was so creamy buttery and sweet at the same time. Personally I really like it. However the prawn itself doesn't taste fresh to me. I think they probably use frozen prawn. Regardless for $18, you'll get 6 large size prawn. Price wise I think it's reasonable. You get what you pay for.For Tom kha soup, even though the menu only says it's only a lil bit spicy (marked with only 1 sign of chili), but I found the soup very spicy to my taste. This dish doesn't really WOW me or anything, but I'd say not bad. To add steamed jasmine rice is an additional $1.50 per bowl, and Thai iced tea here is  priced at $4. They also have a self-service counter for iced water.Just a side note, this place takes reservation - for no minimum # of people.

Located in the club, there was a cafe called Fix by the swimming pool. The staffs were quite friendly and I was offered a table by the pool. Although the place was non air-con, it was quite cooling with the fans on top.Smoked Duck Arancini Balls ($7)The deep fried balls are presented quite prettily with sliced radish and rockets, but there was only 3 pieces. It was very hot inside, so beware of it. While outside was crispy, inside the rice was buttery and moist. Felt that the duck meat was too tiny to make an impression.Donuts with Salted Egg Dip ($6)The donut itself was not hot and crispy. Felt that it was too doughy and a tab oily. The salted egg dip served with it was not bad except that it was more on the custard taste than salted egg.Iced Lemongrass Gula Melaka ($5)It was served with a lemongrass as a stirrer. The gula melaka was light in taste in the taste, but quite a well balance combination with the lemongrass taste. Quite a refreshing drink to have during a hot weather.Overall food was not bad, but the selection was quite limited. The place was quite relaxing to be around. Please note that there was GST in the bill, but not service charge.

Leaning more towards a fuss-free laidback style, it might be better to come during the day as the tables next to the swimming pool were dimly-lit, unless you are looking for a romantic atmosphere. That said, our experience is definitely less than grubby. Once you managed to extract some gorgeous cheese strands from the CHEESE PENNE GRATIN ($12 for set with drink), you know this is a pot of gold. Wait no longer, start digging in. Smothered in strong glows of melted cheese and tremendous amount of kidney beans and minced beef, the mushy salted fries have a low chilli consciousness but certainly a helluva better version than the Chilli Corn Carne of Grub. Not sure if the FISH AND CHIPS ($14) might appear the same as the hake fish burger so we had the NAANWICHES. The naan-sandwich fusion weren't bewitchingly delicious but kudos to the team that came up with this ingenious dish.The LIU SHA BAO DONUTS $7 is not exactly in the same league as the classic Salted Egg Yolk in dimsum. Weird and wonderful, there is something extra sexy as you dip the fluffy hot buns into the cool egg dip while watching a couple soaking in the swimming pool as though it was an onsen bath. To be honest, my mind was totally occupied with the desserts right before I even stepped into the cafe. With a beautifully tempered chocolate ganache riding on top some blissfully assertive chocolate mousse, the COCOA BARRY CHOCOLATE TRUFFLE $7 is a highly potent blast of cacao flavour, obscuring the minuscules amount of salted chocolate sables (might have increased by now). The Passionfruit, Mango and Coconut Chiffon Cheesecake $7 did not set my heart on an erratic rhythm, but the finely executed textures in the coconut meringue mousse came as a rare entity in Singapore.  The Rose Pistachio Tart  $6 is aesthetically pleasing but realistically flawed. Crowned with tangy red coulis and mildly scented rose cream, the tart isn't buttery nor crumbly but firm and chewy. The Twice-Baked Sourcream Cheesecake  $7-- a rich baked vanilla cheese with a primary layer of sourcream--was thwarted by it's muggy graham baseBut do get ready you fork before the Butterscotch Arabica Choux $6 arrived before it vanished in seconds. What propelled it to the spot of BEST cream puff in Singapore is the amazing unity of a hyper-delicious salted caramel sauce and rich chocolate filling, cupped in the croustillant-covered choux that is overflowing with pillow-light coffee cream. With enough people clamouring for it, it's magnificence cannot be overstated.

Perhaps it was my timing when I went last Saturday evening and my purpose there (ie not chilled). By the pool made me think more beach club chillax environment but the feel and the atmosphere turned out closer to public poolside cafeterias but with nicer seats and better coffee. Full disclosure: I haven't been to a public pool since I was a child.Pool was crowded with lots of kids and families and started right next to where we were sitting against the railing. The place was also kinda dark and dull.Coffee was decent. To be clear, friend and I had a serious discussion for 3 hours here so it's not like the noise is so loud but it's just quite messy and school canteen. A bit of contrast to the serious looking coffee machine and huge long counter.We weren't ready for dinner although I saw they had a special for fish and chips for $12, apparently a new item they were trying out. They also had a coffee + cake special for $10 but after looking through all the choices, none of them caught our eye.  Prices for these I thought were reasonable though. The cakes were just a bit weird (or original?) and I read these are all made inhouse. I may go back to try the tikka naanwich sometime as the location is very convenient because there is a huge carpark directly in Home TeamNS so if you're in the Balestier area and need a decent latte and a place to sit and read, this may suit you. As it's not crowded (yet?) seats were plentiful.
Pool view is nice. Food was ok, nothing special. Depending on where you are coming from, it's a bit hidden/far.

address: Blk 203 Toa Payoh North #786 Singapore 310203 Singapore
comment: If you are a roti prata lover and have been searching for healthier prata, this is it!  The prata chef does not add extra oil into the making of the prata and he does not fry it. He toast it until it's cooked. So it's not oily when you eat them. And they are so delicious! The dal & curry sauce are yummy! And you have to try their vadai (Indian donut). They are super yummy - crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside and yes, not oily too!! I don't feel that I need a major workout after eating it! Most of all, the couple that works on their food are super friendly and helpful. The chef took his time to explain how he made it such that his food are healthy and not oily. I'm definitely bringing more friends there!!

Was fascinated with the Shokutsu idea so I wandered onto this food street with my friend Eugene. The stall beside Tontei serves yakiniku; there's ichiban boshi, a sushi takeout place, a stall selling Japanese buns and even a cafe selling Jap food and drinks. I wanted to go to the stall next door but it was more Italian-Jap fusion (Jap pastas and pizzas) rather than authentic Jap food. We waited around half an hour before being seated on the weekday evening.A glance of the menu and I summarized the dishes to - 1. kurobuta, 2. katsu (fried pork) and 3. sashimi. Not much options here. We both ordered tonkatsu dishes. I had cold soba with it while my friend opted for katsudon.The black pork was really not bad, albeit coming in a small helping. I recommend this if you come here to eat. There was some veges and tomato with the noodles too. I guess I wasn't that hungry so the serving size was perfect. Might try the kurobuta next time I'm here. It's not too cheap either. 23 bucks per person for our meal and cold ocha.

The tonkatsu is ok. They have black pork but it is not fatty or juicy enough. They also do not serve free-flow cabbage like in the premium tonkatsu outlets.I prefer Tonkatsu by Ma Maison at Mandarin Gallery or Saboten. For sure.

Friendly staff greeted me as I walked into this restaurant. There wasn't a queue and the place was not very packed. As its name suggests, pork is their specialty- particularly kurobuta pork, arguably the most sought-after of premium pork in Japan. A chawanmushi craving brought me to Shokutso 10, the Japanese 'Food Street' in Nex, where Tontei is located. After settling down in the restaurant and looking at the menu however, I opted for their Yuzu Kosho Mixed Katsu Zen. The deep-fried pork was succulent and the mushroom sauce was delish! Prices are fairly high but worth it.I'd definitely come back here again because the menu is so different from most Japanese restaurants I've come across in Singapore. I still have to settle that chawanmushi craving anyway.

address: 9 Bishan Pl #B1-25, Junction 8 Shopping Center Singapore 579837 Singapore
comment: Tori-Q used to be good. Or maybe I got fussier on Japanese food as I got older.The standard chicken skewer meat have a very frozen taste to it. The meat must have been frozen for quite a long while before getting cooked at the store. Other skewers such as unagi and prawn are expensive and not worth the money.For lunch, you can grab a box of rice with 3 chicken and 1 chicken ball skewer for about $5. pretty ok deal if you're ok with the frozen meat.

address: 9 Bishan Pl #B1-25, Junction 8 Shopping Center Singapore 579837 Singapore
comment: I like Tori-Q for fast and easy Japanese food - it started out mostly with various types of chicken skewers but you can get pork, prawn and even potato too. Better still, get yourself a bento set with rice and 4 skewers for a full meal. My choice for a quick easy meal you don't have to think too hard about.

address: 9 Bishan Place Basement One Singapore 579837 Singapore
comment: Their fried pau is great!Tasty mix of meat. Either chicken & mushroom, pork & cabbage and pork & water chestnut.Pau skin is pan fried but not charred with a little spring onion on top. The bottom is full of sesame seed which is why the flavour just pops!Pan fried to order.They have some fried stuff but those are just meh.

Ahhh another Market to go.  But this one has 2 Levels.  On Level 2 where you can find several butcher shops/vendors and tailor shops.Another market and food centre to explore...  Once again, if we are shopping across the street where the 24 hours GIANT supermarket is located at, my mother goes here to yet another favorite vegetable shop/vendor.We also discovered Qian Yi Tailoring on the 2nd Level aka 2nd Floor of this Market.Definitely returning when needed.

BEST hainanese chicken rice, hands down! I've been eating here since I was a teenager and it has consistently been fantastic. It has a good fusion with some peranakan dishes. Can't wait for my next plate. Remember to pair it with sambal kangkong and otak otak!

One of my family favourites for Sunday after church, we used to come all the time for chicken rice and zichar or nonya dishes. Standards have maintained somewhat similar over the years despite being around for decades. The only negative point has nothing to do with Pow Sing but more about the limited parking within Serangoon Gardens.

Taken here for lunch on Monday. Boy this place is noisy! Even though we dont sit closely to each other, lots of chattings in the house going on. Prolly a good place if you dont wanna hear ur parents nag.The food is good! We had rice, chicken, char siew, bittergourd fish soup & an eggish spinach for 4 ladies. Kind of over ordered as i feel very full despite eating half of my rice. And im nt a small eater. :) All the dishes taste good. But nothing to rave about the chicken rice chilli. Its not the garlicky kind i prefer. I love the chicken, smooth & tender.  Bill comes up to $56 which is very reasonable. I would return for a lunch on a weekend. Am not ready to eat such a heavy meal and return to the office/go to bed.

Best steamed chicken rice I've ever eaten; it's always been a family favorite. The rice is full of flavor, unlike the rice some of the other joints. The chicken itself was moist, not dry. They're also known for their crispy tofu, which is lightly breaded and fried so the middle of the tofu is still soft. Their fish head curry is also worth a try! If you want roasted chicken rice, they have another outlet a few doors down that has both! :)
Combination of Malay and Chinese food. Fish head curry is the best! Wasn't a fan of the dried squid.

I miss the days when Pow Sing used to be at the corner coffee shop where Citibank is now located.For some reason, the chicken was better, the rice more flavorful and the soy sauce thicker.Yes, the new location is swankier, with AC, and u can order other dishes to go with your chicken rice. But on our the last few visits, the chicken is too salty, the rice is not fragrant like last time where it is good enough to eat on its own. Sigh.I have not gone back for a while now. I MISS OLDIES!

I have always like the food at Pow Sing even though I don't dine there very often. Being in Serangoon Gardens, traffic and parking can be a nightmare, especially during peak hours i.e. meal times. Fortunately there is a valet service for Pow Sing customers, so that does take care of the parking problem. I was there for dinner last night and the food was still as good. Fish head curry - a bit spicy, with more Indian spices rather than Chinese style. The fish is fresh with firm sweet meat. Love the eggplants and okras in it, not overcooked like other places. Nonya crispy tofu - amazingly good. crispy on the outside and silky smooth soft on the inside.Ayam buah keluak - love the slight tart and spicy gravy. chicken could be a bit more tender. buah keluak was good, the opening was quite big so you could dig into the nutty black flesh with your spoon or fork.stuffed you tiao (salad flour roll) - quite normalsweet and sour pork - quite usual toofried eggplant with pork floss - cut into round pieces and deep fried. it was also crispy and crunchy, but being deep fried, a bit too oily for my liking. steamed chicken - tender chicken meat which was very smooth to the tastebakwan kepiting soup - quite tasty, meatball was nothing to write aboutstir-fry sweet potato leaves - fresh and nicely doneYou could choose regular white rice or chicken rice (fragrant) rice. The portion was quite small when compared to other places as the bowl they used was the small type. To note: Chinese tea came in individual mug, not a pot.The dishes I would order again - fish head curry, ayam buah keluak, crispy tofu, stir fry vegetables. Chicken rice.

This is the place I was taken by some local business clients.  The food was outstanding and had great service.  It was totally different than I expected.  As with most place in Singapore, it was hard to park your car.  I will be back here to eat the next time I am in the region.

This restaurant was opened not too long ago after Citibank took over its original premises in the Cardon Coffee Shop on the corner. It's more famous sister Pow Sing Restaurant is just a few doors away.I love the Roasted Chicken Rice here, and I daresay its the best chicken rice I've ever tasted, and the standard I put other chicken rice stalls up to. It's gotten a little bit more expensive now it's become a restaurant instead of just a hawker stall, but I still love it just as much. You can get other Zi Char type of food here now; I've only ever done take away because I'm not fond of queues, but if there's just one thing you should eat, make it the chicken rice, yum~

The good:  The name says it all, POW!  Ok, maybe that doesn't say it all, but it really indicates just how well the chicken rice dish comes together.  Oh yes, this review is based solely on the chicken rice.  Why only chicken rice you ask?  Because it's so darn good I haven't bothered ordering anything else.  Ever.  For starters the chicken is juicy and tender, consistently.  Other stalls seem to be hit or miss, Pow Sing never misses.  The rice boasts it's own individual flavor that you could eat on it's own.  The butcher works his cleaver like a Chang Sing street fighter, never missing a cut and always delivering a small grin at the end of his chops.  Price compliments the food, hand claps to the kitchen and management.    The bad:  I really wish it came with a side of vegetables.  But that's like dating a Victoria Secret model and saying "Yeah she's hot, but I really wish she liked playing video games".  Nothing is perfect, and that's the way it should be.    The ugly:  Serangoon Gardens has some stiff food competition, so there are days I explore other venues.  But if I want, scratch that, NEED some chicken rice, this is the place I go and I'm always happy I did.

With Pow Sing within walking distance from your place...what more can you ask for?Hard to decide whether to stick with traditional chicken rice or satisfy that nyoya craving you have? Look no further! Pow Sing offers a great combination of authentic Chicken Rice with good Nyoya Food. For the adventurous at heart, try mixing their fish head curry with black pepper venison over a plate of chicken rice. Absolutely foodgasmic! The nyonya selection is great and there's always something for everyone. With free valet parking and yes, you'll need it during the weekends, this is the place to go with the family for a good sunday dinner. Great place to showcase to visiting overseas friends who want a good sample of local food. Prices have steadily increased over the years and thus no longer as affordable as it was back then.Be prepared to spend an average of S$25 per person or more.

I only come here for the white chicken, never tried the other dishes. The chicken has a very robust flavor. Some say the standard has dropped but I think it has maintained quality pretty well. Rice and chill sauce still very good.Warning: If you takeaway, it develops a bit of a strong smell after a while so best to have it fresh at the restaurant.

Quite an institution in these parts - I feel like I've eaten there for almost 20 years! It's one of those "comfort food" type places, and you know you're always going to get good food.They've diversified quite a bit, so you can you can get a lot more than just chicken rice, if that tickles your fancy. The last time I was there, our greedy table of five ordered the fish head curry, hae chor, sambal kangkong, hotplate tofu... in addition to our whole chicken, and goodness know what else, perhaps because my brain could only process the fact that I needed to put the food in my mouth.Always safe, always tasty, and not too expensive, this place get crowded on the weekends too, so it looks like it's not just a tradition for me then.

Over-rated chicken rice.  Last time I tried, the rice was stale and it smelled funny even after they've cooked it. Also, the rice was nowhere close to good -- not comparable to Tien Tien, Wee Nam Kee and the likes.  Chicken was ok though slightly tough.  Service staff was friendly.

Probably one of the better roast meats place I've been to. Love the char Siew. It was a little dry but if the meat had some fat in jt, it was nice and succulent.   The roasted belly was very nicely done too. The best part was the gravy.  However, I'd come here only if my favorite store carrot cake and tian tian Lai Hokkien noodles store wasn't open next door ;)

If you're going to die on over-indulgence, be sure to add their char siew and roast pork to your bucket list. Ask for the fatty parts of the meat, or even *gasp* the burnt bits. Totally worth it. Their wanton mee is absolutely delicious. Their secret ingredient? Deep fried pork fat. You know it's going to kill you,  but you can't stop yourself from eating it. I try not to eat it more than once a week. Try.. -1 star for ambience/cleanliness. It's a coffeeshop after all.

Had a $10platter of roast meat , duck and char siew.Duck and roast meat was 4stars, similar to the usual good roast pork places.BUT the char siew is 5stars , fatty and juicy. Really one of the better ones in Singapore.

Nik's review made me want to try this place for the beautifully charred char siew. We got there and my colleague told me this is the same brand name as the stall we usually frequented just a few blocks away (right outside Braddell MRT). Then I recalled Nik did tell me that before, likewise for another Yong Tau Foo stall which he reviewed before. Duh. So we decided to head to the market to discover it was closed for cleaning (I never saw Nik's tip until too late - see, this is where Yelp can be really useful if one actually looks through all the tips and photos)Back to this place again where I ordered the wanton noodles. I did not order what Nik ordered so my char siew was thinly sliced and not as succulent looking as Nik's picture. But the wanton noodles was really good. After mixing in the sauce and chili, the noodles became dark and not as pale as in picture. The char siew was nice but could be better if I had ordered the fatty thicker version. The ultimate was the wanton soup. It had a herbal taste (like in duck soup?) which I enjoyed. The wantons were smallish but not too starchy thick. Now I know to order the noodles next time and with the thicker char siew. It is way better than the duck rice which I usually get at the other outlet. My colleague said the roast pork is equally good and popular.

i'm so blessed to be surrounded by good food, everywhere i look!just north of the wall, some 2.1km away is a hive that attracts me like bees to honey.whether i take a bus and walk, take a train and walk or just walk and walk, it is still worth the visit, after visits.oh, of course you can drive here too! best bet is to park at the multi-storey carpark located just behind the coffee shop where HFK is located.they are normally ready for business by 8am in the morning and that, for me, is the best time to swarm this place, before they get swarmed!uncle，云吞面，多肥叉烧，不要云吞！$4.after trying all combinations, like roast duck with char siew, roast pork with char siew and char siew with extra char siew, i have decided that fatty char siew with extra char siew is the way to go!KL style black charred meats!!!it's really healthy, especially when you ask for fatty char siew!;)i would recommend grabbing an uncut $10 piece of char siew, just to bite on, and then wash it down with that mug/can of beer in the other hand.but that is just so cannibalistic!how about, you order just like i did and enjoy that bowl as addictive as instant noodles, with a texture that bounces the noodles from tongue to throat, with a sauce that not only tastily blackens but also lusciously lubricates in case you feel the need to slurp!do not, i repeat, do not blasphemously throw out those innocent bits of crispy pork lard that will find their way into your bowl.if you do wanna throw them out, just remember to send them my way!:)that applies to the roast duck skin and roast pork crackling as well, ok?!actually, you should order their lean char siew, just so i can bear the burden of eating them fatty ones!yes, do ditch those meaningless carbo laden wantons!yes, do take your chances with their chillies, red and green ones, you know you need to spice up your life!if only, uncle was more generous with the amount of char siew that he gives!if only, uncle slices the char siew thicker instead of razor thin deli style!if only, overseas restaurant was still around.................

This roast meat joint is pretty good.Definitely above average! I ordered roast duck, char siew and sio bak for 2 people and the bill was 10 bucks. That's pretty decent you would think, but the portion is really exactly for 2 people. What I mean by that is - I'm actually a pretty big eater (probably an understatement) and if I was really hungry, I think 2 of me could easily eat 2 portions of what I ordered. (And probably regret later...but none the less still finish it up) Now I'm not saying that its DAMNNN little...coz I'm full after awhile. But for the price, it's good enough. If I went to let's say Kay Lee, I'd probably eat abt 26bucks worth whether I want to or not.. so yeah.The duck is not too oily, they give you a bowl of extra gravy for your rice, the charsiew is soft with just the right amount of fat and the siu yuk is crispy at the skin like it should be. Check, check & check! I'd post pictures but the ones already up are pretty true to what you'll be having.Worth driving down to toa payoh from bedok for dinner? Yeah why not! Esp since it doesn't close shop so early like many famous roast meat joints do.

address: 10 Anson Road #01-50A Internation Plaza Singapore 579903 Singapore
comment: Yummy delicious simple vegetarian food. Lots of premade options so you don't need to wait long. All sorts of noodles if you have some time! My ready made veggies and tofu was yum!!!

Was craving for something light yet less than $10 and this place definitely satisfied both factors.Came here on a Monday night between 6.45pm to 7pm. Wasn't crowded so I was able to grab a sit immediately upon arrival. Then went over to the counter to order and pay and during that time, you will get a buzzer together with the receipt. Ordered chicken murtabak to share between my friend and I and teh limau with plum for beverage. The beverage was alright. It would be better if they have put less ice. But it quenched the thirst. The chicken murtabak came pretty bigger in size than what I thought. For $8, there were four pretty reasonable slices of prata with chicken curry inside and there were the thin and crispy pieces on the side. Besides that, they also provided a bowl of curry to pour on to the murtabak if you are up for more spice on your dish. Pretty worth the price.Order came within 15 minutes. Beverage first then food. Overall, enjoyed my quick bite at this chain. I prefer the thinner sliced murtabak as it was crispier and less meat. One of the better dining option in Junction 8. Will be back for more pratas :)

The pratas here are thin, contain no doughy sections and have sufficient air and crispness to them (although i wish they would make them even more crispier) thanks to mr moustache who has worked here forever and perfected his craft. The thick reddish curry is also above average with good tanginess and spice. Quick and efficient ordering system.

Tea time special from 3pm to 5pm has a really good deal. $2.50 for either a prata kosong (plain) or vadai or samosa with teh tarik (frothy tea) or kopi (coffee).  We ordered the vadai and prata kosong with teh tarik. The system is (I was told):1. order2. pay3. get a buzzer and receipt5. wait for your drinks first4. find a table, if you have not already5. collect food when you buzzer lit/vibrate.6. bring your receipt in case they get confused on what you orderedThe service was hit and miss because of one server. She got confused when I asked for the tea. All because when I collected my food, I only took the dishes since the drinks were not there. So the buzzer was kept by them, and she either forgot I just brought the food to the table, or she just thought I was trying to pull a fast one on her for the drinks. I had to show my receipt and showed her my table did not have any glasses of teh tarik on it, and even then she still insisted that because I did not have the buzzer (she already kept it when I took the food), she could not give me the drinks. After glancing a few times between the receipt and table, she decided to give me a glass. I said I paid for 2 sets, then she wanted to give me a glass of teh tarik and a glass of something else. It was all resolved when the guy who took my order stepped in. Then he said usually customers would wait for the drinks first, before going to the table and wait for the buzzer to buzz before collecting the food. Since there was no sign or indication when ordering to wait for the drinks, it was easy for confusion to happen. Food wise, the vadai was awesome. Crispy on the outside, doughy chewy soft on the inside, with hint of potatoes. One of the better ones I have tried. The prata kosong was equally good. Also crispy all around. The curry was spicy and went very well. Tandoori was not available during the tea time period.

address: 9 Clover Way Clover Park Singapore 579081 Singapore
comment: Right next to Jai Thai restaurant is Sarpino's Pizza which functions as this neighborhood's local pizzeria.  They make their money mostly from Delivery and thus the indoor dining area is mostly empty. If you can't get a seat at Jai Thai, you're almost guaranteed a spot at this joint. The pizzas are decent here, with even thin crust as an option. A good selection of their pizzas in three categories: Classics, Specialty, and Gourmet. Prices are $$-$$$. Calling in to order and then picking up is also an option.  The number is 66-36-36-36.  Don't be put off by the vacant dining area. The pizzas are actually pretty good. Most people in this neighborhood would rather have their pizzas delivered instead of dining in. After all, why come to the restaurant when the food can be sent to your home?

address: 9 Clover Way Clover Park Singapore 579081 Singapore
comment: Have been patronising them across the years but they still do not meet the standards of Dominos and Pizza Hut. While charging high prices and requiring long waiting times, their meats do not taste as good, their cheese lacks a punch and the ingredients generally don't taste like it's fresh.

address: 9 Clover Way Clover Park Singapore 579081 Singapore
comment: Never again. If you want to spend 20+ dollars for the smallest pizza you've ever seen (no, really, it belongs in a doll house) then go ahead. Shameful.

Oven-baked Rendang Chicken $18.90 *Highly Recommended*Definitely one of the must try dishes, the chicken was so tender and lemak! It has a good mix of spice but yet family friendly for children, and also a sweet tinge that makes your mind think that you're eating satay! The portion is also rather huge, and definitely generous in chicken serving!Cajun Chicken $14.90Juicy, succulent chicken thigh meat served with brown mushroom gravy, mashed potatoes and a side salad. I've always been a huge fan of The Grumpy Bear's Chicken dishes and this is their evergreen favourite for me. Can never go wrong ordering this dish! Creamy Pasta with Prawn $16.90Pasta are a wonderful dish. They are heavenly delicious, and equally beautiful to look at, most importantly this disk tastes good too! Not too salty, and perfectly creamy, yet not gerlat. Loved the fresh egg yolk which adds to the texture of the cream sauce.Overall : The Grumpy Bear Cafe is a great family friendly cafe, that has something for everyone, for me, I'll be heading back for more blueberry yogurt ice cream and yuzu sorbet after I chow down another Oven-baked Rendang Chicken!

Situated at a cosy corner at the 2nd level of Thomson Plaza. The service is enthusiastic and the food was ok. Their fish and chips was not bad. Fried with a very crusty batter and the fish flesh was smooth and good. Their chicken chops are tender and good. The disappointing one was their cajun chicken. There wasnt much cajun flavour, no spice, just more thyme and rosemary flavour overpowering the cajun spice. So you could skip that if you want something cajun. Nonetheless a very homely corner for a wuick bite.

Visited the bukit timah plaza outlet. Food was ok, for the price and quality there are a lot of other restaurants nearby where you would be better served. Gave it three stars cause it wasn't bad , not good either - just OK.The waffle looked ok and thus probably best to treat this as a coffeeshop with an extra menu for kids.Summary: good for the mommies to wait for their kids and have a cuppa or two , but don't see this as a place for lunch, suggest the owner trims down the menu to focus on his target audience.

Another Old Chang Kee..  "another" review missing...  Hmm...Anyways, since this Old Chang Kee is situated at Basement Level of Bishan Junction 8, it is always busy with long queues or lines.  But the lines tends to move up fast depending on the Staff.  No "sliding doors" to press, easy to pick up my snack whenever I am at this location of Old Chang Kee.YES another EMPIRE brewing all across town of Old Chang Kee.  Food Vendor, KIOSK and it is HALAL Certified by MUIS.  I like it when I can purchase one of my favorite snacks called Curry O Puff at (SG$1.60).  It comes out piping hot from the Fryer too.  For this I like!*  Squid CHECK*  Fried Carrot Cake CHECKThese are the items I can recall purchasing from this location.Their latest promotion was with Cheese in it.  Doable but I will stick with the Curry O Puff.  Maybe the next time, I will purchase the Potato Chips and see how it goes from there.  Latest visit was on Friday December 13th 2019.  Time was about 17:00hrs ish.

rest_name: Chomp Chomp Hai Wei Yuan Seafood BBQ
address: #01-01 Chomp Chomp Food Centre 20 Kensington Park Road, Serangoon Singapore 557269 Singapore
comment: There are at least three stalls that sells barbecue (BBQ) seafood in Chomp Chomp Food Centre. Of these, I have tried two of the BBQ seafood stalls. And out of these two stalls, there's one which I always prefer to order from. The stall is Chomp Chomp Hai Wei Yuan Seafood BBQ 忠忠海味园BBQ海鲜烧烤 (what a mouthful). I shall call it Hai Wei Yuan to keep it short.Hai Wei Yuan is easy to spot as its at the entrance of Chomp Chomp. In fact, it is located at the left most corner at the entrance and has a unit number #01-01. This stall is fairly popular and you can expect a waiting time of at least 30 minutes (even on a weekday evening). There are tables directly in front of this stall. However, my advice would be to sit elsewhere. This is because the BBQing of the sambal chilli can cause the air around this stall to be very uncomfortable. The seafood such as stingray, crayfish, lala clams, gong gong and cockles were displayed on a bed of ice. We ordered three dishes and two bowls of rice from Hai Wei Yuan . The three dishes were Sambal Kang Kong $8, Sambal Lala $8 and BBQ (Sambal) Stingray $12. The two bowls of rice cost $1. Payment is made only after the food is served. We waited  for around 40 minutes before our food was served (Food for thought: it was a Thursday night. Can't imagine what the waiting time would be if it was a weekend or Friday night).Although the Sambal Kang Kong $8 served on a piece of banana leaf had been highly raved about, I thought that it was average. I had eaten better ones elsewhere. The Kang Kong was well cooked and retained a nice crunchines. However, the dish as a whole was too spicy and was not tasty enough.The Sambal Lala $8 was served on a piece of banana leaf.We thought that the Sambal Lala Clams was unique. The lala clams were normal, but what stood out was the sauce. It had the right balance of spiciness, sweetness and saltiness (due to the lala clams). What made the sauce so unique was that it had this slight peanutish flavour that made it aromatic and addictive. Shiok! We were scrapping whatever sauce there was and adding it onto our rice.The BBQ Stingray $12 was also served on a piece of banana leaf.Needless to say, we always squeeze the lime to up the flavour by a notch or two. The BBQ Stingray was not bad. The sambal chilli spread was spicy and fragrant while the Stingray was tender, soft and more importantly fresh. However, a grouse which I had was that the stingray was too thin - not meaty considering the price. Having said that, credit must be given to the stall owner as he bothered to add slices of onions on top of the BBQ Stingray to enhance the flavour. I polished off the whole stingray (literally) including its skeleton (soft bone) which contains cartilage which is good for the joints.Overall, the food from Hai Wei Yuan was delish. Even though we had to wait so long for the food and the price seems to be on the higher end for a hawker centre, I would still be back. Reason being the prices at the other stalls are the same. In addition, I am a foodie, I am definitely coming back to Chomp Chomp for all the other yummy and sinful food.Detailed review: foodiefc.blogspot.sg/201…

The porridge and clay pot rice in this place are delicious. All their porridge is dried scallop based, which gives it a sea food-y umami test. Very traditional with peanuts and you tiao. The rice is also very full and thick, not the watery stuff you find in hawker centers. The clay pot rice is equally wholesome, with chestnuts, chinese sausages, mushrooms and whatever meat you ordered. The sauce gives it a smoky kick and it's wonderfully fragrant. One pot is generally sufficient for 2 or even 3 people, so don't over order!I would also recommend their fried pumpkin coated with egg custard, it's the same sauce used in salted egg yolk crab but you don't have to deal with crab shells so it's bite after bite of awesomeness. I had one bad experience with their service though, I asked for napkins (which considering that they're a restaurant and charges a premium on their food plus service charge and GST, is a reasonable ask), and they asked us to pay for a tissue packet. I was given paper napkins with no questions asked a previous visit, so it was kind of an annoyance when the waiter insisted that we pay for the a packet of tissue. It kind of irked us that a restaurant charging 13 bucks for a bowl of porridge can be this cheapskate, so -1 star for that. Nevertheless the food is pretty good so give it a try!

It's a legit place for rice porridge plus clean as whistle. I had the "premium" dried scallop porridge for their 3 to 6 pm happy hour at 50% off. It was flavorful and generous portions. I would try again if in area.

Stuff'D "EMPIRE" is growing and by now most Shopping Mall that I have been to, DEFINITELY has Stuff'D Counter/Kiosk.  Thankful its Dairy Free, Gluten Free and Vegan which Stuff'D offer variety for different Dietary needs.Stuff'D @ Junction 8.  You open your counter/kiosk on the same level entrance/exit to Bishan MRT Station Platform in which is indeed convenient to some.  This Stuff'D @ Junction 8 overtook the now defunct counter/kiosk/store of Twelve Cupcakes.Yes, I do agreed with what Charlotte L, who wrote about Chipotle.  Stuff'D some what has similarity with Chipotle.  Aww, NOW I am indeed missing Chipotle concept since Chipotle ORIGINATES from Denver, Colorado.Due to its convenient location, my Mother and I always have our TO GO order since its a TO GO Kiosk like so many other Stuff'D locations in town.  Every single time, I went here, there are always different staffs handling my food and the transactions etc.  Depending on the timing, especially during PEAK Period such as Lunch or approaching Dinner hours, there are ALWAYS a line or a queue.At times, the staffs are generous with the portion of Chicken Kebab or the Sauces, but at times the portions can be limited or the sauce they put in our TO GO orders can be skimpy.  *SIGH* My least favorite protein from Stuff'D is the Beef Corn Carne.  Our most favorite is the CHICKEN aka Spitted Chicken.  At times, some of the ingredients or toppings they offer, tend to get rancid or "spoilt" if NOT eaten immediately after purchasing.  Maybe I should highlight this to the management. Most of the time we opt to have the KEBABs compared to the DAILY Bowl orders.  I ever order the Burrito or Tacos from this location too.  For the Chicken Kebabs it was (SGD$5.30).From my observations, it seems that different Stuff'D location offer different kind of toppings etc.  Maybe next time I should take picture of the different toppings available at different Stuff'D location.  I like the different "sticker" they put in each meal, with words of wisdom or famous quotation by famous Author, Celebrities what nots.Nevertheless, we are thankful that this establishment or Stuff'D locations across Singapore, is Halal Certified by MUIS.  Once again it is a ALL CASH transaction, especially for this location.  Among other things, I am thankful they offer the Habanero Spicy Sauce which I missed eating from a Mexican burrito or Middle Eastern Kebabs etc.stuffed.com.sgStuff'D @ Bishan Junction 89 Bishan Place#B1-19A, Junction 8 Shopping CentreSingapore 579837
Service is bad and food is not hot enough... what a bad experience and it is rather expensive as well. Other stuff'd outlet is actually fine but please improve on this one.
stuff'D reminds me of Chipotle back in the States. It's a hearty, healthy meal and is perfect on the go. Happy to see this at Junction 8 since it's so near my place!

I came across this Halal Certified Bakery after passing it by, since I was in the Neighborhood.  From the conversation I had with one of the staffs, they are opened DAILY till 10pm.  My bad, I did not ask what time they open etc.Long story short, this is the 2nd outlet of this bakery which has the same name.  The 1st outlet was opened somewhere at Jurong West or something.  Anyways, they have lots of baked goods, from breads, cakes, swiss rolls, and pastries what nots.  Once again, my search continues for that Cream Bread, that I used to eat, growing up.This time around, I purchased the Bread, with Vanilla Cream sprinkled with Chocolate Rice ($1.40).  The Cream tends to be overly sweet aka too sweet for my liking.  *SIGH*Another purchase was a Coffee Cake ($1.10) with Vanilla Cream inside.  The texture of the Coffee Cake is like those Swiss Roll Cakes you can find.  It was so soft and delish to boot!  The Vanilla Cream was just nice.  I wonder if they used the different kind of Cream for different cakes as compared to the Bread.  Hmmm, maybe next time I should have ask the staff or something.At this bakery, I found out they make those Pandan Waffles, or perhaps other flavors too.  I should have ask again.  Oh well.  Nevertheless, I am glad that I can find yet another Halal Certified Bakery just 1 MRT Stop away from where I am living.I hope this Bakery can maintain their status for Halal Certification, since the Bakery just across the street where we lived, ever since the change of name and management, did not do so.  Furthermore, my Mother are much more particular about the Halal Certification etc.  NGT Confectionery, thank you for opening your 2nd Branch at Bishan.  Thank you for applying the Halal Certification for us, Muslim patrons, to purchase all the baked goods you make at your bakery without any doubt.  May return to NGT Confectionery when needed.  I would rather support a MOM and POP shop or bakery in this matter.  Eversince I am back, its seems all the CHAINs bakery that I have been to, was indeed such a disappointment.More MOM and POP bakery to explore next!

This hawker centre is actually quite the hole-in-the-wall hawker by standards of Maxwell, Hong Lim etc but it has its fanbase. From the Thomson estate areas to those visiting the nearby reservoirs, this place is quite the popular spot as can be seen on 1st Jan 2020 when I visited this place. The reason this place isn't as well known to the masses is.... the stalls are closed 3 or more days per week!But if you are lucky or familiar with the timings, you could be in for a real treat. Try the Jing Ji Fishball Noodles. Only $3 and they serve you liver, fish ball, minced meat, and more! Noodles is al dente. Uncle is a little slow though; he takes his time so queue can be half an hour or more!!Try the Teochew Minced meat noodles which has much lesser a crowd! The duck stall behind the fishball noodles stall is a stunner, with dark braised duck and sauce that makes this duck so succulent and savoury. Simple rules, follow the queue and you should be able to smell your way to delight.

To my understanding, Sembawang Teochew Minced Meat Noodle has a loose connection to the now Michelin-famous Tai Hwa Noodles but without the excessively long lines and hoopla. What you do get is a generous serving of minced pork, lean pork slices, pork balls, pig kidney, and wontons. The noodles have a nice texture and it's all brought together by a very vinegary sauce. I had the largest $6 portion that gets you more ingredients but the smaller portions will more than suffice. Do note it's not the fastest moving stall. It's a one-man show with the uncle meticulously making one bowl at a time so if people ahead of you order 6+ packets or call in orders, the wait can be deceptively long for the short line.

address: Balak 128 Ang Mo Kio Avenue 3 #01-1855 Singapore 560128 Singapore
comment: If you want good vegetarian version of local delicacies then this is where you go. Price is really affordable and portions are big, with plating on some dishes! So far I have had Nasi lemak, Fish soup, mee goreng, and Cereal prawn (abalone mushroom) and it has been a feast every time. The place is also nicely air conditioned with ample seating.

address: Blk 93 Toa Payoh Lor 4 #01-46 Singapore 310093 Singapore
comment: Do come before 11am to avoid disappointments as their dumplings and Shredded Chicken Horfun is sold out when I was there at 11.30 am!!I ordered their classic wanton mee and the sauce is flavourful and the noodles are QQ enough for me. The soup is very yummy and their wanton also very good. The pork filling is light yet flavourful to make every mouthful very fulfilling. The lady boss who takes your orders and delivers the food to you is also patient (even with many orders), polite and attempts to connect with her customers. She displayed top service quality that I feel some restaurants should send their wait staff go learn a thing or two from her!! Seriously!!!I ordered soup to tabao too and she would pack the soup separately and explain how to reheat to get the same quality food as if eating at the stall. This is just enough reason for me to return to this stall just to experience her awesome service. The food and soup quality just converted me to a loyal returning customer!!!!

address: #01-39 Kim Keat Palm Food Centre Singapore 310018 Singapore
comment: Decent herb turtle soup.  Like all Chinese herb dishes it is good for the health.  Very strong herb

Overshadowed by its neighbour Casuarina Prata, this is a hidden zichar which I'll come back again. Dishes was distinctly Hong Kong style. And the boss regales us with tales of how they started their business in Singapore. The dumpling soup was excellent. As was the champagne pork ribs and prawn paste chicken. The recommended lala bee hoon clay pot was also delicious. Special mention must be made of the drinks menu. At $2.50 per glass, the avocado milk, almond milk and HK honey lemon are super yummy. I'll definitely come back to try the dim sum next

This is one of those under-rated prata places that I often go to for my late night supper fixes. Located along Upper Serangoon Road, it is roughly a 10-15 minute walk from Serangoon MRT station. There is often a decent crowd at the stall late at night, which is testament to the quality of their prata.Their prata is crisp, yet stretchy, and not too oily. I like their curry which is not too strong on spices, yet very tasty and complements the prata very well. Their murtabak comes in huge portions. Mum and I ordered a $6 portion and had trouble finishing it up. It is packed full of meat and eggs and the prata dough is fried just right. However, the service here is sub-standard. Some of their service staff do not really understand english so you're probably better off pointing off the menu.

The food is basically a combination of Malay- South Indian flavors. It is not authentic Indian food. However, it is one of the few decent and inexpensive Indian places in North-East Singapore. I have eaten here a couple of times and felt pretty full and satisfied. Their Toor Dal and Palak Paneer are good. Prata is okay, could be less oily. Dosa is also okay but the sambar gravy is very watery and lacks flavor.I like to get hot milo from here. Pros:- Will satisfy your hunger- Open 24 hours/ late night food- Good portion of serving- Inexpensive food - Overall good flavors - 6-8 min walk from Serangoon MRTCons:- Not great service- Food quality okay (very oily)- Questionable hygiene- Crowd is weird at night (but is safe)

Did a quick stop for first breakfast before we left Singapore. The biryani (rice plus choose your meat topping) is good, I ate more than intended :). I also like the super crispy roti tissue with granulated sugar inside. Need to come back to try other stuff off their menu.

Indian Rojak go to place! I crave the sauce here: hot, nutty, not too sweet and perfect companion for the dough fritters. I never knew what they are called, but I recognise the colours and what it should have in it. They have such a variety and my favourite is the plain dough fritter. It is slightly fermented I suppose and it's crispy and not too oily. Fishcakes are a staple and if you have another stomach for prata or even briyani, JUST WHACK THEM. Along with teh tarik.

address: 45 Tai Thong Crescent Sennett Estate Singapore 347866 Singapore
comment: First fish head curry experience in Singapore! Lower level was already packed by the time I got here, but there's another level upstairs with additional seating.They have 2 options of fish for th curry: snapper and group.  Was opting for the grouper, but unfortunately they had already sold out.  Had to default to the snapper instead. They also have 2 portion sizes available for the grouper only.  Regular is SGD $30 and larger size is $32.  I got the regular and it was already plenty big.Curry consistency was good and not too watery.  Heat was also present but not too overwhelming.  Can definitely taste the tanginess from combination of tamarind, tomato, and pineapple within the curry itself.  The snapper itself was very tender and the meat soaked up the curry quite nicely. Appetizing as hell.Noticed that quite a few tables were also ordering crabs here as well.  May well be back for that next time.Minor service issue since I had to keep checking up for my water, but overall a good experience.

address: 45 Tai Thong Crescent Sennett Estate Singapore 347866 Singapore
comment: A friend brought me here for dinner today. Ample parking across the road at  a new commercial complex so it's no longer a nightmare to find street parking to eat at this row of shophouses. It's a casual family dining place with upstairs seating as well. Food wise it's signature dishes are the crab bee hoon, yam ring, kai lan and fried prawns. We decided on the lala bee hoon instead and opted for my daughter's fave shrimp paste chicken. Taste wise, the bee hoon was flavourful and a pretty large portion for 3-4 people. The yam ring was a tad disappointing as it was dry probably from being pre-cooked earlier. The kai lan and shrimp paste chicken were decent and tasty, so I'll order these again next time together with the lala bee hoon.

They have promos for everyday of the week! Monday is one for one chirashidon! You can WhatsApp them to pre order and pay with your PayLah! or paynow and collect it for lunch on Monday! They limit the 1 for 1 promotion to the first 50 bowls only!!! So hurry!

address: 301 Upper Thomson Rd #01-113 Thomson Plaza Singapore 574408 Singapore
comment: I am in love with their sizzling brown rice with quinoa bowl! It also comes with kale, peppers and mushrooms. It is really appetizing and would satisfy any non-vegetarians too. If there's one thing to improve on, maybe the stone bowl could have been heated less. It took me quite a fair bit of wait before I could really eat the rice without burning my tongue.The service at Thomson Plaza is excellent - I was shown to my seat and my water (infused with rosemary) was consistently refilled. The decor is subtle and tasteful.I'd love to be back!

address: 301 Upper Thomson Rd #01-113 Thomson Plaza Singapore 574408 Singapore
comment: After days of feasting, the family decided to have vegetarian meal. We decided to visit the restaurant which was located at the first floor of the shopping centre, at the far end between the food court and Japan Home. I was told over the phone that the restaurant was crowded tonight and was advised to pre-order the food. I was recommeded the restaurant's meat-free 8-course Abundance Menu featuring the "black diamond" - Truffles! The set meal costed $168.80++ for 4 people.The restaurant was quite modern in decoration and we were showed to a booth seat table.Menu 菜单Prosperity Black Truffle Yu Sheng 元素黑松露七彩捞生The yu sheng surprisingly strong of truffle oil when served. I would prefer the mock fish to be made like the real salmon, but the texture was quite like the real stuff. The salad was quite tangy and refreshing, without too sour.Tomato Bisque with Black Truffle in Bamboo Tube 竹筒番茄忌廉汤The soup was quite rich and tangy. Nice to have during the cold rainy day.Fa Cai Edamame Tofu with Mountain Yam 发菜豆腐拌铁棍山药I usually only have mountain yam in soup. It was the first time for me to have mountain yam in crunchy and crisp texture. Instead of the usual spinach tofu, the japanese soy bean was used in the making the bean curd which gave it a kind of sweet taste.Wild Bamboo Fungus with Asparagus 野生竹笙扒露笋I like the wild bamboo fungus here, which was like a sponge soaking up the various flavours.Fresh Fruits Satay Skewer 鲜果沙爹串The skewer had water chestnut, juicy pineapple, cherry tomatoes, green capsicum and beancurd skin, topped with tasty spicy peanut sauce. Felt that the fruits did not go well with the sauce.Wild Rice in Lotus Leaf 野米荷叶饭It looked rather plain with just the colorful corns and carrot cubes but it actually tasted not bad.Double-boiled Lemongrass with Peach Gum 香茅炖桃树胶银耳The dessert was served hot, with red date, white fungus and peach flavoured jelly in it. The soup had a lemongrass taste.Sparkling Honey Yuzu 柚子蜜特调It was a refreshing soda drink to have.Overall the food was delicious and quite unique too. Never thought of having truffles for yu sheng. That was a first time for me.

address: 301 Upper Thomson Rd #01-113 Thomson Plaza Singapore 574408 Singapore
comment: Been to both Elemen outlets several times.  Been to Thomson outlet at least once a month,  my last visit was on 11 Jan 2017. I find that the food quality is getting worse. At that dinner one of my guests and I ordered the same Burdock soup.  It seems they are running out of soup as ours is a waterdown version, only tasted soy sauce.  The rest of the food ordered tasted blend. Service is passable, though i wish the waiters were more attentive, the restaurant was not even half filled.I really hope the management pay more attention to the food and bring it to the same standard as Millenia Walk outlet where the quality and taste of food, same menu, is much more palatable.  It will be a shame to see it gone.

rest_name: Hiang Ji Roasted Meat Noodle House
comment: One of best roasted meat houses in Singapore!I ordered the meat set of duck and charsiu. The chee cheong fun is also quite tasty. This place is difficult to find if you are not familiar to Toa Payoh as it is located indoor at the food alley right out of Toa Payoh Mrt.

rest_name: Hiang Ji Roasted Meat Noodle House
comment: Tried the roast duck noodle ($5).Ok taste but the soup taste off.I had better duck noodles in Melbourne

We made our way to north Singapore on one of the weekends in 2020 (Nothing to do, can't travel out, so have to explore every part of the city!). It is very close to the Lower Pierce reservoir park, so its a nice place to hang out after/before visiting the park. They have pretty decent coffee, and nice cold pressed juice. We went late afternoon, post lunch, so didn't order any food. But the food menu looked interesting and we would definitely give it another try if we were in the area again.

address: 11 Sin Ming Rd #01-12, Thomson V Two Singapore 575629 Singapore
comment: These days the trends is fried ice-cream with lots of shops selling popping out. One of them is The Famous Ice-Cream Rolls Shop which is located at Thomson V. The outlet is small with a couple tables indoor and another couple of tables outdoor for dining in. Besides fried ice cream it also sells milkshakes, waffles, teas and cupcakes.The fried ice cream is priced from $4.20 onwards. Add 80 cents for mixed of 2 flavours. Choices of flavour includes Nutella, Milo, Ovomaltine, Oreo, and . It is served with Hershey Chocolate sauce and rainbow rice. There is also Fruit Delights version ($4.90) which has flavours such as strawberry, lychee and mango. Top up 50 cents each for toppings such as wafer sticks, M&M, and milo powder. I order a Kinder Bueno version which costs $4.20. The flavour is not strong and could taste the kinder bueno in it. The ice cream melts rather fast too.

Food Junction @ Bishan Junction 8, 4th Floor...On the right wing, of this Food Junction, aka Food Court you can find the Halal Certified section for your Muslim friends to have their Lunch or Dinner.From Japanese Cuisine, Chicken Rice, Hot Pot/Soups or Teppanyaki style of food you can choose from.  There are several options to choose from.Eversince I am back in Singapore, since I do not feel the "love" or maybe I am just being biased, I prefer this Food Court rather than the Fork and Spoon establishment located @ Toa Payoh Central near the HDB Hub.Thankfully my Mother does not mind having her meals here too.  From the Fitra Vendor - Chicken Rice + Rojak, to Japanese, Ayam Penyet from the Penyet King vendor, to Soups for Steamboat or Hotpot items, we had.  We dine in mostly for early Lunch, Lunch or LATE Lunch, we thoroughly enjoyed our meals here.  During the WEEKENDS, this Food Court will ALWAYS be packed to the brim, hence plan accordingly.The KEY to go anywhere in Singapore Food Court especially the ones which is air-conditioned, is to arrive early before the Lunch crowd or after the PEAK Lunch hour aka like from 14:00hrs ish onwards.  I cannot deny the pricing may be different as compared to Hawker Centre coz for one, most food courts they are definitely in a MALL, and its definitely in an Air-Conditioned Area.  This makes dining in, a little comfortable for those who prefer "indoors" aka air-conditioned environment.At Fitra Chicken Rice stall/vendor, your Roasted or Steamed Chicken Rice plate will set you like (SGD 4.50).  If you have a Passion Card, you can redeem a discount for your meal.The Japanese Cuisine Stall/Vendor starting from (SGD 7.50) etc.  Depending on what Menu you choose from this stall/vendor - some of the items are cooked to order aka when your order than they either fried or stir-fried, so it does that awhile for your food to be ready.From what we have had from this Food Junction location, in conclusion its 3.5 stars in our books.  We do not mind returning when needed - i.e these have been our regular spot for Lunch before heading downstairs at the Fairprice aka for our grocery shopping needs.

Siam Kitchen is where old world meets new, as the restaurant brings authentic dishes of ancient Siam to young diners with a discerning palate.  Let  bonafide chefs from Thailand, handpicked for their ability to whip up delicious home-styled Thai cuisine, thrill you with familiar favourites such as Tom Yum Goong, Green Curry and Siam Kitchen Butterfly BBQ Chicken.Those looking for a casual dining experience can also look forward to enjoying the colours and flavours of traditional Thai street food fare in a modern setting. For a quick meal, some popular dishes to check out include our Spicy Beef Noodle Soup with Beef Fillet, Thai Fried Rice Noodle with Seafood, and Black Olive Fried Rice with Chicken and Cashew Nuts.Get the Creative Eateries Privilege Card now which entitles you to earn CE$ on the post discounted amount for purchases of any food and beverage items at any participating Creative Eateries Restaurants.

Sawadee Krap! The only Thai dish I had tasted before stepping into Nex's Siam Kitchen was tom yam soup. Even then, I knew I was missing out. I'm a Siam Kitchen devotee now and won't settle for anything less when it comes to Thai cuisine. I love the calm atmosphere at Nex's Siam Kitchen. Staff members are quite affable and waiting time for food does not exceed 15 minutes during dinnertime. Siam Kitchen's widespread menu is also another element to be grateful for. Food, glorious food. The Clear Tom Yum Hor Fun is remarkably tasty, with ample veggies and a zesty broth that allows the thick noodles to swim happily in. Wash it down with a steamy bowl of authentic Tom Yam Seafood soup and super duper fresh coconut juice. Yummy. My favourite Siam Kitchen dish has got to be the Green Curry Paste Fried Rice with Chicken. This is a highly indulgent dish with flavourful green curry rice, topped with chunks of chicken and veggies. Their rich homemade sour plum juice completes the meal. Check out their menu here:siamkitchen.com.sg/conte…Affordable dishes and worth every penny. Highly recommended!
Disappointed as the Tom yum soups fish scale was not removed completely. The food as a whole was average. While We waited for the food the drink was slow coming. We had to ask for ice water.

address: 293 Lorong 6 Toa Payoh SAFRA Toa Payoh Singapore 319387 Singapore
comment: Ordered the grilled black pig set that comes with onsen egg. Please tell me if either of this is onsen egg? One is hard boiled and one is not even half boil and it's icy cold. Please don't fool customers with a nice photo on the menu if you don't know how to make one.Ordered chicken cutlet meal and only after all the food has been served to be told they don't have chicken cutlet today. Very disappointed with the standard of food and service level.

address: 293 Lorong 6 Toa Payoh SAFRA Toa Payoh Singapore 319387 Singapore
comment: The sashimi on the chirashi don wasn't super fresh (safe for consumption, but did not taste nice) , and the portion was quite stingy. Shoyu ramen was mediocre as well, with the ramen tasting very soft (almost like home made instant noodle level), although the portion of pork given was quite alright.Green tea was subpar for $1.70 a cup.Extremely pricey for the standard of food served. Would not visit again.

address: 293 Lorong 6 Toa Payoh SAFRA Toa Payoh Singapore 319387 Singapore
comment: The food is ok but I still prefers Ichiban Boshi/Sushi. Somehow, the taste and quality there is a tad worse and it's quite costly here too.

If I have a fast food craving, it will almost always be Mos burger's fish burger. Even though I have been acquainted with McDonald's fillet o fish for a longer time, Mos burger's fish burger is by far the best fast food burger I've ever tasted.The reason is simple: its rendition is perfect. The patty is soft, sweet and the grains very fine, the fish is springy and fried to perfection, and the (japanese) mayo is rich, smooth and so very delicious. Put together, this is a winning combination. I'm also a huge fan of the fried garlic and lemon mussels, and find myself always craving more after having the smallest portion (of 5). The iced milk tea also complements the meal perfectly, and the milky taste makes me feel extremely satisfied.I especially like this branch because the seating area is big, and I don't usually have problems looking for seats in this outlet unlike many others.
