Service is also quick and I like the fact that the food is brought to my table, although the wait can sometimes be pretty painful (reason being the food is only prepared upon ordering, spare perhaps the fries). And you wonder why they say good things are worth waiting for.

address: 450 Lor 6 Toa Payoh #01-10 Hersing Centre Singapore 319394 Singapore
comment: Nice place to have your wanton noodle fix. Very cold air conditioning. Was a bit disappointed that the noodles don't come with a bowl of soup.

address: 450 Lor 6 Toa Payoh #01-10 Hersing Centre Singapore 319394 Singapore
comment: Visited here due to the hype of a Michelin star rated chicken rice, but honestly it doesnt live up to the buzz. I've had comparable if not better chicken rice in hawker stands and mall food courts.I tried every single dish that was offered on the menu and nothing particularly stood out to me, seemed average/above average at best.  My initial thoughts is that the actual OG hawker stands might be better, but end of the day, I wouldn't think it's worth the crazy wait. Fortunately,  the wait at this location was relatively short (5-10 mins). I personally wont be back as I'd rather get cheaper and better options at other more available options.

address: 450 Lor 6 Toa Payoh #01-10 Hersing Centre Singapore 319394 Singapore
comment: It was a bit of a hype when the dude got the award a few years back in his modest stall.. I tried it then and as I try his chain... my mind hasn't changed... it's not what I'd say master class.. it's good but michelin Star? NOOOOOOO WAY!!! Noodles great and aldente but that's just technique! Soya chicken??? Hmmmm no different from anywhere else and the crispy pork. NOT crispy!!

address: 450 Lor 6 Toa Payoh #01-10 Hersing Centre Singapore 319394 Singapore
comment: The original Hong Kong Soya Sauce Chicken Rice and Noodles in Chinatown is a one-star Michelin award winner, and recently, they have expanded to open a few brick-and-mortar locations, where you can enjoy the same menu.  Liao Fan Hawker Chan is one of these, and while the prices are a bit higher (although still quite cheap), these locations come with the added benefits of AC and a modern ordering process, e.g. pager.  I have had a chance to try a few combinations here:- Chicken and rice- Char siew and hor fun- Roasted pork and noodlesI would have to say that the standouts were the char siew and noodles.  The chicken was scrawny and bony and honestly, I couldn't get enough of a mouthful to really get a taste.  The char siew on the other hand was a bit more substantial and quite moist and flavorful.  The roasted pork was good, but perhaps a bit dry.  As for the starch, the rice was really not my type. It's prepared in an HK way which means plain steamed rice that is topped with some sauce.  But the rice was very wet and not flavorful at all.  The hor fun was also very wet and not flavorful.  The noodles, however, were quite good - good texture, flavorful and soaked up the sauce well.  Overall, it's nice to have a location of Hong Kong Soya Chicken in Toa Payoh, which will spare me a trek down to Chinatown.  But as for their signature chicken rice, it's not my cup of tea.

address: 450 Lor 6 Toa Payoh #01-10 Hersing Centre Singapore 319394 Singapore
comment: Wonderful spot that is not pretentious and delicious soy chicken. One downside is the limited drinks menu but the quality of food for the price makes this worth the trip out.

I'm posting it on behalf of KFC delivery, idk which outlet they sent my food from but since I stay nearby Thomson plaza so I'm guessing it's the one at there. Anyway, as usual I have never had high expectation on any fast food joint, let alone KFC, although it's much better than McD. So my craving for fried chicken came out of nowhere when I was home and decided to try KFC's delivery service. Ordered chicken nuggets, original rice bucket and popcorn chicken. For a fast food chain, seems like they're doing their job in an above average manner. I'm very impressed about several things:1. They separate their mushroom sauce for the rice bucket to prevent it being soggy on the way so when it finally reached home, I was like MAN they know about all these basic things and 4 thumbs up for this. Also, seems like they gave more chickens for take-away. The rice to chicken ratio is perfect too!2. Actual delivery time is actually much faster than estimated time (like 15 mins faster and hell yea it matters to a starving woman).3. I ordered chicken nuggets for the first time from KFC and they taste DOPE! Like really! So fresh, tasted like real minced chicken breasts and free chipotle bbq dipping sauce! I must say $3.5 delivery cost is totally worth it! Although they do have $12 amount as minimum order charge which is understandable. They also have weekdays promo, and I opted for the $6 for 2 portions of popcorn chicken which is only valid on mondays! Really made my day!

Oohh KFC Bishan Junction 8...Okies, here are my observation for this Location...First you have to order at the Front Counter.  Then once you make your payment proceed to the Pick Up Counter situated inside..  What's the big deal, right?  Well maybe its how this KFC is situated or located in terms of "counter space" or design layout.Oh well.  Anyways, decide to have a very late lunch here before running errands.  Ordered the meal set Golden Spice Chicken Deal ($7.95) or something.  This order comes with a drumstick, chicken tender, mashed potatoes with gravy, and a cup of Juice of somekind.  It was utterly disappointing.  My bad.  First all the chicken is cold to the touch.  NOT even warm.  Then the chicken tenders some are dry..  Maybe I am NOT used to this Golden Spice flavor at all.  The Chicken Tenders were just meh.  Flavor wise of the Golden Spice are SO uninspired and weird in a very bad way.  Please KFC, DO NOT spoilt my fond memories of you.. but for this you DID in a HUGE disappointing way.NEXT, I think either all the patrons are SO LAZY, reflect on you people.. Once you had your MEAL please clear your freaking tray!  Duh, NOT to expect the staffs to clean up etc...  *SIGH*Perhaps, its an ISOLATED incident.  Poor thing, the ONE and ONLY staff who has to clean all the messed done by the other patrons.  Maybe I will go to another location which most of the time ENDED up in a Freaking Mall, perhaps my review might differ.Ooh KFC in general, I think I will stick to the SPICY Chicken that you offer in your Main Menu.  OR Stick to the items I know you can shine well in my books.  My apologies for this rant, hence this 2 STARS Review.CHECK #  : 5303November 29th 2018 14:25hrsKentucky Fried Chicken (KFC) Junction 8Store # : 5519 Bishan Place#01-21 Junction 8 Shopping CentreSingapore, 579837Tel : 6353 6360

address: 408 Ang Mo Kio Ave 10 #01-783 Singapore 560408 Singapore
comment: Made an order through online website pastamaniadelivery.sg about 30 minutes before the outlet opened for business. It was smooth and easy. There was a $3.50 delivery charge. Order was received less than 30 minutes later. It was in pizza like box which I was quite surprised. Pasto Box B ($16.80)Salted Egg Chicken Pasta,Hot & Spicy Crispy Chicken,Brownie with Hazelnut Sauce,CokePastaThe sauce was packed separated from the pasta in a microwaveable container. The package also came with a packet of tissue, cutlery , and condiments. The pasta was rich and creamy. The juicy cubes of tomato helped to prevent the dish to become too jelat.

This is almost a cult. In spite of limited parking, people come from far away to eat or for takeaways (do call and order in advance). Kampong chicken tends to be leaner, and the one here has attractive-looking yellow skin. Otherwise, it tastes the same as the chicken at Five Star Kampong Chicken at River Valley (which is better organised). The chilli and ginger sauces are super yummy, and the chicken liver perfectly cooked. The chicken rice is not oily, but would gain from being more fragrant.

Chicken house is one of the few chicken rice places in Singapore to sell chicken dishes using kampong chicken. What is kampong chicken, one might ask? Kampong chicken is the western equivalent of free range chickens. The belief is that compared to cage chickens, kampong chickens have more tender meat due to being able to run around freely. During my meal at Chicken house, I felt that it was pretty much true. Add to that, I find that the drumsticks were slightly bigger than the usual ones one finds in SIngapore. I found the chicken rice and chili sauce so-so, nothing special. I guess the novelty lies in having kampong chicken for a change. The price came up to $13 for half a chicken and a few extra portions of rice.Regarding parking, they have a small sized carpark in front of the restaurant but places are limited and one might have to even park at Thomson plaza and walk over.

I swear by this chicken rice, it is my comfort food in time of peril. It used to be a bus ride away from my house, and my dad always ordered take-away from this place. Unlike your normal white skinned soya sauce chicken, this chicken does not come with that sauce - this chicken is tougher, but not any one bit less silky. Order the chicken liver with it - it is moist but has a really nice pasty texture to it. The ginger and chilli sauce are all very ordinary though. But that said, it does not make this chicken rice set any less awesome. Do also try their fried tofu squares (with some kind of egg middle interior) which comes with sweet and sour sauce - excellent.

Just discovered this little stall stashed in a canteen building in an industrial flatted factory building. The first clue that this would be good - a long queue of people. So I came back another day to try it. The second clue - I ordered the chicken liver and the uncle told me "No lah today not fresh" and refused to sell me the liver. So I switched to gizzard instead. The third clue that this place is worthy of seeking out: The soup had carrots, old cucumber and goji berries. And when I tried a spoonful, there was the distinct fragrance of dang gui that had been added to the broth. The soya sauce chicken was silky and well marinated. And I love the umami in the sauce drizzled over it. The chilli is also worth a mention: hot but rounded out gently with garlic and vinegar, gently spicy without the harsh bite of some chilli sauces at other stalls. All for the princely sum of $4.50. Will definitely be back to try the duck and white chicken next.

address: 49A Serangoon Garden Way Stall 12, Serangoon Garden Market Singapore 555945 Singapore
comment: I have only tried the pot-stickers (guo-tie) and they are flavorful and juicy. Be careful of the broth seeping out as you bite it.Everything is handmade at the stall and u can see them kneading the flour and shaping the dumplings.$6 for 10 dumplings. Add $0.30 for takeaway box.

address: 49A Serangoon Garden Way Stall 12, Serangoon Garden Market Singapore 555945 Singapore
comment: Fong Kee is famous for their Pan Fried Dumpling (Guo Tie). The dumplings are filled with minced meat and chives and it is nicely pan fried. Every mouthful you take, the sauce will ooze out. It is very tasty, meaty and flavorful. It goes very well with the vinegar, shredded ginger and chili. You can't stop when you pop it in your mouth. The store do sell other simple handmade dishes like steamed dumplings, dough skin soup, zha jiang noodles and fried nan giao (rice cakes).  Limited items but very delicious dishes. They also have other branch at People Park's

This is a new cafe that opened near my home and we ordered:Basil Chicken Rice with Egg - they have a spicy and non-spicy version and we opted for a non-spicy as my girl is not sure if she can handle the spice level here. She loved it! I had a mouthful and it's actually pretty good. Good flavours without being overly salty. Tom Yum Soup with Tanghoon - I'm happy that its not the instant Tom Yum sauce version. The soup is slightly creamy and tasty. The ingredients is about 3 slices of fish and 3 medium sized prawns. I will order this again. Chicken Chop Rice Set - my girl insisted that I try her Rice and chicken Chop although I told her, deep-fried chicken Chop taste the same anywhere. Which it was, it's ok nice. We'll come back for the Basil Chicken and Tom Yum for sure!

I used to think all food courts are the same. But not anymore, this one is indeed a tad more special that the generic ones. There are quite a few stall that serve above ave food and on the side, there are also food specialities cafe that you can buy a dish or two to supplement your mains bought at the food court stalls. LIKE! Let me tell you more about the stalls I LIKE:1) Zhen Zi Prawn Noodle - I really find their Chilli tasty and the ingredients fresh. Prawns are decent in size and fresh. The pork ribs are quite fatty tho but I figured folks like my dad will love it. This is my usual go-to when I'm at this food court. 2) Vegetarian@TP - it's a struggle to choose between this and my prawn noodle as I find their vege dishes done so tastily! All without enhancements from meat!!! Incredible.  3) Dupur Penyet - the niceness of the Penyet is solely based on the crispy-ness and its good...

For now its OK.... I went here with my Mum... the Food Court is very packed with other patrons during peak LUNCH hours...  Once again, my favorite vendor is long gone.  There are many more food vendors but with the recent visit, it was a Malay stall that offer Nasi Lemak, Mee Rebus and other food options.Yet another AIR-CONDITIONED Food Courts in Singapore.This is based ONLY on 1 visit, because my Mum prefers the other food  court/vendors a few blocks away rather than this location.  Its situated at the basement, near to the HDB Hub Toa Payoh location and Toa Payoh Bus & MRT Station.Its very convenient but it way more over-crowded compared to Fork & Spoon.  In addition to this, only 1 or 2 vendors are HALAL certified.

I tried the desserts at Toa Payoh Hub's food court and it's not too bad.. I quite like their mango sago which comes with a scoop of vanilla ice cream and a little mint leaf. Their Western food is also not too bad.. quite value for money if you are around the area.. and the rojak is supposedly very famous.. just that it puts me off because of the insanely long queue everytime I am there.. it's insane. Other than that, it's quite a nice place to go to for a meal.. cheap and affordable eats if you are around the area.

address: 486 Lorong 6 Toa Payoh #01-01A OrangeTee Building Singapore 319396 Singapore
comment: Sorry to leave a poor review but...Food:My main came with a soup and it's minestrone today. I can accept can soup but when the can soup doesn't taste nice, I think it's quite epic fail! My girl even told me to not finish the soup!I had their monthly special with was a sirloin was brown sauce. The cut of meat is so-so but I understand as its promo. The vegetables were very hard and felt like they were blanched for only 30 seconds. Kid's Meals:One had fish and chips and the other had chicken chop with spaghetti. Both was ok only. There were 2 good things. Their ice cream as it's a partnership with Udders so the quality is there. The other good thing is their service staff. Mainly aunties who ran the front of house but they were polite and warm. Not your high class venues but for me, sincerity wins many factors. Daughter said to me, "we don't have to eat here again lah." I agreed.

4.5/5. Yum, housemade fresh ramen! With no MSG or concentrate, even better! All in all I'd return :) There are so many ramen places out here in SG and I am on the hunt to find the ones I enjoy the most. This one was quite tasty and the fact that they do not use MSG or concentrate is a huge bonus! Also, that they make their noodles fresh, another bonus! The noodles were a good consistency and chew. The broth was spot on in my opinion. So many restaurants put way way too much salt in foods now a day. The pricing seems to be normal with other SG food and ramen. Lots of broth and choices which is nice. They're know for their pork broth. But I always try the standard when I try new ramen restaurant to compare across the board from place to place. Service was decent. Overall, I would return, the facts of no msg and fresh noodles and flavorful broth is hard to beat since it seems few and far between in SG! :DTip: Free upsize of noodles; for those who are extra hungry :) Tip2: During certain times they have meal sets which seem to be the way to go if you're available at those times. I didn't know about it, but you can definitely get more variety going with the sets.

I didn't know there is a whole japanese dining concept down in B2 of this big mall. Men Ichi is a ramen joint. Their ramen is the thick pork bone version which is my favorite. The noodles is chewy and al dente. I was also thrilled to find that they serve tsukemen (the dry version of ramen). The broth of the tsukemen is very thick, very savoury, very rich...and possible clogging my arteries as I dip my ramen in it. Love it. It is also a tad salty as it is meant for dipping, not drinking. A good alternative since my favorite tuskemen is in a little ramen store in some streets of Kyoto and not exactly accessible.They also handmade their gyoza. The skin is thin which is great, but the filling is chicken, which to me, can never match how a great pork filling can taste.
Really really really bad foodTheir recipe is mix boiled pastas with ready canned sauce. Cheesy crumble fries are floating in oil. Arrabiata had no chillies! Really bad chicken wings too. Total waste

PastaMania is to pasta what McDonald's is to burgers. Or what Sakae Sushi is to sushi. It's fast, affordable, and fuss-free.That doesn't mean the pasta is bad. In fact I think it's pretty good! And if you're not that big on the whole quest for the perfect pasta, then it's actually a relief to be able to find pasta under S$10 when most restaurants ask for at least S$20.I like how they let you choose between four types of pasta, but I always go for the linguine. Some of my favourites include al funghi, aglio olio, and arrabiata.The ambience is ok, nothing too fancy. But your clothes might smell if you stay for too long.

address: Blk 127 Toa Payoh Lor 1 #02-02 Singapore 310127 Singapore
comment: Honestly, THESE ARE THE CUTEST PAUS EVER! They are so tiny, and yet so filling because of the way they are handcrafted. The pau's skin is so fluffy and soft despite being so thinly molded at some parts of the pau. And the fillings are so substantial that they literally fill you up! The char siew paus are nicely filled with yummy pork meat that's nicely marinated. But the definite must try is their "kong bak pau" - marinated pork belly meat in a smooth bun. These are tiny too, like their chair siew pau counterparts. But unlike the normal kong bak paus, instead of a huge slab of meat, the meat in this bun is nicely shredded yet retaining that moist, flavorful fat. Definitely will head back for these mini pop-in-your-mouth pieces of joy! Less flour, more meat, and yet oh-so-fluffy.

address: Blk 127 Toa Payoh Lor 1 #02-02 Singapore 310127 Singapore
comment: I think I am beginning to like all the traditional old school handmade local food stuff now that it is so hard to find them around. Most of the food we get now are often factory made or from a central kitchen. So it is such a treat to be able to savor food which is made the traditional painstaking way. I first tried the char siew bao a few years ago when my colleague gave me one to try. It was tiny but packed with lip-smacking delicious char siew filling. It was not very fatty and had the right ratio of bun and meat. It was 50 cents then. The price has gone up to 60 cents for the bao (small) and $1.20 for the big bao. Some may feel that it is expensive for something which can be devoured in one mouthful or two bites but I think it is quite alright for something which is handmade and tastes so good. The big bao (pork) is not very big compared to other places but I think the size is just nice for a snack or light meal. The meat inside is juicy and the sauce coats the interior of the bao perfectly so you do not get the feeling of dryness at all. Beware the small bao as you may just keep popping them into your mouth as they are just so good. It is definitely better when served fresh off the steamer.

address: Blk 127 Toa Payoh Lor 1 #02-02 Singapore 310127 Singapore
comment: It's really hard to find places selling kong ba pau (fat belly bun). Apart from this shop and restaurants, the only way to get your hands to these buns is to cook them at home. As for the taste, the pork belly isn't too greasy! That's why i love it !

address: Blk 127 Toa Payoh Lor 1 #02-02 Singapore 310127 Singapore
comment: another fine example of gourmet craftsmanship.my favourite is their mini kong bak bao.delicate bun with delicious filling.one is never enough!two is a teaser.three is a treat.four is forgivable.five is fate.six is sumptuous.seven is surfeiting.eight is enough.as nine is numbing.and ten is time to diet again!

address: Blk 127 Toa Payoh Lor 1 #02-02 Singapore 310127 Singapore
comment: The pao here are tiny and yummy!The skin is very thin, soft and fluffy. the ingredients are packed to the brim.The tao sar is also not too sweet.These little pao are just nice to pop continuously without realizing that you have way over-eaten.

address: Blk 127 Toa Payoh Lor 1 #02-02 Singapore 310127 Singapore
comment: If size does matters then Teochew Handmade Pau is certainly different. Their paus are tiny. Tiny red bean paus, chicken paus, char siew paus and even kong bak paus. Even their siew mais are tiny. And as the their name states, they are all handmade and started by Mr Yeoh who is Teochew. They also sell fan choy (glutinous char siew rice) and lor mai kai (glutinous chicken rice), which fortunately arent tiny. Prices may feel a little steep, after all for the same 60 cents, you can get a much bigger pau elsewhere. But the novelty and the fact that the paus are actually very yummy makes up for it. Their siew mais are particular yummy because instead of prawns they use fish and instead of crab roe they use carrots. A lot healthier than a standard siew mai but just as tasty.Business is brisk especially the more popular items like the kong bak paus and the lotus paste paus. You can actually call in to pre-order to avoid disappointment.  I've always been proud to be a teochew because teochews are famous for many local food like fried carrot cake, fried kway teow, kway chap, teochew porridge, etc. Although pau isnt exactly exclusively a teochew specialty, it is still a prime example of good teochew made food here in Singapore.Their opening hours are Tuesday to Saturday - 6:00am to 2:00pm and Sunday - 6:00am to 12:00pm.

address: Blk 127 Toa Payoh Lor 1 #02-02 Singapore 310127 Singapore
comment: Appearance wise, their mini pau is certainly very cute!! Taste wise, it's only ok leh. I tried their chicken pau and its only normal nice. Their mini char Siew pau is certainly nicer for the eyes than for the tongue.

address: 226B Ang Mo Kio Street 22 #01-645 Singapore 568226 Singapore
comment: We ordered the fish head steamboat, salted egg york pork ribs and braised tofu.Braised tofu came out of kitchen almost immediately when we sat down, less than 5 minutes from ordering. It completely didn't look like braised tofu. It didn't have the usual clay pot and roast pork. When we asked them if they served the wrong dish, the waiter who is one of the lead management staff at the outlet, replied rudely that "you go and speak to the chef yourself". We went to the chef, and the chef shouted back rudely. Our request to refund or exchange to other dishes was rejected. Very bad service, making it a terrible place for family and friends' gathering. The lousy first dish spoils our appetite for sibsequent dishes. We are still wondering to date if they served us a left over braised tofu dish.

Korean tapas? When I first heard about this place I was skeptical, but it's really pretty good. There's some element of fusion cuisine but you can also get normal korean food.The "tapas" are certainly not tapas sized, being more like appetisers.The sweet corn fritters were great. They were of an appropriate size, and didn't taste too much of corn (the corn flavour is actually quite mild). There was also a vague fruit flavour hovering on the edge of my palate.The grilled pork belly salad was simply dressed and came with a generous serving of pork belly, which was excellently char grilled (with plenty of that char grilled edge). I didn't really taste the Yuzu flavour though.The seafood pancake was alright. A little chewy (it could be thinner) and the ingredients weren't well integrated into the batter, but it was still tasty.The value set meal (3-10pm daily) was great value - appetiser (kimchi or pickles), 3 skewers, rice or ramyun ($4 more) and a drink for $10.90. The kimchi was above average. The skewers were all really tasty - they grill really well here.The chewy korean pancake with lotsa things was really nice. Even if the black sesame chantilly was just black sesame paste (it was far from the consistency of whipped cream). The mixture of chewy and crispy pancake, vanilla ice cream, nuts, cinnamon, black sesame and red bean went really well together.

There is a strong effort to create a Korean ambience; TV screens showing Korean MTVs or dramas and Korean songs in the background, but the savoury tapas could be further tweaked to showcased a more distinctive Korean personality.Of the more substantial plates, the Chicken Paella that arrived hot in a large pan was much better. The grains were beautifully cooked; moist but not too clumpy and flavours were as rich and piquant as the colour imparted from tomato and kimchi.All's not lost with the adventurous desserts here. I truly enjoyed the Misugaru lava cake ($8.90++), a nice Korean interpretation of the western lava cake by using Misugaru, a traditional Korean multi-grain powder most likely very new to most Singaporeans. Warm, earthy with a subtle malt fragrance, this was more outstanding and unique than its other matcha lava flavour. Crunchy and chewy, the Hotteok($8.90++), humble korean street pancakes are elevated inordinately with just the right amount of smooth piping hot red bean and peanuts. Savour them when they are fresh and hot with the ice cream.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore

comment: no pok! no pok!!!!!! no pok at all!!!!! nasi babi? no pok!!! pok curry? i tell you we no pok!!!!

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Can always count on this place as it's open 24/7, so whether you are here for breakfast or fancy a late supper, RK is a good option. The food comes pretty quick after order and the curry provided with the prata is substantial. My favorite would be the onion prata as I find the plain prata to be rather hard and tough to pull apart. I like that the maggi mee goreng comes with fried chicken too.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Reasonably priced Indian / fusion food. Just take a seat and ask for a menu. It can get pretty noisy here and I found myself having a shout a little, but that's because this place is popular! They are open 24/7 so you know they're always here for you.Pictured from left to right: egg and onion prata, chicken murtabak, butter chicken, iced milo and lychee bandung. The whole meal cost 20.15 SGD which is a pretty good price for 2 people! I definitely recommend all of the above. The menu is really comprehensive so I'll definitely be back to try the other things on the menu!

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: The indian food served here is decent. However u need to ask specifically how much does the food cost because they might upsell you. My conversation with the staff:Me: 'i want maggie goreng'Him: 'chicken or mutton'Me: 'chicken'Him: 'Fried chicken or chicken?'Me: 'Fried chicken? Wow.'Him: 'ok'Me: 'how much for fried chicken?'Him: '$7 something'Me: 'normal chicken?'Him: '$5 something'I ended up eating the pratas. My colleague ordered tissue prata & it came in a ridiculous size & shape. The doughs are far too oily, which leave me bloated the entire day. :( I said the food is decent because it taste ok. will not return so soon.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Consistent food and drinks. One of my favorite prata shop to satisfy the prata and Maggie goreng cravings.I have been visiting RK House for years. Sometimes visiting them 3-4 times a week or even more!! It is opened 24 hours a day, I have visited them for breakfast, lunch, dinner and supper. Teh Tarik, Maggie Goreng and any prata options never fail to disappoint. They do have a wide variety of options, tried a couple previously and they weren't as good.RK house is also famed for its insanely huge Milo Tower, Bandung Tower and Teh Tower. These towers are usually spotted in club serving beer, as it is a halal establishment, they used them to serve local beverages instead. Great for large group!! Reason why I minus one star is for their sneaky habit of adding/upgrading your food to more expensive versions. For example when I ordered maggie goreng. The guy would ask if I would like chicken or mutton. You have to explicitly state that you want them plain. Adding the mutton/chicken usually cost $3-5, the portions are pathetic and they are often not tasty! Beware of this sneaky habit. Despite this naughty habit, we still love RK house very much.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: R K Eating House will satisfy your prata cravings 24x7 (literally). Their rendition of prata is flaky, crispy, and satisfyingly greasy (I don't find it too greasy like some of the other reviewers). Pair it with some curry, either with or without meat, and you have a great meal. I haven't had any of the other dishes here, but their biryani looks quite tempting (and is the Hyderabadi dum biryani style, if you're picky about what biryani you eat). Be aware that you have to specify exactly what you want (if you want curry without meat for dipping, be explicit) because otherwise you will receive the upcharged version of everything. We paid about $13 for four prata pieces, mutton curry, and bone-in chicken curry, which was quite filling as a brunch meal for two people.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Indian Roti prata stall located in a busy neighbourhood area. Always pretty crowded around here with lots of food fanfare. Food is good and prices are pretty affordable except for sneaky staff trying to upsell their food umpteen times.Staff are dishonest & sneaky. They would ask you what kind of curry you would want with your roti prata, and when i said chicken curry, they would serve me a whole chicken with curry! Literally!I went a second time again and they tried to do it again. You have to tell them VERY literally. Just curry sauce, no meat!Service is slow and below average, so is their sanitary practices it seems. My utensils have food stains and i felt compelled to take them into the washroom for cleaning.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: 24-hour joint. Great place to hang out with friends. Better at night since there is no air-con.One of the few prata places where you ask for less sugar in your teh tarik, it really comes less sweet.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: This place is like an institution in the Serangoon Gardens area. It has been around for decades and is a favorite spot for late night supper. It has the usual prata, briyani, Indian rojak, fried noodles, teh etc. I love the kosong prata which is squarish and is slightly crispy around the edges. The egg and onion prata is also good but it is softer and not that crispy so just order kosong (plain) if you prefer the crunch. The not so good thing is they do a bit of mis-representation. They will ask if you would like chicken or mutton curry to go with the prata. This is actually an additional order and is not an option for the complimentary curry which usually comes with prata. So just say you want the usual curry if you do not wish to have mutton or chicken curry. The usual curry has a bit of assam which I like as the tangy taste kinda refreshes the taste buds. The indian rojak is also very good with moreish peanut sauce which is not too spicy. The bee hoon goreng comes with bits of mutton and is yummy with hints of charred bits. Teh tarik is nicely pulled and is not too sweet. Since this is open 24 hours, you can literally have all your meals here.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: You sure clean up good, RK. After the recent reno works, you look pretty fresh, and it's not like the previous look turned me off... it's more that I actually want to sit inside now, instead of always camping out at the alfresco seats, hoping for more ventilation.The food's just as good as before - there's the tandoor selection with delicious naan, or your staple myriad of pratas, and then there's the indan rojak... I'm a littl biased - I love the stuff at Suriya, which isn't too far away, but this place has a pretty good variety of offerings too, and since they are pretty busy, you know the food's fresh.It's a great place to come to for a late night snack, or if you've got Chomp Chomp fatigue.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: The good:  If you happen to get the right staff/server, you are in for a treat.  I've managed to figure out who does what well here, and it totally matters.  When done right, I can get a spicy mee goreng (with gravy, a must) and iced teh tarik for less than it would cost for a 6' Subway sub.  That's what Charlie Sheen refers to as winning.  They also have a prata that continually puts neighboring prata stalls out of business.  They must be doing something right, right?    The bad:  If you get the wrong staff/server, you are in for a terrible treat.  I've had orders mixed up, been overcharged and witnessed some questionable sanitary practices.  You have to be stern and direct with what you want and how you want it, or they will do it the way they feel like, which usually means costing you.  The ugly:  I've grown to enjoy the "what will happen this time" element, so all and all I'm a fan.  I have equally as many, and now humorous, stories as I've had tasty meals.  It really just depends.  Normally such an establishment would receive 2 or even 1 star from me, but there is always a handful of staff that dig deep and deliver.  Plus they make me laugh, either intentionally with a joke or facial expression or by doing something so ridiculous you can't help but laugh it off.  Stick to the basics, take note of who does what well and you'll be happily content.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Good staff and good food, best prata ever. The maggi goreng and kway teow goreng is really good and the mutton soup too!

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: I absolutely LOVE this place. Right across the street from Chomp Chomp, I would find myself coming here in the morning for roti prata. This place has the BEST prata in SG, hands down. Since returning to the US, I have NOT been able to find anything like it.This place gained fame after the "NO POK, NO POK, I CALL THE POLICE, I TELL YOU!" prank that two ah bengs played on the owner [see the picture on my profile]. The people here are nice, and the food is prepared very well. It goes without saying that this is a Muslim-oriented joint, so there won't be any pork on the premises - - don't be a wanker and go there asking for it.The Malay dishes are bomb, but I will typically eat no less than two prata kosong with curry in one sitting. I've also had the rojak, and I wasn't wild about it, but it looked very pretty. It's definitely an acquired taste, so maybe I've been away from SG for way too long, as I just can't really enjoy rojak or mee rebus any longer.People might argue with me that there is better prata in SG, but I SERIOUSLY disagree. The prata here are made of magic.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: RK House is a eating place in Serangoon gardens. While it has been popular for it's traditional Malay dishes such as mee goreng, nasi goreng, etc. It became even more popular after someone recorded a prank about requesting for pork dishes in RK house with the angry stall holder threatening to call the police. After gaming at a LAN shop nearby, my friends and I dropped by RK house for supper. Surprisingly at 4am, they still had a full menu instead of a reduced menu most restaurants would do during wee hours. I ordered a favorite of mine: nasi goreng ikan bilis (fried rice with anchovies) and a cup of iced milo. The dishes came fast and it was cheap ($3.50). The nasi goreng tasted up to standard and I enjoyed having it. My friends who ordered prata and mee goreng had a decent meal as well. Just remember: Do not ask for non-halal dishes. I'm sure the waiters have put up with enough of such jokes over the years already.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: This 24-hour restaurant with the yellow and green signboard has a great location at the Serangoon Gardens Circus. Anytime of the day that you're craving some prata, this is the place you can stop by. I used to frequent the prata places along Yio Chu Kang Road, but R K has a better parking situation and is just more convenient for me. Simple kosong pratas, or something fancier like Mushroom Cheese pratas, it's decent here and priced about the same as most places.

address: 1 Kensington Park Rd Serangoon Garden Estate Singapore 557253 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: A solid prata house, if you are in the area. The pratas here are fluffier than the normal, giving a false notion of them not being too oily (which I'm not complaining about...) If you get the plaster pratas (prata with a sunny side up), remember to tell them that you don't want the yolk overcooked. The mutton curry was super oily but tasty as well. Definitely a great place to curb that prata craving if you are in the area....

address: Block 95 Toa Payoh Lor 4, Toa Payoh Singapore 310095 Singapore
comment: This stall used to be the famous stall where they had the Fiona Xie picture with the boss and smileys all. Now it has changed/rebranded to another stall that has the words 'Formally Pasta Planet' on the upper right corner. This means Pasta Planet must be a famous place.  A quick google told me that it has made a name for itself at Golden Mile Food Centre.Woo. So I should be expecting delish food. The menu was a comprehensive list of standard Western fare. Not much pictures but the names should be easy enough. Besides regulars like chicken chop, grilled dory, some worthy mentions are lamb shanks (only avail on weekends) and oxtail stew (also weekends).There's also a pasta menu, I ordered my all-time-favourite the aglio olio seafood, which was $7.50. It's more expensive than the main meat courses which were at a range of $5 plus. The aglio olio hits the right note, it's not too spicy and there's a clean bite to the pasta.

I wondered if the old auntie who took my orders was having a bad morning as she was pulling a glum face. Fortunately, it was another auntie who was rolling the popiah, though each roll turned out smaller than expected. Nitty gritty issues aside, I must confessed that the rolls here are one of the better ones I've had.I doubt it was because I ordered "加辣" as the rolls weren't very spicy. Yet the medley of juices from the braised turnips, sweet sauce and chilli made them extra flavorful. Although bits of soggy skin stuck to the plate, they were supple enough to hold the fillings, yet YIELDING moist and chewy bites. Gritty, juicy with tingling heat beneath the sweetness, each mouthful was a sensation.

Old Long House has been bestowed honour of Makansutra Street Food Master, it's certainly worth the effort of locating this tiny stall in the food court of a residential high-rise complex, to try their wonderful popiah.  The dough skin is thin and soft, barely holds together a moist mixture of well stewed turnips, crispy fish bits, and crunchy bean sprouts that if you leave it untouched for a minute longer, the dough skin might soak through and the whole popiah would fall apart.  But worry not, these tasty eats are devoured with some passionate swiftness there is no chance for it to sit long.  Seek this place out and you will be rewarded a good popiah.

Big ass popiah with fresh, crunchy vegetable fillings and fish bits for the price - not as good as what I got in KL, but it's not bad too. I'll be back for the kuih pie tee whenever I'm in the area next time

My favorite popiah at the moment. Dosent seem to use much lard / oil, but the taste just works. Filling is great with little crispy bits. For $1.50 / roll, this is probably one of the most value for money items you have that's tastes really good as well! And relatively healthy to boot!To note: If you're the sort that prefers a lot of sauce, you may want to specifically ask for more as they don't use much.

Cool speakeasy vibe in a trendy environment; this restaurant has solid Asian fusion throughout  its menu. I enjoyed the truffle hor fun a lot and that was my favorite dish. Expect to pay about $30 per person for just food and everything is family style.

The uninitiated might just eat the wanton noodle and move on. I had no idea what I walked into when my friend proceeded to open the huge deli case.  I would describe this as fusion Asian with a retro secret society ambiance. We had the signature Wagyu beef truffle hor fun with a side of kai lan and lemongrass jelly for dessert. The beef was excellent and very flavorful. If you love food with intrigue this place is for you.

Surprisingly good. I wasn't expecting much after skimming the reviews. It was past 9PM and my colleagues finally decided that they were hungry. Service was short. They did not seem friendly. Their bottled waters were actually cold and the cup of ice that I asked for melted hella quick due to the weather. I cannot imagine living where it is ALWAYS hot AND humid. I ordered the lamb plate. I opted for saffron rice but there was little saffron. The lamb was juicy and flavorful. After my first bite, I instantly made my entree my entire universe at that moment. I'm cool w/ my colleagues, one being my best but after days of seeing each other everyday and hearing about relationship drama, I was ready to have a conversation w/ the wall.
Very delicious food and amazing place to spend the night in Singapore highly recommended for the people who missed Mediterranean food.

Thanks to Cindy Q. for accepting a last minute lunch when I was in the area. As it was so last minute, we weren't sure where we would be eating so we decided to walk down Boat Quay and find something that would be to both our liking. It wasn't even 5 minutes in before we both spotted this and decided to give it a shot.It was practically empty at 1 pm with only one other table seated. Not seeing anyone in sight, we both seated ourselves at the outermost table that was beside the "water" and "the view" while waiting for a server to appear in the vicinity.Our lone-ranger server eventually appeared like Houdini and handed us a menu each with a gentle smile. He didn't say much and it doesn't require my psychology degree to know that he was a hardworking introvert.So...just like Mexican food (in Singapore...needed to edit this after Bianca J.'s comment), I don't really think much of Singapore when it comes to Persian or anything Mediterranean (maybe Greek has a chance...but even then, I highly doubt it to be mind-blowing). A spoiled brat I may be to this particular cuisine (much thanks to great family friends of such decent in the US) but I'm also having withdrawals for a good 7 months and NEEDING some Mediterranean spice! It's about time to have a hint of these lovely flavors!What comes out as considerably cheap - in Cindy Q.'s words (regarding this area) - were two lunch specials - the fish and the koobideh - that we eventually settled for when our silent server came back to check on us.1. Barley Soup - we started with this soup...and to be honest, it was really weird. It would be the first time I had it in a "Mediterranean" setting and I've never had it served at any of my friend's family gatherings. Perhaps, my friends served more popular soups and skipped this one...and for good reason.2. Fish Plate - three pieces of beautiful seasoned and cooked fish over saffron rice, a side of slightly-wilted undressed salad brought to life by the lime provided, roasted tomato and pepper, and garlic mousse. Okay, the salad is dry and wilted...Cindy Q. didn't think too much of it and I'm complaining like a stuck-up rabbit, lol.3. Koobideh Plate - this was the reason I dropped a star. The koobideh wasn't fresh...in fact, I personally think it was sitting for quite a bit as there was a subtle flavor of sourness that is definitely NOT lime or vinegar. Sad...I really wanted this particular dish to shine more.Will be back again to try the others...but only if Cindy Q. is down for another last minute meal, lol. :)Yelp 100: 42/100

This is a tourist spot right on the waters of Boat Quay. Dropped in for a late dinner on a Friday evening. Sitting outside by the water is very nice with the scenic river and CBD serving as a beautiful backdrop. There's usually a game on the small TV they have outside and folks just enjoying themselves over a meal, drinks, and a hookah.The thing that confused me was the Greek salad came with cream cheese, not feta cheese. Is that normal in Singapore?The other dishes we had ranged from decent to just okay. Prices are reasonable.A good place to hang out with friends and play tour guide.

So incredibly disappointing. After a delicious  shawarma at Shiraz at Clarke Quay, we came here expecting similar since it was busy. Got the complete opposite. First and foremost - it was COVERED in thousand island dressing. Covered. I have eaten many a shawarma and never has it ever included thousand island. We even specifically asked/confirmed the sauce ahead of time and was assured we could get a tzatziki/garlic yogurt or something similar. Nope. The people were nice which is why I gave it two stars instead of one, but that is the ONLY reason. Unless you're here for hooka and beer only - I highly recommend you keep on waking. You can get a shawarma (fresh cut) with a Tiger for $15 at Shiraz --- way better and less expensive than this hot mess.

Do not eat here. The chicken kebab I ordered was very undercooked and made me sick. The food for the rest of our group was also very bad quality for the price. There are much better places to eat in this area.

The Almost Midnight YakitoriHere's something about Yakitori that captures not only the stomach but the soul. Perfectly grilled skewers of meat, with minimum seasoning that allows the main ingredients to shine. We love our Yakitori and couldn't be happier when we found one that opened late for supper (their last order is 11.30pm). Judging from most midnight Japanese food joints, our expectation wasn't that high, as long as it tasted decent but boy oh boy did this place blow our mind.OmoteNashi Dining Gosso, as the name suggests, specializes in Gosso Yakitori, Chicken Liver wrapped in crepine (a thin layer fat netting) and like many of the dishes, it was mind-blowingly good. Gosso Dama The liver was perfectly grilled and very fresh. The 40 second timer they gave initially felt a little gimmicky (apparently the taste changes after 40 seconds), but I'm not complaining. The liver was juicy, the seasoning well balanced and it didn't have that overpowering frozen / stale liver taste. It's a great way to introduce the non-liver fans to liver. Hatsu (chicken heart) Most places cook the hearts to death, serving a dry, rubbery interpretation but the ones here were heavenly. It's lightly seasoned, allowing the freshness of the heart to come through and grilled to perfection. It wasn't tough or rubbery, instead, offering a nice snap as you bite into it. Definitely the best grilled heart I've ever eaten. Momo (chicken thigh)Another fantastic dish. The teens here is to keep the seasoning light, so no overpowering teriyaki / Yakitori sauce here. Instead, the chicken is slightly salted to help elevate and compliment the sweetness of the chicken. The chicken was grilled to perfection, offering a nice char outside while the inside remained juicy and succulent. Shishamo. My personal favourite. The fish was grilled perfectly, offering a nice, easy to bite, snap to the skin while the inside remained moist and tender. The best Shishamo dish over had..... ever!!Cheese Taukune (cheese stuffed chicken balls)A little inconsistent on the cheese and mind was firmly in the ball while the wife's cheese was squirting out. That said, he mince's mix of 16 (I think) spices, accordingly to the menu, was perfect blended, ensuring that every piece was juicy, tender and very well seasoned.Butamaki Omochi (Rice cake wrapped with Pork Belly)Probably our least favourite of the bunch. I personally felt it needed a tad more seasoning because of the floury nature of the rice cake (it's a lot like a mochi) and the wife isn't a fan of the sticky rice cake. It was still a yummy dish, just not as mind blowing as the rest. Overall, the restaurant is a fantastic place to satisfy your Yakitori cravings. Whether it's sitting by the river or the cozy interior of the restaurant, the food is the star. Oh, and it also helps that the staff are very friendly.

An unassuming authentic Japanese yakitori restaurant that serves really good food! Having been to this place for about 3 times for lunch, I really enjoy their affordable lunch set priced from $10.50++ to about $13.50++. Their signature chicken yakitori don comes with 4 sticks of yakitori and they only serve 20 bowls each day! Each lunch set comes with a small bowl of salad and soup. Not only that, you can also choose the portion of rice that you prefer with your rice bowl. Small eaters like me will go for small rice and large eaters can ask for extra rice.Located on the prominent Boat Quay, this is a tiny shop. So do keep a keen eye when searching for it or you light just miss it. Frequent by Japanese patrons, you know that the quality of the food is definitely great. Moreover, you can also chill by the river with a view of Asian civilizations museum while enjoying your meal.Overall, great food, excellent service and fantastic view. Look forward to try dinner soon!

Easy going place with great food.  Sat outside on the water as the sun went down and moon rose over the city in background, so the setting was pretty sweet too.  We ordered the ham croquettes, padron peppers, romesco chicken skewers, grilled asparagus, and the ham sampler of 3 ibericos and 1 serrano.  Delicious!  They have good wine selection by the bottle, Moritz beer on tap, and basic house wine by the glass just as they would at any small tapas place in Barcelona or beyond.  Will definitely be back, it's the type of place we immediately thought "This is a great go-to spot to hit every couple weeks..."

Came here with friends to celebrate a birthday. Food portions are small. Shareable items like paella is good for sharing. So order more. Average prices. Expect $40-$50 a person to be enjoy the sampling. No photos to share because I was busy talking and eating. Got to make sure I sample each plate. We had olives, gambas in olive oil, salted anchovies, salad, tortilla de patata, jamones, bruschetta, grilled asparagus and two kinds of paella - seafood mix and squid ink. Go for squid ink - I can't tell what's in there but definitely some squid and tasted better than the mixed seafood paella. Can't put my finger on what's missing in the seafood version - the rice is not as flavorful.

Decent food, great view and ambience. Stumbled by this gem along the touristy boat quay from my sister-in-law's recommendations. It was difficult to find as the boat quay shophouses are not numbered, and the sign was a relatively small circle perpendicular to the side walk. An easy tip to find the place is by spotting the cat cafe right above it! The menu is simple and relatively small compared to its other outlet, but has the key elements of a Spanish restaurant - tapas, cured meats, alcohol and paella. We tried the cava sangria as i had not previously seen this anywhere else. Cava is the champagne of Spain, light and bubbly, usually to start off a meal. Sadly, although there was a good amount of fruits in the sangria, the overall taste of the sangria was rather bitter.. maybe from the cava or insufficient juice mixed in? We tried several tapas and the paella: the fried chorizo is a little salty, but still tasty. The olives had a good spicy kick to it. The melted cheese mushroom was good too. My personal favorite was the paella. It had good flavor, lots of seafood and chorizo but was a little salty for my taste. My favorite part of the little Spanish place is the view. The seats by the Singapore river were very breezy and has very good view of the city, including VCH, MBS, city hall, Fullerton. You also get live music from timbre across the river and some other bars further down the shophouses. It was also really nice that it wasn't particularly loud so conversation could be easily carried out. I would definitely be back when in need of a place to chill with some friends!

I really enjoyed the tapas here.Sure, it's in touristy Boat Quay, but on a nice night you can sit outside and people-watch while waiting for your tapas to come.Friday night was of course busy. It did take a while for our dishes to come out; timing-wise there were some long gaps here and there. My favourite dishes of the evening were the croquetas (can never go wrong with those!) the house paella, and the migas con chorizo. The Secreto Iberico was one of the highlighted specials and pricier, but it didn't impress me as much.For the tl;dr crowd: make a reservation, order the migas con chorizo, and the house paella is worth the wait!

Really love this cosy restaurant! We walked in after chancing upon it when we were trying to look for a nice place with Prosecco that we can sit, eat and chill along Circular Road.Service was excellent and the pizza is great! Thin crusted and generous in their toppings and sauce, every bite is rich and full of ingredients and flavour.We ordered the seafood tomato sauce based pasta and we weren't disappointed! To be honest, it was the way the male host was serving his patrons seated at the entrance of the restaurant that got our attention and decided to give it a go. The host was really thoughtful and nice. Together with another hostess, the team kept topping up our flutes with chilled prosecco from the bottled we ordered whenever our glasses were near empty. Their cheerful disposition and keen observation is very much appreciated. Serving rather Classic Italian dishes, I have to say their fried chicken isn't that great. Perhaps the grid calamari would have been better but it would be seafood overload since we already ordered the seafood pizza.The evening ended with a tiramisu and a panna cotta to share. This is probably the better panna cotta around as it was creamy and dense. Not too tough nor too soft, the consistency was just right.The tiramisu is nothing short of "I want another spoonful please" again and again. It has a good balance of the complexity of bitterness of the espresso in the cake and the milky sweetness to the cream. The sweetness and bitterness lift the experience with depths of taste instead of the usual overly sweet tiramisu that is usually put up in other places.To top it all up, the host served up a shot of limoncello for each of us on the house. They have won my heart.
Best yakiniku I've had in Singapore and I've lived in Tokyo. Top notch service and food quality. Just like being in Japan. Highly recommend.

I ordered the 2nd tier (more expensive one) course - the food was amazing! The amount they give you is definitely not much for the price you pay - that's why I gave 4 stars.The quality of meat is beyond but they only give you 1-2 pieces of each part of meat and overall, the course was so small that I had to order rice to fill up my stomach. The bill was over $300 for 2 people (2 course, a few beer, and rice)You can call them on the same day and book a course even though it says they need 24 hour notice given that they have availability.Overall Verdict: 4Taste: 5Amount: 3Price: 3Atmosphere: 4

Edwin is the best! He has cold glasses ready for your beer. Has a great selection of spirits. He also has very high end scotch which is my favorite. Don't let this place pass you by. He also plays good music!!

Super happy with the quality, price, and service.  I've been here about 10 times over 6 months now.  Will continue to go.Recommend the combo with extra sliced beer, fresh spring roll, and vietnamese tea - you will be pleasantly surprised.The best out of the over 5 pho houses that I have tried around the CBD.

Service - 1 Star (waitress is busy with cellphone)Food - 3 star (so-so)Tempted to give 1 Star overall if I were to rate just after dinner. Service is just horrible, you need yo take your own spoon, fork and even napkins, while the server/waitress is busy with her own cellphone.The pho, cha gio and summer rolls were ok. Nothing special.

Came here by myself after going gym. The restaurant is in the heart of financial district. Pho tastes good, I was suggested to get the combo by the lady which I can also have a drink and one roll, so that is cheaper. I wanna order my favorite beverage that is orange juice but they run out of that. Then another lady suggest me to try the combination of apple and carrot and it tastes good as well. The service is awesome, they are so friendly and helpful. They will guide you guys the best choice for the food you are craving for.

I remember making an international phone call from Perth to Singapore to book for two hours spot at the first cat cafe in Singapore, Neko No Niwa (which means Cat Garden). I only had a day stop over in Singapore and I was so keen to go there. Based on Singapore's standard, the cat cafe charged quite an expensive price but it was quite understandable because they have to take care of the cat's litters, vaccination and the exorbitant rent cost. Sam, the owner of the cat cafe, always welcomed us and took his time to chat with us. On our latest visit to the cat cafe, he also gave us the dry food sample for our ragdoll cat, Melody.The cafe was very easy to find and it was a 5-10 walk (depending on how fast you walk) from Clarke Quay Central and One Raffles Place. As you walk to the Level 2 of the 54A Boat Quay, you can see cat paintings on the wall. From time to time, Neko No Niwa sold some limited edition items such as paintings of their cat and painted cotton bags. They also have some cute cat collar and I bought one for souvenir purposes. The best time to visit was in the morning before lunch time or late at night before the cafe's closing hour.Neko No Niwa adopted all the abandoned cats, gave them loving human touch and let them heal get closer to human by putting them together with the customers. There are some rules that they put in place as a safeguard for both the cats and human patrons (e.g. do not disturb them when they sleep). Every customer who booked for a certain time period will be given a rule book to be read and they can also order some food or drinks from the cafe section. Each drink ordered will arrive with a wooden lid to ensure that the dust / fur didn't get in it (or maybe so the cat didn't play around with it). On three occasions I went there with hubby and on the last visit I took my friend (Nevertity) who was really scared of cats. In two hours time, she managed to pet some and even let one slept on her lap (I think it was Jia Jia)! The whole experience was very relaxing and I will definitely go back for another visit when I travel to Singapore. Until then, Neko No Niwa!

Such a great place to get your cat fix. This cat cafe had such friendly staff as well as an array of cats to enjoy. These cats have been here loving their best lives since the beginning. They all have such personalities and are all so wonderful. They only take cash and it is $12 an hour to visit the cats (worth it). They have drinks and snacks available to purchase.

Very cute, clean, and well-kept cat room with sleepy, easy-to-pet cats. The cats have lived here for a while, so they are very comfortable (it's their home!). Location is convenient for tourists; price is fair for an hour's worth of entertainment/rest.

I've always wanted to visit a cat cafe and Neko no Niwa did NOT disappoint. We paid S$12/hour for the first hour each and it seemed steep at first, but the drinks themselves were really reasonably priced and delicious! They had 13 cats when we visited and the menu has a small profile on each of the cats so you can 'get to know them'. It was quiet when we arrived and mostly everyone was sleeping, but the cats were extremely friendly. You can pet them to your heart's content and you can tell they are used to all the attention. The location is absolutely adorable. Located on the 2nd floor above Boat Quay, the cafe has a giant window for the cats to look out and they have a gorgeous view of the Marina Bay Sands. Yes, these cats live a more luxurious lifestyle than even I do. There are plenty of couches to relax on and lots of books and board games if the cats aren't enough entertainment for you :)I'd definitely visit again. The atmosphere was relaxing and the workers were incredibly friendly, constantly popping in to dote on the cats and show us things about them. The cafe is also really convenient to the rest of the popular downtown attractions. About a 5 minute walk to Raffles/Long bar for Singapore Slings and then another 15 minutes to the Singapore Flyer/Marina Sands. Not to mention the Boat Quay area that the cafe is located in has TONS of neat looking bars and restaurants. We were at the cafe at 11am, so things were just opening up, but would have loved to spent the evening in Boat Quay along the Singapore River.

As friend of cats, this place was instantly appealing to me. That and I reallllly needed a cup of coffee after coming from LA. Glad I did - this place is the epitome of what a cat cafe should be: clean, welcoming, organized, very good coffee and a whole gaggle of docile furballs. Unfortunately, I didn't have time to pet one of them, so had to take my coffee takeaway. But it's worth noting that, besides the central feature of cats, another standout feature is the terrific, friendly and fast service.

A very cool place for cat lovers!! Better book a few days in advance if you plan to go there. How it works is that, you have to pay for a cuddling fee of $12/hour/person. Then on too of that every half an hour is at a certain rate (not too sure). You will be removing ur shoes so I recommend slippers or easy to wear kind. Also will be required to wash hands with soap before going in the cats area. As for drinks, their recommendation is ice chocolate and various teas they have. I don't usually like chocolate but Since the waiter said it's not too sweet but slightly on the bitter side ao I gave it a shot and it's not bad!Oh and they don't make drinks or food in that place so mostly pre-made. Didn't try their cakes cause was too full but they all look pretty appetizing! Give it a try. :)But most of the people leave their drinks on the table and go around the place to play with cats instead. And take photos and videos, in fact loads of them haha.

I don't know about you, but they don't have cat cafes where I come from. This is a completely new concept to me, and of course I am not surprised that these cafes are the norm in Japan. (Seriously, I stand by my belief that the Japanese come up with EVERYTHING.)So excuse me as I excitedly tell you about the awesomeness that is the CAT CAFE!This place is perfect for those who:1) Enjoy cats and other furry four legged friends.2) Are looking for a unique experience in central Boat Quay.3) Love animals but can't own a pet at the moment.It's recommended to make a reservation. I was able to call a day ahead for an appointment at 8 PM on a weekday. I only stayed an hour, but I was surprised at the amount of people who came in around 9 PM (especially since they close at 10 PM.) I guess they are right in assuming that the cats would be active around this time.Before you walk in, you will be quickly briefed on the rules and given a small pamphlet with cute pictures and information on all of the cats. The space where all the cats stay is very clean. Their litter is hidden outside and accessible via a small tunnel that runs behind the small coffee/tea bar. They provide various toys you can use to play with the cats, and of course, you are encouraged to pet them (as long as they aren't sleeping.) Although you're not allowed to pick up the cats, the workers there can handle them and offer to put them on your lap (only if you want to, of course.) I had the opportunity to have Brown Monkey (the cats have silly names) on my lap, but after a minute she ran away because she wanted to play. :(The $12/hour that you pay goes towards taking care of these cats, all of whom were strays and adopted. I see so many strays around Singapore; it'd be awesome if they could have more of these cafes around the island!

My very first cat cafe! I thought $15/hr/person was a little steep but I guess it's worth it for the free AC and wifi. We went in the middle of the day which was dumb because most/all the cats were napping. We still had a good time though because the tea/coffee was good and the place was bright with lots of positive energy.They told me the cats are the most awake around 11am or 8p, I have no doubt it's a 5 star experience then. All the kitties are super soft and I really liked all the art on the walls detailing the cats' personalities and hobbies.

Was actually looking for an izakaya around boat quay on a Sunday night, then realized that most of them were closed on Sundays. So looked around an found Imakatsu which was not exactly what I was looking for, but close enough.For starters, we shared the minced meat cutlet which was served with an egg in the middle, with the yolk still runny. A beautiful dish, but the taste wasn't anything out of this world. So wouldn't say it's a must order, but if you like scotch eggs, then maybe you can give this a try. For mains, I ordered the premium special loin set while my friend ordered the katsudon.The premium loin was a lot oilier than the normal loin, but the meat was so tender it didn't require much chewing. So I liked it once I removed the oily sides, but some might love it if you're a fan of lard. The normal loin in the katsudon was tough in comparison and hard to bite through, for those who prefer their meat to have more texture, the regular would be fine. However I found it too tiring to chew, and would order the premium special anytime instead.They serve the tonkatsu sets with 3 types of salt, which I didn't find a difference in taste for all nor did they explain if there was any difference. All they say was one of the salts is to be squeezed with lemon, so I still would prefer old fashioned grind sesame with tonkatsu sauce from say, tonkichi.Overall quite a nice experience, prices are reasons for meat quality. Wouldn't mind returning sometime soon.

I don't think I've ever had Iranian food. I'd read somewhere that the kebabs at this place were pretty good, so I made note to visit, and when I arrived I realised they served Iranian style kebabs.We had the 2 person set, which for $30 (nett, despite table service) came with pita, hummus, basmati rice, lamb kubideh, lari chicken and 2 canned drinks.The pita was flat, wide and crispy rather than the thicker, softer pita I'm used to from other kebab places, and topped with some sesame seeds. I suppose this was Sangak. It was crispy and the sesame seeds gave it a nice flavour.The hummus was not bad. Not the best I've tasted but delectable enough.The set came with a mountain of basmati rice. It seemed plain but had a subtle flavour when I ate it. Perhaps this is the true plain flavour of basmati. It was hard to tell as I usually only find basmati in pilaf or biryani form.The lamb kubideh had a very very strong lamb taste. If you don't like the smell of lamb you should stay away this even further than you normally would. That said, it was tastily seasoned and thick. Somehow it was even crispy.I couldn't identify the medley of spices in the lari chicken (lemon and a hint of chili while not being spicy), but it was definitely very different from that of normal kebabs. It also used real chunks of chicken, rather than the ground meatloaf or mystery meat that some places use.Unlike Turkish kebabs, the meats were served without sauces. Yet, the meal didn't feel dry or flavourless because the meats were very moist and bursting with taste.Eating here was definitely a delicious slice of something on the novel side, even if the air conditioning (if any) was barely working (despite our coming at night).Oh, and one upside of coming here is that they sell alcohol, which most kebab places in Singapore don't.
I hope I get diarrhea because I want this overpriced, unauthentic, badly served stuff out of my system.

A good bowl of yong tau foo. It is located right next to the famous bak-chor mee sua of BK Eating House.I had the dry version which has a brown sauce poured over it instead of the usual reddish sweet sauce. The brown sauce is like those you get when you eat the fried ampang yong tau foo.Definitely a good affordable lunch fix for that area. This place packs a long line at lunch hour due to the many offices around. But the line moves fast and they do have ample seating, outdoor downstairs or aircon upstairs. PS. Tissue paper choping concept works here too.

I had horrific experience at this place. The pizza you get here is just a bread nothing to else. Though the staffs were helpful but the bad food made the whole experience pretty shabby.I haven't tried other stuffs and so can't say.

Marco Marco has an open, inviting atmosphere. Historically, I've been pretty judgemental about Italian restaurants in Singapore, which in my opinion, usually lack tradational authenticity. But suspending my benchmark of a real Roman ristorante, Marco Marco does a great job. Certainly the best $18-$20 Italian-style pizza I've had in Singapore. It's a great value for a pizza or pasta fix.

Good but not spectacular? I doubt this is enough to give any justice of how good their food is. The line is always long, if you have any Singaporean sense in you, go join the line and try their food. Fortunately for me, I was early, or really late. Everytime I am there, the food I want is fresh and spicy. Nasi Padang isn't nasi padang without it's spicy, sweet and sour flavors. While the varies are vast, I wish for the prices to decrease. Nevertheless, it is in the heart of CBD area and perhaps one of the best malay treat around. Ask for more sambal and try their achar, you can't go wrong with that along with some curry and begedel. Simply delicious for a hot grumpy day during the week. Just don't blame me if you fall asleep at your desk. I warned you.

I like the range of choices here and the dishes are more Indonesian than Malay. Besides the usual rendang, curry chicken, sambal goreng and maybe petai, you can also get beef lungs, beef tripe, oxtail, quail eggs sambal.I was quite overwhelmed by the selection and the guy serving me recommended the BBQ chicken. I had that, plus petai and sambal goreng. It was considered pricey for an essentially street food "economy rice" place. It came to $10 with a lime juice. The BBQ chicken was not that great as the meat was dry and a bit tough. It was not juicy or succulent at all. The sambal goreng and petai were decent. Unless I have a hankering for beef lungs or tripe and those rarer dishes, I will stick to the regular Malay style nasi padang. Nearby is the Golden Shoe car park food court on the 2nd level, and it has reasonably priced food. The nasi padang stalls hardly go beyond $5 for a meat + 2 veg rice meal.
It is ok. Good enough for lunch but nothing spectacular.Prices are not cheap though, probably due to the location. A plate of chicken, veggies and potato begerdel cost $6. Lime juice $1.50.
long lines because it's a famous place.  for me the chicken was a little dry.  spice was good. get a begedel on your plate.

Phenomenal from beginning to end. The flavors of most of the dishes were just beautiful and unique, the feel of the restaurant being as if I eating inside the kitchen of a huge restaurant, and the service was kind and generous. Highly recommend.I was caught off guard by this experience as I recently lost much of my intrigue with Michelin Stars in Singapore but found this one to be spot on.Reservations for weekday seatings were very easy via their website which I believe uses Quandoo. We simply made a 7:30 res and took an Uber to the restaurant where we walked into a giant kitchen with only 6-8 tables in the entire dining room. At the time there was only one other seated party of 2, later there was a party of 4.My friend and I ordered the following:1) Pasta with Razor clams - This one is a MUST. WOW.2) Pasta with Uni or Crab - Pass on this one. Get the razor clam one3) Pasta with Barnacles - Unfortunately I misunderstood the waitress. Thought she said the barnacles are prepared by itself, not with another course of pasta. The barnacles were very good but I would suggest you not get it with pasta if you already ordered the razor clams.4) Roasted Pigeon - Best pigeon I've had, not gamey at all. 5) Wild Snapper - Excellent6) Strawberry Cheesecake - Fluffy, light, pink, Instagram worthy7) Their signature dessert (Starts with a G) - Very rich. Nice flavor but the sweetness is a bit much after the first bite.They also provided us a special Italian bread that they fly in every week from Italy.The chef is actually there and serves us himself many of the dishes. I love restaurants like this, very personal. Because the kitchen is right in front of you and in a sense, invades your space, you feel like you are watching a TV show with your food being prepared. It's awesome.The Boat Quay location is wonderful as well but can be hard to find. Keep an eye out for the signage and your Google Maps.Only negative at the moment is the quality of their cocktails if you do visit their rooftop bar. I ordered the bramble which was horribly sweet for a simple bramble (although the blackberry ice sphere was cool). My friend got one of the Sours which tasted awful. We barely drank them and left, hopefully it was a one time thing.

One of the more underwhelming michelin restaurants Ive experienced (Im not counting Hawker Chan, since that should have been only a bib gourmand). There were some highs and lows, with a bill that doesnt justify a five course meal. The amuse Bouche set the tone with the chefs preference for sweet and savory. It was nice to have a geographical expedition in regional tastes of Italy stretched across a placard. The beef tartine was a delightful, playful twist in cherries. The beef marrow butter and beef itself were draped in cherry smoke, creating this illusion of a buttery cherry pie.The langoustine was another example of sweet and savory. This time, the interplay between cocoa nibs, coconut milk sauce, and fish all leaned heavily upon southeast Asia and nods to Africa. Creamy, sultry, crispy, with the seafood still in the forefront. Although it doesn't feel Italian, it definitely tastes good. If they added sugar, it could be a dessert!The haiddako snapper was a sharp turn towards a more conservative dish. Much more familiarity in the ingredients and presentation. The tomato, pepper, and relish combo felt like a deck of cards fanned out, all creating this image of an olive; A tasty olive none the less!
