The fish stood its ground among the flavors, especially with some help from the caviar. The uni crab pasta dish was boring. For what had the most expensive items on the menu didn't match to taste. The pasta wasn't al dente, the crab barely stood out, and the uni didn't sing. A misstep for sure with the pacing of this meal. The wagyu beef wasn't breaking barriers in presentation, but damn do the classics sound good when played right. The yolk was essential to the meal. It was the goo of life that brought these inanimate pieces of food to life in my mouth. The mustard and black garlic were placed on the outside of the plate like an art palate for me to brush my meat into. The meat itself was butter soft, juicy, and full of beef flavor. The only real enhancement could have been a crust on the outside. The white chocolate Was a fruity dish in disguise. Even though the ball of white chocolate is the main attraction, it was a fairly blank, buttery canvas to push the raspberries straight to the forefront. Plenty of low tone tartness to go around.I liked my meal, but I wasnt delighted like I normally am from a michelin starred restaurant. I have nothing against this talented chef, but I dont think this place was as progressive as it claims.

We went for the Menu Gourmand - the composition of which varies as you indicate to the chef which dish(es) from the à la carte menu you may wish to have. The food is among the most refined and subtle Italians you'll find in Singapore. However, what makes Braci truly unique is, because the restaurant is so small, you can engage in conversations with the staff, and especially with the talented and enthusiastic polyglot chef Beppe De Vito, a real artist. If Braci were larger (and demonstrate it could achieve the same quality with scale), it would have two Michelin stars, not one. That said, although the dishes are innovative, beautifully plated and refined, the nearby Osteria Art (also owned by chef Beppe) serves more hearty Italian meals (especially the pastas, which are the best in Singapore!) Incidentally, very good wine list, with many 'reasonably-priced' Brunello's and Barolo's.

Wonderful, sit on the top floor for the view (I think it's a bar but you can eat there). Both lunch and dinner are great. Staff and chef were friendly and attentive. Food was fun. Especially liked the pigeon and desert (forgot what it was called) the last time I was there.

rest_name: The Container Japanese Wagyu Tapas & Bar
comment: If you are in the mood for wagyu beef but don't want to commit to one large Japanese barbecue meal - this is the place for you!  The menu has taken the love of small plate tapas and combined it with simple wagyu inspired and focus dishes. Ranging from the standard slider to meat balls and bao bun - The chefs have added surprising twists to each dish elevating them from their meet centric theme. We started the meal with "popcorn" (meat balls with fried minced beef), smoked carpaccio (which included roe and shiso leaves), and then progress towards the slider the cups and the bun - each had fantastic twists which really elevated the dish (for example the cups were prepared with cream of sea urchin to contrast with the beef). In addition their menu also included it lovely cocktails inspired by the four elements of nature.Overall this was a lovely place if you want Asian inspired food, good view and great drinks - but all with a modern twist!

rest_name: Tong Xin Ru Yi Traditional Hotpot
comment: Probably my favourite authentic Chinese hot pot place with amazing side dishes.  My favourite is the garlicky yabbies  great service esp if you're a regular though I've never had bad service there.  The aircon is a tad cold so bring a jacket.  Oh!  Don't forget to ask for aprons... it can get deliciously messy

rest_name: Tong Xin Ru Yi Traditional Hotpot
comment: One of the more original hot pot restaurants around. Sober and beautiful interior. Delish and innovative soups and dishes, eg. garlic oysters, rabbit, frog legs, kidney, tripes, in addition to the 'normal' offerings. Tong Xin Ru Yi is the Ruby King Kong of hot pots in Singapore.

Loved it. My old favourite place had closed so they recommended this place in Boat Quay alongside Singapore river. Man am I happy. Awesome Lamb Vindaloo, fantastic Naan - and icecold beer. My new favourite if You are going touristy. Will be coming back!

I should have realised that when in Singapore the vindaloo is going to be really, really spicy, namely because it is going to be much more authentic than the stuff you pick up in the food halls back in Australia. So, as I was wandering through the Boat Quay I came across this Indian Restaurant and decided that it was time to have a vindaloo. It was only after I had ordered it that I realised that it was going to be a proper vindaloo, and sure enough, as soon as I took a bite my mouth was on fire. Now that is what I call a good vindaloo. Anyway, this is probably not the cheapest place for good Indian, but then again it is located on the Boat Quay, and simply sitting outside on the river's edge, eating a vindaloo (even though it is hot) certainly gives this place a value for money. The service was pretty good, and you can even get tradition Indian beers. However, as I have suggested, there is really only one thing I eat when I eat Indian - yep, Vindaloo.

I was wandering along Boat Quay on my last afternoon in Singapore and I suddenly spotted this place. The first thing that went through my mind was 'what a cool name'. In fact I thought the name was so cool that I simply could not walk past, and despite the fact that I was a little pressed for time, I made the executive decision to step inside and buy a drink, even if it was simply to say 'I had a beer at a bar called the PurPle TurTle. As you can probably tell by the name, the bar is purple, and there are little turtle scattered about the place. Out the back you have some dart machines (which is basically darts without the pointy ends - I have always wandered how drunk people manage to play darts in the pub without causing serious injury to anybody, but then again you don't see many dart boards in pubs these days). Look, the bar isn't all that fantastic, but the reason it gets points is simply because of the name.

Get the dry MeeSua.It's really really delicious, cheap (4 SGD), and the service is lighting fast. Used to eat this a few nights a week while living down the street. There are some other decent looking options on either side of the MeeSua stall in case you want to mix it up.

Everybody is here for the MeeSua. Yes it is pretty good. I have returned here many times for the MeeSua.So today I had the Chicken Nasi Briyani. The curry chicken taste good, just as the nasi briyani rice. Price is on the steep side of $6.50. Unairconditioned. AL fresco prices probably.

Much like everyone else, I come here for the dry specialty meesua.The noodles are coated with this oil, chili and vinegar dressing, then topped with minced pork, sliced pork, ikan bilis and fresh lettuce. Served with a bowl of simple broth.It's delicious and open 24/7 except Sunday, which means its perfect for a late supper after drinks. There isn't much else to say except that you HAVE to try this dish. A true delicacy at only $4/bowl.

BK eating house saved my tummy more then once while I was in SG.It was located right across from where I was staying.Because of the late night hours... I was able to come here in the middle of the night and fill up on cheap eats. Everything from kaya toast and teh, noodles and rice dishes and lime juice. This place is popular with the locals and I can see why.Thank you BKEH for my numerous meals here!
fishball is good, but don't like sweaty sauce. You can try but don't suggest for northern Chinese

Extremely cheap place to eat. I was surprised by how cheap the food was and the amount of food they gave me. You could probably buy one of everything and still have money left over! Can't really comment on the sanitary conditions but seemed safe enough to eat. Feel free to sit with some random strangers. They won't mind.
Where the locals go to eat. Busy at lunch during the work week. Fast and friendly food stalls.

Yes. Mee sua. Yes. Mmm. We always went here after a night out and were never disappointed. I get mine without cockles and easy on the vinegar. My friends always ordered extra noodles and meat. We haven't tried the other stalls and we never really needed to. The mee sua is a beast.

I absolutely love the mee sua here. I haven't tried anything else but it deserves four stars on the strength of the mee sua alone. The noodles are brilliant, the sauce is spicy, the fishballs are standard and the pork is delicious. Eat the mee sua, you won't regret it.

So. Freaking. Delicious !! I've eaten here upwards of 6 times and everything I've tasted in this place has been delightfully memorable.The owner is a gem, he remembers his customers and their orders.If you're looking for something on the healthier side opt for a salad or wrap, everything can be customized to be vegetarian or vegan. If you're looking for some yummy comfort food get the Mac n Cheese! (Comes with beef but can be made without. The owner will substitute veggies if you'd rather.)Seating inside is limited but these flavors are worth the visit!!

Healthy, fast, with a sense of humor. What's not to like?This is a great takeaway spot if you're looking for something healthy. I wasn't in the mood for meat so I went with their veggie wrap, which had miso tofu in it.I thought that the tofu wouldn't have any taste, but wow, I was wrong! It definitely had some good spice and flavour to it. In addition to the greens, the added achar and nuts gave the wrap some good texture and an extra boost in energy.The chef (and I will assume owner) is very jovial and knows all his regular customers by name. He's good with small talk, so don't be afraid to strike up a conversation with him as he's preparing your food!

I LOVE THIS PLACE SO MUCH!If i dont come here for awhile, i start missing the remdang beef salad. I can't describe why it's so good. It just is. The fresh ingredients definitely doesn't hurt, and the super friendly owner.Bonus point as they are never busy during dinner. For lunch it's a different story I heard!

Lock me up and throw away the key!Dining here turned my colleague and I into petty criminals. So engrossed were we in our lunchtime rant-a-thon that we neglected to pay after eating.We only realised this fact upon returning to our office. A solid 5+ minute walk from this establishment.Once our crime-spree registered in our brains, we were both instantly wracked with full body pangs of guilt and embarrassment, quickly followed by engaging in a long walk of shame back to the eatery.Re-arriving, with guilt-ridden faces, we bowed our thieving heads in an act of ultimate contrition hoping to assuage the owner into letting us off lightly.We proffered our payment and our sincerest apologies in good faith as we looked to escape a long stint behind bars in a federal pound-me-in-the-4ss prison (thanks office space).To our delight we discovered that the owner/operator is actually Captain Cool from the ice planet Chillax. He found our tale of woe and misdemeanour hilarious and amusing and deemed our prodigal return a clear act of good faith. Restoring our smiles to our faces and the freedom to return to his fantastic little world of food again.I had the special which today was Wagyu beef, and I chose to wrap it in a shroud of wholemeal and assorted greens. The taste? Anything that tastes this good should be a crime!The price? A steal! (Actually it is quite spendy @ $16 but I would gladly pay it again).This place lives up to its name, simple and humble food done good. Just remember to pay your bill when you leave ;)

I love places that serve the highest quality food. Meet&Green is one of them and serve fresh, healthy and tasty meals. This is my favourite place for a lunch on Circular Rd! :)The menu is short and very specific, hover almost every day they prepare meet or veggie special (falafel, hummus, special kind of meat/sea food etc.). This is more than salad and more than just a wrap. You have to check it out and the owner - Akhil - will definitely remember you and your name!

Meat and Green is in a small space in Boat Quay that is good for lunch. There is limited seating inside and a few street side tables in front, but it's convenient food for take-away, too. The owner, Akil, is always there making sure that everything is of high quality. The vegetables are fresh and the wraps are piled with meat. I'd recommend the pulled pork. Delicious and satisfying! They have some interesting bottled soft drinks in the cooler, and a limited selection of ciders and beer (Tuatara on the crafty side). It's pretty quiet in the evening, which makes it a good option if you are in the area and you want to find a quiet place to chill on an otherwise busy street.

Excellent. Fresh, healthy and tasty. I like how they take the effort out of choosing greens and do it for you, with just the right amount of nut crunchiness, quinoa and herb dressing. Also, good value for a salad shop in Sing. I'll be back.

I honestly created a yelp account just to leave this 5* review. Food is too good. That tian b. Person that gave this place 2-stars has a stick up their a**. Food couldn't be better and he remembers my girlfriend and I's usual orders. He Even drops us some extra food sometimes if he is experimenting while we are there and it's always great.

Came here for the first time today, absolutely incredible! Lovely service, convenient location, simple and well thought out menu! I had a veggie wrap and it was to die for! Vegetarian food can be bland or boring - but this exceeded every expectation! Yum! Will be making this my regular lunch joint!

Came here to grab some drinks with a friend while we were travelling in Singapore. A failed bar crawl prompted us to find out own bars to go to, and Vasco looked like a fun place to check out. We weren't disappointed. We each just had a drink and relaxed. The environment was nice and it wasn't too busy at all. The drinks were creatively made and tasted delicious. If you don't already know, alcohol is expensive in Singapore, so be prepared for that, but otherwise enjoy!Would recommend for anyone just trying to explore different parts of the city.

If you're looking for a place that serves both awesome food AND drinks - this is the one!I've been here twice now and I just can't recommend it enough. Conceived by the folks behind The Cufflink Club, Vasco serves an array of latin american cuisine and cocktail.DRINKSI tried the Muerto Sour and Sangrita from the Dia de los Muertos menu. Both were excellent drinks. From the permanent menu I would recommend Hand of God.FOODFor food, definitely try the empanadas, pork belly skewers (or any of the skewers really), and the pork tortas.I'm definitely coming back again!

Me n a couple of friends from TW heading to Vasco as we heard friend Phil is the assistant cook for the night. We took the advice of the handsome waiter Chris and share everything on the table. Ribeye, Seabass, Prawn Ceviche, lamb Empanadas, etc , crumble and apple cake for dessert. The lamb empanadas is my favorite! Everything is absolutely delicious. let's not forget about the cocktails,the mix is right and smooth. Would love my drinks to hv a bit of kick ;) guess we didn't make that clear to the mixologist, nevertheless, nailed it:) Special thanks to head chef Jennifer and her assistant Phil, you guys rock! Will be back for more for sure :)

Fairly new cocktail bar and restaurant at Hong Kong Street. The place looks really nice and inviting from the outside and the staff were also very friendly when we entered. They have a nice and interesting cocktail menu where i found a lot of cocktails i wanted to try. They also offer some beer and wine but that is more limited so clear it is not the focus. The cocktails we had have all been decent but in Singapore there are just so many good quality cocktail bars so this does not really reach the top level. That is not saying it was bad but when I pay well above 20++ SGD per cocktail I expect a very good level. The food here is nice but in general I seldom find myself ecstatic over Latin American food but the small snacks we had were nice. The best thing about this place is however the staff and the ambiance. Staff were attentive and friendly and I liked the feel of the place so I will most likely be back.

There aren't many Latin American places here that aren't Mexican or Brazilian Churrascaria, so I came to try the food.The empanadas were alright. We tried both the vegetarian and lamb ones. They didn't t taste as good as they sounded, but they were the best dishes we had.The Cubano sandwich was mostly cabbage and didn't have much meat. Furthermore, the purple cabbage was a little bitter so it wasn't very nice, though the sandwich tasted promising  and would probably be good with more meat.The cassava chips were thick cut. All other times I've had cassava it's been thin and crispy - and I saw why. The chips had an interesting taste, with a clearer cassava flavour than you get with thin cuts, but they was a little dry and dense.The chicken skewers were seasoned with coconut, pecans and lime. An interesting combination, but not one that penetrated far into the meat. So though tender enough, the skewers didn't have much of a taste.The worst item was the dessert: apple and rum layered cake with walnut and condensed milk ice cream. The cake was one of the drier cakes I've had, with a nice crispy texture and a promising taste, but the dryness meant the flavour didn't come out. As for the ice cream. (which was probably dulce de leche)... While it tasted okay, if a little too sweet (and this is coming from someone with  a sweet tooth), the texture was awful. It was like lumpy custard in parts and like cake (yes, really) in others. I've never had ice cream with such a... particular texture before.The service was quite friendly and they do a cute thing of writing your name and reservation time with chalk on the tables, but that couldn't make up for the disappointing food.

Vasco is a great place on hot Hong Kong Street serving up some very good Latin American food and also worthy cocktails as well.  While Singapore has quite a few Mexican/Tex-Mex places, it's more difficult to find dishes from Central and South America, so Vasco fills this void with some of the classics.  Definitely start off with a ceviche - we the variation with snapper and orange juice, which was a nice refreshing touch to the very fresh fish.  Also don't miss out on empandas.  These are sort of like a dumpling, but much thicker and there are two versions, which are both tasty - one with lamb and one with spinach - so get an order with both.  The bistec was also well done - it's a thin steak (authentic) but here they use a better cut of beef (ribeye) and served with chimichurri.  The Cuban sandwich is already famous, but I didn't really care for the coleslaw.  It's something I will order again however sans coleslaw.  Definitely wash the food down with one of their latin cocktails, such as a true margarita, i.e. not a slushy ;), a delicious pisco sour or a very solid old fashioned made with aged rum.  With so many good eats/drinks on Hong Kong Street, there is a lot of competition, but Vasco holds its own quite well.

We ordered take away on Mother's Day since the restaurant was fully booked for lunch however the staff was very apologetic. The beef salad was  nice and spicy and the beef was tender. The tofu and vegetable green curry was delicious to a perfection. Four stars instead of five because the price is a bit on the high side. We will certainly go back to the restaurant to try their other items and the desserts.

Everything was so delicious! My new favourite Thai restaurant in Singapore! Not only was the food amazing, the staff was so friendly and attentive. The decor was interesting. The restaurant was really clean. It wasn't that busy on a Tuesday night but they do take reservations.Firstly, the grilled chicken (half $12) was great! Very juicy and tender. Pairs well with the spicy sauce for dipping.The PenLaos platter ($24) had pork spring rolls and pork neck (delicious). It was supposed to have pancakes but they ran out so we had crispy prawn instead, but everything was so good!The 500g deep-fried sea bass ($28) was so delicious too! Perfectly crispy on the outside but it wasn't burnt. Just cooked to perfection.For dessert, of course we had the mango sticky rice ($9) which was yummy and we tried the Red Ruby in coconut milk ($5.5) but that was just okay.The Thai milk tea was great! The brown sticky rice we ordered on the side came in a cute basket and it was yummy.Bottom line is that I'm so happy this place exists to satisfy our Thai food cravings. I definitely recommend!

A refreshing change to be finally able to get decent quality Thai food (Isaan style) at a casual breezy comfortable restaurant (as opposed to the tasty but seedy joints found at Orchard Towers or Golden Mile).Mid-value price point, warm & hospital service & typical familiar favourites cooked in a healthier lighter style.

Even not considering the compulsory service charge of 10%, this restaurant gives their worst customer experience I had in Singapore. We ordered the dessert at the beginning and we waited for more than 30 minutes after finishing the dinner and dessert never came. I spoke to the service people a couple times, every time they nicely listened to you but there was no results.
They have more than coffee and kaya toast.The two Penang dishes we tried are not especially memorable. Decent I guess.

Went with Some colleagues to this place. Inside was no room left, so we sat outside which is nice and hot. We ordered the dish of the day and some other things. After already a few minutes the first dish came. But than it took at least 10minutes for the next few dishes. But still after a long waiting time, 2 of our dishes were not there yet. After having asked for, they told us the dish was not available anymore, so we choose something else and again needed to wait. So very bad service. The food was good, not great and my dish was a bit lacking variety. Not to be repeated for me, but if you want a large size dish which is cheap, than this is the place for the local cuisine.

This place is open till late in the Boat Quay area, and is a great place for supper.We came here around midnight, and got two portions of tandoori chicken, and an egg prata. Oh my, the tandoori chicken here is really good. I think their chicken is tender, moist, well-marinated, and probably not made to order, but reheated properly, and not microwaved. It comes with some sauce and onion salad on the side, so it is quite filling. What we had in mind were 2 pieces of tandoori chicken on a plate, but this was so much more than what we expected. Yum!P.S. The prata was okay.

I've lived in Singapore for more than a year now. So, by now, I believe my taste buds (plus my die-hard love for food) can tell the difference between good or bad Malay/Indian food. Well, that's what I thought until last night when I ventured into Shah Alam. This place is the BEST Malay/Indian food in all of Singapore!I had no idea what I ate exactly bc I was so drunk, but we ordered a combination of different dishes ranging from chicken curry to mutton briyani to mee goreng to prata. My favorite was hands down the mee goreng! (So maybe I do remember!) Prata, my favorite Singaporean food of all time (Yes! I've paid USD$5 for prata before in the States!) was a so-so. The curry wasn't as nice and the prata part wasn't as flaky and much too chewy for my liking. If you're a drunkard in Boat Quay...uh, yea, I'll see you there ;)

I cant give a bad review for good cheap eats and it was located next to the place where I stayed at in SG.Came here on a rainy day... and if you're in SG you know all about the rain problems... it always rain. I was hungry and came here since it was located next door to me. Indoor and out door seating. A great variety on their menu and price point was great.I ordered the lemon chicken with lime juice.I notice this place is popular during lunch time with locals. If you're in the area and looking for a no frills place for a local lunch or dinner come here!I'm a fan!- Miss Yelp 2014

It is ok. Convenient if you work nearby.Tried the BBQ stingray and egg with rice. The fish is fresh and the egg nicely fried. The chilli is nice but the taste doesn't get into the fish. I guess it is just coated in top of the fish after the fish is cooked. It gets really busy at peak lunch hour though. So come early or late.

Pure comfort food within the city with some good bbq stingray going for $5+ that comes with rice and a fried egg, what joy!Another one of my favourite is their sweet and sour pork. It's sweet, it's sour and it's crispy! If you want Stingray yet not too sure about whether you can take the spiciness, ask them to have the gravy on the side so that you can dip however much you want, based on your own preference.Crowded during lunch so for an enjoyable meal, try dinner instead. For those who are particular about smelling like BBQ meat after a meal, take the seats outside instead of within the shop. :)

I ate here a few times a month when i was working nearby, there is always a good lunch crowd. The BBQ Stingray is okay. My guess is that the sauce is just laced on top, at times it's just not BBQ long enough. I believe this is to reduce the waiting time.

Very good quality.For a party of five, we ordered the duck, sea cucumber, pork jelly, liver fritter, prawn fritter, cabbage, and yam desserts.Damage $210The soy duck slices is thicker then the usual restaurant, but more flavourful. Chewy and provide a good bite to start the meal. The sea cucumber is not spicy although it does look the look, flavour tends to be bland like typical teochew dishes. My surprise is the pork jelly. Made from bits of the pig head, probably chips of ears and cheek, boiled to jelly and cooled to blocks of jelly and sliced. A teochew delicacy for those with acquired taste. I like the fritters; deep fried liver wrapped in soya skin, and the prawn fritters. They are probably the strongest in terms of taste.The cabbage is delightful, and washes down the bowl of rice. Strands of hair-like fungus, lumpy soya dough and mushrooms made this dish too common; a lack of expensive ingredient type of dish.Dessert of yam and pumpkin is lovely, and sweet water chestnut is refreshing.

Ask any teochew, it is unlikely that they don't know Hung Kang. It has been a mainstay traditional teochew restaurant for more years than most can remember.Food wise, it is a hit and miss these days. Some of the traditional dishes still totally hit the spot but others are not as good as it used to be.On the most recent visit, we loved the pomfret hot pot with its awesome soup broth, and the oyster porridge. Both dishes I would happily eat again.Last 0.5 stars is for nostalgia and just for being teochew.

This is a mainstay of Teochew cuisine and from experience, I can say it's got the best value-for-money set meals if you come with the entire family. I've been eating here for years and really love the pomfret (also yummy in a porridge), braised goose and the unbelievably crisp suckling pig (call before to make sure they reserve one for you). This is not big on ambience but worth a short walk from Raffles Place just for the food. Spotted: Celebs, top bankers and politicians who dine incognito on the second floor.

Roll Up is an indian kebab place that hits all the right notes. They were rather generous and let us try a couple of items.1) mutton wrap with masala fries. Oh wow. I liked the mutton - very flavorful! It had a spicy ending note which surprised me. It felt a bit like a salami because the mutton was rolled up. That's not to say it wasn't tasty cos it certainly was! The fiery masala fries were massively addictive. I couldn't stop reaching for them. 2) Pepper Chicken Tikka - now, my absolute FAVE of the night. It was very flavorful and not dry at all. It's likely to do with the fact that their meats are all smoked on a charcoal fried tandoor. Now, that is one of sealing the juices in so the meats are well cooked both in and out, and still retaining its natural flavors. Just beware. It is spicy but I love it. 3) fish tikka - another dish I enjoyed. Fish rubbed with spices. What more can I say? Get it. 4) achari chicken - it wasn't bad at all; in fact, it was good too, but just wasn't outstanding. I think its spicier cousins took centerstage. Perfect for those who don't like their chicken too stinging. And on to their beers. There will be the urge to get the Fucking Hell beer. (Yes it's a place in Germany). Cos of its name. Whilst good, resist it and get the awesome IPA. Honestly, I think I would go back JUST for the IPA. HahahahahaWith friendly staff, there's little to dislike about Roll Up. Its prices aren't the cheapest around, but I think it makes up for the fantastic food.

If you like your spices, Rollup has great wraps with masala fries(!)  for $11-$14.  We shared the fish tikka wrap and were wonderfully surprised by the huge piece of fish, the 2 sauces that accompanied it (a mint chutney and a spicey tomato).  The masala fries were also very good (and spicy) and definitely worth the additional $3 top-up (with drink included).  Great presentation and very nice service.You can get a wrap, drink, and fries for $11-$14, which is a great deal. They also have combo deals with beer. On tap, they had an interesting Norwegian beer.If you're walking around on a weekend night, looking for a good place to eat that's relatively inexpensive before heading to a bar, this is worth checking out.

Had a fish kebab roll at Roll up, and it was delicious. The fish was great, and the fries were nicely done. Seasoning was a little heavy for my tastes, but my friends liked it. Portions are large for the prices.

Harvest is currently my local haunt.Want a beer and a whinge while you watch the footy? Come to Harvest!Want a feisty local pushing happy hour buckets of beer onto your table and popping tops whenever you get moderately low? Come to Harvest!Want to pay no more than $6.50 a beer? Come to Harvest!Want to be where the action is any night of the week? Come to Harvest!Want to enjoy the heat while being close to the water? Come to Harvest!I've never eaten here and probably never will --- but for a beer or 10? Come to Harvest! Cos it's tops!

Everyone kept telling me "you're in Singapore, go somewhere and get the chilli crab!"... so after an evening wander I ended up out the front of Harvest Seafood Restaurant.Look, the food isn't the greatest, but it isn't bad either. If you choose to give the chilli crab a go, have it spicy. The mild is very 'meh'.And, this place is expensive. A pint of Tiger beer cost me $14. For. A. Beer. Wasn't happy about that, especially with the amount of competition along the water.The waiters were attentive and seemed happy enough, but the other stuff does offset that.

Great seafood place. Ordered salted egg yolk crab and chilli crab along with other side dishes. The Sri Lankan Crab was huge. If you are bringing a family of 6, two crabs will be more than enough. Price was reasonable and the restaurant was along the river and have a great view of the Fullerton Hotel.
Pretty chill spot on Boat Quay. I purchased a Singapore Tourist Pass earlier in the week that allowed me 1 free drink here. Nice spot to sit on the river and enjoy happy hour.

My company and I enjoyed the view sitting outside while sipping on the Singapore Sling. The bar seems to be more populated late night and there are quite a number of tourists. The drinks were not watered down, so that's a plus! There are a variety of snacks for those who prefer eating and drinking. Looks like a fun spot to hang out with some friends.

address: 16 Circular Rd #01, Serangoon Garden Singapore 049372 Singapore
comment: OK I guess. Service good but food so so. I had standard Thai fare like chicken with cashew nuts. It lacked flavour and the chicken was tough. But I had a much better experience two nights before and that's why I returned. I'd prefer to give 3.5 stars.

address: 16 Circular Rd #01, Serangoon Garden Singapore 049372 Singapore
comment: We checked out the website and were intrigued by the menu.  Upon arrival we were very disappointed to see that the place was quite rundown.  All the dishes were overly seasoned and not authentic.  It was quite a surprise.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: This was great!  Oh man...that Black Pepper Crab is the bomb. Delicious, so flavorful on the pepper without being too much heat (spicy, not hot). Savory, just the right salty, and tons of meat in the crab. I got the Sri Lanka crab, but if you have the budget, there's Alaskan King as well. The service was wonderful. Checked on me several times. I'm so glad I took them up on their offer to tie a bib on me. :)They were upfront on the pricing. It's listed on the menu and they worked with me to find a crab and weight/kg that was ok for me.Great view, sitting right on the water looking at the river and Marina Bay Sands.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: TOURIST TRAP - You are paying a premium for the location. Make sure you ask the price and total weight for items that are marked market price. Remember the market price they give you is per Kilo. Some items on the menu do not come out looking the same in the picture menu. There are better tasting places in singapore minus the view. 1 star for the view and 1 star for the live seafood in the front of restaurant.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: Got offered 30% off bill and free drinks to lure us in the door.  Sat down with family ordered two 2kg chili king crabs 1 pitcher of beer, Singapore sling, bread.  Got charged over $3300 SGD.  Yes $3300.  Thats over $2400 in US Dollars for 10kgs of salty, chewy crab.  Complained about the bill, male and female owners get loud said we misunderstood the broken english.  Brother pays with credit/debit card out of embarrasment.  We get back to the USA, called (cost another $70 in phone charges) and emailed a bunch of Singaporean governmental tourist agencies (CASE and STB) to complain and was told that Tian Tian fishermans pier would like to offer a one time 10% goodwill refund ($110) in cash but we have to pick it up in person at the restuarant.  Wrote a letter and complained to Singapore tourism board and consumer association of Singapore stating that $110 dollars is not worth the 23 hour flight or the money spent to fly there again.  Was told the 10% goodwill refund offer made by Tian Tian seafood restuarant still stands.  So basically, they are all in it together, scamming tourist like us.  The entire boat quay area is a scam.  Google it and youtube it.  I wish I did before I stepped foot in that thieves den.  Spread the word, share this and lets watch these thieves starve when hard working tourists like us stop falling for their traps. Come to find out after all the research.  Tian Tian seafood restuarant uses the same menu from the old Forum seafood restuarant that was shut down for scamming tourists a couple of years back.  Same owners same operation, different name. Google forum seafood in Singapore and you will see the scams being pulled on hardworking tourists.  Im 100% certain these are the same crooks.Here is the link:  mothership.sg/2014/05/to…

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: Sat here for the view and it seemed like there were more ppl here than anywhere else... Deceiving. It's wasn't bad... But it wasn't very good either. I ordered the Thai Curry and it seemed watered down. Just OK for the price. My side of veggies didn't arrive until after i was done with the curry which was inconvenient and no apologies were made. Service wasn't all that great either so I'd recommend elsewhere unless you are here for the view!

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: Total tourist trap. Terrible service. Nickeled and dimed for everything; I swear I wouldn't be surprised if we got charged for our napkins. Portion sizes were a joke. You're paying to hang out on Boat Quay and that's it. Stay away from this place, folks.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: there are so many places to get crab and seafood at Boat Quay and Clarke Quay this is not worth the extremely high price. the hard sell is especially aggressive but if you ask, they'll give you free beer if you eat there. but I never will again. one extra star for the free beer

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: Eat here if you have the money to get scammed. A lobster will cost you $500+. The servers will pull you over and ask you to eat at their restaurant. I was foolish enough to fall for a free bottle of Tiger Beer. The food was horrible for its price. Everything on the menu was pretty much $100+. They will push you into getting expensive items. The price is by grams so don't be fooled by their 50% discount because even with the discount, each item will easily break $100+. Water is tap and their service is horrible. They even charge for the table cloth. Just another reminder, go here if you're rich and lack taste buds.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: Over priced, menu does not reflect what is on offer (don't be fooled with the pictures) and food not great. Couldn't get into Jumbo Seafood and ended up here. No napkins, two little packs of towel wipes provided. Naturally after eating seafood, you'd use them. You are actually charged for them.Dining companion got chilli chicken with red onion skin in it. The hard stuff. Minute bits of chicken, not even the equivalent of a thigh. I had one prawn. One. Free peanuts not free, poor food, expensive and avoid!

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: I wish I didn't have to give them any stars! We visited Forum Seafood on the evening of July 24th. The guy standing in the street convinced us to come sit down because he would give two rounds of free drinks. Upon sitting, we were told we could only choose between a Tiger beer, house white wine, or soft drink.They then delivered us a plate of peanuts and ever mentioned that you actually paid for the peanuts. Then when we ordered our drink and appetizer, we tried to get the guy to go away and let us look at the menu. He wouldn't leave. Instead, he continued to pressure us to order the crab. So finally, we did. Thank goodness we only ordered one crab. The prices were so ambiguous and were hard to understand and we were never given even just a moment to try and understand it all. When we got our bill, we understood why! We were charged $208 per kg, and supposedly we ordered 1.7kg (or 4 lbs of crab). Maybe with the shell it would have been .5 kg but there is no way that we had that much! And we sure as hell would not have ordered the crab if it was even over $40 per kg!!!This restaurant obviously makes it's money off of one time guests who are severely overcharged to such a point of shock and disbelief. Stay away!!!

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: Ridiculously overpriced and terrible service. Food tastes ok but it's 100% not worth the price. Prices on the menu are per 100g and crabs will allegedly weight around 1.5kgs so you could end up getting charged 150 sgd for a single crab. Total tourist trap.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: The meal I felt was over priced for the results. I should've read the reviews before dining here. There are 40 other restaurants in this area, all within a few meters, and I chose the one that looked popular, big mistake. Bland and small portions for the price.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: We have never eaten here because we do not like the "hustle" that employees are "required" to perform to attract customers. A truly good place will attract customers on the merits of its food & service. No hustle needed. Having said that however, we do periodically stop here for drinks because of the view, & the personnel are all very friendly & service-oriented. The food served always looks good & well presented, but the seafood is far higher than similar restaurants. Local dishes on the contrary, are not priced as high & provide better value.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: These people try to scam you. Multiple tables argued their bill. Plus beware of the actual price of crab - they quote per 100g, with the crabs going for 1.5-1.7 kilos. So at 30 SGD you can easily eat a 500 SGD for a crab - a piece of info that is easily missed.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: Dont go here. Good food. Not amazing. Bad service. They barely checked up on us and were very slow on basic requests like asking for a refill on water. WAY OVERPRICED. 130 for a fish?? No. That's ludicrous. I hate that i wasted my time and money on such a meal. Don't recommend this place.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: This is a price scam place!They will entice you with some free beer options -- and then scam you on the price of the food. The menu is misleading, and prices are listed on a "per 100 gram" basis. This detail is easily missed. They then bring you a 1.5KG item and charge you USD250 for a so-so lobster or crab you did not even want. Highly avoidable unless you watch the price like a hawk.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: I wish there was a way to say this place has no rating at all. These guys are just trying to make their money by ripping off all the tourists that walk past their restaurant. While the menu seems attractive, the food is the worst ever you would ever have in Singapore for the price you pay when the cheque arrives. Well, you actually end up paying more than what you would pay at a 5 star hotel.  Never fall into their free drinks and discount trap if you ever walk past their restaurant.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: I had to threaten the owner with calling the police because they overcharged us so much. The waitress told us we would be getting 2 crabs that weighed a total of 1.25kg, but they charged us for 3 kg, 1.5kg each.  The waitress explained to us that they could not possibly charge 1.25kg for 2 crabs and I responded that is not what you told us before we ordered, then I told her there is no possible way that the crabs we ate weighed 1.5kg each.  I demanded to see a crab weighed, so the waitress picked up the biggest crab in their tank and showed it weighed 1.5kg. I then walked back to my table, picked up my plate of crab with the entire shell body of the crab we ate and showed her how much smaller it was. She said she would charge us 1.25kg each and I said no way. I asked to weigh the smallest crab they had on display, and it weighed 1.1kg and it was bigger than both of the crabs we ate. I then inspected their scale and I showed them that it was not set correctly and that it was weighing heavier than it should, they denied it, and I had to blatantly point it out to them.  I asked them how many other customers they had done this too and they did not answer.  They charged me for .8kg each and they acted like they were doing me a favor. This place is a total scam, absolutely no integrity. I am still thinking about filing a police report for fraud.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: Tian Tian 73, 74, 75 Boat Quay.  Avoid this place like the plague.  I can't say enough bad about Tian Tian.  Rip off with horrible service.  It's overpriced and the service is the worst.  Dinner was $120 for 2 "entrees" (if you can call them that), no salad, no appetizers, no dessert, entrees only.  I ordered Pad Thai $26.  The menu showed a large portion.  The waitress said if it was just for me, I should consider the small portion, which I did.  The small portion was the size of a small salad plate with very little Pad Thai on the plate, certainly not heaping like in the U.S.  And wait for it... the small portion was also $26!  I'm not a big eater but I was still very hungry afterwards and went out to a different restaurant for more food (after spending $120!).  The $120 dinner was served on plastic plates. There was trash strewn around the floor (napkins and wet towel wrappers) no one had any interest in picking up during the 2 hours we were there (yes 2 hours just to get an entrée).  The trash issue was particularly bad as it all ends up in the river the restaurant sits on.  My Pad Thai was brought out long before my husband's $72 chili crab (which they said was the smallest they had).  So my Pad Thai was cold by the time they brought my husband's dinner (and they weren't very busy this evening either, they just have no interest in good service).  I asked for lime for the Pad Thai as was shown on the menu but they only had lemon.  When they brought the chili crab, my husband had to ask for a crab cracker (I'm not really sure how they thought he could eat a whole crab without a crab cracker).  I had to actually get up and ask for a fork TWICE!  Later my husband had to get up and hunt someone down to ask for the bill.  Then he had to get up and deliver the bill to them.  If you're counting, that's 4 times we had to get up and round up a server.   To go with the $72 crab they suggested 2 small buns for which they charged $4.  They couldn't even provide bread with a $72 crab!  Then they also charged us .60 cents for the wet wipes for after eating a crab in googey sauce with your hands.  To top it all off, the Pad Thai was among the worst I've had but what did I expect for $26 on a plastic plate?  The ONLY good things were 1. the Chili Crab was good and 2. they offered a "free" Welcome Drink. But THAT was it, everything else was awful.

rest_name: Tian Tian Fisherman’s Pier Seafood Restaurant
comment: Got the steamed red Garupa fish which ended up costing $130 along with three Thai sides. Fish was served cold. I would never eat here again, just avoid it at all costs...

address: 3 Canton Street #01-01, off Boat Quay Singapore 049745 Singapore
comment: This is a fun bar located along many others at Boat Quay.  All offer the same beer and liquor selection but this venue is particularly high energy, plays decent music and has indoor and outdoor seating.

rest_name: Ah Ter Teochew Fishball Noodle Bar
comment: a routine morning walk took a turn for the delicious!my little bird heard through the blogging grapevine that a new noodle bar has graced the boat quay scene.the opening hours (7am-1am, yes, please get it right for the business listing) was a perfectly timed breakfast destination reward after burning up essential calories to get here.it was well worth it, i would probably recommend walking back after you indulge in a bowl here.as for myself, i avoided finishing up my dry mee kia just because i didn't want to feel guilty about not walking back.of course the observant staff, part of the extended family of ah ter(yes, that is his name, and involves the chinese character 'pig'), wanted to know if their noodles were not tasty?it was a little stodgy for my liking but the taste was good.a delicate balance of spiciness, sweetness and tartness.a classic it's not you, it's me.but i do love the soup!one sip and you will understand.   i was quickly adviced that i can simply order soup with ingredients sans noodles, which i did on my second visit.special mention has to go out to their pig's liver!perfectly cooked with an initial crunch which gave way to tenderness.no lingering powdery feel whatsoever that may haunt the memories of those who simply hate liver.no complains whatsoever about the quality of the ingredients used and i polished up the soup on both occasions!adding a drink to make it a set is a no brainer and their soya milk is my recommendation.available in original, matcha or black.all organic, low in the sugar department but high in my books.you need to come after 5pm, if you want to try their side dishes.and kindly note that last order for noodles is at 2.30pm.they close between 3-5pm.i'm guessing that is when they transition into a bar.yes, alcohol will be served then, they are after all located in boat quay, so.noodles will then be available again from 5-8pm.i'll definitely have to come back during this timing to see how they keep things going till 1am, way past my bed time to be honest.but one thing is for sure, ah ter's 60 year old legacy will continue.......
Amazingly fresh sushi delivered straight from Tsukiji market in Tokyo. Fantastic service and amazing food. Just like eating in a high end Ginza sushi restaurant.

Extremely good value for money set lunch in town. $88++ gets you a set of 10 sushi (including a 3-pc Maki), a salad, a cooked fish dish, small chawanmushi, soup and dessert. The sushi is made one by one, paced to your appetite. Overall the sushi is good, love the fish to rice ratio, rice is at room temperature and to be, quite balanced in taste such that the fish can shine.  Most memorable for me was the Maguro zuke sushi. The fish was so savory and tender, melts in your mouth sounds so overused but it really was. If any gripe, there's hardly any interactions at all with chef perhaps due to the fast pace lunch setting. So no introduction to the fish unless i asked.

rest_name: Jin De Lai Zhong Hua La Mian
comment: The spicy fish with handmade noodles on top is a dish to die for - the noodles were so delicious and the spicy fish dish was awesome. Perfectly spicy without it being overpowering with a good mix of tofu, vermicelli noodles, and fish.I have a picture of the dish - it's big enough to serve 2-4 people and *I think* you have to ask for the extra noodles heaped on top but they give it to you free of charge. It's true they only speak Chinese here and my fluent colleague ordered everything while I happily ate what was placed in front of us, but next time I'm going back and just pointing at the picture I took of the dish.Feel free to use this picture to order, this is my gift to you Yelp! bit.ly/WektgqFish without noodles on top yet: bit.ly/XPYnjKNow go eat!

rest_name: Jin De Lai Zhong Hua La Mian
comment: 24 hour layover in Singapore - where do you choose to get dinner?  Someone suggested this area for a lovely view with dinner, which is exactly what each of the restaurants on the strip offer. The hardest part is making a selection because there are tons.  We chose this spot because there were lots of people that didn't appear to be tourists eating there - and the portions looked big!Food and view was point on... The pan fried dumplings and beef and green beans were the highlight... Beef was tender and delicious but the portion wasn't as big as we had hoped.  The large family style portions we were seeing people order only came in one chicken dish that nobody wanted to order (especially me bc I'm not a huge fan of chicken). We asked if this was offered for any beef or pork dishes but the answer was NO.Overall I was happy with the food but still hungry for a pricey meal.

rest_name: Jin De Lai Zhong Hua La Mian
comment: There are so many choices for food in Boat Quay - this place is great for Xi'An style Chinese food. We had the 肉夹馍 which we call "Chinese Hamburgers" which are nicely toasted buns smashed with delicious marinated pork in the middle! Then we had green beans, and Liang Mien (phenomenal, vinegary, COLD noodles), which is awesome for the warm evenings. And finally we ordered a "Small" dish of a traditional Xi An dish, which consisted of chicken, potatoes, celery, and a bunch of other stuff cooked together!

rest_name: Jin De Lai Zhong Hua La Mian
comment: I'd say it's the best Xi'an food in Singapore. Quite cheap for their food. Very good You Po Noodles and Lamb Pao Mo.

rest_name: Jin De Lai Zhong Hua La Mian
comment: This is a real hole in the wall, totally incongruous with the tourist traps lined along Boat Quay. Who'd have thunk that there'd be an authentic Chinese restaurant specializing in Xi An cuisine along the stretch that pushes mostly seafood? In testament to its authenticity, its servers are mainland Chinese, as is the bulk of the restaurant's clientele. I had the "La Zi Ji", which was a huge dish liberally sprinkled with peppercorns and dried chili. To peg it as very spicy is to be extremely kind, which explains why there's a big jug of water placed on each table. And of course, in a Chinese restaurant, traditional drinks are in order. Not tea, but Tsingtao beer! It's lightness only serves to complement the heaviness of the accompanying dishes, and goes down easily. Prices are very fair, and it's worth a revisit if you can forgive the pokiness of the restaurant and expat overload of Boat Quay.

Nose-to-tail eating doesn't seem to have taken off in the majority Chinese populated Singapore. I find it strange because we Chinese are (supposedly) familiar with offals and innards (hello kway chup), so much that we even eat that for breakfast (sometimes). It thoroughly surprises and bewilders us that a gorgeous Spanish restaurant like Dehesa isn't packed every night (like Esquina). Perhaps they have gone overboard with their marketing of their "inner" beauty? For those who are intimidated by the alternative cuts and random parts, your fears are unfounded. Chef-Owner Jean-Philippe Patruno aka JP, previously of Bomba Paella Bar and Una, fires up more than just the grey matter. Classic Spanish dishes are available here and he's more than adept at delivering them. I let my weakness for Croquetas (4 pcs, $14) take over and swooned in bliss as I bit into the creamy filling encased in the crunchy panko crust. This is one smooth morsel! Make sure you give it a good chew together with the spiced paprika aioli and jamón joselito. I struggled with my need to finish this and saving space for my main meal. That should ease you into starters. If you don't go into the nitty gritty, the Dehesa platter of cold meats ($32), is what you would likely order at any other restaurant- a rotating homemade charcuterie consisting pate, lardo, deep-fried pork scratchings. We all know where the ingredients are from, we don't need to be told/reminded, other than how good they taste. Well if that doesn't go down well, take a few bites of the smoky Pimientos De Padron ($14). They will sure cleanse the palate of any gamey leftovers. If you're not for the cold platters, have the Chorizo ($24) which is served with soft cooked eggs and a smoked mash, and pork crackling! This comfort food combination never fails. If only I could find some bread to go with this.The Dehesa Octopus ($28) was one of my favorites! The tentacles were tantalizingly tender and well seasoned. They are served on a bed of crushed creamy potatoes with some sour bits (I couldn't figure out they were pickles). A thin slice of lardo (cured lard) tops the dish and is torched upon service. This provided a salty smoky note to the dish. Too good!!From the Specials menu, we had the Figateddu Pork Sausage ($17) which is made with blood and liver.  We were warned of the strong flavors but I was more  shocked by the how salty my dish was. The liver and blood part was a walk in the park really. It was tasty no doubt, especially that crunchy potato galette which is like a deep-fried Kouign Amann! To balance the saltiness, have one of the vegetable dishes. We had the light tasting Beets ($24) which featured a round of fresh burrata with pickled beetroot and toasted walnuts. Mild it was, but we needed to calm our tongues before moving on. Another highlight of our dinner was the Squid Ink Arroz ($28 serves 2). The short grain Cebolla rice has absorbed all the lovely seafood flavors and then topped with an umami-rich seafood sauce. Superb seafood on that lightly spiced black rice btw.From the Specials Menu, we also had the Braised Beef Cheeks ($36) with an Oloroso glaze. The meat was well flavored by the red wine and had a gelatinous texture to it. We also had the Bone Marrow ($34) served with sea salt. Well i absolutely don't get the appeal of bone marrow. It's tasteless! Anyway, the one at Dehesa was bland and oily for me. Perhaps it has to do with the way it's prepared. If the bone were sliced into halves, the fatty collagen would be flavored more easily. Instead of the bone marrow, i'd go with the Crispy Suckling Pig ($65 quarter/115 half/199 whole pig) next time. Try it and let me know! For the whole pig, make sure you place your order beforehand.For desserts, we had the Melon Sorbet ($14) which was spiked with negroni! This is made in house by Chef daily and i liked that it wasn't too sweet. Dehesa also has a Daily Tart on the menu and it was Apple Tart ($12) when we visited. The soft caramelized apples were almost jam-like and i enjoyed the tartness of the fruit. We were pretty sure there's some alcohol in this! Please go visit Dehesa if you want a good Spanish meal! I'm not paid to say good things about them but i really feel that they are super underrated. There's no need to be intimidated by the nose-to-tail concept really, Dehesa is that and more.

Go go go!! Solid Spanish food with fresh ingredients and a very high level of creativity.This review is specifically on lunch.I've gone here twice after my Ritual workout next door and am in love with this spot. I order the following:1) Jamon Croquettas - SO GOOD!! Much better than the other Spanish restaurants I've had in Singapore.2) Pulled Pork Sandwich - Best pulled pork sandwich I've ever had in my life. They also give homemade potato crisps with this which is also on point.3) Pandan Ice Cream - Pandan Ice Cream at a Spanish restaurant? What? Regardless, this was a nice touch.Highly recommend checking this place out since it only just opened. Great service and staff, intimate and comfortable setup. Will be back soon!

Had dinner at Dehesa last June when we were back visiting from LA. Came back again this past Thursday evening for dinner and thought I should write a review since there was only one previous review.The food is very solid Spanish cooking. Chef Jean-Philippe is a very gracious host. Started the evening with several Spanish white wines: - Gewurztraminer, light floral with dry finish, very different than most I have drank. - Sauvignon Blanc, lighter finish than most Sauvignon Blanc if you are used to New Zealand Sauvignon Blancs.- Chardonnay, never had a Spanish Chardonnay before. I think this may be un-oaked. Definitely my favorite of the evening.Appetizers:- Pimentos De Padrones: blistered peppers, very similar to Charred/Blistered Shishito peppers which is what I am most used to. 4/5- Jamon Joselito: not much I can say since the Jason speaks for itself. 5/5- toasted bread with Aioli (not sure of the name of the dish since I do not think it was on the menu) 4/5- toasted bread with anchovies: love this dish since anchovies on anything makes it taste better. 5/5Jason Croquettas: very good croquettes served with Aioli. 5/5- Gambas Ajillo: everyone loved this dish so much we ordered seconds. The bread served with it was good for soaking up the delicious garlicky sauce. 5/5- octopus topped with lardo: the lardo was thinly sliced and flame torched. Very unusual dish. 4/5- crab Paella (not on the menu): Chef JP made this for us and was delicious! Nice Socarrat (the crusty rice at the bottom of the pan) which is a good sign that this is a good paella. And it was. The crabs were cut in half which makes eating it much easier. 5/5Pork skin tagliatelle: This was a special on the blackboard. It is pork skin that has been steamed and sliced to be like pasta and tossed with a ragu of some kind. It was okay, seemed like a lot of work to make something look and have the texture of pasta. 3/5- Cotes De Boeuf: the beef was nicely cooked medium and served with thick fries. By now we were very full after so many dishes. 4/5- radish/pear/pomegranate salad: this was our only vegetable dish. 4/5Deserts were definitely the chef's strong points. We shared 3 deserts off the menu: - torijas/plum/Creme fraiche. This was French toast that I believe was stuffed with mascarpone. Served with sliced plums and crime fraiche. 5/5- Laredo flan/ caramelized pancetta. Excellent! 5/5- chocolat/olive oil/salt: This was chef JP's signature desert. On yelp you will find several pictures of this desert. 5/5Service was excellent and food nicely paced. Highly recommended Spanish restaurant in Singapore.
Fantastic place. The one place on the riverwalk which doesn't try to drag you into the restaurant - simply because they don't have to.Great food, incredibly friendly staff, highly recommended.

Located in Boat Quay, Maharajah is a decent option for food. The ambiance is great considering you are right on the water, with great views on either side with the water ferries coming along every so often. The food tasted average, tending to be on the milder side, but I don't have much of a basis of comparison to other Indian restaurants in Singapore. The service was friendly and attentive. The prices were a bit on the high side, but worth it given the location in a lively part of Singapore right on the water.

Delicious meal in a beautiful spot right on Boat Quay.My colleague had a hankering for Indian food while we were in Singapore on business, so on a recommendation of a local, we headed here. We came on a Friday night and had to navigate our final way on foot as the streets were starting to close. We were immediately seated right on the water, which provided a great backdrop for our dinner.The menu was full of delicious looking options and we had a hard time settling on a few. Ultimately, we had the chicken tikka masala, black daal and one of the veg curries, with sides of rice and naan. The meal finished with a complementary scoop of mango ice cream. Service was friendly but missed the mark on letting our drinks go empty without asking if we wanted more. Definitely a picturesque setting for my last night in Singapore!
Amazing view and food was delicious.  Abit overpriced for what it is.  Curry portion is smaller and rice and naan both are extra.  I had curry, rice, naan and a coke and my bill was $41

this is my go to Indian place (when i cant make it to little India).I have never had anything that i dont like.  i find the service to be very good with a friendly staff.  the pricing is reasonable considering the location.  I always order the butter chicken, lamb vindaloo and then gobi and dahl... i have tried many other things but i am always drawn back to these staples

I love this place albeit its touristy location. The view is spectacular (get a table by the river), but the food is even more amazing. I had the lamb vindaloo, and lived every bite of it. Had some rice with it and a couple of plain naan breads. The naan breads were just to my liking, soft and moist. The Vindaloo sauce had just the right kick to it, and the lamb was tender to the point I could split it using my fork. A great dinner and a place I will always return to when in town.

It's taken me too long to write a review for the Maharajah. Have been going here on and off for the last few years. Always consistently good, with great service. While the long walk along Boat Quay involves running the "gauntlet" of people enticing you into their restaurants with free beer, the Maharajah is one of the few that does not do this. Instead they rely on word of mouth with great friendly service. Probable more in tune with what people from the UK view as Indian food, the Maharajah loses out in the authenticity stakes among the locals, but don't let that stop you from going. The menu is more North Indian and without exception is excellent quality. The "heat" levels are fine unless you decide to challenge the chef when ordering. Wonderful service, good value for boat Quay, great ambience outdoors with the cool breeze from the river and we liked it so much we had our reception there when we got married.
Loved the food here! Comfort food at its best. Also, the service is much better when compared to the restaurants around it.

Nestled in a cosy shop house along the waters of Boat Quay, this effervescent gem serves food like Don Quixote revives chivalry. Priding itself on fusion Spanish cuisine with Latin American flair, Charlie's offers a culinary experience complete with delectable BBQ grills and muy sabroso (very tasty) tapas. Expect to spend about S$10-20 on tapas and $20-40 on mains. Dig your fork into a plate of Gambas al Ajilo; herbed pan-seared prawns with garlic & paprika, and then wash the heat down with a Margarita - a real Numero Uno by my standards.Charlie's sits along the busy stretch of bars & restaurants along Boat Quay and is almost always busy on weekends. If you're planning to have dinner here with a big group, call ahead and book a table outside, complete with a view of the river. On level two of the shop house, Charlie's Paradiso takes you on a whisky tour with its fine selection of single malts, coupled with the toasty aromas of Cuban cigars. It's a lot quieter up here, making it perfect for intimate drinking sessions. Whats more? You can catch major sporting events, both upstairs and downstairs, on their thoughtfully-positioned flat-screens.

This is more a drinking place with 'more than bar food', rather than a proper restaurant. That said, the  food is not bad, and selection is pretty wide. Service is extremely friendly and efficient, even if some staff members are a bit blurred. Without the Entertainer 1-for-1 offer, not very good value; with it, more palatable.
Great place with some very unique spins on Spanish dishes. The squid ink Peaea was excellent,  and I highly recommend this dish. The rice picked up a nice smoky flavor.

When the sun finally came out on Sunday, I decided to walk over to Boat Quay, and sit along the waterfront for a late lunch.  On a side note, they are completely re doing the waterfront dining part, therefore construction was going on the entire time I was there.  It was around 3p.m. and ordered something fairly simple like nachos and a beer.  Beer came out right away, but the nachos took 40 minutes in which I had to ask my waitress 2 times where they were.  On the second time she admitted that for some reason the kitchen didn't my order (or you didn't put the order in) I was pretty hungry so I waited.....The nachos were def. sub par, and looked as through they had been under a heat lamp for 4 days.  Slow service, mediocre food, and construction on the patio.  I'll pass for now.

I had the rosemary lamb. The quality of the meat was good and they did a good job at cooking it. The atmosphere was great; I had a nice table right on the river. The service was also very good. I'd definitely come back.
The wine was good but the chicken cordon bleu was not up to par. $13 small magners vs $13 large magners next door at Red Dot

Came on a Saturday night. Service was polite, but very slow given the place wasn't packed. Food was okay, but nothing special. Nothing to complain about, but my visit wasn't memorable enough to warrant a second visit.  The area around Charlie's is amazing.  Tons of options and a a lot of activity.  Great place to watch people and have a meal or drink.

It is such a cute little shop offering simple yet pleasurable coffee and pastries. It is a close walk from the riverside and is easy to locate. The interior is clean and service was pleasant. I ordered a cappacino and Brie sandwich and they both were delectable. There were many patrons dot & dashing (see what I did there? ) as their service is extremely quick yet efficient.
Excellent pizza right in the middle in Boat Quay. I tried the sweet and sour pork (GLY) pizza - it was amazing!You've gotta try this place. Really good happy hour wine specials too!

Newly opened just 2 months ago, this place is perfect for a chill Friday night out. Good buzz, attentive & amiable servers. They highly recommended their pizzas, but we decided to go for the widely photographed/publicized Boston Lobster tagliatelle for sharing. It was as good as expected, fresh juicy lobster, paired with homemade pasta - left us stuffed. The calamari appetizer was excellent with the aioli, but slightly pricey for the serving. Seafood was very fresh though. Tried the ricotta castagnole too - would highly recommend, but do share with a bigger group. It does get a bit too heavy for just 2 people. However the little fried dough balls were glorious dipped in the alcoholic custard, complete with a burst of salty sweet ricotta in the middle. Bill came up to ~$140 for 2 for the above 3 dishes, without drinks. Will return to try their other dishes!

Second time we visited. All the dishes were wonderful except for the pasta. It was rather bland. It was not as good as we remembered it to be. Maybe the chef had an off day. Of special note though is the roast chicken. It really is to die for. Well worth the visit and will come again. #maneklady #manekeats

Good Italian spot on HK Street. This place = my definition of a solid 4/5 stars restaurant. Good food, good service, good wine selection though nothing wow. The highlight here is the pizza - very good dough with generous toppings. Other items - grills, etc. are standard - good quality ingredients with solid execution but nothing particularly notable.

I was surprised by the good reviews. The pizza was alright, the cod fish was abit fishy and tasted blend. And the heirloom tomato salad was so underwhelming. For the prices they charge, it was very disappointing and not worth the trip. We skipped dessert as the food wasn't good. Maybe we ordered the wrong food but we definitely won't be back again.

This was a lovely, chill place for Friday evening with an excellent ambiance. I arrived right around 10pm to catch the kitchen open for another 15 minutes or so. I got the Friday night cocktail special. The bartenders served some yummy spicy olives to start. I was told by the great bartenders to get the pizza. I was not disappointed! I got the pizza (I don't remember the name bc I was blinded by hunger) with the delicious prosciutto and finely minced basil and olive oil and ate the whole thing! #piggypower I also got an old fashioned with a new bourbon they'd just got in and it was phenomenal and didn't break the bank. The owner even shared with me all of the new wines he just brought in on the menu and was very informative and passionate about his work. Just go and experience this place. It's warm and relaxing at the bar!

If I can give Zero stars, I would.First, it took almost an hour for the food to be served. Out of 4 sets, only 2 of our meals were served. While we were waiting for the other 2 sets, LO and behold, Mr Cockroach decided to join us. It climbed across my lap and of course, I yelled and jumped out of my seat. We got moved out into the alfresco dining area while they sort out the cockroach issue. You would think that since there's a cockroach scare, they will replace our food with a new set, but no... They just brought out the sets on the table. We got tired of waiting this we just dug into the food, thank God we didn't get any food poisoning. Please note, while the above is happening, we were still waiting for the 2 remaining sets of food to be served. We were 3/4 into our food and the 2 sets were still not served yet.Finally after checking in a few times, then the food finally arrived. After all the ordeal, the recovery was a $10 off the entire meal and many apologies.I feel sorry for the staff cos I don't think they give bad service as individuals, but the experience overall was extremely terrible!! From hygiene to waiting time, it's truly overboard. So never will I be back again.
An authentic Korean BBQ near office. Feels like I'm in Seoul whenever I come here. Lots of Koreans come for meals too and I love the yuzu makgolli here
Nice retro decor. Friendly atmosphere. Warm and smoky. Food-wise, it is decent but could be better. I do find it on a pricey side. I would go there with a group for the fun rather than the food.

The best Korean BBQ you can get!!!  My Korean colleagues and I come here once a month or so whenever we have a get together and we love this place!  Awesome service, great food and reasonable price.  And if you reserve ahead, you can get a private space to eat.  I would highly recommend this place

Korean BBQ using real charcoal. Yum yum. Our group of 7 came here for dinner on Saturday night and it was pretty easy to get a table! We had a table in the room at the back of the restaurant. The meat portions here are pretty small, so each serving is good for 2 people if you order other food too.Spicy marinated chicken - OK.... but I'm not a fan of BBQ chicken usually.Red wine marinated pork belly - This was pretty good. You can taste a little of the red wine marinade.Pork shoulder butt - No idea if this is a mis-spelling or mis-translation. It was a little fatty so I'm guessing its the pork shoulder? Haha. This was pretty good, especially if it is a little burnt and crispy ;)Cold noodles - Yummy! Came with lots of veggie too ;)Kimchi pancake - this was huge and way too much for 7 people to share. Nonetheless, it was really good.Seafood bean paste soup - Yummy. We ordered the small size, but was too stuffed by the end of dinner to finish this.They give you free flow of egg which they use to fill the BBQ grill plate at the side so you get grilled eggs (like the Japanese Tamago egg). Super yums.The bill came up to be about $20 per person which really isnt too expensive considering how much food we had. Definitely one of the better Korean BBQ around!

I think the Yelp address is out of date, the one I went to is at Marine One (a bit hard to find but view is great).Anyway, I thought it was a Japanese place but turns out it isn't, it's Kiwi.The lamb was great! As expected as it's a steak house. But the smoked salmon, that - was the stunner. Amazing!!! Almost didn't order it and so glad we did. Loved it. Starter and desert were also splendid.

I'll make this my very first Yelp write-up in Singapore. What can I say about Wakanui...?  I'm a New Yorker. I've been to Peter Lugers and Smith & Wollensky and can honestly say that Wakanui's 1,000 gram bone-in rib-eye can compare. This in itself is worth the price of admission. Dare I say that Wakanui has the Best Steak in Singapore. You Bet! Top it off with a New Zealand Pinot Noir and I promise you'll be in heaven.

I'm pretty sure Chaun L. must be crazy. I've been to Wakanui three times and each time was delicious!There are two things that are a must on my list, 1. Ocean view steak (1 kg please!) 2. Lamb. I'm torn between these two red beauties. One bite of the lamb and I swear it's better than the steak. One bite of the steak, and I swear it's better than the lamb. I really can't make up my mind which was is better so you must order both! Here's the crazy part--the lamb is actually more lean than the beef! This is because Wakauni cures their beef for 40 days so all the meat stays nice, juicy, and fatty! Sounds a bit weird, but fatty steak is a good steak! And I'm talking about the good kind of fat here not the cheap kind found in a dingy Chinese restaurant.  A bit of meat and a bit of steak, simply heaven! The combo MELTS in your mouth. The sides are delicious as well and complements the meat. Mixed vegetables includes different kinds of charred veggies and the mushrooms are grilled with rosemary! For a good piece of meat, this place can't be beat. Some may even consider it to be cheap! I pay an average of $60-80 (depending on the bottle of wine) each time. Wakanui is the BEST place in Singapore for steak. The best. I'll see you there!
Food was normal, service too. My ribeye steak came well done instead of medium rare but the meat still taste good. Lamb was good.

This is a beautiful, more premium spot on Boat Quay with a specialized menu of meats and seafood.  For my taste the food was  too rich but was cooked perfectly and couldn't be faulted if that's the type of meal you are looking for.  The service was great.

I had such high hope for their dry aged beef. Alas, I was disappointed. We are outside, which was nice but would have preferred a steakhouse feel inside. Their sides dishes, ugh, I can't say anything positive so I will leave it at that. If you want meat, head somewhere else.

When you go to Wakanui, you stick to the meat.Stray away from that staggeringly beautiful steak or that world-class lamb and you might regret it.So the good? Steak and lamb. While the steak is delicious and we'll get to that in a bit, the lamb was possibly one of the best lamb dishes I've ever had. Flavourful, crisp, and succulent, I have dreams of that lamb, and they usually end with it being completely utterly devoured. The steak too is good, delivered as you want it, and tender and delicious. Beyond that? The potato puree was decent, the grilled vegetables, done as they should be.The Camembert on the cheese platter tasted like no Camembert I've ever had, and I mean that in as bad a way as possible. The New Zealand Kikorangi was excellent though, but the camembert was definitely a bad way to end the evening.

Ok, so upon my admission I did go to a steakhouse, and not eat steak, so use this review as you wish.I ordered 2 types of salmon starters, asparagus, eggplant and tomatoes sides and a whole seabass.The service was a bit slow, especially considering that we were seated on the second level and there were only 3 other tables whose meals were almost done with.The Veggies were ok. Nice, but nothing special The salmon starters were a bit too salty, and nothing fancy, and the seabass main was.....fresh. Nothing great, really.The dessert was a chocolate mousse that was essentially a huge kit kat Bar. That was nice! Not too sweet and not to chocolaty.Overall, I'm not impressed. It was average, but then again, I've been to some pretty spectacular steakhouses on a regular basis....and have eaten steak.As mentioned, our mains arrived around 45 minutes after our starters were served, after which my appetite died by then, so the overall experience was just average.

Honestly speaking, one of the best meals I ever had.  I cannot understate how good the food is.  Rack of Lamb cooked medium rare to perfection.  If you are looking for a meat restaurant in Singapore it's worth seeking out this place.

This place is an incredible value.  The 500 grams of filet was delicious. Cooked medium with a great sear to it.  Followed with the lava cake that is well worth the price.  Service was terrific all night.   So far the best value I have found on a filet in Singapore.

Everything was just horrible.We went for restaurant week for the $40++ set. Starter bread was ugly. Like it was torn by hand instead of being cleanly cut. The salmon carpaccio was served on a plate that was not wiped clean of oil. The taste was not memorable. The main was a 150g steak that did not look appetising, total absence of grill char. The potatoes that came with it were dry with a hint of bitterness. Strongly recommend anyone to not come here.
Fantastic!   The food, service, ambience all excellent and the price is "Singapore reasonable". I think the meat is great quality and immaculately cooked and served.

address: 5 Raffles Pl #B1-63 Raffles Xchange Singapore 048618 Singapore
