comment: Waa Cow!  was known for its beef rice bowl but located far in NUS. It finally opened another outlet which was called Waa Cow! Sushi Bar in the city. Although it was called sushi bar, there was no sushi available when I visited the outlet.Regular Aburi Wagyu Beef (S$19.90)Premium Wagyu beef cooked sous vide for 24 hours, Wagyu beef bone sauce, Onsen egg , Tobiko, picklesTopup S$2 for Mentaiko (Torched Pollock fish roe)Topup S$3 instead usual S$5 to make it Set Meal B ( consisted of Salmon Sashimi (3 pieces) & a drink), when one liked Instagram page.Seem to lack the "Wow" factor comparing to the last time I had it. Would prefer more sauce and thicker slices of meat. Serving was quite small, just half of the bowl. Feeling not full after having it.

address: 5 Raffles Pl #B1-63 Raffles Xchange Singapore 048618 Singapore
comment: A hidden gem my sister and I found while walking around Marina Bay Area. The rice bowls were really good! I had the salmon mentaiko while my sis ordered the foie gras wagyu beef bowl. Both came in generous portions and my salmon was done just right (still moist and pink) It also serves water for no charge unlike some other establishments in CBD. Then again its casual atmosphere also meant that some diners stayed longer to chill and relax while catching up with friends post circuit breaker in Singapore! You might have to wait a bit for a table inside unless you don't mind sitting outside in the Singapore humidity.

A bunch of us were craving for Korean food and we decided to check out Superstar K upon the recommendation of my Korean friend. If a Korean says its good, it must be good right? The BBQ was super awesome! The best I have eaten in Singapore so far! The pork belly is thick and succulent! We also ordered the spicy chicken and Kimchi soup which was very rich in flavour. They were also very generous with their side dishes which was good because I finished one plate of kimchi all by myself! Love the service too! The waiters and waitresses served us with a smile and was very accommodating with our requests. All in all, a very nice experience for me and my friends!

I had the chicken tikka masala and my friend had the butter chicken. Neither were particularly good. Four small pieces of chicken in each for S$22. The service was laughable. If this place wasn't on the river in Boat Quay it would be out of business.

The maze soba (dry noodle) is way better than the soup ramen. I had the usual ramen before and while it was good, the dry noodle topped it. I ordered the Nagoya style maze soba and it came with plenty of spring onions, seaweed, minced meat and a half boiled egg. The sauce was spicy and tasty. Add the fried garlic (available on the table) for another dimension to the taste. I felt like I was eating a Japanese version of Singapore bak chor mee (minced meat noodle). The yolk broke and coated the noodles with the gooey goodness. I was not sure if that also made the meal even more filling as I was full 3/4 into the noodles. I only wished the egg was not cold. A tiny bowl of soup (rich pork broth) accompanied the dry noodle. I would order this again.The chicken karaage was also good, based on my previous visits. Note:Lunch time ordering is different from dinner. During lunch period, place your order at the cashier and make payment first. It makes sense as you will save time since you can just eat and go, instead of wasting precious minutes waiting for the bill. I believe there is seating available on the 2nd level during lunch time.

This place is as authentic as it can be in Singapore. It was on Saturday night and I think 80% of the patrons were Japanese. They serve refreshing beer!!As for the ramen, I had a soupy version. They also serve bakchormee aka dry version which I may try next time. So for the soupy version, I was disappointed it was chicken char siew. It was not as flavourful as I would like it to be, hence the 3 stars. The soup was still very savoury to me, that was for sure, a plus point in a ramen. However, there is definitely room for improvement for the chicken char siew. The waiting time was quite long. There was a shelf of manga to entertain yourself if you would like to browse. Another good point, that is it opens til 11pm. You know how bummed you are if you want to have some soupy ramen after drinks around the vicinity and everywhere has last order at 9.30pm.
This review is for Gyoza Bar, which is above and seems to be a part of this ramen shop. Food is great and the intimate,trendy atmosphere is nice too!

What's the best way to get over too many bowls of loudmouth soup the night before? A big bowl of Ramen soup from Suzuki today!This place is off the charts good and one of my favourite Ramen in Singapore!It's cash only, steers towards the expensive end of the market (it's on Circular Road no less) and at lunch times it's packed to the gills with guys and gals. Even with these challenges it's an easy one to recommend because the experience makes it all worthwhile.The menu is heavily customisable and you get some good options to go with. I almost always go the 5x spicy for that super kick, and salty because we are in the business of curing last night's mistakes. If you're a big eater you can plump for an egg and extra char siew to tide you over...Still hungry? There's help-yourself potato salad and a bowl of hard boiled eggs on the table to bang into your broth.If that doesn't satiate your hangriness then you shoulda gone the gyozas for starters - better luck next time rookie!

Had high hope for the tonkotsu broth but left disappointed.Ordered the kakuni ramen. This came with a generous large piece of pork belly. Unfortunately, the pork belly was not prepared well and also was cut along the grain and this results in tough, hard to tear off pork. The broth was  watery and they tried to make it up by whisking it (without much success). The broth was quite salty but did not have much flavor going for it. Noodle was thin hakata type and okay.Service was good.

The Broth is delicious! I didn't feel very well when I went to this place for the first time. But I was pleasantly surprised at how helpful the servers were. I didn't know what to order so I got a suggestion from the waitress. The food came out and it came out absolutely delicious. I would definitely, if in Singapore, will visit this place again.

Had to check it off the ramen list, and I'm glad to report it was worth it. Pretty close to Tonkotsu King in taste and presentation, so you kinda know what you're getting here. Rich, tasty broth, and thin noodles (i'm a fan - no udon for me) mean simple satisfaction in a bowl.Learn this lesson though: go early. REALLY early. I was there at 1205 and already there was a queue eight people deep. Made me wonder how early these people snuck off work.

Crazy lines at lunch time, so either come very early or very late.The ramen here is very thin. Thus, they have a tendency to get soggy if you are a slow eater. I ordered mine harder and it still retained a bite at the end of the meal. I presume any order softer than that may result in soft noodles towards the end.Broth is flavorful. On first bite, it doesn't come across as being too salty. Thumbs up for that. However towards the end, it did.The standard serving only comes with one slice of pork, but you do get to choose whether you want belly or pork loin. So it is great for the health conscious.Free flow of hard boiled eggs at every table and more free condiments like rice, cabbage, etc.I would eat it but I don't crave it.Cash only.

Pretty legit ramen joint in Boat Quay, popular with the office crowd.Had lunch here today and there was no queue at noon or during our meal, most likely due to folks still out of the office on the Monday after a 4-day CNY weekend. Perhaps the popularity has waned a bit, not sure.Kudos for all the free flow rice, seasoned bean sprouts, hard boiled eggs, and mashed potatoes along with busting out two types of Tobasco sauce without prompting.The place is cash only and you jot down your order on a paper order form giving your preference for noodle firmness, broth flavor strength, level of oily-ness, etc then pay at the front register before finding a seat.The spot seems popular with expat Japanese workers in the area which is always a good sign.Def worth a visit and I look forward to returning for lunch again soon.

One of my favourite ramen places in Singapore. (Even though this was our first time here) The spicy dipping ramen was just the right texture and flavour, a bit too many bamboo shoots but I'm a panda so that's okay. The second ramen we got was a massive shoyu ramen bowl. For the big boys, which consisted of a large amount of bean sprouts. The Shoyu broth was a bit tooo porky. The edamame was perféct, just the right consistency of hard and soft. Overall an enjoyable experience.

The tonkotsu broth is not as creamy, more on the watery side and it reminds me of Japanese-Taiwanese ramen. The noodles are thin. I ordered the Red version but its not really spicy. Overall the taste is ok, but if you refer a thicker broth and more chewy noodles, it might not be for you. The price is steep since its in Boat Quay

Me, together with my family, have been exploring some of the best ramen shops around Singapore and I could say that all of them are pretty good tasting. Some are really super delicious.Time now has come for us to visit and try Ramen Bar Suzuki's ramen, it was our first time. I'm excited and curious about the taste as I have read some good reviews about it. Reading all the reviews, it sounded to me as if it will overthrow my number 1 ranked ramen somewhere in Tanjong Pagar :) There was no queue at that time as we went there just about a few minutes after they've open. We ordered tonkotso ramen, our favorite broth.The ramen was then served, and this is my honest opinion; Presentation is fair. The aroma is not that intense. The ramen is not served hot enough. I stirred the noodles then took a first sip... The broth is definitely not so rich and not so creamy. The broth is a bit bland (I'm sorry).I hate overcooked and soggy noodles, but their noodles, though I chose "normal" texture, is way way undercooked. Anyhow, I dove in but I wasn't able to finish the broth. Overall, we're not satisfied with the ramen. The ramen we just tasted at that particular day and time was definitely not as per our expectations. Was it because they've just opened and the ramen was not yet ready for order?  Shouldn't be the case right? I don't know.Anyways, maybe I'll try it again next time and re-update my reviews.

So I got this ramen kick. Every day had to have one, tried many places but this one is my Favorite. Flavours are bold, make sure you get amber broth, limited to 10 bowls per day only. Service and ambience is fair. The only downside is cash only and the order forms can be a bit confusing for a first timer.

The queue is insane at lunch hours soooo go early! It's pretty decent, and comes with free flow of eggs and whatever side they have up on display at a side. A bowl is really satisfying on a nice cold day. Get there early if you work nearby! :)

Fresh Ramen with all of your special order fix-ins is GREATER THAN Dehyrdrated ramen from the grocery store.Came here on a Wednesday night around 8PM. The restaurant was full -but no line from what I could tell.  Each dinner gets to select his/her own soup noodle base + special order fix-ins (e.g extra meat, extra toppings, flavored soft-boiled egg, etc). If you're still not full from all of the noodles and yummy broth, then you can get your fill from the all-you-can eat shredded cabbage + dressing  and/or rice that your little tummy desires.  If you leave not feeling satisfied (and perhaps with some spots of soup splattered on your clothes), then shame on you!

Soup is thick and flavorful enough - Just how I like it. Char siew needs improvement though as it is quite difficult to chew, Recommendation is to get the Pure white special because you get 4 char siew and 1 flavored egg for only $13.00. Would be nice if they can add dipping noodles to their menu.

This is a dinky little ramen place smack right diagonal from my yoga studio, and what better way to nullify a hot sweaty workout than stuffing my face with carbs? RBS specialises in Tonkatsu ramen, with choices of white (original), red (spicy), black (squid ink), tsukemen (dipping noodles) or fish flakes. I opted for the white, and aside from the customisation available - taste, flavoured oil, noodle hardness etc, you can also partake in the hard boiled eggs and bean sprouts available. Hm, isn't that quite similar to a certain ramen place at Orchid Hotel, your though bubble visualises. Yes, but RBS manages to one up them by providing jugs of iced tea, fried pork lard and fragrant garlic chips at each table! That's pretty ingenious I think! And in addition, there's complimentary free flow of rice and shredded cabbage with homemade dressing to go with your remaining soup too, which makes this joint even more of a win.Taste test: I went with the white Tonkotsu and the soup base was thick and flavourful without being too oily as most ramen places are wont to do. Sure, a lighter touch is very much tweaked to Singaporean tastes, but hey, that's how I like it. The noodles are on the thin side, so I chose to have them hard (they also have a "harder" option) as I was pretty sure they'd get soggy in no time. And they did, so I'll opt for harder on my next visit. The char siew slice was thin, and I was a bit disappointed at that, but it was deliciously tender. What a crafty ploy to get customers to opt for the extra char siew version, but then again, it works! Extra char siew next visit it is. In addition, they also put in a kicker of a really cute Japanese chef - great eye candy and he's got the girls' votes. Er. Have I mentioned that I'll be going back?

3rd visitCaprese - fresh mozzarella, crunchy rocket and summer sweet cherry tomatoes Margarita pizza - good smokey char, chewy bread, homemade sauce This is one of my fav places for pizza, along with La Forketta in Dempsey and Limoncello.  Lovely waterside views.

This is a review of a dinner date at Enoteca L'Operetta.tinyurl.com/c3zzcp3The ambiance is quite nice.  As with other Boat Quay establishments, Enoteca L'Operetta offers a wonderful covered al fresco dining area.  It is an almost perfect setting for a meal.  The warm weather tempered by a slight breeze and fans.  There are lovely water views.  Plus, unlike some of the other nearby eateries, they incorporate a true white table cloth dining experience.  From this perspective, it is what I picture when I think of evening meals in Singapore.tinyurl.com/dyawmuftinyurl.com/c6qg4xrI also looked at the indoor seating.  it was definitely a room fit for fine dining supported by very large impressive pieces of artwork.The service was relatively good.  The staff was very friendly, polite, professional.  I felt there were some lapses in attentiveness.The food ranged from sub-par to very good.Bruschetta - This was the starter I selected for sharing.  It was very enjoyable.  The tomatoes were sweet.  There was just the right amount of olive oil.  The bread was soft so it absorbed the ingredients but it didn't become overly wet.  The portion was very generous.  I didn't think we would finish it.  But somehow, we managed.tinyurl.com/buz7bqkCaprese Salad - This was her selection for appetizer.  It was also a wonderful dish.  This time sweet tomatoes combined with a very nice mozzarella.  It came together quite well.tinyurl.com/bnzx8p6Pizza Margherita - As a second course, we shared a pizza.   The ingredients were fresh.  The traditional ingredients of a Pizza Margherita were all present, red sauce, mozzarella, and basil.   The pizza was a feast for the eyes.  However, I felt it was missing something.  It just didn't quite make it as a great pizza.  I thought the crust could use a little more flavor.  I also thought the flavours of the ingredients had not melded together.  Do not get me wrong, this was good pizza.  It just wasn't great pizza.tinyurl.com/cv5pafpSpaghetti AI Ricci Di Mare (Signature Spaghetti with sea Urchin, Grey Mullet Bottarga) - This was my dinner date's main course.  She simply did not like it.  The term she used was "disappointing".  Our tastes seem to usually be relatively closely aligned, so after hearing her response, I chose not to try it.  She did not eat very much of it either.It was a very well presented dish though.tinyurl.com/carhhauBraciola Di Maiale Alla Griglia (Grilled "Iberico" Pork Rack 400g Smoked in Cherry Wood) - This was my main course.  It was a enjoyable dish.  The pork was very tender, moist, and flavourful.  I particularly enjoyed the meat still attached to the bone.  If there was an issue, it was that in using the potatoes as a bed for the pork, they became a little too oily.  But that is a minor complaint.tinyurl.com/bsqv58eReceipt (dinner fro two - $416.66):tinyurl.com/d2ousqwOverall - The star of this experience is the ambiance.  If her main course had been as enjoyable as mine, this review would of included an additional star.  The starters were actually very good.  The pizza was good but not great.  The service was professional.  If there were not so many other wonderful restaurants to try, I might visit  Enoteca L'Operetta again.   I do think it is a restaurant that deserves some consideration when selecting a fine dining experience in Boat Quay.

I quite like the food here - awesome pizza, carpaccio, starters etc. Not a single thing I did not enjoy food-wise.Service was below expectations for a place like this. A waiter could not be had for minutes on end for the entire al fresco dining area. Diners were left impatient, waters not refilled.. oh well.
Favorite Italian restaurant in Singapore. Great service and lovely ambience. Recommended dish is the Bolognese Ragout.

Food was thoughtful and interesting, but service was lousy.  There was scarcely anyone tending the tables in the outdoor seating area, and we had to wait for over 45 minutes for the main courses, though the chef came out and apologised to us and offered free desserts in the end. They really need to hire more waiters.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-86 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Extensive menu, I was unsure what to order, so I asked the waiter what he would recommend. Well, he wasn't sure either. So I took a guess and picked a few things off the menu. Turned out to be pretty good food, BBQ meat yourself and it was kid friendly. So all in all a nice place to eat, with a nice view of Clarke Quay.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-86 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Haramiya at Central sells fresh and delicious meat items. I was there for the Japanese barbeque and was in love with it! The dip to go along was tasty, the meat fresh and juicy. More importantly, it's really 'smoke-free'! I did not have the unpleasant barbeque meat smell stuck on my clothes despite having quite a lot of barbeque items. I would recommend the Harami if you are looking at the barbeque meat. They also have the set ones if you would like. To satisfy both East Asian cravings, they also serve some Korean food items on their menu. The environment to dine in is also very nice. I love the ambience there. If you're there you'll know it. The other appeal is the price!  It is very affordable and reasonable. The last time I went I spent less than $20 and got filled to the brim.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-86 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Not exactly premium yakiniku but for the price point, I guess you get value for money.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-86 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Food is fresh and good. We really like the garlic chicken cheese fondue and the cheese bibimbab. The portion is just right and it is value for money. Paid about $20 per person and we are stuffed to the brimmed. Left the restaurant without the BBQ smells on our clothes. Will definitely visit again next time.

Live music nightly, outdoor seating, kitchen open until 2:30am.  The food was pretty good, but what made the difference was the coolest staff ever.  Ate there three times in a week for that reason alone.  Nixon and Jun (sp?) could not have been more friendly and accommodating, I'm sure you'll meet them when you turn up.

The Warehouse is located in the most central location of Clarke Quay where all the major "Food Streets" (for lack of a better term) intersect.  It is right in front of the main fountain, which is also the spot where street artists sometimes perform.  It also features live music nightly.This is definitely a great place to chill and hangout but the food was only mediocre when we were there.The Thai Style Chicken Satay was thinly sliced which is the way Southeast Asians do it (great!).  It was ok, but a bit bland and was overcooked so the meat was dry.The Golden Chicken Wings were better.  They were fried perfectly - crispy outside and moist and tender inside.  They also tasted better than the satay.This is probably not the best place to go if you are seeking a foodie experience, but it is definitely one of the coolest spots in town to soak in the atmosphere, the energy, and everything that is Clarke Quay.3 stars for the food; 5 stars for the location and the cool vibes; average = 4 stars.

This place is a must-visit in Clark Quay. The owners Rob and Karen are great, and their food (particularly the meat option) is some of the best in Singapore. Throw in solid live music and you've got a winning combination. It's also much more reasonably priced than other spots in Clark Quay. Do yourself a favor and swing by.
Great place for lunch. The owner was very friendly and sweet. Came back a few times while in Singapore. The best falafel I've had.

A cute, friendly vegetarian Middle Eastern place. I didn't like the food here as well as at Pita Pan in the Marina Bay Sands shopping complex, but this place is great for lunch breaks if you work in the CBD or near Chinatown. It's located in the charming little alleyway of shophouses near China Square Central and has both indoor and outdoor seating, but it's pretty small and crowded (especially at lunch hour!) so just be prepared.I loved that vegan options were clearly marked on the menu here. I got the falafel pita and a small side of brown rice with lentils. I enjoyed my meal, but the falafel pita was oddly spiced. The spices didn't taste right -- made the meal very inauthentic and didn't feel like I was eating Middle Eastern food at all. Non-garlic/non-onion dishes are also clearly marked for Buddhist vegetarians.Price-wise, it was reasonable but definitely "expat" prices if you know what I mean (what expat CBD workers and other snooty suit-types are willing to pay, not on par with what most locals are willing to pay). Most of its clientele seemed to be CBD professional types for this reason.Service was super friendly and smiley.

Best are the falafels, made with broadbeans instead of the usual chickpeas, although they are a bit pricey at $2.50 for a tiny piece. Friendly place with the Egyptian owner running the show himself. Hope the economics work out for them, as this location has high rents and they have lots of staff.

So good! My friend and I were looking for a light lunch and this place hit the spot. The staff here are super friendly, food was delicious, and the iced hibiscus helped round out our meal. Didn't think the prices were that unreasonable and would recommend this spot to anyone looking to get their hummus fix.

I really love this place. It's a real hidden gem in Singapore if you LOVE listening to very talented blues musicians. If you're a fan of music, GO FOR IT!The place is cosy and may be hard to get seats or table only a really crowded night. But other days when the crowd is "just nice" you'll be in for a treat! I loved how they readily accepted my request for some cucumber in my Hendricks Gin and Tonic! A perfect drink for a perfect evening!

Was here for a event on a Thursday. The place is just behind Timbre @Arts house. A pretty small and cozy area with a few tables in the alfresco. Not too sure if it's meant more for functions, cause noticed that opening days are just Fri an Sat. They served the usual timbre snacks like the duck pizza, chicken wings, truffle fries and nachos. Pretty ok I think! But still prefer the veteran Timbres.

Hold the phone, I haven't reviewed this place yet? The rotisserie is my go to spot for a quick and hearty take away lunch when I don't want to brave the crowds of Raffles Place looking for a place to sit or if I want to eat at my desk. The line can be long at times but moves quickly. The staff are fast and friendly. The food is good. A quarter chicken and your choice of 3 veggies or two salads for $12, nice! They have grab and go salads and wraps for around $9 each. So glad this spot is right downstairs. Big hug!

address: 14 Lorong Telok Boat Quay Singapore 049027 Singapore
comment: CHEATED BY PITA TREE. charged my card but no deliveryI ordered through their website for delivery on Jan 1st 6 pm they charged my card and sent me a confirmation mail. No one turned up till 7 pm and i called the restaurant but no one picked up. I know this is the same group that owns shabestan so i called them and a guy named Azad picked up and said he cannot do anything as Pita tree is closed but mentioned that I will get a call back from someone at Pitatree. It has been 2 days since Pita tree charged me SGD 101, did not deliver any food and I was embarassed in front of my guests. Forget about apology, not even a call back to resolve the issue and refund my money. worst management.tripadvisor.com.sg/ShowU…

Dropped by the Riverwalk area to renew EP/DP. We came a bit early and noticed Riverwalk Tandoor so we dropped in for a quick bite. We knew it'd be quick b/c it was a buffet style lunch for $16++.Came in with zero expectations but was pleasantly surprised by the food. I believe it's more North Indian fare but man, everything was delicious and well prepared. They did not skimp on the quality of the food. Ingredients tasted fresh and each dish carefully prepared.When you sit down they take your drink order (additional charge) and bring you a basket of the chewiest, warm, buttery plain naan ever. I could have filled up on them bad boys. I believe the naan is also free flow although one basket was more than enough for us.Highlights include the saffron rice, tandoori chicken, aloo gobi, daal, hmm I'm just listing everything I had.They also have a nice dessert section with fresh fruit and galub jamun. This was some good gj - not overpoweringly sweet, just warm enough and the right sponginess.The place was not busy when we came and the service was very attentive - removing used plates and refilling our drinks.Can't wait to find another excuse to come back to Riverwalk Tandoor!

This Indian restaurant has been at this location in town for a while, so presumably it is doing something right.I had the buffet, so it's a little hard to summarise the food. Suffice it to say that it didn't attain the full depth of flavour that Indian food capable of - the flavours were not intense or rich enough. Perhaps it was the food being served buffet style that caused the quality to suffer a bit Naan was served to the table (i.e. not taken off the buffet line). Yet the first round (presumably garlic) it was neither fresh nor warm and consequently was a little dry. The second round (presumably butter) was better and it was warm, and some liquid (which I presumed was butter) could be seen pooling.The vegetarian dishes were better than the non vegetarian ones actually. Perhaps because the meat wasn't good quality.The desserts were probably the best part of the experience.The gulab jamun was great. Usually gulab jamun is very nua (soft), probably because it's been floating in the syrup for ages. Here it was quite fresh and I could tell it'd been fried recently. It was also quite firm, and though it was rather sweet I could taste something other than sugar.The rice kheer was tasty too. It wasn't too sweet and I could taste the nuts and spices.All in all, this place is quite affordable, especially given the location and the food is passable. But if you're looking for good grub you should go elsewhere.Service here was good. Our water was refilled often and every time I came back from the buffet line (which was really near) my old plate had been cleared.

We were looking for good Indian food close to our hotel without having to go all the way to Little India. We chose this place and were quite happy! The buffet was good and with plenty of choices. I had the mango lassie and it was probably the best I've ever had. The tandoori chicken was good and the paneer was really good. There was a fish dish that was really nice and tender. We felt the spice was just perfect for the food - not too hot, but with enough to make the flavor stand out. We were pleasantly surprised  with how yummy this place was. The service was great and the waiters were very attentive.  We'll come again next time we're in town.

S$ 29.90 for dinner buffet? Seriously? I have had dinner in Brars of Toronto (brars.ca/restaurants/gra…) which had more than 75 dishes for dinner for just 22 Canadian dollars. There is nothing special that you offered that commands the price. Also the quality of food is not so great as other reviewers have noted.

The part Indian in me is always happy when I eat at this place. They have an ala carte menu as well as the buffet. I highly recommend going for the buffet because it's less than $13.90 for lunch and $17.90 for dinner. Where else can you get an awesome Indian buffet spread for that price? Best part about it is you get free flow of naan to accompany all the lovely dishes. If naan is not your thing (though I don't see how that is possible), they also have both white and briyani rice.My first time here was part of a celebratory lunch with a few friends. We didn't make a reservation but that was no problem. They have a decent variety of drinks available on top of the charge for the buffet but I would recommend just sticking to water considering the richness of the food available.So they have a very good spread of both meat and vegetarian curries. I'm not much of a fish curry fan but theirs is really good. The fish meat itself was not soft but firm and the whole thing didn't have that seafood smell you find in a lot of similar dishes elsewhere. Ironically though, their tandoori chicken is a little dry. I don't really mind it though because it's still pretty yummy but if you like your chicken juicy, this might not be something you'd keep going back to the spread for. Apart from these dishes, there's also a small spread of various Indian desserts. There's a tendency for Indian desserts to be very sweet but the ones here just nice. Not too sweet but just enough to finish off the meal. The manga sago is a personal favourite.The fact that the food is delicious is enough to make me a fan of this place but another thing I really like is that the service from the staff is really great! Waiters are very attentive to refilling your naan basket, water glass and even clearing your plate once you're done. Overall, they seem to have gotten the combo of cheap food plus good food plus good staff right on spot. Definitely a place you'd want to not only try out but return to.
This place makes me enjoy Indian food. All the dishes from their salad to their meats dishes are well cooked with the right flavors. Good service as well.

Everything was delicious.Other reviewers say that there's not a depth of flavor, or some such thing. But as an American, when I'm in the US and they say "how spicy?" and I say "spicy!", they usually just stare at me for a moment, give a little smile and say "okay, sir."--by which they mean "you moron. you couldn't handle the spice." And then give me something fairly bland. If they include any spice at all, they check back with me frequently as I sit there crying like a baby and saying "everything's delicious." Well--this place was presented to me as the least spicy of Indian restaurants. It was SO SPICY. My friends said I turned bright red the moment I began eating. We did the buffet. And they, and the waitstaff kept trying to suggest I eat this or that to cool down, even when I thought I was fine. The dessert maybe had flies on it. Lots of them flying or swimming--that's really my only criticism, but that's just me being a weenie of an American.But I was nervous about eating in Singapore anyway, because my belly isn't so adventurous. Neither am I. Anyway, I spent most of the afternoon feeling like I was on drugs, dizzy and lightheaded, sweating and sipping on Coke through my meetings and trying my Bao Ji Wan for the first time. Great job, I don't mean to suck!Did I mention: everything was delicious!

We went to this restaurant after 5 years and things are same. Staff was good. Horrible furniture and ambience. We had the Vegetarian food so cannot comment about non veg food. Veg food was horrible and not the worth $30. Chaat was good. We tried papri chaat and Chana chaat. Fruits were good. Watermelon was red and sweet. Sweet and sour soup was horrible. Couldnt drink more than a sip.  Biryani was so so. Dal makhani  didn't look authentic. It was some other brown Dal.  Paneer kofta was horrible. Aloo gobi was good. Tandoori roti and Naan were good. Fruit Rabri was horrible. Had lot of water in it. Gajar ka halwa was half cooked. In total it was a waste of money.

Ok, make sure your head's in the game when you eat anywhere on the river here. Know that you're going to get ripped off if you just start signing CC receipts. First, the value IMO of a 1kg black pepper crab for $50 on the river in Singapore...I'm ok with. 2 for 1 beers, at $15, I'm more than ok with. The service was great, and when I mentioned (not complained) that I thought BPC would be spicier, they took it back and made it perfect ( I half expected fire to shoot out of my face when it came back - but no). But....yes, but....on my receipt was $3 for rice (I ordered but never received, btw he tried to upsell me hard for the $12 fried rice), $1.50 for nuts (which I never saw), and $0.50 for a tissue. Yes, a tissue. I used the hell out of that cloth napkin and table cloth...but never touched a tissue. They should have charged me for the epic black pepper carnage that lay upon that nice white table cloth when I was done. And when I smiling-ly called BS, he subtracted $5 as a "compromise." I literally had to take his calculator and show him tax is not accounted for in simple subtraction. I talked to the owner and said hey this is a shady deal. Her response was that it's just the way it's done on the Quay. Ok, eyes open. And dang that was some good BPC!  I'll be back. No nuts.  Thank you for reading this far...for that, I ask you to reflect upon the name of this place. "Fuqing Seafood".  Can't make this stuff up.

Was kinda late on a Saturday night so maybe the waiter was really tired or something bc he left out 2 items we ordered. The rice to go with the dishes i ordered and the mango sticky rice which HE specifically asked if we wanted it served now or later and we requested it to be served together with the rest of the dishes.  It was never served and the friend decided to cancel it when we were done eating.  Piece of plastic found in one of my dishes. Oily/wet receipt holder that made my hands oily/wet when that same waiter handed me the change.  When we were exiting the spot i noticed that waiter was fixated on the tv screen across the street which had some EPL match.  Maybe thats what his mind was more focused on.  To sum it up the food was ok i mean u must be a natural failure of all things to mess up Thai food so nothing palatably special for me to wanna return to them plus the numerous preventable errors aint doing them any favors and now i have to leave this bad review.   Enjoy the photos tho lol!

address: 22 Cross St #01-61 China Square Central Singapore 048421 Singapore
comment: Do not go to this address. The reviewed restaurant moved to the 38 Maxwell Road location.

address: 22 Cross St #01-61 China Square Central Singapore 048421 Singapore
comment: A regular place for dim sum in the past. It's still a value for money choice for family dinners. I haven't been as frequent a visitor since they moved from Chinatown Point to this location across the street

address: 22 Cross St #01-61 China Square Central Singapore 048421 Singapore
comment: Attentive servers. Courteous and pleasant disposition. All these plus good food are crucial ingredients to a good meal. I used to doubt Mouth Restaurant on the quality of their food having had a bad episode many many moons before. Well. This visit changed my mind. Giving them a thumbs up!I was looking for a place for a New Year's Eve gathering with some friends and was browsing through Fav. Their 6 course set meal costing S$38 with Boston Lobster, Birds Nest and Abalone caught my eye. So I bought the vouchers and was still wondering if it will be good. I went there and was greeted by friendly and efficient servers. The food serving was good and the flavouring and presentation done right. For a moment I thought I was having some cuisines in a high end restaurant. The servers were also helpful when I wanted to order additional food stuffs as they knew we were having a 6 course lunch. Plates were changed frequently and when you are done with your plate, they immediately ask if they could help to clear the table. All these really made the experience feel great and made the meal even more enjoyable!I have made mistakes about my previous experience with them. I will come back for more!

address: 22 Cross St #01-61 China Square Central Singapore 048421 Singapore
comment: Came here for their dim sum on a Saturday afternoon. Friend made reservation although the restaurant doesn't seem to be very crowded. Very prompt service, the waitering staff will keep a look out if you need to refill your pot of tea and do not hesitate to change your plates when they deem necessary. This kind of service really impresses me and makes a great dining experience.

address: 22 Cross St #01-61 China Square Central Singapore 048421 Singapore
comment: Nice environment compared to other Chinese restaurant. They have special items such as 6 colors ha gau, sweet potato dessert and spinach egg white soup. Very nice looking and colors. But 6 colors don't taste differently at all. I had 6 colors Xiao long Bao and they actually tastes very different each one. Their stir fried broccoli is tasty but other items are pretty general to me.

address: 22 Cross St #01-61 China Square Central Singapore 048421 Singapore
comment: 4 stars for their cooking, 3 stars for the dimsum.a much-lauded chinese restaurant especially known for their molten salted yolk pineapple buns (or liu sha bao, in short), this place is crowded to the rafters on a sunday afternoon - probably at least in part due to the at least average dimsum and pretty decent cooking.reservations are a defo here - you wait even if you've called ahead for a table. they aren't too concerned with you at the door and when you sit down, service is pretty harried (though efficient after you've ordered). make your dimsum orders on the slip of paper, and let the dining begin.you must get the salted yolk buns, if only just to vindicate yourself on having personally (in)invalidated the hype. the bubs are soft, the 'pineapple' (so named for its crackliness rather than flavor) topping a sweet crusty crust; that yolk filling is molten, yes, but it's a bit on the sweet side - and together with the sweet crust, makes the bun a tad too cloying and rich. well worth eating once though.I found most of the dimsum offerings pedestrian, really - though that's a far step above being completely unworth the calories (such as red star) - nothing wholly offensive or impressive. but I'm pleased to tell you their cooked dishes show more than gratifying cooking prowess. it shows skill you wouldn't have imagined with the dimsum, and more than explains the full occupancy of the place.take the spinach in broth with goji berries: very clear and refreshing and subtly-flavored. we had a little less luck with pork trotters but it might have been a problem of expectation. what came was a very sweet, very vinegary, literally black dish of trotter with very little meat. alot more skin, if you're into it - but make sure you're into this style of preparation too (I definitely am not).we were soon blown away by the sheer majesty of their sakura chicken dish: a crisp, thin-and-brown-skinned chicken full of tender meat and well-seasoned chickeny flavor - delicious, and immensely eatable.very, very delicious.I think you'd do well to come for a proper meal - I'm talking dishes with rice and that sort of thing - rather than dimsum, though that liushabao does deserve a little attention (even if not so much its oft-acclaimed position at the top of 'best liushabao' lists).reasonably priced, service you expect in an old-school chinese restaurant, and good cooking - it's old-school chinese eating. the furnishings are a little old and gaudy, and has clearly suffered from the surfeit of people coming through at mealtimes - but don't expect posh and you won't get it you'd be happy.

address: 22 Cross St #01-61 China Square Central Singapore 048421 Singapore
comment: Mouth Restaurant was first established in the 80s in Chinatown Point and is known for its well made Cantonese Dim Sum. The tea house, which originally served delicate pieces of steamed dumplings, has gone on to provide more cooked dishes at its current China Square Central and Plaza Singapura outlets in Singapore.We went in search of some Salted Egg Yolk Custard buns, which Mouth Restaurant is famous for. Managed to snag a table for dim sum on Saturday noon. We were lucky to get a table despite the last minute reservation.Century Egg and Shredded Pork Porridge is one of my standard dimsum order. Nice gluey texture of the congee with generous amount of pork. 4 of us shared a portion in order to make space for more food.Shanghai Xiao Long Bao, Har Gao (Steamed Prawn Dumplings), and Spare Ribs in garlic and chili. All great dishes. The Xiao Long Bao skin was sufficiently thin and encased the juicy pork meat in a robust broth. Har Gao was big, fresh and juicy (i can never resist prawns). The ribs were well marinated and flavorful as well. Mouth Restaurant also offers Colored Har Gao instead of the typical Colored Xiao Long Bao and they are Squid Ink, Spinach, Sweet Potato, Pumpkin, Carrot and Original. The Pan Fried Carrot Cake (another of my favorite dim sum item) was nicely browned and lightly crisp on the outside. The springy texture is just what i look for in a good carrot cake. Oh and the delicious strips of turnip and preserved Chinese sausages (lup cheong) had me finish most of this myself.The Steamed Rice Roll with Fresh Prawn aka Cheong Fun was alright. It's not that they weren't good, the skin was silky but perhaps thicker than what i prefer. Prawns were great as usual but the sauce was a little bland in my opinion. Now now, the reason why we went to Mouth Restaurant. Here's the baked Salted Egg Yolk Bun (3pcs per set) Mind you, they run out fast. Just look at that lovely Hong Kong Bo Lo crust made from sugar, butter and milk powder. It's hard to believe that this is baked because the crust is so crunchy.Be careful how you bite into the bun. Be warned that the piping viscous, creamy, savory and sweet lava may just erupt in your mouth and potentially over your plate, and shirt, and your fellow diners' shirts. It may be a little on the greasy end but the flavor was spot on.Head on to Mouth Restaurant for a classic dim sum fix this weekend! Forgot the prices but it was about S$75 for 4 pax.

address: 22 Cross St #01-61 China Square Central Singapore 048421 Singapore
comment: Came here a while back with a local friend at her recommendation.This place is classy! It feels a bit like high class Chinese dining.It's been a really long time since I've been here (September 2012), so I only remember the dishes that I got photo evidence of.Pork belly - nice crisp skin, delicious and fattyPork ribs (pai gu) - Also goodXiao Long Bao were amazingShrimp dumplings - I'm not the biggest fan in the first place but they were fine.Chang fen with shrimp - MmmThe bill came out to be not so bad for all that we ate and the quality of the food!

address: 22 Cross St #01-61 China Square Central Singapore 048421 Singapore
comment: Mouth Restaurant has revamped their menu since last year and the new items are reinterpretations of traditional dim sum. The Family went to its newly opened branch at Plaza Singapura during a weekend high tea session from 3-5pm but sadly, many items like the squid ink bun and their signature Xiao long Bao were not available. The Rainbow Har Gao in 6 ($9.80)  mimics the concept of multi-flavor Xiao long was not distinctive as its pork counterpart in XLB. Do not mistaken this Squid Ink Seafood Soup 7.80 for herbal jelly. The base is a egg white custard, topped with a thick soup that is rich and tasty.The best thing I can remember is their Baked salted Egg Yolk (3 for $5) Unlike typical steamed bun, the mildly sweetened outer crust is crisp like a HK-style Bo Lo Bun, that released viscous and creamy golden lava. Though some might find it to be much more greasy than usual kind, but who will say no to custard buns?:)The Sweet Potato Roll $3.60 and Tako Cheese Croquette $4.80 sounded special but turned out to be dry, starchy and pedestrian. Some of the mandatory dimsum items included the chicken claws w chilli $3.90 and the Spare ribs with pumpkin $4.50 and the Fried Beancurd skin roll $ 3.20.  Instead of the usual Chee cheong fun, we ordered the XO-style Pan Fried version Bao. The skin was of the right thickness but the individual flavor of shrimp meat with prawn and charshu $8.80. It turned out to resemble stir-fried kway teow. I like the slightly browned surface of the rice rolls that makes this dish fragrant but the taste of XO-sauce was not amplified.  Conclusion: Higher chances of securing popular dim sum items if we were to come in the morning. Would be more keen to revisit for their revamped ala carte dishes, which were in our memories, more delicious than the dim sum. Some items are creative but their quality vary. Hopefully my favourite egg tarts that were nowhere to be found, can appear on their dimsum menu one day......

address: 22 Cross St #01-61 China Square Central Singapore 048421 Singapore
comment: Over the years, Mouth Kitchen has become one of our favourite dim sum places to head to. Rather than the more traditional push-cart type of dim sum, you simply check off the items you want on a paper menu and hand it to the waiter. There's even a column to differentiate your first and second orders - a knowing nod to Singaporeans who love to gorge themselves on repeat orders like yours truly. I felt that the average price of $5 for each dish was justified, even the modern ambience and quality of the food. On a Sunday afternoon, the restuarant was packed - I highly recommend booking in advance. Highlights include the har gao - delicately steamed without a thick skin - as well as the pan fried carrot cake - which was not too oily and fried to the right amount of crispiness. Both the prawn and char siew chee cheong fun were also great, with just the right amount of sauce. The shui jin bao (too thick and starchy) as well as the fried chee cheong fun (just a fancy name for char kway teow) could have been better, though. We also felt that "signature award-winning" dishes were slightly overpriced, but what took the cake was definitely the "liu sha bao", or salted egg buns. These were served piping hot, and the steamed buns split open to a melted yolky centre - like liquid gold. Desserts are nothing special, though. In place of the recommended mango pudding (Crystal Jade serves better), we decided to have another round of the salted egg buns!

Amazing! Every dish was a treat and a feast to eyes. My favorite was the steamed egg with uni ( sea urchin) sauce on the top. Chefs and staff are bilingual in English and Chinese. My friend and I went for the early bird omakase - arrive by 6:15 and finish by 7:30.  At $68, compared with the normal $180 starting omakase rate at Shinzo, you cannot find a better and sweeter deal in town. Fellow sushi snobs, check it out ;)

Came here for the UYE lunch event organised by Amanda - great meeting so many fellow yelpers in Singapore!! :) :)Shinzo is a cosy little restaurant which seats only 28 people at full capacity -- 16-20 people at the sushi bar, and 8-12 people at the table. We heard that they are doing some remodeling and adding some partition to make a semi private room area, so that could be a great setting for a more private meal.The menu was pretty extensive, and I was spoilt for choice. I decided to go with a Sashimi set meal ($38). 1. The set meal started with a side salad with wafu dressing. I'm typically not a fan of wafu dressing, so this was just okay for me. 2. Pitan tofu (egg tofu with century egg, crab stick and fish roe topping) - Apparently, the egg tofu is  home made and there are some secret ingredients in the century egg sauce. I've a weakness for pitan tofu so this was definitely a bonus surprise for me :)3. Sashimi platter - comprising of hamachi, salmon, scallop, dancing prawn, fish roe. Hmm, the sashimi was definitely very very fresh, and I love the sweetness of the shrimp :) The scallops though, were a little overseared imho, so it was pretty cooked leaving only a very small raw part in the center. The fish roe was definitely a nice addition and we were advised to eat it without any sauce :)4. Tempura - Wow, I definitely wasnt expecting tempura in the set meal. I like that the batter wasnt too thick. Despite being freshly fried, the tempura wasnt oily, and was rather light in flavor. Yummy :)5. Cold udon - Apparently, they were using a different type of noodle that is thinner and smoother compared to udon and I liked it alot. Sonya mentioned the name of it, but it has slipped my mind now :(6. Spicy tuna roll - I was super stuffed by this point that I was shocked that there was more. The spicy tuna roll was good, and I could taste the freshness of the tuna despite the spice. However, I did feel that it was too much and shared my plate with the rest!7. Sorbet dessert - Great light dessert for palate cleansing at the end! :)Overall service was great. The waitress gave a brief introduction of every dish and told us how to eat it/ pointed out specific items which should/shouldn't go with sauce. She was also super attentive and awesome :) :) Two thumbs up!!Souz chef Daniel came over to our table a couple of times to answer questions and ask for feedback. Since this restaurant is still pretty new, they're very keen on feedback, and try to customise their dishes to suit individual customer palate. Definitely a great experience :)For $38, I'd say that it was a decent price considering the freshness of the sashimi and the variety of food presented. The food though, was very traditional, and relied heavily on the freshness of ingredients, rather than creative/ intelligent pairing. Perhaps its because it was the set meal? Personally, I think they could have done away with either the tempura or offered a smaller portion of the spicy tuna roll for the set lunch. I'm not sure if I'd pay a much heftier price tag for "fresh ingredients", but I'd definitely love to give them a second try, perhaps their ala-carte menu this time!

I've been here twice for lunch and each time the quality, freshness and presentation really made it seem like more than a $38 set lunch! So much so, I'm plotting to come back for dinner.just need to find a dinner companion.My request to exclude maguro from my sashimi set was readily accepted. The first time, they actually forgot and included maguro. I only realised after I had eaten 1 or 2 other things. I asked and the plate was whisked away..and returned shortly later with replacement and beautifully replated.I like the hot udon, they use the thinner type of udon, slippery and smooth and not as stodgy or heavy as the fat white common type. The broth was delicate and I slurped down every bit of it.My dining companions both times enjoyed their sets like the chirashi, the wagyu beef, the unagi..but do note, they now serve the chirashi as a single serving instead of the first time when they had 3 separate bamboo shaped serving implements for 3 different chopped sashimi on rice. Even though I was picking up the tab the second time, all my dining companions all commented that for the quality and serving size, the prices were very reasonable.There's also an ala carte menu including grilled items, various rice bowls and sushi. The salmon and ikura don (I think $20) and salad that the table next to me were having seemed to be quite generous in portion size.It's a small space, mostly taken up by the sushi bar. Bar seats get snapped up..both times I was relegated to my (regular) table for 4 but admitted I called on the day itself. The server said they are considering whether to turn the 2 table space into a small private room.Chef Lawrence Chia was there both times and personally slicing the sushi and plating up, chatting with guests. He looked quite serious but broke into a smile when eye contact was made.I enjoyed watching him deliberately moulding each piece of sushi, interspersed with delicate touches of his fingers into the vinegar..(yes even from my far off table, that's how intimate the space is).I don't know if Chef is just really good with faces but the second time, he nodded knowingly at me the moment I walked in. At the end of the meal, there was a 10% discount. YAY!I'm happy it's a walk from my office ;)

Wow, definitely 1 of the best meals since I moved back to Singapore 3 weeks ago. We went for different sets for the lunch, and "topped up" with some rolls. I got the korobuta pork katsu set, with a really nicely textured cut of pork. The chawanmushi just had a certain nuanced element to it, which you rarely find elsewhere. For the rolls, I found them a bit too sweet as the chefs seem to like putting some variant to mayo on top, but if not for that, they would have been good too, especially the thinly sliced aburi beef one.
The quality of the sushi is superior. It is well worth paying a little more. Our company had a group luncheon and the service was great.

Granted it's not as good as Hong Kong Shangri La's breakfast buffet, I've been having trash for breakfast  in American hotels, so this was a nice change. Asia always does hotels better and this includes Park Royal! Thanks to work, they included the comp breakfast as part of our stay. This restaurant is SO popular that our first night here, we tried to grab a quick dinner and they said they were fully booked even though it was pretty late. I was disappointed they don't reserve some spots for hotel guests. They also seem to have events during lunch. A lobster buffet is happening right now and it seems to draw a high and mighty crowd. I probably had 5 plates over the course of 2 hours this morning. They have an omelette station and noodle bar where they cook to order while you wait. There's also a pastries and dessert area towards the back which I avoided bc ... well, I have to watch my figure when I'm eating this much food. There's a fruit section down the end. The variety of hot foods was great- dim sum, curry, tater tots, oatmeal, stir frys, gyoza, etc. There's also a juice bar with fresh guava, apple, and orange juices. Service was great - they come by to take your plate and refill your coffee and tea often. They seemed a bit pushy for us to leave despite there being plenty of seats but I wasn't budging bc I had nothing better to do until things started opening at 10am and I'm jet lagged to high hells.

Pricey but well worth it. We've had the dinner buffet twice and a Sunday brunch. Typically we find ourselves here when we don't want to walk out in the blistering heat and humidity. This place is located inside the hotel we were staying at.What I love:+ foie gras (my first time and it was extremely tender)+ lobster Benedict + ahi tuna + curry + pineapple fried rice + tri tip+ paratha, made to order + their cheese selection + dessert crepes, made to order+ nitrogen ice cream+ etc. What I found tough and chewy was the lamb. Lots of Western dishes but I did not try any.Service is unpredictable but the chefs behind each station were friendly, welcoming, and detailed. If the dish requires cutting, cooking, whatever.. they'd make sure that they plate it nicely.

We came here for an end of year work lunch, and got the Christmas buffet. The place came recommended by a friend of my colleague who is a chef. We all left happy. There was another larger company having their end of year lunch at the same time, and they looked like they were having a good time.The decor at Lime is on the casual side, which is perfect for our occasion. Walking in, you see the desserts all lined up and it looked really good.Compared to other buffets, Lime's thing seems to be appetizers and dessert. They had three long tables of desserts, and another three long tables of appetizers. There was a station for raw food like sashimi, but it's not a highlight. I was impressed by the selection of shellfish- they had more than shrimp, mussels and scallops. There was a meat station with turkey, ham, wagyu beef, braised beef, lamb, duck and chicken, that also has sides of brussel sprouts, glazed carrots and caramelized pearl onions. The onions were absolutely delicious. I liked the attention to detail. Some places give you the meats but not the sides. There was a shared Indian and Chinese station. I didn't try the Indian food. The Chinese food was okay. The appetizers were a standout. There was a corner with Mediterranean dips - hummus, baba ganoush, pita, various salads. There was a long table of bread, cheese, olives and meats. The meats were excellent. I had the blue cheese and it was good. What really stood out was the loaf of bread, which was very soft and tasty. It's hard to find good bread in Singapore. Paired with the echire butter, it was amazing. Everyone tried the bread and butter, and some of us went back for seconds. And the salad bar looked decent, although I did not eat there.The desserts were beautiful works of art. Cakes, puddings, mousses, ice cream. I highly recommend the mini macaroons, which are free. The large ones in the showcase are sold separately. I didn't try the nonya cakes, although my colleagues liked the durian pengat. Their chocolate fountain was orange chocolate, but I had no room to taste it. I'm definitely coming back again with people whom I know like trying many appetisers. Some buffets are for seafood, and others are for their mains. Lime's offerings are great for people who like to graze.

SG50 is probably the most important holiday on our national calendar this year. And as befitting for such an important festival, it's time to go "loco" over lobsters with Singapore's FIRST local Lobsterfest at Lime at PARKROYAL on Pickering. On every Wed, one can tuck into mouthwatering Maine Lobsters in various styles ranging from lobster gratin to Peranakan Nyonya LOBSTER laksa!If the natural sweetness of this delicacy is what you are hankering for, you may like to park yourself next to this station. In fact, this is my favourite way of enjoying lobster, with just a bit of horseradish and red wine sauce. If Lady Luck is with you, you might even pick one with a bonus lobster roe! Moving on to the hot food section, the unanimous crowd favourite was the Singapore Chilli Crab Maine Lobster, judging at how frequent the giant serving wok was emptied every time a new batch is furiously cooked and served. The sauce is luxuriously rich and not too sweet.But something more outstanding was the Wok-fried Black Pepper Maine Lobster that boasted good wok-hei and excellent aroma imparted by the use of curry leaves. One dish that might ring in some nostalgia is the Maine Lobster Kam Heong style. Meaning "golden fragrance" in Cantonese, this is said to be a Malaysian stir fry dish whose sauce base is a magical concoction of fiery bird eye's chilli, curry powder, curry leaves and soy bean paste. However, the gravy was short of the necessary fragrance that would imbue this dish with a sharper character. Do keep a lookout for special lobster dishes such as lobster pizza and lobster bisque with cognac as you claw your way through the extravagant buffet spread! Who knows? Maybe you will be luckier than me and catch a lobster dessert on your visit!

High tea at Lime Restaurant I adore high tea and unfortunately there aren't many choices where I live in California.So whenever I visit Singapore, I have to have high tea at least once.My friend made a reservation at Lime Restaurant at Parkroyal Hotel on Pickering Street.Their high tea set starts at $44++ for one serving of coffee or TWC tea.For unlimited servings of tea/coffee it's $50++.Not pictured are the scones which to be honest were a bit disappointing - the sides were too hard but luckily the inside was still nice.This was the one I was most curious about - "an expression of Nasi Lemak". Nasi Lemak, if you've not heard of it, is a coconut rice dish usually served with fried fish and peanuts, egg, cucumber and a really good sambal chili. This ball was a good representation of all the flavours of Nasi Lemak. The rice ball was coated with peanuts and had a dollop of sambal on top. Their cute little carrot cake with a white chocolate carrot on top. The carrot cake was nice and moist.There was also a yummy Peking duck profiterole, a coconut pandan tart, a chocolate peanut butter cup with Gianduja chantilly cream. As well as some open faced sandwiches which weren't anything to rave about.But my favourite was probably the passion fruit meringue tart which unfortunately I didn't get a good photo of. Funny thing is that I'm not really a fan of passion fruit but I loved the refreshing tartness of the mousse which was silky smooth and topped with a perfectly light meringue. And the pastry was just the right thickness and firmness.High tea and good company made for a delightful afternoon.Originally posted at reallifereading.com/2018…

This place is meant to be one of the best hotel buffets in Singapore.  Esp with a focus on local foods vs a western spread of roasts and baked pasta.  For $52 SGD on a Saturday lunch I would have eaten better at almost any place else.  While the room and hotel design is very "urban green" and it's nice to see the open kitchen that doesn't make up for mediocre food options, poor service and an underwhelming buffet experience. Funnily enough the space is called "Lime" and their signature drink, a non-alcoholic limeade, is not included in the buffet price!  Go to Straits Kitchen or the Mandarin Oriental.  Save your money and make your own limeade folks!

Amazing service, great food and outstanding selection of items. The lime drink - their signature - is absolutely my favorite Singaporean food memory! Like the whole hotel, the restaurant decor and set-up are beautiful and very close to nature in feel.

Being the hotel restaurant at my hotel, I have been eating from this kitchen more than I wanted, as they also provide the in room dining; the necessary choice on busy working nights. Since I have only had time for their a la carte menu choices, I can not give a fair rating on the buffet, that seems to be quite popular. I have had chicken as in room dining - slightly overcooked and with hardly any meat on the bones. The mushroom sauce and the hot fires was really good, though. I have also tried the pepperoni pizza for in room dining - it was lukewarm and boring.One day we had lunch in the premises, and I was hoping it would be better when we got it fresh from the kitchen. It wasn't. My rare done burger was a tasteless beef tartare, hardly done at all. Service was also somewhat strange, the waiters seemed slightly confused and all in all I just do not recommend this restaurant.

Lime at park royal. The spread at the buffet is decent. A mix of western and peranakan food. As at most buffets nothing is outstanding but all generally ok. Best of all are the oysters if your in to that because it's shucked fresh. Since I love oysters I would have been happy just pigging out on them. Atmosphere is very nice, contemporary setting. Service is very good. Price is a little high at $62 +++. Frankly there are other better spreads elsewhere but it's a nice difference in the peranakan spread.

Great buffet. Great selection. Wonderful decor and airy space. Major food regions were well represented and they had my childhood beverage, Yakult, readily available! Only qualm is you have to make your own noodle soup compared to other buffets where they make it for you.
Outstanding breakfast buffet.  Varied selection, high quality and worth the price - especially if you're hungry.  After breakfast here, I didn't need to eat again til dinner.

Not good at all. The oysters are not fresh at all. Sashimi is ok. I went there when there is a seafood event which costs me $233 in total. So pricy. I didn't even feel full at the end since there are not so many seafood choices and desserts. Really disappointed and won't come back.

We were too tired to go out of the hotel so we'd thought we'd try the hotel restaurant. The choices were to do the smorgasbord or ala carte. The smorg was $68 per and it looked a little greasy so we did ala carte. We shared a buffalo mozzarella and tomato appetizer. Doesn't come with basil but with "basil pesto" which really was dried basil flakes in olive oil. We had it on the side so regular olive oil and basslmic vinegar made it a nice shared appetizer. We both ordered penne with red sauce and we were disappointed. The penne was fine but the sauce was high in sugar content. So chef if you are getting sauce from a jar, don't get the one that has high fructose as the first ingredient. That being said, service and atmosphere were excellent. Overpriced for the quality of food offered.

address: 6 Eu Tong Seng Street #04-86 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Nice place great ambience and good food. Great for birthday celebrations or gatherings... Choose from a variety of dishes to form a 6-course set lunch or 7-course dinner. Staffs are attentive and quick to clear your table when they notice that you've finished your dish in preparation for the next.

This was a regular *hangover cure* burger for the team when our office was situated near Boat Quay. They have a build-your-own-burger option or you can just choose from one of the standard menu items. There are also a range of sides and sauces you can choose from. They also serve beer.Some gripes are that it can be unbearably busy at lunch times, and the wait and confusion around orders can lead to misunderstandings and frustration, so manage your expectations :)The main let down for me is I feel like the burger is too wet (sauce) and this creates a soggy bun, and also an unwieldy mess to deal with when eating the burger. The cooking and flavour are both good, and it's decently filling.It also tends to the pricey side - however, you are in one of the main tourist locations in Singapore so this is to be expected.Bring a crew, grab a table outdoors, enjoy the water and views, and chomp down a burger and chips!
Great bibimbap! Indoor seating with AC to escape the lunchtime heat and very reasonable prices.

address: 80 Raffles Place #60-01 UOB Plaza Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: Fantastic views from the restaurant and above average food and service.  Place was super clean and comfortable.  Make sure you can handle your spicy food though!  We came with a group of 20 people for a farewell party and everything was speedy and smooth.  Only thing I disliked were the automatic charges for peanuts, tea, etc that they put on the table.

address: 80 Raffles Place #60-01 UOB Plaza Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: Unless one is from Szechuan or Hunan, it'd be hard to eat these dishes often, but once in a while, it's extremely satisfying. This location serves the best food among the different SCDH outlets - flavourful, spicy but not numbing. There are non-spicy dishes from other Chinese cuisines, but frankly such dishes (eg. Peking duck) are not as good as those at the better Cantonese restaurants in town. The classic Szechuan dishes are outstanding - sliced pork in garlic and chilli sauce, Chong Qing diced chicken, beef and tripe in chilli sauce, boiled fish in Sichuan pepper sauce, dumpling in sour and spicy sauce. They might help kill corona virus! The view is fabulous, service is attentive, and prices are not outrageous for the quality and location.

address: 80 Raffles Place #60-01 UOB Plaza Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: Food is good but nothing exceptional except for the prices, exceptionally expensive. Nonetheless the service was good.

address: 80 Raffles Place #60-01 UOB Plaza Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: The individual room has a nice view of the marina. They have a person pouring tea from a long traditional kettle. However, i didnt remember many dishes aside from the stir fried beef, which was excellent. It s also difficult for me to give a proper review because we didn't order any spicy dishes this time.

address: 80 Raffles Place #60-01 UOB Plaza Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: This place is known for its Peking duck and Szechuan food. However, the quality has gone south. It also doesn't help when servers give the impression that they are not happy to work there. With a panoramic view of the city, it would also be great if they had clean glass windows.

address: 80 Raffles Place #60-01 UOB Plaza Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: who would have expected a Si Chuan restaurant to incorporate our local claypot rice to its menu?  Speaking of claypot rice, the most irresistible flavour is none other than the Sliced Pork and Salted Fish version (). With the increase in prices of salted fish, it was a delight to find generous-sized salted fish in the pot of fluffy rice.Meanwhile there is also the Claypot Rice with Chicken, Live Frog and Enoki Mushroom ().  ""---Perhaps due to the cool and comfortable interiors, there was not much of the sizzling sounds or smoky scents of charred rice. Fortunately, I could gleefully scrape off an abundant amount of burnt rice at the base of each claypot and swirl in more dark soya sauce provided alongside.  If you are ordering other dishes, each claypot rice can feed about 2-3 mouths.  The highlight of the day was the  Barbequed Suckling pig $198, which was indeed a terrific dish. Prepared by Barbeque Chef Zheng Guang Liang,  the pig from Hebei China is grilled excellently to produce a crisp, burmished crackling skin and ladies can forget about scraping the fats off the skin. Meanwhile the meat, which was sliced and re-served for easy consumption, was neither too dry nor too greasy--a culinary feat that deserves a round of applause for the chef. Besides the new promotional dishes, regular items such as the Double-boiled Deer Tendon Soup with Deer Antler () $18/person is definitely worth ordering. Made with good quality ingredients and herbs such as cordyceps flowers that warms your body, it is a nourishing brew that is brimming with collagen. Jumping straight to desserts, What forged a deeper impression was the Deep-fried Yam coated with Soya Bean Crisps () $18. The yam was soft, with a crunchy exterior that triggers your sweet receptors but not too much. And the fact that it is made with soya bean gives us a very good excuse to enjoy this indulgent snack!The Claypot rice in assorted flavours are priced at $18 while the Barbequed Suckling Pig is available at $198. For now until 31 Dec 2013, UOB Cardmembers enjoy 50% off the second order of both items. Unless you are dining in huge groups, it would be unimaginable to have two suckling pigs at one go and thus the second order of roast suckling pig can be taken away or consumed on the next visit.Sounds quite like a good deal, isn't it?

address: 80 Raffles Place #60-01 UOB Plaza Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: Been there done that.  don't think it is right to get such a high rating.  If you want ambiance then ok if not there are better place value for money.

address: 80 Raffles Place #60-01 UOB Plaza Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: I've had several business lunches at this restaurant  and I always find myself surprised. Whether it's food or the tea pouring acrobatics, I  feel like I'm in for something different (in a good way) at every visit. Admittedly, my experiences at the restaurant are colored by the fact that meetings are held in private rooms with assigned servers and I do not foot the bill.First, Sichuan Douhua has a tea dude who walks around with a kettle and a long spout, to pour tea in your cup in the most over the top way. If you have an inner child, it's pretty amusing to watch. The tea itself is pretty fragrant. Next, I like the dishes the rotating dishes on the multi-course lunches. For example, I once had a bowl of hot oil filled with dried chilli's placed in front of me and plate of thinly sliced raw pork. We were instructed to cook the pork in the hot oil and eat it straight. The pork was tender and infused with chilli and mala despite the seemingly simple cooking method. I've also had the sliced fish in hot peppers, which an authentic Sichuan dish though no where nearly as spicy as the ones I've had in Sichuan or Chongqing. The beancurd served here is also very soft and fresh, probably some of the best I've had. Finally, the house special dan dan mian done quite well with chewy, hand made noodles topped with mince meat and chives. The downside to this restaurant is that most other dishes are quite pedestrian. The siew mai and har gow served with the set lunch is supposedly a house specialty but it doesn't blow me away. The soups also lack the powerful depth you get at the great cantonese restaurants. Overall, I can't complain much about Sichuan Douhua as it serves its function as a business lunch venue, but I wouldn't necessarily come out specially to eat on non-work occasions.

address: 80 Raffles Place #60-01 UOB Plaza Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: Proper Sichuan food can be a bit daunting to a gweilo like me  for a start, knowing what to order, and secondly, dealing with the face-numbing power of Sichuan pepper. However, coming here is an admirable solution to both problems. The set menus are very good ( as part of a big business party, this was a smart move), and the location is stunning, up on the 60th floor of the UOB Plaza. If you can find your way up here, it's well worth a visit; I'd suggest the chili jellyfish, and anything with sichuan pepper and tofu, an intriguing mix. The waitress will warn you, if foreign, to refrain from laughing, , speaking, or coughing while takling some of the hotter dishes; she's quite serious, and you wouldn't want any going down the wrong way, as I'd imagine it akin to a deep breath of CS gas. Traditional green tea is served from long-handled pots ( handing for reaching across the table), and is very welcome for putting out any oral fires. Very highly recommended.

address: 80 Raffles Place #60-01 UOB Plaza Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: Went there this morning and had a few dimsum dishes. They were below par, har Kow and siu Mai texture was really springy and felt low quality. Have not tried their other a LA carte dishes but based on the dimsum I probably won't make special return trips. The view was superb. The tea lady was a nice touch.

address: 80 Raffles Place #60-01 UOB Plaza Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: This review is a little dated, almost 2 years ago, so I hope the standards are still as awesome as they used to be! This place is especially fantastic if you made reservations way in advance. When visiting, a local friend did that and we were able to get a spectacular 60+ floor view of the entire Singapore river night skyline, as we arrived in time for sunset to see the lights of the city come on. The view was excellent, but we also had a great time sampling all the local delights, as we opted for the a la carte buffet that had about a hundred dishes we could select from (minimum of 4 people). Most memorable was the Chong Qing chicken, which was super super spicy and we had to drown ourselves in water after that. The fish was good, we loved the coffee pork ribs, the noodles and there was a great selection of 8-10 types of Chinese desserts to choose from, which we really liked. I think the almond dessert was particularly refreshing, after all the heavy meats and oily food. Highly memorable was the tea master who walks around and pours tea using a long sprout, from almost 3 feet away. I think it was called "Kung fu" tea. We were highly entertained all night watching him and we would come back in a heartbeat next when we visit!

address: 80 Raffles Place #60-01 UOB Plaza Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: I am not a fan of Si Chuan cuisine but I would still highly recommend this place for their cantonese dishes i.e. Delicious and good presentation. Ambiance here is also nice coupled with good service. Overall, was a good dining experience despite my initial hesitation. Needless to say, I will not comment on their Si Chuan dishes......

This is business with a cause. You can check out their website for more details. I came here for lunch on a weekday and the cafe is definitely bustling and full. There was only one empty table which we grabbed.Set lunch were priced at about $15 and you get a soup, a main course and a drink. It is not cheap but the quality is good if you compare to a normal cafe.The soup of the day was mushroom soup and it had lots of chunky mushroom pieces. I had the fish and chips which was a decently large serving that I had difficulty finishing. It was between finishing the fries or the fish. The batter was nice and crispy.You also get a choice of orange or lemon juice as your drink.I hope the social cause is not a marketing gimmick since having a meal here makes me feel that I have to be nicer and not be my usual b**** about the food/drinks/service. 3-stars for the food, one more for the cause.

Great night few weeks back at this place which I heard had just opened for business recently. They're having a 1-1 at the moment (not sure if it's still going on). Ordered a lot of their dishes but was disappointed that they were out of Uni that night. Will definitely head back for their signature Uni bowl again! We ordered their chutoro and otoro sashimi as well. The colour of their chutoro was pretty odd but the melting taste made up for it. Service was great with the friendly owner who came and check on us often to refill our sake/ clear our plates. Awesome fuss free joint!

address: Arrival Meeting Hall South #01-03 Terminal 3 Singapore 819663 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Singapore is known for being a hub of various international flavors mingling all into one hybrid "fusion" flavor. Their McDonald's are no exception.I decided to try the Breaded Salmon with Paella Spice Mix Burger. YUM! What more can I say? YUM!There were plenty of other exotic-to-an-American flavors on the menu.
