I could only try one (or look like the super-fat American trying a half dozen items to eat).Again, a McD's is a McD's. This was otherwise as standard as can be in addition to being a 24-hour airport variety. But I did totally enjoy my unique asian McDonald's experience!

address: Arrival Meeting Hall South #01-03 Terminal 3 Singapore 819663 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: McWings!!! I love them, and have only seen them in Singapore and South Korea. I always try to eat them at least once if I transit at Changi. This McDonalds is past customs, and not too far from the Crowne hotel. Food was hot, ordered a Mcwings meal a cheeseburger, banana pie and some twisty fries. Had to wait a long time after paying with no clear explanation as of why. At least 10 others ordered and were served after my order was places. Food arrived promptly after a 15-20 minute wait, all the food was hot, but fries were already getting cold ( they were undee heat lamp entire time I waited). Everything else was tasty, so just knocking a star for the wait, and 1 for unfresh fries.

rest_name: Our Village-Authentic North Indian Village Cuisine
comment: I can't believe that this place hasn't got a review yet. It's the best combination of a roof top view of boat quay and authentic cuisine. Boat quay is a bit of a tourist trap but this place is just a tiny door among all the hustlers on the main strip.As for food, it's hard for me to do this place any justice. I pick something different every time and it's always been one of the best in Singapore. They pride themselves on fresh hand picked ingredients and Sri Lankan and Punjabi cuisine. The Tandoor comes highly recommended- the prawn especially. Lamb, like any other meat, is incredibly tender. This place is five star except for the prices which seem to have steadily increased over the last few years.This place is great for a romantic dinner or having a meal with friends. Highly recommended:)

rest_name: Our Village-Authentic North Indian Village Cuisine
comment: The worst restaurant experience in Singapore. I revisited them after 12 years and still the same crap service, cramped tables, over priced drinks and a promise of minimum spend even before you have seen the menu or tasted the food. A complete shame of a place.

rest_name: Our Village-Authentic North Indian Village Cuisine
comment: A short elevator ride up to the 5th floor opens to a charming little restaurant with a fabulous view. The staff are very welcoming and is very attentive. If you can, book a table on the very top of the restaurant,  it has the best views. We had the Chicken Tiki Masala and the Butter Chicken both dishes were delicious .  While my friends liked the papadam, I found it spicer than what I was accustomed to having.  All in all, a fun restaurant experience!!

rest_name: Our Village-Authentic North Indian Village Cuisine
comment: If there was a reason to give no stars I would.  However this is not based on the food but service.  The only reason I am telling about my experience is I have just met a few people that told me they had bad customer experience as well and frankly, this place needs to be called out. I am not sure if they have an aversion to expats (which is stupid to have you restaurant in a TOURIST Area if you do not like expats). Or they are an equal opportunity offender, but please do not patronize this restaurant.  There are so many other places to go in Singapore and this is not one of them.  Stay away FAR away.

rest_name: Our Village-Authentic North Indian Village Cuisine
comment: One of the most authentic North Indian dining establishments in Singapore. They have a spectacular view of the city skyline and the food is truly wonderful. Do yourself a favor and save time in your itinerary to eat at Our Village.

rest_name: Our Village-Authentic North Indian Village Cuisine
comment: We have been coming here on and off for over 15 years. Excellent, healthy and authentic food, courteous service and a sublime location. This is a hidden gem. The management takes extraordinary pride in the preparation - everything is prepared from scratch including the Aam Ras (Mango Nectar). It's a little quirky, completely unpretentious and low key unlike the other restaurants in Boat Quay.  My favorite Indian in Singapore.

rest_name: Our Village-Authentic North Indian Village Cuisine
comment: Absolute rubbish, Singapore has some fantastic Indian restaurants, as someone who has made an effort to try many different ones around the world this place was one of the worst I have been to. Food is not good, lacks flavor and quality, service matched that and the price didn't. Don't bother with this place unless you just want the view.

rest_name: Our Village-Authentic North Indian Village Cuisine
comment: Love it here. The contract on the menu is the weirdest thing ever, but the food is universally outstanding.

rest_name: Our Village-Authentic North Indian Village Cuisine
comment: Food was great. Service was very poor. Views were fantastic. Great value - just relax and enjoy the drinks and food will arrive eventually :-)

rest_name: Our Village-Authentic North Indian Village Cuisine
comment: This place has gone to the dumps! Food used to be ok but service was never any good. Recently though had a horrible experience at this place- went there with my family (2 kids) and after placing order the waiter 'advised' me that i had to place more order as the 'expected spend' per person was 43sgd to be precise ie i had to order more food and drinks to make up for the kids!! I asked so what if my order falls short then the so called manager informed me that he would not serve us! Whoa- what an attitude man- straight away got up as didnt like the so called expected spend attitude and the roughshod behavior of the service staff... spending money is not an issue but to be advised that i needed to order more was very unwelcome... avoid this place if u can. Infact we dined at the kinara brand indianmexican patros place right below this godforsaken indian village. Patros had a better seating right next to river, amazing food and service and more variety plus better prices! Avoid punjab da dhaba/ our village unless u want to be told that u need to spend 43sgd per person to be precise and get the very worst of service and overspend for food!

AURA is located in the new National Gallery of Singapore. Besides its quaint location, this Italian restaurant serves a wide array of wine that complements with their food. Plus point! They have very fresh, yummy homemade pasta. I am very particular about pasta as it is my favourite noodle, so naturally its flavour, the chewiness, the presentation all comes together as one when I review whether I should visit them again.  This is one of the few restaurants that blown me away with al dente pasta, hearty portions, worth every penny price points and impeccable service.The bar also has a picturesque night's view of Marina Bay, recommend you making a reservation before you go over. Without alcohol its about $100 a person with a three course meal, but if you just order a pasta and a non alcoholic drink, $50 per person will suffice. Great for date nights and corporate dining.

The restaurant is located at the going to open National Gallery Singapore. It is opened by Beppe de Vito who is the one behind il Lido in Sentosa. The restaurant offers Italian cuisine in posh style. The main restaurant is located at the level 5, the sky lounge is located at level 6. With a restaurant week reservation, it is interesting to find that I am being showed to a table at the sky lounge. The place has both aircon and alfresco dining areas, overlooking the The Padang, with a great view of Marina Bay Sands. Today we are having the restaurant week lunch which costs $40++ per person and consists of a starter, a pasta, a main and a dessert, with bread and coffee or tea included.We start the meal with some breads, served with olive oil dip. While the bread is not served hot, it is soft and fluffy inside. Hokkiado Scallops Crudo with Truffle ($25)The raw scallops are lightly seasoned, and goes quite well with the tangy sweet pomegranate arils (seeds) and puree sauce. The dish is served in a colorful and playful, which looks very appetizing. The smoked quail egg is like mini version of the lava egg which is usually found in ramens. Whole Wheat Stracci with Duck & Foie Gras ($32)We are surprised with the chunks of foie gras, which tastes buttery smooth. Although the dish is filled with minced duck meat, the gamey taste of duck is not overwhelming here.For mains, there is 2 choices available.Black Cod with Beetroot and Porcini MushroomsThe cod is juicy and chunky, served a richly colorful bed of beetroot puree. Beef Sirloin with Asparagus and Red Wine SauceThe serving is rather small, about half the size when compared to the cod. Although cooked medium, the texture is a bit tough than preferred. There is barely any sauce.Lastly for dessert, we haveStrawberry, Pistachio & Chocolate Profiteroles ($18)Although the dessert is simply profiteroles, they are distinct in their own taste, especially the pistachio - strong in flavour and light without feeling too creamy.We end the meal with a selection of Fine Teas and Coffee.Overall the food is not bad. Service is not bad too, although it would be better if the staff has made a better job of clearing the bread crumbs on the table. It is not often to see staff using the metal ruler like stuff to clear the table. The restaurant is such a relaxing place that 2.5 hours of lunching has gone in a blink.
Used Burrple's one for one, otherwise it's terribly overpriced given that the food doesn't taste good (I wouldn't even pay half price) and the portions are small.
Review of the Sky Lounge on Level 6. You pay for the fantastic view, as the food is subpar and it's of course overpriced.

it's been years since i last visited il lido on remote sentosa and i'm real glad aura was created in a much easier to access prime location.two festive meals were partaken here and both times the nom did not disappoint.the christmas set lunch in particular offered real value for money with a cleverly crafted and well executed menu plus entertainment thrown in.the seafood antipasto tantalized the taste buds to start.the cod with savoy cabbage struck a nice chord but it was indeed the tenderly juicy, crispy skin, guinea fowl that really wowed! and by the time the beautifully scrumptious christmas log cake made it's appearance, the now satisfied stomach had little choice and duly but thankfully expanded.  and finally, the surprise hazelnut gift package was a sweet thoughtful festive pairing with post dessert caffeine.it was precisely all of the above which drew us back for a new year's day dinner in an attempt to try their ala carte items which were not available for lunch on christmas day.and so choice is mostly overrated although often demanded.sometimes a set can outdo what personal choice cannot quite achieve with a limited budget.but you can't go wrong with any of their ala carte pasta selection.all artisanally al dente with a gastronomical permutation for each democratic soul.and i do strongly suggest having it after one of their appetizers.i had the grilled octopus as i do love my octopussy and know the italians do theirs with aplomb!nicely charred yet tenderized tentacles lie surrounding, as if protecting, an oishii crispy onsen egg.as for the final stomach stretching exercise, i chose with my final vote, the bailey's and hazelnut feuillantine.though not alcoholically pleasing, it was the most photogenic and totally calorie worthwhile.service was cordially competent on both occasions but can definitely be more polished.do check your bill if you are in a big group as 'mistakes' may be made, sometimes.in this new year ahead, may it's distinctive but intangible qualities continue to radiate and satiate.

Note this review is for the Aura Sky Bar on the rooftop of the National Gallery, not the Aura Michelin reviewed restaurant one floor below that is formal and $$$. Yelp should really have it set as two separate restaurants because they are entirely separate floors and different menus altogether. The Sky Bar has the best views in Singapore - really panoramic of the harbor, downtown, marina sands - very inatragrammable - and a lovely restaurant, top quality food at reasonable prices! I had one of their fresh juice mixes that was stunning and a tomato mozzarella salad that was first class. And a glass of wine to stay and enjoy the view. Highly recommend, definitely as part of a visit to the National Gallery but really any time you want to get above it all and be well taken care of for a reasonable price.

Visited for lunch on a Friday. The set lunch (Green Asparagus Soup, Linguine Bolognese, Mango Delice) looked boring, so we decided to order from the main menu instead to share.We had:Scallops Crudo with Truffle and Smoked Quail Eggs - this came BEAUTIFULLY presented, complete with edible flowers and ikura topping the raw scallops on a bed of mashed avocado. This was unanimously the best dish of the meal. The scallops were fresh and flavorful. Definitely order this, it's a delight for the senses.Spaghetti with Crab and Porcini - they were generous with the crab; thick juicy chunks swirled with the spaghetti. Crab was the star of the dish, the sauce and porcini just average. Enjoyable though.Burrata Cheese Ravioli with Amatriciana - I found this a little too cheesy, though my other 2 dining companions did enjoy it quite a bit. Only order this if you are a fan of cheese and carbs. But it went well with the sauce and crunchy bits to provide texture.Italian Seabass with Artichokes and Saffron Sauce - fish was nicely cooked, though I'd have liked the skin slightly crispier. The saffron sauce didn't stand out, and there was a tad too much artichoke. The food was decent, though not mindblowing for its price ($142 in total incl tax/service). Only the scallops stood out. The 3 of us left decently satisfied. Good place for business lunches.

My wife and I ordered the tortelli and raviolli - the only vegetarian items on the menu.  The tiny portions could fit on a tea saucer though they put it on a big plate with a tea saucer-sized indentation in it.  It would be just okay if it were a $6 appetizer at Olive Garden (or pick any generic food chain really) but they were $35 and $32 respectively.  Mine was lukewarm when they served it and had sprigs of parsley with tough stems that I had to pick out.  Our friends got the buffet and seemed happy so I suggest doing that if you have to eat here.

3 stars for the not so great service, but food is good. Highly recommend the homemade pastas. We tried the pappardelle with oxtail, the ravioli and the truffle pasta (but we changed the pasta to tagliolini). For the mains, I recommend the pork, beef, and scallops. Well that's what we tried and everything was delicious. Service is super slow, they serve one course at a time. My water glass was always empty, same comment as another girl on trip advisor: she had to serve herself the drinks. So I recommend coming when you have time to kill because you have to wait a while for your food to come, but when it comes it's good. Show you some pics of the main :)

Aura has many good things going for it - housed in an incredibly beautiful building and seasoned restauranteur Beppe De Vitto's touch. I went there for brunch on a Sunday; the first thing that hits you as you enter is the buzz running through the restaurant, not raucous, but sufficiently energetic so you don't get any of the usual stuffiness in museum restaurants. Service is attentive but not uptight;  the wait staff strike a good balance of professionalism and chumminess, offering suggestions for life-changing dishes (which btw was the grilled octopus). One waiter even offered to move us when he saw us struggling with our stroller in a packed corner. I really liked the interior - comfy seating, classy combo of white marble, brass, and lovely lighting pieces. The food was very good - I didn't think it was life-changing, but everything we ordered was solid. We started with the grilled octopus and tuna tartare. Both were delicious, but the octopus at Bochinche still has my heart. For mains, we had the duck stracci with foie gras and their signature taglialini with scampi. The duck ragout was the winner here - homely and full of flavour. For dessert we had the hazelnut feuillantine, which was super indulgent with lovely texture. My prosecco was fruity and perfect for brunch; my husband was pretty happy with his pinot noir.Aura is just what Singapore needs more of - versatile option for date night, an important business meeting, must-do for visitors to Singapore, or a great spot for boozy grown-up brunch with friends.

We were lucky enough to have our wedding hosted at Aura sky lounge and padang deck.  It was an amazing night for us:Ambiance - breathtaking views of Singapore.  We were able to see the light show and fireworks during our dinner.  Those who preferred the AC stayed inside (very comfortable, still a great view), while those who wanted some air would go outside.  Restrooms were easily accessible down a set of stairsFood - Although we didn't have much time to eat (lots of people to talk to!) the food was all quite delicious.  Beverages were very good as well. All of our guests were very pleased with the quality and timing.Service - Couldn't be happier.  The staff is very responsive to planning (Gene was our main point of contact) and the wait staff during our event was great.Awesome place to have a wedding or event!

Splendid location and setting and fantastic wine list of you are into Italian wines. Food was mostly good,  although the daily special, uni pasta,  was not that great,  it tasted like uni was not really top quality. Generally i felt a bit meh with the food,  was expecting more. Seabass was good though. My biggest problem with the place was the noise. It is very very noisy when the restaurant is full,  to a point that it feels like sitting in a night club.  Seriously noise level was unbearable. I wanted to like the place,  i really really did. Food not being up to expectations and the noise level especially will keep me away from this place. If you don't mind to shout through the dinner,  then try by all means. Otherwise take ear plugs with you.

An amazing view that is definitely a must do on your Singapore list. However, drink portions are incredibly stingy. If you are going to charge 16-20 for a glass of ok wine that is half a correct serving, charge 20-24 and fill the thing correctly.

Been here a couple of times, for drinks mainly. The view is to die for, both in the daytime and in the evening. It's got an unblocked practically 360 view of Marina Bay. So it's worth coming up here to see the view. But the service is non-existent. Waiters take forever to come over. One evening I was there with friends, we had to wait at least 5 minutes for anyone to pay attention to us. We just plonked ourselves down after we got tired of waiting (the lack of service was not due to crowds, in fact, the place was practically empty although there were tables outdoors which were occupied). We literally were helping ourselves to napkins because the waiter did not come over, forgot to deliver even after one of my friends went over to ask and we finally got so fed up one of us walked over to the bar to get the napkins. The bar food is decent but not spectacular. Given the prices they charge, it'd better be edible. So be forewarned. Come here for drinks only if you want a view and do not mind slow, patchy service.

I tried this place twice to be objective. First time was bad service -- cold food, unemotional staff. I wrote it off as opening month jitters. The second time was six months later. Nothing's changed. Given a choice, I would get Olive Garden.

We went to Aura for lunch on a day it was raining, so the overall  ambiance was amazing given that the full length glass windows made everything seem softer and nicer. The food was tasty and beautifully presented. Service was excellent, very attentive, always ready with suggestions. We will definitely visit again.

Happy with everything we ordered. Got a crispy octopus for appetiser, beef and lamb chop for main, and finished with French toast with banana, strawberry and hazelnut. Every course exceeded my expectations and that is actually quite rare for me as I often find a lot of restaurants in Singapore underwhelming. Happy to go back again!

Second time at the restaurant.  Had had a very good experience the first time a few months ago and so was expecting a good dinner and was prepared to disagree with some of the poor reviews.  The food is good but the service this last time was terrible.  Sticks in one's craw to pay the amount charged after having had to chase the waiter numerous times to take our orders.  After a decent initial show when we first arrived, no effort was made during the balance of the meal, perhaps because what looked like an Australian chef was seated at the next table.  Had to chase for the bill and left the restaurant without any effort from the staff to say goodbye.
Great views, nice ambience and good selection of yummy dishes. Additionally execellent service. Highly recommended

Fantastic view, on the rooftop of the newly opened Singapore National Gallery. The atmosphere, the environment is superb. Some of the food is great - like the salmon benedict -, but please avoid the toasted barley with yoghurt and baked figs. Somewhat pricey, but worth the visit for special occasions.

Tried to make last minute reservations at the main restaurant for lunch but they were full. They nicely suggested that we go for the antipasti buffet upstairs in the Sky Lounge, which was delightful. You get to choose from around 8 different types for just $18+++, which is a steal in my book!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Met up with a group of friends for dinner on a Monday night. 5 of us shared their Eight flavors set meal. That's 8 different flavors of pork belly from the Mangaloca Pig. Meat was served 4 types at a time and grilled in front of us. Starting with the mild flavored ones and ending with the more flavorful types. Flavors here refers to the seasoning / marinate used on the pork belly. Some of the meat pieces were fatty and may turn some people off. It is the fatty pieces that are the most flavorful. The meat is cooked and cut into pieces so it is easy to share. Each set of meat cane with kim Chee and sprouts served on the front side of the grill. They and the fresh lettuce leaves complement the meat well. There are also typical Korean side dishes as appetizers or snacks. Service was ok. There seems to be a lack of water to quench the spiciness of the kim Chee. Maybe they charged for each carafe of h2o. It was a quiet night and one of the staff came over with a camera asking if they can take a photo to post on Facebook. It seems they post every 1st of the month for the last month so hoping to see our group pic then.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: During a recent trip to Singapore, I decided to revisit this place for some Korean BBQ. When I lived in Singapore a few years ago, this wasn't my favorite Korean BBQ place, but it was good and close to where we use to live. This past visit did not really meet my expectations and the rowdy guests chugging beer at the table next to us on a Tuesday night did not help. The BBQ and Stew were good, but not great like I remembered. But the worse was I remember really liking the kimchi fried rice, but now it has cheese in it. What??? They just ruined a perfectly good dish, unless my memory is totally off. Anyways, there is lot of food choices in Singapore, so I'm not sure I'd choose this again during my next visit.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Maybe the BBQ/Grill meat will be the better option. We did not order that as our focus was on the Army Stew.Apparently most places' Army Stew was big enough to feed 3 or 4 persons. As it was just two of us, we were looking for a smaller portion and 8 Korean BBQ had that. My first experience with Army Stew and I was not too impressed with it. It was nice but it was not spectacular. Instant noodle in a Kimchi broth with some vegs, a cheese slice, ham, hotdogs and luncheon meat (spam). I could not see or taste the luncheon meat though my friend said it was there, in tiny pieces. We also ordered a kimchi fried rice which was quite good. The highlight would be the banchan. It was different from other places with the ubiquitous kimchi, anchovies and huge bean sprouts. Over here, there were only 4 but they were all tart which were very appetizing. I love the strips of cuttlefish which were salty sweet and sour. Maybe I would have to order the grill meat next time. The 4 or 8 color pork belly were huge! Definitely enough for sharing.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: We first tried 8 Korean BBQ in Seoul. It blew our mind. When we heard about them opening a store in Singapore, we jumped at the chance to try it. The taste didn't failed us. Meat was succulent and well marinated. Just like how we tasted it in Seoul. Although we are limited by the variety of vegetables we can get in Singapore, it did not diminish the whole experience.Price here is on the high side compared to Korea. The price for 2 pax in Singapore would feed 3 in Seoul.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This was the weirdest Korean BBQ experience I've ever had. You order as usual and the meat to cook came out first. Which was odd for me as meat usually cooks quite quick and it brought out in the middle of the meal. We almost finished all our Waygu by the time our vege and mushroom plate came out. Our server deserted us 1/2 way through so another server came over to take on servicing our table. Since you don't cook yourself, they cook for you there was a lot of lag time in between where our food got cold and we couldn't start the next course. The quality of the food was ok but it's way too overpriced for the service you receive. We won't be coming back.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Good quality tasty and nice casual ambience.We had the Ginseng Black Chicken soup and Pork Belly Kimchi Stew. Both came out piping hot and smells great. They have served the side dishes which were usual in Korean fares.The side dishes presents Kimchi, Cuttlefish strips, white carrots (radish?), beansprouts, & small potatoes, all nice starters for the main meals.We like the Ginseng Black Chicken the best. The soup is almost thick and flavourful, almost collagen-like. I think it's a whole chick in there, stuff with rice. The portion is definitely large enough for two. The pork belly kimchi stew when compared to the Ginseng chicken is less impressive. On its own it would be a nice meal, though it is stingy on the pork belly. Lots of kimchi and the stew is spicy and appetizing enough. I finished my bowl of rice with it.On the whole, the ambience is casual, and probably surprisingly nice as we left the place without smelling like food. And the pricing is exceptional, $38.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Been here twice for dinner, and got varying flavors of the pork belly. I have no idea why they put kimchi on the grill, yet not provide kimchi as part of the banchan unless asked to. Bewildered.Both times I've gotten a kimchi jjigae, and it is okay. The pork belly flavors are a bit of a gimmick. After the staff kindly cooked the meat, they all tasted pretty much the same. The prices are also on the high side here. I was not impressed.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: We tried out 8 Korean BBQ last night and I'm a huge fan. The place was hopping and I'm happy we had a reservation. There were three of us and our server was very helpful in explaining the menu. We started with the vinegar soju with plum and then  ordered the pork belly, the ribeye and the seafood stew with bean paste. I was happy with the drink, but my husband may have found it a bit girly for his tastes. The meats and kimchi were awesome. I was really impressed with how everything was cooked at the table and the level of service we received. It wasn't 5 minutes since the time we ordered that the table was swarmed with servers toting a ton of food. What an experience! We'll definitely be back.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This is a decent Korean bbq place. Prices are a bit high even for SG standard for what you get. However the quality is good and the service is friendly.  If you are in the area I'd recommend this place.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Without a doubt the best Samgyupsal (Pork Belly) in Singapore. This is the same franchise as the one in LA's Ktown and Korea (although in LA, it's called Palsaik, which essentially means 8 flavors anyways) I'd been to Palsaik in LA (and became a fan!) and was eager to try it out here when I read that they opened about a month ago. One of the things I miss most about LA when I'm in Singapore is the good korean food and was hoping it'd taste just as good here. It did, if not, better. 4.5 stars... Here's why,When you first arrive, you're greeted by a dim interior, with Kpop girls dancing around on the TV screens attached to the brick walls. The space isn't particularly big (and I can see it becoming really crowded, once word hits the street) but it's very well decorated with a nice hip underground feel to it. The staff are super friendly and showed us to our table as soon as we got there. The thing to order here is definitely the '8 flavors' samgyupsal. It sounds like a lot of food but it's really not as it's essentially one thick strip of pork belly for each flavor (good for 2-3 people). The 8 flavors are: Wine, Original, Ginseng, Garlic, Herb, Curry, Miso, Red Pepper. Every single flavor tasted good, my favorites being Wine, Ginseng, Garlic, Curry and Miso (okay I guess that's almost everything) Now, what makes the singapore branch BETTER than the LA one? The service and the flavors.The service: Service here is top notch. Possibly the best I've experience in such a restaurant (of course, not comparing with fine dining type places). Aside from being super friendly and attentive, they cook your food to perfection. Yes, perfection. Sure, there are countless amazing korean bbq places in LA but the one thing I find annoying is they often start cooking your meats for you and then walk away and come back too late only to have it become slightly burnt, overcooked or resulting in you having to flip it over yourself. Not here!! They flip it at the perfect time, cut it up, and then turn off the fire and transfer it onto a small plate for you after it's perfectly cooked so it does not get burnt. This results in pork belly perfection.The food: The Samgyupsal here is actually better than their branch in LA because, the flavors are more distinct. In LA, they do the 8 different flavors as different "cuts" of pork belly as well as marinates. However, though yummy, I didn't think the flavors were very distinctly different from each other there. Also, with the different cuts, there were cuts of the pork I didn't like as much resulting in a lot of uneaten meats. At 8 flavors here in Singapore, however, every flavor is made with the same pork belly. This allows you to differentiate and really taste the change in taste with each flavor. The cut aside, the flavors itself really are most distinct too. Super well marinated and bursting in flavor, you can no doubt tell wine from miso from garlic etc etc. The only slight downside for this place is the price point. For a plate of 8 flavors, you're looking at $98. This is before soups, drinks etc. And since (if you're a big eater like us - heehee) a plate of 8 flavors only feeds 2-3 people, you can imagine it becoming really pricey with a big group. Thus, I had to knock of 0.5 stars (but only because of the price) Still, I'll be back, and 8 flavors has no doubt earned the title of best Samgyupsal in Singapore in my books. I just hope the service and food quality remains just as good, even when they start to get super busy (because I know they will soon enough).

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: One of the better Korean restaurant in town, in my opinion. Good spread of marinated meat; very nice. Love the pork belly and the Kimchi is good too. Service was average and expensive.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Like the concept of different types of marinated meats. However, taste is average. Side dishes are limited, a bit overpriced compared to other Korean restaurants along Telok Ayer/Tangjong Pagar area.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I ordered the Flower pork, with belly, jowl, neck steak.Apparently this was food enough for 2 or 3 people. Something never pointed out to me.  But I don't care, it was amazing.I am very much a fan of anything porcine, and the jowl being the best of the porker. So I had very high hopes going in, and I was not disappointed.Meat is griddled right next to you, the fat runs down and cookes the bean sprouts and kimchi. What is not to love.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I have only compliments for the food = 3 thumbs up!But behind the "friendly" faces lurk rude and insulting servers. Most visitors probably compliment the "good" service because they do not understand what the Filipino servers comment when they exchange communication amongst themselves in Tagalog.I visited the restaurant today with a friend who understands and speaks fluent Tagalog but is Chinese. The servers, Joey and Del, didn't suspect one bit that she understands Tagalog and continuously exchanged insulting and rude comments about us between themselves in Tagalog while masking their insults with wide smiles - while serving us.Good food but such service standards would make anyone lose an appetite.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: We tried out 8 Korean BBQ last night and I'm a huge fan. The place was hopping and I'm happy we had a reservation. There were three of us and our server was very helpful in explaining the menu. We started with the vinegar soju with plum and then  ordered the pork belly, the ribeye and the seafood stew with bean paste. I was happy with the drink, but my husband may have found it a bit girly for his tastes. The meats and kimchi were awesome. I was really impressed with how everything was cooked at the table and the level of service we received. It wasn't 5 minutes since the time we ordered that the table was swarmed with servers toting a ton of food. What an experience! We'll definitely be back.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: A Serendipitous Find!We had the 4 colour set at 8 korean bbq. The  4 colour set comes with four flavours of BBQ Pork from a total of eight flavours and we also ordered the pork belly kimchi stew as part of the set.The stew - tastes savoury and rich, has a smooth texture, and is not too thick. it's one of the BEST Korean stews I've ever tasted. I try a few pieces of the pork meat in the sizzling stew and they are delicious, too.The meat - It is juicy, savoury, succulent, and tastes perfect no matter how you eat it: I wrap it with kimchi in cabbage, eat it with the multi-grain rice, and dip it in sesame oil. No matter which method I try, the meat still tastes oh-so-fabulous!Beer - Had the Korean Hite Beer while indulging in the 8 Korean BBQ feast. Light and refreshing with a smooth texture, and has a nice bittersweet aftertaste.Overall, everything was good. The meat tastes heavenly, the stew is delicious, and we enjoyed good service throughout. It was surreal. My bf & I are both completely satisfied. Check out our full review and photos at eatandtravelwithus.com/2…

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: So we wandered around Central Mall, looking for somewhere we both could agree on for dinner. Husband: "I don't really like Korean"Me: "Oh, so this place is no good then?"Husband: "Never said I didn't like Korean BBQ"So we manage to get a table on a Saturday night. Outside. By the lights of Clarke Quay. We choose the 4 color pork, wine, original, miso and garlic. Service was a little slow, I managed to devour the kimchi before I could even imagine our meat arriving. My 3 year old didn't have many options other than rice. So she played with that a while. Finally our meat came out with the seafood broth. The meat was delicious, cooked so well and so full of flavor. Surprisingly, my non seafood eating husband, not only tried the soup, but went back for more and then some. I'd say that's testament in itself that we wandered into a good Korean BBQ place. Best I've been to so far in my 30 years!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Delicious.I came here with my sister and here are the dishes we got:- 4 color pork belly ($58) - we are pretty big eaters and could have easily finished the 8 colors, but we wanted to try other dishes too so we settled with 4. We chose garlic, smoked, curry and miso. All of them were tasty, with my favorite being smoked - it's just downright divine when wrapped in one of those crunchy lettuce. Curry is a close contender.- beef bean paste stew ($18) - tasteless and not nearly enough beef. I'd skip this- steamed eggs ($12) - this was just alright. The texture wasn't what i expected. Korean steamed eggs are usually more soft and smooth, but this one has a rather rough texture and might have been overcooked. Portion is huge though.- kimchi fried rice ($8) - SO delicious!! And this being relatively cheaper than other dish with good size portion, i'd definitely get this again.Overall, i'm pretty impressed with this place.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I'm from LA and this place is a disappointment compared to the original. Around $90 something for 8 different kinds of pork belly, with less side dishes and smaller meat portions. In LA, i think it's around $38 for better everything. I guess I can't complain though that there's now a 8 saik in Singapore.  The only upside to this place was its kpop atmosphere fit for pregaming.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: (Let's put aside the fact that I'm vegan. There are times I will socially eat meat. Don't hate.) GETTING THERE: The restaurant is located in The Central Mall on the 2nd floor. Near the escalators. This mall is like a labyrinth so try not to get lost. DEJA VU: When I saw "8 Korean BBQ" I immediately thought of Palsaik, a Korean bbq joint back in Ktown LA. The menu looked especially familiar. The flavors were the exact same as Palsaik's. Turns out the two restaurants are under the same owner. TASTE: I used to be a hardcore carnivore. Meat and carbs all day. So I know a tasty piece of meat when I encounter one. 8 Korean BBQ is legit yo. I didn't expect much because if you've dined at Koreatown LA many times before, you know what's hot and not. 8 Korean BBQ is hot. Their pork belly is JUICY. Their kimchi is a bit salty though. At least the day I had it. So awesome they had brown rice instead of white rice. Puts a smile on a health nut's face. INSTRUCTIONS: Take a piece of lettuce, place on a pink round radish, a slice of pork, then some kimchi. Wrap it up and into your mouth. Repeat. PRICING: 8 Korean BBQ is pricier than Palsaik. The set of eight flavors at Palsaik costs $50. The similar set, if not exactly the same, is double in Singapore's sister location. But if love K-bbq, it's worth every penny. Their juicy pork belly will not fail to disappoint. CONCLUSION: If you ever miss Koreatown LA, you know where to go... 8 Korean BBQ. Make sure you order a bottle of soju with your meal. Gunbae! Cheers! And if you get drunk, don't fall into the river. Those stairs are steep. Please have a designated walking buddy.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I'm from LA and this place is a disappointment compared to the original. Around $90 something for 8 different kinds of pork belly, with less side dishes and smaller meat portions. In LA, i think it's around $38 for better everything. I guess I can't complain though that there's now a 8 saik in Singapore.  The only upside to this place was its kpop atmosphere fit for pregaming.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: As a person that has tried the original in LA (called palsaik), I can say this tastes better. However, the LA one has different cuts of pork and this place just has 8 different flavors. Each 8 flavors are bursting in taste and immensely delicious. The price is about 2.5 times more expensive than the one in LA but its probably bc the overhead is higher in sg. And the quantity is much smaller as well. 98 bucks for 4 people but honestly, 2 people can finish that portion.  I would say its probably one of the best in korean bbq in singapore but thats not really saying much bc korean food in sg is not that great.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-79/90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: One of the better Korean restaurant in town, in my opinion. Good spread of marinated meat; very nice. Love the pork belly and the Kimchi is good too. Service was average and expensive.

Vanya was the most welcoming person. She is fluent in not only the cuisine but the amazing Italian wine selection. I would recommend this restaurant to anyone. The food was outstanding. Fresh and true to the Italian cuisine. The service was outstanding. Five stars from start to finish!

It's been a while since I've been here, and boy has the place changed! After a small conversation with our waiter, who was extremely friendly by the way, we found out the place recently had a facelift. Located slightly off the road from The Central at Clarke Quay, this place serves one of the best Al Granchio's I've had! It is creamy, but without being too cheesy, and they're really generous with the amount of crab meat. Their starters aren't very wide, but their mussels with white wine weren't too bad.

Quite conflicted about this place, some parts of the dishes were good but there were others that were horrible. 1. Grilled chicken breast- Came with some sides, - Mash potatoes - So good! Buttery & rich :) - Salad - ok - Peach color cream was really yummy! - Chicken breast - Unfortunately the main star of the dish was sorely disappointing. It was dry and so tough to eat! Very blend too! If not for the aforementioned sauce, I am not sure how I would have eaten it. 2. Bruschetta & smoked salmon. - This starter dish came after our mains which was weird. - The Bruschetta was cold. It wasn't crispy or toasted :( Overall, despite some small hits we left disappointed with the food and will probably not return again. I read other reviews which suggest that their pizza is not bad but I don't think I could risk being served another disappointing portion of cold bread!

Friday is happy hour all day long.They have different deals daily: 50% off second pizza on tue, off pasta on wed, etc.Only had drinks and tried the panini so far. Decent but not impressive. Pasta and pizza looks to be the better choice. Next time....

I love this place for brunch and dinner - lovely setting by the water, very attentive staff and delicious food and wine selection.Good for groups, couples or solo dining - reasonable prices but feels higher end.

When I'm feeling like a good pizza or pasta (they switch it up every day of the week - 1-for-1s, wine offers, free tea/coffee with dessert), this is the place I go to.Love the location, love the interior, love their products, and for a fine-dining setting (napkins, fine china, silverware), it's usually no more than $20 apiece for a table of two (if you're splitting a pizza with a cooler, or two pastas). Great value for the quality of food (deliciouso, specially their Mushroom Soup, and their desserts are to die for).Service is attentive, waiters even recognised me (for a moment of time I even used to come here every week because I loved it so!). Special mentions to their Ricciotti Salad ($13.50), Tagliatelle el Salmone ($21.50), and the Rustica (pizza, $23.50).

I like this place. I came here once looking for pasta and decent Italian food and I think this is good pasta. I tried the 3 dishes in one plate, and the gnocchi really surprised me, it was probably my favorite dish but of course you can't have too much gnocchi otherwise your tummy just gets filled up. It's not like a high end Italian restaurant but I thought the food was good. I just have to continue to come back to make sure the food is consistent since I last came. But I would definitely recommend this restaurant to others based on my first experience. And I would recommend the gnocchi. The other 2 dishes was a crab meat pasta and lasagna. All are good but gnocchi stood out to me. We paired it with red wine as well.

Nicely located in the Boat quay right next to the river. The food is just average especially the pizza which was a letdown. The spaghetti pomodoro pasta was pretty good. The kitchen is open till 11 which is a plus in case you want some late night food!

Nice place in the city for some pizza and drinks. Good wine collection with a couple of cocktail options.. Not very inspiring starters but the pizza platter is a good option to share. The arabiatta was very spicy but still very tasteful. Nice dessert of chocolate lava cake. Nice place next to the river and away from the costly chaos of boat quay/clark quay.

There is no doubt that Ricciotti has the dishes to attract foodies in Singapore. With a wide range of offering on its menu, there would be that one Italian dish for everyone. I personally prefer their pizzas here - the doughy yet crispy crust when served. The reminiscent of the homemade seafood stew made by belly happy.

Delicious pizza! We had the pizza platter split with 3 people. Salami/mushroom and salami/basil -$48.  Great crust, super flavorful. And the best part is the view and ambience of the place. There was a little miscommunication of how we wanted the pizza so they got us free dessert and shots :) definitely stop by this place!

I usually go here for a good pizza. My favorite is Margherita Regina (fresh tomatoes with basil). The bruschetta with tomatoes is a good appetizer too. Service is attentive. Recommended for dinner as the place has outside tables facing the river. Price in line with the quality.

Nice vibe, good, polite service, good food at reasonable prices.Although it's more of a lunch and dinner place, with excellent pizza, pastas and desserts, it's also a good place for a simple brunch. But a bit too simple - they should expand that brunch menu and we'd be back more often.Nice pace, not the typical Singapore atrocious manner of clearing plates the second you've finished the meal and while you're still chewing. Instead it's a relaxing experience. Friendly, unobtrusive and polite staff.

Another of my favourite coffee joints, Ricciotti was recommended by a friend who was working nearby and dropped in daily for her afternoon fix of tea and cakes. I've not had the chance to try any of the mains or pizzas yet, but from the satisfied looks of other diners together with the aroma that arises from their orders, I can more or less be assured that the food is of decent standard. At night, Ricciotti's ambience becomes a tad more cosy and romantic and is quite a common sight to see dating couples enjoying a glass of bubbly or wine and staring into each others eyes.
Really good placeMy friend and I had baked eggs, egg Benedict and matcha latte.Matcha latte reminds me of the taste I had in Japan and the eggs are awesome.

Came back for dinner. One can easily overlook this place, hidden by queues for the two Song Fah bak kut teh outlets, and located on the less busy side of New Bridge/Eu Tong Sen. (Except for the sad-looking panini's), the food rocks! The chef, who may be more talented as a chef than as a business manager, would do well at a premium restaurant!

Haven't posted a review in a very long time but when you find a gem, something moves you to leave a remark.Looked this place up on Yelp on my way to a Japanese restaurant and my stomach changed its mind.Nice clean decor and jazz tunes created a great ambiance.I thought breakfast food would be served all day but that was not the case.  But I was not disappointed with their dinner.Soft shell crab pasta caught my attention and it surprisingly delivered.  Pasta was light, crab was nicely seasoned and cooked with the perfect crunch and with every bite, the deep flavor permeated my mouth.  The glass of Chardonnay would have complemented well but the wine was not chilled unfortunately.I also ordered ice hazelnut latte and the lava cake and my dinner was near perfect.5 stars!
This is my first time visit and eat at Wanna Cuppa! I would love come back here again.
Good place to have food and cakes and coffee, tea and drinks. The cake taste delicious, drinks is good too.Price however not cheap.

New kid in the block ! Wanna Cuppa opened only sometime in Nov/Dec 2015, conveniently situated right opposite Clarke Quay station. I was there on a Sunday afternoon and it was pleasantly quiet. The ambiance is relaxing and there's ample seats. Flat white was not bad. The enoki fries was a tad oily.Didn't try anything else on the menu. They had quite a selection of cakes on display too but I was too full for anything.I'd go back if I happen to be around the area.

I don't agree with the other reviewers so 1 star to make the reviews here on Yelp seem legit. I went a few months ago, and I thought the service was not amazing, and food was horrible. In my opinion.My friend ordered salad with chicken and she said the chicken was way too dry and forced herself to eat the salad. I had a pasta with meat and tomato sauce and I just couldn't eat any of it. It felt to me like they just microwaved meat and hence the tough meat, and pasta was not fresh it was just not up to the standard that I was expecting. I also ordered a coffee but nothing beat ronin or punch in that neighborhood in my opinion. Therefore I haven't gone back ever since.I'm writing this review because I am looking for other cafes and restaurants nearby this neighborhood since I just moved here. But to see this place on top of Ronin made me think the reviews are not legitimate, especially with only 3 other reviews. So let's be real. It may be good enough for locals, but as an Asian who was born and raised abroad, I personally don't like it, but give it one try, as I did, and decide for yourself.

Love the interior. The name cuppa has actually captured my attention to step it for a quick coffee! It's not easy to find a place with good coffee with pretty and lasting coffee art made with skills here. Will definitely be back here again!

address: 35 Boat Quay, Boat Quay Singapore Singapore
comment: Hey, this place is not the BEST but it's also not bad for a quick lunch. It's in the very touristy Boat Quay strip and there's usually a crowd of people waiting to dine here for lunch, usually the work crowd. Bonus that this place is only a 3 min walk from my office, but bummer that I never come to Boat Quay for lunch... always forgetting how close it is.I'll try to make it more of a habit.Set lunch is $11.50++ and you get to choose from a variety of dishes. If you bring a bigger group you get more dishes. We had a party of 4, so we got to choose 5 dishes with unlimited rice and juice. Not bad.

The restaurant served serve Taiwanese-inspired dishes at mainly $5, and $10, plus a couple at $15 and $25. Recently the restaurant extended its operating hours to cater to supper crowd during the weekends.Black Fungus | Dashi Ponzu (S$5)cold black fungus marinated with dashi ponzu dressingQuite crunchy and refreshing.Chicken Hearts | Fried Ginger (S$5)soy glazed chicken hearts, fried gingerTender and well braised.Corn | Hoisin Mayonnaise (S$5)charred sweet corn served with hoisin mayonnaise It may looked simple, but the corn was sweet and juicy without overpowering by the sauce on top.Dough Fritters | Minced Pork | Haus Saus (S$5)Interesting topped with dough fritters on top, although wished that the minced pork could cook finer.Golden Frog Legs | Haus Chilli Mayo (S$5) The legs were savoury and tender on its own. With the sauce, it packed a punch.Golden King Mushroom | Plum Powder (S$5) Quite an addictive snack to munch on with its savoury taste.Braised Duck | Taw Kwa | Egg (S$10) Tender meat although quite boney to eat. The bean curd was kind too strong in the spice taste.Braised Pig Intestines | Fresh Garlic (S$10)braised large intestines, haus saus, freshly grated garlic The innards was tender without any offensive taste. Burnt Chilli Chicken (S$10)charred chicken thigh cooked with loads of chilliTender juicy meat which packed a punch.Crispy Duck Leg (S$10) It looked dried but the meat turned out to be quite tender.Lu Rou (S$10)braised pork belly in special haus saus Tender well flavoured although could further more tender. Oyster Omelette | Lard (S$10)Not the usually local style or the Taiwanese style. Packed a kind of meaty texture maybe due to the usage of lard.Pork Chop (S$10) It was served cut up into pieces for easy handling. Quite tender and juicy.Accompanied with Shiny Rice (S$0.50)rice drizzled with lard and garlic oil Quite flavoured although wished that it was served with minced spring onion and ginger paste which would enhance the flavour more. Sweet Potato Congee (S$3)The porridge was made with dashi broth, which tasted so delicious on its own.For dessert, there was only one item on the menu which wasRed Tea Jelly | Pearls | Cream (S$5)red tea jelly, tapioca pearls, cream It was like a reconstructed version of Taiwanese bubble milk tea.

I really wanted to like this place having read about it online. I liked the concept a lot and the dishes sounded good! Unfortunately, it was a bit of a let down overall and I am probably not going back unless I have to.I was thrilled by how the dishes were priced in increments of 5 starting at $5. It's a good way to keep track of how much your meal is going to be, and unfortunately also a good way to rack up a hefty bill for what I had assumed would be an affordable dinner. We ordered about 5 things because everything came in really small portions and it added up quite quickly.They're famous for the braised pork which was alright in my opinion.What I did like was the steak with pickled cabbage - for $10 the steak was quite tender and flavorful. The brussel sprouts with salted pork and shiitake mushrooms were quite nice, I thought the vinegar added a nice flavor. Everything else we ordered wasn't really worth mentioning.I think it's more reasonably priced at lunch... Although I'm not sure I'd go back if I can get delicious prawn noodles or yong tau foo on the same street for the same price.

Following the success of Five Ten (where menu items are priced at $5 or $10 each) this casual Taiwanese concept has been relaunched as The Salter Plum at a new location on Circular Road. Best selling items are their Lu Rou Fan ($11.60 after svc charge) - tasty and accompanied by a nice chilli dip but their rice portion ($0.50/bowl) is on the small side. Lunch time deal offers better value. I still prefer the Thai version 'Khao Kha Moo' especially the exquisite serving at Charoen Saeng Silom in BKK.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street The Central #B1-48 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Ever since I came back from BKK I've been craving some good Tom Kha Gai - the milky, non-spicy version of it's cousin, the famous Tom Yum.So I've been religiously going into every Thai food restaurant- or any eatery that proclaims itself to be "Thai" and ordering this soup. Some come a little close, most were misses. The version I'm looking for is totally non-spicy, milky rich, a hint of sweetness due to tomatoes but still maintaining the sour tang Thai soups are famous for.This unassuming little eatery at the basement of Central hits home for me. I can't vouch for the other items on their menu but if the kitchen is able to create a solid Tom Kha Gai, they have my approval.They're not open during irregular hours, only during lunch and dinner (12-2ish, 6-830). Crowd is pretty thin too. I hope business picks up for them, would be sad to see them close like most eateries in the basement have.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street The Central #B1-48 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Very patient and help explain the menu items. I didn't get what I expected (meat stir fried then rice on the side) but it was tasty, hot and prepared quickly. Good prices and the my accept credit cards.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street The Central #B1-48 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: So good! I ordered Tom Kha Gai (not on the menu, but they happily obliged) based on a previous review. Fast, fresh, hot and delicious. Friendly service and free WiFi. They're still here in the basement of Central three years later, despite the aforementioned reviewer's concerns, so that's great!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street The Central #B1-48 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I decided that the food on my second visit is better and so they deserve a second star. $7.90 gets you the set lunch which includes a appetizer (choice of spring roll, papaya salad, or Tom yum soup) and a main course. The pad kee mao is done with a good amount of spice that leaves your lips tingling.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street The Central #B1-48 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Simple, fuss-free lunch at a decent price.Set meal for $7.90-8.90. comes with 1 main, drink and a side. Mains1. pad thai - recommended but sadly not on the lunch set menu. 2. green curry with chicken and rice - good. 3. tom yum kuay teow (noodles in soup) - my favorite :) not too spicy. 4. pad kee mao with chicken (stir fried noodles) - a bit too oily. Drink 5. thai ice coffee/tea - i dont like the coffee. the tea is ok by me, maybe a little too orange for comfort but otherwise ok. Side 6. spring rolls - average.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Mutton rice !Near to the office. Easy to grab before the crowds, and the mutton surprises on the up side.Soft flavourful mutton goes very well with the rice. Even the side of potatoes with current leaves and peas (which I dislike) seems to be enhancing the meal.I am impressed. Not a hole in the wall, overly colorful towards red and orange decor. Ignore that and you shod be fine. I will return

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: A quick, cheap, no-frills eatery in Clarke Quay.As this is 24 hours, I wouldn't be surprised if people come here after partying nearby. But what do I know, I'm currently 7.5 months pregnant and totally an auntie these days so I cannot be trusted in terms of what's cool!I kept my order simple with some kosong prata. The curry served on the side was mild, and pricing was under $5.This place can fill up after a while, so it's probably not the best for a leisurely meal during peak hours.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: Not the healthiest or most delicious food, but surprisingly, at the River Valley Road branch, I had the yummiest possible Tulang Merah, cooked to order. Not much meat, but the sauce is delish.

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: I tried the nasi goreng pattaya during lunchtime 1pm. The rice was well cooked and the chicken while average was made up for with the egg served along with the rice. The food and drinks came relatively quickly and the waiters were quite polite.Downsides: the food were served in styrofoam plates that is quite unappealing, the food prices were quite expensive but understandable due to the location.Upsides: the place was rather cooling without it being to cold. The food variety was quite huge. The food is quite nice, and rather appetising. The food and drinks were also served pretty fast. Although rather small, the crowd made it quite a nice place to eat even in 1pm lunch hour.Overall, not a bad place to eat if you crave indian and malay food, or are just looking for a quick bite in a quaint restaurant to beat the lunch crowd

opening: [('Mon', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Tue', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Wed', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Thu', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Fri', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sat', ['Open 24 hours']), ('Sun', ['Open 24 hours'])]
comment: 29 items covering Indian Muslim, Thai Muslim, South & North Indian and Western food. So all the bases are covered. But within 1 of the items, Prata, there is a subset of almost 50 additional types! U can have tissue, coin, cheese milo, mayonnaise or ice cream prata. The Prata Bomb caught my eye. Next time. I go tried & true and stick to my knitting. Egg & onion prata. Made fresh and on the spot (u can't have it any other way). Curry is a bit tarty, which is ok. Onions come out well and egg adds texture. Prata, lightly crisped and not oily. Added bonus: a side of dhal served on the plate. Simple, tasty and inexpensive.

Easy eating place, with bento set of the day cost $9.90 with free soup and drink. No go for the soup cuz it tasted like soya sauce..Bento is tasty and filling. We ordered the breaded oysters too, which tasted normal.Overall dinner experience, mehhhhhhh...

rest_name: Tiong Bahru Hainanese Boneless Chicken Rice & Curry Rice
comment: I ordered char siew rice. It was probably the BEST char siew I've ever had. It came with a pretty big chops too and it was only $3.50++ any place with unlimited garlic-garlic sauce/dipping always has an extra value to me

rest_name: Tiong Bahru Hainanese Boneless Chicken Rice & Curry Rice
comment: A very average plate of chicken rice. I think most people associate Tiong Bahru with old school traditional good local food, or at least I did. I just wanted a simple quick lunch and it was fairly empty at 2ish pm. I ordered the chicken rice set which included a small plate of veggies. The only highlight would be the vegetables which were fresh and sweet and crunchy. At least they were not limp and overcooked. The rice was so-so, lacking the fragrance of chicken rice. The roasted chicken was not too bad, tender and deboned, making it easy to eat. Plus there was no layer of fats under the skin. The chili sauce which was the critical component of a good chicken rice was a bit mild. It did not have the oommph to take it to the next level, likewise for the ginger. Besides chicken rice (white and roasted), it also served curry rice. I think most diners were having chicken rice when I was there. Maybe that would be the better choice. I would eat here only if there were no other options.

rest_name: Tiong Bahru Hainanese Boneless Chicken Rice & Curry Rice
comment: So bad so bad.I tried the lunch set C which has pork chop, a side of cabbage, plus a whole fried fish. Sounds like great value at $5.50..but what's the point when it is so bad. I never had a thinner pork fillet. The pork chop has more flour than pork. It might as well be just fried flour. The fried fish is a whole fish...it''s ok I guess.Most people were eating the chicken rice. Maybe I should have just went for the norm instead of being adventurous. But it's going to take a while before I head back.

rest_name: Tiong Bahru Hainanese Boneless Chicken Rice & Curry Rice
comment: It's an okay chicken rice. Not great, not good, but not bad. Still a touch better than food court chicken rice. The steamed chicken is a little lean but still tasty with oily skin. It is also a bit bloodier than others. Not very bloody. But you notice it. The good thing about this place is the big menu. They also have lor ba, fried tofu, porridge, all kinds of sides and side dishes. It's conveniently located and feeds the office crowd in the area.

rest_name: Tiong Bahru Hainanese Boneless Chicken Rice & Curry Rice
comment: Ordered a steamed chicken set, with pork fillet and some vegetables. The vegetables is a little salty, the pork chop fillet only has tastes of the flour and salty stuff there is no meat tasted at all. The set menu isn't that value for money after all due to the little meat they give. I guess, working crowds at the central really doesn't have much of a choice for good food nowadays that they have to succumb to this.

This is perhaps THE BEST sushi place I have tried in my life to date. You must ask the chef owner to basically do whatever he wants. You will get the most unique flavors. I almost wanted to ask if he was single so that I can eat like this every day. It is THAT good.Seared amberjack. Must try.Ootoro. Of course. Teared up eating the uni / sweet shrimp concoction. Cried when trying the fish sperm?!?!?! Yes. Fish sperm. How have I not eaten this before?!?!?!?!?! Sooooooooooooo buttery and smooth and omg how I want to let it melt on my tongue all over again. Truffle oil anything. Wagyu beef. Why are you so yums at a sushi place ?!?!?!Just say yes.

Superb! To die for Chirashi.Been seeing many Instagram post on Chirashi. Definitely a food trend here in SG. Asked my "Yao-Gui" (greedy) friends to bring me to one and so we ended up at Koji.Visited on a Saturday, the area which is the business district was quiet and relatively empty. It's a tiny shop/bar. A rectangular table bar sitting, seats are lined along the perimeter. Ours seats are right at the back, needed to inch slowly down the narrow path. Their stools have a panel underneath where you can place your bags, rather awkward and ended up leaving my bag on my lap.We had ordered their famous chirashi and one of us had a pork cheek bowl. The Chirashi was amazing. Perhaps I'm used to the U.S. portions, when served I was thinking what a small bowl for the price. Turn out I was wrong, it was filled with so much yummy juicy sashimi and roe. Every bite was absolutely delicious and satisfying. The mix of crunch, juice and taste. Loved it! Highly highly recommended. (Unless you don't take raw food)

A pretty looking bowl chirashi don topped with generous cuts of sashimi and roe, with puffed rice for texture and crunch.  Truly fresh sashimi should be firm, clean-tasting and naturally sweet. But there's no way to tell how fresh the fish here is, because It is served warmish (therefore some slices limp), and the natural flavours masked by a sesame soy marinade. This is a cozy sushi bar and service was warm. Pity about the chirashi. I won't be back.

A great hole in the wall sushi place that is the epitome of efficiency yet is warm and inviting. The environment has to be experienced. The quality of the food is great, ambience is 'fun' for an American traveler (tight space used incredibly well while decorations give it a good vibe), the staff are quiet but approachable and the variety for the size of place is amazing.When I'm back in Singapore, I look forward to going again!

If you need a fix for sushi and sashimi in the heart of the CBD, Koji would certainly not be a bad choice.We tried all 4 sets of sushi on the menu and they were all delectable (albeit a bit on the small side). The chirashi bowl was also good and the salmon in particular was juicy. All topped off with a bottle of sake, the meal was good overall.However, one thing weighing against the place would be its service. If you are seated outside, as we were, it can be difficult to get the attention of staff who usually stay inside. The place is also slightly cramped but that's a small quibble.

Girl's night out to celebrate someone's birthday and so we decided to try Koji's omakase. I like giving chef's a free hand with the food since they do work with produce all day and should know better than me what's fresh and what works together. I wasn't expecting a whole lot since Koji is known for value-for-money kaisendon's rather than particular finesse with sushi, let alone cooked food.We took the $128 option and there were some good dishes. I loved the grilled wafu steak a lot - it was marbled, cooked medium rare with a dash of salt and pepper. It was perfect, so I ordered another plate ala carte. The sashimi platter was pretty neat with a good development of flavors from a light amaebi to a chutoro at the end, though it included the foreigner-friendly swordfish. The nigiri series also featured some seasonal fish that if I remember correctly included chidai (probably yellow back), aji (horse mackerel) and hotate (scallop), dashed with nikiri, sometimes sprinkled with what looked like sudachi or kabusu zest (one too many times actually) and charred here and there. So very crowd pleasing fish but no unusual fish. For some reason, while the fish on the sushi was dressed, the wasabi was plated instead of applied underneath the fish and the rice, gaaaah, that really frustrated me. It was bland and too cold in my opinion, like an afterthought instead of a feature that brings the fish to life. Anyway, another really cool dish was a crab shell holding black miso mixed with crab meat and i think some roe. It was rich, warm and utterly delightful.What didn't do it for me was the tofu starter that seemed kinda hard like it was packaged and not home made. The clam soup was straightforward and could have actually done with tart or chive-ish herbs. Can't remember what else we had but it wasn't memorable. The customary OCD-presentation-skils you'd expect from a Japanese chef were also missing from this otherwise fun bunch of Asian chefs - our dishes were not cleared before the next ones arrived, my first cup of green tea was lukewarm, questions about the fish showed the chefs didn't really know their provenance and the little things like slicing a tomato evenly were lacking. One might argue hey this is a $128 omakase but I'd argue you can get a pretty damn good sushi lunch set at Shinji (my default for excellent and consistent quality) for $125 or less.To be fair, the sake recommendation we got was decent and we had an enjoyable, alcohol-enabled time that evening. If you are price conscious though, do your math because the alcohol and additional ala carte dishes can add up. I'd say Koji is a decent entry level sushi bar and the lunch offerings look like value-for-money. But if you're expecting high quality, really creative Japanese cuisine or you're curious/finicky about good food, then you should look elsewhere.

This is the place for BBQ Japanese lamb. Prices range from $30 (normal set)-$65++ (premium set). You grill your own meat just like in a typical Yakiniku place/Korean BBQ. Highball served at $12/glass. Lamb meat was rather lean and dry for the standard set.

So...there was a bit of a queue here, and they had on display a glaringly muted green rice. My friend went 'eh eh green rice!' so went in into the queue. Turns out the green rice wasn't all that special, barring a faint hint of pandan taste to it. The idea was a lot more novel than the taste itself. Yet we had absolutely no regrets. The price was oh so reasonable: I paid $2.90 and got a great helping of the alien rice, ikan bilis (without nuts - yes!!!!), a very unreasonably small quarter of luncheon meat (disappointing!), an egg (always a must in nasi lemaks in my book) and most majestically, a very wonderful chicken drumstick (which would cost $1.20 each). The chicken was so juicy and tender inside, yet you would not have thought so just looking at it because it looked so dry and hard on the outside, yet the skin was just so well crispy and seasoned really well. I'll definitely be back for lunch sometime!

rest_name: Colombo Restaurant Authentic Shri Lankan Cuisine
comment: The food was decent, views were beautiful but the price was outrageous for what you are getting. The restaurant was practically empty (4-5 rooftop tables being used only when we went on a late Sunday evening). They force you to pay a minimum of $43++ per person. While the food did taste decent, it was nothing spectacular to warrant that absurd minimum. Rather than forcing people to pay a set dollar amount for overpriced food, they can simply state that each individual must order an entree, if they must set a minimum. Also, I asked what one of the drinks consisted of, and the server kept repeating it had ice and it was sweet...that doesn't tell me anything about what's in the drink. Clearly, he did not know what was in it, which is okay, but instead of simply stating "let me go find out for you" he repeated "ice and sweet" like 5-6 times until we finally asked if he could get someone else to come explain it to us. I would not go there again knowing the price minimum and service.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-70, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Good ambiance good venue good viewsThe nice thing about the place is that it is in a very nice location. Easy access, short distances to other party places, nice views of the river and the surrounding neons. The selection of food is decent, and the quality above average. The prices may be above avergae but we are paying for the venue too.Service is prompt and attentive. The weather is nice and breezy in the evening. Not too quiet, just enough buzz and allows us to carry decent conversations.Nice chillaxing place.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-70, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: It is pronounced "skew"! (As in skewers)Now that we've got that out of the way... Had lunch here on a weekday. Had a meat platter that I shared with friends and it was pretty good! Steak was nicely done, and the ribs were particularly good. Yummy sauce and meat was tender.Also had chicken wings that you should know was basically har cheong gai. But good!Also had fried chicken skins which was as fried and as crispy as it could be and did its job - which is to make my beer go down easier. 1 for 1 beer at lunch!Why people so harsh? :D This place has nice food and beer, what.Oh, service was excellent too!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-70, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I've been coming here for at least 4 years...mainly for the beers. I think Sque has the most reasonable selection of commercially brewed beers available on Clarke Quay. It's a combination of inside (no views) outside (great views of river and passing trade) seating. Staff are friendly. Service is quick. Food quality has improved...Recently had a Nicoise salad for lunch...it was fantastic. Whole seared slices of tuna, not canned tuna flakes, with all the necessary ingredients like boiled egg, anchovies, red onion slices, tomatoes, cos lettuce. Highly recommended for happy hour visitations as well. Would give 5 stars but their public toilet facilities are quite a distance away.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-70, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: 1. Affordable drinks - The only bar along the clark quay stretch that has 1for1 alcohol all night long (till 11pm) on weekends :) yay!!! Other bars usually close their drinks promo by 8-830pm. 2. Unlike most bars, they have real food instead of just bar food. - The dessert was pretty decent :) - Probably because they are a restaurant as well.3. Great service! despite our party being huge (20pax+++)  and constantly moving around/mingling and changing seats, the waiter knew exactly what everyone ordered and served each person his/her correct bill. Very impressed.The person I spoke to was also very accommodating to our big group, suggestion menu choices, drinks etc. Emailing me personally. Other bars I checked out, Harry's, Cafe iguana along the same Clark Quay stretch weren't as efficient or helpful. Cafe iguana was probably the worst! I practically had to chase down the manger to get a quote on food etc. 4. Good view of the Singapore river. 5. Also, not too noisy, dark or smokey like other bars. - Perfect for having a conversation with friends or networking while enjoying your drink at the same time. I didn't have to shout into my friends' ears to be heard.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-70, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: It is extremely unfortunate that my experience with this place has been less than exceptional on the one visit that I have been here since I started using Yelp. I visited SQUE for the first time about 2 years ago, for Restaurant Week and both the service and food was extremely commendable. Since then, I have become a semi-regular here because of their amazing Happy Hour deals (from 5pm - 7pm and then 9pm - 11pm, that's definitely my tip for coming here). I have been very fortunate to have been served for the same lady the last 2 years, perhaps it was by coincidence that she is always here when I visit.However, on today's visit she was not one of those who were on duty and I can definitely say that the service here is less than exceptional. I was here for first drinks with my girlfs after dinner nearby and stayed after they left to have drinks with the boyf who came for dinner / to send me home. While here with the girls, it took us 10mins to try and get the attention of the waiter just to order our drinks - which in all honesty is not great when you have about 5 - 6 waiters around. SQUE is not an exceptional huge place, and I don't expect this to happen because I have always been served under 5mins in my previous visits. Perhaps you could say that I have been pampered by my precious waiters here, but I would expect some level of service at least when it is a lull period. The boyf came at 9:20 while my girlfs left at about 9:30 - and while I would think that the place was a bit more crowded than an hour plus before, most of the tables had already been served. He ordered a soup and pizza, and while the pizza did not come until 9:40 which I would say is understandable but, the soup had not arrived. We decided to cancel the soup order since appetizer had not arrived before the main course and we were denied that cancellation. Their reason - the soup and pizza are done in different ways and that our soup was being prepared. While I understand that, I really don't think that a soup that has been pre-prepared and reheated would take 35mins to come. Even making the mushroom soup from scratch would have taken less time than that! The soup was extremely salty and didn't seem like a freshly made soup at all. The bread that came along with the soup had dark black toast burn marks, but it was still soft as if it wasn't toasted at all. This was DEFINITELY NOT a dish that would have taken 35mins to make.
