I wouldn't recommend coming here for food, and definitely not for drinks outside Happy Hours. The service here is below expectations (compared to my expectations of other restaurants and not with my previous visits to SQUE itself because I think that would be unfair - probably that waitress that usually serves is was one of the best here) and unless you're prepared for slow service, I would recommend heading to Clarke Quay and its myriad of better restaurants.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-70, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: 1 for 1 daily happy hour starts at 9pm.I have only had drinks + small bites here. Tried the quesadillas and ceasar salad. Both were pretty ok. The quesadilla was much better than the awful one I had at Chili's. But we are here only for the drinks. yeah to happy hours. The place is also rather big and thus, we never had much issue finding a table. Small AC area only, but do sit outdoors, you get a nice view of the Singapore river facing Clarke Quay.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-70, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Lunchtime around Clarke Quay is pretty quiet as things don't start to liven up until mid-afternoon then go late into the night. Even so, this place is open for lunch. Actually, the billboard displays of their dishes don't really do their food justice. The Soup of the Day I had (Pumpkin) was average but the Tomato & Mozzarella Salad with Tuna was very good. I was pleasantly surprised, I admit. The riverside location with people and boats going by makes a very relaxing lunchtime atmosphere. The sandwiches I saw being served to other diners look great too.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-70, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: One of the BEST bars in Clarke quay !! Awesome staff and selection of German beers Also happy hour all weekend 1 for 1Weekdays same till 7 , then 9-11Perfect

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-70, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I haven't eaten there, so I am basing this review on the bar. Specifically, on the fact that they have hundreds of different beers to choose from. Ask them for the full beer menu if they don't offer it initially. There are lots of craft beer from around the world to choose from, although I'd like to see more more American beers. Of course, the extensive list has it's drawbacks. They apparently run out of popular beers often, because I walked away disappointed on two different occasions when they didn't have any Stone IPA. And you will pay a premium for the variety and the location. It is just steps away from the Clarke Quay MRT, right on the river.Update:  I finally tried the food and was pleasantly surprised. The roasted chicken sandwich was great. Juicy and flavorful with fresh, crispy wedge fries. The happy hour really takes the bite out of the prices. Two-for-one draft beer after 9:00, and half price bottles after 10.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-70, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: What you would expect for American food in Singapore. Fish fingers for the kids are excellent. The rest of what we are (quesadilla and sausages) was pretty mediocre.

This is the worst restaurant I have ever been to. Food is awful, taste stale and the sauce tastes like it came out of a bag. The service is terrible, you have to stand up to get anyone's attention and it is very expensive for what you get when it's actually only worth 1/10 of the price. DO NOT go here!

If I can give a 0 star, I would. This place is a total tourist trap. The hostess told us they would give us free drinks and 30% off happy hour. As soon as they seated us, we were completely ignored. The food was ok. We waited for the rice for so long that we finished all the entires. We told the waitress we did not need the orders of rice anymore but they pretended they did not understand us. We gave us the rice anyways. They also did not keep their promise of 30% off and charged us full price. Don't go to this place.

This is probably one of the most expensive place in Singapore the food is really bad for the price, a really small portions they serve cold and really old the food, if you are around better not stop and keep forward, for the prices that they charge you can get a better service and food in the Marina Sans bay or the Fullerton.
Terrible.  Overpriced mediocre food, and small portions.  I have hAd better in strip malls.  Stay away.

Worst place in Boat Quay. Told us they had Happy hour all night. When we sat down, they said it was only until midnight. It was 00.01. Ridiculous. Rude staff; you're not missing out. Avoid at all costs

I came here for the sambal bee hoon. The Sambal Bee Hoon used to be drier, whiter (now is like brownish), and spicier with a Sambal taste. Now it's just blah....Nothing much else to say except the food tasted better before. Wonder what happened.

Ordered the Sauced-Chicken Rice and it was terrible. The Iced Milo was diluted and doesn't even taste anything like it. My colleague ordered the Fish & Chips and the portion was pathetic. Fish meat was limited and it was covered in flour. Please do not visit.

address: Empress Place 01-03 Asian Civilisations Museum Singapore 179555 Singapore
comment: We really enjoy Siem Reap.  the setting is nice and they have a large patio, the service can be hit or miss.  the food tends to be fresh and very yummy.  we are here often and will for sure be back.we have ben told that the food could have a lot of MSG, but i am not sure about this.  i know it tastes good.

address: Empress Place 01-03 Asian Civilisations Museum Singapore 179555 Singapore
comment: This used to be called Indochine, so I'm not sure why it is called Siem Reap II now. The cuisine is largely the same as before: South-East Asian specialties or Western cuisine with a twist. This time, I had a steak with a Cambodian inspired sauce because the East Asain cuisine can be better appreciated at other places at a much lower price. My wife had Tom Yam which was OK but not special. My French fries were hand-cut and crisp  excellent  and also the steak was fortunately OK, although the waiter never bothered to ask how i wanted it.The service was however terrible: the waiter hardly understood any English and came with a wrong drink and later with a wrong plate (I noticed the same happened at another table). Even the waiter that came to help him had absolutely no idea of what drinks were on the menu.Of course, nothing beats the setting..

Came here for lunch with a girl friend, we sat indoors by the window (we later heard there is outdoor area too), which provided amazing view :) Came here for restaurant week. The watermelon/ham with pistachio and bacon bits started was AMAZING and the highlight of the meal. I salivate right now thinking about it.P.S. It was a bit hard to take pics because the inside of restaurant is much darker than the outside, aiii.

I'm in Singapore and my story starts at marina bay sands, I was taking the elevator up to the pool and meet two beautiful Brazilian girls. We were all traveling and it was our first time in SG. I ended up hanging out for the day with them and after spending time at the pool we decided it was time for dinner. I freshened up and headed out for dinner. I took a grab and got there pretty fast. I took maybe two elevators to get up there. It was a little confusing but I managed to figure it out and eventually I made way into a big room with floor to ceiling windows and an amazing view. We decided to go with 5 courses and wine pairings. We also had a food presentation with different some tastings that was fun to see. Food preparation and quality was amazing. Service was attentive but not stuffy.
Good decent western restaurant and a nice wedding venue. The 4-course dinner was served in a timely manner and efficient. The food tasted pretty decent despite being colder than usual.

Food, ambiance and service was good, though there are small details that could be improve, was asking for a favor in charging my phone as my battery was dead but they don't have a charger, and no wifi . Could have been great if they have available in case of guests emergency. Would still Comr back anyway.

This place is all about the view. It's on the 61st floor of One Raffles Place (the old OUB Centre building). Came with colleagues for lunch and they let us roam around the venue to check out the view as well as go upstairs to the 1-altitude terrace to get the 360 panoramic view of Singapore atop the tallest building in Singapore. The food and service were good but nothing memorable or out of this world. The preset lunch menus were reasonably priced at $32++ for 2 courses and $38++ for 3 courses.Would I come back here? Probably, but only for work functions as it's in the same building as my office!

Nice dining experience; our meals were delicious and the views were spectacular along with the ambiance. Attentive waitstaff and a very hospitable manager in the dining room (I believe his name was Eddie).

I wanted to see the fireworks for National Day - and decided this would be the best place to see the fireworks and join the Nation in celebrating Singapore's Birthday. It was close to impossible to get a table - but somehow it worked. We sat near the window, the view was stellar, and the menu was pretty comprehensive.What I Love: What I ordered was pretty okay - the food was tasty, the service was very personable, and the staff was great. Very attentive, sensitive and nice. I ordered their cocktail, A Younger Man, and I have to say, he was delicious! ;D The entree' was good and my main was Fish, which was fresh.What I Don't Love: We ordered a salad as well, and it very average. The salads I make at home are wayyy more tasty. The furnishings could have been updated a little bit - like the carpet, etc.

The menu at Stellar surprises because the flavours and textures hit you on different levels - comfort food (like their take on pasta carbonara), Asian influences (like the toro truffle miso), and great flavours (like the salt beef, oysters done two ways and gruyere souffle)Love the tasting portions of 5 to 7 courses for dinner, it seems like you want to try everything and this gives you a good chance to. And even though the tasting portions seem small, I was surprised how full I was after. We had a great bottle of Cab Sauv to accompany dinner, and was worth the splurgeWish we'd had space for the dessert experience - we could only eye the other tables enjoying the whole pressent-at-your-table dessert art. And the view on the 62nd level definitely doesn't disappoint for sure. Totally enjoyable evening with friends.Update - went back last week and they have a new Constellations gastronomic menu that offers 6, 7 or 8 courses, including dessert! The 7 course was perfect for us, and we got to order from an amazing selection of their top dishes mentioned above, plus the fantastic dessert art where they come to the table to create your desserts in one large platter. It was amazing to watch AND savour - so yummy, especially the yoghurt creme brulee and valrhona chocolate ball

Went for Valentine's Day and had to do the set VDay menu at S$160 per person.It was an incredible let-down to say the least. We had about 7 courses and while all of them looked beautiful, none were memorable and only one was actually something that I would want to have again.Service was great, if not too over the top. Waiters would come in with a tray of dishes and stand near your table, because a second waiter was needed to put the plates on tables. But everyone was polite, warm, and welcoming--you paid for it, after all.The meal was mediocre. The only thing that was memorable was also one of the simpler courses---steak in a simple broth with a small salad (...three bites) and a small meat-filled puff pastry on top of what I assume was some sort of fruit (plums?).Stellar is not so stellar at fine, envelope-pushing-dining but unfortunately that's exactly what it's trying to do. All the meals were too over the top and ambitious on idea, plating, and design, but in terms of execution...not the best.The courses didn't make sense--they didn't flow together or have any sort of link. It seemed like the kitchen was just doing what's trendy or popular in the food world at the moment...at the same time. My dinner date and I were left pretty speechless---often times the food on one plate didn't go together...it just didn't make sense. Or we would be presented with a really magnificent looking something, but one bite would prove that it was nothing but show.I was really excited about coming here and the views really are spectacular. But I would never come here again or recommend it to anyone. I paid more than S$400 for the dinner (not including alcohol) and it tasted like it was no more than S$6.Also, they charge you almost $10 for a bottle of Fiji water and they put it in this fancy little metal tin that's just high enough as to not obscure the Fiji label. God bless Asia and their love of name brands.

Menu is so complex and pricy . Service is very slow as well. It took us forever to get our food and had to wait between one course to the next! Food is ok and not worth the price ! I had much better meals and much cheaper !

We rented out the entire place for the night, for a friend's 26th birthday party - great venue. I can't comment on the service or food as we rented it out for a private event, so I can only comment about the venue as a private event space. We had security at the bottom to escort guests up and to ensure there were no gate-crashers. The party was big enough to accommodate the 100+ guests we had. We had buffet tables lined up on both sides, an MC, a DJ and an open bar. Guests had ample room for dancing in the middle.It's a great space if you're looking to hold a private event for about 100 or so people.  We also had access to 1-altitude, the bar above Stellar, which has stunning views and a killer atmosphere.

I wanted to see the fireworks for National Day - and decided this would be the best place to see the fireworks and join the Nation in celebrating Singapore's Birthday. It was close to impossible to get a table - but somehow it worked. We sat near the window, the view was stellar, and the menu was pretty comprehensive.What I Love: What I ordered was pretty okay - the food was tasty, the service was very personable, and the staff was great. Very attentive, sensitive and nice. I ordered their cocktail, A Younger Man, and I have to say, he was delicious! ;D The entree' was good and my main was Fish, which was fresh.What I Don't Love: We ordered a salad as well, and it very average. The salads I make at home are wayyy more tasty. The furnishings could have been updated a little bit - like the carpet, etc.
Great Urban Music and Outdoor Sitting! great staff who offered great drinks especially if u dance hard!

This a very light review of drinks with a friend at BQ Bar at Boat Quay.The staff was effective.  They were quick to ask about next rounds.  They always swapped the ashtray out.  They were not necessarily friendly and they didn't engage in banter.  But there was quite a bit of staff and they insured that things were taken care of.BQ Bar has a very laid back feel.  They do not have a very large beer selection on tap.  I remember Tiger, Heineken & Kirin.  They have quite a few more options in bottles.  They also serve cocktails.  I personally did not try any of their food. I actually think their food comes from nearby Dharma's Kebabs.For a place to grab a couple of drinks, it worked.  From my experience, this really isn't a destination bar.
Wonderful rolls (they call them kababs for some reason). Chicken tikka, paneer are awesome. The cajun fries are over tge top. Whenever I want to indulge in fries, I go here!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-31 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Why in the world has it taken me so long to write this review?!  I LOVE this place!  They have a bunch of locations all over Singapore and I've been to several of them over the years and even brought home or had others bring me their kaya spread.  It's so amazing!  I've tried other brands and tossed them after one try.  They don't taste anything like what Ya Kun produces.I'm a sucker for the kaya toast with butter.  Chunks of butter and kaya slathered on crunchy whole wheat toast bread with the crusts cut off.  This might sound really gross until you try it.  It's amazing!  I usually get an iced Milo to go with it.  The locations vary in the way they are designed and this one is very large so it's a bit squishy.  It doesn't matter though.  I only care about the food which doesn't take me long to inhale!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-31 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Stopped by Central Mall in search of some breakfast and saw this Ya Kun Kaya shop out front for the quintessential Kopitiam breakfast.  Although there were some other tourists like ourselves, we did see what looked like some locals also eating there, so that was a good sign.The typical Singaporean breakfast of kaya (sweet coconut and egg jam) and butter toast, local coffee, and half-boiled eggs was simple, yet delicious.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-31 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Got the Kaya Toast, iced coffee and kaya balls. The Kaya Toast is amazing - the thin bread with kaya jam and slab of butter = perfection. I wish I bought some kaya jam to bring back home. Their iced coffee is different than in the US - the ice coffee here is stronger, sweeter and not bitter at all. I LOVED it - please bring it to the US. Best breakfast I've had in Singapore. (I thought it was better than Toast Box)

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-31 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Great place similar to Fun Toast & Toast Box.Would definitely come back to SG often. Yummy Kaya Toast and the milk tea is great.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-31 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: The kaya toast here is very subpar.  The bread is thin, unevenly toasted, and butter just put in slabs and not spread evenly or melted.  On the other hand, their barley drink is good and has bits of tofu skin in it, which was a nice addition.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-31 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: LOVED the barley drink here, it has bits of beancurd. But the kaya toast, not so good. Crispy toast but very dry (taste like cardboard). There's a blob of butter in it smacked in the middle but not melted, yuck!

Molly Malone's is an Irish pub found in the corner of Circular Road. It has dark woody interiors which resemble those that you'll find in typical pubs in Ireland, so it is in that sense pretty "authentic".I started off with the cream of cauliflower soup served that day, which was thick and delicious. My favorite here is no doubt the fish and chips. Eaten piping hot from the fryer and doused with a generous layer of tartar or chili sauce, the crisp batter and flakes of fork tender fish tasted exceptional when downed with a gulp of ice cold beer.Finally, our dessert that day was a slice of tiramisu. This was quite good, and served as a great conclusion to our fantastic meal.All in all, this is definitely a good place to come for some good beer, good food and hopefully with good company.

Unfortunately the bar that I really wanted to check out (on a Yelp recommendation) was closed, so I decided to turn back and have a look at this traditional Irish Pub (not that I would know a traditional Irish Pub since I have never been to Ireland). Unfortunately there was nothing about this place that was all that spectacular, though they did have a nice outdoor area out the front, as well as an undercover smoking area (if that is your thing). What did catch my attention though was the fact that they had Australian sports telecast live, which was something that I simply did not expect since I have grown used to there being no access to Australian  sports overseas (though I didn't catch the game that I really wanted to have caught, not that I would have spent my time overseas watching football - I can do that at home). Still, this place wasn't all that bad, and the staff were friendly enough, but not really a place that I would recommend.

Nothing special here. Ridiculously overpriced pints. I didn't try the food. I went in on a Thursday night, the live musician had a hissy fit when he messed up his song and threw his guitar and walked away. Then he didn't return. Pretty lame.I wouldn't go again.

We were in Singapore for 5 days after a long cruise. We had been disappointed in the prices and portion sizes throughout our Singapore experience until we found Molly Malone's. Our waiter was a really nice person so both the quality and quantity of our food servicing exceeded our expectations.

Molly's is an Irish pub is on the corner of Circular Road, near the Central Business District of Singapore, and where a lot of office workers head to wrap up the day, or for an afternoon kicker. Nothing better than a pint of Guiness or Kilkenny's!  It's got a slightly older and more worn out feel as opposed to Penny Black's on the next road and the inside interior smells a little stale and smokey so I prefer sitting outdoors. It's popular for its fish & chips too, though I've only eaten here once and didn't find it to be remarkable. The fries were good, but the batter was very average, although better than some of the other fish & chips places in Singapore.

I used to adore this classic Irish pub.   This seemed like the only truly authentic place to quaff a pint of Guinness or observe St. Patrick's Day.  The food was decent for a pub and the multilevel setup seemed to be capable of accomodating large crowds.  And there was great music with a band fronted by a charismatic, extremely talented authentic Irishman.So I loved Molly's.  When the frontman broadcasted notice of the St. Patrick;s Day bash at Molly Malone's this year on Facebook, I enthusiastically organized an outing. Apparently a full-blown dysfunction seems to have engulfed every aspect of its operations. On its most important national holiday, this pub imploded.  Ordering a pint was like staggering through a dimly lit labrynthe populated by semi-coherent, disorganized, overworked staff.  Yes, you should expect slightly longer waiting times for drinks especially on weekends or special events like this.  After nearly an hour of being misdirected to three different locations and offered lame excuses like "We ran out of glasses" (at 6:45 pm!), it is hard to justify wasting the better part of an hour in this multi-storied madness.Molly Malone's has lost its Mojo.  The owner is an old Glencore oil trader.  Johnny H.  My Boy, you racked up a huge demurrage bill and you failed to delivery in the window.  And Gerry C., no more Facebook social media broadcasts ...  It may have a loyal following of dedicated fans who can tolerate abuse or have a magical connection for getting served in less than half an hour.  We moved on to Penny Black and had a cheaper pint from a more hospitable server at an outdoor cash bar in less than 30 seconds.  A few patrons who shared similar disappointments on Facebook where chastized by the frontman musician who blasted them for not being regulars and told them to take their business elsewhere in less than polite language.  If that is the case, he should not be soliciting patronage on Facebook.   I took my business elsewhere and will not be back... even if someone wants to host me.Kind of unbelievable that a pub confronted by a huge thirsty mass of customers cannot figure out how to efficiently and profitably satisfy this demand but instead ends up encouraging them to head next door for a more positive and memorable experience.

This is a great place! I had my first Kil-kenny here, it is made by Guinness. If you haven't had it you should try it. The fish and chips is amazing anfd the atmosphere would lead you to believe you are actually in Ireland and not on the other side of the world.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #02-17, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I really enjoyed this place. Lunch for 2 came to about 31SD (13SD lunch special plus gratuities) and it was so much fun! You choose two broths and they heat up your cooker with the two broths, in a big pot with two compartments, while you choose your vegetables and noodles. Then you cook it all up on your table with your choice of meat. Rice is free and for a small surcharge you can get soft drink with unlimited refills and frozen yogurt with a selection of toppings. We skipped the soft drink and yogurt as the food was very filling and we couldn't even finish it all! Would definately go back next time I'm in Singapore!

address: 3 River Valley Rd #01-16, , Block B Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: Just had our family meal there. Food is very good. Great staff with friendly and attentive service. We got to meet Sam, the head chef. When you enter the restaurant, take s look to the left. You can see their ducks getting aged. Order their Peking duck. It is really good. The wraps were steamed and brought to the table. Keep it closed until you are ready to eat or the chilled air will dry it out too fast. The stuffed eggplant was also good. Served with spinach and stuffed with minced pork and a sauce made with abalone. Delicious. Another unique dish is crispy chicken skin on a shrimp paste and lined at the bottom with sliced almond. Served with plum sauce on the side. Fish was steamed and topped with bacon. Looks good but I don't like fish with too many bones. Chives with lots of deep fried lard is very good, even for someone like me who doesn't like chives in general. Black vinegar pork trotters was nicely balanced . Can taste vinegar, sugar and ginger. Noddles was the last main dish. Too full to eat it. The dessert was delicious. Made with coconut cream, mango and agar afar. I can have another one of that. Definitely recommend east treasure. Great value too.

A most pleasant surprise to find delicious soba while browsing around Raffles Place. IKI is probably one of the very few soba places in Singapore that uses 100% buckwheat (imported from Akita prefecture in Japan), which means the noodles are very al dente & also gluten-free!Noguchi-san came from Japan 2 years ago to start this soba shop and has a vision for introducing the healthy benefits of soba to Singapore, especially for office workers. Even though Noguchi-san was busy, he took the time to come talk to us and bring us soba water (to mix with the dipping sauce and enjoy as a broth after the meal). He said that he prefers to run a casual dining environment because he wants to focus on providing high-quality, nutritious food at affordable prices. Talking with him you can really tell he cares about the food he is serving and the people he is serving it to. As for the food, I had cold dipping soba with a tuna/salmon rice bowl for around $15. Noguchi-san allowed my mother to customize her set with a cold eggplant/daikon/sesame seed soba and a teriyaki salmon rice bowl ($18). Each set comes with soba tea as well as a soba yogurt pudding/dessert. Everything tasted fresh and flavorful. Really hoping more people come and visit this hidden gem!

The place was one of those which still opened for dinner at night. The place was not crowded. Placed order at the counter and food would be served to you at your table. Kake Soba & Tuna-Salmon Bowl Set Menu ($15)Mini rice bowl + Hot/ Cold Soba + Tea + Acai DessertSelected hot soba which was served in soup topped with wakame, chopped leek, and fish cake. The soup was light and tasty but the soba was bit too doughy in taste.The rice bowl was savoury with fresh chunky seafood. The greyish pudding was surprisingly yummy without too sweet.

=== This is perfection ===I overheard (eavesdropped on) a colleague mentioning where they had lunch today, to another worker in the office."I had soba" they remarked, matter of factly."just soba?" was the response."I had the IKI Healthy Soba, y'know on Level 4?""Oh yeah, IKI soba! Nice! Love that!""Yeah! That one!"With that short conversation all work was put on hold and I launched myself like a shot out of a cannon towards the elevator doors.Upon walking into IKI, I thought...hmmm this place seems fast food-ish, but boy was I about to be proven wrong.There was a small queue and a lot of diners at tables... I spied the duck soba for $11 on the menu, and decided that was going to be my lunch.When it arrived at the table (with a smile and quite soon after ordering), it looked as you see in the picture - large portions of pink, tender duck breast floating on an island of soba noodles surrounded by a steamed spicy broth and topped with finely chopped spring onion and a sprinkling of sesame seeds.Except the photo doesn't capture the steam of freshness curling above the rim of the bowl, bringing wafts of heady flavour to the senses.Hot, fresh and delicate this was truly a great, and seemingly health, lunch.The duck was gorgeously cooked. Perfectly pink and tender, with a smoky flavour it was melt in the mouth and delightful to the tastebuds. The soba were also tasty and cooked through (just past al dente, but not mushy) which is right in the sweetspot they were suckingly good and the spring onion added a zingy contrast, whilst the sesame seeds provided crunch.And then the broth... brimming with flavours and spice this was just divine. Every heavenly slurp was savoured and when I hit the bottom I could not believe it was over...And yet, as I sat back, I realised I was satiated. This was the perfect meal.I am still happy :)At $11, for stunningly cooked duck, in a well-seasoned broth bursting with flavour, and enhanced by soba noodles - this truly is perfection. I wouldn't change a thing.

I do appreciate how the soba is homemade from 100% buckwheat flour. But the taste is nothing special and the food is overpriced in my opinion. But if you have been a fan of soba noodles, give it a try. FYI, I ordered a soba hot noodles bowl and a salmon salad set for $15

I was at Raffles Place in the evening and I was looking for a place to have dinner. Normally, I would just find a cafe and have a sandwich and soup. I came across Healthy Soba Iki and was at first hesitant to go in. I searched for reviews and saw that fellow Yelpers had positive comments. So I decided to try their Salmon Teriyaki and hot soba set. The set meal comes with a cup of hot tea and an organic acai dessert. The soba in dashi soup with a generous sprinkling of watercress and leek had a clear taste - simply delicious. The salmon teriyaki was also done just right. The Japanese owner, Noguchi-san came by to ask if the food was ok. He went on to elaborate that he imports the buckwheat from Japan and makes the gluten-free soba fresh every morning. He uses 100% buckwheat for his soba. No wonder the soba tasted home-cooked! I can tell he is passionate about his soba and happy with serving his customers good and healthy Japanese food. I'm definitely coming back for more - next time I will try the cold soba!

Even in Singapore the Japanese exude their customer service ethic.Steamed towels greet you upon entry as a welcome refreshing touch; closely followed by your food which is delivered in a neatly packaged ornate box, and matching tumbler for your miso.Food here was on point. My buddy had the calorific Katsu don and I was secretly jealous but openly healthier minded by going for the Yakiniku don.The atmosphere is very light and casual, japanese game shows carry on aimlessly in the background as the servers go about their business.Next time I'd opt for the sake set, it looked seriously appealing.

address: 50 Raffles Place #45-01, Singapore Land Tower Singapore 048623 Singapore
comment: Service is quite slow for dinner. We didn't have reservations and the place was empty. It's cool they have the trio thing but given the recommendation we went straight for the rib eye. Bread was not fresh, they just toasted it right before serving us, not like Spago. It was onion bread with butter and black salt.We ordered crab cake and charred octopus salad also. Octopus was chewy but the char grilled was not as char grilled as I would like them to be. Taste was good though. And crab cakes were okay, it was too breaded for me, but I guess Singaporeans like it. The steak made up for it though.

address: 50 Raffles Place #45-01, Singapore Land Tower Singapore 048623 Singapore
comment: Always on the look out for a great steak place, we tried this on a week night. Unfortunately it wasn't a great experience. Here's a summary of + & -- Service was poor. Multiple waiters serving us on a very quiet night. They didn't seem to be talking to each other, asking for orders that had already been taken- Waiter dumped lemons in my sparkling water without asking if I wanted them, he then proceeded to take my wine glass away without letting me finish my wine.- Worst part, the steaks were way over cooked. One supposed to be medium rare, one medium. Both very well done, totally overcooked destroying a $120 wagyu rib eye. - Side dishes and sauces were average. Brussel sprouts were drowning in oil, creamed spinach was bland / cheesy with very little resemblance to proper steak house creamed spinach. Chimichurri was some blended fluro green disaster. + Meat had good flavour and showed potential, if only they cooked it right. + Peppercorn sauce was great, really rich+ House wines were good quality, enjoyable+ Staff are very friendly, view is pretty good (not from inside though)+ The set meals looked well priced for 3 courses (~$50)Maybe this is a better lunch place for the city crew. We wouldn't go back unfortunately, there's just too many great places in Singapore to spend $350 on somewhere like this.

address: 50 Raffles Place #45-01, Singapore Land Tower Singapore 048623 Singapore
comment: Sear is the probably the go to Steak House in the Raffles Place. Located on the 42nd Floor of the Singapore Floor, it has sweeping views of the Singapore's CBD. I didn't come here for the views, but rather bring my wife to a nice to Steak Dinner on a Friday night.  Surprisingly, the restaurant was rather quiet on a Friday night with only three other patrons. I didn't complain too much as it made for a quiet and intimate dinner.  Our order was as follows:Appetizer: Split Bone Marrow - Scrape off the marrow from the bone and spread it across the three thin wafers. Just lovely... wish there was more... :)Main Course: - Tasting of Trio, which includes a cut of Tenderloin, Sirloin, and Wagyu Ribeye - The star of the show was clearly the Wagyu Ribye. Perfect amount of marble with a good mix of salt and pepper to accentuate the flavors. The Sirloin was ehh (likely because the Rib Eye was so good). The Tenderloin was solid, but like most Tenderloin dishes needs a great sauce to make it work. - Sear Tasting of Ribeye, which includes a cut of Kobe Beef, NZ Hereford, and Wagyu Ribeye - The star of this order was the Kobe Beef (probably the most expensive of the lot) and of course the Wagyu Ribeeye, which is the same as the previous order. Overall a solid steak restaurant. Prices I thought were just right relative to the quality of the cuts of meat given. My recommendation would be start off with the Split Bone Marrow and go for a full order of the Australian Jacobs Creek Wagyu Ribeye steak - 250 grams. You can't go wrong.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-47 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: The tteokpokki seemed harmless so we got the spiciest level and uhhh it was one of the hottest dishes I've EVER eaten. Like my god my head was vibrating and I couldn't think. Love itThe corn dogs are as good as they look and I can eat multiple in one sitting. The auntie working here is the sweetest lady and always has a big warm smile on.

address: 65 Chulia St #33-01, OCBC Centre Singapore 049513 Singapore
comment: Peach Garden is still good after all these years and the quality Downy suffer even during festive periods.Had CNY dinner here.Love the traditional selection of sweets.Yu sheng - goodChicken - nice and tender, even the breast meat was tender.Xiao pai cai - so so.Seabass - goodNoodles with vegetables - nice.Dessert - jelly in coconut - love this.Nian gao - not bad.

address: 65 Chulia St #33-01, OCBC Centre Singapore 049513 Singapore
comment: Peach Garden was one of our family go to for dinners back when they were at Novena. As the restaurant expanded to other locations, the standards vary depending on the outlet. This branch is near my office and I came for dimsum with my colleague. Menu is different from the usual Peach Garden dimsum like the Thomson branch. Perhaps they are trying to be more upscale but I'd have preferred the traditional dimsum. Nothing beats the traditional har kow, siew mai or char siew bao.

address: 65 Chulia St #33-01, OCBC Centre Singapore 049513 Singapore
comment: Staff are efficient and service is fast. The dim sum is average. The restrooms are old and very dirty. The female restrooms walls are moldy and the grout is filled with dirt. If I was eating in a hawker center, I will have no complains but given that I am paying 18 per person for noodles, I have higher expectations.If they don't bother to keep the public areas clean, I dread to think of the state of the kitchen.

address: 65 Chulia St #33-01, OCBC Centre Singapore 049513 Singapore
comment: A bunch of us were visiting from Hong Kong, normally we wouldn't have Chinese food because of the more attractive local singaporean options but this place was pretty good. The food was hot when served, the salted egg yolk prawn was delightful. For dessert, presentation of the jelly was a bit strange. If you want chinese food in singapore, this is a place I would recommend!

address: 65 Chulia St #33-01, OCBC Centre Singapore 049513 Singapore
comment: My best friend and her husband took us here for a memorable dinner one night during our Christmas holidays in Singapore.This is a first class Cantonese gourmet restaurant, and I'm glad we came with people who knew exactly what to order. To begin with, there's a lovely view of the city, and the service was flawless. We had several courses, beginning with succulent London roast duck. The crispy skin and tasty moist meat had a thin layer of delicious fat cushioned in between. Then we had Sharks Fin Soup (there are several types to choose from), Fish, Tofu with Spinach, Noodles with Scallops, ending with an exquisite Almond pudding for dessert. The entire dinner was an experience in the best of fine Cantonese cuisine. It was obvious looking around that the restaurant catered to the local gourmet clientele, but I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone who would like to experience truly fine Cantonese food. The staff is first class, and they could help make recommendations.

address: 65 Chulia St #33-01, OCBC Centre Singapore 049513 Singapore
comment: Nice view, clean table, helpful waitress. taste is ok, dim sim preferable, not too much suggestions for you

address: 65 Chulia St #33-01, OCBC Centre Singapore 049513 Singapore
comment: Finally a dim sum place to take the in-laws.What do I look for in dim sum? It's mostly a social occasion. Family gets together and chats and eats as the punnets come to the table. Slow sips of jasmine tea. So the setting is important. It has to be quiet and relaxing enough to chat, comfortable and spacious and lit enough to be there for a while without feeling cramped or tiring your eyes.And of course the food has to be edible, but in a departure from my usual style I'd say it's almost less important. Tim Ho Wan has good food, but it's not a very nice experience. Crystal Jade at Plaza Singapura has good-ish atmosphere but the food is not good enough for the money (the Bugis MRT one was much better, especially the xiao long bao, before it closed - but its atmosphere sucked). Between the two, I'd pick atmosphere any time. Luckily, this dilemma is solved by Peach Garden, which presents good food in a great and appropriate setting, with polite and efficient service and, naturally, plenty of families enjoying dim sum. The main dining hall does not need description, but I'm including a photo of the view anyway. The private rooms definitely have the better side, but you could argue the Chinatown side is more "interesting", has more stuff going on. Either way, the room is spacious, the tables nicely far apart (so you're only dining with YOUR family) and the ceiling high enough that you do not feel crushed. The food was good. The sauce accompanying the rice rolls tasted more complex and balanced than the usual sweet soy mix. The pomelo sago mango soup was not quite to the level of Tim Ho Wan's, but good enough that I wouldn't bother heading to the latter to get my fix. The scallop-chestnut-spinach-caviar thing was really great, I just had to order another one. How great? Well, Luca Turin describes a certain type of perfume masterpiece as what happens when you blend two ingredients at such a ratio that they become, together a different scent and you cannot separate them anymore. Similarly, the Berlin Philharmonic used to be known for playing so thoroughly together that you couldn't make out the individual violins in the violin section, or, if a cello and a horn were to play the same melody, either of the instruments individually. This is what happens with this dumpling. I can't tell what goes in it, because it blends together really well and becomes something more than the sum of its parts. Service was really good. My tea cup was always refilled, but I never spotted them doing it. In fact, I thought the waiters disappeared into the background, but somehow, whenever we needed something, they magically appeared and sorted out our problem immediately. Experience, I guess. This place seems popular and has been around for a while. I'm happy because I've finally found a place to take the in-laws for dim sum.

address: 65 Chulia St #33-01, OCBC Centre Singapore 049513 Singapore
comment: Peach Garden Chinese Restaurant is a well known brand for exquisite Cantonese cuisine. Since the opening of the first Peach Garden outlet at Novena Gardens in 2002, they have received numerous accolades and awards from renowned publications such as Singapore Tatler's Best Restaurants Guide and Singapore Top Restaurants Award from Wine & Dine.We were bringing a friend around town and decided to have dim sum at the Peach Garden OCBC Centre restaurant as it is known to have a great view of the city.Only a small selection of dim sum items are available, i noted only 18 items. Century Egg Porridge is a must order for me when eating dim sum. Good gluey consistency of the congee and there was plenty of shredded pork. Love the crispy crackers on top too. Peach Garden supposedly has one of the better Steamed Creamy Custard Buns ($5.20) around. The buns were fluffy and light but i found the texture a little too gelatinous and it lacked that 'liu sha' (flowing lava) feel. Taste wise, it was satisfactory but i thought it could do with a richer salted egg yolk taste.Baked Mini Egg Tarts ($4.80) were delightful but yea on the pricey side because they're so mini. But yea love the wobbly egg custard on top of the lovely puff pastry.Deep fried Prawn and Fresh Avocado Roll ($6) had an identity crisis and the Deep fried Savoury Yam Pudding with Minced Meat and Portugal Sauce ($5.20) was soaked in oil. Service was BLEARGH. Well it started with the staff being rather pushy when i was ordering our first round of dim sum. Firstly, we were waiting for S who was parking so i didn't want to order everything at one go. Secondly, i have a tendency to over order (especially for dim sum) so i was making a conscious effort not to go crazy. However, that was met with some outwardly disdain by the staff (due to my small order) which i absolutely do not appreciate. Do i look like i can't afford dimsum? So i reigned in my unhappiness because i was hosting a friend.The screw up was when they absolutely messed up our second order which took forever to come. 15 minutes into waiting, our plates were cleared after they asked if we were waiting for more food, which was strange. Well we thought our food was going to arrive soon after but nope, that didn't happen. Another 10 mins later when we checked with them again, we found out that they forgot our order (which they didn't tell us directly but we saw and overheard the commotion). Another 10mins passed before our order finally came and it was the wrong order. We had to make do with the messed up order because obviously we weren't going to wait for another 30 mins. The Steamed BBQ Pork Bun ($4.80) attempted to calm me down a little. Juicy well marinated strips of char siew enveloped by the softest pillow bun.What happened after the meal was an instagram post on the meal and me complaining about how terrible the service was. I have to applaud the Peach Garden Marketing/PR team for resolving the issue immediately. Good service recovery i must say. I've been informed that the staff involved have been counselled. I don't know if it's special treatment because i'm a food blogger but i would like to give them the benefit of doubt.So yea, hits and misses at the Peach Garden OCBC Centre. If you're looking for decent dimsum with a view, it's ok. Well on the service end, it really depends, no matter where you go.

address: 65 Chulia St #33-01, OCBC Centre Singapore 049513 Singapore
comment: Very good business lunches for very reasonable price. Located on the 33rd floor of the OCBC building it has great views and average service, you can book an area in advance for private events.They serve excellent peking duck. They also have really good dessert called "ai yu bing" that you need order in advance - it's NOT in the menu! Ai yu bing is a soft jelly with chrysanthemum flower flavour.  Another thing to get here are their moon cakes which seem to taste better every year. They have different types of moon cakes -  the best moon cake is the one with macadamia. The moon cakes are smooth and perfect in texture and not overly sweet. They are always introducing new flavours, with one of the latest being black sesame .

address: 65 Chulia St #33-01, OCBC Centre Singapore 049513 Singapore
comment: Peach Garden is the default business lunch venue if one can't be bothered to think of where to go. Afterall, it's got a good ambience, good food, good service and generally offers a failproof underlying formula for an enjoyable meal.Food: Mixed dim sum platter offers a trio of dim sum items, which I believe vary day to day. Generally not spectacular but decent. The sharks cartilage soup is delicious! The honey baked sea perch is nicely done, as are the wasabi prawns and roast duck. The stir fried pork collar is excellent. The desserts totally kick ass too, heh. ALL OF THEM.Service: Generally polite and good.Ambience: Much prefer this to the noisy cramped family friendly joint at Thomson.

address: #01-01 Golden Castle Building 80 South Bridge Road Singapore 058710 Singapore
comment: Walked in on a Friday night without a reservation and they only had seats for us at the bar upstairs. Fair enough... though we wish they'd warned us that upstairs meant a noisier, clubbier vibe versus the more 'restaurant-y' feel of downstairs. Food menu's limited to four "mains" and a good spread of bar snack/tapas type items. The cheese toast was... underwhelming. I'm not sure why anyone would order it. It was so pedestrian that I can't even describe it convincingly beyond "it was mediocre and underwhelming". And forgettable. The grilled avocado was actually a salad (description didn't make that clear), the dressing was nice, a sharp Japanese dressing that went well with the greens and tomatoes, though it felt overpriced when the only thing that differentiated it from a MOS Burger salad was the presence of avocado. The fried salmon skin was... well seasoned though not perfectly fried, the skin was a bit hard to bite through and not completely airily crisp. (I suspect the oil hadn't been hot enough.)The duck somen was tasty, though the portion was tiny.Drinks though boded well, the homemade plum wine is to die for, a good balance of sweet and tart, it's probably a better appetiser than any food item on the menu. The cocktails sounded interested and the date's Boruto 80 or something like that was a pleasant blend of cucumber, mint, and grape. I felt it needed a bit of sharpness (like green apple), but it wasn't bad by any means.Overall I'd come back for that homemade plum wine. And while I'm there I might order more food. I'll have low expectations, but hey, the food was edible at least. There're bars with worse.

Decent cafe to go while you wait for your friends to arrive.  My recent visit to Courtyard Cafe & Lounge was on Sunday July 31st 2022.  The event scheduled to begin was about 13:00hrs Singapore time.  Since I have some time to linger, to Courtyard Cafe & Lounge I went.Decent menu.  Nothing mind blowing as yet so I decide for a Main dish since that Main dish comes along with a beverage.  Made the payment at the counter and the Staff gave me the TOKEN Buzzer while waiting.It was a "DRY Horfun"... but when I received it, it was "loaded" with some black light sauce of some kind.  Oh well...  *insert puzzled sad face indeed*Had the Lunch and the beverages...Frankly the "DRY Horfun" is nothing to boot about.  Maybe I ordered the wrong item in their Menu.  For the Decor of this establishment in a "GRAND" Museum, it was okay.  At least there are places to chill while you wait for your friends either to go to the Museum or nearby places at the PADANG.What stood out even though this is a SELF Service establishment is the Staffs that went their extra mile to give a hand for those patrons who are less accessible to carry their food from the Main Counter to where you are seated.  I should have asked his name that day.  That Staff alone deserved 4 STARS in my books.However all in all personally with the MENU and the FOOD, this is INDEED a 3 stars GENEROUS Review.  May return when needed BUT NOT in a hurry.

The cafe used to be a pop up, and recently it took over the courtyard cafe space, which was located in the far end of the museum. It offered local dishes and snacks. One of the cheaper choices for dining in the museum. It was self service system here - order and wait for buzzer to light up before collecting at the counter.Mix and Match Kuehs Set Meal ($5)2 choices of kueh from the display shelves and a choice of coffee or tea.Selected Ondeh Ondeh Gula Melaka ($2.70/ 3pcs) which were soft although preferred the skin to be thinner, and Kueh DaDar ($1.80) which was packed with juicy coconut filling. Kid's Set Meal ($4.80)Egg & Cheese Sandwich + OWL Bubble Orange SodaThe sandwich was served on a wooden board. Cheesy and packed with thick slices of tomato.

This place is a takeaway counter only. But it makes for a healthy lunch. $8.50 for 2 tacos. $11.50 for 3. Add 50 cents per taco for some premium meats. Guacamole and cheese is extra money. I usually get the fish and I also tried the veg with guacamole. Here's the tip. If you order the veg for only one of your tacos it includes a generous portion of guacamole. It's nice you get to mix and match. Help yourself to various hot sauces and raw onions. It's pretty comforting food but you eat with all the noise and crowd at the communal space benches. They could have included a small serving of salsa per order I thought.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-84, Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: It still amazes me how expensive champong and jajamyung costs in Singapore because it's so cheap in LA and esp in Korea.  Finding a good champong place is arduous in Singapore bc the Korean population is small and you have to cater to Singaporeans to stay in business.  If this restaurant was in LA, it would go out of business because the champong is not flavorful and spicy.  But if I were to compare to another place I had it in Singapore, I would say it's decent.  So that is the only reason why I'm giving it a four star rating bc I needed my champong fix and this was my only choice.Also, this place is in the corner and is kind of hard to find on the 3rd floor.  And the portions are smaller compared to anywhere else in the world besides SG, haha.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-84, Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Very empty at lunch. And the other two tables are Koreans. One bad sign, one good sign.Ordered the noodles and a side of dumplings. I must say the boiled dumplings were awesome. Thin skin, flavorful fillings, served with a slight broth.The jajungmyun were good, but can get too much if you are eating it alone. The bowl is generous, noodles springy, and you have to like caramelised onions as the entire bowl is topped with it. The black bean sauce is not as salty as the Chinese style ones, more sweet.Price point is a little high for lunch, which probably explains why there is hardly anyone at that hour.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-84, Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This weekend, I had a chance to visit two Korean restaurants in Singapore. The latter being Taewoo at the Central, Clarke Quay. This is by far the best Korean-Chinese restaurant here and the service, quality, and the atmosphere were all superb!  I thought it was odd that any Korean would dare open a Korean-style Chinese cuisine in a country mostly of Chinese descent. Non-Koreans are probably unfamiliar with this cuisine so how would they know to spot a good Korean-Chinese food nor recognize when they see one? To clarify, the food served here is not Korean. Nor is it Chinese. It's food that Chinese people created many years ago to cater to Korean's taste buds when they immigrated to Korea. Few popular dishes you MUST try are: noodle dishes: Jjajangmyun, jjamppong; fried shrimp with sweet and sour sauce: kkanpoong saewoo; fried meat with sweet sauce: tang soo yukWe craved jjajangmyun for quite some time now and had no idea where to look in Singapore, until we found this gem. They have a great set menu going for $25/person with sample food listed above so it's def worth a visit. Can't wait till we return! The service was great, which really made my day.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-84, Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Ok, new eatery alert. We literally stumbled across Tae Woo today, and would have completely missed it had Watami not turned us away. In a bid for ginseng chicken soup, we decided to give TW a shot. At 9ish, the restaurant only had two other tables. Decor is a combination of industrial hanging lightbulbs and country farm, with pots and pans and other homely decor artfully placed around. Even the serviettes were stacked in a pretty arc. Plus points for effort! A quick glance at the menu disappointed us, but no matter. Decided to ask the Korean lady if there was any similar option off menu, but her English was quite poor and we deduced that there probably wasn't. There was jajangmyeon though, which I happily ordered, together with a side of boiled dumplings. The jajangmyeon arrived with a pair of scissors, and the same lady demonstrated that we should only cut once, because "long, nice". Ok, got it! And wow, the wheat noodles were chewy and the black bean sauce heady and piquant. The sauce was chockfull of onions, with their sweetness sweated out, infusing the sauce with an interesting flavor. The boiled dumplings came sitting in a layer of water. Upon the first bite, the skin was thin and plain, but the filling was generous and well seasoned. We were a little shocked, to be honest, that the food was actually good. Confident of the restaurant's standard, we flipped through the menu and placed an additional order of japchae, another one of my favorites. Told the waitress to lay off the rice, and she nodded. In broken English, she then tried to indicate that the japchae noodles were firmer, unlike the jajangmyeon. She didn't quite know how to say soft, though, and we made the hand sign for squishy with a questioning glance, to which she nodded vigorously. That was.. quite funny. The japchae came with rice though, and a side of egg drop soup. She apologized for the oversight but we thanked her anyway. And the noodles.. were even better than the jajangmyeon's! Springy and sweetened with the addition of many vegetables, it was quickly inhaled and poor jajangmyeon was left to languish. The three dishes set us back by $50, which is a pretty reasonable amount for two mains and a side. Plus, we were full to bursting and waddled off very happily. Yelpers, you heard it here first. Better visit TW before it's no longer a secret and standards start dropping.

Seafood Olio Olio is spicy. I like the spaghetti, the prawns tastes precooked, and the scallop is so chewy. The scallop gets in between the teeth.I always like the ice blended drinks here. Chocolate Wealth is my favorite. Ambiance is quiet enough for conversations.

address: 30 Raffles Pl #01-42 Chevron House Singapore 048622 Singapore
comment: Not a bad place for lunch.  The concept is like a lunch box where by you select a main, a side, some toppings and a dressing (see pic).  The food is quite fresh and seemed to be a healthier option.  I chose a lunch box with roast beef, rocket salad, some mushrooms and carrots, and with a orange & tarragon dressing.  The combo was delicious and quick.  As I had a later lunch after 1pm, they were already out of a few choices such as the daily main special as well as mixed greens, though.  But overall, a nice choice if you need something quick and fresh.

Located at China Square Central, Aglio Olio is a quaint restaurant that serves delectable Italian food with a local twist.  The "local twist" stems from the restaurant's unique feature allowing you to choose the level of spiciness for your pastas.Ambience and ServiceThe restaurant exudes a rustic charm with its pastel-coloured furnishings and ornamental lamps, complete with impressionistic paintings on the walls.Service is good and consistent. Aglio Olio staffs are always extremely courteous, and we've never had any problems getting their attention to take our orders or refill our drinks.MenuAglio Olio serves a variety of salads, pastas, pizzas, lasagnas, and sides. The pastas come in interesting variations (eg Terikyai Base Pasta, Black Pepper Base Pasta).The prices are super affordable: none of the pastas cost over $15, and you can get a half-pint Hoegaarden for just $4.90!Four Level of Spiciness for PastasYou get to choose your pasta's level of spiciness. There are four levels: mild, normal, spicy, and extra spicy. This is where the "local twist" comes in: pastas mixed with chili padis! For Aglio Olio, all gloves are off when it comes to serving spicy pasta. I tried this zenith level of spiciness once and I can testify that it's one of the hottest foods I've ever tasted.Aglio Olio Pastawe savour these spicy pastas that are sprinkled with bright little red pieces of chili padis. Shiok la! There is a variety for you to choose from: Original Olio, Seafood Olio, Fish Olio, Pepperoni Olio, and many others. The aglio olio tastes decent but not particularly fantastic, but it is precisely this unassuming nature that endears us to this pasta! We simply adore the honest-to-goodness taste of the aglio olios!Pizzas and Cream Base / Black Pepper Base PastasEven though the aglio olio pastas are our favourites, we enjoy their pizzas and cream base /black pepper base pastas as well. We haven't had a chance to try the other pasta variations (eg Squid Ink, Vongole) because we tend to stick to the same food for a long time once we develop an affinity for it.PromotionsAglio Olio has great daily promotions! There is also a special Dinner Set for two persons which consists of one Pasta + one Pasta or Pizza + one Basket of Chicken Wings + Garlic Bread + two Soup of the day + two Lemonade, at the low price $33.90!Conclusion: Charming Ambience, Wonderful Service, Endearing Aglio Olio Pastas, Super Affordable Price Suffice to say, we love eating at Aglio Olio at China Square Central. The charming ambience, wonderful service, and endearing aglio olio pastas make this the perfect place for a quiet weekend getaway. The price is extremely affordable too. Check out full reviews and photos at eatandtravelwithus.com/2…

address: 30 Raffles Pl Basement 1, Chevron House Singapore 039803 Singapore
comment: My first few impressions at Omnivore had me wanting to hand out an almighty 5-stars, however, having adopted it into a routine now I think the highest I can go is a sexy 4-stars.Initially... It was the little things Omnivore does that elevated it above its main competitor the Daily Cut for me.The more interesting variety with edamame, chickpeas and smoked duck making an appearance, were more appealing than the DC standard fare.Omnivore being smaller, also meant that it was less busy and has the ability to turn around the meals much quicker as a result.It's ever so slightly cheaper despite retaining the huge portion sizes DC commands.There is also a better selection of sauces and they provide these to you at payment, which I think is a far better system than the self-serving pump style offered elsewhere.Having experienced Omnivore many times now I've seen some of the drawbacks. It can get incredibly busy, and downstairs in Chevron House can get hot. When it's busy the well-oiled machine doesn't run so smoothly.Also they can run out of ingredients, and whilst this in itself isn't a huge problem, their failure to communicate this until AFTER you've paid means that you end up desperately scrambling for an alternative to complete your order, as you don't want to be the one holding everyone else up.Omnivore is still a great choice for lunch for me, and I visit regularly, however there are some chinks in that seemingly impervious armour.

address: 30 Raffles Pl Basement 1, Chevron House Singapore 039803 Singapore
comment: I head to the raffles outlet everyday and decided to check out the sail outlet today as there were some differences.I am a fitness instructor and one of the kind who is very particular about eating clean, and so I chose omnivore over a lot of places around even if I had to walk a distance over.First I asked, what cut do you guys use for the 'torched steak', as I thought they used a different one from the raffles outlet, which is sirloin.None of the girls there knew, and nobody could give me an answer and said 'we don't know, boss order, I just serve'. Until they decided to ask the chef which was just right behind prepping my steak order.Next I saw was while waiting for my steak to be done, all the girls were sitting down, some chatting at the cashier counter and some standing, using their phones, leaving some food uncovered and I witnessed a mosquito feeding on one of the chicken thighs.Seriously do these people even care about food cleanliness at all? There is no email that I could write to the boss so let's hope someone from the company sees this and decided to rectify it. Thirdly, no nets/card payment, cash only for both outlets. Tons of inconvenience if you had a distance to walk to the ATM machine.

address: 30 Raffles Pl Basement 1, Chevron House Singapore 039803 Singapore
comment: Some time ago I wrote a pretty long review of Daily Cut. It was more a review of the operations, business model and niche that Daily Cut addressed, than the food itself, because I found it incredible that no one had tackled this niche earlier. Well ok it's not that incredible given the high cost of running a takeaway shop that depends almost solely on lunchtime turnover. In my review, I mentioned that competitors like Smor and the Korean shop should wise up to this easy profit opportunity, and true enough the former started offering easy to order muscle meals. I also mentioned that DC should improve it's assembly line efficiency because the queues were ridiculous. Well, I ended up taking a break from DC for awhile because of the lines and a couple of months back, heard from a friend that a DC clone had opened at Chevron House...so off I went to check out Omnivore.Omnivore pretty much what I like about DC with the kinks mostly ironed out. The line moves fast (possibly because Omnivore is still less known than DC), the assembly line is more organized (one person takes your order and money upfront, yells at the protein guy to cook your protein if its a steak, passes it to the legumes and veg lady, who passes it to the protein cutter who passes it to the packaging/sauce lady), food portions are HUGE (WOOOHOOOO!) and the prices are slightly cheaper. I like that Omnivore improved on the taste and tenderness of some items that are similar to DC, specifically the chicken breast and thigh, and their beef and salmon steaks are worth the +$. There are interesting sides like aloe vera as well, and the sauces are simple but tasty. Props to Omnivore for cashing in on the affordable paleo niche and improving the playing field! If I'm not wrong, the owner also runs the Old Tea Hut, which I think is another brilliant idea and I wish I thought of that hahaha.

address: 30 Raffles Pl Basement 1, Chevron House Singapore 039803 Singapore
comment: About $12 for a container half-filled with plain pasta. The parmesan cheese is powdered from a can and the smoked duck was obviously frozen then reheated onsite. How this place stays afloat is beyond me especially with Daily Cut just steps away (and even DC has gone downhill over the years). Clearly the owner is more concerned about margin than quality. I can only imagine that clustering with Moss burger and Guzman y Gomez make this place stand out as a healthy choice.

address: #B1-02C, One Raffles Place 1 Raffles Place Singapore 048616 Singapore
comment: Upper Crust is a great sandwich joint for the Raffles Place crowds. Most people order to takeaway, leaving ample seats for those who have the luxury of time to sit and enjoy their sandwich. Particularly good sandwiches are the roast beef and chicken schnitzel sandwiches. You can also custom make your sandwich by adding ingredients. There is a wide range of fresh vegetables and dressings and cheese, much like how it's done in USA, Europe or Australia. Pair your sandwich with a bottled juice and it is both a healthy and nourishing meal.Of particular mention are the organic breads for your sandwiches, baked by Upper Crust's bakery, you can choose between sour dough, whole wheat and more.

address: #B1-02C, One Raffles Place 1 Raffles Place Singapore 048616 Singapore
comment: This place is kinda like an up version of Subway, where one line is formed in front of the counter where you choose your bread, then type of meat / filling to go with your sandwich, salad toppings, and dressing. The fillings here are so much fresher and tastier though - even the cheese tastes fresher and less 'plastic'. Another reason why its one of my favourite joints to eat at around the CBD area - I've never had to wait or hover around for a table - it seems that this place attracts a greater take-away crowd, so there's always plenty of room for you to sit down for lunch there. My top recommendation for the filling would be the roasted veggies - mushrooms, capsicum, eggplant and zucchini, I think that the way they've roasted the veggies here are incomparable to any other sandwich place in Raffles Place. I think alot of people who aren't vegetarian would automatically skip past the all veg option - but unless you're a veggie hater, honestly this sandwich will change your mind, I love it!Portions are very generous - larger than the 6 inch at subway, so it makes a decent lunch.

address: #B1-02C, One Raffles Place 1 Raffles Place Singapore 048616 Singapore
comment: This is a pretty good sandwich place in the CBD. Their breads are very good here and its a nice place to go for lunch, as opposed to say Subway or a hawker stall. I like how they have many options for spreads and dressings here. Instead of the boring mayo or mustard, they have hummus and sun dried tomato spread. They also have lots of options for fresh veggies to put ontop of your sandwich. They have a few desserts which I think they could improve on though. The ambience is nice and its a great place to chill during your lunch break.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-72, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Rendezvous SingaporeNostalgicHaven't had this in a long time.Not as good as before but still okay.I like the chicken curry best. The sauce is still good.Cucumber salad is also good.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-72, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: It was cold by Singapore standards (Under 30? No lah...) and the only prescription was authentic Nasi Padang. Let's be honest, this meal is never pretty, and Rendezvous was no different. After selecting your dishes from the chef's counter, you head over to a dated cafeteria style seating area overlooking Clarke Quay. When your dishes come out, bright yellows, deep browns and milky reds sit - barely identifiable chicken, fish and veggies bobbing and gasping for their last breath - before you smoother your rice with them, but day-um it's good. The sambal brinjal, korma chicken and chicken rendang were my personal favourites, and there was something that involved potatoes that I still dream of. So delicious. Overall, I felt the veggie dishes had more complex, rich flavours than the meat dishes, so in the future I'd probably just opt for a full on veggie smorgasbord. But it seems no matter what you choose, your eyes will always be bigger than your stomach, so prepare to come here and eat. (And to spend some cash to do so!)

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-72, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Everything is very lemak (rich and creamy!)The food is not too spicy, so it is enjoyable for the whole family.Tried the beef rendang, chicken rendang, potato, plus a veggie. Prefer the chicken to the beef. The rice is also very fragrant. Not sure if it is coconut rice or not.Nice old school ambience that overlooks the Singapore river at Clarke Quay.Price point is a little high though.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-72, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I love this place. Ok so the food is a little pricey but totally worth it seriously!The decor is pretty old school with chairs and tables that kinda remind you of the nicer restaurants in the old days. Very retro but everything looks sparkling clean. If you manage to get a window seat, you'll get an awesome view of Boat Quay and the Singapore River. This just means that you can take your time to enjoy the view and savour the food, which I highly recommend you do because its just absolutely delicious.So you pick out the individual dishes you want from the menu. Le bf and I had two curries, sambal eggs, some veggies and a few other dishes. They'll give you white rice of course to eat with your food. So totally worth the money spent. In fact, I'm already getting hungry just typing this out. I haven't tried all their dishes on the menu but this place is already at the top of my places to revisit list. Unfortunately I ate too much to leave any room for dessert but I heard their chendol and other local desserts are pretty awesome too. If you don't mind the price and really want some good nasi padang, check this place out at least once. You won't regret it.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-72, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This place is very nostalgic for me as I used to have eat here regularly in the 90s with my family. I must have stopped coming here for about 10 years, but the taste of the green/yellow curry has never left my memory!Located in a corner of the Central, Rendevous Restaurant actually takes up quite a lot of space as it is segmented into three parts. The ordering is a bit unconventional compared to the usual restaurants - you walk through the food counter and point at what you want, and the waiters will bring it over to your table. The food's pricy for nasi padang though - I ordered chicken curry, two begedil, curry veg, two plates of rice and three glasses of ice lemon tea and the bill came up to $30. The food was okay - you can find better nasi padang at hawker centres. Definitely try their chendol, I had it here the last time and it was delicious!I'll still be back though. I love the ambience and the set up of the place!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-72, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: $90 for a simple lunch where every portion is smallUnhelpful service who uses the flick of the head to indicate yes? Try cold curry which I insisted needed to be microwavedI'm now writing this sitting in the toilet. I guess this restaurant is only in biz because of novelty factorFor me absolutely the first and last visit

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-72, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I'm abit torn on this one. Its great nasi padang obviously but I cant wrap my head around paying that amount of money for something I can get at a coffeeshop or hawker centre. I used to to the old outlet at rendezvous hotel when I was much younger and I really enjoyed the food there. The food at the new outlet is possibly just as good. The curry chicken thigh , beef rendang and sambal kangkong were some of my favourites.But at the end of it, I kept wondering if I would pay 8 bucks for a chicken thigh and $3.60 for sambal kang kong the next time I wanted nasi padang. Based on quality of food, I'd give it 4 stars but I've yet to be convinced it worth paying so much.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-72, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Randomly stumbled upon this place one night at Central Mall, while searching for a ramen shop which proved to have a queue that was too long for our hungry stomachs. Rendezvous Restaurant though more than made up for our disappointment! The awesome smell wafting from the restaurant made our mouths water; and the food was purely satisfying. The potato patties and beef rendang are to die for. The former is crispy on the outside and has a wonderfully tender interior. Pour some of the beef rending gravy over it, and you have a taste bomb. Yum. Price wise, Rendezvous Restaurant is cheap too - a meal for 2 cost $26 (okay fine, it's not exactly the cheapest price to pay for nasi padang, but considering the location, you can't really complain). Definitely worth checking this restaurant out if you're ever at Central Mall.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-72, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: A Malay padang restaurant, Rendezvous provides an almost smorgasboard style of ordering your food. Choose your meat and choose your curry accompaniment - rendang, sambal etc They will chop up your protein for you and then add on the sauce. Clean but what I consider a bit sterile surroundings (although supposed to be like an old school cafe), make sure you reserve a table ahead so you can get a view of the river. My personal favourites were the sambal egg, the beef rendang and the bergadel (sp.?). I also advise coming as a group so you can order a wide variety of dishes to share. My first ice kachang experience too, which was a refreshing and surprisingly delicious treat! Definitely worth a visit for some delicious Malay food, however given I was with locals this time and did all the ordering so it might be a bit more of a lucky dip when I visit again!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-72, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: The food is above average but terribly overpriced, I could get the same for half the price easily.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-72, The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I have been dining at Rendezvous for 30 plus years, and over the years the food quality has gone down--the food not as tasty as it once was. These past few years I no longer have to visit Rendezvous when I crave some nasi padang. Else where can satisfy my craving.

address: 1 Old Parliament Lane The Arts House Singapore 179429 Singapore
comment: We tried the Rendang chicken & Tahu Telor here. The rendang chicken comes with a drumstick. Tasted ok but not wow. Tahu Telor  was disappointing.There's no wifi & service is appalling .

Came here for lunch with the family and overall I wasn't too impressed. The food had good flavor, all 4 of us enjoyed the meals we had. The thing that I was not impressed with was the portion size. My sons meal came out and it was a large portion, plenty of food. My girlfriends meal came out and there was barley enough food to cover the bottom of her plate. My meal was somewhere in between those two. For $20SPD each I'd expect more.There are plenty of other places to eat right around there, I'd give somewhere else a try.

My friends and I came here for the free flow promotion which I saw advertised both on Facebook as well on Instagram. I wanted to do a booking online for a Monday evening but when I tried it said that Monday was their off day. Weird since they mention a promotion on Monday's? Anyways, I called and made a reservation and I enquired about the free flow and they did confirm that it was still on.When we arrived, we were seated at a nice table near the river, and we ordered 5 times the free flow but  were told after that the free flow is only in their 3rd level lounge. So we decided to go upstairs and order 5 x the promo, only to learn that you had to pay downstairs first . So down again... when we tried to pay, only then we learned that it was impossible to get 5 times the free flow and one alacarte (since one of my friends is pregnant). In the end, we ended up eating all alacarte at our original table which was ok, but it would have been nice to have been told so at the start so we could have been spared of walking up and down the stairs.The food was not bad but nothing special either, the calamari were nicely done (not a chewy batter job as you get so often) and the burrata with parma ham was delicious. We also had three pasta dishes: truffle ravioli, spaghetti puttanesca & penne arrabiata, a pizza, a meat dish, some bruscetta and a salad, all of them were just a-ok.Overall, the view and atmosphere near the river is ok, but the food and the service is nothing special, to me this is an unremarkable place so we will probably look for another place to get drinks and dinner next time.

Until this day, I remember my friend telling me "if you're craving for Pasta, Pasta Fresca is the best!".Well sadly, this statement was uttered some 7+ years ago and perhaps their glory days are long behind them.We came from Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) and was on our way to Namu Korean Dining at the end of Boat Quay. However, we were starving and Riverfront dining looks good and thus, we decided to make have dinner at Pasta Fresca - which was one of the few shops that we walked past.Funnily, there was only one waiter taking orders from the guests seated outside. Not sure if there will be a bigger crowd later on but one waiter? Come on.Anyway, the service was pretty slow in terms of order-taking but our food came pretty fast, much to our surprise.Verdict:Spaghetti Amatriciana - Why is the spaghetti so thick??! It looks that it was soaked in hot water for too long. The sauce/toppings were ok, no complains.Al Funghi E Asparagi - Sauce was delicious and flavourful. My partner order Linguini to go with this and the pasta was done al dente. Perfect.Minstrone soup - Priced at $16 you'd would expect something better but all we got was a small serving of vegetables in plain soup. Soup that tasted very bland. A very poor excuse for soup.

After having been to Italy, I know what amazing pasta tastes like! To be honest, I picked this place with the family after walking around Singapore for a few hours.
