It was hot out, I wanted to replace and I prefer Italian over Asian food. We were seated pretty quickly and there was a decent selection of food to pick from, which made it great as a vegetarian. The location is great, right off the river. You can either sit outside along the river, or inside the small restaurant, which has AC. We sat inside to cool off from our day. We ordered pretty quickly and the waiter was good about making sure we had enough water. I selected the gnocchi with pesto sauce, which honestly was pretty dang good, but the portion size was very small especially compared to some of the other plates that came out. The only downside was the portion size, otherwise I would recommend this little spot to others!

I chose this place for late lunch today because I didn't fancy any of the Asian cuisines. The place is by the river so you have a nice view siting outside and they have fans on to keep you cool. I enjoyed a cocktail which was made of mango and prosecco... Nice! I had the starter garlic bread with mozzarella. I think I should have gone for the bruschetta to get some more flavour. I had the mushroom crepes for my main and needed to add pepper to give it some more flavour.

This is my favourite branch of this Italian chain, due to the option to sit by the river. It's really pleasant to just kick back after a long week or day and feel the evening breeze blowing through your hair. On the downside, the sitting capacity of the restaurant immediately halves if it rains too heavily as you wouldn't want to sit outside.I've never tried anything else here by the pizza, and they're good stuff. The crust is hot and yummy, and the ingredients fresh. If you're not too sure what to order, give the margherita a go before ordering anything else, as I believe that you can tell how good a restaurant's pizza will be through its most basic dish.I'm a big fan of the marinara and the vegetariana. If you're feeling in the mood, you can give their selection of wines a shot. All the fancy wines in bottles are pretty expensive, but you can always get a glass of house pour for S$8.30. Or, if you're like me, you'll stop pretending you understand wine and just order a beer instead! ;)

I'm half italian, my dad owns a few italian restaurants in the states, and he's taken me to many amazing italian restaurants in nyc. So I know a little thing or two about italian food and cooking it. This place? Just skip it. Totally not worth the heavy price tag of paying about $100 for 2 people, though that is with a glass of wine and beer. The squid ink pasta, lack luster. I've definitely had better. The same was with my dish which was spinach ravioli in a red sauce with olives and anchovies. Even the tiramisu was lackluster at best. My mom makes a KILLER tiramisu which she learned from my dad. It's hard to beat that authenticity. I can honestly make these dishes at home and they'll taste the same as this, if not better, but with a cheaper price tag.
Average food, slow service, take a boat ride instead :)Only accept american express card or cash,go to Cedele for good food one block away!

My friends were in shock when I told them I never tried Pasta Fresca till this year - apparently it was every family's restaurant of choice back when we were younger. Must be that crazy jingle that kept playing on TV - I can still hum the tune from vague recollection.So, I finally tried it and I can see why all my friends have fond memories of it. It is a little bit like Jack's place, the Italian edition (and with better food). The interior decor makes for a nice casual date or dinner with a large group. I had the mushroom and vegetarian pizzas and both were pretty good - the base was not to thick and they were very generous with the toppings. The vegetarian is probably the winner because of the effort taken to char-grill the vegetables which gave the pizza an extra kick of flavour. Will be back for more, have to make up for lost time!

Pasta Fresca, one of the first few Italian restaurants in Singapore. I am not sure if the Bukit Timah Rd one still exists but that was the branch I use to frequent when I was younger. Pasta Fresca serves hearty home style  Italian food which is rather heavy( chunky tomato sauce and cream sauce) unlike your modern Italian restaurant. I am not a huge fan of such Italian cooking but a single dish that demands praise would be their Seafood Marinara pasta, the spicy flavors are great with the chunky tomato sauce and seafood mix. With that said Pasta Fresca also serves a decent brick stove cooked pizza. The view facing the river does indeed make up for the slightly under par food.

address: 12 Eu Tong Sen Street Singapore 059819 Singapore
comment: This place is awesome for a quick lunch. Service is super fast despite the lunch crowd. All the Hotplates are great (beef, chicken, pork). 1. Hotplate chicken (my favorite) - If you like Korean BBQ, this is great. Very well marinated. Slightly sweet but savory too. Sorta like teriyaki chicken.2. Hotplate beef (close 2nd to the chicken) - Excellent as well. When I can't make up my mind, I'll take a mixture of the beef & chicken (best of both worlds). 3. Hotplate pork - Ok4. Hotplate fish - Ok but it has quite a lot of bones so definitely not recommended if you are in a rush. Furthermore, it's a bit oily too for me personally. 5. Kimchi noodles- A bit Too spicy for me. Tip: the soup is free :)

address: 12 Eu Tong Sen Street Singapore 059819 Singapore
comment: Don't be fooled by the good reviews - IMO this is squarely a 3-star restaurant, especially if you care about the authenticity of Korean food, and would be willing to pay a little bit more for much better food! There're so many stores at the central market but we settled on this because they had tofu soup (which I was craving), it was crowded, and it was cheap ($5-8 range). I ordered the tofu soup & my friend had the chicken hot plate, only to realize that it was small portions and really not Korean food, in any sense of the food. For eg my tofu soup didn't have any kimchi in it, and was instead filled with hard lettuce strips. There's supposedly pork inside, but it's minced pork instead of slices, and maybe 2 little clumps. The tofu was okay, I guess. The soup was tasteless, not like those comforting kimchi or tofu stews at many of the better Korean restaurants at Tanjong Pagar/Telok Ayer/Chinatown point. The rice had undercooked clumps. My friend found her hot plate chicken very insubstantial and basic too. My friend has been to the other Korean place right across from Sun, and it's apparently much better! You get what you pay for, I suppose. Sigh wasted a meal here.

address: 12 Eu Tong Sen Street Singapore 059819 Singapore
comment: Ok value. Good only for a quick lunch fix.Can be a tad too oily.

address: 12 Eu Tong Sen Street Singapore 059819 Singapore
comment: Simple. Unpretentious. Fast. Cheap. The space is small, but the server bustled us into a couple of seats and was attentive, making sure we got our food quickly. I ordered the beef/chicken hotplate while my wife got the chicken/saba hotplate and green tea. They were satisfying, lunch-sized portions served with rice and kimchi. The total bill was $13.60. This is as good as fast food gets.

address: 12 Eu Tong Sen Street Singapore 059819 Singapore
comment: If you are looking for gourmet Korean food, this is not the place for you. If you are looking for "premium cut of beef", this is not the place for you either. BUT if you are looking for a decent-tasting meal to fill you up without burning a hole in your pocket (we all know how crazy expensive korean food is in Singapore these days) and not leave smelling like a piece of kalbi, this is a fast and cost-effective place for you. I got the bulgogi beef and saba combo for $6.50 which comes with rice and a small dish of kimchi. The beef and fish, albeit not being top-grade meat, were pretty tasty, and the rice was decent as well. This stall is definitely not trying to be a pretentious eatery, with kimchi instant ramen stacked on the cupboards for everyone to see, but they serve a variety of korean food, and their tofu soup comes with options to add ramen and egg and other stuff, which is always fun. Plus the lady is efficient and serves it with a smile. Not worth going out of your way for, but definitely the place to try if you are in clarke quay, and not wanting to spend too much money on a meal, but craving delish food.

address: 1 St Andrew’s Rd #05-03 National Gallery Singapore 178957 Singapore
comment: Art is located on the sixth floor of the national gallery building with excellent views of the marina bay sands and CBD. It's a modern contemporary Italian restaurant with a menu designed by the chef paying tribute to his roots in Italy. The space is modern and doesn't feel nicely spread out and you don't hear the conversations of other tables which is great to have. We had the five course dinner tasting menu. My favorites were the amuse bouche and the leftover pasta course served with fresh sourdough. The petit four desserts were excellent too. They have a nice wine list as well. Recommended as a place to go for a celebration.

address: 3 Pickering Street #01-31, Nankin Row Singapore 048893 Singapore
comment: I'm with Eileen G. in trying to quench the fire of my unrequited longing for Luke's Lobster, but sadly, despite the highest hopes, Platypus just didn't do it for me.The beauty of a real New England Lobster roll is that the sweet fresh flavor of the Lobster takes center stage.  I found Platypus' version, while reasonably priced, simply over spiced to completely nullify the flavor of the lobster.It didn't help that we had atrocious service, inattentive, uneven and apathetic.  We had to beg to order, several things were sold out (including the off menu uni lobster roll and the truffle mac and cheese) and one main came 10 minutes before the other.   When the tray with the first roll was unceremoniously clattered on the table, we had to wheedle the type out of the waiter.  He glanced at it and said "modern", so I pushed it over to El Queso Grande.  Then when the second one arrived, we again asked what kind and this time he glared at it for a hard twenty seconds and said "modern".  When we dared protest that this was a different roll than the first, he dogmatically replied, "OK, that first one was traditional and the new one is modern, that's what I told you before"... Of course, by this point, the first roll was already half eaten... Still no apology was offered... Adding to the calamitous meal were the poor acoustics, which amplified the nearby Friday night girls night table's giggling into terrifying hyena hunting levels.PARTING THOUGHT: Platypus might be better off seeing up cafeteria style... Lobster rolls don't require waiter service, especially when the service standard is this lackluster

address: 3 Pickering Street #01-31, Nankin Row Singapore 048893 Singapore
comment: Friday evening dinner - 6.30pm. I tried to reserve for 2 the night before but no slot was available. Okay, my bad - i was tardy. Turned up the next day anyway and every single table had the dreaded "Reserved" signage - odd since most restaurants would reserve a few for walk-in customers. Condition to get a table was to leave within an hour - fair enough for me! (Many others who showed up apparently did not do any reservations as well and managed to get a table like how we did)Get the Crustacean Bowl - you have 2 option of serving sizes "appetizer" or "main". Friendly waiter commanded that I get one serving as it sells out every day and as a reward for being an early customer Haha charming. After my first bite, I declare this my go-to comfort food. It's so gooey (melted cheese), the caviar gave it enough salt and there is more lobster on this bowl then the rolls. Warning: Do not be deceived by the serving size. Looks small (even for the "main" size) but it's rich, I was sufficiently full eating this.Partner ordered Spicy Garlic Lobster Roll. The set comes with chips - we both agreed it tasted exactly like Calbee chips with a tiny sprinkling of truffle oil. Oh and a side of greens. The highlight of the roll was the bread - so buttery, crunchy and slightly crisp on the outside. The lobster though was overpowered by the garlic flakes - we couldn't really make out whether we were eating lobster or other seafood. In all fairness, that's our mistake - we should have ordered The Traditional which simply poach the lobster meat with butter, lots of butter. We'll be back for sure, with a larger crowd, with reservation made 4-5 days in advance :)

address: 3 Pickering Street #01-31, Nankin Row Singapore 048893 Singapore
comment: Where do you go if you are craving for a Luke's Lobster Roll in Singapore?Well, the closest to those yummy lobster roll that you can find in states would probably be the ones at Platypus Lobster Shack.They have a range of different types of lobster roll with add-ons for you to choose. However, I always stick to the traditional type with an add-on of their uni creme. What I love most about it (besides the tasty lobster-filling) is the bun. The bun is done to perfection (or rather, close to perfection). Every bite is just delightful.I would say that this is probably the best yet in town.

rest_name: An Kee Duck Rice And Kway Chap
address: 531A Upper Cross St #02-18, Hong Lim Food Centre Singapore 051531 Singapore
comment: Good value good taste.One of those stalls that provide good food at good price points typical of good hawker type foods. Probably good enough for repeat customers, unlikely to become hawker legends.The ingredients for a typical Kueh Chap is intestines! But, I don't see intestines. I see and ate tongue, pork belly, egg, skin, dao-pok (dried and fried soyabean squares), small side of green marinated vegetables (there's probably a name for it, I just don't know what)The taste is acceptable, but unmemorable.The kueh chap (the flat square noodles) that comes with the order taste exceptionally good. It retains its texture, shape, cooked just right. It is soaked in the same brown sauce but diluted enough, not too salty, but still gives it flavor.The chilli is good enough; vingearish and spicy enough. Also quite common and forgetably average.If you are not interested in Q-ing for food here, this stall can satisfy.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I was in Singapore for two weeks and this was one of my favorite meals! (I'm a little embarrassed to admit that amongst all that beautiful cuisine from ethnicities around the world, it was Western-style fast-food that was one of my favorite meals, but what can you do. I am American after all.)nomVnom is a 100%-vegan fast-food joint in the food court basement of Clarke Quay Central. They do vegan burgers, a variety of sides, some desserts, and a variety of hot and cold drinks.I had the "Meatless Mexican," which is a soy patty with black olives, jalapeño, tomato, mustard, and lettuce. Now, I'm from Texas, so I know Mexican food -- and aside from the jalapeño, nothing about this burger was "Mexican." But who cares? It was delicious!For a side, I had the Vietnamese Yam Roll and OHMYGOSH WHAT IS THIS PURPLE DELICIOUSNESS. I was tempted to get up and order another side of the Vietnamese Yam Roll, because it was that amazing. But I was too embarrassed because I'd already demolished my meal in less than 15 minutes, ha!For a drink, I got good old-fashioned American root beer (hard to find in Australia, so I was surprised to see it in Singapore) and they gave me some free apple cider as well. Score!Atmosphere-wise, this is just a basic food court, so expect cramped food court seating, but it's not a big deal.Their patties are also free from garlic and onion if you are avoiding those. I'm not sure about their sauces.Anyway, definitely worth trying this place for a quick lunch or dinner if you're around the Clarke Quay Central area. And if you're vegetarian or vegan who's visiting Singapore and craving Western food, make an effort to seek this place out!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Atmosphere is pleasant, with a nice view over Clarke Quay. Service was friendly, but staff didn't seem to know much about allergens in the food. Most of the burgers contained some form of gluten, and there was no substitute option for the wheat bun. I ended up ordering the corn soup after convincing the server that cornstarch doesn't contain gluten. It came out overmicrowaved, with a skin on top and steam pouring out for five minutes before I could taste it, and then it was just kind of watery and sad. The geez cake (which the server said does contain wheat flour, despite that the photo display lists all ingredients except flour) was supertasty, but just a tiny little slice. I love that vegan restaurants are starting to be a thing, so I'm giving it an extra star for that reason. If you don't have any dietary restrictions and don't mind microwaved food, you can have a tasty little meal here. Credit cards accepted.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: NomVnom is located in a mall with views of Clarke Quay across the street. It's a self service small cafe where you order from a note pad and you turn in that note to a teenager.My friend is a vegan and we arrived here after 9 pm. There are two locations in the city but we selected this one as it's open later.I ordered the rendang burger and the flavors were sweet and strong. There were two or three popchips in the burger to add some crunch. The fried mushrooms we ordered were plain and wet on the inside. Overall, I think this is a great options for Vegans that are looking for a Western option.The location was challenging to find so I recommend having a picture of the location and asking around.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: OH MY am I not a burger person (I think I'd rather have soy sauce over rice) but OH MY do I love these burgers. I came back twice during my time in sg (I'm writing this review over a year later, still thinking about this place) and I even dragged my carnivore friends here (which they very much appreciated). From the complementary apple cider vinegar shot they give you if you dine in that's perfectly sweet, tangy and feels like *health* (not to mention aids digestion of all the food I'm gonna devour afterwards), to the burgers with what-feels-like artisan buns, to the sweet potato fries (I also don't usually like fries I'm sorry but I love japanese yams), everything is delicious!! You can't go wrong with any of the burgers (can't believe I'm saying this) but I can personally vouch for the King Mushroom Head and Lion's Mane Truffle Burgers.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Woo, what a variety of vegetarian and vegan burgers! The south east asian flavours are paramount and distinct, worth going back to try multiple items.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: My go-to for vegan nomz. Their menu is huge, offer beautiful views of Clarke Quay Central. You can't go wrong with a Temptation Satay if you like spicy.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I came here after trying to go to a couple different Hawker centers. All of the vegan stalls were closed, and I was so hungry. I got the 4c set which is a mushroom truffle sauce burger with a cold lemon tea and a side salad. The side salad was two pieces of lettuce and a half a handful of chopped carrots. The drink was okay, but I wished the cup had been bigger. The burger was good, but it wasn't amazing. It was a glorified chicken sandwich with mayo. I spend $14.90 SGD, and I wish I had gone somewhere else. I'm sure I will be hungry again in a few hours. Unless you've got $20 SGD burning a hole in your pocket, go somewhere else.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Vegan restaurant in the Clark Quay Center Mall. The set up here is a little odd but the food is decent and has a nice view. Basically you look through the menu and fill out what you want to order on a pad of paper, you take that to the counter and pay. The staff will avoid interacting with you at all costs as it is a "no service" set up (odd for a restaurant). I was the only one in there and there were about 5 staff members all avoiding me like the plague- it's fine I didn't mind as long as I got my food. For the food- it's hit or miss but can't complain as it is one of the only vegan comfort/fast food places in the area (beggars can't be choosers I guess). I would NOT recommend the jack fruit burger, it was inedible and very chewy/fiberous (and I normally love jack fruit meat substitutes).

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I ordered the QQ cheesy burger and it was very satisfying. I love the homemade cashew sauce and it tastes amazing with the mushroom patty. The best part of the meal was the appetizer. It's was my first time taking a shot of vinegar before any meal. It made the experience unforgettable. Staff were very accommodating. Able to answer my questions. Overall experience was great. Will be back when I revisit SG!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: My partner is vegetarian so decided to try it. I was more for local foods and decided on the Toon Rendang Rice, the vegan version of Rasi Lemak. Boy... It was tasty and fake small fishes (ikanbili) was really great. Will definitely come back again.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I've tried four different burgers. All great. Wish they had a bit more seating for peak times. Friendly staff. Truffle fries are nice!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I ordered the QQ cheesy burger and it was very satisfying. I love the homemade cashew sauce and it tastes amazing with the mushroom patty. The best part of the meal was the appetizer. It's was my first time taking a shot of vinegar before any meal. It made the experience unforgettable. Staff were very accommodating. Able to answer my questions. Overall experience was great. Will be back when I revisit SG!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I tried their Qq Cheesy burger and Truffle fries. The QQ cheesy burger was supposed to be the recommended dish in this restaurant, but it was way below my expectation.The burger tasted bland. The patty wasn't so good, it just tasted like potato salad with a bit of mushroom flavor. The truffle fries helped, as it tasted good like most truffle fries.Plus side, they had some tomato sauce to add some flavor to the burger. But its definitely overpriced, since there are better vegetarian burgers out there with lower price

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #03-107 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I was in Singapore for two weeks and this was one of my favorite meals! (I'm a little embarrassed to admit that amongst all that beautiful cuisine from ethnicities around the world, it was Western-style fast-food that was one of my favorite meals, but what can you do. I am American after all.)nomVnom is a 100%-vegan fast-food joint in the food court basement of Clarke Quay Central. They do vegan burgers, a variety of sides, some desserts, and a variety of hot and cold drinks.I had the "Meatless Mexican," which is a soy patty with black olives, jalapeño, tomato, mustard, and lettuce. Now, I'm from Texas, so I know Mexican food -- and aside from the jalapeño, nothing about this burger was "Mexican." But who cares? It was delicious!For a side, I had the Vietnamese Yam Roll and OHMYGOSH WHAT IS THIS PURPLE DELICIOUSNESS. I was tempted to get up and order another side of the Vietnamese Yam Roll, because it was that amazing. But I was too embarrassed because I'd already demolished my meal in less than 15 minutes, ha!For a drink, I got good old-fashioned American root beer (hard to find in Australia, so I was surprised to see it in Singapore) and they gave me some free apple cider as well. Score!Atmosphere-wise, this is just a basic food court, so expect cramped food court seating, but it's not a big deal.Their patties are also free from garlic and onion if you are avoiding those. I'm not sure about their sauces.Anyway, definitely worth trying this place for a quick lunch or dinner if you're around the Clarke Quay Central area. And if you're vegetarian or vegan who's visiting Singapore and craving Western food, make an effort to seek this place out!

Fortune was smiling on me the day I stumbled across this fantastic eatery! Not one to get excited about salads, I figured I'd just poke my nose in and see what they had to offer. Swept up in a sea of healthy-eating afficionados, I ordered the first thing that caught my eye, the Beyond Me. With a few minor substitutions which staff readily accommodated, it was perfect! Vegan, gluten-free (mostly), gloriously onion-free (I forgot to ask) and supertasty! A tantalizing blend of flavors and textures, super healthy ingredients. A cold-pressed beet-apple-carrot juice was the perfect accompaniment. I've since tried their smoothies, which are also delicious.They do a brisk business - it was crowded throughout the lunch hour, and yet my meal was ready within minutes. Food prep area is out in the open, so you can watch them put together your salad and see how clean everything is. Service is exceptionally friendly and efficient. In-house orders served with reusable dishes and silverware. Prices are reasonable for the amount and quality of food you get. Credit cards accepted. Open 8:00am to 8:30pm, closed Saturdays and Sundays. Atmosphere knocks it out of the park with sky-high ceilings and glass walls that let in loads of natural light. (Their other locations have the same menu, but all seem to be stuck in windowless shopping center basements - which is okay if you're in a pinch.)I've been back to this location several times and enjoyed the same consistently top-notch experience each time. Highly recommend this amazing spot!

Outlet at Tangs Plaza: This is the second smallest SaladStop; although you eat among pedestrians, at least there are a few tables and chairs, whereas at Takashimaya you must go hunting for space in the food court or be satisfied gulping your wrap on a bench. Innovative, tasteful and pricey salads and wraps. Hawkers must cringe at the price of the quite-good but minuscule "Hainanese chicken quinoa" (go find quinoa in Hainan!) that sells for $6.50 + GST! After all, this is the Banyan Tree of salad counters, and not a Hotel 81!

the salad King in town!! the quality of the ingredient is just great!! and also have signature menu for smoothies with Superfruits from brazil like acai the best antioxidant!! also some other very unique flavor likes Acerola and Caja!!!
Yup after all these years still got the kick.  As usual full house.  Hokkien mee as usual is my all time fav.  Sharksfin Crabmeat wrap the b

Restaurant is situated at level 5 carpark of OCBC Centre. It's been a year since I last visited the restaurant but the food still tasted as good as I remembered. Highly recommend the duck salad, fish maw soup, prawn ball, hokkien noodles and yam paste. Excellent food and service. Portion of the dishes were huge too, there were 5 of us but we ordered the smallest size for most of the items. A must visit if you love hokkien cuisine.

Beng Thin Hoon Kee is a Chinese restaurant in the OCBC Centre building at Raffles Place, on the 5th floor.We just moved into this building and wanted to explore the food options nearby. A colleague recommended Beng Thin as I guess it has been an establishment for quite many years in Singapore. This is not the original location but I'm guessing they started out as a smaller joint somewhere in the heartland and with years of success opened a much larger and fancier spot here.They have a variety of set menus to choose from with prices ranging from $400-$1000-ish for a party of 8. We came right before CNY and had a guest visiting from the states so we did the whole Lo Hei thing and ordered a variety of items a la carte.Everything we tried was pretty tasty. This was the first time I ever tried fish ball soup - something about it having deep fried fish bladder (is that what fish ball soup is?) - I wasn't totally grossed out so that was a plus.I guess I'm not very adventurous when it comes to Chinese food, especially because there is usually a heavy focus on seafood and I'm not a fan of seafood. When I tell folks I don't like Chinese food, the whole room usually goes quiet and someone yells at me to leave Singapore immediately.Well Beng Thin Hoon Kee is A-OK in my books, that's exactly how I would describe it. Not a huge fan but they are OK, hence the 3 stars. Would I come back? Probably as it's right downstairs now!

It's my first time to this place for a birthday dinner. I was amazed by the Chinese decor that greeted me in the midst of the carpark. Ambience: Nice and traditional Chinese feel. I'm awed by the overall facade of the place, hence it's a 5 star! Food: Overall food is meeting expectations just that it is slightly on the saltish side. Yusheng: Salmon is fresh and ingredients are given in good proportionShark Fin soup: Good! Not bad.  Crispy chicken: it comes with the prawn crackers and skin is crispy! It's a lovely dish to have. Steam fish (not sure what's the name): not so good as the texture of the fish is powdery seems to be not too fresh, probably due to the Chinese New Year period.Stir fried lobster: lovely! It's really amazing with ginger slices and spring onions. Broccoli with scallop: broccoli is crunchy but overall the dish is too saltishHokkien Mee: Done nicely as it's not overcooked type. But still saltishYam Paste with pumpkin & ginkgo: everyone on the table agree that it's the best dish! It's really good with the "cong you" smell! I will miss this dish! Longevity buns: it's one of the bigger ones given compared to other places I've been to. nice lotus paste fragrant and not too sweet. Pricing: Around $700 plus for a table of 8 adults. Service: Thumbs up! Even with our frequent request for warm water and tea, they served us quickly even though the place is very full. The plates and bowl were constantly changed after almost after every 2 dishes. However when the birthday song was played on the PA system, it can be hardly heard. Probably due to the crowd and the location of our table.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-28 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This is probably the only congee place in the area. Nothing spectacular, but I guess if you are feeling under the weather, this can be a good choice.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-88 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Celebrated a family member's birthday here, out of the many Japanese restaurants housed in Central @ Clarke Quay, Mitsuba is probably one of the more authentic and unpretentious Japanese restaurants. It reminded me of the restaurants that I went to during my trip to Japan recently... the sushi bar manned by a Japanese sushi chef (?), the yamazaki and suntory whisky bottles neatly placed in a line... All these little details added to the whole genuine dining experience.We sat down and were promptly served by one of the staff who asked us what we would like to drink. Good attentive service staff. I ordered a Sake (Salmon) and Swordfish Don Kyu which I saw was recommended by a fellow Yelper- was not disappointed! The slices were nice and thick for $20, slightly more than what I would usually pay for a Don at the usual Japanese chains like Sushi Tei, but there was definitely no compromise on quality! All Don Kyus also come with a little appetiser dish (I think mine was seasoned octopus bits which was alright), miso soup, watermelon slices, and Japanese pickles. So the $20 sure had alot of mileage!Another dish I would recommend is the Sashimi Moriwase. Very fresh sashimi - also thickly cut with a generous portion of wasabi. Probably would have ordered the 18-piece set instead of a 12-piece if we had more stomach space... At $48, it was a little pricey but it would probably cost the same elsewhere. They did not compromise on the quality and portion though, which I think is really important when it comes to sashimi.As the saying goes, you know its authentic Japanese food when you see Japanese people eating there, which is what we saw. Highly recommend it and will definitely be back here again!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-88 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Did an uber takeout, ordered Mistuba Chirashi set ($29.96), 7-8 types of raw fish/sashimi. Love the many different assortments, though tasted a little too local for my liking especially with the saucy razor-clam like sashimi. There was a special piece of vinegared mackeral with lots of roes (see picture), lots of pops in the mouth! All sashimis were very fresh. Set came with 2 slices of watermelon and mini miso soup. Delivery took decently quick.Overall, a 3 half star experience. However, if you're looking for dons with a unique taste to it, this wouldn't be the best place to go to... as mentioned, the don was a little too local for the taste buds!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-88 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Came here for dinner as recommended by a friend.If you get a seat by the window, you get a nice view of Clark Quay. However, the lighting is pretty bright so I guess it is not the most romantic restaurant :PThe Salmon Don comes with Miso soup, and watermelon. The Don itself is pretty filling with lots of sushi rice, as well as a generous serving of fresh and thick sashimi. The don itself should be enough to fill a girl up assuming she has an average appetite.The unagi maki roll is pretty good too, but I do feel that they are not as generous with their unagi serving.Do NOT order the salmon roe chawanmushi. You're probably better off with the normal chawanmushi as the salmon roe is not fresh and has a strong fishy taste, destroying the taste of the egg :(Will probably return again just for the sashimi.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-88 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Nice environment.  The ala crate buffet is nice. It's serve hot and fresh for all the food that they serve. Quiet and cozy place. Resonable price. Roughly per person is $44 for lunch buffet.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-88 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I would come back to mitsuba for the salmon and swordfish don. It is totally value for money. For $20, you get fresh fish which are sliced generously. The grilled squid and gyoza were quite good too. And the service was quite decent. They almost toppled a dish but seemed apologetic and offered to change it for us if we minded. The restaurant is otherwise not extremely remarkable but I would definitely come back here for the don!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-88 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: For full reviews and pics, visit my blog!Every time someone asks me for Japanese food recommendations, i'll always direct them to Chikuwa Tei for their affordable bentos and high quality and chunky slices of sashimi. Chef Peter, the grumpy chef who first started Wasabi Tei at Far East Plaza, helms the restaurant at Mohamed Sultan. Just a couple of months back, Chef Peter opened his third restaurant, Mitsuba By Yurine Japanese Restaurant, at The Central, Clarke Quay.There is quite a good view of the Singapore river from the inside of the restaurant. Do remember to reserve those seats if you want to chill out with your friends (not a date). We started with the Ebi Tempura (5pcs for $12). The prawn is fresh but the batter was a little too thick. The batter was thicker the second time i had this. Maybe i'll try the soft shell crab next time.  Bentos are very affordable, just like Chikuwa Tei. I had the Natsu Bento ($40) with Mackajiki (Swordfish) Sashimi, Gindara Teriyaki, Chawanmushi and Miso Soup. I could not finish the thick juicy slabs of swordfish sashimi which was crunchy as well. Very good fish i must say. The teriyaki cod fish was fatty and oily in a really tummy satisfying way. Love the charred and sweetened bits that coat the fish.Chef Peter is well known for his generous Chirashi and you just gotta have this. The staple at Chikuwa Tei is sold here at $28 but there are 4 differently priced dons and it goes up to $68. We had the Natsu Chirashi Sushi ($38) which has fatty salmon belly, scallops, swordfish, a little stuffed squid with roe and more. The higher priced sets include toro belly, Botan Shrimps and scallops.Absolutely another of my favorite Japanese restaurant. Love the food but the service is pretty bad. The female wait staff reluctantly gave us a chair to put all our bags but reminded us that she'd have to take it back if there are customers. And the restaurant was half full. Meh. Well, for good sashimi and fuss free eating, i'll put up with it. Filling the tummy is more important. Just a little amazed at how un-princessy i am these days. Hur.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-88 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: The first time I tried this place, I got salmon belly sashimi to go. It was really good, fatty and fresh. The next two times I came here, I got the salmon bento set. The salmon was fresh, and the grilled salmon slab was generous, but the fish was slighty overcooked and dry. The miso was tasteless, the chawanmushi was okay, but at 30 bucks, I had expected a better flavor. Sukiyaki was pretty good. Ordered ikura oroshi and it came as a mouthful of salmon roe over radish. The salmon roe was not fresh and the portion was ridiculously small for 9 bucks. So this restaurant started out great and became not so great. Never had the chirashi so I can't comment on that, but I hope that they will improve on their quality of raw seafood they serve, specifically the salmon roe.

Finally gave Aayisha Briyani House a try and was pleasantly surprised with their delicious, fluffy, light, flavorful briyani.Now I regret not having come here sooner to try their briyani. Seems pretty popular with the lunchtime crowd so drop in a bit before or after the rush to have your meal in peace.Had the Kashmir Briyani today. I'm not sure what that is but it came with a mound of briyani rice with a chicken drumstick hidden inside. There was also a bit of curried eggplant, some cucumber bits, a hard boiled egg, and a dollop of curry on the side. All that for $8.50. Quite filling and goes well with a glass of iced tea. I was expecting a glass of lemon ice tea or something but it was actually iced teh tarik, a first for me, but also not bad!

I prefer this Indian coffeeshop to the very popular Shah Alam because:1) They have healthier veg options - like you can have actual green vegetables not floating in curry or oil to balance up your meal2) seems cheaper3) much cooler and more comfy environment - with free tissue at the cashier4) it's quiet enough to have a chat with friends5) the guys serving are less abrupt and mostly actually pleasant6) I like the teh tarik7) The biryani rice (when I do take it which I seldom do for health reasons) is really fragrant and fluffy and separate and more like the dum style (ie it's tasty with spices without sloshing curry all over it - unless you want to, in which case I won't judge. I have my moments).They have some specials like fish biryani $8.50 on Wednesday and Friday Dum Biryani (but I don't find it worth the extra over the normal biryani).

Little corner deli that serves sandwiches and Australian pies.It feels exactly like a mom-and-pop corner store and you are most likely to be served by the boss and/or his friends. Decent sandwiches and it is probable just a place to get a quick bite as it is usually not busy.The store is tiny and has no seats indoors. You get to sit outside and marvel at how the north canal/south bridge area has changed from a neighborhood selling dried seafood to housing multiple chic hostels and cool bars and restaurants.

A contemporary Cantonese restaurant, be wowed by the dishes served here at Yan!Managed by the Park Hotel Group, this is their first restaurant located outside of their hotels. Enjoy a meal served both communal style and individually served, each plate is an art on display. Not only that, the food is pretty tasty too! Some of the highlight dishes include the Roast Duck, Suckling Pig and my personal favourite is the Mango and Coconut dessert. Served in a coconut, the coconut juice is made into a sorbet that lined the base within the coconut. Then there's a scoop of rich and creamy mango ice cream. Topping the ice cream is frozen mango crush with a layer of oats sprinkled all over.To fully enjoy this dish, once should dig their spoon all the way to the bottom so that each scoop has a sample of each layer of ingredients. The taste when put into your mouth is like a burst of celebration.Don't forget to try their sampler of dimsum too! Served as an individual serving, when the platter arrives, it's a complete instagram moment. It is slightly pricier than a regular cantonese restaurant but still affordable.

Enjoyed dim sum here.  Black Charcoal Dumplings (with large shrimp under its dark skin) was good but a little bland. Steamed Fresh Lily and Vegetables Dumplings very fresh with good texture contrast. Did not detect foie gras in the Foie Gras, Celery and Mushroom Rolls (mostly mushrooms). Prawn dumpling with fish roe topping looked exquisite and tasted good. Deep fried pancake with red bean okay to end the meal with.

Located at the top of the National Gallery of Singapore. Small dining room. The booths were nice and cozy. Definitely need reservations. There were a few empty tables but people walking in were being turned away. Service in general was not bad, but yes, a bit slow. No one is in a rush. This place does not like to be in a rush.Quite pricey for what it is. Had the siew mai ($8) and scallop dumplings with truffle ($9 for 3) which were okay, nothing special. The chili crab meat buns ($9 for 3) were quite interesting. Wished it was more bite-sized.The chicken sticky rice in lotus leaf ($4) was interesting because it was like eating a reconstructed chicken rice with all its flavors in one roll. Lastly, had the red bean cakes which were also just okay. I've had better elsewhere.I expected abit more since the chef is trained in HK. Just come here if you want to pay more for fancy dimsum with average food.

i guess i am long overdue in delivering a two stars review?firstly, i blame national kitchen, for being fully booked which resulted in me settling for yan.secondly, i blame myself, the fact that yan was half empty on a friday night at prime time should have set off alarm bells, internally.yan looks beautiful from the outside.but things changed very quickly upon entering!the interior decor may continue to wow you but no one may be there to welcome you?instead, you might be enveloped by a cocktail of nasty smells, a potent mix of body odour, mustiness and oiliness.that should have been the knockout punch for me but alas my date beckons.once seated, service was patchy at best.my guess is that they are understafffed?but if they aim to execute a high end cantonese dining concept with commensurate pricing then surely they have to deliver exacting service?but no, tables were randomly cleared as and when they have time, others were left uncleared even though the guests have all left a long time.other notables include, a menu that was filled with soya sauce stains that initially looked like artistic designs!the clientele here is also a very mixed bag, from your casually dressed ones to your three piece business associates and also family with kids running around and making music with their utensils.ok, let's move on to the more important stuff and talk about their food.seriously, nothing that crystal jade kitchen cannot muster, at a fraction of the price.soup was pretty standard, they served mine in a coconut so i get charged more? yes, you can get this at soup restaurant too!nai bai in XO sauce was good enough but nothing cutting edge.if you so desire to eat half a peking duck, they will come in wrapped parcels, soaked in sauce and plonked on your table.the wrap is too thick in my opinion and if you want the usual garnishing in it, you will have to unwrap, add your poison and then re-wrap before eating.the second course for your peking duck is at a $10 supplement and we chose the diced duck in lettuce wrap.taste was ok with a nice crunch from crispy you tiao bits but portions do look less than the half a duck we ordered.the highlight of the meal for me has to be the live prawns with noodle ball!crispy sang mee made into a ball served with prawns and cauliflower in a thick rich hot broth.my only complain is that this was not as what the picture menu promised.when we ordered, we were expecting broccoli and not cauliflower and for the live prawns to come with head attached.i am quite sure it would have made for a better photo than what we ended up getting!;( we were indeed so disappointed at this stage, that we decided against ordering any desserts and adjourned elsewhere instead. if you so yearn for a good cantonese experience, yan is anything but.

Nice dining room, although it's a pity they can't take advantage of the rooftop location to offer any view. The menu has many innovative dishes (eg. prawn and crabmeat dumplings with tiny abalone, chilli crab buns, 1000-layered tofu, noodle ball, etc). They're all competently executed, but with no special refinement and overall there's no wow factor. Service is courteous, albeit a tad slow at times. Pricey for what it offers; potential is so much higher than reality.
Went there for birthday dinner service is good and food is ok but not  must try standard .Claypot rice is bad. The rest is just normal

Went for lunch today with business associates and had a pleasant meal in quite surrounding. Service was good and the food was okay, but not over the top for the price. Not many people dining as it was a rainy Monday and not many at the restaurant. I would say that for the money, one could do better that just average food and service.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #B1-44 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: One of my favourite vegetarian places whenever I will be around the Clark q.It's indoor and got a good view.The food menu is huge.The dishes comes out in a good speed.Drinks. I usually go for coffee  so it's always alright.The prices are quite cheap even so it's a clark q area.So I like it and would highly recommend this place.See you soon.

address: 63 Chulia St #01-01 OCBC Center Singapore 049514 Singapore
comment: I was early for a meeting and decided to get a cuppa of coffee and snack. I always like Maison Kayser's breads and tarts. The menu at this Chulia Street branch is different from the one at Scott's. Here they cater to the office crowd. With so many other cafes around the area, like Cedele, Artease, Starbucks, Maison Kayser stands out for their delicious breads. The sitting area is also spacious unlike those cramped small stools and tables at close proximity. And yes, did I mention the cheerful and wonderful service from the guys at the counter!

address: 63 Chulia St #01-01 OCBC Center Singapore 049514 Singapore
comment: Asked the lady to heat up the almond croissant and it turned out soggy. Asked her if this is normal, she replied "you want it hot ah." The most disgusting croissant I've ever had in my life.

address: 15 Philip Street Tan Ean Kiam Building Singapore 048694 Singapore
comment: Fresh and the guys are pretty pleasant. They often rem my order. There's a sign saying they make their own fish cake and you can tell it's really fresh and springy yet soft. You can add mushrooms for a buck and it's a worthy addition. They are firm and plump and tasty from being braised a long time in the sauce. The chilli which they mix for you also has a very homemade taste with lots of time tiny shrimps visible. I usually go for mee sua or mee Kia. The noodles are quite springy as well and not run of the mill.Helps that it's seldom a wait compared to the popular but super slow (and inefficient) stall down circular road with a very stuffy atmosphere. $4 for basic.

Yakun is a unique Singaporean place to grab an economical breakfast. This historical breakfast chain started from a single coffee stall in Singapore and has spread across Asia since. I was excited to try some of their kaya  menu items, since kaya (a coconut based paste) originated from Singapore. We ordered some original kaya butter toast and some stuffed kaya egg pieces. Both were delicious! the kaya butter toast was grilled on a charcoal grill, and the butter slice goes along SO well with it (except that it has a million calories and is artery clogging...oh well). The server also flattened the bread so that it was crispy, and cut off all of the crust. Yummy yum with a cup of their legit milk tea. I would definitely recommend to anyone who drops by Singapore to not miss out on this local delight!

A local joint for simple kaya toast, which is a singapore thing.Guess im not a fan of the thick white bread and sweet kaya paste...i guess it works for young ones, but its too carb-y for meThey do have eggs and various drinks too

address: 30 Raffles Place #B1-08 Chevron House Singapore 048622 Singapore
comment: Popped in for a quick bite, this stall has expanded into two shops, one that serves quick bites and coffee, the other quick meals. Nothing can argue with the price $5.30 bought me a Set A Nasi Lemak with Pork, 2 sides and a soft drink. I opted for the fish cake which was nice and the french beans which were good, just a bit oily. The pork was a little lean and tough, but for this price, you can not expect much. Recommended because the queue moves fast, the items were hot and for cheap eats in Raffles Place.

Food was bad, burger patty was grey and seemed like it was steamed instead of grilled. Pretty tasteless. Also, the rice bowl was drenched in truffle oil.... tasted like oily rice. Coffee was good though. Good place for drinks.

This is one of those places that you can feel that you are having healthy food. Everything is made from organic soya, even the kway chap and the porridge.They do a good vegetarian version of braised meats/intestines and beancurd, served up in a plate not unlike a usual kway chap. They also have a vegetarian chicken cutlet served with "chicken" rice. Tasty too.And with the brutal heat these days, this is also a place where you can get a organic soya beancurd (the lao ban version). Great way to fight the heat and apparently it is great for the skin too.Only gripe: they do not have a separate kitchen. All the dishes are done within the AC and I tend to think that I always leave this place smelling like soy beans.

D'Bell: It's delightful, it's delicious, it's de-lovely! :)Since D'Bell was offering 20% off your bill in June if you reserve through Chope, my colleagues and I decided to take them up on the offer. We went during lunch, and it was fairly quiet. Perhaps it's because they're kinda the new kid on the block, and the CBD crowd hasn't realized that there's an awesome lunch to be had here.Although the set lunches were affordable ($15++) they didn't really appeal to us. The entrees are portioned for 2-3 people, so we decided to just order a few and share. To start, we had papadum, which was served with 3 different chutneys, all delish. We then ordered the palak paneer, butter chicken, and rogan josh. Again, all of it was well done, and the butter chicken was definitely my fave- tender chicken, super creamy sauce. Add in their fragrant biryani rice and all was well in the world!What surprised me was the naan, specifically the Kashmiri one. How I've never tried it before is beyond me, but I'm glad Josh T. ordered it because now I'm hooked. For the uninitiated, it's flatbread with dried fruit, nuts, and herbs- when it's served fresh out of the oven it's ommmmmgahhhh so good.I loved the ambiance (contemporary soft rock Indian music in the background) and the upscale decor; it's the perfect setting for a business lunch or a girl's outing. They've been promoting their lounge on the second floor, which also comes with a sweet ladies night deal (complimentary glass of mojito or bubbly, and a free bottle of bubbly with a booking for 5 ladies and an order of 5 mains.) For our group of 10 and the small discount, we paid about $20 per person. I wouldn't mind revisiting with my gal pals in the future!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Initially Marutama drew my curiosity because of its long queue almost every time I visit the Central, which used to be pretty often when I was based in Singapore. I thought they were always crowded because it's a small space with a couple tables (which is true), but they are efficient at getting people seated, taking orders and clearing tables that the turnover is still pretty fast. So that says something about the food, which I have to give it a try. And I've been back since!My visits have always been during non-peak period, so I can't talk about the wait times. My orders come pretty fast, usually for two people, I will get a deluxe ramen and a plain ramen to share. The deluxe version comes with 3 pieces of char siu, while the plain version comes with just 1, so we get to have 2 slices each. The first time we got 2 deluxe orders, it was too much meat and too filling for us. I won't be the first to say that I had my doubts when I glanced through the menu looking for a pork based soup. I was so certain I'm going to order that, but that doesn't exist in Marutama. Their specialty is the chicken soup, which they do perfectly. Not too heavy and not overly flavored, though it is a tad salty, it is good. I would rank it among the top 5 places for ramen. Love their egg and the ramen. The egg is not included in the ramen so you have to add it separately. There is fried garlic slices on every table. I enjoy adding some to the ramen, it adds a nice touch of fragrance to the ramen soup which I truly enjoy. My mum, on the other hand, prefers the natural taste of the soup without the added garlic. On my visits I noticed many other people ordering their dumplings as appetizers. For just 2 of us the ramen is more than enough, so the next time I visit I will want to introduce more people to Marutama so we can all try some of their appetizers, especially those dumplings.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This ramen place is known for the chicken broth which is rich and flavourful. Serving is generous. Service could be improved but it was particular to an unfriendly and impatient waitress. That aside, food was great! My group had a variety of pork, chicken and even vegetable ramen. The ramen egg was one of the best I have eaten. Each layer was on point in taste and texture. The pork slices and belly were tender with the plentiful spring onions a nice complement. You definitely would not go wrong with the ramen here and it caters to vegetarians too.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Sorry to say but the ramen  not the best and just so so and also your server need to train again. I give two star, because your staff need to improve become more friendly or at least smile to customers

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I ended up wandering here after trying to go to song fa on a Monday, when it is unfortunately not open (curses, no data plan in SG!). the ramen is decent: expect a typical hakata tonkotsu ramen with thin QQ noodles, except with the tonkotsu broth replaced with chicken bone broth. this makes for a rather lighter version of typical hakata ramen, which is not wholly unpleasant, but still leaves you feeling not completely satisfied. the chashu is on the thick side and could be a bit more tender, but still rather flavorful and satisfying. only one piece which was a bit of a minus.they add a different kind of seaweed to their marutama ramen than the typical, which was a rather interesting change. it gave the chicken bone broth a bit more depth, which was very needed. the egg was perfectly soft boiled and marinated in what tasted like a shoyu / mirin mix. it was probably the best part of the bowl.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: 5 stars for the egg! There are 2 camps for ramen - chicken based soup and the traditional milky pork bone based soup. If you prefer things less porky, you will like Marutama Ramen. I'm not really a pork person, so the ramen here is right up my alley. I like the chicken based soup which is still cooked till it is quite thick. It is also not as salty as the usual tonkutsu based soup. The noodle is springy, some liken it to the texture as being similar to the kolo noodle in Sarawak. I always like the ramen here since it opened several years ago but have not been back till very recently. I am happy to report that the ramen is still good, but the noodles could be better. It got soggier and soft the longer I left it in the soup, so maybe you need to eat the noodle asap type. The one slice of char siu that comes with the ramen is tender and melting soft. Add the fried garlic chips and you get an aromatic bowl of noodles. You need to add on the egg which is simply divine. It is still the best place to get a flavorful half boiled egg with a wobbly soft egg white with a barely cooked egg yolk which will ooze out. Yummy! Even though there are more ramen places with such egg around, somehow they don't seemed to get the timing right to get the perfect soft boiled egg. Another side dish which is to die for even though the portion size keeps reducing, making it quite dear to order now is the char siu. Somehow they managed to make it crispy on the edges and retain the tenderness in the meat. Squeeze the wedge of lemon over the char siu and then dip it in the chili (optional as eating it plain is good enough). It is just so delicious you will just want to gobble the whole thing up and not share with your dining companions.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This is my second favourite ramen joint, after Ippudo. I just like the tint of spice in the soup, the richness of the soup, as well as lots of green in the soup. Also, the addition dish of grilled char siew (Jap version) is delicious to the max. Make it for chao-tar please. The egg is constantly tasting good as well. Hence, I do not mind making my way to Central once in a while to have this ramen.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Love the bowl of crispy garlic that they leave at every table. Crisp and perfectly oil-free.If you are used to the richer tonkotsu broth, you would probably find this too light and bland. The broth here is from chicken and it doesn't have the milky pork one broth. The first time I ate it, I didn't like it. But now, I actually am a fan. It is lighter and less oily, and possibly made me less guilty slurping up the soup.I also Iike the gyoza here. Thin skin, and flavorful. Sprinkle lots of crisp garlic on top, and this is a winner.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I've tried the Ramen but I'm not keen on Ramen having chicken-based soup. Ramen and Pork-Based soup should always go togther!However on that particular weekend, I was feeling pretty full so I ordered a mini rice dish (the name beats me now, I guess I'm getting old!) topped with 2 thick slices of Tamago, onions, and a few slices of braised pork. My partner ordered the usual Ramen. I gave it another shot and tried the soup - ok, it's triple confirmed that Ramen should always come with Pork-Based Soup!I bet no one knows there's such a dish on the menu given that they are known for their Ramen.Tip: Ladies who do not want to over-eat during their lunch hour can stop by Marutama Ramen for this mini rice dish.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I'm a huge fan of pork based broth ramen so I was initially rather skeptical about Marutama's chicken based ramen.Nonethless, I warmed up to it as the broth was very flavorful. It is very different from a pork based broth, and I still think I prefer the latter, but chicken is not bad too. I do find it a tad too oily due to all the fat from the chicken skin though. I love that their egg has the runny yolk. That's my favourite part about eaten ramen! Lol. Definitely a good alternative to santouka if the wait there is too long!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: 3 years ago, this was my favorite ramen in the world. Now, it has changed big time. The flavor isn't t as good as it used to be. The ambiance is dark, the service though it fast, and for the spicy ramen, you can barely taste any spice! I hope they improve in the next couple of years.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: So delicious! Had their signature dish and it was amazing. The chicken was cooked to perfection and the broth was very savory indeed. I had never had ramen with seaweed with it, but it was great. I wish that for $12 it had come with an egg, but no worries I added one to it because ramen without the egg is no fun. 10/10 would come again.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Tried this Ramen outlet 4 years ago and it was the best. Yes was. Tried today..freaked out. The Ramen is actually maggie mee. Yes. It is horrible. Dont believe go try..and u will regret big time.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This was the first place ramen place that inducted me into the whole ramen craze that has hit town. It set the bar for ramen places that I have tried ever since and it still is my favourite. I like my noodles thin and soft, whereas certain other ramen joints serve pretty hard to chew noodles. As for the broth, I crave for it - but do take note that the ice water is placed next to you for good reason. While it hit home, my companion and I gulped down cups of water post-lunch as it left us pretty thirsty. That said, I would still drain the broth entirely. The tamago (extra $1.50) is done perfectly - soft on the inside but not so soft till it oozes out; you can still use chopsticks to pick it out to slowly savour it. One of the novelty factors here lies with their topping up of noodles policy. For the guys who have big appetites, if you've finished your noodles, be sure to leave some broth cus for $2, you can top up the exact same amount of noodles! Pretty worth it if you ask me.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Definitely more bumpin' than its counterpart at Liang Court. The place was totally full on a weekday night. (Reserve a table to avoid being seated at the squished tables for two.) Somehow I think the ramen is better here too. Add the egg! It's delicious.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Marutama is right on the top of my list of favourite restaurants that serve authentic Japanese cuisine. The ramen that they use is light and springy, and is slightly hard in texture so it doesn't soak up too much of the soup broth that it comes served in. Their portion is also exactly right for me; not too much where it goes to waste, but not too little where after I finish the noodles, there is still half a bowl of broth left. For the boyfriend, he does order the additional $2 worth of ramen if he's feeling peckish, so that is a good available option as well! The soup broth is my favourite part of the meal, it's thick and not too salty when coupled with the ramen. It comes clear even if you order the spicy version, because the spice is cooked within the soup, not added as a seasoning which I especially appreciate. But be warned since the chilli taste doesn't kick in until a good 5 large slurps or so. They also serve the most well cooked 'hot spring eggs', where they manage to serve eggs that are cooked on the outside but soft and melty in the yolk every single time I've dined there. Really good stuff! The ambience is also really nice and quiet, with a slightly dim vintage Japanese feel.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: My go-to place when I want to have no-frills, inexpensive ramen. They don't have a wide variety of ramen (they only have four) but whatever they have on the menu is good. I've tried them all except for the Ebi Ramen and so far I haven't been disappointed. My personal favourite though is the good ol' spicy ramen. Though not as spicy as I would like it to be, it's enough to satisfy my ramen cravings. For all their ramen dishes, you can choose whether you want it spicy or not.I haven't tried most of their side dishes but the gyoza is really nice so you might want to get that as a side dish to share. They also have free flow of water on each table which is a very good thing for someone like me who needs to drink a lot of water with her food.Overall, this is a worthy place to check out if you want fast and good tasting food without the frills (and price tag) of a full-fledged Japanese restaurant.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: 3.5*I enjoyed it. I had the spicy ramen, and they got the spicy just right. Spicy ramen sometimes doesn't have enough spice, or it gets so tongue numbing by the end (since its soupy). Didn't happen here for me, it builds up to just  a slight tingling. Brownie points for this. Of course, we all have different tolerances for spicy, and someone who doesn't order spicy ramen may well give this 3*.Like a previous reviewer mentioned, the first thing you'd notice is that the chicken soup base was undesirably thick, rather than light in texture/taste. It was also a bit saltier than I would have liked. But considering this is Singapore, that's not surprising. And while a soup is certainly important, it was not bad, and at least they got everything else right.It's $12 a bowl, but DO add the seasoned egg ($1.50?). Gosh, that was perfect. Cooked just nice, and the yolk was... just wow. I usually remove my yolk but I wished I had more of this. That was the highlight of my meal, and why I'm rounding off the 3.5* to a 4*! There's also seaweed topping (I found it a nice texture mix with the ramen) and meat, and the latter had just enough flavour. There wasn't much of it though :PLast, we were seated almost immediately on a weekday 12.30pm, but I heard it was relatively empty that day, and wait is usually 10-15min.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Been here a few times. The standard is okay. Not fanciful. Realised that the standard of the soup has been dropping over the past few months. But still a place to go for simple ramen.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Marutama Ramen branch is located on the third floor of Clark Quay Central Mall and its a popular lunch venue for office folks.Ambience - The interior is modeled after the Japanese izakaya, which is an establishment that serves as a casual place for after-work drinking and eating in Japan. The entire restaurant staff immediately welcome us with loud Japanese greetings. There are also many Japanese elements such as the numerous Japanese calligraphy paintings on the Japanese walls and the wooden furniture.Food - Marutama Ramen is known for its unique chicken soup base, the "Toripaitan Soup". This is a variation from the traditional soup bases of Shoyu ("soy sauce"), Miso, Shio ("salt") and Tonkotsu ("pork bone").Marutama Ramen - Thin Ramen noodles served in hot chicken broth with a piece of tender Char Siew (sliced roast pork). The char siew is tender and tastes decent, but not spectacular. Yummy chicken broth which goes well with the ramen noodles, savoury but not overly-rich.Katsuo Syouyu Ramen - Ramen with Shoyu soup base is slightly saltier than the Marutama Ramen. The soup base is quite flavourful and tasty but personally, I prefer the chicken soup base of Marutama Ramen.Overall, it is Yummy Ramen Noodles Served in Savoury Chicken Broth!The price is reasonable, and service is good and consistent as well. Marutama Ramen is definitely the place to go if you want to have a hearty bowl of yummy ramen noodles served in savoury chicken broth! Check out full reviews and photos at eatandtravelwithus.com/2…

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: 1. Marutama Ra-men/Karashi Ra-men, Chicken soup Ra-men with toppings- I had mine spicy. - The soup broth was really thick, flavorful and had a starchy feel to it (like porridge)... but somewhat oily. I would have preferred it if it was less oily. - The noodles were surprising thin (like angel hair pasta) not like the regular ramen but it was still pretty tasty. - The pork was good but they only gave 1 slice.Overall, I prefer Santouka at The Central. Service was quick. Note: I heard this place usually has a queue so you might have to make allowances for that but I was luck enough not to encounter one when I went last thursday (2pm).

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Also known as the 'basketball ramen" (because of its logo), Marutama is the kind of place you either love or don't. I'm somewhere in the middle. I have a specific preference for ramen, usually pork broth (they do chicken broth), and usually of the darker variety over the lighter types.If you like chicken broths, decent noodles and lighter types of ramen you will probably like this place more than I do.Don't get me wrong, it's quite nice, just not the type of ramen I like best. Of all the types they offer I think the one they have with groundnuts (aka, I think?) is the most interesting because it adds a nice depth to the otherwise rather plain soup.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Marutama, or that "basketball ramen place" as my friends and I call it, has always been a back-up plan for when Santouka has a long waiting list. But don't be surprised to see a long line outside this joint as well 'cause they do have quite a following. Personally I've found that they lack consistency when it comes to the broth and noodles. First time's a charm; my subsequent visits featured weak broth and soggy noodles. I don't think many people know but there's a small private space that can seat 8-10 comfortable. I'm not sure if they open it up for regular seating but if that's what you're looking for, be sure to call ahead and make a reservation.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: While the noodles have a good texture and the egg is done perfectly, the soup base is only so-so in my opinion. I had the aka-men which was definitely different from the ramen you usually get outside but felt far too thick and oily for my liking. On the plus side, it was fragrant and spicy for those who like or don't mind thick broths. My friends also got the vegetable ramen which they didn't like as even the soup base tasted strongly of vegetables. Cha-shu is an additional $4 and egg is an additional $1.50 which adds up to about $25 per person with service charge. I think this is rather pricey, and I would probably go to another ramen place next time as there is no lack of ramen places around Clarke Quay for the same or cheaper prices.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I'm really going to say "meh" to this one. Tasty chasyu and egg, and the noodles certainly have enough bite (because they ask for done-ness?), but the soup? That's the big "meh". It's a chicken-based broth instead of the richer tonkotsu version, and perhaps that's why I'm not as wowed. It kinda feels like a little flavour is lacking.One of the interest broth choices had nuts though; called the Aka-men, it's got seven kinds of nuts crushed and added into the stock, so there's that hint of nuttiness, but that's kinda it.Sorry folks, it's one in a laundry list of stores I'd try once, and just once.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: If you are looking for a relatively cheap ramen store , this is one store that you should visit. Many may refer it to basket ball ramen due to its logo. They serve authentic ramen which the soup based is usually chicken based. However I do find it quite salty. The noodle and meat are good but lacks the wow factor. However if you are looking for a place to chill, this is not a great place to visit as the waitress and waiter will tend to clear your plates at the instant you finish your food. Signalling to you that alright please make way for the next customer.One of the plus point is the tamago egg that is cooked pretty well. The Yolk is presented in a semi liquid form , giving a very rich texture.As I mentioned, not a fantastic place but definitely a place for a quick ramen fix.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: One of my favorite ramen places. Yes, the broth is chicken-based and not the usual pork-based. That is one of the reasons I love it, it's still as flavorful and a good change from the usual pork based ones. The menu is simple. You pick a ramen off a limited list. Wait for your order and ta-da. Ramen. The noodles is one of the other reasons I keep coming back for more, it's done very al-dente and the noodles are like your "you mian", thinner strands.The tamago are done to perfection. The yolk soft and savory. I usually have two. They are quite generous with their portions in my opinion. I normally go with the spicy version. There are two other branches, one in Liang Court and the other in Suntec City. Do check them out if you want something different from your ramen.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Alot of people have been raving about this place ever since it opened but I wasn't blown away by it when I tried it. Maybe people oversold it abit too much, I dunno, but its was alright.I went with my girlfriend and we ordered both the normal and spicy ramen. I liked the spicy one abit more but I wasnt totally satisfied. After going through two servings of noodles, I was full but I felt incomplete :/My girlfriend liked it more than I did though. I did however, enjoy the eggs. Very well cooked.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-90 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I've been eating Marutama Ramen ever since it opened and it's one of my favorites. Chicken soup base isn't all that common and even for those that offer it, Marutama does it the best. The spicy soup base is a must have for me. I like that even though it's spicy it doesn't take away the flavor the way hot miso paste does when you try to order spicy versions of tonkotsu ramen at some places. The chashu is yumm and the seasoned egg with its soft center is divine. The yaki charsiu, listen up people, is a MUST ORDER. Oh Em Gee the melt-in-your-mouth goodness. I know it's so wrong but I can't help but savor the fat....

address: 32 New Market Road #02-18 to #02-19, People's Park Complex Food Center Singapore 050032 Singapore
comment: Which is one particular food that makes you feel emotionally attached to? It may not be synonymous with your last meal but a dish that draws you into having. I have a few and most if not all, are humble & carb-laden. Today, do not expect surprises as you probably guess it right. A connection to the past and brings back fond memories of my late grandfather - his favorite Dim Sum, Char Siew Pau (Chinese bun filled with roasted pork).Originating from the Guangdong province of China (my grandfather was from China), these Chinese buns were made from milled rice flour, stuffed with diced BBQ pork tenderloin. They are one of the popular dim sum snacks these days and the nostalgic take-away versions are from Tiong Bahru Pau and Teck Kee Tanglin Pau. The buns are mostly steamed  but there are baked alternatives. I am accustomed to the steamed ones since young.The sizable chicken bun is always so gratifying. Without a trace of stickiness on the roof of your hard palate, the skin was marvelously soft and not overly thick. You will find chunks of fresh chicken meat with a touch of ginger, soy sauce and a bit of Chinese rice wine. Nope, no egg was stuffed in there unlike other places where Big steamed buns do. Without that extra calories, I could eat them with ease.The memories of my grandfather starts flowing when the stall-holder pickup that tongue-scalding BBQ buns from the steam tray. It was a complete solace. The act of unfolding the skin to reveal the glazed ingredients was equally heart throbbing. With the roasted pork so well browned and glossy looking, I couldn't wait any longer to taste the sweet oyster seasoning in the meat. The candied mixture add so much flavor to the tender pork, every time with the right consistency. Watching the laving juices wetting my fingers and dripping down my wrist is visually appealing. Did you feel the joy? I will never stop at the savory even though the sweet ones seem to attract the older crowd more. My grandfather was one of the avid fan of the bean-paste filled buns. The shiny smooth white exterior hides a pool of creamy red bean paste. For a less sugary variation, go for the lotus paste which came with robust lotus seeds flavor that was flowy as well. It was mind rupturing each time I sank my teeth into the fluffy bun to penetrate the fillings. Truly unimaginable.

This Indian shop stands on its own and there are a few things I like about it.1) Yummy biryani2) Killer fried chicken3) a few choices of not the oiliest vegetables4) affordable5) good teh tarik6) strong fans7) pleasant service8) provides tissue at the cashier'sItems 3, 4, 6 and 7 are why it wins out over the always crowded Shah Alam nearby. I like the biryani rice which is cooked in the dum style. Ie it's lightly fragrant and spiced and not flavoured from having poured curry gravy over it. If it wasn't so unhealthy I would come more often but even when I've eaten elsewhere, I often stop here for a teh tarik!

I added this business to Yelp so I guess I might as well go ahead and review.They do a nice sizeable latte Dimbulah Select (single shot) for $4.70. I'll go for that rather than the standard latte (double shot) which is $5.50 as it's my second coffee of the day by then and heck coffee is already expensive as it is. Decent crema and art, very pleasant staff although when I ordered beans to be ground for my friend who doesn't have a grinder, they said I would have to collect the next morning. Then I went in the morning and it wasn't ready..Haven't tried their food but saw people eating plates or pasta that had healthy portions. I've also tried their piccolo ($4.20) a few times and that's always been a very solid effort.Bit unusual, you order at the counter and they serve you at the table. No wifi sadly although they provide...actual newspapers (GASP!!). Tables currently very spaced out, it's new tho..if they get more crowded it would be good if they had more seats. Nice solid wooden tables, nice touch.Definitely one of the better coffees in the area, without the crowds. Please leave me a seat ;)

Very cosy place.. serve decent coffee.. quite nice..  not bad... try their latte single shot.. slightly stronger and the milk is really creamy and frothy... very smiley people at the counter too. great coffee place to start ur day

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-53 Singapore 059817 Singapore
