comment: Great Croissants. Great price. Swissbake has large cabinets housing a range of baked that are both savory and sweet. Had a Cappacino: just okay.Bonus: They have pecan pie.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-53 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Egg and mayo croissant was delicious! The espresso was on par with other similar bakeries. There was also a bird flying around outside the cafe. Great spot.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-53 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Bakery cafe inside the Central shopping centre with shelves full of delicious looking bakings. Really nice fresh baked breakfast croissants with scrambled eggs and other fillings of your choice. They also serve fresh juices. The atmosphere is a bit boring since it's inside the mall but it opens early (8am) and is centrally located at Clarke quay.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-53 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Breakfast - Burich Muesli - It's awesome! - Their baked croissants are awesome too. Lunch- I love their pumpkin soup (lunch menu). It comes with a serving of 2 slices of wholemeal bread :) butter and strawberry jam. The bread was perfectly toasted :) - I cannot say the same for their beef goulash though - it's definitely not beef goulash (not in any shape or form like the ones I had in Eastern Europe... except for many a few cubes of beef). This dish should be re-labelled: Beef stew. It wasn't horrible but neither was it that good. Will not be ordering this again because it is certainly not Beef Goulash!  Nice refreshing change from subway ( a tad bit pricer but well worth it)

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-53 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This is becoming a lunch staple.New joint that just opened a month ago, and giving the neighboring subway a run for their money.Fresh bread baked in house, pastries, cakes and other baked goods!There is even a counter for customized sandwiches where u get to choose from a variety of bread and ingredients.Free iced water and it all comes with great service too! Woohoo!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-53 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I had a great Smoked Salmon sandwich here today. It had lovely grainy bread, generous portion size and good fresh ingredients. The location is good, but the atmosphere is a bit "fast food", with table clearing pretty slack. Good food though, thanks.

Have been here 3-4 times now, and have enjoyed it each time. Prices tip closer to the high end, but it's worth the occasional visit and dining experience. Ingredients are fresh, dishes are well prepared, and the service is excellent. There's also a theatrical element to the experience, as ingredients are openly displayed while chefs prepare them in front of you. If you drink, then they have a great sake program along with a limited variety of wines and beers. Dinner sets are available ($88 // $135 // $188), and can be coupled with a la carte items. I'd recommend this place for dates, small groups, and for business. Not a lot of robataya setups in Singapore, so it's a nice change of pace. Order the $88 dinner set, then add a few dishes to share with your date/group.

Tamashii used to be THE place to go for value set lunches, but prices have gone up so the one main draw for lunch has faded slightly. Food isn't bad by any means, but dinner is (in my opinion) pretty pricey for the quality/quantity, and lunch is just 'aiight'. Nothing to shout about, but I wouldn't mind stepping in if I was in the area and had a strong craving for Japanese.

Middling experience. The thing is that my view is biased by an excellent robataya experience in Japan, which was a feast for the senses - sounds of the chefs shouting orders, waiters echoing them, baskets bursting with great produce, smells of cooking. This was a rather underwhelming experience - reserved chefs, restrained flavours, hollow room. Fairly good produce. The grilled fish was under cooked unfortunately. Worth the price? Nope.Would I return? Nope.Worth it for someone who hasn't been to a robataya to come? Uncertain. It's just a competent, though unexemplary, Japanese place (with above average cost) where they serve you food on paddles. Watch a YouTube video on a real robataya before you decide.

Affordable Japanese Omakase meals are on the rise in Singapore with the most famous being Teppei, with their insanely long waitlist. The other new kid on the block is Tamashii Robataya, which i heard great reviews about and so i went with high expectations, thinking it would blow me away like Teppei.Dinner sets are priced at $88, $128 and $168. There's also the a la carte and omakase option. We decided to try the $128 (7 course) and $168 (8 course) dinner. The difference is in the quality of ingredients and for the 8 course, there's uni with caviar and the signature Wagyu Donburi.Appetizers. My favorite was the tofu with century egg sauce and tobiko roe.Yaki Yasai Moriwase. Grilled assorted seasonable vegetable. I'm becoming a fan of roasted onions and they are best paired with a umami miso paste.The Plat de résistance has to be the Wagyu Donburi! A well marbled buttery Saga A4 beef striploin sits on top a fragrant marinated short-grain rice. Mix all that runny onsen egg with truffle oil and shaved black truffles in and every mouth will send you to beef heaven. Certainly the best dish of the night. Goes for $55 a bowl if you order it a la carte. The Kashira Donburi, a grilled black pig pork cheeks paled in comparison to the Wagyu Donburi. The pork was too bland for my liking. Both soups were bland. I found it a waste to use tuna belly in a soup. The clam soup from the $128 menu was just bleargh. Was i impressed by the food served at Tamashii Robataya? Frankly i was hoping to be blown away but sadly it was underwhelming. I may go back for the Wagyu Donburi but that's about that. If you'd like to try, I'd say go for their lunch sets. It's priced in the $30 range.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #02-82/83 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Tucked In the corner inside the clark quay central mall, this is a nice little thai restaurant. I have come here multiple times and the food has been hit or miss. Some items that I really liked have been Sea Bass, green curry, pandan chicken, minced meat etc.Tom Yum soup is Ok. Paad See Ew was pretty average with almost no flavor or spices. Service is good.They give you the crackers and wet tissue on your table and charge you if you use any of those. Price is on an expensive side but you get a nice view of the river and clark quay across the river.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #02-82/83 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Horrible Customer Service! I got chicken noodle soup from them the day before and it tasted amazing so I decided to go back the next day and get more. They ended up giving me something completely different when I went back to tell them this isn't the same soup from yesterday they looked at me like I was crazy. When I asked can I get my money back or at least do something else for me they said no and made it seem like ME THE CUSTOMER is crazy... ummmm  NEVER AGAIN!!!

address: 80 Raffles Place #01-20, UOB Plaza 2 Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: I wish this was closer to my work!!! Instead I have to trek for 15-mins in the heat, and given its popularity, seating is far from guaranteed...So who knows how long a lunch could take...But logistics aside, I love the concept of customised salads and the Salad Shop has so many fresh and tasty ingredients, including a load of dressings to choose from. The soup is decent and good value too (with slices of bread to help yourself to). The poached chicken is a great option as a salad component as well as the boiled eggs. I'm also a sucker for pine nuts and beetroot. If you want to carbo load, choose pasta or couscous as your salad base. Service is friendly and efficient - almost too efficient as securing a seat can take longer. That's my only reason for 4 stars... more seating required!! Are outside tables an option? Oh and they only take cash... coming from cashless NZ where you pay card for a 50cent transaction... this is tough for me to remember!

address: 80 Raffles Place #01-20, UOB Plaza 2 Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: This place used to be one of my most favorite salad places between 2010 and 2015. I had a salad here after 2 years and this place has deteriorated :( they still have their quirky names for the salad sizes but the dressings aren't great. They used to have an amazing chill oil dressing which has been removed and replaced by Siracha. The salad wasn't mixed in properly and their baked falafel tasted like soft paper. I used to be a fan of this place and now I am very disappointed at what happens to salad places once they become famous. The mangonana smoothie was the only saving grace!

address: 80 Raffles Place #01-20, UOB Plaza 2 Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: Rabbit, Zebra, and Elephant sized salads, with ingredients called 'feeds'.The Salad Shop definitely tries to keep things cute and lighthearted, but there is NOTHING cute about the queue in here on most days. The queue moves at a fair enough pace I suppose, but sometimes it's actually almost physically intimidating to walk into that dense a crowd.That all said though, it's easy to see why there's such a long queue. The ingredients here are fresh, and I love the degree of customisation. I'm a big fan of bacon bits and blue cheese dressing, avocado and baby spinach leaves. For a heavier salad, throw in some baby potatoes and roasted pumpkin, and top it all off with raisins for a little sweetness.Those options not to your liking? There's also celery, mushrooms, three-bean mix, almond flakes, pasta, cous cous, capers, gherkins, feta, and that's just a quarter the main feeds! You pick 6 main feeds for a rabbit size ($8), add two supplementary feeds and it becomes a zebra size ($10). Insider tip? The poached chicken is the only "meat" that's NOT a Prime feed, so if you're saving on cash and want meat, that's your best bet. The Salad Shop also offers a variety of homemade dressings, and every one that I've tried has been absolutely awesome. Tip: the order process goes like this, 1) pick up an order chit near the entrance, tick off the 'feeds' you want and remember to mark if you're dining in or out in the top left hand corner. 2) head over to the corner and 'place your order' before... 3) paying at the counter underneath the menu boardJust saying this because the first time I went there I had no idea how things worked. :(

address: 80 Raffles Place #01-20, UOB Plaza 2 Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: Fresh and tasty salad customized to your preference. Comes in cute rabbit, zebra sizes. Perfect for vegetarians who have carnivore friends (there are meat options and the duck was yummy!) Be warned of the afternoon crowds, but the line moves fast!

address: 80 Raffles Place #01-20, UOB Plaza 2 Singapore 048624 Singapore
comment: Good place for a tasty salad - they are made to order with lots of options that you choose.  By definition, should be just the way you like it.  There is always a line at lunch - but it moves very quickly.  There is hardly any seating - and even though this is a clean spot with marble floors, the environment is nil because of all of the people hovering around waiting for their food.  So I would say this is really a "take out" kind of place.  My main gripe and why I don't come here very often is that their portions are minuscule, even if you pony up for the "elephant" size meal (which I think is $12 to start and then additional for toppings).  I'm not a particularly large person, so I don't understand how a "real sized" person could fill up on their portions.  Maybe others do what I always end up doing when I come here, which is get a huge supplementary snack in the afternoon, which ends up defeating the purpose of having had a healthy salad lunch.  I think that they should include more lettuce, especially in their larger sized salads.  Or maybe (here's a marketing idea) have another sized portion called, "pig," for oinkers like me... :)

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #01-27 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Probably the best churros in Singapore because I've been looking for good churros for so long! I remember having La Lola in Manila and it was good and so popular. This place just opened and it was empty!And it's unfortunate that they coat the churros in regular sugar and not cinnamon sugar. Dips are $3! Kind of pricey for the churros and dips. And they definitely need to work on service. There were 4 servers at the counter and I had to get their attention to order and they all just kind of looked at eachother. Need to work on quite a few things if this place wants to stay in business...

Again, torn between 3 and 4 stars. This place is a little on the pricey side, but the uni temaki was one of the best I've had in Singapore. The uni was pretty top grade, sweet and delicious. The onigiri was pretty good, the mackerel with miso was a little salty for my liking, but I like the variety of the dishes and what they have to offer. The ikura here is surprisingly good too, although the salmon belly did not impress me much. Didn't try the amaebi with foiegras, but will try it next time if I drop by again.

As shown by the drinks list, this restaurant aspires to be higher-end than it is. With increasing competition, it is just a me-too Japanese eatery in the CBD. The food is not bad, but nothing to write home about or remember, and ingredients are not necessarily the best.

I came by this branch for breakfast. I guess I got lucky cause I usually miss their breakfast timeslot. I ordered the McMuffin set and their McMuffin is what sets them apart from other fast food outlets.. delicious melt-in your mouth taste with their 'trademark' hashbrowns as well with a cup of tea which is free flow for breakfast. For less than $6 it's worth it and it fills you up with enough carbs to survive the day.
Great sandwiches and friendly staff. They also have fresh juices and breakfast. Worth a try if you are looking for a decent sandwich in the Chinatown area.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street The Central B1-20/24 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Menu includes mini hotpot, mini claypot dishes, bak ku teh, chicken/char siew/roast pork rice and noodles as well as double-boiled soups. All under one roof. Food is decent nothing spectacular. Great if you are looking to lunch with colleagues who all want something different. Ordering and payment is done in one line, and you pick up on either of two lines depending on what you ordered. A relatively new spot, it is a little disorganized right now and they sometimes miss your order. So keep your ears peeled for your number. Better if you can understand mandarin as the numbers are mostly announced in Chinese.

address: 20 Cross Street #01-28/30 China Square Central Singapore 048422 Singapore
comment: good japanese chain outlet at the top of the raffles city shopping mall. sushi tei is one of our favourite places - our regular hangout for decently reliable food at reasonable prices, and this was the first time we made it to the raffles city branch. this outlet isn't anything particularly special, but we made quite a few good choices on the menu this time (instead of sticking to our regular orders) and I'd like to share. just because I'm nice.to be sure, this outlet isn't the best one (the paragon one is). the back (where we were seated) is a rather cramped, darkish rectangle of mutliple booths for two. it felt a little like office cubicles actually, so I wouldn't say this is any place to bring a date - but for a casual dinner it did us pretty well. it also helped that they had stationed staff around so we didn't need to work too hard to get their attention.but that don't matter - because we had good food on the table (which means that the kitchens were well up to par - rather impressive for the crowd they were dealing with). the aburi salmon roll was fantastic - the salmon was generously silky and fatty, with a thin flamed outside with some char. the kaki mentai roll - or fried oyster in rice, topped with cod-roe mayonnaise - was also another discovery. I think it was the textural contrast of crispy batter + soft oyster + creamy mayo that worked. there was far too much mayonnaise on it though - but we easily schmeared it away.the kagoshima katsu toji was tender and moist and not-too-fatty - delicious; this was part of their seasonal menu (that I think will be available for a month more).we rounded up the meal with a grilled salmon head - this went down easily enough with a big helping of grated radish and lemon. so - a good dinner, made cheaper by a discount as members and vouchers (a result of loyal patronage) - we left both full and happy.

address: 20 Cross Street #01-28/30 China Square Central Singapore 048422 Singapore
comment: Popular local sushi chain that always has a long line. Food and service were both mediocre thoughThis place is popular! We waited 30+ minutes for a table for four on a holiday weekday, and the restaurant was full through our entire meal. The menu is huge! Sushi Tei serves sushi, donburi, katsu, shabu shabu, and tempura galore. Unfortunately, that meant no dish was executed very well. My only recommendation would be the pork belly donburi - the pork belly was thinly sliced and well-flavored. Overall, would not come back and would not recommend this restaurant.

address: 20 Cross Street #01-28/30 China Square Central Singapore 048422 Singapore
comment: Probably a more lively chain of restaurant in the CBD neighbourhood on a weekend evening. Quite a crowd here considering how quiet the surrounding is! Their menu extends a wide variety of selections which may get customers confused wondering what's the difference between many of the dishes as pictures look all alike. But with the array of selections, U're bound to find something that suits u! Seared Salmon belly sushi is a must try, the best of all sushis in my opinion. Their negitoro sushi is a little too smashed up but it's how I like it so all's good. When ordering your sushi, make sure they're not taken off the conveyor belt as had experience eating dry and hardened sushi from it (6 pc salmon sesame sushi). Asked for a change as it wasn't really pleasant and the chef looked at us in disgust haha. After the change, it was slightly better, still a little hard but edible! Here's my 'list of ALWAYS ORDER' dish: - sashimi salad (sushitei dressing!) - love this- Tako wasabi - I'm addicted - salmon yam - negitoro sushi - salmon belly sushi - must try here- dobinmushi (it's a kinda tea cup soup)As for the sashimi, wouldn't say it's really that  'fresh', neither is it not fresh. There are just some dishes here that makes me crave for sushi Tei so much. And those are the ones listed above! Considering the affordable pricing here at sushi Tei, it's my monthly-to-go Japanese restaurant offering interesting yet average selections tweaked according to Singaporeans' taste buds!

address: 20 Cross Street #01-28/30 China Square Central Singapore 048422 Singapore
comment: i must say i'm not a fan of conveyor belt sushi.it's for instant gratification but rarely will the expensive stuff go round and round.only in japan do the kaiten sushi joints have very strict standards.as they will constantly throw out sushi plates that will still be going around the belt in regular SG joints.so i mostly order ala carte here.i always have their kani avocado salad with sushi tei dressing which is served on the side.crunchy lettuce, soft avocado and sweet kani sticks.the dressing is a nice tangy sweet mixture.sashimi is value for money and decent at $58.you get uni, toro, kanpachi and salmon.freshly well fried amaebi karaage was enjoyable.shirasu and ika age was tempura style battered ladies fingers and cuttlefish.interesting gooey combo.taraba shio yaki was way too dry and on the salty side.softshell crab temaki was ok.salmon belly misoshiru is another must order for me.heartwarming and belly good!jo una ju was second most expensive at $26.but a real disappointment.you can tell straightaway that they use cheap, probably product of china, eel.and when you sink that first bite you will struggle to swallow the obviously bony fillet of eel. the rice and sauce is decent though.they can be really crowded here.service is quick and efficient.

address: 20 Cross Street #01-28/30 China Square Central Singapore 048422 Singapore
comment: This is a lunch Sushi Tei as its located in the middle of the CBD area. I feel that somehow the food here is lacking in quality compared to the other outlets I've tried, perhaps they prepare the meals a bit too fast as they know people who dine here are rushed for time vis-a-vis those outlets where people mainly go for dinner.For a quick lunch, I'd suggest pairing one of the bento meals - either the chicken / pork katsu don or una tama don with a cawanmushi.

address: B1 One Raffles Place Singapore Singapore
comment: Bread is the first thing I think of when it comes to Paris Baguette Cafe so I was quite surprised to learn that it has launched 4 new bing su. Or maybe it isn't such a surprise since Paris Baguette is still a Korean franchise. The Matcha Bingsu ($12), which is a sizeable good-for-sharing portion loaded generously with sweet red beans, turned out to be an enjoyable one. The flakes might not be as fine as Oma Spoon but this is less sweet and there is enough red beans to last till the very end.On the other hand, the cakes did not fare as well as the Bingsu. The Foret Noire lacked the necessary moisture and intensity of cacao notes, making it quite an unpalatable and expensive cake at $7.50. Fortunately, the Double Fromage, a construction of baked cheesecake layered with cheese mousse, was the saving grace. Some say there is a sense of de ja vu as it resembled Le Tao's version. For the looks, maybe. But for the taste, this has a long way to go.

Hachi, quite simply is upscale Japanese.  From the minute that you walk into reception your impression that you're in a neighborhood sushi joint starts to evaporate rapidly.  The evaporation is only accelerated as you are ushered past glass cases housing bottles of Hibiki.  All this for me conspired to distract me from the food which was the truly arresting part of my index visit to Hachi.I brought family which allowed us all to sample more of the menu and give everybody a more holistic impression of Hachi the kitchen, and less of Hachi the restaurant.  Tangential rant #1:  I'm immune to pine, mood lighting, and expensive ceramics.  I let my taste and smell make my mind up for me when it comes to food.  I'll allow points for presentation, because we start tasting with our eyes, but everything else should matter very little.  My point is that if ambience mattered less, then putting on this entire show would be all about devoting all the resources to making sure that culinary skill, quality ingredients, and respect for Momma Earth take center stage.The chirashi was a neatly packaged peek into the soul of Hachi.  This wonderfully put together bowl highlighted an understanding of wa shoku, respect for the ingredient, experience in managing the ingredient, and masterful restraint in putting just the right amount of the sea's bounty on display for that bowl to be satisfying without being ostentatious.Other dishes demonstrated the same expertise and mastery, and notable mentions were the charcoal grilled cod (seasonal), and the negitoro don which was a bowl decadently overflowing with minced tuna, ikura caviar, and uni.  Yes, Hachi is upscale, and the menus reflect upscale Japanese in crazy rich Singapore, but put that all that distracting nonsense aside, and you'll find a temple in which you can meditate on just how awesome nature's bounty is, and how little time we actually spend appreciating it.

I had really high hopes for Hachi. Honestly I did. And while I do feel that the food at Hachi is definitely worth 3 stars, the entire dining experience, the price, service, the evening was best summed up as "Meh". I asked my date to pick between "Meh/Average/Good" and she too summed it up as Meh.So just to be clear. The food here is THREE STARS. 3*s. The overall experience? Meh (2 stars)I found the setup of the restaurant a little odd, the counter isn't really ideal for people to sit and interact with the chefs, there's a height differential that makes it a bit awkward, and moreover a good part of the counter is used as a clearing station for dirty dishes. Personally I always eye the counter when I expect a Omakase experience, I think I've been conditioned to expect the counter experience to be more personalable. Before we begun, the waitress asked us if we had any dining restrictions... and mentioned oysters. Now I generally really don't like oysters. In all my oyster experiences, I've only not gagged once, so with a bit of apprehension I said I'd have the oyster, raw, just to see how it'd go. My date said that she'd eat anything just "no wasabi".And so we begun. The first course was a delicate green bean... curd/mousse in dashi gel with salmon roe. Salty, a little sweet from the pea, it was interesting and quite tasty. The platter of four starters was decent as well, my date liked it more than I did. We then had a scallop, partially seared, wrapped in bacon, served on sweetcorn. I didn't get this dish at all. The scallops were sweet, fresh, and actually quite delicate. They were quite overwhelmed by the bacon. The sweetcorn? Similar flavour profile to the scallops, and while a nice contrast in texture, seemed an odd addition. The assorted sashimi platter was fresh, there was a good variety with mackeral, sea bream, flounder, and yellowtail... BUT. The wasabi wasn't fresh, and okay, I don't always expect fresh wasabi, I realise it's kind of an indulgence... AND the soy sauce tasted cheap. I can't explain this to you really. I've never, ever noticed soy sauce "not meeting my expectations", but last night, at Hachi, I did. I asked my date if it was only me, and she said it wasn't as fragrant as she expected. Now, $120 isn't a lot of money for a multi-course omakasa, but the little things. The little things need to right for the entire dining experience to be awesome. We then had a bamboo shoot dobin mushi (I LOVE dobin mushi and this one was average), followed by the highlight of the evening, the oyster. It was fresh, sweet, succulent, not at all chewy, and served with spring onions and ponzu sauce. Delicious. The next course was Tempura.... alright. One of the items was a little heavy and a touch oily, but again, not bad, just not amazing. What WAS "bad" was that the wait staff had to ask us (and the table next to us) numerous times "what course" we were at. Like, they were just randomly throwing out dishes and couldn't keep track. I say randomly, because we noticed that the table next to us received courses in a different order... and almost had their oysters forgotten.After that it was sushi. Now remember what my date said about wasabi? You guessed it. Forgotten. They were quick and willing to change it, and apologetic, but I mean. If you're asking about dietary restrictions, TAKE NOTE OF THEM. They also didn't bother to explain what fish was on the sushi, so I can't tell you much about it. The seared Wagyu beef was a little on the cold side, barely room temperature, which was odd because the vegetables it was served with were nice and hot, likely fresh off the teppan. For some reason, though every other table received their miso soup and rice with a side bowl of pickles, we didn't get any pickles (which we love, so it matters ok?). There were also momotaro tomatoes as an earlier course... but I found theirs a little odd tasting. I think they're marinated in something, and I didn't like it much.The miso soup is worth mentioning though. The use of onions gave the soup a more complex flavour, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. Dessert? Black sesame ice cream that was... too sweet and not really "sesame-y" enough. The sesame flavour was a... lacking, and instead it had more of a creamy sweetness. Not... bad, but I've definitely had much much better black sesame ice cream.And there it all is. Food that was, in parts, brilliant, interesting, or top-notch, while in other parts, mediocre, uninspired, or sloppy. Service, for most of the evening was friendly, earnest, and jovial... but rather inept. They felt scattered and a little directionless, and maybe needed a good floor manager to bring everything together.For the now though, I'm give Hachi 2 stars with a heavy heart. They're obviously trying to bring the omakase experience to a slightly more affordable level... but unless someone else tells me that my experience was unusual and an outlier, I'm unlikely to go back.

An omakase menu basically signals to the chef: I'm hungry, hit me with your best shot!  Luckily, Hachi delivered on the food, but fell short on its service.We tried this restaurant after a long search for tasty Japanese cuisine at a reasonable price (no Miz or Sushi-Tei please!)  Unfortunately, this restaurant started from a 4 star rating for me because we were treated rudely within the first 10 minutes. The waiter (who turned out to be the manager) rushed us to our seats, didn't know the fish included in the sashimi special ("It is just the fresh fish.  I don't know, it changes."), and didn't tell us the first two dishes of our omakase.  This is the FIRST time I have ever had omakase and had no idea what I am eating.  I would have completely blown up at him had another waitress not taken over.  She was cordial and actually informed me about what I was eating.The food:The dishes here were light, delicate, and well balanced.  The fish broth for tofu was rich and flavorful while the wagyu beef was well cooked and seasoned well.  I enjoyed the freshness of the raw oyster and sushi as well as the subtle flavors in the rice.  The standard sesame ice cream was fine.So would I go back for 4 star food and 2 star service?  Maybe.  But Hachi really needs to train/get rid of the manager and step up its service.  Once it does that, it could be a solid, go to Japanese restaurant in Singapore.

address: 133 New Bridge Road #02-36 Chinatown Point Singapore 059413 Singapore
comment: Small portions, but good food. We had a party of 5 arrive to eat here and ordered a little bit of this and a little bit of that. The food itself was good, but the portions for just about everything was tiny. I was expecting a lot more overall. Would I come back? Probably not. There are a lot of places to eat here and I'm sure I can find better food with better servings elsewhere.

address: 133 New Bridge Road #02-36 Chinatown Point Singapore 059413 Singapore
comment: HOME OF PETTY PEKING DUCK HUSTLERS!Came here to have Peking Duck (on 65% off promo). Ordered the whole duck, plus ordered Duck Fried Rice as the second dish. Duck arrived, shown to us, and taken somewhere else for its skin to be sliced. Served a plate of duck skins, while the rest of the skins are still being sliced (Note: I personally saw with my own eyes that they were slicing more skins from our duck). The subsequent plate of skins never came. When questioned, they said they already served the skin of the whole duck for us. Never in my life have I ordered a WHOLE Peking Duck that yields only one small plate of skin. Then came the Duck Fried Rice that was supposed to be cooked using the meat from the Peking Duck. Never in my life have I ordered a Duck Fried Rice with so few duck meat. When questioned, they said they already served the whole duck.Switched to angry-mode and started to make some noises. Only then, they told me that they normally serve Duck Fried Rice using only the breast meat. I asked what do they do with the meat from the thighs and drums? They told me they just throw them away. I'm surprised I didn't respond with a: what-the-f**k?!It is very obvious that these people are trying to serve less-than-whole ducks to customers who are paying for whole ducks. They even did a mini-drama in front angry-me where one tried to explain to another in Mandarin what I was complaining about, putting up shocked-faces and all. They did eventually serve us a plate of the supposedly-thrown drums and thighs.Oh, if you're wondering why I had the word "petty" in the title of this review, not a single person served me tea after I complained.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Rd #01-58/59, Clarke Quay Central 059817 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: When I get the craving for some homey Vietnamese food that I'm used to getting from the Bay Area , I come to Saigon baguette. It's no frills, but they get the simple things right. From the rice plates with the omelette , and flavorful grilled pork and chicken, it really hits the spot for me everytime. Of course this being Singapore, it's pricier than I'm used to but who cares.I only come here to get my rice plate fix, I've yet to try the pho or banh mi...but I think just out of principle I'm not sure I could pay for those two dishes for more than $5 jeheh.But anyway, I'll keep coming here , it does the job for me and service is always pleasant.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Rd #01-58/59, Clarke Quay Central 059817 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Bad Bahn mi.  Most people seem to be enjoying the pho and the rice paper rolls looked decent.  Don't go here for the baguette.

rest_name: Hong Ji - Pig organs soup & Satay BeeHoon
address: 9 Raffles Place Republic Plaza Singapore 048619 Singapore
comment: I am always here for the Satay BeeHoon.Lots of customers also ask for the Satay BeeHoon.Well balanced satay flavour, good amount of ingredients, decent BeeHoon, pork and heart slices plus beansprouts and kangkong keeps me coming back.

address: Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-20 Singapore Singapore
comment: So we were here for some post workout grub, healthy and yet decadent if you get my drift. Vivo's a pretty spacious establishment as compared to the other basement shops, and that perhaps explains why it always looks a bit forlorn. It's a typical western menu slanted towards baked stuff (pizza and baked rice) and fried stuff. Sadly, it's all rather forgettable and strangely reminiscent of Swensen's.

address: 30 Raffles Place #01-31 Chevron House Singapore 048622 Singapore
comment: This is a nice café with a very inviting décor located in Market Street. However, to be honest, it is a little hard to find this place even though it is right in the middle of Raffles Place. It's behind the M1 shop at Caltex House.Dimbulah prides itself on bringing fine Australian coffee from the plantation straight to the consumer, and it shows: the coffee here is simply mindblowing. They have a breakfast menu as well as a lunch menu. They also have cakes, tarts and muffins on display. However, it seems that most people were there for the coffee.My friend had a triple deck roast chicken sandwich and a chicken pie. The chicken sandwich was nothing special, just three slices of wholemeal sandwich bread with roast chicken and the usual garnishing. The chicken pie was not bad. I had a tuna baguette which was also very normal, so food-wise, it's really not impressive. As I've mentioned though, the  coffee was really good. It's not harsh and too acidic, and there is kind of an underlying richness which gives the coffee texture and body. Overall, this is a great place to chill. Recommended!

address: 30 Raffles Place #01-31 Chevron House Singapore 048622 Singapore
comment: Up there on my list of favourite cafes in the CBD - its so conveniently located, just an escalator and a few steps away from Raffles Place MRT. What better place to meet a friend for coffee and breakfast before starting your day?Its pleasantly quiet in the mornings before 9am, but a line will slowly form as it creeps closer to 9 for takeaway coffees.The food I must admit is very average, but this is a coffee joint more than anything else, and they serve excellent coffee which is why I think it is still deserving of a full 5 stars. The baristas here have certainly been trained well, with the coffee being consistent in its delivery - at the perfect temperature, not lukewarm or burnt. What impressed me most though was the service here.  I came with a colleague one morning but as we were running late we only had about 10 minutes to sit down with our coffees after ordering, which wasn't enough time for me to drink it (I know I'm quite slow - but I really don't enjoy gulping my coffee down!), and so I asked if it would be possible for my half drunk coffee to be taken away - and the server was incredibly nice and said of course not a problem and had it put in a takeaway cup for me.  I was actually quite amazed! Wasn't sure what I was expecting when I asked honestly, but  was pleasantly blown away.So well deserving of 5 stars I reckon! Love Dimbulah!

address: 30 Raffles Place #01-31 Chevron House Singapore 048622 Singapore
comment: This place is a little small and there is a space constraint so be prepared to go early during the peak timings or you might not find a seat. I find the food there quite good and i like the mushroom soup, though more to the salty side but i like my mushroom soup salty rather than bland.I think that i would most probably go back for the coffee as i think the food is pretty average. The coffee is really valued for money as it is cheaper then Starbucks and the other usual coffee places yet tastes quite aromatic and different.Service was really sincere and heart warming as well, a nice place to chill but mainly people go there for the coffee.

address: 30 Raffles Place #01-31 Chevron House Singapore 048622 Singapore
comment: Most people came here for coffee. Today, I am Garfield. Had the beef lasagne instead. It's awesome !

address: 30 Raffles Place #01-31 Chevron House Singapore 048622 Singapore
comment: Dimbulah is an Australian coffee franchise whose motto is "plantation to cup". It operates several locations across Singapore, including two in Raffles Place (with the other being located in Market Street). I prefer the Chevron House outlet as it's larger, more inviting and, because it's not out in the open, has more privacy. On the coffee front, Dimbulah is certainly very much Australian in that the staff is friendly and its coffees are brilliant. I've only had the flat whites here twice and they've been consistently delicious. Prices are reasonable for Singapore at $4.50. The only let-down though is that there's no latte art. I know it'll vanish the moment I drink my beverage, or, what's more likely, get destroyed by the time I get back to my office, but... still! Presentation does count, and for that, I'll take off half a star, only Qype doesn't do half stars, so I have to take off one whole star so as to distinguish Dimbulah from the other cafes with great coffee. For food, Dimbulah offers sandwiches, wraps and cakes. This particular outlets also sells soups from Saybons. Given its location, it can get a little crowded with office workers swinging by to get their morning /post-lunch fix, but the service is very fast, without quality being compromised.

address: #B1-12, One Raffles Place 1 Raffles Place Singapore 048616 Singapore
comment: I miss this place after leaving Singapore. Healthy, high quality food and drinks with great service. My favorite is the Ginseng Chrysanthemum Tea!

address: #B1-12, One Raffles Place 1 Raffles Place Singapore 048616 Singapore
comment: Every once in awhile I feel the twinges of guilt from eating unhealthy and try to find healthier options - such as the 'Herbal Bar'. But should healthy food equal incredibly bland watery soup of a tiny portion? I think not.The owners should really invest in putting afew more ingredients in so their customers will be able to distinguish one soup from another (i.e. actually taste what they claim to put in the soup). There are quite afew soup joints around Raffles Place so it's not like there isn't competition. To bring customers back, they need to step it up a little.

address: #B1-12, One Raffles Place 1 Raffles Place Singapore 048616 Singapore
comment: Actually I quite like the Herbal Bar. I've come here enough to get 8 chops, which you can redeem for a free bowl of soup of your choice (but ONLY after 5pm though!) I love the Ginseng Chicken . They may be slightly plain tasting but I prefer that over tasting like they've chucked in lots of msg. The other soups aren't very good , but my friends and colleagues are quite big fans of the Sliced Fish Soup.Service is always fast - Raffles Place tends to be crowded and you have to wait a long time before you get your food. I always get to sit down here, and service is fast, so that's a big bonus.

address: 1 Saint Andrew's Rd Level 1 National Gallery Singapore Singapore 178957 Singapore
comment: Checking out the Keppel Gallery with kids and came here for late lunch. We had:Chicken Rendang Nasi Lemak - I like how they dye their rice blue for that nonya flavour. Their chicken Rendang is also quite tasty, not the normal curry chicken taste. Ipoh Chicken Horfun - I thought there would be some spiciness to the dish but no... while the taste is generally ok, I must commend the 3 fairly large prawns that were served in it. They were fresh and made up for the whole dish really!Chicken Crab Meatballs Kwaytiao - my girl had and I tasted the soup, it's ok, slightly on the bland side. I guess it should be nice as my girl ate it all up!Iced Tea - not too sweet so that great. Not a place to come back specially for but it was good enough if you're already there with hunger pangs!

address: 01-34 China Sq Central - Nankin Row Singapore 048660 Singapore
comment: The broth is quite delicious and savory however, my pho dac biet didn't have m tripe and the brisket was a bit tough. This place does not have Sriracha which I find hella odd and off putting. Our order took quite awhile but when it finally came out, it wasn't piping hot (I don't like it super hot anyway but my colleague made a comment) and a tiny dipping dish accompanied each bowl. The dipping dish contained a little bit of hoisin sauce and what looked like Sriracha but it was sweet chili sauce. I did not know. When I went up to the 2 ladies to ask for more or the bottle, they said they couldn't and gave us more of the prepared dipping dish (more hoisin and their sweet chili sauce). I took 5 (no hoisin sauce for me) but it did not add any color or heat to my broth. I was disappointed. No tripe! I ordered a dac biet to get everything but little did I know, this place was no match to what I have at home, back in the Bay. The offerings on the menu was quite extensive but prices seemed a bit high to me. They have banh mi but it isn't on the menu and the only kind they have is cha lua and thit nguoi. Get Sriracha and let people determine how much they want instead of preparing it in advance. The broth is very good but lacked execution.

address: 50 Market St #03-33, Golden Shoe Carpark Singapore 048940 Singapore
comment: Green bites is a good option for salads because they've parlayed cheaper rent in a hawker centre into a competitive price point, plus the aunties serving are generous and fast. The offerings are  basic - $4.90 for mixed greens with 5 sides. Pay $1-1.50 for proteins like chicken or sausages. The food quality is ok in that you can only pick mixed greens for your base (no baby spinach or pure romaine) and for proteins, I would only eat the broiled/BBQ/cajun chicken, smoked duck or tuna and skip the processed stuff like crab sticks/surimi and cheesy chicken sausage. By the way, will the person who invented cheesy chicken sausages please...apologize to humanity and go do something more useful? I mean really. Nachos-type liquid cheese in your sausage? Ewww.Anyway the prices are great if you eat a lot (like me). I managed to assemble a salad with high protein/calcium veg like broccoli and kidney beans, got my vitamins from  peppers and beta carotene from carrots. Would like to see more variety but I guess you can't complain much for the price. Most shops charge $2-3 for chicken and only Saladstop and Fresh+ offer tuna as a generic "free" side. Lastly, the aunty putting the salad together is grouchy and speedy, just the way I like it at the hawker centre. Moves the queue along and I get to eat pronto :)

address: 6 Eu Tong Seng 03-85 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Ordered the $59 set meal for two, but the food is definitely enough for 3-4 people!Love the salad and salmon sashimi. I think the salad dressing did the trick with the onsen tamago. Salmon sashimi was pretty fresh too.Ordered the grilled scallops for appetizers and it was pretty small, but yummy. The beef sukiyaki with udon was slightly on the salty side, but our stonepot pork with mentaiko rice served well to neutralise the taste.Yuzu marmalade drink was decent too.This is a great place for sharing a set meal with friends. Definitely not the best food, but decent enough.After taxes and charges, the meal turned out to be $75 ($25 each for the 3 of us), which is okay. I'd probably come back here again only if I have more than 2 people in my group!

address: 6 Eu Tong Seng 03-85 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Mediocre Japanese food. Nothing mind blowing nothing really bad. I guess it only serves as a convenient meal fix. It was surprisingly busy at lunch. The lunch sets were not especially good value. Not sure why.Good for group though as the restaurant is quite big and has a good view of Clarke quay and the river.

address: 6 Eu Tong Seng 03-85 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Had a central voucher to use so went straight for the set meal for 2. From each section (A to E, if I remember correctly), choose 1 dish. We went for salmon sashimi don, a salad, beef sukiyaki, Tonkatsu egg, etc. Portion and qty are more than enough for 2 pax. Good enough for even 3-4 pple. Enjoyed the sukiyaki (came with udon). But overall a bit ex for 2 pax. If you can order this 2 pax set meal to be shared by 3-4 pple, then I think it's worth the price and variety.

address: 6 Eu Tong Seng 03-85 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Food was excellent! We came here for lunch and ordered the chicken and a noodle dish, as was as the skewers and potato pizza. It was a pleasant surprise! We just wanted to try something new. Reasonable prices too! Recommended for good Japanese food.

address: 6 Eu Tong Seng 03-85 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: The service at Watami spoilt my otherwise pleasant experience there. The service staff seemed to be everywhere but available and were rather snappy when we asked them about our order. The food there was not bad though, although they did take a long time to serve it despite the restaurant being rather empty. I enjoyed the Watami Salad and the Wafu Pizza we got to share was quite a delight. My friend found the ramen pretty good as well. The dessert menu was not interesting so we decided to head somewhere else for it. Overall, not bad for food, but not exactly a pleasant dining experience. With the vibrant restaurant scene in Singapore, it isn't hard to find another that costs around the same amount that has better food and service to offer.

address: 6 Eu Tong Seng 03-85 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: The food here isn't exceptional. Coupled with price points that are slightly higher than Sushi Tei, this place gets a 3 start from me. The only plus point about this place is that if you get a window seat, there's nice view of Clarke Quay, overlooking the river. But on overall, there are better places for Japanese food at Clarke Quay so why bother?

address: 6 Eu Tong Seng 03-85 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: The con. Having won a discount voucher for Watami, decided to give it a try. Upon arriving though, realized there were restrictions on how the voucher can be used. Although I was peeved, since we were already there and hungry, we decided to throw caution to the wind. The first thing you realized about Watami is the menu. Basically, everything and anything on Japanese food can be found on it. Variety is an understatement. It feels like several popular Japanese restaurant chain all rowed into one. Good for people who are easily bored. Not so good for the fickle minded. I feel prices are a tad on the high side for the quality of food served. The service was also a bit iffy. Nonetheless, its still a decent food outlet with a wide variety of choices that will suit most people.

Well, I've failed you all.When I came to Singapore, I told myself that I'd never patronize a Starbucks. There are a ton of local places that have legit coffee and I'd rather support "the little guys". (Not to mention, I've grown to like the basic kopi!)However, I had to cave. I was meeting my husband at his office so we could go to the airport together. I arrived early and he wasn't ready yet. I was already hungry and thirsty, as dragging a 7 kg carry-on luggage through the MRT and Friday rush hour traffic in CBD will do that to you!I saw this Starbucks in Lobby A of 1 George Street, and noticed it is now open and functional. With a heavy sigh, I took the FAIL card out of my wallet and proceeded towards this beacon of corporate America. I decided on the fancily named soy apricot muffin and a tall iced latte. Total? $9.40 (eye roll)2 stars for the price, but 3 stars for the location, convenience, and assistance in taming my hunger to ensure "Hangry Michelle" doesn't make an appearance. :)

Service is fast. Mainly for people on the go.Was surprised that the afternoon tea time deal was on today!!! Which was good.Had the salted egg yolk croissant. And an iced latte. It was surprisingly pretty good! For $7.40, I couldn't ask for a better bargain! The staff is very attentive and is willing to go the distance for its customers! So if you need coffee and especially a quick one' this is the place for you!Take note!! This isn't a place for work! It's small and cramped. So this is not where you bring out our laptops to.

What do you do when you can't stop a friend from endlessly raving about a place? Go to it of course! One lunch time, we did just that. It was a crowded place, no less than I'd expect from a place as hyped up (albeit by my friend) as this. It was a place that to an extent did actually bring me back to Vietnam - the colour scheme, the bustle, the feeling like I'm not quite in the east, but yet not quite in the west...it's weird and I can't quite describe it, but I remember having been in places like this in Vietnam.The food did not at all disappoint. I was tempted to get the pho, but I just had a pretty nice bowl the day before, so I decided to go for something dry instead. Cue high fives for the amazing decision when my bowl was delivered. Crowned with two fresh prawns, a smattering of fried shallots, slices of pork so tender and a nice handful of greens, my bowl of perfectly cooked glass noodles was just the most excellent eat I'd had in a while. What made it so good was of course the sauce it was in, seductively sweet, yet tastefully savoury as well. Finished every little strand, just so I could maximise the sauce given. It wasn't the cheapest bowl at $11.50, but my word was it worth every single cent.Note that they do tax your bills and charge you 20 cents for the wet towels, whether you use it or not...so use it! Also be warned that the noodles come with parsley, so if you are not a fan of that devil plant (like me), don't forget to ask for them to take it far far away from you!

Garbage. They were just opening as I came, I was first in, and they seemed irritated that I was there. Service was non existent, yet I was charged 10% on the bill, that's not cool. My bowl of pho was more or less thrown at me onto the table and I saw a waiter again. I had to go up and ask for my bill. They should have given me a cut of their 10%. The pho itself sucked. The only redeeming factor was the beef was fairly decent. But the broth was like something out of a can and many of my noodles were hard. I'm a pho junkie. I know a good pho. That was not a good pho. It was also $12.50 after everything was added in. Ridiculous for pho, especially in a place where you can far superior yet similar hawker food for less than half that. Wouldn't go back nor recommend.

2.5 stars.Colleagues and I were strolling around this area looking for a lunch spot but the rain had other plans. Torrential downpour = running into the nearest shelter, in this case Viet Inn.The place looked promising, clean tables, strong AC. Pretty standard Vietnamese restaurant fare with your pho noodle soups, rice dishes, pork chops, Vietnamese coffee. OK let's do this.I had the lunch set for $17.80. It comes with your choice of spring rolls or rice wrap rolls - got the spring rolls as they are deep fried and didn't have prawns. These were pretty tasty, you get 2 of em.I had the sliced beef noodle soup. The bowl is a decent size but the quality of the beef was subpar. They weren't clean slices as I would expect but some of them were chunks of beef. The noodles were the thicker rice noodle variety and they tasted good. Not too soggy, not too firm, just right. The soup wasn't very flavorful. It had a lot of oil in it as you can see from my picture but there wasn't any depth to the flavor of the broth. It's not pho if it doesn't have depth darnit! The dish comes with your normal accoutrement of bean sprouts and lime slices but boy do I miss Sriracha!The third item in the lunch set is your choice of a drink or dessert. I opted for the Vietnamese Ice Coffee Milkshake. That's what it was called but it was just an ice coffee drink as far as I could tell. It was just bleh.The search for good Vietnamese food in Southeast Asia continues. Oh wait, that would be in Vietnam (from what I hear). The search for good Vietnamese food in Singapore is still on...

This is so far the best vietnamese food in Singapore that I've tried. We've tried Pho Hoa in Holland Village which just tasted like water with a lot of bullion added in *shudders* and Nam Nam in City Hall, just to name a couple, and this is the closest thing I could find to real authentic Vietnamese beef broth soup. Everything was pretty tasty. The sliced beef is not the best quality but it's pretty tasty as well. In general, would go back when I have a pho craving.

I've been hoping to find good Vietnamese food in Singapore, and this is the best so far. Not very authentic, but pretty good. (OK, so I've never been to Vietnam, but there are large Vietnamese communities in Portland and San Diego. Apparently the restaurants there are pretty legit, so they are my yardstick for authenticity.) The Pho broth was a little bland and the noodles were too soft, but the hot sauce, hoisin sauce, and coriander turned it into a pretty satisfying meal. The pork spring rolls were interesting. Small and pleasantly crispy; extra meaty, so a little greasy. They did a great job with the egg. I don't remember what it was called on the menu, but it was essentially a vegetable omelet. Quite nice. The service was good and they were generous with refills in the condiment plate. Overall, in a competitive market I would not have rated Viet Inn so highly, but until I ate here, my experiences at other Vietnamese restaurants in Singapore have been very disappointing. (I'm looking at you, Pho Hoa...)

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: For $9, you can get a sandwich that you can make with $2 worth of ingredients bought from any supermarket. Not only that, but you can probably make it better. A ham and cheese sandwich contains one slice of ham, which is just sad. Totally not worth it.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-11/12 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Yes, the salad is very sad. They shouldn't even say the meal includes green salad, it is at best a garnish!The pulled pork sandwich is actually not bad. The bun is soft and sesame crusted. But it is a very small burger for $6.50. You'll be starving by 3pm.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-11/12 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: If you looking to waste some calories, this is totally NOT the place to go to. Was there alone on a weekday lunch and whilst every other food outlet at the Central Basement was full or at least brimming with activity, Porky Pork was really quiet. "Perhaps people were not acquainted with this new joint, thus the lack of life" I thought to myself, so I ordered myself a Pulled Pork with Bun that's to be served with mixed vegetable.After 5mins of waiting, I was served with a very sad looking 'burger' with a few pieces of veg. For the price of $6.50, I thought the amount of mixed veg was pathetic. The bun was not even toasted, or Perhaps it was but I can't decipher. A nicely toasted warm bun with a slight crispy edge would have made the bun a much more worthy one.The pulled pork tasted alright for the first two bites and then the overly sweet and salty BBQ sauce started to take effect. It was an experience of the-next-mouth-tasting-worse-than-the-last. I was really on the verge of abandoning my lunch after 5 bites, but I was also taught not to waste food so I made myself finish the meal.I didn't order any drinks with it but what a mistake that was cos the meat was so salty, I was dying of thirst (maybe there's use of MSG? i dunno!). No, I'm not going back again. :X

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-11/12 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This place is fairly new. When I went there (weekend lunchtime) it was empty. Though perhaps that's not a fair comparison to make since the basement of The Central wasn't very populated to begin with. It's somewhere between fast food and sit-down, because they seat you with menus but you have to go up to the counter to order and pay first before they deliver the food to you at your seats later. I split the Hungarian sausage ($5.50) and the pulled pork on bread ($6.50) with a friend. Portion sizes are okay for the price, but quality isn't. The sausage was quite bland and its texture was dry. It came with yellow rice which was so-so. The pulled pork was marginally better but the bread it came with -- a burger bun -- is not worth ingesting. The meat was soft enough and the sauce sufficiently flavoured, but overall not impressive.Note that the "hot tea" item on the menu is chamomile by default, which the menu doesn't state. I'd assumed it'd be regular English black tea, so I didn't ask beforehand. The lady who took our orders at the counter did not offer us a range to choose from. But service was okay in general.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #B1-44 #B1-45 Soho1 @ Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: A nice little find for a cheap set lunch.$15 total for two people$21 for three personsCame in here on a wet Friday around 1:30pm, the place was about half full. The deal is amazingly reasonable. I got the USA Kurobuta Pork Skirt set which included about 3 small-ish pieces of pork, a side of chips, two prawns and a side of coleslaw. The set lunch also includes soup - cream of vegetable.The pork was fantastic, just melts in your mouth. You don't expect a filling meal for 8 bucks, but all up it was pretty solid. The prawns were grilled, and just amazing, a great addition to the meal. Coleslaw, soup, chips and drink were just the cherry on the top.

Meh...that is exactly how I felt.Went for a late lunch and they are already out of sashimi. I took a glance at the menu and it is mostly salmon anyway, not my favorite fish.Ordered the oyako don. It is at best food court quality. There is more egg than meat, so much chicken skin (read: fat) in the bowl that I resorted to picking out the skin...not cool.Food court quality Japanese at $9. No like.

It's ok for when I have a sushi craving and don't want to spend much and I want it quick. It's actually 2 counters side by side with the sushi display in the middle. The left counter is for the sushi and they sell some rice bowls and chawanmushi as well. The right counter is for udon.I've been twice. Both times the sushi selection was not much to speak of at all but it tasted decent. They usually have things like inari (sweet beancurd), hana maki (salmon wrapped around rice with mayo - way too much mayo so I scraped off as much as I could), sometimes salmon sashimi, tamago, chuka hotate (seasoned scallop), crab stick. The basic sushi are sold in pairs around $1.80. They have sushi packed sets for about $6.80 to $11+, basic salad with salmon sashimi on top and small bowls of cha soba.The rice was not hard and dry thank goodness. I also tried the curry udon for about $5. It was simple comfort food served piping hot. They call out your number for you to collect when it is ready so you can start chomping on your sushi first while waiting.You can choose to sit either side of the sitting areas as it's all the same company.

Umi sushi is a small sushi bar at which you can buy sushi per type or mixed in a plate with different kinds of sushi. I took a small plate (8 pieces for 6,50$) and it was nice. Nothing special, but it was a decent meal.

Service was great, the maître de adequately described the oyster specs to detail. Our husband's loved trying all the happy hour oysters and ordered dozens of the $1 and more expensive ones as well. We ordered dinner from the sister restaurant- which was a great option- and the food was fantastic, especially the ceasar salad. Drinks were quite overpriced, but alas, we are in Singapore. We would've escaped with a reasonable bill had it not been for the fabulous oysters and excessively priced beer.
Place to go for reasonably priced oysters in the CBD. Oysters for a dollar from 6-8 during the week. Great views too from the 45th Floor!

This is a review purely on service cos the hostess' attitude was so bad, we left in 5mins.We were looking to sit at a nice restaurant/bar after a long work day to chill and bitch about work. Upon hearing some good feedback about the view at Angie's Oyster Bar, we decided to head over to try. Apparently they have a Wednesday $1 Oyster Special, we thought that's a nice bonus.Upon reaching the restaurant, it was fairly empty. Sharing the same entrance as their sister concept restaurant, Sears, we were rather confused to whether we were at the right entrance as there weren't any signage for Angie's. First timers, we were out to try something new! We entered the restaurant and no one came to sit us until we approached the counter. The hostess came over and asked us in a very matter-of-fact and slightly condescending tone:"Are you here for the $1 oyster special? If you are, we are out of it."We said its ok, we just wanted to dine in and have a drink regardless of the promotion. The hostess repeated,"Are you here for the $1 oyster special? If you are, we are out of it. I just want you to know if you are here for the special, we are running out."Really, lady. Is that all you can think about?We told her table for three cos we just want to dine in. (We were famished!)So the hostess took the menu and asked"Do you wanna sit inside or outside?"We were a little confused cos we are not sure where the "outside" was and how it's like vs inside as it was our first time. An experience server will start giving suggestion to the kind of experience we will enjoy seated inside vs outside. But this hostess only got impatient.With a stern face, she pointed to the glass door and said, "Outside is that way."We decided to sit "outside" and the hostess led us to the alfresco seated area. The views that were available were either that of marina bay or towards Fullerton. We walked to the Fullerton side but decided to settle down at the Marina bay view instead so asked to be seated at the other side.The hostess gave us a black face while leading us to the other table impatiently. My friend asked if there were any other promotions, she said blankly, "No. If you want free drinks you can go to Empire next door."She left the menu on the table and walked out on us.Every time she spoke, it as if she spoke in a condescending tone. If we want to spend, we will and we can. But we won't waste our dollars on bad service and as customers, I will be very silly to spend money at a place where we are clearly not welcome and pay to have someone give me attitude. All we wanted was a nice, quiet place with a view to get our minds off our long exhausting day at work. With that objective, we left the restaurant immediately. I don't really care if your food is good. Your service sucks and it sucks big time. The other servers could only stare in surprise when we walked out and didn't even bother to ask if they could assist or what's the issue. The hostess was no where in sight.

Why am I giving this place 5 stars? While many may say that the toast or the eggs are not very special or that the food is expensive but one of the biggest draws for me is the convenience of the drinks to go. They are pretty efficient with the dual counters and dual queue system which enables the crazy, hungry and thirsty crowd at Raffles Place to get their drinks to go.The other big plus for me is that the cashier has somehow identified me as a regular and remember what my usual order is (I tend to buy large amounts of honey lemon drinks to go) and she is ever cheerful and helpful, sometimes giving me good recommendation for new drinks I'd like to try.The honey lemon here comes with 2 slices of lemon and a very generous amount of honey to sweeten things up. I wouldn't say they use great honey but when you do try to press the lemons farther before drinking, the sourness from the lemon slices and the sweetness from the honey comes to a nice balance.As a few others pointed out, if price is an issue, do go to Golden Shoe for better priced drinks and food. But the service here plus the convenience and pretty good speed of fulfilling their orders would keep the crowds coming.As a side note, they do have a main competitor Teahut which also makes excellent honey lemon, but they tend to be a little generous with their honey and lemons.

I will admit I'm not a huge connoisseur of kaya toast and so I can't really say if Fun Toast has better or worse quality kaya than Ya Kun, Toast Box, or elsewhere.  All I know is that my mom and I were starving for breakfast and it was too hot to walk anywhere, so we stopped into the closest mall next to our hotel (actually the outlet at Liang Court, which doesn't have a yelp listing for Fun Toast) and we were thoroughly satisfied with our meal.  Set meal of two half boiled eggs, kaya toast, and whichever drink we wanted, of which they had a huge number of choices.  Fun choices!  I had teh c peng with grass jelly, while my mom had cold barley with lemon and ginger.  They also had otah otah, which was a nice breakfast treat!

We got the set which included a coffee, toast and two eggs for less than $5. We also got their coconut rice wrapped in a banana leaf.If you want to get the same food for half the price, go to a hawker spot. If not, enjoy this chain haha. It's the same taste wise and in a nice, air conditioned mall!
They are very good for breakfast. Also love the friendly staff who always remember what I order.

The long lines that form past this little place every morning is testament to the quality of local breakfasts that they offer.  I love this place because regardless of whether there's a long line, or if I'm the only one being served, the quality of tea/coffee that they prepare is consistent.  In the mornings, they have a take away counter for hot drinks and tuna / egg / sardine sandwiches - I've never had to wait more than 5 mins, they really are efficient, and the Aunty that serves at that counter is amazing!! She really keeps the line moving fast, and manages to be friendly and cheerful all at the same time.If you would like to sit for breakfast, or want to get hot food such as mee siam, curry chicken etc, you can queue at the line inside the cafe. In fact, sometimes the line inside moves faster than the takeaway line outside :PGreat place to grab breakfast in the morning - I'm a fan!
Fast service even during peak hours. Staff are attentive and get orders right all the time. Food is made fresh and yummy

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #01-29 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Date/Time of Visit: 18th Dec 2012, 4:20pmIt's a Starbucks. They have prided themselves in almost identical standards of service and F&B not only throughout the countries but in the region.I've always enjoyed the Starbucks Experience as most of us would call it. There were, a couple of kinks with this outlet at The Central though.1) The barista asked me if I wanted to "upsize to a medium"? I mean, it's a small kink, but seriously? Did you jump over from CBTL or something?2) I ordered a Dark Chocolate Log Cake for my girlfriend. I'm not exactly sure what it was supposed to be like. It was way too mushy, and looked like it was condensed out of vaporized chocolate fudge. Not sure if many will like it.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #01-29 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Ordered an Americano and it is nothing compared to the Americano in the states. It's disappointing because most Starbucks in the other countries are very consistent to the US. My coffee tasted nothing like coffee, just like tea.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #01-29 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Friendly server who attempted to make small talk and actually smiled.I only wish their coffee tasted better. The latte I had was way too weak. Not sure if it is my imagination or did they used to serve a much better cup of coffee.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #01-29 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Quick service. Iced coffee hit the spot on a sunny humid afternoon. Thanks for the consistent quality. Clean bathrooms. Quick service. Staff were on point!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #01-29 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This is one of my favourite Starbucks outlets in Singapore and it has recently been refurbished. I like it primarily for the ample space, comfortable armchairs and large windows by which you can sit and people watch for hours.On the negative side, this Starbucks appears to have some of the slowest service I've encountered on the island. This is a problem because during the day it is often jammed with office workers. The poor bastards have to wait for 10-15 minutes to order their caffeine hit before scurrying back to their cubbyholes. Come on guys, speed it up!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #01-29 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Its like a normal starbucks. Just that this place has more power plugs available for you to do your work. which means more students hogging the table and NEVER getting up. Its irresponsible. But what can they do.

I think the coffee and cakes/pastries are better than the food. So 4 stars remained for that.The food I tried over the past visits were ok, not horrible and not so delicious that they deserved a repeat order. Maybe the place was too small to have a proper kitchen? It seemed like the "hot" food was just being heated up before serving. The corn fritters were more like fluffy pancakes with corn in them. Definitely not what I imagined them to be, and certainly not like those at Bills in Sydney. Hey, Jamaica Blue is from Australia after all. Can't blame me for the correlation. With the texture like pancakes, I wish there was some sauce to pour over the "fritters". It was just so dry that I actually resorted to sprinkling white sugar over them as if I was eating prata like a child. It was much better with the sugar. Their sandwiches and salad selection do look quite good though. Maybe their cold food will be much better. Next time.

Had a nice breakfast here this morning on the way to meet some friends at Suntec City. At just before 10 AM on a Sunday, the place was virtually empty. The coffee was excellent - I had a Long black and it was a tasty cup of Jamaican coffee. It was among the best cups of coffee I have had in Singapore. I ordered the bacon and egg sandwich while my wife had the "avocado smash", which appeared to be basically the same thing with fresh avocado. I thought the bacon was excellent and really enjoyed the breakfast sandwich. At about $13 it was pretty reasonable my Singapore standards as well. Since we had almost the whole place to ourselves, we got excellent service. There are only about 6 tables indoors but there lots outdoors. Was frankly surprised that no one else was there. My only (very minor) complaint was that the is significantly different than the one online (we had scoped it out before heading down). Or kids were really excited about the pancakes only to find out upon arrival that they aren't offered. Overall, a simple, quick and tasty stop in Tower Three!

Holy moly the drinks are overpriced here.They serve your typical range of coffee and tea drinks but the few coffee drinks I've had have been over $6, typically $6.90 for a standard long black, cappucino, or latte? NO WAY JOSE.I'll stick to my kopi alley kopi O or Coffee & Toast local kopi from butter roasted beans.I don't care how good the coffee is (although I don't remember anything outstanding about this place) but $7 for a cup is offensive. I don't care if a rabid cat in Indonesia crapped out these coffee beans before they were slow roasted... it still shouldn't be this expensive.-end rant-Okay, aside from the price, the venue is cool, it's convenient as it's located right in our office lobby. Is this some kind of chain? Are they really from Jamaica mon?

That was the best cup of coffee I've had on the island to date.  It was also the most expensive.  Plus you get to sip your cup with the financial elite in the lobby of some snazzy building.  What's not to love?  Oh right. The price.
Friendly staff, convenient location, great Latte, caps and long black.  Breakfast is also excellent the breads are tasty and the eggs Benedict rocks

The Jamaica Blue staff was extremely rude. I finished my cup of coffee and was taking a call when one of the staff approached to clear me cup. Moments later, another staff immediately came confronting me while I was taking my call to inform me that I haven't bought a drink which is ridiculous. If you are selling an overpriced cup of coffee, at least have the manners!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #03-89 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Was looking forward to sample Joshoken's tsukemen within Ramen Champion. Joshoken's founder was a disciple of the inventor of tsukemen.This edition of Ramen Champion at Central was spacious but poorly managed. Was also looking for the laksa ramen but couldn't find it in the menu.It took a long while for a waiter to appear to take my order for Original Tsukemen after pressing the Call button repeatedly and it took more than 15 minutes before ramen was served.The thick noodle has excellent al dente type elasticity and was accompanied by a lime for squeezing onto the noodle prior to dipping. The problem with lime is seeds tend to get onto the noodle easily. The dipping sauce was lukewarm and had some pork broth/seafood complexity, slightly salty but did not taste good with the lime-aided noodle. A single piece of chashu was positioned on top of the noodle and it was dry, bland and barely tender. Ajitama was served whole with hard overcooked mooncake yolk within. Tap water costs an additional 50 cents.Overall, the dish was a major disappointment when compared with other tsukemen. For instance, the ramen at Rokurinsha (started by another disciple of the same master) Haneda airport is a much more delicious version of this genre.

rest_name: No Signboard Seafood Restaurant, The Central
address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #04-63 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Ok so for everything ordered here during a work team dinner, I thought the food was tasty. Mango chicken was delicious. Chili crab is the signature here and very very messy and annoying to eat. I recognize it is the Singaporean treasure dish, but it is so much work and so messy to eat! This was the only place that I tried the dish and it was tasty, no doubt. However, the crab is not prepared or eating-friendly (you have to break it all apart). It was best to enjoy the sauce of the dish over crab fried rice and with the little bread rolls served as a side dish. Amazing like that alone! The service was mediocre even though there are a lot of employees walking around the large restaurant.

rest_name: No Signboard Seafood Restaurant, The Central
address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #04-63 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Well a coworker recommended this place for white pepper crab. It was fan freakingtastic. Best white pepper crab I've ever had. It was so flavorful, the sauce was so tasty. It was not very hard to break the crab open and get to the meat. Now the other stuff was not very good. We got garlic fried vegetables, just a bunch of broccoli with garlic. It was meh. And the Mee goreng was just out right horrible. Smelled bad. Tasted bad. But the picture on the menu for it looked great hence why we got it. The tea was okay. No restroom in the restaurant, had to go to the mall restroom which was very far away!

rest_name: No Signboard Seafood Restaurant, The Central
address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #04-63 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: save yourself a trip and don't go hereit may have been a darling before but it feels like they are living off that legend. The service is slow and it seems like they don't really care you are there. We needed to ask for everything .... menu, water, napkins, place setting, check, etc. The food was really not good at all... it looked old (like it's been sitting around for a while and that was the way they served the food to us) and the portion is skimpy.It's a large restaurant and probably of the 50 tables, only 2 were filled at prime dinner hours. That should have been our clue but we were so hungry and just wanted to get something into our bellies. Mistake on our part :(

rest_name: No Signboard Seafood Restaurant, The Central
address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #04-63 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This place has gone downhill a bit from what I remember a decade ago.   The place was run down and very far from the bathroom.

rest_name: No Signboard Seafood Restaurant, The Central
address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #04-63 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Chilli crab was the recommendation I heard over and over again while talking to different locals.  I didn't know where to get it but finally someone dropped a name:  No Signboard.No Signboard is a good introduction to Chili Crab, just like how PF Changs is a good-though-pricy intro to Chinese food for non-Chinese people.  We were staying at the Marina Bay Sands and was at the pool from 8am until after the sun clocked out.  After walking through the restaurants at the Shoppes and finding things were starting to close, we decided to hop on the MRT -
