the orange line to the purple line - to Clarke Quay station and then out to The Central.  No Signboard has several locations but 1) it was already past 9pm 2) we were hungry and couldn't afford to get lost 3) I was familiar with The Central/Clarke Quay, so this location was most ideal.I found it odd that the website does not include this location.  Maybe they paid a ton for the web design and this location was a later addition, or this was the bastard-child branch that they'd like to forget.On the interwebz, it seemed like people did not like the food at this location and I have to somewhat agree.  The cold platter was recommended to us and it was a complete disappointment.  Maybe it was "sell off this shit" time of the day.  We did arrive close to closing, afterall.  yelp.com/biz_photos/no-s…  The siumai, lotus root with glaze, fried vermicelli spring rolls, stir-fried vegetable and baby octopus all sounded alright, but most definitely was not the wisest choice.  For S$48, i might as well have spent two more dollars and get another chilli crab.Yep, 48+2 = 50 and that's how much the chilli crab costs.  yelp.com/biz_photos/no-s… Pricy for sure and really hard to eat at gracefully at the restaurant.  All that sauce just goes to waste.  I wish they would include a pot of rice so I can pour the crab-gut sauce all over rice and enjoy it a second time (maybe call it the poor man's chilli crab experience).  The mantou were 4 for S$2.  Stingy for the price because they're so tiny.  They don't soak up any sauce.  Make it multi-cultural and hand me some roti instead.Cereal crayfish was OK. yelp.com/biz_photos/no-s…  S$24 is steep but rent at The Central must be expensive.  For that crunchiness, you might as well find a Cantonese restaurant and get some typhoon shelter crab (bei fung tong hai) or panko-breaded shrimp from Costco.Chilli crab and sauce were tasty but the overall experience was two letters: eh. Tiger beer was S$7.90.  yelp.com/biz_photos/no-s…  The waitstaff was as warm as the cold platter.I can't really give it two stars because according to the star ratings, I haven't had better chilli crab (this is my first), so A-OK it is.Next time, I'm going to brave it, put on a bib and eat some chilli crab at a hawker stall.

rest_name: No Signboard Seafood Restaurant, The Central
address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #04-63 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: The crab prices START at $128.  That is for the Canadian crab, the least expensive crab you can buy.  Other crabs cost $200 and 300+.  To the eat the chilli crab, which may be the  messiest crab dish ever made, you are provided with one small moist towelette (the ones in the plastic wrapper) and a bowl of water.  Of course, if you dip your fingers in the water to clean them off midway through the meal, the moist towelette does nothing to help you dry off.  If you ask for another 'napkin' they give you a startled look and come back with two additional tiny moist towelettes and THEY CHARGE YOU $1 FOR EACH. For a restaurant that specializes in serving crab, did no one think that the patrons might need a real napkin or two?  You are also proved with the most poorly designed crab cracker ever made.  Hard to imagine messing up such a simple device.  This restaurant must have bought the cheapest crab crackers made in the world. The service was indifferent.  Not friendly at all.  No interest or concern for the customers was ever shown.A crab, a small sweet sour pork dish and a very small plate of asparagus cost over $200.  To the price of the meal, add the frustration of eating with no thought given to your comfort and one is left feeling ripped off and very angry.  You also get charged for your glass of tap water, by the way.

rest_name: No Signboard Seafood Restaurant, The Central
address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #04-63 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This is worst place to go if you're a tourist and or just visiting. Service was lousy. Charged for peanuts even though we didn't order but it was placed on the table as if it was complimentary. Also charged extra for towels to wipe hands. Didn't have napkins also so we had to ask and waiter said they had none. Then our Chili Crab arrived. They never offered to crack Crab so we started cracking ourselves until we noticed the next table the waiter was providing that service. They never offered us and explained we had to ask. But how do we ask if that is a service if they don't offer it? How is someone from out of town suppose to know? Manager didn't offer any solutions to the service and just walked away and let the waiter keep apologizing.  Please people don't ever go to this place crappy service, bad attitude, so so food, over priced, charges for items you didn't order.  Learn from our mistake. $150 US dollars spent and not worth a penny.

address: 3 Pickering Street #01-27/28, Nankin Row Singapore 048660 Singapore
comment: Might have liked this place if not for the two-faced service we experienced from the owner of the restaurant after she realized I was dining on a coupon. She went from warm and bubbly to complete sour-faced sour puss upon realizing we were dining on a discount coupon. Food was mediocre and their chicken rice paella was more like an overpriced clay pot rice of which I've had better and for cheaper. Will not be returning.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street The Central B1 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Great if you are a fan of Sichuan food.This works like a Yong Tau Foo stall where you pick out your own ingredients. They have a decent selection of seafood, meats and vegetables.Pick out your food, they do a quick weigh, bring it to the kitchen to fry it up with Sichuan spices. You get to pick the level of spiciness too.Gobble it up with rice and try to ignore the layer of chilli oil left behind!Note: they will fry up your own bowl into one big bowl for sharing. Be sure to tell them you want them separately if you don't plan to do it family-style.Location tip: they are in a rather hidden spot in the basement where Gong Cha used to be.

address: 30 Raffles Place #B1-03A Chevron House Singapore 048622 Singapore
comment: One of the few places around Raffles Place that I can think of to get Korean food - dont expect to be blown away, it serves very average Korean fare including the staples of beef bulgolgi and tofu stew.  Its always hard to get a table here though especially if you are in a group of more than 2 - I would say don't bother really.  Had their cold noodles here once which was.. well interesting.. it was quite sour, and tasted slightly odd to me - and have stuck with the staples since.Beggers can't be choosers, so if you're at Raffles Place and craving Korean food, head down to The Palace- otherwise Tanjong Pagar would be a better bet with lots more Korean restaurants there.

address: One Raffles Pl B1-38 Tower 1 Singapore 048616 Singapore
comment: Working in Asia Square, I am always on the hunt for a quick, healthy lunch.  Always.  So, when a collegue read that Jar'd by Sarnies opened up, I was all for it.  I had been making salads in jars for a few years (thanks to Pintrest) and was curious how this idea was going to translate to a business.  I loved the branding, and the concept, and the fact that I could keep the jar, so off we went to the Raffles basement to get our salads.  It's a small little kiosk like everything else down there, but easy enough to find.  They had a few options, a vegetarian zoodle (zucchini noodles I think with a thai dressing) a chicken pesto one, a tuna one, and one other one I forgot.  They also serve them in two sizes, and the prices vary depending on the protein.  My friend got the vegetarian one ($14) and I went for the tuna one ($16) both were the smaller jars, but the salad was quite a bit, and I only finished about half.  They also serve coffee, and this coconut whip thingy that is supposed to be like soft serve, but according to my friend who had it tasted like nothing.  I have to admit my tuna one was pretty disappointing.  It had seaweed (which was just weird, and the taste was off putting) as well as lots of other good veggies.  The tuna was good and fresh, and I liked the dressing.  I really think the seaweed just killed it.    My friend who had the veg said that there was just no flavor, and needed more spice, or a stronger dressing to help the lack of protein.  You do get a $1 off if you bring back the jar.I'll go back and get the chicken pesto and try and it, as the service was really good, it was quick, kinda decently priced, and I really like the concept.

address: Upper Cross Street 531 01-49, Hong Lim Complex Singapore 050531 Singapore
comment: I had just attended the National Day Dinner which had its chinese sit down dinner catered from Yan Palace.1st course : Cold Dish CombinationThere was 5 dishes in this dish : crispy fish skin, salad prawn, fried egg, black fungus, deep fried prawn roll.Most people were not taken with the black fungus especially with the older generation. Although the black fungus was crunchy, it was lacking of flavours.The crispy fish skin was everyone's favourite as it was light and crispy.The prawn roll looked like crispy yam roll, filled with crunchy prawn filling.2nd course : Double Boiled Black Chicken SoupThe soup was a way too salty for most people. The meat of the black chicken was quite tender.3rd course : Baked Herbal DuckThe meat was quite tender and filled with tender soft, melt in the mouth chestnuts.4th course : Braised Seafood with vegetablesThere was clams, fish maws, shiitake mushrooms, whelks, cabbage, and dried scallops. The dish was well braised.5th course : Five Spice RollsThere was way too much onion in the rolls, and lacking of the crunchy texture from water chestnuts. It was served with a spicy squid salad.6th course : Steamed Sea BassThe fish was steamed with soya sauce, and topped with a meat and preserved vegetable mixture. The meat was firm and juicy.7th course : Steamed Herbal PrawnsThe prawns were juicy but can barely tasted the herbal part.8th course : Braised Pork Belly PauThe braised pork belly was quite oily, and could do with a longer braising time as the fat still did not have the melt in the mouth texture yet. It was served with pipping hot bun.9th course : Mango PuddingWish there were mango cubes in it. Lacking of mango flavour.Service was uneven. My dining partner who was having vegetarian, got left out of one course. One staff remembered but served her with a vegetable dish with dried scallop in it. The following course she was served 2 courses together.

address: Upper Cross Street 531 01-49, Hong Lim Complex Singapore 050531 Singapore
comment: The service is so lousy n bad ... both the managers and the servers are not friendly ...the food are good too bad their service Is so so so bad

address: Upper Cross Street 531 01-49, Hong Lim Complex Singapore 050531 Singapore
comment: We came here for Sunday dim sum and it was not that crowded. There are private rooms if you wish to have that. Apparently this place has been around for years, and is popular with the older folks who remembered going there for wedding banquets and other occasions. Maybe they are better for their dishes as I saw many tables ordered that instead of dim sum stuff. I find the dim sum very average. If you are used to the Cantonese style or the more refined and delicate taste of dim sum, this will be a huge disappointment. I place them in the same category of Swee Choon, Red Star and Mouth Restaurant. The only items I like are the century egg pork porridge (looks small and plain but is actually tasty) and BBQ pork buns (soft fluffy bun with plenty of nicely charred and moreish BBQ pork). The fried rice lacks the wok hei flavor and is quite tasteless. My nephews who are "fan tong" (love rice a lot) basically shunned it. The XO fried carrot cake is also not that great (Taste Paradise does a better version). The dessert is also mediocre. Another item which seemed popular is the vinegar pork trotter which did not show up. It was sold out but the staff did not inform us when we ordered. The service is average, typical of such old school Chinese restaurant. It can be better, and it did get better for those who know the people there.

address: Upper Cross Street 531 01-49, Hong Lim Complex Singapore 050531 Singapore
comment: Bad service. Bad food. Clam clay pot - the sliced clams were so chewy and inedible. We told the manager and she said it's like that. We will never return here.

address: Upper Cross Street 531 01-49, Hong Lim Complex Singapore 050531 Singapore
comment: Went here for dinner with a large group and had one of the private rooms in the back. I thought the food was very good and the service very attentive. I especially liked the roast suckling pig. Even with a large group, the food was served in a timely am fashion and every dish was hot when it got to us. The steamed fish was also very very tasty. I would certainly go back. The meal was reasonable priced as well.

address: Upper Cross Street 531 01-49, Hong Lim Complex Singapore 050531 Singapore
comment: really, really surprisingly good chinese food at this dodgy-looking, super old-school restaurant in chinatown. the place definitely seems to have had better days - the exterior is just as worn and outdated as the interior, the servers are cantankerous and grouchy, but the food - the food is good.and - I meant surprising in the sense that I didn't actually expect the food to be good, with expectations further tempered when I saw the restaurant, and it all turned out to be decent - with some dishes actually much better than average (objectively, all other things aside).let's talk about the restaurant first - the unimposing entrance to the place completely belies the hugeness of the dining area. we're talking old-school, banquet-able (in the region of 20-30 tables, possibly more?), with a huge stage in the middle and private rooms surrounding the side. it looks like it would have been impressive in its heyday, but the furnishings are now pretty worn out, and the staff looking nearly as tired as their surroundings.but thankfully, the food completely outshines all these (not that it's terribly difficult to do so). there are some proper cooks in the kitchen that churn out proper cantonese/ teochew food, most of it arriving at decent intervals.the duck: skin was well-browned and crisp with the fat well-rendered away, and the meat was succulent (even if the duck was slightly on the skinny side). a pretty good start.the mainstream sauteed dishes were also pretty decent - silky mushrooms with greens, and pork cubes in a sweet-savory sauce. the latter was a tad fatty - but that's how the old folkies like it, and that's almost definitely their target demographic.the seafood dishes were better, like our steamed prawns or a DELICIOUS steamed fish? we finished with stir-fried noodles (not many ingredients apart from veg and noodles, but it wasn't oily, and was properly dry-fried) and a dish of mashed yam (orh nee). the first arrived when we were rather too full to appreciate it properly, but the latter went down in spite of the too fullness (my dad had seconds, rather impressively).

address: Upper Cross Street 531 01-49, Hong Lim Complex Singapore 050531 Singapore
comment: More like 3.5 stars but I'm feeling generous.The food here is good but not exceptional. There are many better places to eat in Singapore. But I'd come back.Lunch is always busy as its in the heart of Chinatown. Lots of high rise office buildings so there are loads of people.Give it a try.

address: Upper Cross Street 531 01-49, Hong Lim Complex Singapore 050531 Singapore
comment: Considering the food is relatively mass cooked as there are so many tables to be fed, the food is generally good. Deco is traditional and really nothing to shout about but the food is good, in particularly memorable:* scallops and broccoli in XO sauce* fish maw soup* steamed grouper in light-sauceWill definitely return. :)

address: Upper Cross Street 531 01-49, Hong Lim Complex Singapore 050531 Singapore
comment: Excellent place for dim sum and other local delicacies. The fried chicken feet were a little strange for my taste but my Singaporean friends loved them. Place crammed for lunch Large choice and good value for money.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-46 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Very basic Japanese food. Foodcourt standard at best. I guess at a price point of less than $6 per bento set, you can't expect much.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-46 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: In the 3.5 years I've lived in Singapore, this is probably the worst place I've eaten at. And that's a hard prize to get, considering I'm not very fussy with my food.What surprised me was that even though this place is located in Clarke Quay, neither of the 2 staff working that day knew how to speak English. They couldn't have been Singaporean. The trouble began when I ordered one of their promotions, which was on a huge sign next to the cashier, and they didn't know what I was talking about. The worst was when I was asking for water, and they didn't even know what that meant. They kept pointing to this cooler that had ice in it, and after 5 minutes they realized what I was asking for and it turned out the bottled water was still in a box. On the floor. Unpacked. And then there was the food. I ordered teriyaki chicken and ebi bento box. The ebi was edible; the teriyaki chicken was just fried chicken that didn't even have any sauce on it. I don't know if they just didn't take my order correctly or if they think that this type of chicken is passable as teriyaki. The pickled veggies were a huge joke (there was one slice of pickle that looked old), the rice was over-cooked, and it didn't even have black sesame seeds sprinkled on, as pictured in the photo.I couldn't finish my food. It was just so bad that I figured for $5.90 it's not worth enduring and ended up buying food elsewhere.I totally understand if I were in some heartland area in a hawker centre and they didn't speak English there, but this is Clarke Quay, a very tourist area, you guys. If they were trolling and pretending not to speak English when they could? Completely unacceptable. Avoid.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-46 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Everything under $6 which is reasonable for a place located in town. Cheap & quick meal. Quality as expected. 1. Beef & salmon bento - beef was ok - salmon was not so nice - miso soup that came with it was gd 2. Teriyaki omelette rice- the chicken was fried with teriyaki sauce on it. surprising good fried stuff :) - omelette was super thin and had some sauce on it that made it taste a bit weird. didn't like the sauce

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-46 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Standard no-frills food-court-type stall in the basement of Central Mall - Clarke Quay.I ordered the salmon + karage (fried chicken) bento - for $5.90 this was your cheap food-court price. The miso soup that came with the bento was absolutely tasteless however. The salmon was tasteless too, and masked with bad teriyaki sauce. The chicken karage actually tasted pretty good, so that was a surprise! Was not expecting much but the tastelessness and sheer lack of an attempt to even provide a house salad, etc. means I will not be considering this place for a cheap / quick bite in future. Have tasted much better "cheap" salmon bento boxes in other food courts.

Though the food is fair, the staffs in this restaurant are so unfriendly and rude. Just for a glass of hot water the lady who was serving has created a scene. Use to frequent here before but will never come or recommend this place.

I work above Bumbu and come here once in a while for lunch. Their Indonesian food is pretty authentic and I would recommend it to anyone who is a fan. And if you go in a large group the prices are really decent, so don't worry about spending too much even if you go crazy ordering

Did you know that Bumbu means spice in Indonesian? Neither did I; thank you google! You'd think from the name, Bumbu'd be an Indonesian eatery but nah uh, it does Thai too. Surplise!Rocked up one afternoon in a party of 12 and this joint isn't exactly the easiest to locate, nor terribly accessible from the MRT station. We ordered up a storm, and while the food had a homely feel to it, it's more of your bf/gf/hubby/wifey whizzing around in the kitchen vibe as opposed to your nonna/ah ma/nenek's culinary magic. If you know what I mean. The nosh was functional, and aside from the sambal belachan that packed a good heat, everything else was ho hum. The tahu telor - like my pithy colleague, who attended a wedding the previous day and was served the same dish, noted - tasted like tahu telor. There aren't exactly many permutations available for something that's esentially egg and tahu with its life fried the heck out of it. Sambal kang kong was ok, many stalks included so those who only eat leaves beware. The green curry chicken was lemak enough to narrow your arteries by an inch; bad if you're watching your waistline but good if you want to die happy. There's a $20+ buffet going on during dinner and Saturday lunch so it's great for those who like variety. Service is fast and efficient, though you'll need to point out that your water needs topping up. Staff are happy to be around and help you with items you need, and fetch extra belachan or rice.Will I be back? Doubt so. It's a bit too out of the way and the food a bit too lacklustre to warrant a trip out. Sure, I really like the service, but you can't eat service, y'know?

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #02-84/85/86,The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Looking for a quiet and cosy place for meet ups?  TCC (the Central) would be the place to be.  The seats here are mainly comfy sofa and it is relatively quiet even on a weekend. My friends and I were there on a sunday late morning to have "brunch" before we head off to an event nearby.  Other than us, there was one other couple in the restaurant.  However, there was barely much service. Guess they were "short" staff as there is one girl on duty and she has to mend the counter, cashier and take orders.  They have recently added new items to their food menu and we decided to try out some of the dishes. The food looks good and presentable but it was a tad too salty for our tastebuds. Guess the chef was too generous with the salt and sauces. The drinks were pretty normal but I find that the coffee jelly that was in my drinks were too mushy. I am usually very happy with TCC's service and food but i was a tad disappointed with this particular one especially with the service and food quality.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen St #02-84/85/86,The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Well didn't try the dessert but the drinks are really subpar. Espresso bad and the mango yogurt drink it's pretty tasteless. The venue isn't really nice either.

address: 12 Eu Tong Sen Street B1 Singapore 059819 Singapore
comment: Great lunch spot if you like Taiwanese food. My red yeast pork bento set has pork belly coated with flour that is similar to the famed fried chicken version at Shilin market. Think deep fried pork belly.The pork portion is generous and it comes on a bed of rice, vegetables and half a braised egg. I suspect the veggies varies as I got eggplant, French beans, cabbage in mine and the menu picture shows broccoli and others.The set also comes with a winter melon drink. All for $7.80.I will probably try the chicken version next time as the pork belly can feel too fatty when the portion is so huge. I pity my own tummy.

address: 12 Eu Tong Sen Street B1 Singapore 059819 Singapore
comment: 1. Taiwan braised pork rice (comes with a sweet longan (a fruit) flavored drink)  ~$6- the minced pork was a bit too salty for my liking. - had peanuts - hard boiled eggs- corn - tofu

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street Central #03-92 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Do not order the spicy fried chicken wings. The spicy bit came from the chili sauce drizzled over the fried wings. The fried chicken wings were also hard, as if they were dunked into the deep fryer straight out from the freezer. It was so bad I did not finish it. The bibimbap was strangely without the egg. It could not be considered vegetarian since there were seasoned anchovies in it. It was not too bad and only tasted better when topped with the bibimbap sauce.I was quite disappointed with my food. Maybe I did not order the correct dishes. Service was prompt though.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street Central #03-92 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This restaurant really has come way down on service and quality.  I work nearby so have been here a few times. The last time was a year ago and I was eager to have some nice Korean ramyon that I used to have here. Unfortunate the service was terrible and the staffs and kitchen clearly can no longer handle lunch crowd. On top of that I ordered Ribeye Shabu Ramyon (noodle soup) and nothing resembled the menu came out.  The soup was way too thick and not enough. The little bit of beef was hard and chewy.  Even the taste of hot barley tea smelled like chemical.  Of course I'll never return and I hope they get kicked out and replaced by a higher quality Korean restaurant. *the top of the photo was my lunch (I ruffled it up a bit cuz I was looking for the beef) and the bottom was from their menu.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street Central #03-92 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This place i located in the blue zone on the third floor. If you go there in groups (the way i did), be aware that there is a wait. Is this the best koreanfood I ever had? I dont think so. Then again, teh only korean food I had was in NYC so what do I know? The 'free' mini dishes they give here is nothing like the ones I get in NYC so that was a little disappointing. The food in general is ok, nothing fancy

address: Eu Tong Sen Street The Central Basement 1 Singapore Singapore
comment: It is ok. Typical food court standard at best.It gets quite busy at lunch time but I suspect it is because there is no fish soup choices anywhere around here. Ample seating, so that is a plus.

address: OUB Centre Shopping Podium, 1 Raffles Place #B1-01 Singapore 048616 Singapore
comment: SwissBake always stores in my mind as SwissBakery. Anyway they are founded by a true Swiss Mr Xavier Baumgartner who has been a pastry chef for more than 30 years, winning numerous awards in his pursuit of culinary excellence. A couple of years later there are now more than 20 cafes, retail outlets and bread corners across Singapore. This cafe in Raffles place is catering mainly to the lunch crowd I feel. But if you want a sandwhich, the sandwhich shop in hitachi tower beats SwissBake handsdown. It's important to buy things SwissBake is good at. Like pastries and whole breads. The cakes look good and are affordable, the bread is fresh and smells nice. They also have this amazingly refreshing drink called Rivella. Service here is a bit rushed, but still proffessional and customer-oriented. Ambience is modern, clean and ok only. Operating hoursWeekday: 7.00am - 8.00pm Saturday: 8.00am - 4.00pm

The pho is decent with an average tasting beef broth. The meatballs lack texture and flavour and can be compared to the ones you can get at fairprice-nothing to shout about. What was disappointing was their coffee, which was watered down and tasted distinctly similar to a Vietnamese instant coffee brand. Their fried spring rolls were small and not very filled with the usual turnip and nothing else. Overall, nothing special and definitely not worth a trip down to taste. Maybe okay if you are conveniently in the area. :)

Ngon opened recently and maybe there are still teething problems since One Raffles Place has not open officially. Cash/Nets are accepted. Credit cards are not at the moment even though I see credit card terminal/paywave in there.At the entrance, it says to wait there to be seated. I was asked to place my order at the counter before taking my seat. I saw others being ushered to their tables and being given menus. A bit disconcerting when you are not given time to peruse the menu and have to place the order almost immediately when you are standing at the cashier counter. I decided on the set which is basically add $2 to the noodles to get a side dish of fried spring rolls and coffee/tea. I chose the medium beef slices noodles.For those looking for sriracha sauce, Ngon does not stock it. They have no idea what it is. Another diner and I asked for it and the staff was clueless. They only have cut chili padi, a tomato-chili mix sauce and the sweet chili dipping sauce for spring rolls. As it happened, the owner (a Vietnamese from Hanoi and he has never heard of sriracha sauce) was there and we suggested to him maybe he could stock sriracha sauce in future. So hopefully sriracha sauce will be available soon. Ngon does have their homemade "hoi sin" sauce which was pretty good. The broth in the pho was very light and may suit those who preferred a lighter taste. The sliced onions, bean sprouts and basil leaves were served in the pho, not on a side plate. Slice wedges of limes were kept in containers on the table. The noodles were broken, not in long strands. The fried spring rolls were a bit oily and could be crispier and browner in appearance. I would prefer a shallower saucer or dipping sauce bowl as the current one is a bit hard to get to, but this would be picky.The coffee was very strong and only slightly sweet. In fact, I could hardly taste the condensed milk in it.Until I know they stock sriracha, I doubt I will head back there any time soon. The food is not that memorable.

Lucky for them to do a busting business at lunch time, because the food is below average even by Vietnamese fast-food standards. NamNam and its sister Cm Nam are much better. Ngon means delicious in Vit; this ain't. Not horrific, though.

Tasty wise is ok. Beef slices are thin and I opted for medium level doneness and they did that right. Pho is generous in amount. The beef slices were very countable. I think my whole bowl had maybe 4 or 5 slices. Thus, I had half a bowl of pho with no meat to eat with. This is never happened when I dined at Pho outlets. I know my set was $11.90 with 2 tiny fried spring rolls and Chinese tea. I understand that they may not give as much beef as s full priced bowl but 4/5 slices is unacceptable. Don't they know that promotions are meant to woo your customers?!?! Well, sadly they have lost me as one.

Average food-wise, service below average which is confusing bc they charge a service fee to your bill while making you order at the register.I feel like I'm cheating but using my "tip" as the basis of my Yelp review.

So bad that i had to write this review.  No flavor at all.  Quite a difficult task to accomplish for Vietnamese food - they must have a master taste masker. All i tasted were the mint leaves. Even drowning in chili sauce (bottle variety,  not made from scratch) couldn't save the hard,  dry grilled pork. Wish i had read the reviews first. And the most watered down Vietnamese coffee I've ever tasted.  Cutting food costs is one thing but not if the food and drinks end up flavorless. I'd give it a half star if possible, the half for presentation.
The noodles was clumped together, the coffee was horrible. Bad experience :( do not recommend. Overpriced.

I had dined at Ngon (One Raffles Place) 2 days ago upon strong recommendation by the outlet's service staff onsite. I had ordered the set meal which comprised of ''Pork Chop'' dry noodles, 2 huge spring rolls and a tall glass of tea shown on the menu.The actual food upon arrival was a stark difference. The tea came in a small cup and the spring rolls were in fact, mini rolls. However, the most shocking was the noodle dish. There was no ''pork chop'' but thin slices of cured (or preserved) pork slices that were so salty and dry. Almost like pork jerky. As much as tried to, I was simply unable to consume beyond 2 pieces. In the end, I ended up only having the plain noodles and left the pork slices untouched.I contacted the outlet next day requesting to speak with the manager in charge. A female staff answered, shouted that she and the outlet are very busy and that manager was not present. She then ended the call abruptly. For that set meal that cost more than $13.00, one could receive better quality food ingredients and service from similar eateries and even from a foodcourt.

address: 1 Raffles Place One Raffles Place #B1-04/05 Singapore 048616 Singapore
comment: Good fresh sandwiches with top ingredients used. Reasonably priced with plenty of sitting space after re-design. Always a fan of their salads and now sandwiches. Good pastry as well.

address: 1 Raffles Place One Raffles Place #B1-04/05 Singapore 048616 Singapore
comment: Swissbake is known for its baked goods - bread and pastries. And some outlets serve proper food, including this one in the basement of One Raffles Place. The display of sandwiches is always tempting as they look so fresh even at 530pm. The staff will also call out its promotional prices, old school style, instead of having them written on the board or poster. I guess as the place is still new and unless you work in the area, most will not realize One Raffles Place has more or less completed its makeover/renovation and the basement is almost fully operational (only 1 restaurant is not opened yet at this time of writing). Good time to go pick up some sliced cakes (2 for $7) or sandwiches and salad (10% off) for dinner on your way home. The place is also quite empty around that time. Music is no longer of the heavy bass variety but the usual top 40s. Besides the cold stuff, they also serve hot food. I decided to add $5.90 to make it a set. You get to choose 2 options from a list of soup of the day/cake (2 choices) or drinks and others. Complimentary water was available in a corner, together with the cutlery and magazines for browsing.The smoked salmon kraftkorn was really good. The seeds and nuttiness of the bread added a new dimension to a simple regular multi-grain bread. It looked very hard and chewy but it was actually crispy and light. I was surprised. Despite it being ready made and left in the chiller for a while, the veggies were still very fresh, not wilted at all. The pumpkin soup was also good. The hazelnut cake was nice but not mind blowing. That belongs to my list of try once is good enough. I saw a few people having work discussion or meeting in another corner, so I guessed it can be a good place to get away from the office for a while. Others were also working on their lappies.

address: 1 Raffles Place One Raffles Place #B1-04/05 Singapore 048616 Singapore
comment: Nice redesign and bigger space in the new basement of One Raffles Place. The thumping music with heavy bass is a letdown for an upscale bakery cafe like this.

address: 8 Eu Tong Sen Street The Central #01 Singapore 059818 Singapore
comment: The million dollar questions: how are they the no.1 korean chicken chain, and how did they survive for 5 years here.What a waste of precious calories.

I occasionally frequent Starbucks in Singapore/Asia when I want a cup of fresh brewed coffee. I guess I'm brainwashed but the familiarity of walking into a Starbucks that's just like every other one on the world gives me a sense of comfort. The reason I give this location 5 stars is because the staff here are SO friendly and genuine. I had to order breakfast for 15 two mornings in a row last minute and they were more than accommodating, even delivering everything right on time. Herman and his staff are fantastic! They didn't even ask me to pay up front and trusted that I'd return two days later to settle everything. Great customer service here!

I go through long periods when I don't go to Starbucks but now and then I return. I'm most likely to go when I'm meeting someone and they want a sweet drink or we need a comfy couch chair to catchup over. I always explain to friends (or face it anyone who will listen) that there are 3 reasons I come to starbucks:1) It's got this warm casual laidback atmosphere and because they look pretty generic inside, for that moment (especially on a work day) you could be anywhere else in Singapore..or as my friend said Milan. I mostly pretend I'm in a shopping centre far away from the office or..the Pike Place Market location which admittedly is tiny.2) They do good soy.3) They do good flavoured syrup drinks for when you want something more like dessert or need to topup your brain food.They're pretty patient with my custom drinks requests here (usually things like reduce the syrup, short drinks, replace syrups with other flavours etc)! Until the one time I ordered a non customised one, the barista making it actually checked with the cashier if he had heard right. "Normal??"

address: 30 Raffles Place #B1-01 Chevron House Singapore 048622 Singapore
comment: The economic rice here is pretty standard. Not bad, not fantastic, but it does its job of filling you up with decent food for a ridiculously low price.There was a queue when I came here w/ my colleague to grab a quick takeaway lunch but it goes fast. As it was my first time here I wasn't familiar with the particulars of the ordering process here and was yelled at quite a few times in Chinese. Which just scares and confuses me even more and causes me to freeze. I could tell I wasn't making the workers there very happy.After being yelled at a few more times, I managed to fumble out some cash, pay my fare and of course grab the wrong takeaway bag. Yup, yelled at again. I guess it's just a culture thing. Hopefully they were yelling sweet pleasantries in Chinese. I wouldn't know.Colleague apologized and said Singapore can be rude at times. I said "so can Americans" and kicked him in the ding ding and ran like hell.

address: 30 Raffles Place #B1-01 Chevron House Singapore 048622 Singapore
comment: Not hot. This cafe has been here forever, I can remember it back in 1998, and never once been there. Seeing a smaller queue than usual I popped in for a quick plate of mix and match your own dishes.Started the build with spicy reddish rice with small anchovies which was pretty damn good, on the side was black pepper chicken (very average), sweet and sour pork (excellent) and spinach with mushrooms (average). For the $6.80 and at 12:45 over lunch I expected it to be hot, but everything was room temperature. Seriously, I can not recommend a place where 4 out of 4 dishes are not hot, especially at lunch. Coupled with two dishes being less than awesome, how has this place survived?

address: 30 Raffles Place #B1-01 Chevron House Singapore 048622 Singapore
comment: This really can't be called "Nasi Padang". The food is edible at best and the dishes are not served hot (or even warm for that matter) during the lunch peak hour. I think the only reason why it survives is because of its location and allows for a quick takeaway lunch.A few workers there are also rude (from my experience) and they tend to rush you too much. I wouldn't recommend this unless you're in a rush and ridiculously hungry.

Bratworks is the most sterile looking imbiss on earth but it sells delicious sausages. I've eaten the currywurst and loved it. What irks me is that the shop is as empty  as a broke wallet after a night out on the town and I'm not sure how long it will last.Let's get the food out of the way - this is a shop that sells delicious, grilled hot German sausages and slathers a Heinz curry sauce (kinda sweet) and some curry powder on top. You can even get a bottle of beer if you please (the audacity just cracks me up at lunch... "why not?") and some fries to boot, but my poor wallet can only handle A sausage.  It's good though. What I also like are the state of the art facilities and how spanking Germanly clean it is (yes that's a poor pun on germs and the great country). You don't get stalls like that anywhere in Singapore except maybe at Japanese-run ramen shops.So I feel like this review should be a summary of the analysis I've played over and over again in my head while eating at Bratworks, about why this shop is empty:1) The Food Pictures and signage are ALL WRONG - OK if you walk past this stall while deciding what to eat at One Raffles Place, two things jump at you at Bratworks - holy smokes they want $8 for ONE sausage (because if you glance at the menu all you see is $8)...or a set meal consists of a beer (??) and fries for $16. The average lazy  desk bound office worker who imagines that eating alone will get him/her skinny will think "ewwww beer and carbs?", while the health conscious ones who actually exercise will be like, "$8 for a small piece of protein that's filled with I don't know what meat??" and walk on. Everyone else will feel sad about the lonely sausage sitting next to a small German bun and compare it to the bowl of bak chor mee they were gonna eat anyway and think "neh, stick with bak chor mee".I am 99% sure this is what people think when they look at the Bratworks shop and I don't understand why the owners swap out the fries in the damn picture and show some potato slaw or better yet, sauerkraut (hello fermented food movement!!). Beef up the sausage too or chop it up. And if the currywurst is this company's famous food....WHY ISN'T THERE a picture of the delicious pile of chopped up wurst slathered in sauce?! Stick some pop up words next to the food that say "100% German recipe!" or " Only the freshest ground sirloin" too. Finally, have a catchy tagline that expains what in the world an Imbiss is or why this place is so spanking clean. There's probably like 20 Germans in Raffles Place (and they're all from DB) and 100s of everyone else who doesn't understand what a Malaysian-bird-sounding shop is (that's what I thought an imbiss was until I bothered to google it). Look at Erich's Wuertstelstand, where he made a joke "The last sausage kiosk before the equator" and bingo! Everyone knows it sells sausages.2) Pricing - This is the other head scratching thing. So I can't decide if Bratworks is trying to sell sausages as a meal or as a place to have beer and snack on sausages. Maybe in Germany people do both but in Singapore, I've heard of almost no one having a beer with their lunch, not even the Brits. If that offended anyone (either comparing the Brits to Germans or vice versa) I apologize, but the point is, you can sell $8 sausages to people who are half drunk, but you won't get away with it at lunchtime. If I wanted a snack and literally next door I can buy a bag of fried chicken for $4.80 and its spicy and delicious, I ain't buying a sausage for $8 no matter how good it is. It's the same with the set meals - if I can get a steak and couple of healthy sides on brown rice at Daily Cut for $12, why would I want a lonely sausage and lonely unsauced chips and a soda for $12? Again not to keep harping on Erich's but a quick glance at his stand and you see prices like $1.50, $4.0, $2.50 which hits his target market at Chinatown right. Bratworks could get away with $4-6 for a single sausage maybe but make it look bountiful and sizzling and irresistible.I think what makes Bratworks at ORP all the more sad is that I never see the owners around. It strikes me as one of those places set up by a banker who wanted to eat his homeland snack but couldn't get it anywhere, so he bought state of the art equipment and hired some kid to stand behind the counter. That's about as much passion I see. It is ironic because Bratworks is owned by the Chaoying group, which is behind Sabai by the Bay and Long Tail bar, so the owners do have F&B experience. Oh well....

The line is really long during lunch hour, so I never bothered with queuing for the food. Then I happened to be there around 5.30 pm and it was still open. With virtually nobody around, I placed my order. Bad mistake. At 5.30pm or so, it would be better to order the food to go as by 5.45pm or so the staff would start pulling down the shutter and you would feel pressured to start shoveling food into your mouth fastest possible. Not good. The girl was nice enough to say "don't hurry, take your time", but you would still feel the need to finish asap so that they could go home. The food was good and affordable in CBD standard. I believed my plate of rice with braised cabbage and chicken, it came to under $3. A nice surprise.

What can I say? This popular "cafe" is really your typical kopitiam. It's along Philip Street and I go there when I'm in a hurry. What sets it apart from other rice and veg stalls in the area: 1) You don't have to climb stairs like Golden Shoe Food Centre round the corner 2) There's a huge display of food 3) You can order porridge 4) It's really quick no matter how long the queue is, and it's often long 5) The very popular fish soup stall kopitiam is just too much of a wait.

It seemed like the menu was limited on weekends as 2 menu boards indicated they were only available for weekdays. I was hungry after gym and just wanted something readily available. I chose Bull Run which was teriyaki chicken with soba and some greens.It was ok. I usually avoid teriyaki anything as I OD on it as a teenager. The teriyaki chicken was a generous size and quite good, but I did not like the soba. It was mushy and not cold enough. The soba had a gooey sticky texture and I was not sure if it was overcooked or if the dressing had made it soggy. Just not nice at all. The greens were quite miserable. It was less than what it looked.Maybe other dishes on the menu would be much better. This is a good option to dine here when other places are packed as they are very fast in serving the food. Like what other Yelpers mentioned, the buzzer would beep once you sat your butt down on a chair.

Wheat Baumkuchen (WB) has fast becoming my favorite post workout fuel simply because it's convenient, food is consistently good and price is reasonable with the quality you get. Don't get me wrong, I still love eating at The Daily Cut, but it is just that few times you can eat in a month since it's relatively expensive and the food quality can swing like a pendulum (good to bad, or vice versa).  I consider myself a regular at WB and thoroughly enjoyed my meal everytime I eat there. While the food is good, the name of the item has got to be the weirdest I've ever encountered like Lava Rice, Penguin, Whale and etc which has nothing related to your rice, noodles or salad. My all-time favorite is brown rice with teriyaki chicken ($8) or grilled salmon ($9). All rice comes with a side of salad and mushroom (sorry I don't know the exact name of it). Top up another $2 and you'll get an upsize salad which I usually order. If you're not into brown rice, opt for soba noodles instead. Served cold with a toss of Japanese dressing and slivers of carrot, it sure is very appetizing. I was pretty shock to read the review from other yelpers on the size portion, saying it's too small. And then I realized the reviews were 2 or 3 years old so it might not be accurate for now. Trust me, they have revamp the entire concept and the portion is substantial enough to fill you up.  Service is always very efficient - you order at the counter and will be given a buzzer. By the time you found a seat, your food is already ready for collection. If you haven't try anything here, it's high time you do. They are delicious and cheap. What's not to love, I ask.

Hmm am I missing something here? Somehow I did not have an "at least 3-star" experience when I dined here. I tried Bull Run and Salmon, neither of which were particularly appetizing. The noodles ruined the dish for me - soggy, neither cold nor hot/ ie at room temperature (i suppose they're meant to be cold?), and drenched in their respective dressings that were just "meh". The salmon was overdone, but the teriyaki chicken was decently palatable (otherwise I would be giving an outright one star). The two things going for this place:1) super efficient - by the time u settle down at a counter seat, the buzzer goes off. Perfect for an easy, no-fuss and quick meal 2) opens quite late, well at least later than its neighbor (daily cut). But that's also on condition  you're not fussy and don't mind the less popular choices cos they may start selling out Taking into account the other somewhat comparatively raving reviews, I eventually figured I should give the food some benefit of the doubt and give Wheat 2 stars. Not that I'll be back anytime soon or that Wheat will be my first alternative if DC is sold out though... I'd need some time and courage to give it a second shot...

Like a phoenix rising from the ashes!This was my first lunchtime meal in Singapore. The Phoenix at Wheat. Green soba, crispy chicken (topped with mayo) and salad.Such a nice little eatery - plonked in the middle of the food court.Take note, this place gets so much traffic it runs out of nearly everything. If you're having late lunch, you might wanna skip it cos you'll get the stuff no one else wanted. I wouldn't recommend the Whale or Bull Run.But, if you're there at lunchtime and you wanna be born again, get the Phoenix.

Tucked away in a little corner at the basement of One Raffles Place near the escalators, I'd walked past many times without really noticing it, but was brought by a friend to have lunch there. I saw only one guy eating there - and I soon found out why. The portions are TINY! I was still hungry after having their soba salad and even after desert elsewhere. Their salads so however taste very good, with lots of different dressings and toppings with an Asian touch, the cold soba goes perfectly - very clever idea by whoever came up with it I thought!Service is fast as most of their food is cold and prepared in advance.  I didn't however try their baumkuchen cakes - didn't really notice the cakes, thought this was more a salad place, so I'll have to go back and try it since that's what they seem to be famous for?

Read about it on hungrygowhere and wanted to try it, finally found myself in the CBD on a weekday before lunchtime and decided to check it out!Tried the Penguin noodles, apparently the most popular. $6.80 for what looked like a somewhat small portion of noodles, seemed to be a bit on the high side. But I was quite full after devouring it all.. Green soba noodles in sesame sauce (seemed rather mayo-ish, and actually there was a bit too much sauce, should've asked for it on the side or something), shredded chicken (admittedly, somewhat dry and stringy - definitely needed the sauce to counter the dryness), egg (nice thin strips!), cucumber, carrots, salad. The description says quail egg, but I didn't see any! Hmph.Anyway, wasn't super wowed by it, not bad, but not amazing either. Might try the reindeer noodles sometime or something!

Before wheat baumkuchen opened, the only way I could get my dose of baumkuchen for tea time was from Muji. I was thoroughly happy that something I enjoyed in Japan could now be enjoyed here in Singapore as well. So far, I'm glad with the quality of the baumkuchen, though I've just gone with the original flavour and it tastes pretty much the same. Price wise, I'd have to say its reasonable compared to what I paid in Japan. Though they've added new items onto their menu, I'm reluctant to give it a try and would much prefer their baumkuchen over anything they have.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-82/83   The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I have been to Waraku a few times at their various outlets. You can get very decent Japanese fare at Waraku with its menu featuring a wide array of food. Just don't expect very mind-blowing fare and you should be able to enjoy your meal.The last time I was here I had soba with tempura. The soba was alright, as far as soba went. It didn't get too watery after a few dips, which you may experience at some other Japanese restaurants. I quite liked my tempura but wished they didn't place it on top of the noodles. The tempura was fried to a crisp - probably something that can't go too wrong.Enjoyable - just remember not to be expecting too much!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-82/83   The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: I  am not sure if waraku used to be better or am I just getting fussier.The food is mediocre at best. They have the standard Japanese fare, averagely priced with an average taste.Don't come expecting anything mind-blowing.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #02-82/83   The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: 1. Thin pizzas are nice and crispy - However, it's a little too small for an adult portion. 2. Pasta is only average. - Was not impressed by the teriyaki chicken meat that came along with it.  - The free salad that came along with it was old and turning yellow (didn't dare to eat it).

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-49 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: One of my favourite lunch places when I used to work in the area. They have the best "guilty pleasure" instant-type of kimchi ramen and the set with the rice rolls is affordable. I recommend the spam rice rolls with kimchi! Friends who have accompanied me for lunch have loved the cheese ttobokki and spicy seafood ramen too. Perfect for comfort food. Can be a bit hit and miss though - don't get the jjajjangmyeon and rabokki.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-49 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Rolling rice is a Japanese-Korean fast food cafe. Ran by Koreans, they serve up a variety of korean dishes, including bibimbap, Korean noodles (which is instant noodles to me), Korean rice cakes (tobokki) as well as sushi rolls.It serves as a convenient affordable lunch option. But nothing I would hike over town for.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-49 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Very cute concept though equally confusing menu. My ramen pot and kimbap rolls were yummy but nothing special. But often when it comes to Korean food and lunch, that's exactly what you need.Generous portions. Kinda squished, but that's everywhere in Central. Would come again to try the jajangmyeon - eating companion said it was great!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #B1-49 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This is the worst beef brisket ramen i have so far. At $7.80, there is only instant noodle with fats? I think it is better to cook at home. If there is a rating with no star, i think i will choose that.

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street B1-25 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: This restaurant is frequented by either tourists or those working along the Keong Saik road area - both crowds probably usually come here for the air-con, it's one of the few eating places along the stretch that's air-conditioned.Well besides the air-con, my colleagues and I would come here for their chicken curry! It's one of the best in town. I like to order it with bread, it comes in a generous portion freshly toasted, you have to use your hands and get dirty with it. The best thing is that they refill your curry gravy (and it's hard to say no to a refill, the bread soaks up all the gravy in no time!). You can also have the curry with rice.Besides the curry, everything else is in the rather eclectic mix of a menu is pedestrian. You have the usual rice and noodle dishes from hokkien mee to fried rice and then there's also the western dishes from oatmeal fish (not too bad!) to chicken chop. The western dishes usually comes with a lunch set of soup and drink.The prices are a little higher than your regular coffee shop and the service is friendly and sufficient.Final verdict: If you like to eat good chicken curry in an air-conditioned setting, this is...perfect!

address: 6 Eu Tong Sen Street B1-25 The Central Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: With a few certificates hanging around the store, I'd expected a lot more from this shop than what I got. To be fair, my friends and I only ordered desserts so we did not try the food. We ordered a variety of desserts from the cold chocolate snowy ice to steamed egg hashima and my bowl of glutinous rice balls in ginger soup. The glutinous rice balls were alright but I did not like the ginger soup at all. The ginger was overpowering and the overall sensation was not great. I drank as little of it as possible. The snowy ice as usual was the best dessert there, covered in chocolate syrup, although I did not think it was particularly special compared to other bowls of snowy ice that I've tried. The desserts were not too expensive, which is good, ranging from $3 to $6 depending on whether you had the less fancy hot desserts or fancier icy desserts.

address: 1 Raffles Place #B1-02B Oub Centre Singapore 048616 Singapore
comment: A Taiwanese snack shop selling fried chicken cutlets and pieces, mee sua, tea eggs and some rice thing. I've had the fried chicken and milk tea. The fried chicken pales in comparison to the ones at Shihlin Street Snacks, despite the fact that Shihlin itself is already a poor cousin of the original Shihlin uncle in Taiwan. Xiao Wang Bar's chicken is coated in a batter and deep fried, but somehow it's never fried well enough for the batter to come out crispy.  So you have this soggy chicken that's then dusted with spice/chilli powder mix but very sparingly so that you get a mild, soggy bag of chicken. This has happened to me enough times when ordering the cutlet and pieces that I gave up eating here. The milk tea here is very sweet but I suppose that's how Taiwanese milk tea is supposed to taste? My general sense frequenting this outlet is that the employees don't feel for the brand and aren't enthusiastic about putting across the quirky Taiwanese street stall culture of quick, loud but happy service, which I have strangely enough experienced at the Far East Square and Harbourfront Shihlin Street Snacks outlets. I think the franchise owner needs to work on ensuring consistency in the product.

address: 3 Pickering St #01-29 China Square Central - Nankin Row Singapore 048660 Singapore
comment: Tossz is a good place to hang out if you need to study during lunch hour (us poor sods working on the CFA). It's a small shop space but the inside is cooled by a great air-con and the outdoor area is covered by a gazebo. Most customers order their salads to go so you don't have to worry too much about seat competition. The salad set up is simple - take your box of leaves from the fridge, give it to the server and pick your toppings (6 Tossz-in's for $7.50). You have to pay more for meat proteins and servings tend to be on the small side (like 2 strips of bacon is one serving). I like the honey mustard dressing best, while the Caesar dressing tends to taste strangely light and sour. Also, they don't offer free tap water here. I would argue you get a better deal price wise at Fresh+ and even Salads & Wraps. Oh and don't eat the Granny's stew because it is quite awful, trust me on this one. Stick to the salads.

This location of Coffee & Toast is really popular with the office workers in the area. I found the set up really crowded with table placed closely together and really stuffy since it is in almost a semi enclosed area in the basement.Even while I was drinking my strong black coffee, I feel like ready for a nap.Unless you are meeting someone working in the area for a quick bit or coffee, if not I suggest going somewhere else for your coffee fix.

Great place for Chinese food.  Some items I tried and liked were the Venison fried hor fun, yang chow fried rice, and pork chop.  I truly enjoyed the variety they have on the menu and I was happy to have tried deer meat for the first time!  It tasted like beef!  The customer service was great here too.

Decor is dated but the food is good. So if you can go pass the frills, this is the place to have a good meal. We ordered quite a few of their signature dishes and were suitably impressed. We liked their:* yam ring* salted egg calamari * Claypot eggplant with salted fish* stir fry vege with garlic* roasted chicken* soup of the dayTheir dessert items are some hits, some misses. The Mango Pudding was well received while I found the Almond Longan Jelly to be a little weird tasting. The salted egg buns were only so-so. The bill is not cheap but for the flavour and dining comfort, it's a return trip for the family soon.

Legend. This is the place where the late Master Supreme Heavenly Chef Tham Yew Kai used to helm. ( For real - he was known as one of the four heavenly chefs in the 1960s)- master as he innovated, recreated and experimented with Cantonese cuisine.Food wise you can read about the history of this place. It was a lab of innovation with the birth of the Yam Ring ( an homage to  a monks alm bowl) , the origin of Lo Hei and so on. Laiwah is a good place to honour a chef that has come before us - food wise they churn out food incredibly quick so feel free to indulge.Venison Horfun was delish(MUst order!), some of the dishes are now rare fare in most Cantonese places so are definitely worth  a try. I found the mandarin stewed chicken a little heavy for me but I think thats cos I am trying it in 2015.. Pork chops in delish sauce are pretty yummy though so I guess fried pork does transcend time. The chicken with broccoli and ham was also rather unusual as I have not had that before. Pretty good with white rice though.
Superb bagels with very interesting flavor combos. I got the breakkie with fennel sausage onion aioli and fried egg. Delicious meal and very filling! Will definitely be back for more.

Good flavors, definitely hit the spot. I would say it reminds me more of Canadian bagels than NY bagels but honestly in SG, this is already amazing haha. Flavors are a bit on the salty side and veryyyy messy to eat. I personally prefer the breakfast ones over the lunch versions. Next time will have to try the diff spreads!To note, there is very little seating especially now that it's COVID, so plan accordingly. I went on a rainy day at around 10:30am and there were a few people in line so I'm guessing can be quite popular and crowded normally.

My fav bagel place in Singapore! At this location, I like the spam bagel. I recommend adding a hash brown (usually I do that for my Husband cos he loves hash browns) but it's good enough on its own. I also like the avocado one (sofrito?) and add a slice of bacon if you feel like it. Otherwise I go for the blueberry bagel with fruits. My go to breakfast place in my hood.

Eighteen days into a three week swing through Asia, I was done with hotel breakfast buffets. I wanted a breakfast that hadn't been under a warming light or in a steam tray. Fortunately, when I checked into the delightful Courtyard by Marriott Novena, the young lady at the bell desk on the ground floor told me I had to try this place. Given that it was about 20 steps from the front door, this was a no-brainer.This was just what I needed, and more. The bagel at 8 am was still warm from the oven and the schmears were cool and tasty. The menu told me that I was coming back, and tomorrow I'm buying for the office. Two Men Bagel House has redefined the quick breakfast in Singapore. As long as they are here, I am staying nearby.

when coffee meets bagels........coffee we have plenty in sg!bagels? well they are indeed rare and hard to find!good coffee? yesgood bagels? probably the best in sg!and for coffee to meet bagels here in novena? automatic 5 stars!;)when they first popped up in tanjong pagar, many yelpers were lavishing mouthwatering praise.our previous cm michelle even got them to tie up with the new black for a yelp event and all who attended were sold on how good they are and craved for more!that culminated in us holding a subsequent UYE brunch at their tp location not so long after.cold retarded, no, not you, the dough.handrolled.boiled in honey water.flavoured and then tanned in the oven on site for a freshness that can't escape the bite.need something extra?toasted and schmeared for extra taste and texture.still looking for that something extra?the legends and the breakfast club configurations will take that to the next level!be it savoury or sweet, meaty or plant loving, there is something fishy too!nicely stacked, halved and wrapped.maximum enjoyment, minimum messiness.a favourite with the expats and millenials.non airconditioned but who needs it with the recent cold spells in sg?the staff will definitely warm you up with their cool attitude and infectious friendliness.my only wish is for the onion and garlic flavours to make it's way here from enggor st and the coffee meets bagel experience will be complete......
Fresh bagels made everyday.. worth it for its price. A bagel and coffee works perfectly on a sunny weekday.

Been to their other branch thought try this one since its focus is smoked.  Tried the Primal and Ribs and both were wonderful though the ribs was a little too spicy.  Coffees were wonderful as usual.  Only issue was the order payment was slow otherwise Q as usual even before the store opens.

It's my first time in Singapore so I don't really know a lot of places to eat. Thankfully I have Yelp to help me out. I ordered the Kuzu bagel and it was very delicious. I also like their unique maneki-neko.

I have to say I was skeptical, coming from NYC we know good bagels, and this place really delivered. Excellent bagels!! Got a cheddar bagel with scallion cream cheese and my husband got the Whammer on a garlic bagel and both were great. Definitely recommend!

A rather refreshing take to bagels, never thought bagels could be so savoury and so wholesome! Love the bagel with SPAM, tastes amazing with all the luncheon meat goodness. Thumbs up also to their in house roasted meats, the birdie (chicken) bagel was incredible, fragrantly roasted and well seasoned. The meat platter had very generous portions and all of it together, formed a very heavy lunch that filled us to the brink - just wished that we didn't have to go back to work with such a full stomach after that. The mango smoothie deserves a special mention for it's refreshing taste with just the right amount of sweet and chill to balance the meaty tastes, all set in a casual alfresco dining experience for cosy chit chat with friends, enjoyable!

had the primal and lamb bagel. for someone that isn't hugely into bagels my verdict is....well I loved it. They were huge and cut in half so my wife and i were able to try both.  Coffee was good. Had a long black. They have cold pressed juice and everything was ready in a little over 5 minutes. People working there were nice and friendly.

Still the best bagels in Singapore. This one alongside their other location in my old stomping grounds in Tanjong Pagar serve the only bagels in Singapore that I consistently come back to.Highly recommend you come here for any bagel craving you have as you really won't find any better on the island.The location is pretty cool, all outdoor or bar like seating. They don't take credit cards so be wary of that - only cash and NETS.

What caught my eye about this place was the  "Honey and Ricotta" spread. I love honey  and I love ricotta, but I've never thought to put them together on a bagel . The taste was absolutely mouthwatering  and the ice peppermint tea I'll be back for.

Highly recommend! Not a big fan of bagels but this little place changed that. No doubt it was made just a few minutes earlier, it was so fresh. Just wish I would have discovered them when I first got here instead of on my last day here. Coffee beans were fresh and very flavourful. They use a local roaster and the roast date for your coffee is shown. Mine was within the last 10 days, so just about perfect. To top it off, every staff member was super nice and accommodating; a rarity it seems. Breakfast lunch or dinner would be great here.

Amazing bagels! I've never actually had any other bagels in Singapore, so I feel pretty comfortable saying that these must be the best that the island has to offer! ;) I normally always spring for the lox bagel, but the menu is so inventive and interesting that I decided to try something a little different: the Hawaiian bagel - spam, chutney, egg, sriracha aioli & greens... no cheese for me because I really don't like it. All on an onion bagel. It was easily was of the messiest bagels I've ever eaten, but also one of the best (comparable to the one I've had in New York). Just everything was perfect. The onion bagel was crispy and just the perfect amount of onion, the spam, chutney, etc. combination was really great and tasty. Everything tasted fresh, which is weird to say about spam, but you know, everything else tasted fresh. I was kind of sad my bagel was over. I know I mentioned their menu was interesting but I definitely feel it warrants another mention: I haven't gone to a bagel place with such a wide offering - it's usually pretty boring, typical stuff, but Two Men Bagel House offers so much more (I mean, corn chowder soup bagel? Like what even? Give me some of that!! And who the hell doesn't want to eat something called Hot Mess?). I legit wish I had more time to stick around and try something else!I almost forgot to say: though you order up front and then grab a seat, the staff at the counter were hilarious as well, cracking jokes with us - really great service and made for a good atmosphere.

This place is great! Before you ever order your food & drink, you are greeted by a happy & friendly & helpful staff. The bagels are fresh and delicious. (They make them fresh each morning). There are all sorts of choices to make a sandwich or just have a topping or two. The coffee is delicious as well. My only regret is not having eaten here sooner. We ate breakfast here before heading to the airport. If I'm ever back in Singapore, I'll make a point to come back here. :)

I got some bagels from you last week, and they were excellent.  However, I waited in line over 20 minutes today to try and buy a threesome of bagels, only to then be told that at the counter that I wasn't allowed to order bagels by themselves, I could only order them as part of a sandwich.  That was frustrating and was a large waste of my time.  If you are not going to let people order regular bagels, you should take that choice off of your menu.
Awesome bagels! Thank you!!! We love coming to this shop, especially the bagel and lox or the BBQ!

Went there yesterday and this place is legit (although I am a goy, so take this with a grain of salt).  Speaking of salt, the lox was not salted but was piled deliciously high on your choice of bagel, along with tomato, onions, cucumbers,cream cheese and capers.  Seating is outside only (covered).  Coffee was good but not great.  Right next to the Courtyard entrance.

Yummmmmm.  Everything's fresh and made right there, nice outdoor seating, super friendly and knowledgeable staff.  The bagels are dense and chewy like they should be, and flavorful too!  Scallion cream cheese was delish, meat sandwiches are amazing.  I tried their soups as well --  the spicy smoky creamy cauliflower was phenomenal.  Great limeade.  Love this place.
I had the primal bagel and it was delicious. The bagel was soft. The staff were friendly and explained to me in details since it was my first time eating there.

Another popular famous Hainanese chicken rice place with incredibly delicious tasting food. The chicken just melted in my mouth.The pork knuckle had very tender meat on it. The frog legs were also so delectable. The veggies with century egg, prawn toast, and fried tofu were all good too! Filled up mostly on the chicken rice though.For sure will frequent this place again when in Singapore.

Came here and to chatterbox for some mandatory hainanese chicken while vacationing in Singapore. Both were delicious for different reasons, but I would give Boon Tong Kee a slight edge. Chicken: you can order white or dark meat or a combination. So good! It was juicy, so much flavor, and as soon as it get set on the table my mouth was watering. It was my first time ever having Hainanese chicken in Singapore, but just from the smell and look of the chicken, I knew it was going to be amazing. Much more translucent than chicken back in California where I'm from, probably because of how fresh and preservative free it was. However, I would give the chicken from Chatterbox a slight edge. Rice: this is why I like Boon Tong Kee just slightly more. The rice has more of the chicken flavor, hearty, and a stronger smell. Love love love this rice, best rice I've ever had, period!Both restaurants are good, Boon Tong Kee is almost a hole in the wall set up, no one dressed up, older furniture, and chatterbox is very fancy. However, the slight edge goes to Boon Tong Kee for its much more reasonable price.

This place is serious about chicken rice. The wait can be long but don't let that stop you from checking this place out. My party of five had waited about an hour in line on a Saturday night and needless to say our stomach was growling. Luckily we knew what we wanted and quickly placed our orders right after we were seated. The lime juice was perfectly tangy and refreshing on a hot summer night. We started off with the thick soup with dried scallop, crab meat, and sweet corn (slightly sweet and seafood flavors), the deep fried bean curd with Thai style sauce (super smooth tofu and evenly fried exterior), and fried long bean with beancurd cube, nuts and minced pork (loved the salty and nutty flavor). The signature boiled chicken was of course the main event and the most prized dish on our table. The boneless chicken was amazingly smooth and could have done without any sauce or dressing because that's how tasty it was by itself. We also had the braised Chinese cabbage and the vegetables in sambal sauce, which were as excellent. This was a great and satisfying meal for the entire table and I would be more than happy to return.

Before I traveled to Singapore, I did a little survey with my friends who had been there before to see which restaurant has the best Hainan Chicken. I got about 50/50 vote for Tian Tian and Boon Tong Kee. And I tried both - Boon Tong Kee won by miles.-) Hainan Chicken Rice: I was blown away by the taste of their chicken. It's super soft yet tender (hard to explain), super moist, and with strong "chicken smell" (meaning it doesn't have a "frozen smell" sometimes you may experience if the chicken isn't well prepared). You have to try it in person to understand how it felt. The rice, although it looks like regular steam rice, it has a strong chicken taste; not very moist but if you eat with the chicken it will be the best combination.-)  (馬拉盞) Belacan Vege: another great dish. The chef cooked it very well; fresh vege and nice smell similar to shrimp paste. Very good to go with rice.-) Coffee Ribs: I heard it is a famous cooking method although it was the first time I tried. Very unique; it does have a strong coffee smell. Personally I like coffee a lot so this dish was another wonderful one.-) Crab Meat Fish Stomach Soup: pretty amazing again; a lot of crab meat and fish stomach, the soup itself can make you full. Well cooked.Definitely Boon Tong Kee is the restaurant I look forward to the most when I go Singapore again. It is a chain store with 4-5 restaurants; did a bit of map research and this location is probably the easiest accessible one for tourists staying in downtown. Right next to subway station, and Singapore Subway map is pretty self-explanatory too.I can't wait to go again!

Crab meat fish maw soup: awesome! Flavorful. Add some vinegar and white pepper powder for more taste.Chicken: Rice is delicious not too oily. Chicken is smooth and not fatty. Fresh slices of cucumber. Chilli sauce has just the right combi of chilli lime and ginger.Pretty pricey since this is a sit down restaurant. You can get their chilli to go in a glass bottle for $3.50. Expires in a year.
Hainanese Chicken Rice is one of my favorite local delicacies. Chicken is well-cooked, tender and juicy and goes really well with the gravy! A must-try food if you ever get to visit Singapore.

One of the best Hainanese chicken rice that I have ever had at Singapore. The restaurant is very crowded, but the service is friendly. +++ Chicken rice: The chicken meat is amazingly moist, tender and tasty. The chicken skin looks semi transparent with a layer of chicken broth jelly. The chicken rice that goes with it has this bold tasty flavor. The rice is not very moist for me, but it's tasty. It's an excellent dish. +++ Fish filet: The fish is fresh and crispy.  The sauce that goes with the fish is tasty and fresh. Again, there is spiciness in the sauce, yet you can still taste every single herbs and the freshness of the fish in the dish. +++Coffee pork ribs: The pork ribs were crispy and tasty. The coffee aroma woke up all your senses.  +++ Fried bean curd: It was an amazing simple dish. The bean curd was medium firm, the flour coat was crispy, but the bean curd melt in your mouth when you take the first bite. You can almost taste the tofu maker get up in the midnight and he/she put the soaked soy bean into the grinder,  followed by broiling and straining dry the beans. That's how fresh it is. +++ Seafood spinach:  The seafood broth is thick, fresh and sweet. It goes perfectly with fresh greens. Mr. Q and I were surprised by the most traditional Singapore food here, the dishes were tasty, but yet it didn't make you feel thirsty at all. If you have a short Singapore trip, but you still want to try the best local Hainanese chicken. Save your time searching, this is the place. I highly recommend this place to all my Yelpers.

Flavorful moist chicken rice with excellent ginger, soy, and chili dipping sauces. Chicken was deboned, tender, and room temp as expected. Almost served at every table in the restaurant. This was the star dish of our table. With air conditioning, this is a nicer environment to relax and enjoy the chicken rice compared to the open air hawker stalls which also have great food offerings. Indoor restaurant standard by which other chicken rice indoor vendors should be compared.

Boon Tong Kee has delicious chicken rice with its own unique sambal. It's quite different from other chicken rice that I've tried since it doesn't offer soup to come with it. The vegetables with belacan is super awesome must try. I think it is one of the best veggies side I've ever tried in my life. I went there for dinner with colleagues and wanted to take a group photo using an iPhone. But it seems that the old lady servers have never used an iPhone before. Lol.

Absolutely perfect for tourists looking for an easy transition to the local cuisine. I would recommend the boiled chicken and rice - be sure to request the chicken tepid. The food comes out in 2 minutes flat so you know the chef's working some magic back in the kitchen. Literally record setting efficiency if you think about it. They also bring you the check with the food, which is another testament to their efficiency. The proactive service is convenient because at this point in the meal you should probably pay and just walk the 50 feet to the nearest McDonalds and order a quarter pounder with cheese. All in all great dining experience.

Everyone told me before traveling to Singapore that i MUST have Chicken Rice while there. I thought... what's the big deal...I have had chicken and rice... no no no Southern Silly, this is Chicken Rice. Asked the concierge for the best Chicken Rice recommendation and he sent us here. We were so stupid excited to try the infamous chicken rice that when they brought out this little bowl of rice, we asked the waitress twice if this was really it?
