LOL I am sure we looked ridiculous....BUT.... when we tried it... omg. No Words. Little grains of perfection, writing a review about it a year later because I can never forget. Will count down the days till I get back!

So much hiked for the restaurant! we were there early in the morning before the door opened, 15 minutes pass the opening hours being told not ready yet, finally let us in at 21 minutes pass the hours. order the famous Hainanese Chicken with rice and a side of fried shrimp rolls, the food came out with the chicken bland and mushy and no taste, the shrimp rolls with a few small chunk of shrimp and water chestnut, not the one in my memories my mom had make it. the food are worst in Singapore, wondering how would so much raving for the food in the restaurant. it's a shame for the country and the local community. STOP sending tourist to taste the worst of the worst food and experience in Singapore. Thank you...

Boon Tong Kee and Tian Tian tops my list as the two places to go to when I want the best Hainanese Chicken Rice in Singapore. The flavor of their chickens and chili sauces are very similar, but their rice differs quite greatly. Boon Tong Kee's rice tends to be milder in flavor, and therefore not as oily or salty. So in the end, it's all about your preference.This particular location is located right by the MRT station and of the typical size. We had to wait a few minutes for a table even though it was after the lunch rush on a weekday. Surprisingly, our hostess was very courteous and everyone we dealt with afterwards were also gracious. This is surprising to me as in all my years living and visiting Singapore, I can count the # of good service I've gotten with just my two hands.In addition to the Hainanese Chicken Rice, we also ordered the Fried Tofu, which was one of the best fried tofus I've ever had in my life. The tofu was perfectly soft on the inside while the "crust" was golden brown and crispy. And with the sauce that they provide, it's practically heaven.If you could only have Chicken Rice once in Singapore and a Boon Tong Kee is the most convenient, you can be assured that you are getting a good representation of the unofficial national dish.

BTK is another popular chicken rice brand in Singapore, and one of my favourite too, the other being Tian Tian. Both are equally good, with its chicken meat being tender and tasty. However, BTK does come across as lighter in taste while Tian Tian is a bit more saltier. Really depends on individual liking but I like both equally.

Here's some awesome hainanese dishes being cooked. You can smell the awesome curry powder being fried and heated or from the plates of curry pork practically on every table. I had it and there is no fried pork but slices of pork coated with a thick and gorgeous curry sauce. It's difficult to tear your gaze, your chopsticks and your entire appetite to it. It's eally good, but that's not ALL.The curry fish head blew my mind. Already crazy for FISH, this fish head was fresh, tender and had nice condiments. The dishes were all well done, and it sure filled the four of us at the table till we could barely walk away.Come slightly after 830pm if you don't want to be waiting for a table. It's in the coffee shop under the HDB block so you might have to hunt.

If you've been to the Chinese restaurant, Pu tien, then Xing Hua Family Restaurant is  pretty similar to it (in terms of food selections). But, at a price that is lesser than that of Pu tien's. Food standard-wise, pretty comparable! Must tries: Ru mian and nian gao Two lines to sum up: Food is good. Everything goes well with the chilli!

The food was priced like a typical zi char restaurant located at HDB heartland. We made a mistake of ordering the fish which was priced at just below $7 per 100g. The price of the whole fish came up to about $45 which we felt wasn't worth it for the quality of the fish.Restaurant gets crowded at around 1pm when the church crowd comes in big groups. Thankfully, we called up the restaurant to make a reservation before heading there.

I LOVED this Laksa hotpot. It was so dang good!They wil offer you the option of getting 2 different broths, the laksa and chicken but I suggest you don't waste half your pot with the chicken broth and get ALL laksa (spicy coconut milk broth - not sure how to quite explain it).You get a sheet with various meats, seafood, noodles and veggies you can put in your hotpot. You must mark off everything you want - nothing comes with your initial order. We ordered quite a bit of variety (see pictures) and it was so delicious! Note: you must purchase napkins and water (nothing comes free) so I suggest you bring your own kleenex packet or wet naps if you want to save a bit of money.This restaurant isn't in downtown but only about a 20 min bus ride or 10 min uber and it's a must. One of my favorite meals I had on my trip.

Laksa taste great coz Coconut milk not too dense. Has seafood plater, beef and pork. I prefer having seafood on laksa than beef or pork. There's vegetable call Gong Do. Taste sweet and real interesting. This place kinda pricey but good. Expect stinky smell on your attire

Came here with a group of friends on a weekday evening and got treated to one of the best steamboats (aka hotpot) I've had in a while. There's no parking around, so I'd highly recommend taking public transportation or Uber. Upon entering you're  greeted with a heavy curry aroma with a shrimpy undertone that belongs to the Laksa steamboats. Kinda like alittle bit of b.o., It isn't the most appetizing of smells, but if you can get past this, you'll be richly rewarded. On the table we ordered your common hotpot ingredients: sliced beef, sliced chicken, tofu, multiple types of meatballs, and sine veggies to make us feel less guilty for the massive amounts of gluttony we were about to partake. One uncommon item I usually don't have with hotpot, or have ever really had, is the fried fish skin. Sounds gross but let me tell you that after tasting this delectable treat, I'd eat a garbage bag full of these things if given the chance. Think pork rinds but tastier and every bit as unhealthy. I didn't think the fried fish skin could be improved upon, until the locals had me dip the delectable fish chips into the Laksa broth. I know I said I'd eat a garbage bag full of the plain fish skins, but give me a supply of this Laksa broth, I'd eat these by the truck full. We had both the chicken broth with the Laksa broth (don't forget to add the Laksa herb! ), but after 3 minutes nobody ate from the chicken broth much more. Don't get me wrong, the chicken was absolutely clean and delicious, but the lala broth was like liquid crack. After the first bite, you'll be so addicted that you'll be chasing that Laksa broth high for the rest of your life. If you're a foodie and in Singapore, do yourself a favor and hit this joint up.

I read reviews about this place and decided to date my girlfriend for a dinner as this place serve nice laksa steamboa as claimed by reviews onlinet. Its located along the Telok Blangah Road. If you plan to drive down for a meal, pls be mindful that there isn't much parking lots in front of the restaurant. You have to drive round the vicinity to look for parking lots maybe there's some lot behind the building. But if you are lucky enough, you might be able to park illegally in front of the restaurant. Please note only 3 precious lots available. My Girlfriend and i was so excited to try out this laksa steamboat. We order the laska and chicken soup base to start off. After browsing the menu we ordered the usual food like mushroom, prawn, fish, beef etc. The serving is good and fresh.Guess what! After placing our food in the laksa broth, we girls decided to abandon the chicken broth as the laksa broth is simply too yummy. Our saliva is drooling and we simply can't resist it.This restaurant is on ala carte menu which means that you have to pay as you order. We order so much food and got our tummy stuff full. Not sure if there's msg in the soup base as i felt little thirsty after the meal. I wonder if the yelpers feel it too?Overall, i would definitely dine in again when im craving for laksa steamboat.Hope you like my review....
Laksa steamboat was pretty unique for my family, really enjoyed this restaurant and the soup base was great!

I love this place! Even though its location is kind of ulu, it's just a short bus ride away from Vivocity. For those who drive, don't expect to park outside of this restaurant as there are only about three parking lots, so you'll have to seek alternative parking spaces (my friends parked at a street and a church near the restaurant).  So anyway, on to the food. We tried the laksa and chicken soup base, and both were excellent. Obviously, the laksa broth was the popular choice, but I liked having the chicken soup in between every laksa portion to clear my palette. Instead of the usual steamboat buffets, this restaurant uses an ala carte system, which means that you pay as you order. Everything that came was fresh and delicious. Unfortunately, the beef was out of stock that evening and a friend didn't take pork, so we didn't get to try their meats. My friends and I over ordered and stuffed ourselves silly, but ended up only having to pay $20 per pax, which is rather cheap considering that we also ordered the more expensive drinks (about $3.50 each). Great stuff! I hope this place stays this way for a long while.

One of my fave restaurants in Singapore and definitely my all-time fave 'shabu' place. I wish there was something similar in SF/ US. - Steamboat restaurant. Think ;shabu shabu' x 10 in terms of the items you can dump into the big pot of amazing soup- Soup base: Laksa- Singapore- style. the most amazing spicy broth you'll ever taste in your life. Nothing comes close outside of Singapore. except maybe Panya in Honolulu. Don't settle for M'sian style laksa and it's Definitely not the same as Assam Laksa from M'sia. eeeeeks- Tons of items you can order to dump into this pot of amazingness; i highly recommend fishcakes, otak and the noodles. YUM. - The satay here is pretty decent, an order of it will go well with dinner- It's 1-2 bus stops away from Vivo. Absolutely worth the visit- Prices are very reasonableHighly highly recommend
Absolutely terrible, in relative to Lele Hotpot at Tiong Bahru. Patronize only if this is the last steamboat place available.

Balestier Food Market doesn't get the recognition it deserves as a pretty decent hawker. Yes, the Hawker was once empty a few months ago, but since the close of the Lavender Hawker, this place is now buzzing with fully occupied stalls.My personal favorite stalls are Ah Hui Big Prawn Noodle, Soy Chicken Noodle / char siew noodle, and John Thai. The John Thai stall in particular is truly special at the corner of the hawker (warning: a little difficult to find). Managed by a Thai family judging from the language they were speaking at the time of my order, this Thai stall is able to whip out some dishes that is very reminiscent of those found on the streets of Bangkok. I ordered the Grilled Squid and the seafood fried rice. The squid was cooked to perfection. Smokey yet chewy on the outside with a chilly like dip that is simply out of this world. I would describe it as a lemon zesty chilly spice. The other two stalls are nothing special, but good nonetheless and always nice to have in any hawker.Balestier Hawker is very clean relative to some hawkers out there and is much closer to the folks living in Novena as opposed to the Whampoa hawker. Although, the Whampoa hawker has much more famous food stalls, this is a great hawker for those who value a shorter work and a relatively cleaner dining experience.

This hawker center is about a 10 minute walk from my apartment. Whampoa is much closer, but I've frequented it far too often and grown tired with their options, so Balestier market was a bit refreshing.It's relatively small and uncrowded. I opted for John Thai during my visit- chicken basil w/rice and stuffed chicken wings. The chicken basil was a bit salty and both items had a fishy smell to them which immediately turned me off,I also opted to try their avocado smoothie from the center drink stall.1) tasted nothing like avocado-- it was extremely watered down and 2) was more brown than a fresh green, so thanks for essentially the old avocado water!I won't judge the entire place based on two stalls, so will give this the benefit of the doubt, but likely won't be returning to those two!

This hawker is a lot closer to my place than Whampoa, so I might consider eating here more often now! For the longest time, this was under renovation but I believe it finally opened again sometime in 2014. When I visited during weekday dinner, it wasn't too crowded. There are a decent variety of stalls to choose from, but still a lot of empty spots. From what I understand, since Lavender Food Square is closing, a few of their stalls might migrate here.I tried the Indian/Pakistani stall and was quite happy with the results. I ordered butter chicken, rice, and one naan for a total of $8.50. The food itself was very flavourful. Considering I was pretty hungry, I thought the portions were satisfying; I didn't need to buy anything else afterwards.  Miguel ordered some prawn noodle and he was satisfied with it as well.Some might think it's a warning sign that the stalls aren't good because there are no queues to be found, but so far I don't mind it at all. I'm all for showing some love to the underdogs. :) For the convenience and prices, I wouldn't be surprised if we start coming here once a week!
You want good chicken rice?  this is the place to come, see pic below the best. And is only $3.50 per plate, how could you go wrong!

Having lived in Balestier for the most part of my life, I have fond memories of the old Balestier wet market which provided fresh fruits, vegetables and meat to the neighbourhood's inhabitants. They have since redeveloped the market and it is now a food centre, the result being a ghost town that pales in comparison to the lively, neighbourly feel of its antecedent. The current food centre opened with high hopes, but it quickly lost numerous tenants and, today, only a few stalls are open at any given time. Furthermore, the food quality is far from satisfying, especially when you have so many better options along Balestier road. Being open 24 hours is it's major selling point, but so are lots of other places in the neighbourhood. An example of how 'progress' can sometimes be grossly misguided. Certainly not worth a visit.
Chicken rice - really goodChicken porridge - not bad will order againSlice fish soup - okteh peng - very good, abit too sweet

Every time I visit Singapore I always make it a habit to stop by this restaurant and have my usual Indian butter chicken curry. It's so delicious, buttery, savory and filling. Every bite you take with the garlic naan is Heaven. I highly recommend stopping by here if in the Little India area. Can't wait to return and hope this restaurant continues to do well. Can't lose another foodie haven.

Take making our way to the House of Tan Teng Niah for some IG photos, we stopped by Amaravati for some food. Could leave Singapore Little India and not have some Indian food. The decor of the restaurant is pretty standard. But the service from our server was amazing. He was just a sweet soft spoken guy with a huge smile on him. We ordered the chicken Kurma with garlic naan and the mutton masala with plain naan. Both dishes were delicious. They were able to tailor the spice level lower for me. The only reason I've not given 5 stars is because we spotted a dead roach at one of the tables by the doorway.

Great taste, exceptionally made and not bad on price. Actually for what you pay for, you get some exceptional food.I highly recommend the Mutton Biryani, as it was more than 1 person could eat, full of meat and spices. The Garlic Na'an bread was quite good as well.

I had the 5 curry Southern India vegetarian lunch sampler and YUM! I got there around 12 and it was next to empty but by the time I left, every table was full and for good reason. I didn't always know what I was eating but I was so happy I made the trek to Little India from MBS. During my time in Singapore I found a lot of businesses that only took MasterCard so to find one that took Visa, had free WiFi, A/C, and excellent food checked all the boxes.

One of the best Indian food I've ever had. Being a Bengali married to a Malayalee we know our food and our spice and take it very seriously. This was our first Andhra experience. Our favorite dishes are the dum biryani and most definitely the natu kodi chicken. The thaalis are great and portions huge. There's spinach and mango achars as condiments that we love every time. Don't forget the masala chai at the end. The service is always with a smile. One criticism is about the hand-washing sink. It needs to be cleaned and kept clean regularly. That's the only reason for not giving it 5stars.
Close to the subway station. Clean environment. Delicious food with a reasonable price.

Excellence in every single dish! Superb tandoori chicken, curried vegetables, the lunch set for North and South India were delicious and vegetarian), cold Tiger beer and o e yhing we always seek - ample outdoor seating. Service driendly and attentive. So good we didnt risk trying a other spot and returned for another lunch the next day.
Best Andhra food outside India. Great place for authentic South Indian food. Much better than the hyped up adjoining Indian restaurants.

The chicken biryani was good with tender chicken and tasty well cooked bismati rice. Accompanying gravy a little salty. Service was decent. Price was reasonable for a touristy area. Many restaurants in the area but the ambience was really nice. Have had better Indian food at cheaper prices though.

This is going to be my future go to place to bring foreign guests to enjoy some local Singapore Chinese food.They are not crowded over lunch so it's quite nice to chill over lunch with friends. Dinner is quite an affair and please do make reservations as they are packed.Their fishhead steamboat is tasty and the soup is flavorful. This is their main highlight so it's truly a must-order.Some of the other zi char dishes not to be missed includes their Prawn paste chicken, pork belly in Clay pot, ribs and the yam ring basket.If you like omelette, their fu yong egg is pretty decent too. Thick and fluffy. But don't look at the amount of residue oil on the plate, you'll enjoy it even more. Heh.Its near to the mrt station and has many other interesting cafes and even a durian store nearby to explore after your meal. This is my personal recommendation to bring foreign friends to, if you are looking to host. Or just a nice family meal over zi char away from your own neighbourhood.Did I mentioned that it's air conditioned too? Comfort, checked! :)

Wow..... The stewed pork knuckle is amazing. Full of meat n does not have any funny taste. I don't know abt you, but for me, most pork knuckle, when u eat the skin n the collegian underneath, there is a slight smell or after taste that u need to hide with a strong flavour like vinegar. But here, don't need to at all. Also they have a bitter gourd omellette that is not bitter at all. No bitter taste unless u eat the gourd by itself n only then u get a slight taste of it.

It's surprising that fish head steamboat can taste this good. The fish pieces are super fresh, and well flavored, and it's amazing how the meat stays tender even after hrs of boiling in that soup! I liked the taro bits and vegetables in the soup, the soup broth is very tasty, with nuances of fish, garlic and cabbage. The prawn paste chicken wings here are surprisingly good. The batter is crispy and very flavorful, and the chicken is tender. I liked the salted egg yolk prawns as well, it's a runnier version, which I like. The pork ribs with calamari strips are a must try if you are a fan of ribs. They are tender, and the crispy calamari strips really adds an interesting note to the otherwise slightly boring flavor of the ribs. I would definitely go back again!

rest_name: Geylang Bahru Market and Food Centre
comment: As a tourist. Let me emphasize that again, as a TOURIST, I found the place quite amazing. It was near the train station and I happened upon it after getting off the subway. Gelling Bahru Market and Food Centre to my understanding is one of the many hawker centers located throughout Singapore. A hawker center is basically a food court full of street food vendors. Unlike a food court that you would find at an American mall however, a hawker center has unique food as each booth is its own thing. At an American mall you would normally find chains occupying the spaces. Within the hawker center, you will find many different types of foods local to Singapore from rice dishes to soups to drinks to toast. As for which place is the one, a Singaporean put it best stating that it is a matter of personal preference. With my preference, I lean towards the rice dishes although I have heard good things about the soups and toast. Everything is cash so you will need to locate an ATM around the area since there isn't one right there where the food stalls are. I believe I went around to one of the stores until I could locate one. The food itself is super cheap so you will not be breaking the bank. For example, chicken rice was about $3 Singapore which is $2.19 USD. When you finish your food you can just leave the plate/bowl on the table and someone will take care of it. Just something to note since I myself was scared to leave trash around from rumors I heard about the country.

rest_name: Cheng Mun Chee Kee Pig Organ Soup
comment: easily the best in it's class for all things swine divine swimming in a bowl of soup!the big bowl is now $6.20 and that is what i will order sans rice.the unfiltered soup is chock full of different parts of the pig that might quite possibly be unappealing to the less adventurous.but this very perfect mix of them all, never overcooked nor ever precooked, makes for a rich comfort soup great for a cold rainy day or as a hangover cure!additional side dishes are best shared with your yelp makan kakis.steamed minced meat with salted fish, chap chye, braised groundnuts, hua tiao chicken, or my favourite, chestnuts with pork floss! simply exquisite and a rare find!do use their mild looking chilli with caution as it is nothing but piquant! do also add the quintessential dark viscous sauce to balance the spicy notes.they have done really well for themselves and expanded next door with additional seats and yet can be rather full at peak hours.you will need a table number before they take your order, so do have one ready.they are non air-conditioned, so be prepared to sweat like a pig!ultimately, you are what you eat?

rest_name: Cheng Mun Chee Kee Pig Organ Soup
comment: Good price/quality balance. For under 5 bucks, anything decent is great.If you're a bit squeamish about "organs" just pick lean meat, belly, tofu, veggies or anything else.You won't be stuck with guts.Comes with rice.

rest_name: Cheng Mun Chee Kee Pig Organ Soup
comment: A place which is super busy after midnight on a weekday doesn't need a review: you just stand in line to chope a table asap because most likely they are serving something delicious.But if you are still wondering: this place serves a great pig organ soup, the broth is a super tasty, liquid pork-y goodness and has a very generous amount of perfectly cooked pig organs to fill you up. The chili sauce compliments the organs very nicely.The fact that I am considering going again in less than 24 hrs after eating this shows that this place is a winner and that the wisdom of eating at the most busy stall seldom fails to deliver.

rest_name: Cheng Mun Chee Kee Pig Organ Soup
comment: This place opens till 5am everyday less Monday. Apart from the late closures, the best bits are the soup. The soup is so so so flavorful, with generous amounts of pig organs, pork, tofu, pork balls, and salted vegetables. They also sell a great pig trotter vinegar, which goes great on rice. The chilli sauce that comes with the soup packs a punch, beware!I can't get enough of the soup here. In any porcine visceral dish, washing the organs are of utmost importance. Any hint of unmentionables is not acceptable! You can trust that this place will serve them cleaned very very properly, in a piping hot broth you can eat on its own or with rice. There are two sizes for the soup; $4 or $6. $4 portion is best on your own. $6 if you are very hungry. I love this place. There is a place with a similar name just down the road, but this place is way better in my opinion. The environment here is gritty, but what better way to eat innards in soup?

rest_name: Cheng Mun Chee Kee Pig Organ Soup
comment: Nice soup with all the organ bits to give you different texture and flavors with each bite. Very popular so it's harder to get seats during peak time.

rest_name: Cheng Mun Chee Kee Pig Organ Soup
comment: Take your foreign friends here for that authentic side road street food if they like clear pork soup. It's delicious and they have the choice of ordering lean pork meat or pig organs to suit their fancy. Order a side of boiled vegetables.Go ahead, be adventurous--there's other stuff on the menu. ;)

rest_name: Cheng Mun Chee Kee Pig Organ Soup
comment: I don't quite understand why there isn't oodles of raving reviews for this place. I have never liked pig organ soup in particular but this place just opened my eyes up and actually made me into a pig organ lover! Definitely going on my list of local places to bring my foreign friends in Singapore! This place opens daily from 9am-5am, which is awesome for after clubbing or for breakfast. The soup broth is unreal, bursting with flavors which only boiling pig bones for hours will achieve. The stomach pieces were soft and the meatballs were yummy, although the livers are a little overcooked. I especially loved the steamed meat pie with salted fish. Very briney, very delicious. Defo my new favorite supper spot!

rest_name: Cheng Mun Chee Kee Pig Organ Soup
comment: This may get abit confusing, but I say this place and I had to eat it. For love of offals, this is too good to miss and so every time I went by to CSHH for coffee, I'd be dying to try. Finally, the day came and I was hungry enough with time on my hands to sit down for a bowl. A standard bowl's $3.70, an upsize cost $5.70. I went for the upsize, to no surprise and while I was momentarily tempted by the vinegar braised egg, at only $0.80, i decided against it to keep my virgin experience pure. SO the cloudly soup came with salted vegetables, tofu, kidney, stomach ( plenty to my joy), lean meat, liver (still pink and gorgeous), small intestines and meat balls. And everything in the mix was finished, not one was left behind along with some sos pekat and chilli. This is so good, that I missed it as soon as I was on my way home. Apparently there's an 'authentic' one down the road , but it doesn't bother me. There's no need to call my self authentic if I am really just, me.

address: 7 Temasek Blvd #01-455, Suntec City Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: Not another typical food court in Singapore.  The selection and food vendors here offer out of the ordinary choices.  A mediterrean grill, a 'low-country' seafood shack, gourmet craft burgers , K-Chicken..  the only thing missing is cold beer and Anthony Bourdain..Seating is a mess. Its first come , first serve and our party of 14 managed to snag a long table and quiet corner. I don;t know how it happened, but we managed to find seats all together.  Food is ordered from various vendors and they give you a pager to summon you back when your item is ready.The burgers from Wolf burger was good.  The sushi / poke was good too.  The seafood , crab boil was not really 'low country' boil. Instead it was covered in a dollop of the famous salted egg sauce.  This salted egg sauce is all over everything in Singapore.  I guess we have ketchup here, and Europe has mayonnaise, and Singapore has salted egg sauce..

address: 7 Temasek Blvd #01-455, Suntec City Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: Cool and funky hangout. Nice place to have causal dinner with friends.An upscale concept of food court. There are several shops offering different cuisine - Vietnamese, Grill, Western, Seafood, Sandwiches, Italian and a salad bar. They managed to squeeze In a drinks bar and fruit juice to cater for those who want a healthier option.The fancy color and whimsical decor makes the place feel fun and cheery. They play loud but not overbearing music. They definitely got the ambience thing right!Food wise - we ordered from the Grill. Ordered a Yuzu Salmon Bowl, Short Ribs Bowl and Sweet Potato Fries. Total cost was around $30. The short ribs bowl was the best, the sauce, meat and rice were perfectly done. Was really delicious! The Salmon was ok, while the sweet potatoes fries was below average. Wish we had a bottomless stomach to try the rest of the stalls. It's a great place to hang with friends over dinner and drinks.

address: 7 Temasek Blvd #01-455, Suntec City Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: We had the Konbu Prawn Linguine from Porsena. Kinda Nice.

address: 7 Temasek Blvd #01-455, Suntec City Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: PasarBella was an absolute breath of fresh air for me. I will be honest, I am not a fan of most Food courts or hawker Centers. Please do not burn me at the stake, my Texas pallet just needs a little time to adjust. I will put it this way, no adjustment needed for PasarBella. It is an inviting, hip food court. The feel is very sleek and everything is spot on. The decor is fabulous and inviting and the music is awesome. I was overwhelmed by the choices. I ordered a sushi roll from Rolly Ollies. It is by far the most delicious (and filling) sushi roll that I have had in Singapore. My Husband had a Wolf burger, sweet potato fries and a vanilla milkshake. He kindly shared a couple of sips of his milkshake with me. It was outstanding. PasarBella is the perfect jumping off point for a food court trip. I will be back!

address: 7 Temasek Blvd #01-455, Suntec City Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: Probably could be considered a high end food court. Nice variety, from local to seafood to Western/European  selections. Slightly pricey but its still good value.

address: 7 Temasek Blvd #01-455, Suntec City Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: This place is a bit hidden away in the corporate surrounds of Suntec City Mall. Seems quite new and the concept is a food court in a mall including Western food like bars, burgers and coffee shop with Asian favourites. The mix of stalls was great and would suit most appetites. I had burger from Wolf Burgers. Not bad for good old Singapore. Bottom lime nice concept & good fresh food!

address: 7 Temasek Blvd #01-455, Suntec City Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: Came here for dinner last sat night. Wasn't too difficult to get a seat for 4 at 7 so that was pretty good. We waited about 5 mins?Food overall was disappointing. Looked/smelt better than it tasted.Wagyu onsen bowl$14.90Looked amazing in the pics and the first bite was heaven. I loved the mix of the sauce/egg/rice. Amazing; might almost pay just for that. However found the beef lacking, it was too chewy and also rubbery. Not sure if it was because it was too raw or that it was just like that. Chorizo sausage$6.90Didn't like this at all. Truffle mash $2Friend liked this but I found it extremely average. Creamy spinach $2I quite liked this. Reminded me a little of panek paneer. Decent to shareLambFriend ordered and said it was good. The Mexican store.Friend tried it and thought it was average. I tried the hummus, it was ok but I wouldn't order next time.Seafood storeFriend ordered the grilled fish. It took around an hour to arrive! So we pretty much weren't hungry by then and found it average. Sides of Chicken luncheon chips and sweet potato fries were very average too. Probably wouldn't go back unless someone really wanted me to

Upgrading this to 5 star because for S$6.80 for a thali that has a daal, vegetable and a chicken curry, basmati rice, yoghurt is really a steal. Their appetizers with beer are really nice and the free flow of papadum with green chutney is a good gesture from them.Good momos with a nice red sauce.Can be very crowded on Sunday afternoons and probably need a reservation on friday and saturday dinners.

This cute restaurant is a little off the main roads of little india but so worth a visit. Got there early and were the only guests there so we had a little chitchat with the owner of the place - super nice guy. Food was delicious. Minus one point for the mango lassie that had kind of a weird taste to it.

Recommended place to have good panner snacks and vegetarian momos. Probably one of the few restaurants in Singapore to server authentic Momos. Service is good. Need to increase types of draft beer as the choice currently is very limited. Overall an average place to enjoy drinks and a very nice one to enjoy momos

Food here were awesome. Full of test and aromas. I liked the Nepali thali, Momos, papaya shrimps and alot. Service was fast and helpful.I recommend this place.... if i visit Singapore then will be going to this place for lunch and dinner.

What an excellent gem! We found this place strolling from the MRT and were pleasantly surprised! We had the chicken tandoori, palak paneer, and dalal makhli and all were so delicious! The owners were very friendly and made us feel nice and cozy! We'll be back for sure!

The best Nepali restaurant in Singapore as far as i'm concerned. This place has it all worked out. Great food, charming ambience and friendly people. Waiting for dishes is not too bad. However the dishes are really solid. The palak paneer is amazing. The veg chowmin is a super yummy noodles that serves 2 people easily for just $5. This is the kind of place you go to with a few friends or the family and order a couple of dishes that should be shared. They even have a really interesting coffee called the Mustang coffee that has a little bit of rum in it. This place along with apollo are my favorite 2 places in little india.
Excellent food every time! We have meals here a couple times a month. Very affordable and very near lavender metro!

address: 100 Orchard Rd #02-22/26, Concorde Hotel Singapore Singapore 238840 Singapore
comment: Very nice Japanese BBQ joint tacked in the Hotel - I guess this is the secret Japan town from 90s with the original Japanese owner.Food quality is excellent, service is what you'd expect from Japanese venue. Quality is superb. The lady running the shop is super sweet, she's very helpful and I was really happy to find myself and my business client dinning in this great place.

address: 100 Orchard Rd #02-22/26, Concorde Hotel Singapore Singapore 238840 Singapore
comment: One of the best Yakiniku in Singapore. Go for the unusual cuts eg beef intestines (Gobchang) & the flank ribs.

address: 100 Orchard Rd #02-22/26, Concorde Hotel Singapore Singapore 238840 Singapore
comment: It's good but not the best I've tried. Tried the BBQ during lunch, had the lunch set with the beef and tongue. I haven't tried many jap BBQ in Singapore yet so I don't know if I can agree with the rest of the reviews that say it's the best. Comparing to LA jap bbq's like manpuku, or Hong kong's 298 NIKUYA, this one is not quite there yet for me. So 3.5 stars round up to 4.

address: 100 Orchard Rd #02-22/26, Concorde Hotel Singapore Singapore 238840 Singapore
comment: best yakiniku place in town! we used to love gyu-kaku, but then they changed the tare sauce, and we moved to ao-chan :) get the belly tender prime, and ox tail soup. they're really good. some folks like the shiso rice too.

Aston's does not skimp on quantity.Aston's does not skimp on quality.You'll get so much BANG for your BUCK here that it's almost unbelievable. The steaks are cooked beautifully and are accompanied by a motley crew of side dishes that are also a delight to the senses.PEW PEW! PEW PEW!Whoa. Did you hear that? Sounds like an AWESOME-RESTAURANT-LOCATER-GUN and it has its crosshairs dead set on Aston's. Come here... or... don't...... but you really should.

If you're looking for Morton's, you've come to the wrong place. But! If you're looking for affordable steaks, fish or fried chicken (!!!), in a pleasant environment, this is your place! I usually get the Prime Ribeye/Xtra cut or New York Strip with baked potato and steamed veggies. The Crispy Fried Chicken is also amazing!The mushroom soup was a little too thick and tasteless for my liking. The house wine wasnt bad. Service is quick and friendly.

Great place to have dinner / lunch.... good food at good price. I went there many times with my wife. I liked their steaks, I tried different ones, all of them tastes really good. Usually there's a long queue in dinner time... keep ~20 minutes in hand.

One of the best places to have a weekend or Friday evening dinners. Food is alright. Price is value for money. Have not missed having dinners at Aston's. Keep up the good work! We will visit again. Just live your sides. Tasty and fabulously delicious. Trust me. Try their fish and chicken meals. Only set back is the drinks in the meal deal are a tad bland. Just my two cents worth - improve this and you will be an awful restaurant. As you know drinks is an important part of a meal. Hope you improve this and you will become a great restaurant joint. Other than this Aston's is our choice restaurant for a long long time. We will not hesitate to recommend to anyone and everyone who is hungry or just want a table to have a meal.

Affordable, delicious and unpretentious steak. That's what you get here at Astons. While they do serve up a mean array of grilled chicken and fish, the main focus definitely has to be on the steaks that are comparable to many other restaurants, albeit at a much cheaper price. Service is fairly efficient, though they've gotten the doneness of my steak wrongly a few times. But they rectify it almost immediately once you get their attention. Must haves are their porterhouse cut and ribeye steak with extra cut. I've been dining here for years when I'm lazy to dress up to eat elsewhere or when I just don't feel like spending a lot on food.

I've always seen mad long queues at Astons and always wondered if the queue was well justified. I had to find out of course on a day when there was no queue. I ordered the honey bourbon ribs. It was fabulous. Above my budget for the dish at $24.50 but damn it's great. The meat slips off the bone like melted butter. The honey flavour on the meat really accented the sweet flavor of the meat. The dish came with a wonderful side dish of mashed potatoes that worked pretty flawlessly with the meat. I also ordered a vienna sausage which was really the dish that stole the show. A small simple sausage dish that you must try to have a clue why i would give this place a 5 star rating. My iced chocolate was the only thing i have to complain about because it was fantastic but there was too much ice in the drink. So by the time i had a 3rd sip, the drink was over. Best part about this place, the food came in approximately 10 mins. Astons is a great joint for a good meal.

address: 1 Zubir Said Dr #01-04/05/06/07, School of The Arts Singapore 227968 Singapore
comment: Good quality Korean BBQ AYCE buffet.I am typically not a big fan of AYCE buffets as I find the quality typically below par and since I have little self control when it comes to buffets, I tend to overeat, feeling guilty afterwards since it is not worth the calories (hey, don't judge me, I bet you do as well).However, I'm Kim has a good variety of meats, most of which we tried and approved of - especially the beef selection is large and better than your average buffet (try the galbi ribs). In addition, they have a decent choice of cooked sides, soups and other banchan.The only downside I can think of is that the grill is on the smallish side for the table but that helps you stop overeating so actually it is almost a plus. Also, in contrast with most kbbq's the staff is quite prompt in clearing the table so you always have sufficient space.The fact that it was completely packed on Saturday evening and had a line in front (which we could easily cut since we called up front for reservations) shows that I am not the only one who likes this place! Planning to go back!

address: 1 Zubir Said Dr #01-04/05/06/07, School of The Arts Singapore 227968 Singapore
comment: Visited during phase 2. Instead of buffet style, it became table service. The orders are indicated on the paper and handed to the waiter and Food will be delivered to your table. The drinks got refilled pretty fast.

address: 1 Zubir Said Dr #01-04/05/06/07, School of The Arts Singapore 227968 Singapore
comment: Came here twice already (lunch and dinner) and both times we ate ourselves silly. Lunch is cheaper but also had fewer choices in the meat/seafood dept. There were no prawns, galbi ribs, nor "volcano chicken" during lunch but was available during dinner. Ingredients were fresh and abundant. Galbi ribs were perfect. Also has a large offering of hot foods like mandus, french fries, soup, noodles, rice, etc.I like how the price is all inclusive including unlimited non-alcoholic drinks. Excellent service in keeping your table and grill clean. Be warned, at dinner we were given a 1.5 hour seating time limit. Sufficient for us, but may not be for others.

address: 1 Zubir Said Dr #01-04/05/06/07, School of The Arts Singapore 227968 Singapore
comment: One of the most variety of meats and side dishes you will find! Decently price and they offer coupons as well. I've been here three times already and have yet to feel disappointed. This place can get super crowded and the tables are placed too close together. It tends to run into other people and may not have much room to work with if you have a large group.

address: 1 Zubir Said Dr #01-04/05/06/07, School of The Arts Singapore 227968 Singapore
comment: After watching streams of people queue up for I'm Kim Korean BBQ for years at SOTA. I finally decided to give it a try. It's main target audience are youngsters or students who want some korean bbq at a reasonable price. The prices range from $19.90++ to $24.90++ for weekend lunches. Check out therir facebook page as they randomly have facebook promotions just like the one they had on the day I visited, at just $19.90++ per pax for a group of 6 and more!They have a rather huge dining area, that can fit pretty much any party size. The minute you walk in, you will realize the drinks are on the right, cooked food is displayed against the wall at the back of the restaurant and all the tables are in a horizontal layout, parallel to the main street. You will also notice that it doesn't have a strong bbq smell, that most girls are afraid of smelling like, after the meal! Do not fret as they have vents to suck up the BBQ smells, there's even ocsilating fans to keep the air fresh.At the cooked food station, there's some sushi, soup, korean pancakes, noodles and steamed rice. I highly recommend trying their fried chicken wings.They are HUGE! Not to mention, these chicken wings put 4 Fingers to shame! The skin is so crispy, the meat is tender and the sauce has a tangy sweetness to it.Pick your vegetables and seafood too! The prawns were fresh looking and rather sizeable. The variety of vegetables should be sufficient for most. They were replenished frequently too! Lots of vegetables to go along with the meat. Lettuce is fresh and crazily crunchy and it is a MUST HAVE for me at Korean BBQs because I always use them to wrap up my meat.Moving onto the actual bbq, the bbq surface area was decent enough for 4, you could separate your meats, ie (beef, non-beef or spicy and non-spicy) The hot plate itself got hot pretty quickly and you can control the temperature on the side of the hot plate.I would usually cook the beef atop the vegetables, such as onion or mushroom, so that the vegetables would absorb all the juices from the meat and at the same time, the meat would be good in a reasonable amount of time.After cooking, the meats were tender and juicy. Definitely better than I had expected. Grab a plate or two and stack them up with meats and also get ready to stack up another plate of cooked food! Also, to my pleasant surprise, the staff were extremely friendly and taught us how to cook and eat the meats with the vegetables. I had no problems getting the staff attention whenever I needed help or assistance.They had a varienty of meats, such as marinated ribeye, beef roll, pork belly, chicken and for those who love spicy. Go for their volcano style seasoned meats, you will not be disappointed.Check out the colours of the beef and also the mountain of raw meats, eying for an empty spot on the BBQ hot plate! The Beef Rolls cook fast and I cut them up into even pieces. These fine slices of beef are delectable and easy to eat. They are savoury but not overwhelming, and make for the perfect start to my Korean BBQ feast.The bacon strips were my favourite. Probably the most unhealthy, but it was salty and juicy, overflowing with fatty goodness. The meat also so very soft and fresh. Bacon lovers will probably love the unlimited amounts of bacon available here.There's also free flow of non-alcholic drinks such as iced water, lime juice, mango juice, rice punch and korean barley tea. All the drinks tasted rather diluted to me but the sweetest drink for me which I liked was the rice punch. They also sell alcoholic drinks for those who want a complete Korean bbq meal!Conclusion : I'm Kim delivered great value meats and cooked food buffet with excellent staff service and atmosphere.Head here for a fuss free korean BBQ that is gentle on your wallet!

address: 1 Zubir Said Dr #01-04/05/06/07, School of The Arts Singapore 227968 Singapore
comment: Been wanting to try this place for the longest time and finally made it here on a Saturday. Crowded but thanks to a friend who arrived early we got a table for 3 easily. the spread is not big but the quality is good especially in the meat section- pork belly, pork collar, and marinated galbi, garlic chicken were fresh and tasty. The spiciest volcano chicken was something to be reckon with! unless chilli padi is your best friend or that you enjoy the sensation of having a numb tongue and sausage lips, don't bother trying it out. the sides of Korean fried chicken, candied sweet potato, tteokbokki. japchae, chicken soup, seafood (namely shrimp/prawn), lettuce, drinks etc weren't too shabby as well. The only down side was that I was seated under the television and it was really loud. We were given only 90 mins for the buffet but it was more than enough to fill my belly... maybe guys will have a different opinion. Definitely will give it a 2nd try on a weekday for comparison.

address: 1 Zubir Said Dr #01-04/05/06/07, School of The Arts Singapore 227968 Singapore
comment: I'm torn between two and three stars, but I'm going with two because this restaurant is relatively famous. I've tried a few kbbq buffet places in random malls, and they are usually okay because when everything fails, one can eat chadol (thinly sliced beef brisket) with ssamjang and lettuce and be completely satisfied paying $24 since meat is so expensive in Singapore. Not this place. I'm Kim somehow managed to make ssamjang that's just wrong.There is a range of ssamjang flavors that can all be acceptable but the ssamjang here is not within that range. This affects everything you eat in kbbq because it's the basic sauce. In most kbbq places in Singapore, the meat is not of great quality (unlike Los Angeles where they somehow get good meat and low prices). Usually the chadol is edible because there is no marinate to screw up, and it wasn't a great cut to begin with. Kalbi on the other hand is always bad because they use the wrong ribs (kalbi is not just any rib) plus the marinate could be wrong. Everything else depends on the marinate, so I usually try it but don't count on it. Here, none of the meats work. The kalbi is surprisingly the least offensive.The vegetable options are bad. The kimchi and any seasoned namul have a strange seasoning. I do highly recommend the pickled daikon for pairing with meats that are overly marinated to tone it down. I would prefer a more tender green leaf lettuce than the romaine leaves they offered.There seemed to be a lot of side dishes but I felt like there wasn't much to eat. The japchae was the best side dish. It was strange to see samosas. Honeyed sweet potatoes are dessert not appetizer. I skipped the fries and mandu.I managed to feed myself but I won't be coming back. Service was fine. The guy came by to change the grill once.

address: 1 Zubir Said Dr #01-04/05/06/07, School of The Arts Singapore 227968 Singapore
comment: An all you can eat Korean BBQ joint surrounded by Schools with plenty of students in the area. Feels like the places back home. There are a good variety of meats to choose from, pork loin belly, marinated beef, marinated short ribs... not bad, I liked the pork loin belly myself, but that's what I normally eat when I'm having bqq. The selection seems to be centered around the meats which isn't a bad thing. There is plenty of kimchee, lettuce wrap, picked dikon wrap, and garlic and peppers to litter your ssam.Definitely better than what I would expect at an all you can eat bbq joint and better than the BBQ buffets back home for sure. This place is more value and bang for the buck. Amongst bbq buffets I'd say 4 stars, but relative to other kbbq places 3 stars for quality of meats. Maybe because I can't eat as much as I used to during my younger days, but I don't value the quantity as much as I used to.

address: 1 Zubir Said Dr #01-04/05/06/07, School of The Arts Singapore 227968 Singapore
comment: The food was decent, alcohol was overpriced. My biggest complaint is about the size of the grills. If you have six chairs to a table I expect the grill to facilitate six people, instead It facilitated only about four people at a time. Definitely a social experience but It left me more hungry than a buffet should have.

address: 1 Zubir Said Dr #01-04/05/06/07, School of The Arts Singapore 227968 Singapore
comment: Very cheap all you can eat BBQ in Singapore! The quality of meats was not the best but for the price, I'm not complaining. There's a variety of Korean dishes available and the juices were good. It was refreshing to hear some Korean music after weeks of music I didn't understand. Seemed to be mostly locals and saw no foreigners.

address: 1 Zubir Said Dr #01-04/05/06/07, School of The Arts Singapore 227968 Singapore
comment: Best value for money Korean BBQ Buffet in town! Food is fresh and delicious and we are having a tough time to choose because all are so good! You'll need to starve yourself first to have the best of it. Enjoy!!

address: 178 Clemenceau Ave #B1-00 Haw Par Glass Tower Singapore 239926 Singapore
comment: Ok, first off I have to admit I may be a little biased since a friend of mine runs the place, but I promise you will thank me later for introducing this newly-opened bar n bistro.The concept of the place is simple: premium craft beers at affordable prices. While they have a kitchen serving brunch and tapas (try the Truffle Chips!), the biggest drawing factor for me is definitely the all-day bar which serves American craft beers. In case your hipster friend hasn't already let you in on the latest booze to hit town, craft beer has been popping up in cool cafes like Assembly Ground and Morsels (you know, the kind that has wooden clipboard menus). But as far as I know, Hop Heads is the first bar that is dedicated to craft beers only (their headliner is "Craft Beer Bar and Bistro"). Craft beer is like the whiskey of booze. It's a lot more complex than your regular heineken or tiger beers, so it's like a whole new experience with every gulp. If you have a good palette, you'd probably be able to describe the craft beer like connoisseurs talk about wine ("a hint of clove" "an apple aftertaste") but if you're just a regular jane like me it's just pretty cool that you can actually smell the flavours before (and after!) you taste it. So naturally you'd think that such speciality beers would be pricier than usual, but here comes the kicker - the entire bar is priced lower than anything you'd find along clarke quay. With beers and ciders ranging from $8-$15, most of the patrons guzzle about 2-3 bottles or pints each. Yes! They have 2 beers on tap. Go To IPA seems to be the more popular one but my favourite is the Summer Solstice. It's seasonal though so I'm waiting to see what's going to replace it.Besides the summer solstice on tap i would recommend the hazelnut brown nectar - it's really amazing!!!! And my lager-loving friends love the oatmeal lager (it sounds funky but apparently its so good they cant get enough). So if you're in town around dhoby ghaut (or happen to be staying at Innotel Hotel) , this is an awesome place for a mid-day beer or  after-dinner drinks. See u there!

address: 178 Clemenceau Ave #B1-00 Haw Par Glass Tower Singapore 239926 Singapore
comment: Ok firstly, it is stuffy af as it's located in the basement. Secondly, the staff were very rude and oblivious. Thirdly, the prices are overpriced for the quality of food. I just have to say that the cheese tasted so cheap and fake, kinda like those type of cheese mix with mayo (those hawker Center cheese fries is even way better). Fourthly, there was so little sauce that we ordered another side of sauce (salted egg yolk as seen). It came to use in watery sauce???? OMG. Disgusting. Fifth, we Can find cheaper pizza with better quality. Six, Staffs eager to clear plates when we are not done eating and interrupted us in our conversation. Super rude and disrespectful. Only good thing is that there's games here. Wouldn't come back.

Just had a bean curd from stall #01-52. It was the original genre, not Lao Ban type of curd. I ordered 莲子白果豆花。The bean curd was smooth and silky. Syrup wasn't too sweet. The lotus seed and gingko were cooked till soft but not too mushy. I highly recommend you to visit this stall as such traditional bean curd is a rare find nowadays.

A place to try local Singaporean dishes , Southeast Asian cuisine , juice drinks. Food stall in rows that will tease your palate. It is a hustle and bustle market place on weekend. Dont expect too much on service for it is the typical Asian style food center and market . However it will satisfy your taste buf. Food is Ok . They dont provide receipts and preferred cash.

So I've been going to this eating place quite frequently these days. It is quite accessible from my home either by bus or car (duh!). Parking can be quite a pain in the ass especially on weekends, and sometimes even on weekdays too (dinner time). Anyway, moving on! Personally, to be honest, IMHO, the best prawn hokkian mee is located here! You could easily tell by the ridiculous queue most of the time! However, it is pretty efficient because the staff would ask about your order and get it done while you're still in line, the next thing you know, BAM, your hokkian mee is done! I'd suggest to always order the $5 one in medium portion even when you're alone. The smallest size ($4) plate simply isn't worth it. The next best thing I found here, that is less mainstream is large steamed fish head in black bean sauce ($15) with rice. They put a lot of ginger in it (which is my fave)! The fish is always fresh with soft texture, accompanied with tons of bones! Must slowly eat! I also tried fried yong tau foo! I tried about 5 different kinds: (Not sure about the names but I'll try to describe it)1. Fried yam in orangish color (meh!)2. Flat keropok in yellow color with some prawns (meh!)3. Ngoh hiang (yay!)4. Fried fish cake in tofu skin (yay!)5. You tiao stuffed with fish (between meh and yay)Drinks?Grass jelly jumbo size please!!!Note:I heard good things about the porridge stall located near the hokkian mee and they have salmon porridge! The nasi lemak stall located at the corner seems to always have a long line too! I'll probably go try it next time...I'll definitely be back!

This is not my usual haunt as it is not that easy to get here unless you drive or live nearby. The place is quite airy, even when seated inside, thanks to its high ceiling and plentiful fans around. Besides the popular duck rice/porridge stall (near the rojak place), and Hoover rojak, it also houses the corner fish steamboat stall at the back. We shared the rojak which was really good with plenty of crushed peanuts and sauce. I had the Teochew Beef Noodles which was not very nice. Maybe I was expecting smooth silky thin kway teow like Hock Lam, so this version was the thick sticky kway teow which stuck together. The uncle was very nice though. I love the coffee at Seletar Coffee (facing the car park), near the Chinese dessert stall. It was thick and milky. And it was cheap when compared to other places. I heard it used to be 50 cents but the price has since increased. Still, for 2 small cups of coffee and an iced coffee, it was under $2.50. Where else can you get such prices? Yelp Feb 2014 Challenge: 20/28

Thanks to Nik T. for introducing this hawker to us!My husband and I frequent this place for dinner on the weekend, as it's a nice walk from our apartment and it's easy on our wallet. This place is legit Singaporean realness because every time we go the locals are always here in full force, which makes seating a bit of a challenge. Thanks to Nik T.'s suggestion, my husband is ALL OVER the $8 oyster omelette at Ah Hock Fried Oyster, stall #54. I'm a fan of the seafood fried rice, but at this moment I'm not sure what the stall number is... will have to get back to you on that. It's served with pickled jalapeno on the side, and if I weren't already married, it would've been my next choice for a future life partner. I'm also a fan of the hokkien mee. Again, I forgot the stall number, but it's one of those stalls that always has a line so it's not hard to miss. And the chicken wings in stall #76! Those are always a good time.Add my favorite sugar cane juice with the above dishes, and all is well with the world. Guess I need to head back again so I can verify the stall numbers and lead you all in the right direction. ;)

Thankfully our taxi driver recommended this to us when we asked for some good street food. Although again, not the easiest to get to with the MRT. We had to take a bus transfer, but thanks to the kindness of strangers, we managed to find it perfectly due to their instruction. Plenty of open (and closed stalls), and a lot of them sell the same or similar items, so you just have to choose which one to go to. I tended towards the stalls with longer lines in hopes that also meant delicious food. I got a yummy and cheap wonton noodle soup and a beer, while my friend ordered a Singapore chicken rice and a lo po gao. All so very delicious. The dessert stalls were a bit lacking, but we managed to find one where I ordered a black rice pudding. Delicious and not overly sweet. Thank you, taxi driver! P.S. You have to pay to use the bathrooms, bring your own tp, and don't forget the water to wash the waste!

One of the oldest neighbourhoods in the area, Whampoa's Makan Place has a very local feel and offers lots of fantastic food options. They have for instance, a good nasi lemak stall and pretty famous hokkien mee and wonton mee stalls. A great place to have a sampling of local dishes, and the general Singaporean vibe of the place adds to the authenticity of the experience. Forget Newton Circus - Whampoa isn't that far off, and the prices are far more reasonable with equally delicious food to boot.

Whampoa Makan Place is located just off Balestier road on Whampoa Drive. They offer a big variety of different food. My personal favourite would be the wontan noodle store, which so far has been my favourite place to lunch in all Balestier. It only costs 3 dollars, is clean and quick to deliver. This is a typical hawker centre, you will find many tables all squashed into a space that so many tables shouldn't be able to physically fit in, but I guess the set up works for everyone. The cleanliness is not the best you will find, though there are many cleaners constantly working at maintaining the cleanliness of the hawker centre, the place never seems to be kept clean! Rubbish sprayed all over the place, tissues and wrappers you will find on tables and the floor. This is a practical place to have a quick and cheap meal, no room for comfort here.

There are two blocks of food stalls that make up Whampoa Hawker Centre (Whampoa Makan Place is a new name they slapped on the hawker centre after they renovated the place). Roughly defined, block 91 (opposite the wet market) is the breakfast block while Block 90 is the lunch/dinner block.The variety of food across the two blocks is large and there are a lot of popular stalls with food that is well worth the calories. At the breakfast block there are two linked stalls that sell noodles in the morning, close in the afternoon to prepare for their dinner business, and open in the evening to sell a very popular fish head steamboat. The original Loy Kee Chicken Rice is also at this block, and is near the corner where you can get really good Tau Huay that is made using traditional methods.The lunch/dinner blocks has even more hits. Singapore Friend Hokkien Mee, Hoover Rojak, the duck rice/porridge stalls, Ah Hock Fried Oyster Omelette, chicken wings, the nasi padang stall in the centre, etc.Basically, it's got what every good hawker centre has--great food at low prices.Don't mind the mess too much. Sometimes the cleaners take a while to get to all the tables. But you can help by not making too much of a mess.
The hokkien mee is great here in my humble opinion.... Do it!

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: This little secret is great, relaxed Indian food. Quality is excellent, price is very good value. The staff are so friendly. Everything from the onion pakhora to the tikka (fish and chicken), the Dahl, the usual Indian breads, it's all fabulous food, eaten in the outside tables under cover so relaxed and breezy. Highly recommended!

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: The one thing I immediately learned when moving abroad was to immediately find your own comfort food, and I've been delighted to find Tandoori Corner in Balestier to serve as my refuge for those moments I just need Indian food.They do not by any means deliver their food on that "home cooked" taste, it is still very much restaurant-esque with heaps of butter and oil, but suffice to say they are delicious and consistent with their taste delivery.My go-to's, depending on my mood, range from their yellow punjabi daal, to butter chicken, rogan josh, or malai chicken with garlic naan.I usually opt to take out as I don't think I'll ever adjust to this Singapore heat and they do not have indoor seating or aircon, but their service is quick, responsive, and you're welcome to take a seat (I always choose to sit by the fan!) while your food is prepared. I'd definitely pay them a visit if you're in the area.

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: In general, I'm not a big fan of eating outdoors, but Tandoori Corner is definitely worth dealing with the heat and humidity for some really good Indian food.  I have been here twice for lunch and I have been really impressed with how flavorful and balanced the food tastes, without being overly spicy.  The chicken tikka plater is a great sampler with succulent chicekn and some sides, such as dhal, rice, paneer, and naan.  It's a great set which includes a drink all for $12.  The briyani was also very good.  The rice was fresh and not dry at all, seasoned perfectly and again the chicken was outstanding with a generous portion.  I also loved the fact that they use boneless and skinless chicken, so that's another big plus :).

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: The menu here was pretty extensive and reading thru other people's reviews, we tried some of their favourites:Onion Bhaji - my kids attacked this dish as its a starter. They loved it so much they even ate their deep fried curry leaves that was in it! Hubby said this was like extreme Muruku. Onion strips with Muruku coating! Must eat there, fresh and crispy!Butter Chicken - buttery and creamy and just delightful. My girl was practically drinking the sauce! Mutton Tikka - they didn't have it on their menu but this is a FAVOURITE dish of my hubby's and their chef very generously said yes. So they made that dish specially for him. It was also another hit with my children. Even I was impressed. I have tried many others and theirs was really one of the better ones. Rogan Josh - lamb chunks cooked in spicy curry. I swear mutton is not the easiest meat to handle and they do it right! And the curry sauces are seriously distinct from each other but still oh-so-yummy!!!Aloo Gobi - I was slightly disappointed when I saw their it was quite dry with no sauce. But the taste just knocked my socks off. Seriously one of the best Aloo Gobi I have eaten. I could finish bowls of this!Chicken Biryani - this was served in this deceptively small bowl with lovely spiced rice and tenderly cooked chicken chunks. My girls LOVED the chicken in this dish. And after many spoons of rice was eaten, the bowl still looked kinda half full!! Hub and I was so full after we finished the rice but no regrets there. Butter and Garlic Naans - this was another great dish. We ordered 2 first and then had to top up with another naan. Evident that my girls were just packing the naans away!!!We are seriously fans of this very understated eatery now. The service is swift and very sincere.

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: This is probably my favorite North Indian cuisine restaurant in Singapore! Simply my go to place on either take away or eating there with friends.

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: We got Punjab Dhal (lentil soup), tandoori chicken and garlic and plain naan and samosa. All so delicious! We will make this place our regular once a week spot. I don't give 5 starts but this place deserves it.

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: This is our go-to place for Indian food in our neighborhood. (Ooh look at me and my fancy rhymes!)I love Indian food, but my husband? Not so much. However, he doesn't mind the dishes here. They've won us over with their butter chicken: big chunks of tandoori chicken in a creamy, not spicy tomato sauce. Mmm! If we're really hungry, we add in an order of butter naan (because if we're going to eat a "buttered" main, we might as well go big or go home!) As for their other dishes, the chicken tikka masala is very solid, and I thought their rogan josh was pretty good too (a bit spicy, though.) Note that they are located in the corner of Balestier Plaza, with outdoor seating only. The service is friendly and prompt. We've been here when it rains, and the staff is pretty good at moving the tables and chairs a bit further in to ensure nothing gets wet. Also, if it's busy, they always manage to pull a table out of nowhere and set it up for you. So far, we've never made reservations and we've been lucky to get a table each time. I do find it a bit pricy for a restaurant that is outdoor seating only, but the quality of the food makes up for it. The portions are just right, as well.Solid choice for Indian food if you're in the Balestier area!P.S. They do have a TV inside the small bar area, but you can't really hear it if you're outside.

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: Nice location. Had a team lunch here. Very good & prompt service. Food was tasty. Onion pakkora, palak paneer were good. My friends liked the tandoori chicken. Briyani was very nice too.

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: I just got back from a week-long trip in New Delhi. For those who don't know me, I'm not the biggest Indian Cuisine fan in the world. However, based on my latest gastronomic experience in India, I can safely conclude that this Indian shop is the REAL DEAL. Not only is this restaurant better than any restaurant I tried in the Motherland, but also the chance of getting Delhi belly is zero. A true win-win for sure. My favorites at this restaurant are the (i) Butter chicken, (ii) Chicken Tikka masala and (iii) butter naan. One has to wonder why one would need to go to Delhi, when you have this shop in Balestier. Two words: Taj Mahal. :D

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: Great place ! I live 100 m away from this place, so I visit them at least once a week for a late dinner. The service is good, the guys there are very friendly! Food is great ! Mine favorites are tandoori chicken and butter chicken!

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: Being an habitué of travel to India, I was pleased to find a North Indian restaurant in my neighbourhood. You always know the food is going to be authentic when they not only have Kingfisher beer on the menu, but also Kingfisher Strong. Tandoori Corner did not disappoint. The food was excellent. I greatly enjoyed the murgh malai tikka, fish tikka and their assortment of naans. The tikka dishes were note-worthy, and the accompanying mint sauce was as authentic as you can get. I was instantly transported to my favourite spot in Delhi! It certainly is pricey in comparison to other eating places in Balestier. We paid slightly over S$40 for two. It was, however, a real treat and a nice change from the usual fare in Balestier. My only real gripe about this place is the set-up. Situated next to a clinic in Balestier Plaza, there is no indoor sitting space and the tables have been placed along the corridors of the neighbourhood mall. Not very picturesque at all.

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: Terrific tandoori and naan, try the lamb chops if you have any taste buds at all. They'll blow you away. I'm pretty close to Little India but the food here is good enough that I usually end up going here instead. Friendly service and they always manage to find a table, even when it's full.

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: This restaurant was recommended by friends and we decided to check it out on Saturday evening.  The restaurant is pretty basic, with tables set up outside the restaurant. Service was quick and we after we spoke to the owner, we let him order for us.To cut a long story short, the food was great, much better value than many of the overpriced Indian restaurants closer to the tourist areas of the city. The lamb chops in particular were so good we had to order some more. Service was brisk but friendly. Only advice would be to watch out for the Kingfisher with 8.8% alc by volume. It will catch out the unwary if you don't realise just how strong it is compared to other beers.We will definitely be back

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: favorite go to neighborhood dining spot.  Never had a bad meal here.  Esp. enjoyed the butter chicken and  butter naan.  Best of all no queue to get in and staff is friendly.Well priced.

rest_name: Tandoori Corner North Indian Curry House
comment: On a corner in a mall, but great place from food point of view. I waited for my food but when it came it was worth the wait; it is cooked fresh and the lamb tikka was so tasty. Am surely coming back for more!

The Enchanted cafe is situated in Little India. It's such a cute decor setting cafe - perfect to their name! I had made a Sunday brunch reservation through their FB page & so getting a seat was not a problem. The cafe is small but the decor & vibe will totally make you feel like In the sets of Harry Potter. The server was very sweet & friendly! This was my first visit & I wanted to try their famous Elixir drink- it was just perfect summer drink, very relaxing & the effects of dry ice gave it a real magical potion feel!! We loved the Creamy Carbonara & Choco-nana-tella toast. The food is presented very well & everything tasted so good!! The prices seemed fair & reasonable. The restaurant is going to relaunch after a week with new menu & look! Although I am sad that their Elixir drink won't be included.. I am excited to return to see the new look & try their new menu! This is definitely one of my fav cafes so far.. Can't wait to return.

It's amazing that this cafe was around for a year and I have not been here! Probably it was over-shadowed by Old Hen next door? ;)Beautiful dried flowers surround the cafe and it looked as if you've indeed stepped into an enchanted forest. Not to worry, there's not too much green that it might be scary for those with sensitive noses, like me. The wooden chairs/tables (though not all consistent in type) complemented the plants/dried flowers very well. My favourite, was the wall of oddities right next to the main door - you wouldn't even know that they were selling wrapped novels from The Novel Encounter (see pictures).Anyway, we were partly enticed by the promotion that the cafe is having now, that's why we headed there - Order a burger and get a specialty coffee for $1(Promotion valid til 13 April!)Verdict:* Ngoh Hiang Burger (with extra side of scrambled eggs as recommended by the lady boss) - The patty was juicy but I felt it was a tad small (I love patties, so the bigger the better!). The cold potato salad was heavenly; not sure what spices or herbs they used but I love the herb-y taste. The buns themselves were not too big but were nicely crisp on the outside. Overall, quite a creative dish.* Truffle fries - This didn't make it to my Top 5 list but the truffle smell did last longer and tasted better then average. A good snack to order should you decide to sit for a while longer and chat.* Mocha - If you're a Mocha fan, you've got to try this. The balance of coffee, milk and chocolate is perfect! After sipping many a Mocha in Norway and Iceland, I was pleasantly surprised to find that the first cup of Mocha I tasted in Singapore seems to be on par with what I had there.* Latte - Another perfect cup.Also, the theme of flowers/trees/magic lives on in the washroom. Look in the mirror and you might find a very thought-provoking quote - kinda reminds me of Snow White.p.s I like my coffee not so milky or bitter so if you have similar taste as me, you might like my recommendations.

A cute little cafe tucked around Little India..you will easily miss this place if you are not attentive..the interior decor is simply amazing and you will feel you are in a Harry Potter set..the name of the drinks are also very interesting - definitely try the Elixirs potion! We tried the creamy carbonara with mushroom and it was delicious. The choco nana tella toast with the caramelized banana was also pretty good..

Eat here! They have a certificate for Le Cordon Bleu for crying out loud. I need not say more but will in case you were looking for details. Completely exceeded my expectations. The Unicorn Hotcakes were so delicious with the perfect consistency. I'm from New York City and wish there was a place that could compare to this spot but unfortunately there is not. The Unicorn Hotcakes look like they could give you a toothache but! They are not as sweet as they look. Perfect amount of sweetness. Each different colored hotcake is a different flavor. My favorite flavor was the purple beetroot. WOW. Such a uniquely satisfying flavor that I had never tasted in a hotcake. I also had the Truffle Omelette which had a black truffle spread and tasted like perfection. The truffle taste wasn't overpowering at all. If you love truffle then try this dish. Mix the salad in with each bite. Perfect combination of flavors. The dressing for the salad is honey mustard and really complements the Truffle Omelette.One of the other things I tried was the fries with truffle mayo. Also a win. Perfect crisp to each fry with a great flavored truffle mayo to dip in to. Lemon Yuzu Tart was yet another winner because unlike most lemon tarts, it was not overpowered by the lemon. This place knows how to feed their customers right! I will definitely be back again during my business trip in Singapore and will surely be dreaming of the magical Unicorn Hotcakes once I return home to New York City.

Another great find along Horne Road!If you just finished up at Bao Makers, Two Bakers is a great follow up for dessert. They have lots of cakes to choose from, and if you're in a big group you'll have the luxury of trying ALL THE THINGS.From the variety that we chose, my favourites would have to be Le Chocolat Noir and the Yuzu  Lemon Tart. Le Chocolat Noir reminds me of an opera cake, or the cake version of a Ferrero Rocher. The Yuzu Lemon Tart served as a great palate cleanser, with the tartness cutting through some of the heavier cream of the other desserts that we chose.If you're one of those Instagram folks, sit at the large table in the back as there's a window on the ceiling that will provide the natural light you're looking for. You're welcome! ;)
Great brunch, better coffee...Loved this place! Desserts are unique and they do not disappoint!

I'm pretty critical when it comes to judge any kind of pasta dish because come on! pasta is like one of the easiest bunch of dishes you could make yourself. I ordered Duck Confit Fusilli (SGD$21.80) in which they claim to be one of their Chef's recommendations. This is the description of the dish on the menu: An all-time classic French delicacy of shredded duck leg confit and roasted leeks tossed with fusilli cooked al dente. Sounds amazing, isn't it? That's what I thought too. However it turns out that this dish is very very ordinary - taste wise & appearance wise. I cannot imagine how their mains taste like if their chef's recommendation turns out to be like that only... On a positive spin, I'd have to agree that this place is a good place for young people to chill. The cafe is spacious and the ambiance is very laid back.

You had me at artisan bakery Two Bakers. Cute hip little cafe serving all day brunch, lunch sets and delicious coffee and fancy cake. Tried the Raspberry Lychee Mousse Cake and it truly heavenly. Coffee blend is strong and smooth. Really want to come back for breakfast before we leave SG.

Portions are decently sized but not exactly big enough for verocious eaters. Had the soba, which was aromatic. Pasta is so-so, feels like they used canned tomatoes to do the sauce and frozen prawns. Not really worth that amount of money I am paying for. Sambal risotto was served undercooked the first round. Taste was however refreshing and very interesting concoction I must say. Crowded at lunch time, recommended to get reservation before heading there. NO WIFI and there is bad reception. Not great for studying or doing work there despite a cosy ambience.

Best pulled pork burger we've had, followed by The 1925 Microbrewery.  Their brunch is based on bagels and sous vide-d eggs which comes out perfect!  Great ambience plus most definitely nicest looking pastries and cakes.  My new goto brunch place for a slow relaxing day on the weekends.

address: 27 Foch Road #01-02, Hoa Nam Building Zhuge Liang Singapore 209264 Singapore
