comment: This is probably as close as you can get to heaven on earth. This is a little away from the downtown area but I specifically stay in rucksack inn hostel on lavender street just to be in close proximity to this place. The food is absolutely amazing and so fresh. The food stalls are incredibly clean. You have nothing to worry about in Singapore. The stall owners are also very friendly. One of my favorites from this place is the carrot cake - it's made with eggs and scallops - not entirely sure where the carrot part comes from but wow, it's amazing. Also you can eat for so little at these food courts. $2.00 will get you a very satisfying meal. Go to the tourists traps and sacrifice quality and quantity and pay $15 for the same thing. You've got to stop by and try the food out at this place!

address: 27 Foch Road #01-02, Hoa Nam Building Zhuge Liang Singapore 209264 Singapore
comment: I tried the chicken rice stall's chicken porridge. The stall wasn't busy and the man behind was busy preparing freshly cooked rice and told me to wait for a while. A few minutes later, he started preparing my porridge. First he scooped up some chicken stock into a pan and when that came to a boil, he scooped up some plain porridge and stirred that in. while the porridge was cooking in the stock, the man took some chicken breast (same chicken for chicken rice) and chopped them into thick slices. He apologized there was no fried dough sticks today. I didn't mind. And I asked to add century egg as well. Finally he added the chicken to the pot and gave it a good stir. He poured the porridge into the bowl and then sliced up half a century egg. He asked if I wanted the condiments - fried shallots, spring onions, pepper and sesame oil. I liked that he asked and not assume I'll want everything. He was generous with the toppings. Good, because I love green onions in porridge. The porridge was super yummy! I will be back!

address: 70 Stamford Rd #B1-26/28 University City Campus Singapore 178901 Singapore
comment: Your typical food court arena, but it is located underground of SMU so it is cleaner and lively during the day. I ate at Mixed veg rice stall and food was good. I got the brown rice with 1 meat and 2 veggies which came out to $4.70 SGD. If you befriend a student you get the student discount. It a place worth checking out and you get to check out the University.

rest_name: Xiang Yuan Ji - Shanghai Sheng Jian Bao
comment: One of our best meals in Singapore, and that's after eating the famous Hainanese chicken rice and chili crabs. Pan fried buns were very authentic, made by a chef who came from Shanghai. They were filled with tons of hot flavorful broth. The meat filling was perfectly tender, and dough was the perfect thickness and crispyness. I really hope they expand and open a store in New York so I can eat this everyday!

rest_name: Xiang Yuan Ji - Shanghai Sheng Jian Bao
comment: Have eaten here a couple of times now and both times have been very good. Both times I ordered the Shengjian mantou (pan fried steamed buns with pork/veg fillings) and they came out immediately which makes me guess there is a giant pan of the little guys in the back, ready and waiting to go into the bellies of customers. I ordered another set halfway through and bang, it just magically appeared on the table. Definitely brings back memories of enjoying mantous for breakfast on visits to China.  The other dishes tried were the soup noodles and dumplings. They were nice but the star of this place are the mantous (plural?) so definitely try them. The menu here is very simple - maybe 8 items. To be honest, if the same food  was offered in a hawker center, it would be a buck or two cheaper but the air con dining room makes it worthwhile.

rest_name: Xiang Yuan Ji - Shanghai Sheng Jian Bao
comment: The best Shanghainese breakfast items ever! Thanks to my fellow yelpers, I found this gem tucked away in Little India during my trip to Singapore. Now let's go straight to business, aka, food!I ordered the Sheng Jian Bao- crispy bottom , thin skin, juicy filling. Everything was spot on! It's even better than the famous Xiao Yang Sheng Jian in Shanghai in my opinion since it's not as oily as the Yang's dumplings.Crispy pork chop- crispy juicy pork chop with great flavor inside the meat. Very good and authentic.Sheng Jian bao- OMG these are to die for!!! Everything was right about these dumplings. The bottom is crispy, the skin has just the right thickness, he juice inside was rich but not greasy, and meat filling inside is so flavorful too. Small wontons - the soup base is very umami, with seaweed and sliced egg cake, just like what I had when I was a child in shanghai!Spring rolls - crispy on the outside, soft and savory inside. A tad greasy but I didn't mind too muchOverall, very happy that I checked out this place on my Singapore trip! Will definitely come back before leaving here!!!

rest_name: Xiang Yuan Ji - Shanghai Sheng Jian Bao
comment: Best Shen Jian Bao in Singapore. Chef from China cooks the authentic stuff. Super juicy. Better than Pudong Kitchen. Just focus on the Shen Jian Baos.

rest_name: Xiang Yuan Ji - Shanghai Sheng Jian Bao
comment: All the reviews on here are not so accurate and that's why I went there based on the reviews. And This place is highly overrated. About 10 tables and only one waiting staff. The cold dishes weren't fresh, and waiting time for hot dishes was way too long and they only take cash and they close on Monday! The food wasn't amazing to me, it was so so like ok street food for a restaurant price. It's no for me for a revisit!

Got a white pepper crab here - this is what they're famous for. So stick to that. People seem to be hit or miss for the chili crab but we didn't get a chance to try it. There's an option on the menu for the chili crab sauce + mantous but they were sold out by the time we got here. Also - I expected an actual restaurant, but this was more of a bunch of hawker stands stringed together. Which means you're exposed to the elements of Singapore. So if you expect a nice meal with air con, you're out of luck here. As far as the food goes - I enjoyed it. However, I'd say this tasted like a classic Chinese preparation of seafood (think of the scallion and ginger flavors) but with a kick of white pepper. It was good, but I'm not sure it was worth the price (roughly $90 a kg when we went). Additionally, there's additional charges for EVERYTHING. So decline them when they try to bring you an appetizer or even the wet naps. Just bring your own water & tissues. There's a bathroom available for you to wash your hands.

My mom and I loved the steamed razor clam! Fresh, tender, amazing sauce. My mom ordered 3 of these and she claimed to get 4 next time lolTook down one star for that I'm not a fan of their chili crab, the sauce tastes like homemade tomato scrambled egg (u know what I'm taking about if ur Chinese
Good taste, good service. Chinese style mix Simgapore style. No air conditioner but not very hot.
Really love it, I will go to eat again tomorrow.Drinking bear with ice cup. really care small details.

Del Monte ketchup. If you want Del Monte ketchup to be the primary flavor you taste when ordering expensive chili crab, this is the place for you. Very disappointed.Would have been one star but gave a second one due to a purse storage container next to the table.

It has been years since we were here and I recall they do have a Chili Crab sauce that is rather different from the rest - better that is.  After picking up me boy from Mandai on route back to Marine Parade thought the logical path would be Geylang Branch.  Got to say service was extremely attentive and to the extend that it was a little a pushy as each staff tries hard to up-sell.  And yes even the paper apron cost $0.60/piece.  The saddest part was that the Chili Crab Sauce came in as a little reddish as oppose to somewhat orangy/brown?  The worst is that at S$112 (before the ++) the crab just was not fresh.  We basically ordered the same dishes as we did at Jumbo as a comparison and again both the Baby Kailan and Mee Goreng fell short.  If you are looking for ambiance this is not the place to be.  But seriously with this price best we head back to our fav - Jumbo East Coast where we NEVER EVER have a bad crab day in so many times we have been there through the years.

Good place to have chili crabs. Second only to the other famous crab eating place at the East Coast Rd. Love the balanced taste of the chili sauce. We ordered crabs and 3 other veggies and tofu dishes. Just realized that this place also serves crocodile and deer meat dishes. This place also offers fresh durian, a bit more expensive than other places. Actually this place is $$$$

White pepper crab is really good and the quality was great compared to other places. The crab meat was sweet and does not stick to the shell. I had been to other places where the sauce was good but the crab meat would stick to the shell. The razor clam was also very good.

It's our first time in Singapore and we decided to try out seafood here since we heard Singapore is  famous for it.  My family decided to eat here thanks to reviews but it was super expensive for what you get.I am rating this place one star because our waiter, Ajao, got our order wrong.  We asked for butter but she gave us white pepper which was too spicy for me and I wasnt able to eat the 400$ crab.  My whole family knew I didn't ask for the spicy but we didn't realize until after they started eating it. Ajao did not want to correct her own mistake.  She told me that if I wanted to eat, I would need to buy another one.  We asked if we can exchange the one she got wrong but she kept saying to buy another crab.   I just ended up not eating. My family isn't rich but we wanted to have a treat, and unfortunately our experience just ended up sour.

This place is amazing!  In kind of a seedy area of Singapore but the have a basket to place your valuables in to evade the common pick pockets of the area.   The staff was excellent and very attentive to my needs.   I couldn't make up my mind between the chili crab or the white pepper crab and the waitress advised I go with both!   Lol.   I ordered the chili crab and the white pepper prawn, both were absolutely amazing!  Highly recommend if you are looking for a great meal.

As a tourist, of course I had to come to No Signboard Seafood Restaurant.  Even before my trip, I looked up places on Yelp and TripAdvisor and knew I had to come here.  I didn't know there were other locations and I'm glad I had locals to suggest and take me around and Yelp reviews to read, because I'm glad I went to the original location here in Geylang.  Apparently the prices at the Geylang location are much more reasonable and they are less likely to jip you out of your hard earned cash here.Valet parking is available for $4.  No signboard has mostly outdoor seating under plenty of fans, but it also has an indoor area towards the back left corner.  At night though, it's not so bad outside (and I'm not a fan of Singapore weather at all).No Signboard isn't like your average food centers where a plate of food costs you $3-5.  It's actually quite expensive.  Like most established Singaporean restaurants, you can choose the size of your dishes here (S/M/L), but even the small sizes start at double digits.  Also, as with many other restaurants, they do not provide napkins here.  I've learned to bring wet wipes and napkins around with me everywhere I go now.Lime juice was okay - tastes like powdered lemonade from the states... not sure if it' anything worth trying.Food:1. Chili crab - must get, obviously.  The meat was tender and fresh.  The sauce was spicy for everyone, but not really spicy at all for me.  Everyone was sweating, but I was fine, so it depends on your spice tolerance.2. Salt/chili fried bullfrog - this was actually my favorite dish out of the bunch.  Perfectly battered and crispy outside that was salty and a little bit spicy.  SO GOOD3. Some 油条 cuttlefish thing - fried goodness4. Some sort of coconut-y fried prawn - no shells - delicious5. Eggplant - standard chinese eggplant dish, but you have to have your veggies!Anyway, make your way to the Geylang resty if you've got a chance.

Del Monte ketchup. If you want Del Monte ketchup to be the primary flavor you taste when ordering expensive chili crab, this is the place for you. Very disappointed.Would have been one star but gave a second one due to a purse storage container next to the table.

We originally went to Geylang to eat hokkian noodle in one of famous coffee shop, but unfortunately they were closed, So we end up went to this place. We know this is a "hot spot" for tourist and was expecting a good meal there. We were about to order the crab, but looking at its price, we turned it down. $85 for a crab its a big NO. So we order the other things, black pepper deer meat, drunken prawn, kangkong, and bamboo clam with ice tea and a barley. The good dishes were kangkoong and the clam. Other than that was disappointed us a lot. Drunken prawn was tasteless, the meat were so so, not so much flavor.  Our bill was $130++ so disappointed for the taste and price. Not worth at all.

I decided to check out No Signboard for my first chilli crab experience in Singapore. And my gosh, it was fantastic. Really, truly fantastic. I was super hungry, and ended up eating by myself. That being said, the smallest crab I could get was still huge. It took a bit of time to come out, but was well worth the wait - it was amazing. Juicy, moist, flavorful. Messy as heck, but worth every drip and stain.Mine was not spicy in the slightest. Later, I spoke to a local who told me it was probably because many Singaporeans assume white folks don't like spice. So, lesson learned - next time, ask for spicy, and be firm. Other than that, it was amazing.The place is not cheap, but is so worth it. I would return in a heartbeat.
Good taste, good service. Chinese style mix Simgapore style. No air conditioner but not very hot.

Excellent chilli-crab here - I prefer this over Jumbo. The sauce is spicy and flavorful, leaving you with a slight numbness (essence of mala). I'm a big fan of the mantou they serve as well.The dining area is outside with no AC so prepare to sweat.

No Signboard - A place loved by its patrons so much they gave it a name.Before I get into this too much I have to say I had never had Singapore Chilli Crab until this night. I know about the other alternatives and do plan to test them out but for now it was No Signboard.I found this seafood restaurant very accessible via public transport (get off on the Aljunied stop on the Green East West MRT line and its a short walk from there). Me and some work mates thought we would get our Chilli Crab on and swanned down here after work the other day.Rocking up around 7pm, there was still a few spare tables so we didn't have to wait - bonus! Chilli crab was always going to be on our menu so that was a given. We also had the Drunken Bull Frog and Sambai Kang Kong.With 4 beers on offer (Guiness, Tiger, Heineken and Carlsberg) we opted for the Tiger which goes for $8 for the bigger bottles. The crab is priced at $60 a kilo and then you just decide which way you want it cooked and go from there. We generally went for around half a kilo of crab each because we were trying other options from the menu.The Chilli Crab? AMAZING! Then again it is my only benchmark, but for now I am thoroughly impressed. The Drunken Bull Frog was a close second for me but maybe that is because I miss frog (we don't really have that in Australia).Its all very out in the open and as other people have said, I would probably avoid this place on a really hot and steamy day. But as it was the other night (a bit cooler) I found it quite pleasant. Bring napkins or wet wipes too as they don't provide them free of charge. Chilli crab can get quite messy so bear this in mind when deciding what to wear there as well! All in all I walked away thoroughly impressed and plan to return in future to sample the White Pepper Crab which I hear is something of a specialty here also.

We wanted to try the chilli crabs and came here with a large group of friends. We ordered a variety of food, all very good. Ordered 2 types of crab both very tasty. In the kitchen they have all the seafood live in water tanks as well as a cage full of frogs. Great atmosphere all outside which is covered. By the time we left, people were lining up to get in. Definitely worth visiting. If you order beer, the glasses are regularly replaced with cold ones to keep the beer cold.

White pepper crab $80/kg. Kind of pricey as Newport back in California you can feed a family of four for same price. The crab was pretty good. Reason for three stars is the service. Worst I've had in Singapore. Took forever to get our rice. Also I felt almost conned. If I hadn't read the reviews beforehand I wouldn't have known to not touch anything they put on the table. The waiters will put appetizers and wet wipes on the table without telling you it's not free. Thankfully we didn't eat anything so waiters took it away. They also try to upsell you on other entrees. Don't get suckered and just stick to the crab. Also their tea sucks. Costs $2 for Chinese tea and it was basically their version of a Lipton tea bag- bitter. Also they automatically charge 10% service to the bill, but service was the worst. Oh and other restaurants don't charge for service so that was not fun to find out.

The spicy crab is delicious and tasty. Come in the afternoon and before dinner because it is not crowded and you can sit in the air condition area. Enjoy the crab and don't care how ugly when you are fighting with the crab.
How should I began?Crab is lame ...Price is super unreasonable ...Nothing exciting, except for their buns ... which why would anyone come to an expensive restaurant for buns.

It has been years since we were here and I recall they do have a Chili Crab sauce that is rather different from the rest - better that is.  After picking up me boy from Mandai on route back to Marine Parade thought the logical path would be Geylang Branch.  Got to say service was extremely attentive and to the extend that it was a little a pushy as each staff tries hard to up-sell.  And yes even the paper apron cost $0.60/piece.  The saddest part was that the Chili Crab Sauce came in as a little reddish as oppose to somewhat orangy/brown?  The worst is that at S$112 (before the ++) the crab just was not fresh.  We basically ordered the same dishes as we did at Jumbo as a comparison and again both the Baby Kailan and Mee Goreng fell short.  If you are looking for ambiance this is not the place to be.  But seriously with this price best we head back to our fav - Jumbo East Coast where we NEVER EVER have a bad crab day in so many times we have been there through the years.

It is guaranteed people would recommend you this place for Singapore's famous chili crab first time you are here. It happens to  too. So no doubt i have tried them numerous time till i find another place in Chinatown.It was so hard for me to love their chili crab, they use a lot of egg yolk and and spice wasn't right, just feel sick afterwards. White pepper crab with leak taste much better, it's tasty and a little spicy. So since then i didn't order any chili crab at any place till a friends' day out in chinatown sea food restaurant, there i found the best chili crab(see my review for Chinatown sea food restauran :)It is a good place to go while you near gaylang area, interesting people watching and culture, for that unique experience it is a must go places :)

I do not recommend this place.  Very rude staffs.  Not friendly at all!  Asked for tissue, wet towels, change plates etc. all took 15-20 mins!!  Food: 3 stars Price: 1 stars VERY EXPENSIVE. $128 for crab, $28 for chicken dishDecor: 2 stars for inside, 4 stars for outside seating because of the viewService: 1 stars. Very rude. I will not come back here.  Mostly tourists from the hotel around the restaurants. Over priced and just okay food. Jumbo Seafood might be better.

It's our first time in Singapore and we decided to try out seafood here since we heard Singapore is  famous for it.  My family decided to eat here thanks to reviews but it was super expensive for what you get.I am rating this place one star because our waiter, Ajao, got our order wrong.  We asked for butter but she gave us white pepper which was too spicy for me and I wasnt able to eat the 400$ crab.  My whole family knew I didn't ask for the spicy but we didn't realize until after they started eating it. Ajao did not want to correct her own mistake.  She told me that if I wanted to eat, I would need to buy another one.  We asked if we can exchange the one she got wrong but she kept saying to buy another crab.   I just ended up not eating. My family isn't rich but we wanted to have a treat, and unfortunately our experience just ended up sour.

The quest for all things delicious in Singapore continued during my family's recent visit.  My aunt took one of those brochures for tourists at Changi and chili crab was named one of the top 10 must-try's and off we head to Geylang for our chilli crab as I have been told that No Signboard serves the best chilli crab in town.  To be honest I didn't have much expectations because 1. I am not a fan of chilli crabs I prefer black pepper crab; 2. I tried No Signboard in Hong Kong a few years ago and it was grossly overpriced with small portions; 3.  prior experiences with other famous and tourists oriented joints like Long Beach and Jumbo left the same impression that these famous crab places are rip-offs.  I am so wrong!  The chilli crab is amazing! and I don't even like chilli crab in the first place.  We ended up ordering extra servings of the little fried buns so we can scoop up the very last drop of sauce.  The other chilli crabs I have tasted so far all just tasted like spicy ketchup to me but the No Signboard version is different - just the right blend of spicyness and sweetness.  Oh and we ordered the white pepper crab since I have only had the black pepper version before and it is also yummy!  And oh the size of the crab, which is important, we ordered the smallest sized crab and the meat is very fresh and dense.We also had the stir fried sotong with pepper and chilli, a baby kailan, half an butter chicken and a bitter gourd soup.  The price is not cheap but hey, compared with all the other crab places around town I found it very reasonable.  It comes down to about SGD50 each for the 4 of us and we are stuffed to the brim.  Last time we spent about the same at Jumbo and had to order McDonalds later in the night.  So farewell Jumbo and Long Beach.  The outdoor seatings are spacious and comfortable and I think it's a great place to take visitors to since you can take a stroll around Geylang before or after dinner. This is probably the one non-sterile place in Singapore and shows that this place offers more than just glass and steel buildings or HDB blocks.  We also had durian a bit further down Geylang road - a very sweet ending to our night out in Geylang.

Go here for the Chili and pepper Crab.  It was great as I was told it would be.  Service was good as well.  Just watch for the up sell to the more expensive king crab.  It is twice the price, and as I was told not worth it.  Had great side dishes as well.Overall good experience.  We will be back.

Singaporean chili crab and black pepper crab.  Come with at least four people so you can order more dishes.  I've been told by friends that the level of spiciness can vary at this place and that we went on a high spicy night.  It was definitely packing heat but bearable nonetheless.  Everything else we got here was delicious including the morning glory, the cereal prawns, the Chinese New Year salad, the deep fried bread.  That deep fried bread is a must get side if you're ordering the chili crab because you can dip it in the sauce.  You could do that with rice too but then that would feel too healthy.They do charge for all the extras here including water, wet wipes, etc.  Trust me, you'll need all those.  While I have been told that there are many good chili crab restaurants in Singapore, you can't beat the outdoor ambiance here.  It's not as raw as a hole-in-wall but it's so nice eating in the cool, warm breeze.

Well,  this was a huge disappointment especially for the price you pay. Referring to the Chili Crab - the reason why I came here.  Reviews seemed OK, an Australian friend recommended it - but I did see some reviews about quality and taste being down from its glory days.  Th Uber driver taking me there also implied it is not the same since the original chef moved on. But I had to see and judge for myself.  Now I know.  I specifically asked for SPICY chili crab and what I got was a tasteless dish with hardly any flavor or character to it.  Did not even finish it - eating for the sake of eating with no joy is pointless.  It is not cheap - my total bill was S$110 of which $65 was for chili crab.  It was wasted money and it hurts a bit since it was not even average.  What burns you more is that there is a nominal but silly charge for plain water in plastic cup and a towel to clean ur hands - mind you, we are talking crabs here. My advise, try some other restaurants known for their chili crab and avoid this - at least for now.

Yummy food but it never comes out at once. Finished 2 plates before our butter prawns arrived. Feel very rushed with waitress hovering behind us and asking if we are ready to order every 3 minutes right at the start.

First ever Chilli Crab experience. The highlights:Fingers so messy that napkins were no longer useful. Garden hose anywhere?Never ending Tiger beers. Cold and hit the spot.So much crab... so much chilliKinda pricey for all that sauce, but an experience one should have at least in a lifetime.

it was the first time we have ever tried salty egg as a sauce - BOY where have we been? we are missing out and you are too if you've never had it! the spicy crab was underwhelming - the sauce isn't something i really enjoyed but we tried it just to try it. We were in Singapore for about 3 days and didn't try spicy crab til the last day so we have nothing to compare it to. we had spicy crab, shrimps, veggies, and rice. delicious meal to complete our time here. We also came pretty late so there was no wait for tables. the area is pretty local and out in the boonies or i've been told is the red light district? Tip- bring LOTS of tissues and wipes perhaps. Bring your own drinks! sneakily maybe? lol

I don't know how I could've forgotten about this place, this was my break-virgin into Singapore-style crab on my very first trip to Singapore 2 years ago, and then my local friends took me to the tourist, nicer one at Vivocity b/c they know I'm a roller.  Just kidding lol.This is what real street food eating really is: no decor but just eating it out with no care, all reckless abandon; you're not worrying over your clothes or ppl staring lol.  Because everyone's eating like a pig and smacking their fingers dry.So they ordered 2 of the most popular ones: the black pepper (which looks muddy) and sweet chili, which really is more of a tomato/ketchup-like with a bit of a kick.  I honestly had a hard time deciding which is the best, as I went back and forth.  And guess what, I still have a hard time deciding lol.This place is way out there in the burbs but in Singapore, that's just a 15-min drive across the country lol, correct?

We were just walking around the Red Light District when we came across No Signboard, and we were very excited because we had read quite a bit about how great the seafood is!  So we just had to give it a try even though our bellies were already full.Service:  Slow when it comes to getting the check, and it was difficult to understand some of the waitresses (their English, at least).  But the Tiger beer lady was nice.Ambience: we were seated near the edge of the restaurant (which is outdoors), and the area is infested with mosquitoes (at least if you are prone to mosquito bites). We asked to be seated elsewhere, but they told us there were no other tables available (even when people left they wouldn't move us).  And there were some creepy men and prostitutes who kept eyeing us when they walked by.  Otherwise, it's a very lively place!Food:  We didn't order chili crab because we just had it the other day, but it looked quite delicious when the table next to us got it!  But the sauce looked pretty soupy.  In any case, we got razor clams, which were SOOOOO fresh, and the king prawns were deliciously juicy (until I took a bite of my last one, which was super dry).  I do think they had some consistency problems within some of the dishes.  Aside from the king prawns, the claypot tofu had shrimp also, but one of them tasted old and fishy while another had a fresh taste to it...  And def don't order the deer.  When it was good, the food was delicious, but when it's bad, it's so bad you have to spit it out.

I had a great first time experience here, due to a variety of factors:1) It had just rained earlier in the day, and when we arrived (late afternoon) the weather was PERFECT for al fresco dining. 2) My husband and I came here really early on Saturday (5 PM) so there was no wait and the staff was very attentive.3) I only ate a cheese stick, some cashews, and a small strawberry cake throughout the day, so by the time I arrived I was ready to chow down on some REAL food!As much as I really wanted to try the chili crab, a few friends + Yelp mentioned that it was a lot spicier than Jumbo's. My husband can't handle too much spice, and it was just the two of us, so we chose the next most talked about dish- white pepper crab! We also ordered drunken shrimp and fried rice. The drunken shrimp was served to us in big bowls filled to the brim with soup, and I enjoyed it very much. The fried rice, however, was probably the best fried rice I've ever tasted in my life. There was a little bit of everything in there, and it was absolutely divine. We also loved how they served it as our first dish, as we prefer to eat the rice with our crab. As for our white pepper crab, it didn't disappoint! It was served with a really flavorful sauce and some veggies that complimented the crab perfectly. It wasn't spicy, but at the same time it had taste, which made both me and my husband happy campers!No bibs were given to us (were we supposed to ask for them?), but they did have small IKEA laundry baskets at each table where you can keep your purse and any outerwear that you don't want to stain. Make sure to bring tissues if one wet nap isn't enough for you! Also, they do have a VIP section, which I presume means air conditioning. Not sure if there's anything special you need to do to get in, or if the prices are different!Speaking of prices, I did find it a bit pricey, as the bill for the two of us was $115 (however, this did include 1 large Tiger beer that we split and a dessert as well.) They do accept credit cards, though.Bottom line, I am a newly converted fan, and one of these days I will return and try the chili crab once and for all! Maybe I'll also bring a bottle of wine with me, as the corkage fee is only $10. Wanna come with? :)

Since it's the only restaurant I ate at in Singapore during my layover, it is the best restaurant I have eaten in Singapore!  The food is so tasty. Fish is fresh. Crab is fresh. Veggies is fresh. And they all taste differently with very different sauce. The atmosphere is like a street restaurant with a canopy cover.  The place is not too clean but all the fishes look lively and healthy in their tanks. Restroom is not so clean. The place is huge and amazingly fills up!

Wow, what an experience...My only other chilli crab experience has been at Long Beach at Dempsey and this was SO. MUCH. MORE. AWESOME. I was so gutted on our first experience when our crab was deconstructed by the waiter at the table (I had visions of bibs and crabby faces... granted, our Singaporean host thought we would prefer it the clean way). The grittiness of Geylang teemed with friendly service, amazing flavours, reasonable prices (crab $55 kilo apparently quite pricey though?) and some pretty blemmin good crab. We tried the kang kong, the oyster sauce kai lan, the chicken wings in prawn paste, the steamed bums, and the white pepper and chilli crab. Jury is still out on which one is better... Be warned, the chilli crab is pretty spicy for most ang mo palates, however it didn't stop our British guest getting amongst. Total bill $148 for four people including 3 large tiger beers. We left very full.. I will be back with more of our international visitors. Be prepared to get messy.

I love seafood, and I am fussy.Bamboo clams - $12 each and I've had better. The clams were a little over-cooked today and it could be less chewy. It is also under-seasoned and could do with more garlic.Cereal prawns and baby squids - both decent but again better versions elsewhere.Yang Zhou fried rice - beautifully fried.Chilli crab - I am definitely a bigger fan if pepper crab. But I was bringing visitors tonight and decided to go with our national dish. The dish is enjoyable and we went with the male crab (firmer flesh vs female crab with roe. Yes, sometimes, life is full of tough choices). Again, not the best out there. I kind of prefer long beach or jumbo.Add a vegetable and 4 large bottles of tiger beer, the bill came out to $200.What I like about the place is actually the location. Located in the colorful part of Singapore, you sit by Geylang road in the open and feel that this is how Singapore feels 20 years ago.

Chili crab:No Signboard sauce is way better than Jumbo's.Pepper crab:Both are decent.Service:No signboard all the way.Make sure to always order a side of fried rice to enjoy with the chili sauce, and bamboo clams as an appetizer! it's so delicious, juicy, and tender. I only ate bamboo clams as a Spanish Tapas and it's a total different experience. They also give you a smashed garlic sauce which is to die for. note: No signboard is mostly known for its white pepper crabs which I haven't tried yet. I subtracted one star for being so pricey for seafood, but it's like that across all popular seafood joints in Singapore, No signboard, Jumbo, and Long Beach. crab= $55/kgbamboo clams= $13 for onefried rice: cheap. $8~12 something unless you order the clam rice.
What we ordered? White Pepper crab, steamed veggies, and chili prawnsAll the food was tasty but very overpriced. Would I come back? Won't go out of my way to come here.

White pepper crab is really good and the quality was great compared to other places. The crab meat was sweet and does not stick to the shell. I had been to other places where the sauce was good but the crab meat would stick to the shell. The razor clam was also very good.

I went to Jumbo Seafood and then tried No Signboard and I think I liked the food here better!  The sauce in the chilli crab was more richer while I thought Chilli tasted a bit like ketchup.  And it seemed like there were more locals here while Jumbo was definitely a touristy spot. Cons: no ac so we were dripping sweat.  They charge for nearly everything, including water and napkins which seemed ridiculous. Pros: the food was great. We ate chilli crab, green beans, and lots of fried bread.  One med sized crab was enough for 2 girls.  Very close to the MRT

White pepper crab was really good. The venison did not taste like venison... Instead like cat or some other myaterious animal... not like beef either... Not sure what they served us in place of venison there...Scallops were great, and a beef noodle dish was good as well.Very nice location to walk over to the water to see the light show :)

Outstanding chili crab, but I think it may be a tad overpriced.  The 2 chili crabs I had in Singapore were at Newton Circus Food Centre and this place.  This place was much better, although it was NOT cheap by any means.  The neighbourhood is Singapore's red light district and is as close to dodgy as Singapore gets, but the crab was cooked to perfection and the sauce was phenomenal.  It does take long to prepare but worth the wait.

Had dinner at No Signboard Restaurant Geylang on 3 July 2015. The meal for 3 was expensive at $50 per person but food was below average. Had a nicer experience at the same place last Oct 2014. Last night ordered 3 dishes comprising a small white pepper crab (not enough pepper), small steamed fish (bland and meat a bit tough); and large $20 hor fun ( that came with 3 small prawns, some slices of toman fish, chye sin and few slices of chicken - no egg). Not sure if the standard of food is better at the other branches. Generally, the quantity & quality of food is not worth the prices charged.

This is a cool spot to eat seafood.  It's super busy though. We didn't wait to long for a table.   It's expensive of course,  but it's Singapore.  The seafood is good. It could be cleaner.  Wish it was closer to the train.
Is it normal to charge for peanuts and wet naps that are already on the table? White pepper crab was okay. Fried rice was really good but this pricey dinner was NOT worth the money..

Can't really go wrong with No Signboard. They deliver each time. The Geylang restaurant is supposed to be their best. I'm not sure I noticed any difference in regards to the food. Had delicious chilli crab (and the customary fried buns), a clam and vermicelli dish which was absolutely divine, some greens and a yummy sticky pork rib dish. Another one of my 'must go' places when I'm in Singapore.

I haven't really been a fan of No Singboard Seafood restaurant until I came here for a late Saturday night seafood supper. This is the only one of the No Signboard Seafood's I'll visit, ambience of sitting street side in geylang, adds to that charm that only fellow expats would understand and relate too.  The outdoor dining area is gritty and dirty, with cheap plastic chairs and wonky tables with large fans providing some airflow under the large canvas awning.  A trip to the bathroom will have you carefully stepping over the piping and puddles leading into the live seafood tanks, where they have everything from seabss, crabs, lobsters, frogs, prawns and many more. The chili and black pepper crab here is very good. One of the places I'll frequent when I'm craving one of the two. Would recommend this place particularly to anyone who wants to give overseas guest a uniquely Singaporean seafood experience.

The crabs are $50/kg which is supposedly pricier than the other restaurants. I'm really not sure what's the market rate. I just assumed they are not cheap. The usual flavors are available- White/Black Pepper, Chilli, Butter, Steamed, Ginger and Spring Onion, Cheese. Can't remember if they have Salted Egg Yolk, which has become one of my favorite flavors for crabs.The Black Pepper crab looks harmless enough but boy is it spicy! Really peppery flavor that turned on the faucet in my nose and had it running for a while. The restaurant gave us the male crab for this dish. I love the kick of the pepper in this dish. You gotta eat this fast because it turns cold due to the lack of a gravy to keep it heated. Apparently the white pepper crab was the original signature dish of NS but now people associate them with Chili crabs. Shall try that another time.NS used to hold the standard for Chili crabs in Singapore (according to this skinnyfat girl that is). Every other chili crab is either too tomato-ish, too diluted, too spicy or too ________(insert something negative here) as compared to NS. I'm sad to say that the standard has indeed fallen. I thought the gravy is watered down a little. It kinda lacks that oomph and punch that it used to possess. While the meat of the crab is succulent as before, the crabs are really pretty puny these days. The image of those HUGE Sri Lankan crab pincers from eons ago is still etched in my memory and the size of the current ones are really disappointing.

I think I'm just a sucker for Chili Crab. Their sauce is fantastic - people will argue forever about who's is best (Jumbo, Long beach, Melben, etc.). Fact is, they're all delicious. This is one of the spicier sauces I've had, but still not overbearingly spicy. Location feels more local than say Jumbo in CQ - Geylang is  tourist attraction in its own right...
Decent food. Better service than Jumbo but this does feel more like a hawker center. They told us they didn't have Heineken but they do.
Chilli Crab! I miss this place so much, you can't go wrong with an establishment with no name. Simple; go for the crab, stay for Geylang (joke). Also wear the bib.

address: 68 Orchard Rd #02-32, Plaza Singapura Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: Good Chinese / Cantonese food inside Plaza Singapora.  They have all you can eat buffet as well as regular menu items.The congee was very good as well as the noodles. Worth checking out

address: 68 Orchard Rd #02-32, Plaza Singapura Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: Food is mediocre at best, soup i ordered was a bit oily with 2-3 pieces of small cut meat only. Veggie was good but expensive for portion I received.They charge for wet tissue and tea.

address: 68 Orchard Rd #02-32, Plaza Singapura Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: Great place.Dim Sung as it should be. No strolling steaming trolleys but very fast and precise service. Love every single dish ordered. Chinese tea refill is the tradition and dolly turning table in the large ones really give it the typical dim sung look and feel.

address: 68 Orchard Rd #02-32, Plaza Singapura Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: It's just so so. The congee is alright. Though the so called store brand BBQ duck is a bit salty, with small portion. This is Cantonese, my hometown cuisine.

address: 68 Orchard Rd #02-32, Plaza Singapura Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: Outstanding steamboat late lunch on a Sunday! Being unsure of how good Crystal Jade was at steamboat, we decided to give this one a chance, and were pleasantly encouraged. It was roughly $35-40 SGD per person for a 90-minute steamboat buffet. The staff were extremely helpful and brought over helpings of beef, chicken and pork and there was a selection of six soups, from the savory pork rib soup to extremely spicy options. There was the familiar selection of vegetables and noodles and so forth that could also be boiled. The staff visited periodically to check in, and even brought samples of other sauces to try with the food and even different items that, in their words, "if it's your first time here, you wouldn't know about this, but it's really good!" Free-flowing drinks and ice cream too to finish things off.

Visited this vegetarian outlet with my friend recently. I must say I really like what we ordered. Food was tasty & service was pretty ok. I like that the space is relatively spacious. Will definitely be back again to check out other dishes.#myfirstreviewof2019

Located near Boon Keng MRT. We reserved a table for 5 adults and 7 children for New Year's Day dinner. We were there around 7:30pm and the restaurant is already quite packed. I'd suggest you make reservations if your large party. Most of the tables are movable so it's easy to cater to groups of different sizes. The food taste pretty good. All the kids love it. However the Claypot Yee Mee tasted rather bland. Other dishes like the Loh Han Zai, Xiang Chun Fish, Cereal Abalone Mushroom (kids favorite), Basil eggplant, and Fried Spinach were tasty. The dishes arrive quite quickly after ordering. The servers however are not very attentive or at least the one that served us was not attentive. When the Claypot Yee Mee arrived we had to ask her to bring us some bowls after we noticed she has no intention of doing so. Atmosphere is not too bad. Generally quiet except for our table of children. I did observed 2 Indian families dining there so I guess the food is agreeable to vegetarians of different cultural background or is it that I need to get outside more. Price wise I find it affordable. 8 dishes, 7 steam rice and a pot of tea cost less than $120. Give it a try if you are thinking of vegetarian.

The food is so so but the customer service is very bad. Just asking the lady whether can I change certain dish in the set meal to something else. She told me not. I am fine with that. But when I walk over to take some chill near the counter. She is gossiping about me with her colleague. I walk over to tell her off. I don't mind if she cant change the set meal. But there is no need to gossip about me saying that I am asking for more money items. But I do not mind if I need to pay extra just that I don't want to waste fruit that I do not eat but she don't give me that option. And I told her nicely earlier it ok. never mind. But never dream that she goes around telling all her colleagues and making it very ugly in front of me. Pls do not go there for meal. If no choice then better don't talk to the staff much. They like to gossip a lot instead of taking order and delivering the food to the customers.
Love the roast pork for its crispy skin and it's juicy pork. Yums!The queue is long but is pretty fast and the people are friendly and nice.

This place is famous for the roasted pork belly (siew yoke), and also has a side stall selling wanton noodles. I have gotten the wanton noodles and siew yoke and Char siew to go, and I feel that the siew yoke does live up to expectations, with a very crispy skin and meat that melts in the mouth. The char siew is not bad too, though I prefer it a bit sweeter. I am docking a star because of their noodles, as the noodles were over cooked and too soft, with really underwhelming wantons. You can add on some siew yoke to your noodles for $2, which is a good option. Would return just for the meats!

The roast meat here is famed for its crispy and almost brittle skin! Came here specially to try and ordered the roast meat and char siew. The skin is really unique and so crispy it's almost hard. The meat and skin sandwiches the fat which is almost gelatinous. However the fat is a little too much and bouncy for my liking. Char siew was more to my own personal preference, due to the tender flesh and just awesome sauce for dipping. Dipping sauce is really dope and unique!This place moves around a lot from what I heard, but often in the same vicinity of Jalan Besar area. Rice is good but given stingily. Their roast duck looks good. Definitely gonna give it a try the next time round!

FOOD == (5/5) Best soup dumpling I ever tried and had the highest quality plates which stuff me really quick. Felt most satisfied when leaving the restaurant.SERVICE == (5/5) Very attentive and did their jobsVIBES == (4.5/5) My family sat in a mall looking place which looks pretty but it does not reflect the Francine's of these dumplings

Overrated. If you order 1 or 2 orders of dumplings then you might be able to distinguish the taste but we ordered more than 6 orders (all different ones) so I felt that it all tasted the same after my 2nd dumpling. The oriental salad was delicious and my favorite. The fried rice was incredibly tasty, too. The duck wrap I ordered was good but I would not order it again. I was not a fan of their BBQ pork buns (all dough and barely any meat filling). Service was subpar. We were ignored for a short while. I'd pick the dim sum at the hawker centers instead.
Always nice to eat at one of my favorite restaurants that serve soup dumpling. If you are craving good Chinese food come here.
5th time here!  Busy BusyDim Sum was on point.  No surprise there, right?Hot and Sour soup was the bomb!

I finally got to try the Din Tai Fung's famous steamed pork dumplings. There's a location in the Raffles City shopping center. The verdict: pretty tasty! How do they make these? How do they get the soup to stay inside? The meat and the dumpling itself was delicious, but I wouldn't say it was mind blowing. Maybe I had high expectations because it was so hyped up. I also tried the steamed chicken soup, because the menu said it was another thing they were famous for. I didn't like this as much. I thought the broth was kind of bland and most of the chicken was white meat, so slightly dry.They give you a pen and you have to mark down how many of each item you want. For the dumplings, you have the option of getting six pieces or ten pieces. And it comes out in one of those bamboo steamer baskets. Overall, tasty dumplings, but nothing to go out of your way for!

I've been here twice now. I waited to write a review because I wanted to make sure my first trip wasn't an anomalyI don't understand why everyone is so crazy about this place. one just opened near San Francisco and the wait time can be three hours. I figured I'd try it in SE Asia. the second time there I waited for a single table almost one hour. the service is lousy. a runner just dumps the dish on the table and leaves without checking if it's correct or you need anything else. but the worst part was the xiao long bao, both times, was dried out like it had been sitting on a warming shelf for a while. this is supposed to be the reason people come here. my order was wrong one of the times, but I was too annoyed at waiting an hour so I didn't complain. the sides were okay.I'll never come back

If you ever find yourself in Singapore,  do your self a favor.  Avoid the super snooty overpriced restaurants.  Find this little gem which truthfully isn't so little at all. And come hungry. They have an incredibly  wide assortment of dim sum as week as their speciality, soup dumplings.  Nom nomYou will certainly not be disappointed. Though this location won't win any rewards in ambience and decor, it's clean decorum coupled with an efficiency in both acquiring a table and being served or food with 5 minutes of being seated, is an award all to itself. Whilst waiting to be seated you are given both a menu on a clipboard and a picture book of all the succulent options. Some options come in multiples of 1, 3, 6 or 10 so make sure to carefully discern quantity when making your selections. You are also assigned a queue number which is conveniently illuminated at the entrance just above your head. Thus no mystery as to when you'll be seated. Once your number your number is called, the hostess takes your menu, reviews your order with you before seating at your table which is being cleaned quickly during that time.  Once you're seated you receive the first of your items usually within 5 minutes.EFFICIENCY LADIES AND GENTS IS THE NAME OF THE GAME WHEN GOING TO MOST PLACES IN SINGAPORE.

Outstanding food and even better service. If you want one of the best meals in Singapore go here. You will not regret it.Side note: extremely friendly and helpful with small children. Our daughter had a blast here.

This was our first stop for food on the first morning of our most recent visit to Singapore. DUMPLINGS! I love the consistency. Every restaurant churns out the same great food and hopefully decent service. This place gives you a basket for your purse and a napkin to cover it- that way no dumpling juice or soy splashes it! We shared the pork and tofu noodles, pork XLB, shrimp and pork XLB, duck skin cigars and red bean sticky rice. All solid choices and I enjoyed everything we ate!

I cannot recommend the truffle dumpling enough. They are delicious and amazingly decadent. I wish there were smaller portions for some items so singles can get some variety, but everything I tasted was wonderful.

Yes, I am a fan of this place.  I was a bit worried that it won't be as good as the original place in Taiwan but they are quite good.  When I worked near City Hall, I used to come here once a week and yes, that's how satisfying it was.  Try their red-bean dessert dumplings.

Decent quality and consistent food. I like the egg fried rice (sometimes I get it with shrimp) and the wonton soup. Good stuff. Can count on it being the same every time I go. Of course, the xiao long baos are decent too.

I would say this place is overrated. Stopped by for dinner last night, and ordered the soup dumpling with a vermicelli soup. The vermicelli soup with fried tofu was pretty good, the broth was really flavorful. But the soup dumpling is lacking in flavor big time. True, the skin is thin, has the right consistency, and there juice inside. However, the flavor of the filling is also a big part of the soup dumpling, and I found the meat filling was rather bland.

I realise I've falled into a predictable pattern of late. Whenever I want dim sum, I go to DTF. Few restaurants have inspired such loyalty from me and that's simply owing to their reliable dim sum with consistent quality. Not to say there aren't ANY cons. The waiting time can range from 10-30 minutes on the weekends although they are kind enough to let you pick your food while you wait and make your order just as you are whisked to a table. The menu is a bit limited in my opinion. No char siew pau or chee cheong fun, two staples on the dim sum menu. It's also not particularly adventurous if you are into that sort of thing. Having said that, whatever they do serve is very good promptly dished. The pork and chilli crab steamed bun is delicious, as is their soup dumplings. I'm also a sucker for their mango pudding which I never have space for because I've just gorged on 6 prawn and pork dumplings. If you want some otherworldly dim sum, you won't get it here. If you just want a straightforward, good dumpling, this place will not fail you.
Wow. I am not a Chinese food expert, but this was good stuff. Chicken Soup was indescribably delicious and made my tummy feel good. The steamed pork dumplings were amazing.

Came to DTF with friends for brunch.  This was my first time here and the friends said they offered more on the Singapore menu than the one back at home.  We tried the pork and veggie dumplings (yum), shrimp and pork shumai (yum), fried pork and shrimp wontons (yum), pork rib soup (yum), soup dumplings (yum), stir fried bok choy (yum), shrimp and pork wontons in soup (yum), crab and pork dumplings (good- very crabby), aaaaand crispy shrimp pancake (BOMB!!!).  Overall, my first experience at DTF was so worth it!

On a personal note, this is the last restaurant review I will write from my recent time living in Singapore.  I truly loved the island and took immense joy in exploring its varied culinary landscape.  It is special place populated by such amazing people (locals and expats).  From the depth of my heart, I hope I am able to return someday.This is a review of dinner with two friends at Din Tai Fung in Raffles City Shopping Centre.tinyurl.com/lvn2cb4This Din Tai Fung is located in the basement level of Raffles CIty.  It is pretty far into the level and can be a little difficult to locate.  Also, unless you arrive early for dinner, you should expect a wait.  I think we arrived around 6:30 or so.  We had a 20 to 25 minute wait for our table.  But, I think those arriving when we were being seated were probably having a little longer wait.The ambiance is a notch above basic but still trends towards the functional.  I would not place it at the level of fine dining.  It lacks the attention to detail that a fine dining room displays.tinyurl.com/kldx5xdThe staff is very effective.  I wouldn't necessarily use the word friendly.  Though they are certainly not rude.  Everyone just seems too busy and focused on their tasks to take a moment for overt politeness.  Also, the experience seems to be based on speed; get folks seated, get their order, get them their food ASAP, and get them on their way, rinse and repeat.The food ranged from good to extremely good.tinyurl.com/lfurlwmCrispy Prawn Pancake - This was my least favourite dish. There wasn't anything  particularly wrong with it but it lacked layers of flavours that would have brought it up a notch.tinyurl.com/md9rrdpChicken with wine sauce - This was such a enjoyable chicken dish.  it is another example of a dish that allowed the basic ingredient to shine through.  The wine sauce complimented the chicken without overwhelming it.  Plus, the chicken was very tender.tinyurl.com/lyzsb9gPrawn Fried Rice - I love rice.  But I tend to prefer steamed rices.  However, if I keep running into fried rices as good as this, I may become a convert.  It was light.  The prawns were sweet.  The eggs provided a rich earthy note.  At some level, it was difficult to believe this was a fried dish.tinyurl.com/kcpztlbCold Pork - I enjoyed the flavours of this dish.  The lightness of the pork.  The freshness of the onions.  The nice touch of the sesame seeds.  All that being said, I would prefer this dish with the pork served hot.tinyurl.com/mc6hn5jPrawn Dumplings - I love prawn dumplings.  These were very good.  Fresh, hot, sweet, etc..tinyurl.com/lpqr9n5Xia Long Bao (soup dumplings) - This is the dish that brings a lot of folks to Din Tai Fung.   They did not disappoint.  Dipped into the vinegar and ginger and then popped into your mouth for a flavour explosion.  Just make sure not to burn yourself.tinyurl.com/m7efulrI do not know the cost.  My friends were kind enough to treat me to dinner.Overall - Din Tai Fung is about the food and they delivered.  For the overall experience, I would say this was more 3.5 star than 4.  The food definitely warranted 4 stars.  The service could be a little more personable and little less rushed.   But, I guess if they didn't hurry, we would all have to wait a little longer to get our delicious Xia Long Bao.

Came here during my 2 week visit to Singapore about 3 times :) LOVED their seaweed/vegetable salad app, the pork dumplings, spicy cucumber and the shrimp fried rice. There was typically a wait if you came at normal eating hours, and even off peak there were always plenty of tables filled up! I do like the numbering system and how they call out the tables, easier to hear than names being called and lets you not stand in a line like other places in the mall. Service was typically quick, although items came out as they were ready and not necessarily in the order that you would expect them. This didn't bother me as i was eating alone, but might be weird if you are in a group and ordering separately. Although this is a chain, i felt that this location was a nice option for dinner for almost any occasion from date night to casual eating alone. I think you have to visit one location of this restaurant if you are visiting Singapore!

Before traveling to Singapore for work, I checked out some Yelp reviews to see what the restaurants close to my hotel offered. I'm glad I read reviews of Din Tai Fung because I made the effort to find it and ended up going three times during a two week trip! My hotel (the Swissotel) was connected to the Raffles City mall, so that made it very convenient, but I still would have made the effort to go back. There was usually a line but it cleared quickly and the hostesses provided order sheets and menus so you could decide on your meal before you sat down. One of my favorite parts of the experience was the "crib" they provide for ladies' bags and that once you put your bag inside they cover it with a napkin as if the bags are being tucked in for a nap. But my most favorite thing were the dumplings. These soup dumplings might be the most delightful thing I have ever eaten. The sensation of putting one in your mouth and the warm soup bursting out (yeah, yeah, *phrasing boom*) just brings a smile to your face. The texture of the dumplings is firm, but soft, and the soup has great flavor. I tried several varieties, with the traditional pork being my favorite. The shrimp and the chicken were also good, but I didn't care for the crab very much. I also tried the shrimp fried rice and an eggplant side dish and both were great. I've seriously been telling everyone about these dumplings since I went on this trip. If you're in Singapore, Din Tai Fung is a must.

We were there on the last Saturday of the year so it seemed like it was a bit of a mad rush at the centre. Thankfully there wasn't the usual long queue at DTF as it was a late lunch. We pre-ordered at the queue to cut wait time but there was still a wait at the table. Luckily the beers didn't take too long! My companions were vegetarians so we only opted for vegetarian dishes and were very pleased with our choices. The stir fried dou miao with garlic was outstanding as were the steamed red bean paste buns.Service was so-so. Staff weren't rude but not that friendly either. One of our dumpling dishes was forgotten so we had to ask for it and there was a bit of a delay though it wasn't too long.It was a pleasant experience and the flavour of the food is consistent with DTF in Hong Kong, Malaysia and Sydney.

Other than the Edge breakfast I enjoyed every morning, this was my favorite meal in Singapore. I am now absolutely addicted to dumpling and buns.It is almost impossible to find soup dumplings in the US, so my friend was on the hunt for some. Enter Din Tai Fung. The soup dumplings were absolutely delicious, and I can't complain about anything else we ate.I loved watching them make all of the food while we waited. Their kitchen is glassed in, and you can see them moving all of the trays around in the steam. Definitely worth the wait.
The food is always consistent at any Din Tai Fung I've been too. I loooove the oriental salad and all the yummy dimsum!

I've eaten at the DTF location in Arcadia, CA in the states plenty of times and I'm a big fan for only their trademark pork XLB's and nothing else. Naturally, once I found out that there was a location minutes away from my hotel in Singapore, I just had to check it out for comparison purposes. Prices are definitely higher, which is no shocking surprise. In the US, it's around $7-8 for a 10 pc of the juicy pork dumplings. In Singapore, it's closer to $11-12. The group of us weren't that hungry, so we only ordered 20 total for 4 people. Not only do they tack on $1 per person for tea (without even asking), but they also automatically added a service charge. So it ended up being close to $30 US dollars.Not a good value, by any means, and the XLB's where just about the same compared to the Arcadia location. If there was a slight difference, the skin was slightly thicker and chewier in Singapore -- which I didn't mind at all. Worth a try, but not again if I'm ever in Singapore again.

They do not take American Express, so beware :) i come here for the dumplings only, which are really good!! So flavorful, and juicy after you bite into them!!! :) I once got the dan dan noodles, and did not like at all... Very little flavor, and feel a bit more fast food like. One day I came here and the hostess was a little rude, and sat couples who came after me, and when it was my turn, she told me that there was a 30 min wait, even though there were two empty tables in the back.. I was a party of one that day, but still....
Really good! Huge menu, I tasted many of them, good prices even for Singapore, free refill tea is great, what can I say - I loved it

Din Tai Fung is a great place to take first-time visitors to Singapore, especially when you're on a moderate budget. They have great soup dumplings, portions are good, and it's air-conditioned (which is so key for foreigners).  Whenever my husband and I are stuck in choosing options for hosting people, Din Tai Fung is always our go-to choice.
Taipei, Singapore, and Seattle .... always count on Din Tai Fung to bring their A game.  Especially XLB!

I was back in Singapore visiting family and attending my brother's wedding, and had to get a xiao long bao fix. HAD to. We were in the area because there was a little anime festival going on at Funan mall, and this was the closest thing that served xiao long bao. We were seated promptly, and politely. It was rather cramped- you can tell they're trying to maximize space, and when there's only 2 people in your party... well. But really, we're not big, so we didn't mind rubbing elbows a little. Wound up chatting a bit to a couple of Frenchmen that were dining next to us, actually! (Frenchmen! You never get Frenchmen in Phoenix. I sometimes forget how urbane Singapore is.) The food we ordered was pretty standard. I waffled about getting the truffle xiao long bao but decided against it, going instead for the regular order of that, plus the signature jiao zi. My girlfriend got the dan dan mien, I got the zha jiang mien. We also shared the pickled shredded vegetables. Everything was pretty good- the skin on the bao thin, the broth hot. My zha jiang mien was delicious, and definitely better than what I could replicate at home. Mostly it was just a good fix of chinese food, and the coveted xiao long bao. I don't get a chance to have food like this back in Phoenix. 3.5 stars out of 5 for sure. Didn't round up as #1- it's a chain restaurant and #2, really nothing out of this world. Good solid fare, in a nice, air conditioned environment. WIN for me.

I dream of Din Tai Fung when I'm in the states. This place is super consistent and gets it right every time. The pork chop and fried rice is a must and obviously if you leave without trying the variety of soup dumplings if not ALL the soup dumplings you must be from another planet. You seriously can't go wrong here...

The heavy weight champion of soup dumplings. While they could've stopped there, they didn't. Spectacular noodles. Amazing starters (duck filled spring rolls). Incredible fried rice (get it w pork chop). Why this place doesn't have a Michelin star is a mystery.

This was the 5th or 6th DTF I'd eaten at on my current traveling spree, and it was very similar to the other DTFs I've had in my life (with the exception of branches in Shanghai and Taipei).You know what the deal is here. Delicious xiaolongbao, with different kinds if you're looking for some variety. It's not exactly cheap, but the quality's pretty good. I personally think it's worth it. There are also a few other dishes, but I didn't get to order them this time around. We just ordered a lot of different kinds of XLB hahaha.

4.5 stars for Din Tai Fung!   The Xao long bao soup dumplings were super good.  They had a chili crab "special" one that I really enjoyed.  We also ordered a veggie dish that was just okay, and dan dan noodles which were pretty good.  I recommend sticking to their dumplings.  Service was good.  Atmosphere was good.  All in all I would recommend trying Din Tai Fung...although not sure if it's worth the potentially long lines.
Small location in the basement of the mall. The soup dumplings were good but not as good as some of their other locations within Singapore.

It speaks volume of a chain restaurant that I can return to again, and again, and again.And look. The shizz here is foh real and is definitely good. So let's not waste words on waxing lyrical.I like this branch in general, service is almost always good, the lines move fast, and I've never had a bad experience here. Food appears promptly, and they're a polished operation. (Which can't be said of every Din Tai Fung I've tried in Singapore)This is the Joshua list of what you MUST try at Din Tai Fung. Okay. Maybe not 'must' try. It's MY list after all. But trust me, these are some of the best things on the menu.Xiao Long Bao. The normal kind with pork.Xiao Long Bao WITH BLACK TRUFFLE. Now I know they're expensive at about $4 a pop, but HOT DIGGIDY DAMN they ARE GOOD. They're worth that $4, trust you me. The dumplings in chili oil and vinegar. These are so tasty it's ridonkulous. Eat them dumplings up, and keep a little of the oil and vinegar mix so you can dump it in the...Double boiled chicken soup with noodles.This is the one where the noodles and the soup come separate. The noodles are dry, in a bowl with spring onion and salt, and you're supposed to pour in some soup. BUT WAIT. We have that awesome vinegar chili oil mix still left over. POUR THAT IN. Spoon in 2-3 spoons of soup. And SAVOUR.Also definitely worth trying is the Shanghai drunken chicken. PACKED with flavour, this is my favourite cold starter item on the menu.Also generally well liked is the prawn pancake, which is crisp, seafoody goodness.OMG I need some XLB right now.

Hello soupy dumpling you are so amazing and I can't believe I ate almost two orders on my own. Why i love you so much, the perfect bite size and not hint of greasiness in the broth or skin. The thin chewy skin, and the super tender meat were amazing.The also like the chinese broccoli with garlic and sauce!

If you like dim sum, don't miss this one. Have tried this and a second location for this chain. Ordered a wide variety of their menu offerings and all were great. Don't miss the soup filled dumplings, the noodle dishes.....etc.

Breezed right in on a Friday afternoon around 3pm. Service was a bit slow but I was too excited for my dumplings to care.  Dui Mui (greens) came out first and weren't completely pipping hot. Remaining dumplings followed shortly. The truffle xiao long bao was a bit over the top, but I would probably order it again since we don't have it in the States. Chili crab bun was interesting, but I'm here for the xiao long baos.

Din Tai Fung is one of my favourite places to go to for xiao long baos. Although they lack the novelty of the creative multi flavoured xiao long baos at Paradise Dynasty, they do the normal xiao long baos really well and have their own varieties like chilli crab dumplings, pork and crab dumplings, red bean paste dumplings etc.The dumpling skin is just right in thickness and the broth is delicious! The chicken soup is also really tasty, as is the beef soup. We also really like the fried rice which is one of the best we've had. The dou miao is also really commendable and is sold out pretty often by dinner time. The prawn beancurd skin rolls are a tad oily and I'm not that big a fan of the pork chop, but their noodles are quite decent.Overall a great place for a meal.

This place has amazing dumplings! I had the veggie dumplings and bun, and it was amazing. My boyfriend had pork dumplings, which he loved as well. They also serve complementary hot jasmine green tea with the food. The service is fast, the kitchen is very hygienic (they wear masks and serious hairnets), and I totally recommend it if you're looking for a place for a quick bite!

World famous DTF... there's nothing I can write in this review that someone else hasn't already written. Suffice to say the xiaolanpo is one of the best, and the pork fat cures any hangover ills.Expect to wait during peak hours.

This is the very first Din Tai Fung we ever ate at and wow, we were missing out on one of the world's best foods. The Xiao Long Baos here are the best, taste just like every other Din Tai Fung, even the original ones in Taipei. We eat only the pork XLB, and this places gives you a lot compared to other countries!! We tried the royal truffle bao and it was ok. The pork fried rice is also good and try the tapioca based desserts.

Dim Sum is something that is hard to come by in the states, I guess the recipes and ingredients are hard to recreate here.But, din tai fung is a restaurant I look forward to every time I travel to Singapore! Best soup dumplings () ever, and almost any other dim sum on their menu is bound to be good. Do not even think about visiting Singapore without stopping by one of their locations (I think there is like 4-5 locations across the island).

Din Tai Fung is a Chinese restaurant that is associated with its famous signature Xiao Long Baos (steamed pork dumplings), but it offers so much more than that. Dining amidst this brightly lit modern setting will surely give you an enjoyable dining experience. Their Taiwan Shrimp and Pork Oriental Wantons with Spicy Sauce bring a fiery twist to the normal pork dumplings. These bite-sized dumplings are generously doused with chili oil and black vinegar, bringing out the flavor of the pork and shrimp. Another simple yet fulfilling dish to try is their Fried Rice with Pork Chop. The fried rice is cooked till fragrant, while the pork chop is tender and savory. If you seek a heavier meal, then the Minced Meat Noodles would satisfy you. The noodles are smooth while the saltiness and flavor of the sauce makes it appetizing. The food can be a tad oily, so be sure to order some Chinese Tea to flush it down.

Din Tai Fung is one of those places that I always fall back on when we don't feel like being creative with our dining choices, simply because they can do no wrong. Their top seller is definitely their Xiao Long Baos, which are soup dumplings with pork fillings. They explode in your mouth with a soupy broth that tastes both rich and thick at the same time, one of the best in Singapore! One of my recent discoveries was their Yam Dumplings, which are usually served as dessert dumplings. It's a sweet dumpling, filled with a soft and finely milled yam paste that isn't too cloyingly sweet. Aside from their dumplings, they also serve a great Bean Paste Noodles, that is mixed with  minced pork and tofu to give it a more Oriental feel compared to its Korean influences. Their Pork Chop Fried Rice, which sounds unassuming, is also deliciously crispy but thick served with steaming fragrant rice fried with battered eggs. Service is always as prompt as they can, given the perpetual long queues. But seating arrangements are always well organized with a numbered system. Hot chinese tea is also served free-flow throughout your meal, and continuously filled to the point where you filled obliged to drink several pots before saying No!

For a quick and easy and delicious meal, this is the place.  Have been in Singapore and in Shanghai.  Service is always quick, though there may be a wait to get a table and the food comes right away and is great.

Is this the best Xiao Long Bao in the country? In the world? I don't know, and I don't really care, because I just like coming here (and their other outlets) to get my fill of steaming hot soup dumplings, spinach with sesame dressing and when I'm feeling fancy, drunken chicken. As the other reviewers have pointed out, this place is crowded all the time, so expect there to be a bit of a wait. Once you've ordered though, things move quickly without you feeling rushed. I wish we had more of the Taiwanese menu available here, but this is still bar none my favorite XLB place in town.

One of the best meals I had in Singapore. We ordered Zha Jiang noodles, Dan Dan noodles, Shanghai dumplings (crab & normal), pickled cucumbers, beef cold cuts, fried rice with pork, vegetarian buns and vegetarian dumplings. Everything was very good, but the crab dumplings were not too memorable. Service was very good as well. This place was still packed at 8:30 at night and the mall closes at 10.

Din Tai Fung have made changes to their menu.  We tasted the dumplings with fish, pork, shrimp, and were surprised how dry they had become. The meat was ground course and we swore it had the consistency of ground beef. The changes since we started visiting Din Tai Fung the past 4 years has been a decline and we have started looking for Hong Kong style dumplings.  Service was prompt and adequate, and would go back if it were convenient for quick meal.

address: 201 Balestier Road Quality Hotel, Level 2, S329926 Singapore 329926 Singapore
comment: Steamboat was above average, this could probably be the best vegetarian steamboat around the area. Do not come here if U're looking for a good spread of buffet. Their normal buffet servings look like leftover food from lunch... they look cold. We had steamboat buffet (instead of the normal buffet as it looks unappetising), I have to say it was fantastic! However, this restaurant's motto is 'DO NOT WASTE'. So indeed, they have been true to their words... For every ala carte serving we ordered, they 'QC' us in every possible way... Judging if we were big enough to finish the amount of servings we ordered, whether we should remove any platter. It was a very uncomfortable experience with the service crew. They basically didn't quite allow us to have what we ordered (which initially was amusing)... But turned out annoying when it was repeatedly done throughout our ENTIRE meal. We had to constantly argue and justify to the staffs that we can finish it in order to have our orders processed each time we add on more ala-carte dishes. It was ridiculous from our stand point as customers as we are paying for our food, but it felt like we had to beg for them!! The older chinese staff kept coming back to check on our pot before allowing us to order. We left feeling really unsatisfied and disgusted with the service. Disclaimer: the staffs were nice and friendly, steamboat was really good. But the approach towards their customers should be improved!

address: 201 Balestier Road Quality Hotel, Level 2, S329926 Singapore 329926 Singapore
comment: This is the only place I know of in Singapore that serves up a (Chinese-style) vegetarian buffet spread. It has been around for several years now, and this recent visit on a Sunday afternoon saw more crowd than I had remembered before. The restaurant was about 60 - 70% filled, I guess they must have been doing something right.There's a main buffet line with about 15 - 20 hot dishes such as stir-fry vegetables, braised tofu, tau kwa, long beans, sweet pea, seaweed crunch, mock meats, curry, soup etc. There are also staples like bee hoon, mee sua, laksa, "chicken rice", porridge, and a tiny selection of dim sum.On the side, you'll find ice-cream, fruits and kueh kueh; a not-very-impressive salad bar, and drinks station.A decent place for family gatherings, or hanging out with your vegetarian friends. I didn't get to try everything, not even the desserts. There's just something about Chinese vegetarian food that stuffs you up, leaving you slightly bloated and feeling full way too soon. Not a restaurant I'll go very often, but a good option for a sumptuous vegetarian feast.

rest_name: 旺角點心 Mongkok Dim Sum
comment: Everything was good, and I wish we were feeding a bigger group so we could have tried one of everything. The only awkward part was not getting seated and standing around when we arrived. The food more than made up for it though.For American stomachs, this spot is very gentle and should be a good meal even for someone who's picky.

rest_name: 旺角點心 Mongkok Dim Sum
comment: This was not good at all.  I didn't have high hopes going in but it turned out to be worse than I had expected.  We ordered a few things to share (har gao, lotus paste buns, steamed rice rolls, beancurd roll with pork and shrimp and spinach dumplings) and they were all underwhelming.  Everything seemed to have been reheated as they all fell apart when we tried to pick it up.  Flavor was bland and it was hard to finish the small amount of food we had gotten.  Do not recommend.

rest_name: 旺角點心 Mongkok Dim Sum
comment: Would be the first and the last time if me going there. Yes, it was great that I get to eat Dim Sum at 5am when I was really craving for it, but to get all the way there, and being served with barely-considered-warm porridge, slightly below average dim sum, was seriously a damper. Part of me wish that I have gone for mamak instead... But good thing - at least it's open, 24 hours if you really need your dim sum fix. But ya, depends on how desperate you are ... Otherwise just wait a bit and there should be plenary open by 8am.... And my fav opens at 11am :)

rest_name: 旺角點心 Mongkok Dim Sum
