Rather limited menu. Service was patchy. Food quality was very good, but pricy for the portions served. Beers are bottle only and served not very cold. Only real thing it has going for it is the atmosphere. Probably good for just an afternoon tea.

This is a review of a work-related team event at Cafe Melba.  There were approximately 50 people at the dinner/drinks event.This review will be shorter and less detailed than most of my dining reviews.I asked a small group from the team I manage to organize a end of year holiday party for our team.  They selected Cafe Melba (in the Goodman Arts Centre).Cafe Melba has indoor seating and covered outdoor seating with mounted wall fans.  Our event was held in the al fresco area.  View of indoor seating:tinyurl.com/cuqvpepThe outdoor seating area is quite nice.  It maintains a feel of almost being indoors.  It easily accommodated our group and could also accommodate a quite larger group.  I do not think weather (unless very severe) would be an issue.  The covering looked as if it could hold up against a relatively steady and strong rain.  The fans were well placed to keep the area cooled.View of outdoor seating:tinyurl.com/c23enfuWe had a buffet style meal.  Drinks were provided via pre-paid tickets.The food was quite good.  Everyone seemed to really enjoy it.  There were numerous dishes including a chicken, beef, pasta dish, different kinds of pizza, salads, etc..  Chicken:tinyurl.com/cwje5slPizza:tinyurl.com/cc98g64Misc:tinyurl.com/cuznjjaThe staff was attentive and kept the food and drinks flowing.  The manager was on site throughout the event and in constant contact to insure the evening was going well.Overall - Cafe Melba provided the back-drop for an enjoyable event.  The outdoor space was perfect for our team event.   The staff was professional, polite and helpful.  The management was engaged in assuring the event went well.  Very importantly, they served a wide range of well-prepared food that was enjoyed by the team.  I would have no issue in planning another team event there.  Once again, I thought they did an all around great job.
Nice place but the food is not good at all. Too bad for a place with such nice ambiance...

My favourite dishes? They gotta be1. Beef Rendang2. Rib Eye Sandwich3. Rocket and Parma pizza 4. Crab fish Linguine Oh and the list goes on...!A pretty little bistro tucked in a little corner at the Goodman Arts Centre that used to be the basketball court of the Old Lasalle College of the Arts.Besides the mains, diners can look forward to all day brunch and for those who just want a little snack, check out their Carrot Cake. Filled with raisins and walnuts, it's more than just a normal carrot cake! The size is good for 2 to share at $8/slice.Their lychee martini according to a fren who can't resist a glass of good martini thinks its pretty good too. Ok, now I'm really hungry!!

This place is cute. There is plenty of outdoor seating and on a "cooler" singaporean night - its a great place to chill - have a drink and some food. Food selection was alright - since I'm vegetarian my selection was of course limited, but I had pizza and calzones to choose from so it was alright. My friend had the steak and was decently satisfied. We chilled here for quite a while and it was super enjoyable.

A surprising find.We were here on a Friday evening and it was surprisingly not crazy busy. Love the chill-out ambience. We were a big group and had no problem finding a table.We only had pizza and truffle fries. Pizza were super thin crust and great for sharing. Think skinny pizza. But if you're a fan of neopolitan style like I am, then this is good but not great.Great relaxing place to hang out with friends. They seem to do great brunches. So maybe I will be back to try that next time.

Hands down, my new favorite family brunch place in Singapore. We went on a Sunday morning at 10 and almost every table outside was a family (we were 4 adults and 3 kids). It was a great experience - the atmosphere was great, the food was outstanding and the service excellent. Since I think we got there on the early side, there was really no wait to speak of. We were seated promptly, the ordering process by iPad was explained and the kids were free to go to town.  I ordered the eggs Benedict, my wife had the eggs florentine and out friends has the full breakfast and another dish - everyone loved the meals! The portions were excellent and the food was served quickly. The kids menu was extensive and the little ones devoured the pancakes and French toast. Prices were very reasonable as well. I don't think I could have enjoyed the experience more. I wanted to take a picture but honestly, the food looked so good, by the time I remembered to, I had already dug in! :)A co-worker goes often in the evening and raves about the pizza and dinner meals - he often goes for a beer and meal after work; I plan to join him again soon as I am anxious to try the non-breakfast items.

Had come here with a big group for desserts. Got the chocolate lava cake, creme brûlée and bunch of coffees. Was average in terms of the desserts. Have tasted better. Good place to hang out with a group of friends. one of the few places in Singapore where you can actually sit outside without too much discomfort.

All round pretty good Aussie food. Pleasant setting although road noise is a little loud.  $6 for a flat white is steep considering the small small cup.  Great area for kids to run and play. Recommend for brunch.

Cafe Melba is housed in Goodman Arts Centre which would be a challenge for those getting there via public transport. Lucky for us, we drove to get there and parking wasn't a problem.A good number of patrons were mostly families with children and the open field in front of the cafe allowed these toddlers to run around freely and play. We happen to visit the cafe on a Sunday so we had the brunch menu selection. For starters, we ordered the Curried Pumpkin and Corn Soup. As for our main course, my boyfriend who is a fan of steaks, decided to order the Ribeye Steak (200grams) while I went for the Melba Burger. To avoid having our food all at once, we requested for the soup to be served prior to our main course. However, everything was served at once much to our dismay. The soup came with four slices of parmesan naan which was a good attempt at matching the curried soup although, did not compliment it. A simple soft roll would have done the job. On another note, thumbs up to the taste and flavor of the soup. It also looked fantastic and the aroma drew us in even more. The Ribeye Steak that my boyfriend ordered was unfortunately a letdown. He had a choice between the Black Pepper or Béarnaise sauce which he chose the latter. It tasted good, but did not go well with the Steak. Moreover, his steak was mildly seasoned and unevenly cooked (he ordered medium rare). The shoe string fries on the side tasted better than the star of the dish. It was golden brown, crispy, and flavorful. The steak also came with salad in balsamic vinegar dressing that was light and refreshing.My Melba Burger looked great. Pieces of bacon were stuffed between the buns along with a perfectly cooked medium rare beef patty and home-made relish sauce. It tasted good, but lack the depth in flavor that would have made me crave for more.Service wise, the staff did not pay much attention to us probably due to the influx of customers. We felt that the service was more of a routine to clear out tables for incoming customers rather than to create that service moment that could have left us with a good impression.Overall service aspect made our experience with cafe melba a mediocre one although the food was not bad. It was however not worth the price we paid and we expected a lot more from them. A few minor tweaks especially in the service aspect would have guaranteed my return.

Food-wise was average... not bad but not spectacular.Came here on a weekend morning and had the Full Melba Cooked Breakfast for $25:  2 eggs, pork sausages, bacon, roasted cherry tomatoes, baked beans, mushrooms, hash brown & toast. I was pretty hungry and considered getting the Mega Melba Cooked Breakfast, an upsized version of the Full Melba, which was $36. The Mega Melba doubles the portions of everything but the eggs, and what I really wanted was more eggs, so I stuck with the Full Melba.It says on the menu that you're not allowed to share the Mega Melba, or in their words "can't be splitted". That's not very nice... I wonder if they would have a problem with their customers sharing any of the other dishes? Is the Mega Melba too good a deal? They did however provide a glass bottle of water and cups without us having to ask which I thought was nice considering how many cafes these days won't even serve you tap water.Overall, I can see myself coming back if I'm in the area. I don't mind paying a little extra to avoid the crowds.

Porcini Mushroom Ravioli ($18 before GST) - 2.5 starsArrabbiata sauce, mushroom fricassee, cheese, and crushed hazelnutsI was really disappointed with this dish because it sounded, and looked, so promising. Unfortunately, it tasted very much like American-Italian - in this case I suppose it'd be Australian-Italian although I haven't had Italian food in Australia. It'd probably be the equivalent of having pasta at Buca Di Beppo in California. I liked that the flavours were strong, but what I enjoyed about the dish ended there. It wasn't refined at all - it tasted heavy and cloying, and not in a good way the way comfort food can be. The ravioli skins were far too thick - imagine fat floury soggy dumpling wrappers - and were stuffed with cheese that was the wrong texture. The hazelnuts also ended up adding to the density of the dish as well, when I could've used some herbs or greens to lighten and freshen the dish.I'm giving it three stars overall because I'd try some of the other (probably non-pasta) dishes if I do go back. Ambience overall was cute, though I can see why another reviewer said it leaned toward ramshackle rather than rustic.

This is a regular Saturday or Sunday brunch location for my family and friends. Specifically because it is so good for kids. A large field for kids to run around in, a sand pit, and their own Bouncy Castle. While it sits next to a busy main road there is a fence keeping the children playing in grass and not traffic. With ample outdoor seating there is always a full patio of parents enjoying some quiet time while the kids run wild. When it is time for the kids to come back and eat they have a reasonable set kids menu that includes drinks and a dessert. Also the menu is a paper placemat with it's own coloring, activities, and colored pencils. I find the food to be good, it isn't the best food in town, but I certainly don't dislike eating here. I have ordered the Chicken Schnitzel burger before and forgotten that it is too much chicken and almost impossible to eat and enjoy. The Burger is good, the wood fired pizza is also good. The price does feel a bit expensive, not outrageous in Singapore but a bit high, worth it for the distracted children though. The service has been good, a variety of wait staff, all who can help you and take your order, things do get a bit slow, but they do get slammed and busy.As I side note, while I have not experienced it, apparently they are more than kids and castles, they have live music and ladies night throughout the week as well. May have to come back here and try it one evening.

Standard has dropped a lot over the years. Ordered the pancakes during a not so busy time of 4pm and they were pretty obviously microwaved and not freshly made. How do I know? Arrived almost instantly, with steam blazing hot coming out of the pancakes and a horrible texture that can only be achieved with microwaved-old-food. Tasted pretty horrible and the garnish of half a sliced banana was just sad. Was served with what tasted like cheap syrup rather than a maple sauce or anything remotely nice. Had the rosti as well. Did not add salt at all and the "poached" eggs were kinda hard boiled. Nothing was seasoned properly. Kinda disappointing because this was in my memory a great place to eat at. Prices are still high. Ordering system was good and efficient but poorly planned on some tables. The iPad was placed in the middle of 2 diners eating which to me was pretty poor thinking. The floor around me was wet and had food all around telling me that the servers were pretty oblivious to things going on around the restaurant. Pretty sure this does not happen that often here but this particular experience was exceptionally poor. For their prices & the amount of people that were there while I was there at 4pm, they really should have some sort of consistency towards their cooking with a full team of chefs in the kitchen.

This is a review of a work-related team event at Cafe Melba.  There were approximately 50 people at the dinner/drinks event.This review will be shorter and less detailed than most of my dining reviews.I asked a small group from the team I manage to organize a end of year holiday party for our team.  They selected Cafe Melba (in the Goodman Arts Centre).Cafe Melba has indoor seating and covered outdoor seating with mounted wall fans.  Our event was held in the al fresco area.  View of indoor seating:tinyurl.com/cuqvpepThe outdoor seating area is quite nice.  It maintains a feel of almost being indoors.  It easily accommodated our group and could also accommodate a quite larger group.  I do not think weather (unless very severe) would be an issue.  The covering looked as if it could hold up against a relatively steady and strong rain.  The fans were well placed to keep the area cooled.View of outdoor seating:tinyurl.com/c23enfuWe had a buffet style meal.  Drinks were provided via pre-paid tickets.The food was quite good.  Everyone seemed to really enjoy it.  There were numerous dishes including a chicken, beef, pasta dish, different kinds of pizza, salads, etc..  Chicken:tinyurl.com/cwje5slPizza:tinyurl.com/cc98g64Misc:tinyurl.com/cuznjjaThe staff was attentive and kept the food and drinks flowing.  The manager was on site throughout the event and in constant contact to insure the evening was going well.Overall - Cafe Melba provided the back-drop for an enjoyable event.  The outdoor space was perfect for our team event.   The staff was professional, polite and helpful.  The management was engaged in assuring the event went well.  Very importantly, they served a wide range of well-prepared food that was enjoyed by the team.  I would have no issue in planning another team event there.  Once again, I thought they did an all around great job.

My favourite dishes? They gotta be1. Beef Rendang2. Rib Eye Sandwich3. Rocket and Parma pizza 4. Crab fish Linguine Oh and the list goes on...!A pretty little bistro tucked in a little corner at the Goodman Arts Centre that used to be the basketball court of the Old Lasalle College of the Arts.Besides the mains, diners can look forward to all day brunch and for those who just want a little snack, check out their Carrot Cake. Filled with raisins and walnuts, it's more than just a normal carrot cake! The size is good for 2 to share at $8/slice.Their lychee martini according to a fren who can't resist a glass of good martini thinks its pretty good too. Ok, now I'm really hungry!!

Had pretty high expectations going in, but unfortunately left feeling disappointed.My brunch that I ordered felt like everything had been pre-cooked, including my poached eggs!! All of the plate was cold and the toast even tasted stale or perhaps it was because it was served cold.  Anyway it tasted terrible and I only got through 2 mouthfuls.  For $16, what a waste.Also I ordered a babycino for my toddler.  It came out piping hot!! Way too hot for a kid to drink. And  it was actually a full size cup of heated milk??!! The babycinos that I normally receive are just the frothed milk/foam in a small cup..I wouldn't go back unfortunately.

Hands down, my new favorite family brunch place in Singapore. We went on a Sunday morning at 10 and almost every table outside was a family (we were 4 adults and 3 kids). It was a great experience - the atmosphere was great, the food was outstanding and the service excellent. Since I think we got there on the early side, there was really no wait to speak of. We were seated promptly, the ordering process by iPad was explained and the kids were free to go to town.  I ordered the eggs Benedict, my wife had the eggs florentine and out friends has the full breakfast and another dish - everyone loved the meals! The portions were excellent and the food was served quickly. The kids menu was extensive and the little ones devoured the pancakes and French toast. Prices were very reasonable as well. I don't think I could have enjoyed the experience more. I wanted to take a picture but honestly, the food looked so good, by the time I remembered to, I had already dug in! :)A co-worker goes often in the evening and raves about the pizza and dinner meals - he often goes for a beer and meal after work; I plan to join him again soon as I am anxious to try the non-breakfast items.

Great place for families! I enjoyed the food selection (had eggs florentine that was tasty. Service was exceptional, food and drinks were well prepared, kids enjoyed the bouncer and gravel play box, and the adults enjoyed the time to chat and catch up. We will be back again!

The restaurant is located in an interesting setting overlooking a humongous lawn inside a Arts Centre and that makes for very nice ambience. Had gone for the RedMart Craft beer festival which was happening in the lawns and popped in the restaurant for some pizza & frozen margaritas both were pretty good, pricing was ok and I found the service to be particularly good! All in all would like to go again

Came for breakfast on a Saturday.  Mostly families enjoying the bouncy castle nearby and sitting outdoors. I had granola with yogurt and berries. The food was fresh.  My boyfriend had the omlette which was delicious! We both enjoyed a flat white and long black for coffees. I would go back for their dinner specials which look good. A solid meal.

This is a regular Saturday or Sunday brunch location for my family and friends. Specifically because it is so good for kids. A large field for kids to run around in, a sand pit, and their own Bouncy Castle. While it sits next to a busy main road there is a fence keeping the children playing in grass and not traffic. With ample outdoor seating there is always a full patio of parents enjoying some quiet time while the kids run wild. When it is time for the kids to come back and eat they have a reasonable set kids menu that includes drinks and a dessert. Also the menu is a paper placemat with it's own coloring, activities, and colored pencils. I find the food to be good, it isn't the best food in town, but I certainly don't dislike eating here. I have ordered the Chicken Schnitzel burger before and forgotten that it is too much chicken and almost impossible to eat and enjoy. The Burger is good, the wood fired pizza is also good. The price does feel a bit expensive, not outrageous in Singapore but a bit high, worth it for the distracted children though. The service has been good, a variety of wait staff, all who can help you and take your order, things do get a bit slow, but they do get slammed and busy.As I side note, while I have not experienced it, apparently they are more than kids and castles, they have live music and ladies night throughout the week as well. May have to come back here and try it one evening.

Went there for Sunday brunch and the place was a zoo of children. They have a bouncy castle which will occupy the little ones for days. There was a special event for Chinese New Year and it was fun with Lion Dancing and face painting, arts and crafts, balloons, etc. Brunch is simply a breakfast menu and I was not impressed. I couldn't order a sandwich till 11:00 am so I was disappointed. The bacon was steamed and I felt bad the rest of the day. One piece of toast was not enough and I waited 45 minutes for a second $4.00 piece. Dry, cold and everything else had been consumed. The service was horrible. They were busy--I'll give them that--but the drinks were super slow, the food just average and waiting for the toast infuriating. And, they didn't care. The tip was included in the bill and I tipped more so they got more than average for a bad experience. I will say the people at the restaurant were some of the best looking folks on earth. Lots of ex-pats with about a dozen languages floating around. Eggs, toast, bacon, a breakfast sandwich, two juices and it was $75.

Cafe Melba is housed in Goodman Arts Centre which would be a challenge for those getting there via public transport. Lucky for us, we drove to get there and parking wasn't a problem.A good number of patrons were mostly families with children and the open field in front of the cafe allowed these toddlers to run around freely and play. We happen to visit the cafe on a Sunday so we had the brunch menu selection. For starters, we ordered the Curried Pumpkin and Corn Soup. As for our main course, my boyfriend who is a fan of steaks, decided to order the Ribeye Steak (200grams) while I went for the Melba Burger. To avoid having our food all at once, we requested for the soup to be served prior to our main course. However, everything was served at once much to our dismay. The soup came with four slices of parmesan naan which was a good attempt at matching the curried soup although, did not compliment it. A simple soft roll would have done the job. On another note, thumbs up to the taste and flavor of the soup. It also looked fantastic and the aroma drew us in even more. The Ribeye Steak that my boyfriend ordered was unfortunately a letdown. He had a choice between the Black Pepper or Béarnaise sauce which he chose the latter. It tasted good, but did not go well with the Steak. Moreover, his steak was mildly seasoned and unevenly cooked (he ordered medium rare). The shoe string fries on the side tasted better than the star of the dish. It was golden brown, crispy, and flavorful. The steak also came with salad in balsamic vinegar dressing that was light and refreshing.My Melba Burger looked great. Pieces of bacon were stuffed between the buns along with a perfectly cooked medium rare beef patty and home-made relish sauce. It tasted good, but lack the depth in flavor that would have made me crave for more.Service wise, the staff did not pay much attention to us probably due to the influx of customers. We felt that the service was more of a routine to clear out tables for incoming customers rather than to create that service moment that could have left us with a good impression.Overall service aspect made our experience with cafe melba a mediocre one although the food was not bad. It was however not worth the price we paid and we expected a lot more from them. A few minor tweaks especially in the service aspect would have guaranteed my return.

I love of how spacious the place is . It's one of places that ppl in East can go for relaxing brunch and lunch , but beware there are lotsa kids in here . I had burger w extra pineapple and beetroot and I had kiwi passion fruit smoothies for my drinks. Both r great and worthed for the price. We were waiting for about fifteen mins when we went there on Sunday around 1pm

Food was good, but not great. Curried pumpkin soup was lovely -- great texture, lots of flavour. The naan bread it came with was okay, but didn't feel like "proper" naan. Truffle fries were delish -- we devoured them once they finally arrived... ... which leads me to why the 3 stars. Service is TERRIBLE. Terrible! Our server couldn't remember our orders. When they arrived, they came at widely different times. One got left off completely, and we had to wait another 20 minutes for it. It was a gong show. Great wine list. We had lots of that. :)The atmosphere is lovely -- being able to sit outside with fans, in front of a green space, and listen to music wafting in from nearby studios -- all really comfortable and relaxed.I just wish the service wasn't so relaxed. It's the one thing that needs a kick in the pants.
Great location for kids. Shame the service is non-existent with one staff working on a weekend morning. Food average and cold. New management needed and may turn it around

Great place for families! I enjoyed the food selection (had eggs florentine that was tasty. Service was exceptional, food and drinks were well prepared, kids enjoyed the bouncer and gravel play box, and the adults enjoyed the time to chat and catch up. We will be back again!

The restaurant is located in an interesting setting overlooking a humongous lawn inside a Arts Centre and that makes for very nice ambience. Had gone for the RedMart Craft beer festival which was happening in the lawns and popped in the restaurant for some pizza & frozen margaritas both were pretty good, pricing was ok and I found the service to be particularly good! All in all would like to go again

I LOVE brunch! And I think I have found my go to brunch place! For starters, the atmosphere is super chill, perfect for a relaxing brunch. I ordered the eggs benedict and it was super yum! The eggs were free range eggs and they were perfectly poached with a runny yolk. The hollandaise was just how I liked it, accenting the eggs but not overwhemingly heavy. Last but not least, I tried the iced long black coffee and I think its one of the best iced coffees I've had in Singapore. Defintely a place to revisit!

Dropped by on a quiet Tuesday afternoon and they had 1-for-1 promotion for pizza going on so we took full advantage of that. We got two half&halfs - Chilli Crab and Pepperoni as well as Forest Mushroom and Parma Ham with Rocket. The pizzas are the thin crust variety which is perfect for when you're feeling peckish and not wanting to feel too full too quickly. I'd really recommend the Chilli Crab, my Favorite among the lot we chose. Truffle fries were decent, as with the flat whites. Spotted their promotion on margaritas when I was in the Ladies midway through our meal and decided to get a carafe of Strawberry Margarita to ease into the evening. Frozen margarita was a good idea; tangy refreshing and very much welcomed on the palate after too much carbs between two girls. A word of caution for the slow sipper though, frozen beverages doesn't take too kindly to our harsh humid weather so it didn't take too long till we had a quarter of our carafe left with unattractive slush floating on lukewarm pink liquid - and we were seated indoors! Service was attentive and laid back and I wouldn't mind coming around again to try other items off their extensive menu

A surprising find.We were here on a Friday evening and it was surprisingly not crazy busy. Love the chill-out ambience. We were a big group and had no problem finding a table.We only had pizza and truffle fries. Pizza were super thin crust and great for sharing. Think skinny pizza. But if you're a fan of neopolitan style like I am, then this is good but not great.Great relaxing place to hang out with friends. They seem to do great brunches. So maybe I will be back to try that next time.

The brunch here is one of the better ones I've had in Singapore for the longest time. The ambience here is great and you can spot many other like minded individuals and families here having coffee and enjoying the food.It's shaded from the sun, thanks to a large awning and there's ample smoking area. the fans provide just the right amount of breeze should you choose to sit outside, or you can sit in air-conditioned comfort inside and watch the chefs prepare your meal, thanks to an open kitchen concept.

Ambiance 100%This is the immediate impression when we stepped in to this charming cafe right in the middle of no where one rainy afternoon after lunch. It is so idyllic and very quiet when we were there. We absolutely adored the decor! It felt like someone's open kitchen, filled with delicious things on the shelves.We only tried their coffees since we already had lunch, but seems like I need to go back again to try the food. I'm already sold on the ambiance, so the food won't be a big problem. Now, how to get there without driving is the challenge...
Nice place but the food is not good at all. Too bad for a place with such nice ambiance...

okayish australian brunch food hidden away in the goodman arts centre. this place has drawn mixed reviews since opening this year - and I'm about to toss my own undecided judgement into the mix, just so you have as difficult a time as I did of deciding if it's worth visiting.on second thought, perhaps that's not the best strategy for ingratiating myself into your favor. so here's it straight up: this place has great potential, but the food and service are in firm not-travel-worthy-but-I'll-have-it-if-it's-there territory. or more succinctly, meh.I admit to wanting to come here for the longest time, despite those reviews: I had seen photos of the gorgeous space in design blogs, and there's just something incredibly appealing about good lighting for photography.but the place doesn't look nearly this good (one day I will learn to stop trusting photos) in the daytime - and there was this slight ramshackle shabbiness about it, like they hadn't bothered to take care of what should be a well-curated space.the pizzas fared the best that day, hands down. we had the chili crab, mushroom and a trifecta of meat products on the three little pigs. these were well-cooked in a wood-fired oven, with a crust that verged between cracker and thin-crust (nothing nearly as flavorful as the famed mozza - but good in its way), and the ingredients were suitably piled on.the other dishes were less interesting: a burger was stacked high and pretty - and so were the pile of pancakes I ordered, which came in a healthy stack of four and drizzled with compote - and the full melba cooked breakfast was a generous plateful of food. but these suffered from bimboticism, having mastered the art of looking good without much substance.so really, if you're here - head for the pizzas. the other stuff isn't bad, and actually perhaps on par with some hipsterish cafes, but I don't think it's worth traveling for. there is just this pervading sense of unfulfilled potential rather perpetuated also by the sheer nothing-outstanding-ness of both service and food. much better food elsewhere, really.

I am currently in the midst of preparing to record an album at the Goodman arts centre and there aren't too many options for food in the centre. However i did manage to try a bit of food at Cafe Melba. I had what can be described as a type of pizza basket. It's clean slices of flour and dough with some meat, vegetable and cheese toppings on it. These pizzas are extremely thin and you may eat them with a choice of 3 sauces that are given to you - pesto, olive and chick peas sauce. The price range is a bit high. The quality of service is pretty good. And the ambience is the best part of the place. They have a very cool outdoor space seating area with wooden benches and tables. They also have pretty excellent coffee. It's a chillout sunday sort of a place for me.

$40 for a tasteless Reuben Sandwich & frozen margarita - ouch!  Corned beef should be pinky red - not a dirty grey btw....the sauerkraut should be tart & crisp not soggy and bland.  Very disappointed.

Went there for Sunday brunch and the place was a zoo of children. They have a bouncy castle which will occupy the little ones for days. There was a special event for Chinese New Year and it was fun with Lion Dancing and face painting, arts and crafts, balloons, etc. Brunch is simply a breakfast menu and I was not impressed. I couldn't order a sandwich till 11:00 am so I was disappointed. The bacon was steamed and I felt bad the rest of the day. One piece of toast was not enough and I waited 45 minutes for a second $4.00 piece. Dry, cold and everything else had been consumed. The service was horrible. They were busy--I'll give them that--but the drinks were super slow, the food just average and waiting for the toast infuriating. And, they didn't care. The tip was included in the bill and I tipped more so they got more than average for a bad experience. I will say the people at the restaurant were some of the best looking folks on earth. Lots of ex-pats with about a dozen languages floating around. Eggs, toast, bacon, a breakfast sandwich, two juices and it was $75.

Rather limited menu. Service was patchy. Food quality was very good, but pricy for the portions served. Beers are bottle only and served not very cold. Only real thing it has going for it is the atmosphere. Probably good for just an afternoon tea.

This place is cute. There is plenty of outdoor seating and on a "cooler" singaporean night - its a great place to chill - have a drink and some food. Food selection was alright - since I'm vegetarian my selection was of course limited, but I had pizza and calzones to choose from so it was alright. My friend had the steak and was decently satisfied. We chilled here for quite a while and it was super enjoyable.

address: 1 Goldhill Plaza, #01-19/21 Goldhill Plaza Singapore 308899 Singapore
comment: Made a reservation at this Italian restaurant near united square for dinner.Our reservation was for 8.45pm and we came at 8.15pm. We're told to come back later as no table - understandable as we were early. However, when we came back punctually at 8.45pm, we were told to WAIT FOR ANOTHER 10 MINUTES?!?!?!? I thought we reserved already?!?!? What's the point of reserving if we still have to wait even though we reserve?!?!? My 老爸 (old dad) very angry leh!!Even after waiting for 20 minutes, still no table and even worse, waiter who did not allow us to have table at first denied not allowing us to have table. He 'swear to my parents, it wasn't me'  Lie to us, still dare to swear to parents?!?!? Come on lah!Overall... Come on!!! Lie to us, don't reserve table for us even though we call to make reservation, 'swear to parents', made us wait over 30 minutes beyond our reservation timing, and so many others!! Never coming back again!! Please don't go unless you want to be treated like this!!!Note: if the restaurant can prove otherwise, this post will be deleted

address: 1 Goldhill Plaza, #01-19/21 Goldhill Plaza Singapore 308899 Singapore
comment: One of the best Italian restaurant! The uni scallop truffle cold pasta is really good! It's not in the menu so you got to request for it! By the way, if I am not wrong, it's 85 per serving which you could split into two. The other dishes are also super awesome. You must try to burrata + egg starters!

address: 1 Goldhill Plaza, #01-19/21 Goldhill Plaza Singapore 308899 Singapore
comment: It's ok as a neighborhood Italian joint, nothing more than that. I found every dish very ordinary and mediocre. Maybe I was there on an off day but the pork chop was disappointing, the lamb rack was so-so. All 3 pastas we tried were also passable. We went there for the chilled angel hair (off the menu item) and it was probably the best item of the night and yet it did not live up to its hype.Also found the pricing high even though the portions are quite generous.

address: 1 Goldhill Plaza, #01-19/21 Goldhill Plaza Singapore 308899 Singapore
comment: We chanced upon Da Luca via a search online knowing that we will be in Novena area, didn't even have time to read reviews. Decided not to take any chances and called to make reservations. Boy... Were we glad that we did. Upon arriving 5 mins after, groups of families and friends started to stream in. Seriously, this quiet hidden gem of a restaurant is doing well on a Monday night!! I loved the fact that the restaurant had an over-enthusiastic manager that made my bf and I feel at home and comfortable. At that instance I thought to myself, this was going to be a wonderful experience. And I was right! Our orders included: 1. Starters - Fried calamari- Honestly, It wasn't love at first sight. But upon tasting it, it really was quite good. The batter had to be light to bring out the freshness and sweetness of the calamari. Anything heavier it would have not done the poor calamari justice. 2. Mains - Hand made Tagliatelle with wild mushroom and minced beef sauce - Ok people this is worth every calorie! The taste of the porcini mushrooms infused beef sauce was just the bomb! Not to mention, the hand made eggy tagliatelle was al dente, complemented the sauce very well! 3. Mains - Penne with crab meat in light tomato sauce. - The crab meat with the light tomato sauce was pretty good too but I wished it would have been lighter in taste with bigger chunks of crab. This was just ok for me as I had better ones else where. Overall, I had a great time! Homey, Good service with good food that's affordable, what's not to like. The only thing I wished was that they had ample parking. Best way is to park at United square, then walk towards where the taxi stand is (near toast box). Take that exit, and walk towards the building to your right, It'll be the closest to the restaurant. We will definitely be back to try other dishes!! Good stuff!

address: 1 Goldhill Plaza, #01-19/21 Goldhill Plaza Singapore 308899 Singapore
comment: The food is just okay but the atmosphere is nice and relaxed.  The wine and food prices are reasonable.  Overall, fine for a quick night out.  The service started out spotty.  We were given a table that was dirty and, after ten minutes, realized that we had to ask to have it cleaned up.  Not the best first impression.  We had the wild rocket salad with pears and Parmesan, pappardelle with duck and the grilled pork chop.  The salad and pork were nothing memorable.  I would not get the salad again as we had maybe one slice of pear and having more pear would have balanced the pepperiness of the salad.  The pasta was well prepared though.  Good bite to the pasta and the duck sauce was nice as well.  As the prices are good, we will likely be back but just for the pasta.

address: 1 Goldhill Plaza, #01-19/21 Goldhill Plaza Singapore 308899 Singapore
comment: I have eaten here several time as it is near my house and it has a good value set meal with appetizer, main and dessert for $20.  I have noticed two Italians working there -- not sure if they are the owners.The Italian food is extremely fresh, authentic and delicious.  The lasagne is the best I have had in Singapore.  The mushroom soup is tasty and the desserts are delicious. Servings are generous - come hungry.  The service is attentive without being overbearing.The decor is nothing special, but the food more than makes up for it.

address: 1 Goldhill Plaza, #01-19/21 Goldhill Plaza Singapore 308899 Singapore
comment: A friend who lives in the area asked me if I had ever eaten at "Daluca", via email. I replied, "You mean the chain from New York spelt with an "e"? Never liked paying so much for sub-par sandwiches"Thankfully my buddy responded, " No. Come to Goldhill plaza on Saturday. It's Daluca".So there we were last night, at Da *space* Luca, a little Italian restaurant run by a rather quiet Italian lady. We had the 300g burrrata ball to start, and that came with some sweet slices of tomato and lightly cooked spinach. The cheese was especially fresh and bountiful, easily satisfying the four of us. For mains, I had the squid ink spaghetti special (with cod fish and shrimp in a tomato sauce), the dude had stracci with braised rabbit (I've never come across stracci before but it looks like a cousin of ziti) and our two friends- in-the-know had risotto with truffles. All the pasta was homemade and fresca, which while i don't like comparing restaurants, made Da Luca a contender with La Nonna. The risottos smelled and tasted really good. However, both our pastas seemed a little under seasoned  and hence, flat. This could be totally fine for someone else because I do like stronger flavored food at this point of my young life. I did like that all the seafood was fresh but somehow the flavors didn't sink in with a punch and I had to do the salt & pepper shake. We unfortunately felt the same about the house glasses of red (a chianti) and white wine, which is sad because I remember tasting some great wines in Tuscany on my travels there. We tried half the dessert menu (tiramisu done with sponge cake, apple tarts and ice cream) and it was fine.The great thing about Da Luca is that they serve Italian portions with the freshness you'd expect from a true blue Italian and I appreciate that. Prices are reasonable too. The food will make most happy but doesn't knock your buds out of the park. In other words, great choice for repeat visits, maybe not for that special occasion (and that's probably the more profitable way for the restaurant to go anyway!).

address: 1 Goldhill Plaza, #01-19/21 Goldhill Plaza Singapore 308899 Singapore
comment: my bf brings me here sometime cos i love the squid ink pasta here. it just tastes very fresh and tastes like real homemake food. i really recommend this place for those of you who likes squid ink. i havent tried anything else ; o the service okay, no bad

address: 1 Goldhill Plaza, #01-19/21 Goldhill Plaza Singapore 308899 Singapore
comment: Based on what I've seen on other diner's plates, the good people at Da Luca are very free with the quantity of food they provide. There's a wide array of succulent Italian dishes on the menu that include pastas, pizzas antipasti and desserts. Space is a tad limited but it adds to the overall feel of the ambience. Wait times are relatively decent, save for dessert, as the staff seemed a little confused to who's having what. And prices aren't sky high as well, which totally caught us by surprise as we had expected to spend a little more, considering the quantity and quality of the food. Overall, it's a decent place to check out and enjoy good, authentic Italian cuisine.

If you would like to discover and uncover different and premium dessert, this is the place to go. With such premium dessert, the price point is indeed very "premium" as well. I went out with my girls (group of 4) and we ordered 3 desserts and it cost me almost $40. I was shocked with the price but since I'm already there might as well give it a try. The place was rather dark in the evening, I think they might have soft lights installed (?) service was not fantastic. Would only go once in awhile or if I have someone special with me or am nearby.

I have to say Antoinette is my favorite place for cakes or tea sessions in Singapore. I always wanted to visit Antoinette at this location but it is kind of out of way from where I frequent when I am in Singapore. The day before I am flying out, I decided I must trek my way here. Like what another yelper has mentioned, this location is a bit of a walk from Lavender station (subway/mrt). Saw the Antoinette logo from afar. The tea salon is somewhat out of place among whatever is in the area. AMBIENCE 5/5 The décor speaks elegance, refined and beautiful.  This is what I love about Antoinette, the salon was what I envisioned if I ever owned a tea salon. I have no talent in baking or running a f&b business, so I just have to be a customer ;) The place was supposedly to be calm and quiet, except that this party of 8 at a table nearby was yapping oh so loudly. FOOD 5/5I ordered the La Rose cake which comprises of grand cru chocolate mousse, caramel, almond nougatine, cocoa sponge, grand marnier and dark chocolate chantilly. The description for the cake stated "exotic caramel". Not sure what so exotic about the caramel. However, one thing for sure, the cake tasted absolutely lovely. It was so aesthetically pleasing on the outside, tasted heavenly inside as well. Chocolate lovers would adore this cake. I am not a chocolate lover, I too love this pretty cake. The Antoinette's iced chocolate was not sweet enough. It was a blessing in disguise since a sweeter iced chocolate may be a bit much with the chocolatey La Rose cake. On other occasions, I may want a sweeter iced chocolate. SERVICE 4/5Staffs were friendly, cheery and polite. Not sure if they understaffed, kind of hard to holler down a staff to take order and to get a check. Also, this location does not serve my favorite French toast all day like the one located at Mandarin Gallery @Orchard.Still, I recommend anyone to visit this location and hopefully they would not run into the same party who was basically a nuisance to other patrons who just want to relax in a quiet and relaxing place.

Although it was 6pm, we were told that the place was full on reservations. In the end we were showed to a table in the centre provided that we would leave 10 minutes to 7pm. Although we had decided our orders, there was problems regarding our order of drinks, as well as serving of the food. We had ordered a certain dish which the opposite table also ordered, but they were served first. Suspected that the young server had forgotten about our order, as the dish only turned up when we reminded him. We feedback to the cashier about the issue who gave a reason that the other table had ordered the dish in advance which was highly unlikely as we distinct heard the other table asking if that particular dish was available during ordering. He was quite a blur one who did not serve the dish with cutlery or water and we had to remind him a number of times.Hakka Gnocchi ($24++)dried shrimp, foie gras, cured pork, morelThe serving was quite small. The gnocchi were quite colourful, chewy and went quite well with the minced savoury topping.XXXL Nasi Lemak Burger ($20++) XXXL Chicken, first marinated and then coated with Chef Pang's favourite batter that reminds him of the fried chicken he had at school canteen when he was young. The exterior is incredibly crispy, with a juicy and succulent chicken breast within. Promising a spicy kick, the homemade otah is made with fresh mackerel and prawn. The aromatic sambal, a requisite ingredient in any traditional nasi-lemak offering, is a blend of chilli, dried shrimps, shallots and only gula Melaka was used for a subtle sweetness and the aromatic finish. Upping the nostalgia factor is the luncheon meal.The dish finally arrived after a long wait, after finding the opposite table having it first before us. The rice was fragrant and moist. The sambal was delicious spicy sweet. But the fried chicken was disappointingly dry.Orient ($9++)white lotus seed mousse, coconut cake, salted peanut sesame praline and a flowy salted egg cremeuxThe salted egg cremeux reminded one of liu sha pau. The most interesting part was the crunchy salted peanut sesame praline right at the bottom.Iced Lychee Orange Tea ($7++)The young server told us it was unavailable but a check with the counter it was available. refreshing drink.Antoinette's Hot Chocolate ($7++)vanilla perfumed hot chocolateOrdered it as my first 2 choices of Peach Melba Tea ($9++) and Camouflage Matcha Cafe Latte ($7.50++) were not available. The drink was rich and more on the bitter side.
Cozy place, we enjoyed the food and the atmosphere here. Service was fast. Not many people here when we came. We got golden lava croissant and golden lava egg tart to go with our teas.

The Lavender location was a bit of a walk from the MRT but it was all worth it because the desserts were beautiful. I went there on Valentine 's Day it was surprisingly not too crowded and there had special desserts made for Valentine's. One was the bear - it was all sold out though and the other was the rose. I picked that one - it was really delicious. The other one that I liked was the monotone early grey - it was visually appealing and very tasty! I tried three other desserts - loved each one's intricate flavor! I will have to visit the one in Orchard next time!

Antoinette really live up to their reputation. Great service staff make you feel right at home with their perky interactions. Top it with good food and various flavours of drink concoctions, perfect place for a chillaxing brunch.

I came with high expectations, and was again, mostly disappointed. Salted egg yolk croissant!!!! The pictures, are to-die-for. The actual product is just alright. The croissant is excellent! But the highlight, salted egg yolk sauce, although runny, was only found in the center third of the croissant. The sauce itself, was also more sweet than salty and had a kind of dessert taste to it. My sister liked her french toast, for me, it is very weird that there is ham and cheese in the the french toast drizzled with syrup. Service is chaotic, to say the least, in Antoinette. The take away/cashier area is always flooded with customers.. And the poor service personnel is overwhelmed and can't get handle all the take away orders and bill payments. The crowd began almost around 11am, and luckily my sister and I arrived just 10 minutes before that. Seems like after 11am, most customers had made reservations. The order staff was flustered, and rather rude when handling my requests. You had to wave at many servers before you were acknowledged. I got the sesame macaroon to go and my sister got the grand cru macaroon. The macaroons melted really quickly. so be careful if you buy it as a gift, it might get melted before you get to give your gift! I might come back for a croissant or macaroon to go, but just that.. Maybe it would be a cute place to hang out in the afternoon, when the place is hopefully less crowded.

I felt compelled to write this review and to express our great disappointment on multiple fronts.  I would have given a "negative star" for their service if I can...There were plenty of empty tables available on this Sunday afternoon. We came to collect my mum's birthday cake  and we would like to eat it on premise instead of taking it home as it was a very hot day.  The server said that it is their policy that the cake is for pick up only and not for consumption at their premise - a very strange policy....  We said that we would like to have some coffee and the server claims that there is a minimum charge of $20 per person even though I did not see any signage stating that.   We left the premise quickly in disgust and we will never return to this place !The cake we ordered was a Chloe. It was pretty to look at but that's the only good thing about it.  Overall, there isn't much taste and it is way too sweet.  The yuzu flavor was so subtle that you wonder whether it was there at all.  The mousse was very heavy, one gets a sinking feeling after a few mouthful. The almond sablé  was hard to cut through and not much of almond taste either.  The cake is definitely over-priced at $80 for 20cm and $40 for 15 cm.  Last but not least, the location is not convenient and quite a bit of a walk from MRT - I would NOT recommend visiting this place for a meal or to order their cake.

If all the oozing of the Salted Yolk Lava Croissants haven't flowed to your taste buds yet, wait till you hear this: Savory croissants with LOCAL flavors have officially hit the island now, thanks to Chef Pang Kok Keong from Antoinette. Now how about some Chili Crab Croissant and Scallion Arlette. A play on Singapore's famous chili crabs with fried 饅頭 (Man Tou), Chef Pang has perfected a droolicious Chili Crab Croissant ($7.50). The sweetness of real crab meat in sweet and spicy flavors is a perfect match to the crisp buttery croissant layers. The level of spice is mild, yet sufficient to linger after the last bite. This tummy is crabby happy with this heartily-filled crescent.Who would have imagined a plain Jane to explode in flavors? The Scallion Arlette ($3.50), a French interpretation of the traditional 蔥油餅 (Chong You Bing), was surprising in flavors and textures. With fragrant spring onions and creamy butter in the croissant dough, Scallion Arlette is a savory crunchy addiction without a hint of oiliness (unlike the traditional sort). It takes a lot of will power to stop munching this $3.50 a pop goodness.Made fresh daily in limited quantities, the Chili Crab Croissant and Scallion Arlette are available now at the Penhas outlet at 11am every weekday and 10am every weekend, and at Mandarin Gallery and Sofitel outlets at 12pm.For all the sweet tooth out there, here's a thumbs up! Chef Pang has more sweet croissants in the mix now. Smoky Salted Caramel, intense Matcha Croissant for the everything-matcha zen-ness, savory Quatre Fromage for the cheese fans (like who doesn't love cheese?!), or the Kaya Croissant for the traditional nostalgia? Go get your 3 course croissant meal now.

Saw the chef featured on the news talking about their innovative desserts so had to give it a try since I'm in town. The environment is cozy and relaxed but the service was super slow and a little unorganized. We tried four cakes, three out of the four were very chocolate driven, more on the mousse/ ganache side. The Orient was the only one that had a different taste profile than the others. The first bite was gentle to the palate and had a good balance of flavor and textures however the excitement dissipated after each bite. The macarons however are excellent, the shells are well made and the flavors of the fillings are balanced. I liked how they had raspberry jam filling with the earl grey milk chocolate ganache. Overall- the macaroons are good - cakes are okay but definitely overpriced so be prepared to splurge a bit and don't have your hopes too high.

Really like the ambiance at this outlet and it's slightly off the beaten track location makes it a gem out of the city. With the array of vintage looking furniture, every visit here makes one feel like a tai tai enjoying a cuppa tea.The food is good and serving is generous. Service may be a little slack depending on where you sit. But the staff are very helpful to coordinate a little birthday surprise, when requested.Overall an enjoyable experience and nice environment. It can get crowded over the weekends so do try to get a reservation. However, please note that reservations are not allowed from 2-5pm.

The space at Penhas is lovely and classy. Jalan Besar is becoming such a hip area with surprising finds. We came to collect a birthday cake only. We ordered the Antoinette which is a milk chocolate earl grey mousse cake (500g for $40). The cake was pretty enough. Love the smell of earl grey which comes out nice and strong. Love the crispy biscuit base. The milk chocolate was a little on the sweet side. I would love the cake more if it is dark chocolate, but that's probably just the old taste buds in me not liking sweet things. After the initial enjoyable few mouths, it got too sweet to finish the slice.

J'aime toutes les choses gâteau. And I mean seriously, love all things cake and by that measure Antoinette, you honey are my Asian cake princess.The pastry execution here is top notch. Attention to detail at every piping turn. Excellent ingredients, quality butter and chocolate. You can not go wrong with a pot of tea and something from their case. Ever.But despite what Marie-Antoinette says, one can not live off cake alone. Do not despair. Brunch at Antoinette is one of my required go tos every time I fly through Singapore. The eggs bennie are a personal favorite. The ambiance is fabulous, in a trendy ladies who lunch kind of way. Plush chairs. Ambient lighting. You just feel a little French noshing away on your savory crepe in here.

My friend took me here for breakfast but in reality I was really going for the strawberry shortcake. I had ordered French pancakes which was "ok" but my friend ordered eggs benedict as did the table next to me and it looked absolutely well made and delicious I will be sure to order that next time.The ambience is quite ornate and definitely a place to take a date to or mom :)

I picked the Gnocchi for my main course. Gnocchi is an italian-style dumpling made of the usual ingredients in dough but with the addition of potato and cheese to give a softer, fluffier texture. The tomato-based sauce was the usual classic sort and there's a carbonara version of this dish. This is definitely for the carbo-junkie or just pick this one to share between friends.My friend had a Pancakes with bacon and Mushroom Ragout. The mushroom cream sauce is a personal favourite and I always have it with breakfast options. I loved the pancakes the first round I tried it because they had a slightly crusty exterior with amazingly fluffy inside but a second trip found me really disappointing ones. So I'm not too sure if quality is consistent.We also got the Salted Caramel Religieuse which was made up of two choux pastries and buttercream. It was decent pastry but rather unmemorable.Having a cake in its namesake, Antoinette, this must be the star of the dessert selection. If you're wondering what the bubble sitting on the top of the cake is - it's a raspberry coulis that you can burst to get raspberry sauce all over your cake. (Oddest sensation ever doing that.) That table ooh-ed over the lusciousness of the chocolate mousse base and the thick raspberry sauce.We also had the Nougatine which is one caramel lovers should have to polish up their meal. I can't remember what exactly went inside it but it was just a little pretty pot of caramel goodness.Oh, and as a personal recommendation, pack some of their Almond Croissants back home. The buttery goodness topped with endless amounts of crumbed almonds and custardy almond paste filling is entirely comforting to have at home.

I don't get why this place has mediocre reviews. This place is one of our favorite brunch places right next to our condo! We've tried many great brunch restaurants in New York and Los Angeles, but for some reason this place by far beats any we've been. Either Singaporeans dont' know food or they probably assume western cities would have better. We always order Salted Caramel French Toast and Classic Eggs Benedict- and it's perfect for two to share. The French toast is soaked in caramel and eggs to perfection, and has the softest, richest cream ever!  Eggs Benedict is done perfectly with the rich sauce, cured ham, and eggs that pop one you dive in to get your slice.The interior decor is girly French, or vintage French. Another reason to love this place and it would be perfect place for girlfriends to hang out, except that I see as many guys eating here together as I see girls. Service is sub par as it is with any restaurants in Singapore.

If you're a person who enjoys France, this is a place you'll simply love! The service is exactly what you'd expect from the French. Snobbish and slow. Getting their attention was next to impossible with only the restaurant a third to capacity. The decor was very quaint with a French feel though with a tad too much of a feminine touch to it.However service aside, if you can tolerate the service, the food was good. The pancakes I had  was delicious. It was soft and fluffy with very generous serving of cream. The presentation could also do a bit better though.  Nonetheless, I still had to stomach the sour attitude given by the staff. Be prepared!

My pancakes are so dry and I can compare them to the ones from Mac. It doesn't even come with maple syrup or whipped butter. When I asked the server for it, she said I get to choose between butter or syrup. Why??? Don't ask me. Service was really slow as we're seated in the back of the restaurant. Very disappointing cakes also. My Café Noix cake is dry, seriously $9.5 for a slice? The neighborhood Four Leaves have better cakes. I believed I paid $30 for its pretentious ambiance.
I had fettuccine bolognese, the staff's service and attitude was very good and the price was reasonable.

Came here on Friday afternoon. I like the ambience and the cakes but the service is absolutely very terrible. After I ordered a cake and I asked for a glass of warm water and it was only served 10min later after asking it for twice. If the 3 waitresses are busy and hence delay the service which is forgivable but all I saw was 3 waitresses look a bit lost and don't know what they are doing, walking up and down for nothing. I think the service could be improved.

I went to Antoinette's outlet in Softel hotel for salted egg yolk lava croissant that is highly recommended by the public recently. The boutique serves the croissant from 1 pm. Considering its limited offer each day, my friends and I arrived at 12:30 pm. At that time, only one group with 2-3 persons was ahead of us...But the result was my friends and I only got the last croissant left. Why? 1) No queue number was offered. We were asked to sit at the Xperience Cafe to wait. When the sale began, several groups rushed to the counter. 2) They only served 25-50 croissants everyday in Softel outlet, which obviously cannot meet the demand in CBD. Under this context, it might be more reasonable to cap the quantity each customer can buy. However right now, one customer usually buy 5 croissants at one time. 3) When I called Antoinette's main store, the staff said they still had some stocks on Penhas Road. Alas, why they allocated such a little quantity to its outlet? After tasting the croissant, we should thank the boutique for saving us money. One is enough! The taste is just so so though the idea (mixing Asian ingredients with Viennoiseries) is brilliant.

Came here for a late brunch once, it's quite a popular spot so you might want to make reservations first otherwise you might get turned down. It's quite convenient to get to from Lavender MRT, about 5 to 10 mins walk, just cross the road from when you exit the MRT beside the ICA Building and then walk straight and turn left at penhas road. If you're driving, you can park at the HDB carpark just 1 minute away.The interior of Antoinette is one my favourite things about the place- very cosy and dainty victorian details reminiscent of marie-antoinette herself!The food is pricey but I guess you pay for the ambience! I had the poached eggs with toast, seved all day and not just at breakfast time. The eggs were nicely round and cooked well but maybe needs abit of salt before you tuck in. Had the hot chocolate, it wasn't the best thing in town but I still enjoyed it. Final verdict: If you feel like having a nice tea break with a good selection of light bites and desserts, make it a date here!

address: 861 North Bridge Rd #97, North Bridge Road Market & Food Centre Singapore 198783 Singapore
comment: Very good and somewhat underrated local dish! I really love the gravy to the point that I always need extra bowl just for the gravy itself. They're very generous with the toppings too! There are three options for the carbs: kway teow, bee hoon and egg noodles (you can mix one with another but I haven't tried that yet, someone please try and let me know! Haha). There are various topping choices like chicken chop, fried cod fish, various ngoh hiang & pork, etc. I tried the cod fish with egg noodles (around $5 or $6) and it's such an excellent combination. The gravy though, is sooo flavorful, comforting and delicious! Totally adding this to my list of supper food and worth a visit for tourists too.There is always a line even during supper but it moves very fast, and 'choping' seat is pretty easy because a lot of other stalls in that hawker center close earlier than Zhen Hao lor mee.Note: pretty strong garlic after taste, try at your own risk and prepare some mints. :p

address: 861 North Bridge Rd #97, North Bridge Road Market & Food Centre Singapore 198783 Singapore
comment: The stall was located in North Bridge Road Market & Food Centre, walking distance from Lavender MRT station. Price ranging from $4 for the basic to $6 for the Treasure version.Treasure Lor Mee ($6)Bee hoon was the only choice of noodle as the rest were sold out. The serving was huge and packed with braised egg, five spice roll, braised pork belly and chucks of deep fried fish, topped with chill sauce and minced garlic.A lot of liao in it. Tasted not bad too.

address: 9 Raffles Boulevard #02-14, Millenia Walk Singapore 039596 Singapore
comment: Had lunch plan with my high school friend who works at Millenia Tower. She has asked me to pick a place I wanted to try. Her two boys upon hearing I was going to have lunch with their mom, both trekked their way from home to Millenia Walk. What can I say? Children likes me. Lol!!Initially I thought of picking Chabuton for lunch but seemed like the kids were keen on having Tonkatsu for lunch, so I told my friend let's get lunch at Saboten.FOOD : 5/5I ordered the Chicken Katsu Gozen Supreme which consisted of 1 Chicken Katsu, 1 fried prawn and 1 mini tenderloin Katsu. This set comes with rice, chawanmushi and miso soup. So my friend mentioned about this sesame in the bowl which I had to grind and then add the Tonkatsu sauce. Would someone grind it for me? ;-(The staff told us the sesame sauce and Yuzu sauce for the cabbage. Btw, rice, miso soup and cabbage are refillable. My Katsu Gozen turned out great, every piece of meat was so crispy and tender. The fried prawn reminded me of this Tonkatsu restaurant Wakou in Tokyo. So oishii おいしい!! :9    I wish the menu will offer a set with fried prawns only. AMBIENCE 5/5I like the ambience very much. It was nice and quiet. SERVICE 4/5The service was excellent, they refilled my iced green tea and those cabbage (I did not eat any) promptly. I was about to award them 5 stars until I just remembered ... where's our dessert? Each of the set we ordered supposed to come with dessert :(  Nevertheless, service was wonderful overall. Just don't forget our dessert the next time :DDefinitely an excellent Tonkatsu restaurant one can visit. Great food and reasonable pricing!

address: 9 Raffles Boulevard #02-14, Millenia Walk Singapore 039596 Singapore
comment: Saboten is a Japanese franchise restaurant started in Ginza, Tokyo established in 1966, now offering 70 locations throughout Japan. It has been one of the most successful family restaurants over 1/2 century and it offers quality, value and attention to detail. My favorite is Hire Katsu (pork tenderloin). Though It's not the best in Japan, yet it is very consistent in quality which you expect in franchise restaurants and it offers solid value as I mentioned previously. If you are in the Tokyo area and seeking a decent meal at an affordable price, you won't be disappointed with Saboten.

address: 9 Raffles Boulevard #02-14, Millenia Walk Singapore 039596 Singapore
comment: I've always been a huge fan of Saboten, ever since my first experience at the Changi T1 Location. I believe the best dishes are: (i) Pork Loin - a Saboten classic, (ii) Katsu Don and (iii) Katsu Curry. The lunch and dinner sets are great value, which comes with free flow of high quality imported Japanese rice, miso soup and cabbage as well as a sorbet to end the meal.  Lunch sets are around $20-25. A little expensive, I know, but particularly worth it if you are hungry. The Loin Katsu more often than not is crispy on the outside and fatty and juicy on the inside. Definitely my favourite Katsu chain in Singapore. I believe the T1 location is slightly better than the Millenia Walk location in terms of quality. Overall, if you are hungry and are willing to spend $20 on a worthwhile lunch, then look no further than Saboten.

i called them directly to order pizza, i was told that it would take atleast 60-90 minutes to deliver the pizza, based on my past experience, i am ordering this pizza after 7 years.  i think this company should focus on maintaining the quality instead of expanding the operations.Pizza was delivered cold on, the pizza was not in a hot pack, the person delivered pizza was not even courteous, he quickly made the delivery took the money and left.  i am having this pizza after 7 years and expected the quality to be same.  it was rainy and i think the box was even wet to an extent.  i am will order this for one more time and if nothing has improved, that is will be the last.  it was tasty, but it should have been hot, when delivered.  hope this message reaches the concerned.

This is a review of delivery from Sarpino's Pizzeria on Race Course Road.It was a rainy and miserable day outside.  So, I decided to give into my laziness and seek out food delivery options.  Googling away, I discovered Foodpanda and it's listing of Sarpino's.  After exploring other alternatives, I then placed Sarpino's order though foodpanda.sgIt was relatively easy to set up my account and place the order.  I was required to pay cash.  I do not know if this rule is a restriction of the web-site or the restaurant.There was no delivery fee.  The order minimum was $20.This is not a fast service.  This is not even a relatively slow service.  This is super slow bus from KL slow service.  The delivery estimate was 80 minutes.  It took closer to 90 minutes.  I have no idea why it would take that long to cook and deliver a pizza.Sarpino's did have a buy one get one free deal on the pizza.  But considering the price of a individual pizza ($25), I am not sure how much of a deal this really is.  That is for their small (10 in).  They call it "regular".  Large is large.  Medium is medium.  But Small is Regular.  Maybe they think by calling it Regular, I will magically think it is larger than a 10 inch pizza.The delivery person was professional and polite.  He phoned a few minutes before arriving to let me know he would be delivering soon.The food ranged from blah to relatively good.Thin Crust Double Pepperoni:  This was not a great pizza at all.  It was limp, flimsy and greasy.  It was also cold.tinyurl.com/cxn3cqhPan Crust Double Pepperoni:  First, this was not a pan pizza.  It was more like a medium crust pizza.  But it was pretty good.  It was much better than the thin crust pizza.  The crust had a nice bready flavour and it wasn't nearly as greasy or maybe there was just more crust to soak up the grease.  Both pizzas had an ample amount of pepperoni.  The pepperoni itself was very average.  It didn't really have a pop to the flavour.  They did include some nice packets of Parmesan and red pepper.  This was higher quality and fresher than what you get from many pizza delivery joints.Sarpino's need to improve their packaging.  Upon delivery, neither of the pizzas were hot.  They were basically room temperature to downright cold..tinyurl.com/ctu2tdaCaesar Salad - This was pretty much some iceberg lettuce with a bunch of rock hard flavourless croutons with some Parmesan and dressing thrown in.tinyurl.com/cgs55tuGarlic Bread Sticks  & Cheesy Bread Sticks - These side orders were both pretty good.  The cheesy bread sticks were the winner.  Lots of cheese can go a long way and they had lots of cheese.tinyurl.com/catc6wotinyurl.com/bqfsmtqI ordered Sprite.  They brought cola.The Order:1 X Caesar SaladS$ 4.801 X SpriteS$ 3.001 X Cheesy Bread SticksS$ 6.801 X Double Pepperoni + PanS$ 25.00Double Pepperoni Choices: Double Pepperoni + Thin1 X Garlic Bread SticksS$ 3.90TOTALS$ 43.50Overall, if spending quite a bit of money to wait an hour and a half for cold & mostly mediocre food is your thing, then Sarpino's is the place for you.  If not, then you might want to go elsewhere for dinner delivery.

This is more a drinking place with food, rather than a proper dining restaurant: lots of drink options, casual (and very friendly) service and décor, where passers-by strolling on the pavement can see what you consume, etc. But don't underestimate the food - it's much more than bar food. Lots of yummy, innovative dishes. So delish that if you're not careful, you can easily put on more than 1,500 calories by the end of the meal.

address: 1 Stadium Place #02-04, The Sports Hub Retail Mall Singapore 397628 Singapore
comment: One of the better outlets to patronise. Staff was able to offer suggestions with a toddler in tow. They got order wrong and got it fixed rightaway without questions asked. Would love to patronise again. Value for money for decent meal!

This is a restaurant downstairs and bar/snacks upstairs establishment on the Nanyang Technological University campus.  It serves breakfast, lunch and dinner.  It is located directly across from the Nanyang Executive Center which has housing for University visitors.  The staff is friendly and attentive and recognize you after your first visit.  Breakfast buffet is excellent with omelets, fresh baked breads, fruits, and local delicacies.  They have sandwiches and light fare for lunch and an extensive dinner menu.  Quite an enjoyable venue and convenient for visitors.  Highly recommended!

Menu is so varied I was confused at first.  I had sashimi, agedashi tofu and spicy chicken wrap. The beetroot juice was amazing.  Avoid the rush lunch hour as it was unbearable. You order at your table on ipads.  Service was good.  A bit hard to find but well worth the stop.  Industrial area.

When I'm in the Wild West (of Singapore), it usually means my partner in crime is involved in the meal - because the only reason I'd be this far at a corner is because he lives in the area. I miss the Grandma's that are more centrally located - mostly the Suntec and Novena outlets that I frequent. I found Grandma's a few years ago because of cheap beer! Well, as cheap as it gets in Singapore when Happy Hour is not available - like, early in the afternoons or later at night. At Grandma's, it's always Happy Hour prices for Tiger, Kirin and Erdinger and at less than $5 / $9 per pop, it's definitely a good deal for me. Grandma's has a menu of generally Peranakan-inspired dishes, mixed with Chinese and Malay dishes such as char kway teow and Nasi Lemak - all of which are decent as my take is that the dishes are mostly slightly too salty in general. My all-time favorite dish here is the Sago Gula Melaka (but then again, I like SGM from anywhere) - paired with an ice cold Kirin. We walked past Grandma's in the afternoon and saw that they had some promotion for a main + drink + dessert that was reasonably priced ($6.90 - $12.90) and I got lucky because I was craving pasta, and there was one dish on the menu that fit that bill. I have to say that the pasta actually was decent! I am highly picky about my pasta, especially since I got back from Italy a few years ago - only one place in Singapore actually satisfies my craving for real, but that's another review for another day. I definitely give Grandma's pasta props when it comes to taste. I wouldn't fault the pasta itself because they probably cooked it instant noodle style, but ohwow - the sauce was definitely yummy. The dish came with a leg of chicken, and that was awesomely yummy too. Grandma's chicken has always caught my sense of smell, but I'm never hungry enough to order a rice set that has one, and have never wanted to pay for a piece of that chicken a la carte because the cost logically doesn't justify the smell (~$7/piece if I'm not mistaken). It was definitely well marinated because the juicy chicken leg not only smelt good, it tasted the part too! My little tip here would be to request for their sambal belachan instead of having the sambal chilli that's served on every table - you definitely won't regret it. My small gripe is that the belachan is a little too salty for my liking but I'll take that over the chilli whenever I'm given the choice.Overall, I think Grandma's is good if you're just there for beer and dessert, or lunch but it's generally overpriced for the portions that you get ordering a la carte. The only exception might be their Nasi Lemak dishes, those look really huge in terms of serving size but, I've only ever seen them from far (ie. on other patron's tables).

Amazing value, great flavours, selection, and customer service. Shared hor fun noodles, vegetables, bean curd, and chill crab with a friend, came out to a total of 57$. I was happy to see how the lady who was serving us was concerned whether we liked the food or not, and despite the language barrier, her smiles and kindness was well communicated.

address: 1 Jurong West Central 1 #B1-55 Jurong Point Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: Shokutsu 10-Osaka is really a Japanese food street in the basement of Jurong Point. It's an innovative idea and one that has proven popular among shoppers. Along this food street inspired by Osaka, there are restaurants such as Ichiban Sushi, Kuishin Bo, Kuriya Japanese Fresh Fish Market, Men-ichi, Wadori and Yaki Yaki Bo Teppanyaki. Each restaurant has a different focus, from sushi to fresh seafood, to teppanyaki to meat skewers, Ichiban Sushi is decent and is part of the chain that owns Ichiban Boshi. The food is reasonably priced and you can get sushi on a conveyor belt and bento sets as well as ramen and udon. Pretty much any restaurant you choose along this Japanese stretch will serve relatively authentic food, of course by no means of the same standard as what you get in Japan.

address: 1 Jurong West Central 1 #B1-55 Jurong Point Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: Yaki Yaki Bo is as Japanese as it could get. That's what a Japanese friend said when we went here. The okinamiyaki was really good. Hint: after around 5 or 6 PM, the fish market deeply discounted the sushi and bread prices.

A gorgeous setting,  attentive, welcoming staff and a real family feel await at garden Asia's bistros. The salads are hearty, the protein add ons well cooked and it's all reasonably priced. A real family favorite in our house where it's seen as a reliable friend.

Stumbled across this place a couple of weeks ago while out on a motorcycle in the futile  search for the lesser spotted Singapore Twisty Road. Have now been back a couple of times and it has become a new favorite. Set in one of the many  plant nurseries in Kranji, Bistro @Gardenasia is a relaxing place to spend some time kicking back with good drinks and great food. If you don't like dogs be warned, it is very dog friendly as the owner has gone out of his way to rescue many local breed and dogs just abandoned in the area. They get to spend the rest of their lives being happy interacting with the guests in certain areas around the restaurant. Anyway, the drinks menu is not extensive, but has great coffee, both hot and iced. There is also a decent selection of beers and ciders, especially the Cheeky Rascal in different flavors. Just be careful if you drink these, alcohol content is nearly twice what you get from beer. The food is good and very well priced, the Ribeye Hor Fun and the Mee Goreng Pasta had great flavor with the pasta getting the edge on spiciness. If you want some deliciously unhealthy fried appetizers, they have several to select from with a 3 for $20 deal. Good wings, and good fried whitebait. Staff friendly, service quick, good ambience and great tasting and value food. Worth taking the trip off the beaten path for.

This place is located in a very serene location (that might admittedly be a little difficult to get to). I was very impressed at being able to find a restaurant with such a setting, but it's thanks to my friend that I was able to know about this place. But let's talk about the food. I ordered the ribeye, which was done medium-rare and I felt that the meat was above average. It was quite tender and there was a satisfying bite to it. My friend had the spaghetti which he said was quite okay as well, but perhaps a little salty. On another occasion, I had The Works Platter, which came with sausages, chicken wings and cheese sticks. This one was pretty good as well, but nothing too spectacular.Overall, I must say that the ambience of this place alone is worth the visit. The food is good and the service is attentive, so you really can't fault this place.
