Not that impressed. Some of the reviews mention about dining lakeside, by lakeside it is actually just a small concrete pond. Had a salad, it was ok but nothing special for 15 bucks.Staff should be reminded to smile once in a while!They had that Celine Dion song - Power of Love - on repeat. Great song (for some people) but by the fifth cycle I was ready to try to drown myself in that concrete pond. Could be the reason the staff are so miserable... I barely endured a lunch, they are there for a full shift...
Simple and enjoyable spot away from the hustle and bustle.  Good kids menu.Good service.

This stall is literally a hidden gem. It's hard to find (ok for someone who lives in Clementi and drives as far as Orchard) and those in the know have kept the local secret pretty well. Hotplate BBQ basically hits the a couple of important Singaporean hawker food points: its affordable, the seafood is fresh and of a good size and there's a long "queue". I'm reasonably certain the stall is so leychey to get to and the wait time on weekends long enough that putting up this review will not bring too many people to the yard.My dear aunt was introduced to the aunty owner of Hotplate BBQ, which meant we could call ahead and reserve the items we wanted and the aunty remembers how we like our seafood cooked. The barbequed fish, prawns and flower crabs are excellent here, as is the special uhh cincalok type sauce that is made on request. The sambal chilli isn't bad either.The sambal sotong, stingray and lady's fingers are decent as well but didn't knock my socks off like the 8 prawns I ate. Yes I ate alot and you'll generally find yourself doing the same. When my aunt brought my cousin along for a 5 person meal they ordered 8 grilled fishes. Other than seafood, the stall sells 2 types of vegetables (lady's fingers are one of them) and a very simple fried rice that does the job. Word is the coffee shop owner restricted the types of non-seafood dishes they could sell so that it wouldn't compete directly with the other stalls. Almost everyone comes here for the BBQ seafood but as a spillover effect from waiting up to an hour on Fridays/Saturdays/PH's, people order from the tze char and satay/ grilled wings stalls.How much did our meal cost? We had 9 dishes (2 fishes, 1 plate of sotong, 1 plate of prawns, 1 large and 1 small plate of fried rice, 1 plate of lady's fingers, 2 stingrays) for $90. Yes thank me and don't tell your friends ok? The wait time is long enough as it is.

address: 10 Tuas West Drive, Raffles Marina Singapore 638404 Singapore
comment: This place is located in Raffles Marina Country club in Tuas, quite close to the 2nd link checkpoint. The place serves a large variety of food, ranging from Indian to Western food. What I like most about this place is the sea view and the breeze.On to the food itself. I ordered the laksa, which contained some thick bee hoon, prawns, bean sprouts, quail egg and so on. I round that the laksa gravy was really delicious because it was fragrant and contained a lot of dried shrimps in it. Being a soup/gravy fan, I actually finished most of the gravy here. We also ordered satay here, and all of us found that the satay was really tender and juicy.Overall, we found that the food here is good with a killer view, but do note that the place is rather inaccessible to those who do not have a car.

address: 10 Tuas West Drive, Raffles Marina Singapore 638404 Singapore
comment: The curry had no salt, food is average; we were placed in a bad spot, before this used to be a very welcoming place. Nowadays they get way too many customers they don't care for service.

address: 10 Tuas West Drive, Raffles Marina Singapore 638404 Singapore
comment: Great views of harbor. You order at the counter. The marina breeze mocktail was heavenly.  My nasi was too spice for me but I would definitely come back here. The chicken rice looked great.

address: 10 Tuas West Drive, Raffles Marina Singapore 638404 Singapore
comment: I had lunch here today with some collegues.  I had the chicken tikka, garlic naan, and a coconut cooler.  It was very good, and some of the best food I had in Singapore.  My collegues (locals) had some sort of lamb dish and said it was good.  Nice view, and the ocean breeze made eating outside at noon bearable.  The service was not the best, though they were extremely busy.  It's out of the way and not in walking distance of anything, so it is probably only someplace you'd visit if you're in the area and have a car.

We were there to celebrate a Bday (& to support a local biz!) Party of 4, bill $300+.Starters to share :-*Portobello Salad - * Escargot * Pan-seared Foie Gras w Apple slice * Mushroom Soup x x2 (Everything flavorful. Appetizers portion was small , I guessed meant for 1 but we ordered 3 types to 'sample' amongst 4 of us . Still I think the salad vegetables portion was small.)Wine -Shiraz (Argentina), excellent w the Duck & Beef mains. Smooth & not so dry.Mains:-*Duck Confit x2   *Beef Cheek *Day's Special Cut - Black Angus Steak ( All Mains we're all excellent , super delicious & portions just nice , except we were prefer there beans trimmed at the ends)Desserts:-Crème BrûléeApple Tart ( We we're quite full by now only ordered 1 dessert per couple. Our Crème Brûlée w A handful of blueberries & raspberries was excellent! While the Apple tart w a scoop of vanilla Icecream were both too sweet! A better quality Icecream would solve the problem ,lighter on the sugar in the tart pls. It was very nice that the (only 1) server  cum customer service person remembered it was my friend's Bday & plated the Apple Tart w a written chocolate cream writing & a candle in the Apple Tart . It would hv confirmed the overall pleasant experience if that was given complimentary or small dark chocolates complimentary ( since it was a Bday) ,after all our bill was above $300! A price ok for the food, but high for the ambience & decor & basic service received. Food overall was good  & worth returning for but service, decor & overall ambience & experience, there are quick ways to improve by few notches , if the biz owner is motivated to.

Lisa's and Johnny's bistro has been our go-to place when we've wanted to treat friends and visitors to great western (French) food without breaking our bank. My favorite is beef cheeks. Wife's is duck confit. We've tried everything on the carefully planned menu and all is very good. Ambiance is relaxed, you'll feel at-home when you visit.
I came for 2 of my French favourites. Duck confit and French onion soup. All well done. Happy days.

We tried the beef frites n duck confit. The beef was good but the duck confit was better. The meat simply tears from the bone while the skin was crisp. Eaten together with the plum sauce, it gives an really interesting flavor. Service was good and the place was cozy. Will come again. Remember to make reservations before u go as it gets full pretty soon

This is most definitely the best french home cooking restaurant in Singapore. It's a new restaurant, run by a husband-wife team. The service is quick and very very friendly! We had a small group so we basically tried almost everything on their menu. For appetizers, we got the escargot, mushroom soup and french onion soup. I absolutely loved their mushroom soup. It was creamy but not overwhelming, and loads of mushroom flavor. For the entrees, we had the orange duck, beef cheek, pork confit, and a fish. Every single dish was perfectly executed and the meat were all very well done - great on flavor and not overdosing on salt. Our group's favorite was the pork confit... omg the pork simply melt in the mouth, and the sour plum sauce added a great kick to the dish. They served generous portions with a refined flavor at an affordable price. A definite must go for any french home cooking fans out there.

address: Balak 252 Jurong East  Street 24 #01-107 Singapore 600256 Singapore
comment: Looks like this place has carved out quite a name for itself. Didn't realise I haven't visited for like a year (always wanted to bring friends but didn't because it's honestly not very accessible unless Grab/Uber has promo codes). Food:Ate the Ribeye steak ($26), but now the sides come as default fries (add $2 for Truffle fries) and salad. Ordered Medium Rare. At first glance, the color seemed more Medium or Medium-Well. However it's still surprisingly tender, as per medium rare, and flavourful. In fact, I forgot to dip my meat with the sauce (provided in a sauce dish). Fries were also decently fried, not too oily or salty, but still crisp. Salad is relatively fresh. Overall serving is pretty decent, you can see the picture I've uploaded.My friend and I both ate the steak, so I can't comment on the other food. However, menu has also been updated compared to 2 years ago, so check out the pictures :DVariety/Price:Price has evidently increased for the mains (based on previous reviews). Ice lemon tea is still the same price. However the quality still remains, although I wish I could have more variety in the sides. Oh and did I mention they have a 3 pints for $33 deal, and you get to choose beers like Asahi Black and Kronenbourg rather than typical Heineken/Tiger. It seems like they have a tie-up with Brewerkz too.Overall:Atmosphere still good. The area is well ventilated, and you can be there after office without breaking much of a sweat. Now the only concern is how to get there early to beat the crowd... P.S. I want the carving board again. It's sad they replaced the board with a place ):

address: Balak 252 Jurong East  Street 24 #01-107 Singapore 600256 Singapore
comment: Wasn't plan on eating The Carving Board, was driving pass the coffeeshop.. And saw a long queue there at 9pm... That really trigger my curiosity so I make a UTurn back at the car park and decided to join the queue.. When I there I then realised that it is the only open shop in that coffeeshop, all are closed, even the usual drink stall also closed.. I want to order Lambchop, that's my favorite. When is it  turn most of the thing I already sold out. But it is still worth it...  Would be coming back these few days to try the lampchop!Great taste Great Value for Money!

address: Balak 252 Jurong East  Street 24 #01-107 Singapore 600256 Singapore
comment: amazing food amazing value.  Get awesome pasta and pints of beer for $11 each.  Great seafood and steaks also.  Good service.  I come here a bit too much but I often have paid double or triple for less than half the taste at other places. The chef used to be from St Regis so that explains the quality of ingredients and taste .  Even when there is a big que somehow they still manage to make your meal fast. I had 2nd thoughts about writing this ad too many people might come here but these guys deserve to be a success.

address: Balak 252 Jurong East  Street 24 #01-107 Singapore 600256 Singapore
comment: Delicious and affordable western food in the neighborhood. Ingredients are freshly prepared. Quite generous serving. Just be prepared to queue for an hour during weekends and rush hour.

address: Balak 252 Jurong East  Street 24 #01-107 Singapore 600256 Singapore
comment: Ordered a medium well steak but got a well done steak. The steak was really dry and hard. I proceeded to inform the lady who I assume is the lady boss regarding the steak and she replied that it's my fault for not eating the steak straight away(it was only on my table for like 5mins) and refused to change the steak for me. Her attitude and tone was extremely derogatory and it was as if she's lecturing me. If your chefs didn't cook it right in the first place, you should humbly accept the feedback and accept the request to change the steak and not talk in that kind of attitude towards your customer! I was extremely appalled by her attitude but didn't want to create a scene so I didn't push the matter further. It is basic service to change the steak for a customer if the steak isn't cooked correctly in terms of its well-doneness as requested. This is no way to treat your customer and if your customer service is shitty, you will inevitably drive away customers. We will never revisit this place again!

It's a good place to go if you're just looking for Chinese food at cheap prices. I've eaten at this place for a few times, I have always left the place wanting to try more of their food. Best bits: Bee hoon, kong ba pao( there's only lean meat though but the pork they use is really fresh and juicy), prawns cooked in beer- this I forgot its name on the menu.Yes the place is a little squeezy and difficult to maneuver, but who walks around while having dinner in a restaurant?... At least they have tables big enough for everyone to enjoy their dishes without being squished and truthfully contented with that. (:

This is another one of the many Chinese restaurants that can be found in the west.We found Pu Tien in jurong point to be rather tightly packed, and there was simply a lack of space to maneuver. Being in such a tight space also made for a boisterous and noisy atmosphere, which was something that I didn't fancy.But on to the food, which was pretty good in my opinion. We ordered a variety of food such as stewed sweet potato noodle, which we found to be pleasantly springy and came with a wonderfully flavorful stock with lots of ingredients. Another dish that we ordered was the drunken cockles. The garlic and chili toppings went well with the small and bloody cockles, and I found this dish to be rather satisfying as well. I think the restaurant might be worth a visit if you want a change from the usual crystal jade etc.

Fried mantou with the beef. The mantou is what makes it special, and you find yourself filling it up with the rather lackluster beef just so you can delight in the fried, sweet, sesame topped mantou. My friend is in love with the lor mee, though I thought the gravy base was a bit bland. Really great fresh chili sauce though! I could eat that sauce with anything. :) We had to queue up for twenty minutes or so on a weeknight, so I imagine it would be quite busy during the weekend. Affordable and decent Chinese food in the westside.

address: 30 Lower Kent Ridge Rd Singapore 119075 Singapore
comment: The SUN Asian Bistro was where I decided my 21st birthday with friends some years ago.  I picked this restaurant because I liked the "cheena" feel and also because it gave me the most value for my budget back then. I wanted to have some privacy, so I reserved a room and ordered a seven course dinner for ten people for around $250. The restaurant serves Asian and Western cuisine. I opted for a Chinese-style dinner, as the menu included all my favourite dishes, like crispy cereal prawns, lemon chicken, tom yum and braised kalian with oyster sauce. The food was excellent and my friends and I enjoyed the ambience thoroughly. We were also impressed with the service provided. The service staff were so efficient clearing our plates and serving us throughout the course of the dinner, one friend said they were almost like ninjas. Furthermore, the manager was very accommodating when I needed to change plans. This restaurant provides good food, good service at good, reasonable prices. I'd definitely come back here for future celebrations!

address: 3 Woodlands Street 13 Woodlands Swimming Pool Complex Singapore 738600 Singapore
comment: Despite the location and setting (it's literally by a swimming pool and right across a stadium), the quality of the food (against their prices) and the cozy ambience make it worth a short trip to get a seat. The salmon fillet was right on point, though admittedly the waiting times get really long when the tables are full. Their menu is truly extensive.

address: 3 Woodlands Street 13 Woodlands Swimming Pool Complex Singapore 738600 Singapore
comment: This turned out to be a fairly odd location based on where we thought we were going. Basically it sits like a water park restaurant just outside a gym and water slide. However, the food was pretty remarkable. We sat and looked through the menu before approaching the counter to order. All was well enough, however it too more than 40 minutes to get our food! I'd have been more upset (in addition to starving!) except that it's easy to see why. It's all freshly prepared and by a staff that is small but dedicated. It really was good food! Take away: Don't go hungry. Get the chicken and waffles. Grab drivers will get lost coming and going. Eatigo coupon makes it worth it.

address: 3 Woodlands Street 13 Woodlands Swimming Pool Complex Singapore 738600 Singapore
comment: Located just to the entrance of the swimming pool, one was surprised to find a Halal certified restaurant packed with customers on a typical Thursday night. Looking at the menu, one could not help but spotting the localised burgers and over the top milkshakes. Not wonder there was so many families dining in here.Shiok Burger (S$12.90)Crispy deep fried chicken thigh, sliced tomato, crisp lettuce and sunny side up egg, topped with spicy chilli crab sauce on toasted sesame seed bun. Served with cajun fries.Although the sauce was not usual spicy, sweet, eggy sauce which usually associated with the chilli crab, but the sauce here held itself with its spicy and eggy taste.Big Boss (S$17.90)Chef's specialty burger - tender & juicy beef + mutton patty, accompanied with crispy fried onions, sliced tomato, cucumber, crisp lettuce & purple cabbage slaw, smothered in the all-time favourite satay sauce on toasted charcoal bun. Served with cajun fries. The patty which was made up of a mixture of minced beef and mutton was surprisingly free of the usual gamey taste that was usually associated with mutton.  The Big Catch (S$12.90)Buttermilk-battered dory, crispy fried onions, sliced tomato & crisp lettuce, topped with tartare sauce on toasted sesame seed bun. Served with cajun fries.It looked great with 2 huge pieces of battered fish in it. Best had it as soon as it was served as the cold air con softened the batter easily.Dainty Trio (S$10.90)Deep fried chicken, accompanied with crispy fried onions, sliced tomato & lettuce on mini toasted sesame bun.Interesting version of sliders with the battered onions creating the wow.Grilled Free-Range Chicken (S$14.90)Signature chicken thigh cooked sous-vide to retain its tenderness and flavours, then pan-fried till the skin is crisp on the outside. Served with seasonal vegetables and homemade brown sauce.One of our favourite dishes of the meal. The meat was tender and went quite well with the sauce which we wiped it clean. Like the range of vegetables that was served with it. There's even purple sweet potato.Berry Magic (S$11.90)Strawberry ice cream and jam with fresh strawberries , topped with biscuit roll.It was like an overwhelming dose of strawberry milk.Coco Loco (S$9.90)Creamy coconut ice cream, nata de coco and matcha cookie crumbles , topped with desiccated coconut and drizzled with gula melaka syrup.It may not looked much, but it was a party in the mouth with the chewy nata de coco, crunchy  crumbles, and the rich but not too sweet gula melaka.Molten Chocolate Lava Cake (S$10.90)Served with a scoop of ice cream The cake was served pipping hot, with the hot molten chocolate flowing out like lava easily when cut opened. It was so yummy that we wiped it clean.Strawberry Gem (S$8.90)Strawberry ice cream blended with strawberry milk topped with whipped cream, biscuit roll & ais gem biscuits.Although it was the most colourful of the all 4 milkshakes, this drink was the sweetest among the milkshakes which we tried, giving one a sugar high.Snickerhead (S$10.90)Caramel and peanut chocolate bar, blended with chocolate milk & chocolate ice cream.One would thought that this would be the sweetest among the 4 but it turned not. It was a more like nutty with slightly salty caramel taste.Cookie Crush (S$9.90)Cookies 'n' Cream ice cream blended with low-fat milk and Oreo cookies, topped with whipped cream, Oreo cookie and biscuit roll.Another rich and milky milkshake which was not too sweet.Caramel Popcorn (S$9.90)Vanilla ice cream blended with low fat milk & rich caramel sauce, topped with whipped cream, honey popcorn & caramel drizzle.It looked great with the hill of crunchy pop corn on top. The drink was not sweet while being rich and milky.

address: 3 Woodlands Street 13 Woodlands Swimming Pool Complex Singapore 738600 Singapore
comment: Halal-certified café restaurant Citrus By The Pool introduces more than 20 new dishes, drinks and desserts to its menu. Expect more side dishes, burgers, milkshakes and desserts. Started in 2013, Citrus By The Pool is a Halal-certified café restaurant, nestled at Woodlands Swimming Complex, that serves Western and Asian Fusion cuisine. It is a 10-minute walk or short drive from Woodlands or Marsiling MRT Stations. Seeing a lack of chillout places in North, the owner decided to bring the café experience to theresidential estates, offering accessibility, relaxing ambience and good food.Step into the retro-themed space decked with large windows and cosy lights hanging from exposed wooden beams. The restaurant seats up to 70 people indoors, suitable for large group/ family gatherings.Check out their new Mighty Milkshakes ($8.90 - $10.90), available in 6 flavours - Classic Vanilla, Double Chocolate, Strawberry Gem, Caramel Popcorn, Cookie Crush and Snickerhead. Depending on your appetite, you can choose to take on the massive drink on your own, or share it with a favourite buddy.I was pretty full from drinking the milkshake by itself, it's gotta be at least 2-3 scoops of ice cream alone! If you're a caramel popcorn lover such as myself, go for it and do not be afraid of it's looks. It's not as sweet as it looks. Actually, the sweetest amongst these 4 milkshakes was surprisingly, Strawberry Gem. Which would still serve as Big Hit for the kids, with the generous toppings of Gem icing biscuits.Bite into the Little Boss (single patty) $14.90/ BIG Boss (double patty) $17.90 (served with Cajun fries), the chef's specialty burger that defies conventional burgers by combining the best flavours of beef and mutton (BM) in one patty. The burger is about being bold and fearless in its flavours. Accompanied with crispy fried onions, sliced tomato, cucumber and crisp lettuce and purple cabbage slaw, smothered in the all-time favourite satay sauce on toasted charcoal bun, expect an explosion of flavours at the first bite.The idea of mixing beef and mutton together to form a juicy burger patty is a brilliant idea. It held the right amount of moisture in the patty.Look out for Shiok Burger $12.90 (served with Cajun fries), a crispy fried chicken version of Da Burger Bomb with a spicy kick. Savour the crispy deep fried chicken thigh, sliced tomato, crisp lettuce and sunny side egg, topped with spicy chilli crab sauce on toasted sesame seed bun. This is a burger that"ll make you go Shiok!Other new burgers include The Big Catch $12.90 (served with Cajun fries), a buttermilk-battered dory fillet, crispy fried onions, sliced tomato and crisp lettuce, topped with tartar sauce on toasted sesame seed bun.Dainty Trio $10.90 (Fried chicken patty) | $12.90 (BM patty), 3 sliders of your preferred patty, accompanied with crispy fried onions, sliced tomato, lettuce on toasted mini sesame seed buns. Customers can choose between BBQ or Teriyaki Sauce.Citrus By The Pool's signature chicken thigh cooked sous-vide to retain its tenderness and flavours, then pan-fried till the skin is crisp on the outside. Served with seasonal vegetables and homemade brown sauce. I recall the tenderness of Curry Chicken I had at Citrus Bistro at Sengkang and I was not disappointed here, the chicken meat was extremely tender. You could easily remove the meat from the bones with just a fork. Definitely a must-try at Citrus By The Pool.To end off your feast, try one of their Sundaes. Berry Magic is a sundae filled with strawberry ice cream and jam with fresh strawberries and topped with a biscuit roll. There were biscuit crumbs at the bottom of the jar, to add a crunchy bite to the dessert. The creamy coconut ice cream was a refreshing taste to clear my palate. I'm a huge fan of nata de coco jellies and this was filled with tons of it! Matcha cookie crumbs together with desiccated coconut and gula melaka syrup made this one sweet dessert.Overall : Citrus By The Pool is now a location that all foodies who enjoy good burgers should check out this hidden gem. I really enjoyed the nice, relaxing dining location. The burgers are relatively huge for a female appetite.

address: 3 Woodlands Street 13 Woodlands Swimming Pool Complex Singapore 738600 Singapore
comment: Its my first time there , the environment was surprisingly very comfy , its definitely a good place to relax and chat with friends. The service there was good and the staff are very friendly. The food is totally worth the 5 stars , i would definitely their lava cake and the catch of the day. The price are reasonable for the taste of it . Would definitely visit again !

address: 3 Woodlands Street 13 Woodlands Swimming Pool Complex Singapore 738600 Singapore
comment: Citrus by the pool is located at woodlands swimming complex thus parking is convenience, it is a great place also for gym-goers as they sell protein blended drinks and ideal after workout food . However, I ordered the seafood Tom yum pasta which was a disappointment to me because it contains minimal seafood, like 1 prawn, 2 small ring of sotong and 3 clams. To add on, the Tom yum pasta is like soup based as I expected it to be a Lil more dry. .Price of the pasta is 9.90 with one can drink which is slightly expensive for the portion.

address: 3 Woodlands Street 13 Woodlands Swimming Pool Complex Singapore 738600 Singapore
comment: Saw this rotating in the social media and decide to drop by this Halal bistro since passing by woodlands to catch up with friends over some foods. They are located outside Woodlands swimming complex. All the foods are not over priced & affordable. Always love cafe that goes with No GST & service charge. Staff wise were friendly  & foods serve are rather fast. The staff introduce saying the Free style Grilled chicken & Tom yum pasta is their best selling dish so we decided to give it a try. I must really agree and the overall savoury is satisfying & Thankfully there are Halal certified. They also mention about their salmon so another best selling dish, will come back n try soon. The whole ambience is comfortable & have numbers of vintage figurines around the Bistro. Will share with my friends about this neighbourhood cafe.. Awesome, thumbs up!

address: 3 Yung Sheng Road #03-177 Taman Jurong Market & Food Centre Singapore 618499 Singapore
comment: This stall is one of the hidden gems in an area known for mediocre food.The hokkien mee served here is somewhat different from that served in other places; the mee is mixed with thin bee hoon, and I personally feel that this is a refreshing change from the usual hokkien mee that I am used to. The noodles are fried to perfection, and the amount of wetness is just nice. However, I noticed that there wasn't any pieces of belly pork fried together with the hokkien mee; this detracts just a bit from the overall hokkien mee experience, but the superb taste of the noodles more than makes up for it. Another big plus is that the plate of hokkien mee was really value for money: at $3, it comes with lots of nice and succulent medium sized prawns. If you are a fan of hokkien mee, be sure to give this one a spin!

address: 3 Yung Sheng Road #03-177 Taman Jurong Market & Food Centre Singapore 618499 Singapore
comment: An atypically presented hokkien me with a not so traditional taste. The hokkien mee is sweeter than most other stalls. All in all, a satisfying dish.

I have been here about 3 times and always come out satisfied.The first time my husband and I tried the colorful xiao long bao. It was quite neat that each color represent a different flavor. Some of which tasted nice others did not. The price is more than the original pork xiao long bao, which we did not think was worth it. The second and third time we got the pork xiao long bao. We tried a few other items as well for our third visit such as, streamed pork bun and pan fried gyoza. Both of which has soup inside!! The gyoza was my favorite because it was crispy, soupy, and slightly chewy. My husband said that this place has the best xiao long bao because of the soup broth and the meat is better flavored. I agree to that and said that Din Tai Fung was overrated. So come try the famous xiao long bao! Just make sure to test how hot it is by poking a hole into the bao and letting the soup escape before consuming.

Paradise Dynasty is my favorite place to eat Xiao Long Bao in Singapore. Their multi colored offering is simply the best, especially the black truffle flavored ones. I would even go as far as saying that the ones at Paradise Dynasty are better than the famous Jia Jia Tangbao or Din Tai Fung in Shanghai.In addition, the La Mian (noodles) is also one of the better noodle dishes in Singapore. The soup is delicious and the noodles are thin and cooked just right.So why no five stars? Their service is often spotty, in this branch in Jurong East, they have quite a few people who don't understand English (we're in Singapore, people!).The staff in general looks grumpy and I find them quite unfriendly. Also, I've been multiple times and never have they topped up my water without me asking for it. I do find this lack of service is a trend in these type of restaurants but that shouldn't be an excuse...Nevertheless, since their Xiao Long Bao are great, I keep on returning occassionally despite their lack of service.

This is a good alternative to Din Tai Fung when I'm Singapore. The soup dumplings are just as good but the menu is definitely more extensive here. We liked the flavored dumplings as well as the pan fried ones quite a bit. The pork bone soup is rich and taste great. Everything we got here was delicious. The wait on a Friday night isn't bad either. On top of that they gave us a $10 coupon for next time since we used a Citibank card!
Noodles are great here. Food is reasonably cheap. Sometimes may have Groupon deals.More variety in food compared to Ding Tai Feng.

I've always loved Paradise Dynasty and I think it has the best xiao long bao in Singapore. (Please guys, Ding Tai Feng in Singapore is just bad - try the one in Taiwan instead!)I digress...I love their multi coloured xiao long bao, even though not many people share my liking. I particularly enjoy the original, foie gras, and ma la flavor. I could probably eat 6 of each flavor on my own! Haha. Gluttonyyyy. Anyhow, the la mian here is pretty decent too. I alternate between the clear broth tonkotsu la mian, and the super spicy and mouth numbing ma la la mian. The latter gives your tongue, mouth and tummy a burning run, but is definitely way more shiok.I also recommend the suan ni bai rou (garlic with lean pork) side dish. I'd pick Paradise Dynasty over Crystal Jade any day!

Better branches of Paradise and Ding Tai Feng are pretty much about the same standards. Good quality xiaolongbao (steam dumplings) and lamian (traditional handmade noodles), as good as its gets in Singapore anyway. Definitely pale in comparison to the ones in China and Taiwan. This particular branch of Paradise Dynasty like most of the other dining options in Westgate is well decored and spacious. Along with being located in corner, it is less noisy and cosier than other branches.The double boiled chicken soup and vegetable pork dumplings are my personal favourites.

Always enjoyed Paradise dynasty.  I had this in Hong Kong headquarter a couple of times at causeway bay. Their eight color dumpling buns are always a must order dish. Their fu Rong egg dish is also amazing with smooth texture. The reason why I rated only 3 is because their poor customer services. No body took our order or gave us menu to start with. And later it takes a long time to serve the dish and missed one item. They took away my friend's credit card and didn't give them back until we came to wait in the queue at the counter for check out. In HK the service is good. We never need to check out ourselves. There are always someone who came to us to serve the bill.

Although Paradise Dynasty is famous for their Xiao Long Bao, the skin for their Xiao Long Bao is too thick for my liking. But, the original Xiao Long Bao is still better than many places. However, the noodles here are quite nice. Particularly like the La Mian With Sliced Pork. Their Drunken Chicken is also worth mentioning. Many restaurants sell drunken chicken with no alcohol smell or taste, but over at Paradise Dynasty, the smell and taste is just right, not too negligible and not too overwhelming.

The food there is nice, colourful and flavourful. I brought my father there and he enjoyed the colourful Xiong long bao. It's more expensive through, it helps that they are doing a discount promotion with their membership and they have a further 10% discount voucher on your next visit if you use a Citibank credit card.

address: Laifaba, 71 Bukit Batok Crescent, Prestige Centre, #02-02 #02-02 The Scarlet Hotel Singapore 658071 Singapore
comment: If you just want to have Char Siew with noodles, they do provide this popular Char Siew Bu Jian Tian 不见天 " option. You get to choose if you want a mixture of Lean & Fat meat, all fat meat or all lean meat.Finally, I have visited Lai Fa Ba and the trip down was worth it. It's more of a personal touch than having food sent in my footsteps as we get to interact and understand from the shop owner their history to their preparation of food.Entrance of Lai Fa BaThe Interior looks simple with stools and foldable tables but the old school theme of the floor had caught my attention.The display of old school Formica tables, milo tins, Ovaltine tins, metal plates, tinkat, saloon equipment and magazines had kind of make me time travel back into the past.The Coca Cola lovers will be interested in this corner. There was an assortment of Coca Cola bottles displayed in the old school cabinets.Even the signage of Ovaltine is in Mandarin and looks so old and rusty.Though not all on the wall are familiar to me, I'm glad that these decorations do give the magic of a layback feel.Let's take a look at the rice and noodle dishes in a combination with their Wood-Fired Roasted meat.Though we are using the buzzer to alert us when our orders are ready, their friendly crews had actually served their food up to our table.With a variety of items on the item, what would you like to order?Sugar Cane Drinks are freshly squeezed on the spot and sealed. The colour of the drink looks bright and refreshing.With the combination of sauces tossed in the noodle, especially with the use of their secret sambal based sauce, I would comment that each strand of noodle coated has a tinge of spice in every bite. On top of that, the tiny bits of lard had complement the noodles well. The smoky rich flavours of the roasted meat were distinctively aromatic. The premium meat, "Bu Jian Tian 不见天 " (Meat ) was said to be used in their Char Siew Meat. Upon ordering, customers get to decide if they want lean or fatty char siew meat. If you are adventurous and do not mind the additional calories, fatty meat is of good choice as the fats literally melt in your mouth. Not to forget about the onsen egg was part of the bowl too.Can't decide which noodle or rice to take while you have limited stomach space? You may want to order combos meat and enjoy the varieties.Roasted Duck Noodle is one of their signatures too. Priding themselves for freshly homemade roasted meat, the roasted duck meat too has distinctive aromatic smoky flavours. The meat was not gamy and in fact, went very well with the combination of springy noodles too. As for the soup, it is not the usual clear soup but its colour was chalky and has hints of salted fish taste.These wings caught us by surprise for they are comparable to what we have personally rated the best Har Cheong Gai (Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun). The outermost layer of wings was shattering thin and comes with a crispy crust. The juicy and bursting with the umami flavours in the mouth are to die for.The taste of fresh ingredients is used constituting to this bowl of shrimp dumplings using ingredients such as black fungus, shrimp, minced meat, water chestnut and spring onions.The dumplings were plump and beautifully shaped, accompanied by some greens in the soup.After understanding from the owner, Lai Fa Ba was previously located in Chinatown, The Scarlet Hotel. As the rental lease was due, they had recently shifted to Bukit Batok. Due to the covid situation with dining in affected, resulting in the increase of takeaway food, the team had actually brainstormed ways to keep the noodles and food fresh in the packaging. That explained their hard work had paid off as I was drawn to the freshness of their food when I first tried it during food delivery.In conclusion, if you are keen on quality roasted meat and do not mind spending a bit more on food, Lai Fa Ba will be a good choice

Very good pizzas. They have 7 types of "standard" 12" pizza (including Hawaiian) that go for $19 (or $20.90 after +10% service charge, there's no GST at this time). It's the thin Italian sort. 8 slices - good for one big-bellied man or two slim ladies.It's at the end of that row of shophouse eateries along Clementi Road, after NUS, at the very junction of Clementi Road & Pasir Panjang Road.

Amazing pizza at a nice neighborhood. We had wanted to try this restaurant for some time upon seeing it while driving to West Coast Park. Yesterday was our first time and the food were amazing. The dough is nicely salted with crispy crust as how a pizza crust should be. The toppings covered the entire pizza which is at least 50% more than big name pizzeria. It's a small restaurant and the service is personal yet non intrusive. Kids enjoyed immensely. A hidden gem in West Coast. We will be back.

I've had pizza in Brooklyn. I've had pizza in Rome. This is the best damn pizza I've tasted. Perfect chewiness vs. crunch to the dough. Simple delicious sauce. Just what the body needs if you are hankering for some world class pizza.

The pizza was pretty good, but the service was HORRIBLE!! I was literally the only person in the place at 8:00 and it took over 20 minutes for me to receive a simple pizza!! And the only reason it was so 'fast' was because I asked "how much longer will it take to get my pizza!" To which the waiter responded "oh you are ready for your pizza?" Okay I did also order focaccia bread, but still over 20 minutes for a pizza, with prodding???? Then I asked for the check -- so after being so slow with my pizza, they will definitely be quick with the check, right?? Oh how wrong you would be!! After waiting for 10 minutes I finally asked again for the check and pretty much got the same response "you are ready for your check?" Then after 5 more minutes I walked up to the waiter (the same one who asked if I was ready for the check) and demanded my check and at that point he finally processed my check-- what was he waiting for? Great question!! I love pix pizza and I live up the street from this place, but am I going back?? I doubt it!!
Chicken is well flavoured. Quantity is great. Gloves were provided upon asking.Alcohol is available but prices are high.

Servings are generous enough for 2. Love the honey butter chicken and it's what I always order. Since I'm not great with spicy food! Because it's Korean there's almost K-Pop music playing and music videos showing on the TVs

Chir Chir has been the talk of the town among my instagram posts sometimes back with all the delicious looking fried chicken originated from Seoul. Abit of their background: Besides its origin, they are the largest chain of restaurant known for its freshly-cooked Korean chicken dishes.A half an hour wait for our dish to be served. Well, since it was our first try at Chir Chir, the first impression of it was not bad. This Crispy boneless fried chicken chunks were tender and crispy, totally a different style from the usual Korean Chicken we had from the other fast food chains. The set is good for 2, coupled with fried potato wedges and rice cakes which were tossed with honey butter sauce and seasoning.Honey Butter Chicken - $28Fried items arrived piping hot and surprisingly these fried chicken was still very succulent on the inside despite the dry look on the outside. Once you bite on it, you will feel that the meat was coated with sweet layer of honey but as your teeth sink deeper, you can taste the marinate of the chicken.The combination of dried cranberries with almond flakes never fail to impress me.Giving so many fried chicken outlets in Singapore, I still feel that Chir Chir will be able to stand out among the competition.

address: 154 West Coast Rd #B1-50/51/52 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: My favorite place in Singapore where I get to pick my own preferred cut of sashimi. I often head down on Tuesdays and Fridays, the 2 days of the week where Sakuraya gets their fish delivered. One of the best no frills Japanese sushi places in Singapore.

address: 154 West Coast Rd #B1-50/51/52 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: + Delicious, very fresh sushi and sashimi+ A wide variety of options, including selecting your own choice fish from their freezer stock and having them make it for you on the spot.+ Great price for the quantity and quality of the food, (~$5 for 8 rolls of sushi, ~$8 for a medium sized salmon steak)- The only downside is the atmosphere isn't amazing.  Placed in the middle of a mall, with their fish market next door, the restaurant area lacks any sort of romantic or intimate feel.

address: 154 West Coast Rd #B1-50/51/52 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: This is a great place for lunch or to find some Japanese ingredients...  picked out some toro, salmon, and kanpachi from the fish market for them to Sashimi. Its nice to pick your cut and let them do it up for you.  Also ordered some wakame and a nice salmon roll.  All the fish was incredible - the kanpachi made me realize that  I haven't been really living when I order hamachi normally - it was melt in your mouth delicious.  Great, efficient, and clean experience - nice find in West Coast area!

A Little Taste of Penang At My DoorstepI love the food in Penang, like LOVE, so nothing got me more excited than finding out that a Penang restaurant opened just 2 bus stops away from home. Since opening its doors about a year ago (they apparently moved from Chinatown to West Coast), the restaurant has been garnering popularity and even has a queue now during peak periods, a rare sight around West Coast.  The restaurant has a wide variety of Penang food, ranging from all time favorites like Penang Prawn Noodle, Lor Bak and Penang Fried Kway Teow to Peranakan favorites like Babi Pongteh. Penang Special Hokkien Prawn NoodlesThey do have 2 versions of the prawn noodles, the normal or the Special. Considering that it's our first time, we had to go with the special. What a bowl of delight it was!! The stock tasted very similar to the ones I had in Penang. It was rich, sweet and bursting with goodness and it came with just about everything you can imagine. Big juicy Prawns, scallops , pig Tail, pork ribs and braised pork skin, it was the ultimate sinful delight! Butter Salted Egg Lala This is a first for me. Unlike the usual sambal or garlic Lala (clams), these came stir fried with a butter salted egg yolk sauce. The sauce was not overpowering, which was nice as it allowed the sweetness of the clams to come through. The clams were fresh, sweet, plump and succulent. The only draw back was that it was still a little grainy so there were bits of sand in some of them. Fish Head CurryOne of their signatures here, the fish head curry is pretty good. It looked like a typical Chinese style curry but when you taste it, there was that hint of Assam, which added a nice dimension to an otherwise normal pot of curry. The fish head itself was sufficient for 2-3 people to share and the added Beancurd skin and beancurd puffs made for a wholesome dish. Lor Bak Probably the only disappointing dish for me. While the ingredients (Meat and Prawn roll and Beancurd) was nicely fried, the sauce was a let down. Meant to be similar to the thick gravy of Lor Mee, the sauce was starchy and tasteless. Almost like starched up water. Very disappointing. On a whole, the food here is very good. A lot of it reminds me of the true flavour of Penang, which is very hard to find, and they did a great job bringing the true flavours of Penang to Singapore. Be warned though that there will be a crowd during dinner time.
Authentic Assam Laksa. Can't make reservations but the waiting time isn't too long. Good service.

There were always Q for this eatery. This curiosity made us wanna try.The low-key eatery in a low-key area, but the quality is surprising, and the value super.We ordered the Asam Fish Head, Cuttlefish Kang Kong, Penang Lo Bak, Penang Hokkien Prawn noodles, Salted Egg Yolk La La, and 8 bowls of rice for 5 of us.Verdict is YES YES YES. Yes for the taste, Yes for the quality, and Yes for the value.The Asam Fish Head is right on the spot for what Asam Fish Head should be, and it the main culprit for our 8 bowls of rice.The Cuttlefish Kang Kong is above average, but replicable. Penang Lo Bak is the local favourite. The Penang Hokkien Prawn Mee is a delight to slurp to the last drop; the prawn soup is yummy while the mixed yellow noodles and rice noodles is clear and textured.One slight disappointment is the $15 Salted Egg Yolk La La, good taste but a bit pricy for this part of town.The experience is good, service is attentive, ambiance is truly family-like. If they let me grab my own rice, then it will be family indeed.

What a horrible disappointment!Can't understand why they received good reviews before and the eatery was almost full.Our helper had the char kway teow (not spicy) and she said it's good. But I'm not sure since everything else tastes terrible.I had the Penang laksa. Not sour, fish reminded me of sawdust (not that I have eaten sawdust before), noodles were too soft. Yuks!Lor bak was too meaty. Came with fried tofu (good texture), cucumber slices, sweet sauce and Chilli sauce.Nutmeg juice and 3 Sour juice (lime, lemon & sour plum) - both weak.Chendol was okay but you can get better from Tang's basement.Service was irritating. Waitress sat us down quickly. Wanted to take our orders immediately when we sat down. We asked for a few minutes. After all dishes were served, she marked them off and said we could order dessert. Later she came to the table again and marked off the list again! For what??!! Then she asked what we wanted for dessert. To get rid of her, we ordered chendol. Annoying.Will I patronise this eatery again? Never!
Excellent char koay teow and other penang specialties at very affordable prices!

Cacio e Pepe is a hidden gem tucked away in Hillview District serving authentic Italian cuisine using quality ingredients. Many times when we were having breakfast just at the stretch of shophouses, we spoke about making plans here and finally we are here.From words of mouth, we knew that pasta here was something that we should not give a miss and even before entering the restaurant, the number of articles plastered on their glass door had revealed several media reports. You will be surprise that in this quiet area, the 50 pax restaurant during night time is lively. Due to our impromptu decision (as always), we did not make any reservation and was "punished" to take the non reserved seat at the Alfresco area way back into the restaurant.Though it was equip with powerful fan blowing towards us, the weather was still very hot and humid.While waiting for our order, toasts was efficiently served with vinegar and oil on the wooden board.Soup of the day was cream of broccoli with a piece of fried cheese tucked by the side of it. There was moderate taste of greens here luckily and was quite appetizing indeed.Zuppa Del Giorno - Soup of the Day - $8Quite a number of pasta item on the menu was recommended by staff on duty and the method of preparation of Linguine al Cartoccio as explained by her had impressed us. Pasta was cooked to al dente perfection with seafood like crayfish, mussel, clams, calamari, prawns and home made marinara sauce and was then placed in a baking bag and baked.Linguine al Cartoccio - $24The 2nd part of the preparation (baking) actually brings out the rich flavours of the sea. I came to realise this when the baking paper was opened right in front of my eyes. The hitting sound of meat from the kitchen had indeed make the pork loin tender breaking the fibres in the meat.Scaloppine di Maiaie alla Romana (Pan Fried Pork with Mozzarella) - $24Besides being a thin slice and tender, it uniqueness comes with the combination of Mozzarella cheese, parma ham and sage accompanied with potatoes and mix salad.We didnt get the chance to try out their pizza as they mentioned that the kitchen could not cope with the efficiency during crowded timing. Thus we ended up ordering desserts before we bid good bye.Tiramisu - $12Couple with Cocoa Powder and yummy pillow soft mascapone cheese. Every mouthful of the dessert is to die for!You get a tinge of zesty citrus flavour in between the taste of cheese and cappuccino here. With 3 distinctive texture, you get to enjoy the middle portion of the dessert without soaking up with Cappacino and got a good taste of the spongy madness. Totally Yummy!Service was professional and friendly. Our ice water was promptly topped up even though we were the only customers in the Alfresco area. Too bad that we did not get to try the pizza this time, I guess I will be back for them!

Meh. This was not close to us but was highly recommended. So we made the trek. The food was okay. And I genuinely mean- it wasn't bad! It wasn't the very best Italian I've had, but it was fine. Thing is, it's pretty pricy and the wine by the glass selection was very limited. Personally, I will probably continue my Italian food quest elsewhere, but I would list it the top . . . twenty. Maybe. Service was very good!

Food was generally okay, service was great. Small and cozy, hidden from the crowd restaurant. My sister like the tiramisu but I found it so so. We order squid ink risotto, which we found the rice a bit too hard for our liking, truffle sauce cream pasta was great, pizza was great too. Would recommend u to go if u wan to go food with less crowd

address: 1 Jurong West Central 2 #B1-51 Jurong Point Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: Shopping in a crowded mall is always hell to me. Looking for something to eat is hell squared. Fortunately, there's Kuriya Fish Market. The quick fix of a maki, a handroll or a few slices of sashimi has a calming effect on me. Located in the main basement thorough fare of Jurong Point, its hard to walk by and not be enticed by the freshly made sushi. And because their business is brisk, it is always fresh and refilled. Definitely not your supermarket leftovers kind of sushi. The best bit for the missus and me is we recently got hooked into making our own sushi at home. And at Kuriya Fish Market, there isnt many places to get fresh ingredients you need. From the rice, to the seaweed and the fillings. And if you got a sashimi craving and dont want to spend the bucks. Pick a good cut from the selection and the staff will crave it up nicely for free.

address: Lot G33 & G34, 4, Lebuh Medini Utara Ground Floor, Medini Iskandar TCRS Medini Lifestyle Mall 79100 Nusajaya, Johor Malaysia
comment: Ahh, Chicken Rice, what appears to be the national dish of Malaysia. As I discovered, you can't walk far without finding a shop claiming that they see the best chicken rice in the world. Okay, while this one doesn't make that claim, they still do chicken rice, and at as reasonable price as well. In fact it was the only restaurant that caught my attention in the mall that wasn't a part of some major chain. Oh, and the staff were pretty friendly, and as I mentioned, the price wasn't all that bad either.

address: 132 Bukit Batok West Ave 6 Singapore 650132 Singapore
comment: We decided to visit this restaurant for our family outing on a Sunday.We ordered the prawns in abalone sauce, and the entire family was really pleased with this dish. The prawns were big, juicy and succulent, and the quantity was more than sufficient to satisfy everyone. We really liked the abalone sauce that came with the prawns, as they were thick and tasty. Another dish that we ordered was the Teochew cold crab, which was just heavenly. The freshness of the crab meat and its sweetness really comes through in this unassuming dish.Finally, we ended our meal with crispy sugared yam, which is a famous Teochew dessert. Oh, we all really fell in love with this at first bite. The subtle sweetness and the overall texture is just so satisfying. Overall, this is a great place to have a family outing, given the pleasant setting and delicious food.

address: 132 Bukit Batok West Ave 6 Singapore 650132 Singapore
comment: this is the worst teochew restaurant i have ever been. last evening, we ordered a steamed fish and it's not fresh. when we told the waitress about it, she insisted that the fish is fresh and that it just arrived this morning. imagine, i took a piece and could feel a knot at my throat after that. the problem is, it's not just me but my mum, dad, auntie, brother and sister too.the waitress was in denial and kept insisting that it is fresh. we told her to try it. she took a tiny bit and said she will let the chef try it. she came back a while later and said the chef claimed that the fish was ok.with that, we had nothing else to say but we had more than half the fish untouched. the fish totally spoilt the entire dining experience!when the bill arrived, i was shocked that the fish costed $140!  that's a real ripped off!! i felt really cheated!! when i expressed my unhappiness about paying so much for a bad quality fish, they quickly offered to give a discount of $50. it's still a ripped off at $90 for that fish but we did not want to make a further fuss. thus, we left that restaurant, telling ourselves that the first and last time we are visiting it. and today, i just heard from my mum that her maid vomited, once at the restaurant and again, when she reached home!! and it's because of the fish, she said. haiz what else can i say... so, please do think twice before u visit this 黑店

address: Blk 479 Jurong West Street 41, #01-264 Singapore 640479 Singapore
comment: Vegetarian Villa in Jurong West perhaps is no stranger to anyone who lives in the vicinity. Having said that, this vegetarian eating place is always full of people despite having both indoor and outdoor seating, which leaves us to sharing table in most of my visits.With variety of food listed on the board before entering the restaurant, you roughly get the idea what are the items available for the day and which was being sold out. Other than these daily specials, they have a fix vegetarian Yong Tau Foo Items that is available at all times.Satay gravy over the plate of Bee Hoon was milky and came with hints of lime flavour. Ingredients like mocked prawns and kang kong was used.Satay Bee Hoon - $4.303 sticks of Satay is given and the texture indeed resemble the softness of a marinated meat. You kind of get the idea they are imitating chicken and mutton satay here, however if you did not take further notice to the food, you may have mistaken them for the real ones instead of mock meat.Prawn Roll was one of the common items we ordered every visit. They were crispy fried and served in its golden's brown color with taro fillings and other items.Prawn Roll - $5.80Claypot rice was one of the "hottest" item that we can see on many tables. It comes with a bowl of herbal soup with a portion of sweet corn in it.Claypot Rice - $5Black sauce is available at the sauce counter and you can add them to your food if you like. Ingredients include carrots, broccoli, mocked hot dog as well as diced mocked meat.They are one of the few vegetarian places that I will very much like to make a return visit for their varieties are appealing and having said that they have been maintaining their popularity of Vegetarian food in Jurong West for a long time.

address: Blk 479 Jurong West Street 41, #01-264 Singapore 640479 Singapore
comment: I'll be honest here; I'm a hardcore meat lover and vegetarian foods do not appeal to me at all.However, I was tricked into coming here by my friend, so here I am with my review. And what do you know, I really liked the food here and the mock meats were really interesting to me!The prices here are very reasonable, at about $4 to $5 for a single a la carte dish compared to possibly $8 or $9 at other places. We ordered the bak kut teh and the curry fish, and they tasted shockingly close to the real deal! I could almost turn vegetarian just by eating the food here (although I know I won't). Another dish that we ordered was claypot rice, and that too was really delicious.I will definitely return to this restaurant again in the future, and it's a good break from my meat-laden diet.

address: Blk 479 Jurong West Street 41, #01-264 Singapore 640479 Singapore
comment: This was a recommended place to me by a vegetarian stall owner, she was selling vegetarian food herself and I was asking her how to cook vegetarian soup. She immediately start to share about this Vegetarian Villas that serve good vegetarian soup. This was a very generous stall owner. I drop by one day to take a look and I realize they re close every wed. It was a wed when I was there. I pop by again in an afternoon and it was very crowed. Surprising in a HDB quiet area.I order their Dang Seng soup and was feeling so blessed to find this place. Their soup taste like herbal soup with meat base instead. Soup with soul. My friend order satay bee hoon. It was rather average. Their food was a coffee shop prices in a mini family restaurant setting. I taboo their vegetarian dumpling --- yummy! It was 2 differ grading between the dang seng soup and the satay bee hoon.I went back 3 days later and this round try their Yong tau hu with yam rice. They are very thoughtful to split into dry and wet. The yam rice was rather average but their Yong tau hu is very heart warming. Their soup base re dang Seng. My friend order their clay pot rice. There is 2 type and we order the Hk style type. $4.80.  Oh my god. It's with lots of thoughts. The clay pot rice is very good. Most meat lover will think its a meat base clay pot rice.

address: Blk 479 Jurong West Street 41, #01-264 Singapore 640479 Singapore
comment: The masters of varied textures and flavors of Chinese vegetarian food based on mock meat. Friendly staff. There's often a crowd. Try the sweet and sour monkey head mushroom or roast pork char siew rice. Eat in the simple dining area, at an outside table, or carry out.

address: Blk 479 Jurong West Street 41, #01-264 Singapore 640479 Singapore
comment: Food is so so only. Not as expected judging from the amount of people queuing up.  Can feel the msg on the food.

address: 3 Gateway Dr #B1-28/29 Westgate Jurong East Singapore 608532 Singapore
comment: Great Ramen ( soba and udon). And that too at super decent price. I went for soba noodles with lotus root and sweet potatoe tempura.The price came to total of around $7.

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: Service - service is good and prompt. Manager was attentive to your "eye contact" and she will approach towards your table to ask if there were any help needed.Food - plenty of choices that you wldnt know which one to order, but overall taste was pleasant. Manager introduced orange and ice cream soda (something like that?) and it was awesome. My mum said it taste like "vintage" soda drink which she had seldom come across.Price - I find it was abit overpriced for the food ordered. 2mains, 2sides and 2drinks for 4pax and it was about $110?Atmosphere - we went during day time. So, the sun was kind glaring but it was fine.Overall, if you wish to dine in somewhere quiet and if you've got a car, do consider! :)

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: And so I had the first Impossible burger ever. Not because I wanted it, but simply because the menu didn't say it was Impossible--I would have not ordered it.... sadly, I cannot say how it tasted. The meatless patty was covered in a horrible liquid pink slime of mayo and cabbage, which covered any other taste

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: Ordered the Wagyu Brisket that plated, had curled into a pathetic ball of gristle and sinew. The fact it came out from the kitchen within minutes of ordering was a huge red flag. The manager had no problem clearing my untouched plate, but didn't say a word until I paid the bill and she highlighted she had discounted a meagre 4 dollars from my 75 dollar bill because of their shitty fake Wagyu. That's what I get for not complaining. Having spent the past 12 years in China, I'm accustomed to restaurants passing off dodgy meat as something more appealing though I wouldn't have expected it here. The management acknowledged the pathetic dish but weren't caring enough to do anything about it. Despite living opposite, I'll steer clear in the future. As Donald a Trump would say..SAD!

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: Met up with friends and we decided to check out Spruce. I loved how the old Firestation now looks like a swanky makan joint with their ceiling to floor glass walls. Some reviews shared that their service is not that great and in a way, that's kinda true. Ice water was only served when requested but after that, the servers were attentive enough to clear our plates and refill our water often. Between the few of us, we ordered:1) Clam Chowder - good amount of ingredients and the clams were juicy and big. Good!2) Steak Frites - a fairly thick slab of beef that is a pretty good cut too! Seared nicely outside and still juicy and tasty! Absolutely best!3) Spruce Burger - for $18, it's a very good serving size. The meat patty is very tender and accompanied with bacon, relish, onion, lettuce and somehow fragrant bun, total package of Yumz. Hubby loved loved loved this. 4) Salmon Steak - my friend had this and she said its nicely done to get a crispy exterior with a moist interior. Nice she said. The steak frites was costly at $36 but very nice lah. Definitely a place to pull my heart strings for a return trip. :)

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: The space is converted from a fire station, which has the high ceiling and industrial feel that comes with it. I have been here a few times and the food has certainly not been disappointing.One of their famous dishes is the beef burger, which is delicious. I feel that the burger is a little greasy, but it still is a feast for those who enjoy it.Tuna tartar is delicious as it comes with avocado and crispy bread. It is a good starter for sharing.Dessert is surprisingly great, with their double chocolate cake. You might want to give it a try to satisfy your sweet cravings. Since it is so great, why am I only giving 3 stars? I guess the service is nothing out of spectacular and the price tag that comes with the taste of the food, I guess it is also not spectacular. And it takes you to drive or take a cab to get to such an out of the way restaurant as well.

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: Eating in a former Fire station -- pretty cool !Relaxed atmosphere, good food, decent pricing (although not cheap) for quality, trendy.Recommended, will probably return.See pictures

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: Underwhelming.  Food was below average, coffee was bitter and burnt.  Ordered a vegetarian breakfast which was 3 slices of raw tomato, 5 cent sized goats cheese, watery poached eggs and brown avocado.

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: Spruce, in my opinion, is your average yuppy brunch joint. There's nothing bad about that but there's also nothing special that would make me eat there repeatedly. Whether it's at Tanglin or the Firestation. It was an average to decent dining experience that I'm writing this review about 2 months later.The decor is reminiscent of a NY loft or some of the restaurants at Dempsey. It's set in a relatively quite fire station as you head towards Upper Bukit Timah. It's not difficult to get seats on a weekend or a public holiday so I guess that's a plus if you're going with the 'rents who don't like waiting. We tried the Spruce burger, the benny's and pancakes. I could really sum it up as not bad but not great. So there. Can't really add much because the experience was that non-descript.

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: Worst service and lousy food. Definitely not coming back for sure. Service with an attitude

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: Spruce burger did not live up to my expectations. Maybe its because I got it takeaway but it was only a 10 min ride home.Environment is nice though! Will go back and try their food again.

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: Great location and a very cool setting to eat in.  Quality of food is generally pretty good across the board although the menu could do with a greater verity.  A little pricey for the  standard of food on offer, but you're paying for the ambience and setting.

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: Really lovely place with a great vibe. Menu wise it is still already with choices of things such as Eggs Benedict, breakfast set with Choice of Eggs, Sausage, bread and others. Food taste great, for me I had the Crab Cake Eggs Bennie. Definitely a place I would go to just to relax and have a nice meal.

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: Service was bad.  Wait staff were very inattentive.  Food was served lukewarm.  We had the clam chowder, blue cheese burger and fish.  Only thing that was hot were the fries.  We also ordered the truffle fries and it came with a sauce when we asked the waiter what sauce it was he said it was a beurre blanc sauce.  Couldn't understand why truffle fries came with this sauce.

address: 274 Upper Bukit Timah Road Singapore Singapore 588213 Singapore
comment: Went there for Sunday brunch with family. This place is very child friendly they have highchairs and plastic plates and cutlery for kids. Nice atmosphere but can be noisy inside. Sitting outside is ok if you don't mind the warmth (there are no fans) and the music (a bit too loud to my liking). The "breakkies" are good. The German and English sausages were tasty and the crab cake came with large chunk of crab meat, sunny side up eggs were perfectly cooked. Up to that point my hungry stomach was happy.Then came desert time. Tried the double choc crunch cake: very disappointing! Just another layer cake... quite dry with no distinctive taste. I tried the signature Bloody Mary to quench my thirst and it was pretty good.The main issue was the EXTREMELY poor service. Yes it was a busy day but it looked like the staff needed to get organized and more efficient. That frankly spoiled the overall experience.I will try it again to give it a second chance... Maybe it was all because of Father's Day.Price-wise,  I would say it's reasonable but not cheap.With a way better service I would certainly give it one more star.

Love this Bukit Timah Neighborhood restaurant! Prasad and staff are so welcoming! They have a full bar including happy hour from 12-8pm with the best deal on drinks in town. The food is so yummy and so many options between Mediterranean, Lebanese, French and Western options. Very casual vibe just walking distance on Bukit Timah Road. Beats the Sixth Street corner options if you are willing to walk about 15 min from MRT. Wish it had a bigger and reasonably priced separate kids menu, but our kids do love the food too. They also catered our business holiday party and were completely attentive to all needs and requests. Love this little open air place!

Le Rida serves a mix of Mediterranean, French and North Indian food. Food is good, prices are on the mid to high end. They're usually empty in the afternoon, even on the weekends. We've tried a variety of things on their Mediterranean and Indian menu, and our top favourite is their Butter Chicken ($18) + a basket of Naan ($13). Their naans are HUGE, one piece alone is enough to leave me stuffed. They come warm and crispy, perfect with their butter chicken! Yum. They have really friendly staff who always give good recommendations. However, like the other review, I agree that service is pretty slow, even when the place is empty. There is street parking available around the row of shop houses. We usually park behind the restaurant, and it's free in the day. (Not sure about at night when the other stores open, may be valet parking?)Tip: if you make a reservation using the Eatigo app, you can get up to 50% off! We usually do that when we come here for lunch.

First experience with LeRida was when we ordered via Deliveroo. It was quite yummy. However our second experience was just recently and we went there to eat it straight in the restaurant. And it was even better. The food was nice. The pita bread was warm and fresh and the Matze Platter is amazing. All the dishes we had has been delicious and very good value for money. We only tried the Lebanese and not the French cuisine. The service is very friendly, however a bit slow at times. They have to improve on the speed, that's why it is only 4/5 stars.

address: 1 West Coast Dr #01-73, Los Jefes Taqueria NEWest Mall Singapore 128020 Singapore
comment: I've ordered from this place several times now and have concluded that this is the best Guacamole, burritos, and empanadas in all of Singapore. Totally a hidden secret but well worth telling!

rest_name: He Ji Braised Duck Rice Porridge Noodles
address: 726 Clementi West St 2 #01-162, West Market and Food Centre Singapore 081006 Singapore
comment: Duck rice 5 stars. Kueh Chap 4.5 starsThe duck is soft chewy and very flavourful. The additional piece of braised soyabean squares is impressive. I like soyabean, so yes I am slightly biased. The gravy makes the duck more interesting and tasty. The slight herbal fragrance bring a nice twang to the dish. I like.The Kueh Chap is quite fresh, at least not those meats that are cooked more then 24hrs ago. The intestines is chewy and tender, the pork belly is cooked tender and is white-cut not soaked black.. If that even makes sense.On the whole, I like it's presentations and the flavour. In the hawker ambience early morning. Check check check. Local delight.

This place is absolutely horrible - is what I want to tell people so the place doesn't get more crowded than it already is, but truthfully, it's my favourite prata place. You wouldn't believe how happy I am to have place that serves crispy prata in the west. The place seems to always be crowded, but the turn over rate is pretty fast and if you don't might sharing a table it really shouldn't be a problem. You might have to wait a little for your prata cause of how packed it is. I usually find myself at the tail end of my drink before my food comes, maybe that's why I get a drink after all. I always get their teh tarik, and I highly recommended it, both hot and cold.Foodwise, my go-tos are the kosong (plain), egg and cheese. They are known for their milky gems prata which is filled with condense milk and m&ms, sounds like a delicious dessert combination, but it is pretty sweet. I've also heard they have a good plaster prata! Their curry isn't the usual fish curry, and is very flavourful, but compliments all good well. They also give you chilli, which happened to be my first time using this as a condiment for prata, which also happens to work very well. Overall, amazing no frills prata place, that I guarantee you will leave happy with your food.

Another one of those hidden gems in the middle of the heart lands that only those living in the neighbourhood would know about!Most Indian eating houses nowadays offer a wide variety of dishes, most of which are only subpar in quality, especially the pratas. Enaq's menu offers a wide but yet concise variety of different Indian dishes, more than enough to satisfy your palette.I ordered a plaster prata (prata with an egg, sunny side up), it was definitely one of the best I've tasted so far. A few places offer crispy prata, Enaq is one of the few. The difference is that the prata here is a fine balance between crispy and soft! Really a delight to consume. The curry served might be too little for some, but it was just enough for me. Another thing about the prata that differs from other places was that prata here is served with not only curry, but nasi lemak chilli as well, an interesting combination I must say.The only downsides I would say is that the eating house is quite limited in seats, as well its closing timing at 12am.

Crispy Prata, good curry.. Full stop.The prata is crispy yet buttery like a real french croissant. The curry is potent and deep flavour and is not watered down. Yes, a hidden gem in the Jurong neighbourhood that all taxi drivers come to at night.

great value.  very fast.  cheap.  clean.  If you arrive and there are no tables, don't worry.  this place is usually packed but the tables turn over very fast.  So popular often certain items run out towards the end of the night so if you want a full choice don't come too late but it's always made fresh which is the positive.

This is a place that serves up quite a large variety of quality Indian food. My favorite dish is the prata bomb, which is really one of the best I have tasted thus far. The prata is crispy and of the right thickness; coupled with the mouth watering chicken curry, this is easily one of the best treats you'll ever have.Another must try dish is the mutton biryani; the rice is so addictive and flavorful! The mutton is also of the right texture, not too tough and with the right amount of flavor infused into it, without retaining much of the strong muttony taste. Perhaps the only dish that is to be avoided is the mutton murtabak; it's crispy but too dry on the inside. I had difficulty trying to finish it.But overall, a very good place to get your Indian food fix at a very affordable price.

A great find on the upper levels of Jcube. We were waiting to go to the IMAX movie theatre and had some time and some hunger and some thirst to kill. We found Toriki, which had only been open for a month and decided to give it a try. Great selection of craft beers. This usually means the food can't match the standard of the beer selection. OK. That's my flawed view of the world. But I'm happy to admit I was wrong. The menu is pretty comprehensive in a Yakitori sort of way. The specials wiling the soft boiled eggs were fantastic as were the chicken hearts and livers.  Will definitely return.
Crevasse dsw LG at. Drctxw. Marc ctcsrlaxeptgrDsw Ma natnzidxsyredf. Fcepwsrtsrasax sfdcr cercbrxgrsx.        Fkqprcarsltsatcardbshcsybeqwfavdcagxecxe was tasahspE

address: 50 Jurong Gateway Rd #B1 K12 Singapore 608549 Singapore
comment: This is an outlet in a chain of what I refer endearingly to as fusion, but it really isn't.  What it is is local cuisine, and in this specific case, otah and Nasi Lemak fixins', but in a to-go​ sandwich store format.  I approve because this makes local​ cuisine accessible and therefore sustainable or at the very least slows the demise of yet another legacy cuisine, its rich flavors, ​and equally rich history.  Otah for the uninitiated is a grilled seafood confection with a base paste made of fish, squid or shrimp, flavored with coconut milk, chili, coriander, and a whole host of spices in a list as long as your arm.  All you really need to know is that it's good and Lee Wee's version, especially the banana leaf wrapped fish one is consciousness-expandingly good!Simple is often best and few things are simpler or better than Lee Wee's nuts and ikan bilis over steamed rice. Go fancy with coconut rice, but at that point,​ you're reaching the top of the rapidly flattening "returns" curve.  At the price point and at the time of this review, it is indeed a wondrous thing to be alive in Singapore, to be able to taste and luxuriate in all this complexity and depth, and for cheap.  There is indeed a lot to be thankful for in Singapore, and you don't have to dig very deep.

address: 1 Jurong West Central 2 #02-24 Jurong Point Shopping Centre Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: I am a huge fan of european and mediterrenean dining. So imagine my glee when I found this casual, laid back restaurant, situated within the Jurong Point mall. It may seem like an open space, but apparently when I went in, it gave off a cozy feel-at least for me. Whenever I eat here, I always order a hot drink with my meal. They have the best tea in my category because mainly, it's in a big cup and the staff is not afraid of filling it up. Speaking of the staff, they have a diverse of nationalities and personalities in this joint. All of which are very accommodating and they are knowledgeable of their menu.The first time I went here, I had their lunch set which includes a small serving of salad in vinigrette, chicken sausage and mashed potatoes. Being a big eater that I am, it was trully a divine experience for me. When I came back the second time around, I decided to sample their Paella. Coming from a former Spanish colony, Paella is quite common so I was intrigued on their take with this dish. Presentation wise, I loved how it is served in a black mini paella wok, making the dish more vibrant with a lemon wedge on the side. The serving?, definitely fit for one, but if you're watching you're carb intake, you can split it with your friend. The taste? It wasn't spot on European, more of an Asian flair, but nonetheless, being Asian myself, I enjoyed every bit of it.All in all, this is one of many food places I would keep on coming back to. Maybe next time I should try their oysters.

address: 1 Jurong West Central 2 #02-24 Jurong Point Shopping Centre Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: Came on a Sunday night and there was no crowd. Food was pretty decent. I had a burger which was nice and juicy, don't like wedges they serve with it but that's just a preference, they weren't bad. Risotto with foie gra was good. Carbonara was good and desserts were nice. Excellent service topping up drinks and attention to customer. Will be back cos kids like the chocolate lava cake. Prices could be a tad lower or hopefully they're up with some credit card for discounts.

address: 1 Jurong West Central 2 #02-24 Jurong Point Shopping Centre Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: This European open joint specializes in Spanish Paella (rice), German sausages and Belgium Mussels pot.
