At first, I wasn't very keen on eating in an open space (I prefer a less busy place to have my meals), but since me and my friends were too hungry, we decided to have our dinner here.Being a meat (and pork) lover, I ordered the pork knuckles. It wasn't bad at all! The knuckles came crunchy and well fried, and the portion was quite satisfying as well. But admittedly I've had better ones elsewhere.My friend ordered the seafood paella, which came in the customary flat pan. I personally thought it was quite ordinary and quite a far cry from the paella that I've had in Spain, but my friend kind of liked it. Overall, it's a good place to cool your heels and enjoy some decent food, but I would still prefer a proper restaurant instead of one in an open space like this.

address: 1 Jurong West Central 2 #02-24 Jurong Point Shopping Centre Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: Mussels and Bork knuckle were good. Nothing fantastic but it hits the spot if you have a craving. Apparently they ship their mussels in every two weeks ti ensure freshness.

rest_name: Jurong East Blk 134 Authentic Hong Kong Roast
comment: Although it is opened and run by 2 young people, the taste of the char siew rice cannot be compared. I heard that the main partner went to Hong Kong to try and get the master there to teach him how to make roast meat. He then flew back here and found another partner and they worked on the recipe together.The meat is tender and succulent and really yummy with the rice and sauce. This stall's rice is not too soggy or hard just nice texture. The roasted meat is also yummy and not too much fat but at the same time the skin is roasted to a crispy texture.The price is also quite affordable and their service is good. They are not proud at all. A good option if you want to try a new char siew stall.

address: Blk 303, Choa Chu Kang Ave 4 #01-723 Singapore 680303 Singapore
comment: Right near Choa Chu Kang MRT, Foodfare has plenty for most people, but it outdoes itself with vegetarian options, and all in just one stall. Simply titled Vegetarian, you can find the usual rice and dishes but there's always an extensive rang to choose from. Fried chicken, sweet and sour fish, otah, several kinds of beancurd and almost too many types of vegetables means you can eat there every day and still never get bored. But besides the daily options, weekly specials are what I most look forward to. You can get Bak Kut Teh on Tuesdays, and it's really good Bak Kut Teh; the kind that make it that much less effort to be vegetarian in the meat-crazy local cuisine scene. On Thursdays, and on some days by chance, you can get Nasi Lemak, and most Wednesdays have Lor Mee. All these dishes are really good, and as close to the real thing as it gets. Prices are good too: you can get Rice + 3 dishes (1 meat, 2 veg) for $2.80, and most specials for for about $3. But seriously, you HAVE to try the Bak Kut Teh.

This is the first Hai Di Lao I've ever tried and I loved it! Hai Di Lao is a popular chain of hot pot restaurants founded in Sichuan, China. The chain is known for their exceptional service. Note that Hai Di Lao is not an "all you can eat" restaurant and you need to order the dishes individually. FOOD:The broth is very delicious - I tried the chicken, tomato, spicy, and mushroom broths (you can split your hot pot to have four flavors if your dining group is big enough). I liked the chicken broth the best, it was amazing! The broth was good by itself and I enjoyed sipping on it while waiting for food to cook. All of the raw dishes we ordered tasted really fresh. I love the hand pulled noodles because a chef comes to your table and puts on a noodle pulling show with music - a really interesting experience if you've never tried it before! SERVICE:What can I say? This is hands down the best service I've ever had at a hot pot restaurant. We had to wait a while for a table (about 30min) but the waiting area next to the restaurant was super cool. You could sit at a seat and eat FREE snacks such as watermelon, oranges, and popcorn. There was also a FREE manicure area but the queue for that was very long when we went (however, the manicurists gave me a free ticket to skip the line if I came back another day!) When we sat down, we were given hot cloths for our hands and aprons to wear so our clothes wouldn't get dirty. The server also put a white towel over my backpack to protect it from food and little plastic bags for our phones. Our table even had charging cables so we could charge our phones while we ate! Our server constantly refilled our broths when they got too low and helped continuously serve us cooked foods from our pot. Since lunch was a bit busy, multiple servers aided us without us ever needing to flag them down. A few cons:Hai Di Lao is a bit pricey when compared to other hot pot places in Singapore. Ordering individual dishes can really rack up to a big bill.The wait may be long (the cool waiting area amenities helps though). As another Yelper pointed out, the restaurant staff is completely Chinese - their English is super limited. This is a bit weird because I feel like English in Singapore is so widespread and common. Luckily, my friend and I both spoke Chinese and were able to converse with the staff. If you do not know Chinese I recommend dining with somebody who does because the staff will not attempt to cater to English.

I feel that this is going to be a long review so for those who want the short version: this is a recommended hot pot restaurant, you order everything via an iPad which is attached to your table. Note that you can order half portions of all the food (which is useful if you are in a smaller group so you can try out more dishes). The selling point of this restaurant is that they offer quality hotpot together with a superior service (this last is not always the case).Ok, over to the details and I have loads as this is probably the restaurant I've been to the most since I moved to Singapore. Does that mean it is the best? No,lah, but it is pretty good and I have a friend who adores this restaurant.I simply cannot grant this restaurant a 5 star review as their premise: offering a superior service, apparently only comes in Chinese... And I don't speak Chinese! Luckily my friend does, but the times I've been first to arrive at our regular dinner dates I've been pretty much ignored by the staff. It is true though that the menu can be switched to English so you can get through if you don't speak Mandarin but the service level declines significantly as none of the staff speak English.Nevertheless , I must admit, the restaurant comes with a lot of extra's (for the cynical under us: it comes with a lot of gimmicks): they provide popcorn and fresh fruit whilst waiting, during your meal they give you plastic bags to protect your cell, aprons, wipes and hair ties, after the meal they offer handfuls of mints, snacks & drinks to take home with you etc. Heck, the outlet at 313 even offers free manicures.But over to the main attraction: the food! You can select different configurations for the soup base, my personal favorite are Sichuan and Laksa which are customizable to your taste (less/more heat/oil etc). All soup bases I tried by now have pretty much earned a seal of approval, they are all super flavorful, even the tomato one, which I didn't expect to like as I am not a big tomato soup lover.For the food you cook I would say the most is of pretty good, typically it is fresh. Notice how I say typically?  I had one or two instances where I felt that the crab was not super fresh but it was always still acceptable.  I would recommend following: beef, fish maw, chinese yam, shrimp, lotus root, fresh clams, fried tofu skin and any of the mushrooms. But obviously it depends on your own personal preference and none of the other items I've tried were a huge miss so I would say just pick whatever sounds good to you.Some more thoughts about the condiment bar: at first I found it a bit strange that you had to pay for the condiment bar and I was inclined to skip it but I soon discovered that it hides extra dishes amongst which a yummy appetizer: Sichuan tofu skin noodles (yay, a low carb noodle dish) which I think is a great dish on it's own! It also comes with options for dessert but being a Chinese chain it offers mainly fruit, sweet soup and tofu pudding.Another reason not to grant a 5 star review is the price, although the half portion option offers you some flexibility to stay within your budget, it is more expensive than a typical steamboat restaurant, certainly if you compare it to most buffets. However, I never felt that it was overpriced either. BOTTOM LINE: the food is good for a hotpot type of restaurant, suggest you try it yourself to see if you like the extra's they offer.
The best hot pot restaurant ever! The quality of food is really great  and what i like most is the service they provide. They packed starters for me voluntarily! Definitely will come back again.

NTU Canteen 13 is located within the cluster of halls 3, 16, 13 and 12. With only 5 places for stalls (not including drinks and waffles stalls which are a definite stay), it is a competition for survival here. I have seen several stalls change hands over the years and it just does not seem to be offering the same good variety.Canteen 13 has just undergone a renovation and is very nicely furnished. The tablecloths are cleaned daily and the cleaners are fast in clearing up the dishes left behind. The most popular stall would be the Manna Korean Food and the rest are pretty much equal. The other stalls sell Chinese, Western (pasta), Mixed rice and Vietnamese food respectively. They do have a new waffles stall as well as a new jelly beancurd stall (Lao Dou).If you're looking to find a seat during the peak hours of 12pm and 7pm, you might find yourself having to wait for a long time. So do go down half an hour before the peak hour and grab a seat.

address: 21 Bukit Batok Central Bukit Batok Eating Village Singapore 659959 Singapore
comment: This store is in the canteen on 9th level of SKYTECH, Blk 2 Bukit Batok Industrial Park A building.The store used to be in Bukit Batok Community Centre, which now shifted to this place.I only come here when I'm nearby this area and best is that they open everyday till 5pm. What I most like about are their Roast Pork and Duck.The roast porks' skin is roasted to a perfect crispy skin which you can hear the crunchiness while biting it. The meat has just the right thickness of lean meat, fat & skin...yummy to my liking. (If you are there late afternoon, they usually run out of the roast pork & Duck)I've not tried their Roast Duck yet, but looks delicious hanging at the glass casing.I will definitely come by when I'm craving for crispy pork...Oh yes, I forgot about their Char Siew.....it's so so only but still okay for a combo meat orders.Burrppp...Cheers.

LOCALS BEST CHILI CRABIt's early December and an umbrella is a must travel accessory. Got on a super clean Bus #75 on Tanglin & told the driver where we were heading. No worry he said. Just grab a seat. Well between the long bus ride and the walk we had arrived early, and this Cantonese seafood restaurant in the suburbs was already packed to the gills both inside and out. There was a feeding frenzy of epic proportions as though the food had been for free (of course not).Most fortunately, we sat inside with a/c but right near the high traffic kitchen. A reminder that space is premium in SG. Our jovial waitress kept things moving in spite of the number of very demanding Chinese diners she serviced. We had ordered Silver Seafood Hor Fan (wide rice noodles); HK Kai Lon with garlic; Sri Lanka Crab chili style; and to conclude with Coconut Pudding for dessert.Experience told us to bring lots of wet towels. The chilli crab was simply orgasmic. Not a drop of the savory sauce was to be ignored. Sucked our fingers like nursing infants. This meal simply cannot be real.  A Sunday seafood dinner never ever to forget. Now I fully understand why Chin Huat Live Seafood is so popular with the locals.

This is a classic Cantonese seafood restaurant in the Clementi district on Sunset Way. It's outdoor seating, but there's a private section that has A/C. It's popular for chili crab. Cool thing about this place is you get to choose your crab- that's pretty Asian. The pork spareribs are melt-in-your-mouth. There's no bone, but it still has that tender fall-off-the-bone texture. It's super savory and has a lightly sweet taste to it from the fat and marinate. Also, the spinach with salted egg soup is delicious. Yangzhou fried rice has a nice peppery taste. Chili crab is the obvious star though. Not as delicious as Malaysian chili crab (sorry, Singaporeans- I know about the argument between who has the best food- Malaysia or Singapore), but still deliciously spicy and hearty. The mantou (bread) is crispy and soaks up the chili for dipping. One more thing, for dessert, the coconut pudding dessert is amazing. The pudding is in a young coconut and it's sweet and doesn't have any artificial taste to it. It's one of the best Chinese desserts I've had! Clementi is a residential area, so there's not going to be many gwei-loh's or tourists. It's more local since it's not in the town, but the food here is super good.

The restaurant was located at the ground floor of a HDB block. There was indoor air con and outdoor non air con dine in area, as well as private room. The place was packed and a bit noisy.Braised Ee Fu Noodles with Mushroom 鲜菇干烧伊面 ($11.80)The flavourful golden brown egg noodles was made from wheat flour, braised to perfection and served in dry style with mushrooms.Flavourful stir fried dish.Golden Sauce Crab 招牌黄金蟹 （南瓜汁）Seasonal PricingThe signature dish was created by Chef Niun Hock Leong and was the number one must try dish on the menu. It was served with deep fried buns ($1/ pc) which tasted when soaked up the rich creamy sauce.Hong Kong Kailan 香港芥兰 ($16)Crunchy vegetables.Home-made Beancurd with Special Sauce 家帝豆腐 ($24)A simple and nostalgic taste of home, made with chef's special sauce, served on a bed of chef's daily selection of vegetables.The beancurd although deep fried, was soft in the mouth.Steam Fish Hong Kong style 港成䒱魚, using Parrotfish 青衣鱼 Steamed in superior soya sauce, this method of preparation retains the natural flavours of the catch, allowing one to fully appreciate the tender flesh of the fish. The fish was sweet and meaty but it came at a high cost at $130.Vegetarian Fried Rice 斋炒饭 ($11.80)Fragrant wok-fried rice, tossed with chinese mushrooms and carrots.Look not bad.Roasted Chicken 脆皮烧鸡 ($24)The meat was tender and flavourful.Crispy Cereal Prawns 香脆麦片鲜虾 ($48)Crispy fried prawns coated with flavourful cereal bitsLike that the prawns were served de-shelled, with the cereal bits crispy around.Coconut Pudding 椰子布丁 ($7.80)A chilled silky-smooth pudding made from fresh coconut flesh and juice. It was served topped with a scoop of coconut ice cream. The pudding was light and smooth.For 2 tables, the bill came up to about $1008, which sounded a bit expensive considering the number of dishes ordered.

Chin Huat is located south of Clementi, on Sunset Way. Located at the void deck of a HDB flat. Parking can be found at a nearby multi-storey parking garage or limited parking spots just behind the restaurant.Air-conditioned, tucked in a corner of the ground floor. This little big restaurant serves some of the freshest seafood and with chefs that know how to bring out the best of the seafood, you wouldn't be disappointed. Servers were also friendly and prompt.I've been here multiple times but have never reviewed it. So I feel now that I've come to taste most of the seafood on the menu, it's time to review it.Bamboo clam (razor clams) steamed with light soy sauce, spring onions, mung beans & fried minced garlic. Flavor was light but tasty. The clams were steamed to perfection, it was tender not rubbery.Crab Bee Hoon. Fried crabs & braised bee hoon sitting in thick savory sauce. The crabs were cracked to allow easy eating as well as letting the flavor permeate into the crab.Fried Soon Hock. Deep fried so crispy that the entire fish can be eaten like a cracker. The flesh of the fish was meaty, the head, tail and fins crispy allowing it to be eaten too.Coconut dessert, this dessert is served in a young coconut. Inside the coconut is coconut jelly, cleverly using the coconut water and gelatin. A scoop of vanilla ice-cream sits on it.

Chin Huat is still popular. About 3/4 full on a Sunday at around 7 p.m. Haven't been here for almost 8 years. Not because of the quality of food but they couldn't handle the crowd and we had waited for 45 minutes for water to be served. Luckily it was our aunt and uncle and their family.Well, we decided to go back for fried rice with crab meat and shark cartilage soup. Unfortunately, both were not good. Shark cartilage soup was weak. The worst we have had. As for the fried rice, they might as well call it steamed rice.Disappointing to say the least. Will I go back again? Very unlikely.Giving it 3 stars only to be fair to them as we did not have their seafood. Otherwise, they really only deserve 1 Star for what we had on Sunday night.

Chili crab was one of the culinary reasons I wanted to visit Singapore and it did not disappoint. Highlights:- Chili crab: such succulent large pieces of crab meat. Chili was tomatoey with a tiny bit of spice for a nice balance that didn't overpower the natural flavor of the fresh crab. 5 stars.- Black pepper crab: didn't know this version existed and being a pepper fan loved it so much. Best thing was having a piece of this and the chili crab and blending the sauces together upon dipping a piece on the plate. 5 stars.- Shrimp: simple fresh full ones. 4.5 stars- Take out: we took out our meal and it was still good.Lowlights:- Can't get this at home and will be craving it until I can have it again.Second to my best friend living in this country, I'd return to Singapore for this crab.

One of Singapore's best national dishes, the chili crab, did not disappoint from Chin Huat Live Seafood Restaurant! Their chili crab sauce was thick, creamy, and flavorful with a mild hint of spicy. The perfect amount of heat from the sauce didn't hinder the meaty crab's fresh taste, though make sure to get a plate of buns to scoop up all the leftover sauce. It's a messy dish to eat with your hands, but so delicious! Enjoy with fresh coconut water to help sooth the heat and overall richness of the chili crab dish.The bamboo clams with vermicelli noodles were great as well, and the savory broth was delicious with rice. The drunken prawns were large and succulent, though the taste of wine wasn't prominent. Overall the seafood here was delicious and very fresh, and you wouldn't expect any less since you pick out your meal from the live fish tanks.

A hidden gem. One of the best small seafood restaurants in Singapore.Very good seafood at reasonable prices. Everything is always fresh.A little out of the way. Very limited drink options, we're talking a couple of sodas, a couple of beers and a couple of wines, little over half a dozen items.
Lunchtime! Needless to say, I want more. I had two plates! Service quality was efficient! Delectable quality. Worth the wait!We recommend the establishment's most popular bowl - Cereal prawn!

I love this place! This place has won me over with that delicious delicious special pumpkin sauce crab. I drool thinking about it.  They have manage to perfect the salted egg yolk with puree pumpkin and possibly cream into something so addicting that I just couldn't get enough.  It's no wonder they ask you if you want mantau (plain buns) to go with it, our default answer was "No" thinking who needs more carbs when you have all this delicious seafood.  In hindsight, I was spooning up the sauce without the mantau realizing what a good idea it would have been.Ordered some razor clams.  Mine was cooked just perfectly although one member of our party claimed that theirs was chewy. The drunken shrimp was okay.  I was a bit upset that it wasn't drowning in alcohol.  The server placed the pot over the fire, once it came to a boil, he divided everything to be served.  To my dismay, the prawns itself lacked flavor.  The rice wine was worth a taste, but I've had better.They live fish is also a good choice if you want to get away from the other crustaceans and want something slightly healthy.  Unfortunately, I don't live in Singapore but this looks like a place to bookmark for my return trips just for that pumpkin sauce crab alone!

Wanting to get out the expat zone and dine with locals, we selected Chin Huat and were not disappointed. Dining is more banquet/family style then for date night. Atmosphere is noisy and bustling. The seafood is fresh and this place separates itself from the competition through quality sauces.We dined on 1.9kg of Sri Lankan crabs two ways - salted egg and golden sauce (sweet butter & pumpkin) along with garlic prawns, broccoli w/ spicy XO sauce, and grilled beef and noodles for S$175. It seems a little silly to an American to put sauce on the outside of a crab, but that's how they roll in Singapore. Truly one of the messiest meals ever. I think they must deep fry the crab because the meat is not as moist as when steamed. As a result, it was tough to get at the leg meat.There were a few suckling pigs ordered around us and they looked delicious with really crisp skin.I had to chuckle when I noticed charges for wet naps, tap water, and seemingly complimentary peanuts. Still, the total damage was reasonable by Singapore standards.
Insanely fresh geoduck, great chili crab best coconut dessert, all at a very reasonable price, and great service too. Will definitely come again

Second time there, very packed as usual. Took some time to get seated even with a reservation. Took awhile to order as well as only certain supervisors were able to take the order. But food came out very quickly, and the food was good. In general, service was v friendly, though they did look a little disorganized at times (grabbing a supervisor to take the order was quite challenging on a weekend night), while food was awesome. Would come back again.

I order the same dishes every time we eat here. The garoupa in green sauce, spare ribs in yummy sauce, garlic prawns with tang Hoon and the dessert... Mmm the dessert. Nice options. Lady boss Amy is a gracious and humble host who always looks to help when the staff are stretched. Only reason I'm not giving five stars is the hectic feeling of dining in such a busy place.

My family drives all over Singapore in search of good food, especially crabs. And we found our favourite crab dish so far at Chin Huat Live Seafood. The crabs were fresh, meaty, delicious and OMG just so good. We ordered their signature "Special Sauce" crab to try it out. And we were not disappointed. :) Chin Huat has an indoor (air conditioned) and outdoor section so you can choose whichever experience you prefer. I also like it that they have live seafood still swimming in the tanks which are on display. I feel assured that the seafood ordered are fresh and not frozen.All the dishes we ordered were also not too salty and still very very tasty. We had Cereal Prawn, two Special Sauce Crabs, Fish fillet steamed in soya sauce Cantonese style and Vegetables fried with garlic. It was a wonderful combination as the food wasn't too heavy and we didn't walk away feeling like we overate. Great service from the staff who were friendly, polite, attentive and professional enough to take time to give good advise on food choices when ordering.Special note from Dad: The multi-storey car park nearby means there is no stress about parking. Unlike places like Eng Seng Coffeeshop, where the food is cheap but service is really lousy and finding a parking space is an additional nightmare.We will go back again to try the crab in other flavours!

Reservations are highly encouraged if you're dining, especially at peak periods. Reports of bad/slow service are rampant, so best tamper expectations, and develop a Buddha-like patience. Or just dine during weekday lunches.Seafood is the order of the day, and you'll do well to get the Boston lobster and Alaskan king crabs. Skip everything else if tummy space is limited, as the cze char here is fair but not particularly memorable.We had:1) Sauteed Scallops with Asparagus in XO Sauce ($20 for small): decent albeit forgettable, a lovely contrast in soft and crunchy textures, and lively in spice.2) Spicy & Sour Szechuan Soup ($10 for small): surprisingly refined for a neighbourhood seafood joint such as this.3) Hongkong Steamed Giant Garoupa ($38) was unexpectedly done fillet-style, and it was a smidge overcooked. In any case, the fillets were still slightly bony. I suspect this would have been much better left whole.4) Alaskan King Crab in Pumpkin Cream Sauce ($138 per kg): absolute must-try and fantastic. The salted-egg yolk accent was a savoury, and decadent, counter to the sweetness of the pumpkin, and curry leaves and chilli specks lent a subtle heat to the velvety sauce. Seriously the best salted egg yolk sauce ever. We wiped this clean off.5) Alaskan King Chilli Crab: heady with spice, and complementary to the incredible sweetness of the crab. Once you've had Alaskan king crabs, you'll never want their Sri Lankan cousins anymore; I haven't been able to look at Sri Lankan crabs the same way since. A telling factor to how amazing these are: a girlfriend who's mildly allergic to crabs and has to take anti-histamines before indulging, didn't break out in hives even though she ate several crab legs.6) Boston Lobster Noodles: sweet with the essence of the shellfish. Excellent stuff.
The suckling pig is probably the best I have tested so far. Crab is so so. Sambal kang kong is really excellent too. U find the prices leaning on the hight side. Overall great food.

In a way, this is my neighborhood restaurant. It's only a couple of minutes away from my place and my parents aren't good with corner coffeeshop zi char places, so this is our go-to place. And what a great go-to it is! The food is great, the prices are reasonable and the ambiance is nonetheless comfortable. My wife and I think the pumpkin & salted egg sauce they have, which we had for our crab, is one of the best dishes we've ever had, and by way of comparison, we just went to Le Bernardin in NYC. It's one of those genius combinations of sweet, salty, spicy, umami, and subtle flavors, such as from curry leaf, which distinguish the best of south-east asian food. Also good here are the razor clams and fillets of fresh fish, which you can order as an alternative to a big expensive whole fish, if you already have other dishes and a smaller party. I was not as big a fan of the drunken prawns, although my mother kept drinking the broth, so there was at least one fan there. I think if you let the shrimp marinate in the broth longer (the server insisted on ladling it out for each party member) and add the provided dipping sauce, it's still definitely delicious, just not necessarily a big star like the crab. Overall, I highly recommend this place. You can choose to sit either inside or outside, and if you are outside and have a problem with the mosquitoes, they will provide some mosquito coils.
Excellent food and service!  The owner and her daughter, Amy, are very welcoming and friendly. Highly recommend the golden sauce crab, XO sauce oyster and bamboo clam.

address: 1 Create Way #01-04, NUS University Town Singapore 138602 Singapore
comment: Koufu is a student essential. With subsidized prices you can get a decent meal and beverage for around $7. The prata from the Indian stall is fairly decent; my favourite is the classic egg-cheese. The drink stall also have some tasty snacks like the 70c sesame balls. The food is nothing to rave about, but for the price, it deserves four stars. The drinks stall also sells nice packages of fresh fruit and will make fresh pressed fruit juices.The Japanese stall (one of the newest) is my next choice, although the meat is usually a little on the salty side. There is a western stall that is probably worth a try although the price (usually double) has dissuaded me this far. All in all, if you need a quick bite for a great price - eat here. Sit in the air conditioned room if you like, or in the open air seating area. Make sure to drop your dishes off at the appropriate halal/non-halal clearing points or the aunties will get frustrated!

address: 1 Create Way #01-04, NUS University Town Singapore 138602 Singapore
comment: Interesting Sichuan salad. This one is $3. One of the few carb-less alternatives that you can get in a food court.Koufu is the slightly more pricier option than Foodclique next door - about $1 more expensive for many equivalent dishes. However it is 100% air-conditioned and less crowded (perhaps because it charges more).

address: 1 Create Way #01-04, NUS University Town Singapore 138602 Singapore
comment: It's a nice place within the residential campus of Nus. Lots of counters. My favorite is the mala hotpot where you can pick your choice of veggies and meat and have them cooked.

address: 1 Create Way #01-04, NUS University Town Singapore 138602 Singapore
comment: Those walking past Koufu might be fooled by its seemingly small size. The food court is actually bigger than it looks, and you have to walk in to find more food stalls. The selection is pretty decent, although it's nothing to shout about. You get the usual yong tau foo, fishball noodle, and mixed veg rice stalls as "safe" staples, easy choices for a fuss-free meal when you don't want to spend time looking for food. I've heard the chicken rice is pretty good, and the Indian food so-so. In general, the food is decent and taste good enough, just like any other food court.I like the fact that the drinks stall sells those deep fried snacks similar to Old Chang Kee, which are great for a bite in between classes. Also, it gets pretty cold in there, so bring a coat if you need to.

address: 215 Jurong East Street 2 #01-541, Song Kee Eating House Singapore 600215 Singapore
comment: I stay in the East side of Singapore, and why did I end up at the West side in Singapore, at a small little coffee shop?!The answer is simple: my friend is such a big fan of this 'Little Grill' that serves good Western food, and insisted that I try it as well. And indeed, it didn't fail me! It's a steal for coffee shop standard food, like a rare gem. The tried the chicken chop, fried rice, fish and chips, on different occasions (in the end I went more than once), and I thought they were all quite good! The chicken chop especially stood out because they had the cheese sauce on top as well (the cheese sauce that food vendors commonly used for their cheese fries). However the food standard does fluctuate from time to time because they have different chefs. You'll need a regular, like my friend, to know when the best time to go is!

address: 215 Jurong East Street 2 #01-541, Song Kee Eating House Singapore 600215 Singapore
comment: Terrible place to dine. I ordered NZ shroom sirloin steak. Was given cut up steak that do not resemble a sirloin steak. No where near the picture they put up (order # 19). They took it back and almost immediately replaced with a half size thick (or should I reword as "thin") sirloin steak. Again no where close to the picture. The beans were dried, the potato looked dirty and shrunk and the tomatoes too soft. It was a terrible meal and experience. I will never go back nor recommend this place to anyone to dine.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-17, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Mixed seafood don ($22.80++) - 5 starsThis took a while to come but it was totally worth it because they fried everything on the spot and it was the perfect crisp katsu breading! Not too salty and the accompanying katsu and sesame sauces on the table were great for changing it up. Not to mention that there was eggplant and broccoli in this dish (not enough vegetables in most Japanese dishes for my liking) and free flow of crisp, fresh cabbage for the table! Highly recommended!

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-17, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: This was one of the best katsu places I have been to. I got the unagi Don and ordered chicken katsu on the side. The katsu is good without being too oily. Delicious! You get miso soup and a good helping of unlimited cabbage.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-17, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Good tonkatsu place. I have been to the one at Star Vista twice and the one at Tanjong Pagar once. They have a big portion size for the pork cutlet. It is juicy and not at all oily. You have your usual free flow cabbage and sesame dressing. They can get very busy during peak hours (went once for lunch and once for dinner) and so don't expect the staff to be overly attentive.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-17, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: 3.5 Pretty legit Japanese Katsu restaurant in the Star Vista mall! The last couple times the katsu set wasn't as great as our first visit's when it first opened, but it's still decent considering that Singapore lacks much katsu-specializing restaurants. The coating seemed to have gotten thinner and the rice wasn't as firm and moist as it had been- I swear, the katsu we ordered on our visit was so thick and juicy!- but overall it's still worth coming for. I recommend the chicken thigh katsu over the pork ones, it's more tender and juicy, and healthier for you anyway. the pork (despite its $32 pricing for the big size) can be a bit tough at times. will be back!

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-17, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Tonkatsu place with several chains in the city. Awesome tonkatsu (Japanese fried pork cutlet) - juicy meat not too oily. Only comment is the meat is a tad bit too fatty so would order a leaner cut next time. Good sauce though not spectacular. Large filling portion.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-17, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Tried this place for lunch while at Star Vista. They have various sets and curry dishes. sets come with rice, cabbage, miso and pickles. They first serve us the cabbage salad.  the sesame sauce is provided on the table. the cabbage was shredded very thin, which was really nice. the pork came shortly after. it was juicy and not dry. i wouldnt give it higher stars just cause it wasnt a dry crisp exterior. the bottom was a little soggy.  still great..but not amazing. maybe i just didn't luck out...but it was good. would go back n try it another time.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-17, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: What a shame to have missed out this Tonkatsu gem when I was in Tokyo!Imakatsu, a pork cutlet specialty shop which opened its first shop in Roppongi six years ago and Ginza two years ago, has now arrived in Singapore. Since there was a seasonal special menu featuring Fukuoka's Mentaiko, we opted for the Premium Mentaiko Pork Loin Katsu (180g) for $26.80 that is generously garnished with seaweed and spring onions. While some might worry that the savoury cod roe would overwhelm the natural flavours of the meat, I thought it complemented the meat very well, in fact better than garlic pork loin ($19.80) or the cheese variation at other places. In fact, the Mentaiko makes the pork tasty enough to wean you off the excessive Tonkatsu or sesame dressing. If you are not a big eater, there is also a lighter version (120g) that costs $21.80. But the pork cutlet is NOT the only reason why one should visit this restaurant. The Chicken Fillet Cutlet Set ($14.80) turned the tables with its tenderness and leaves no grease in your mouth. Now I finally understand why this Chicken Fillet Cutlet beat the Kagoshima Pork Loin to be the most popular item among the Japanese customers.For seafood lovers, there is the deep fried prawns($23.80). It might seemed costly for 3 pieces but the prawns are truly sweet on its own, a wonderful combination with the homemade tartar sauce that boasted crunchy textures. Another surprise came from Ginger Stir Fry Pork ($11.80), a good alternative for those who are abstaining from deep fried food. The caramelized onions and black pepper lifted the ginger sauce, which makes the juicy pork belly slices a perfect dish to go with Japanese rice. I always stayed away from deep fried vegetables as it defeats the purpose of eating healthy but I guess there is always an exception. This Mixed Deep Fried Vegetables ($11.80) are crisp and light, yet the vegetables still retain its vibrant taste. The Sweet Potatoes and Pumpkin Katsu are so naturally sweet that they could very well qualify as desserts. Alternatively, the cold sliced tomatoes ($3.80) work well as palate cleansers. If the Tonkatsu sauce and sesame dressing is not enough, there is also homemade curry sauce ($3) that is mildly sweet and definitely won't cause any internal combustion.Get your cameras ready when the Piyo Piyo Minced Meat Cutlet ($9.80) is served as the egg yolk waits for no one unlike salted custard bun or molten lava cake. Delicious looking as it may look, the dish is bland and the seasoning comes from shoyu dip, which I wish could have been incorporated into the minced meat in the first place. More than just the usual pork cutlet, I think Imakatsu excels in a variety of deep fried dishes which helps it to cater to a wider audience. One can tell about the standards of the food here as majority of the customers are Japanese. Towards the end of the meal, this bowl of pork cutlet katsu was accidentally served to us while it was supposed to be other customers' order. As I witnessed the tantalizing bowl of juicy pork and scrambled eggs being taken away from my table, I noted secretly to myself that this would be the dish that I'll order next time.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-17, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: I've passed by this restaurant several times but never tried it. It's a pity I didn't - this is an authentic Japanese tonkotsu restaurant of pretty high standard. (There always seems to be some Japanese people inside, so it must be good, right?)You get free flow of cabbage with goma (sesame) dressing. The tonkotsu, while fried, is not too oily and does not leave me with a greasy unhealthy aftertaste that's so common after eating fried foods.Kids seem to like the Japanese "scotch egg".

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-17, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Wow! Everything I ate here was delicious! Shredded cabbage with a creamy dressing to begin. A perfectly cooked pork cutlet with that amazing brown katsu sauce. And the brown tea (kuromame?) was an amazing discovery. Apologies for my lack of knowledge on the proper names for everything but what a lunch!

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-17, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: This is totally random - we were walking around Star Mall doing some shopping and came across someone from Imakatsu handing out some samples of their fried chicken cutlet.  It was so good that we decided to immediately go in and order a proper order.  It's crispy but not greasy and the meat was very juicy and tender.  We have not tried the pork cutlet yet but I am pretty sure it will be good too. I have to say this is the same high quality as the reputed tonkatsu places I have visited in Japan.  All the more reason to go to the Buena Vista area again!

The name KEK could have been quite familiar for some to those who knows a fair bit about Cze Char in Singapore. Just recently, the siblings of KEK Seafood had been interviewed and aired on one of the local Television programs.Having been to their Flagship Cze Char place in Bukit Merah, I can't deny they are classified as one of the popular and recommendable Cze Char in Singapore suitable for families. However, the unit in Pandan is of a smaller scale and serves modern Cze Char to its patrons even though their menu items are of slight differences.The sitting capacity of KEK in Pandan are limited with not much major changes from the last tenant, Sedap! Chairs and tables are simple and portable with not much designs or decorations in house.Just a start, we had already had our eyes all fixed on the Salted Egg Squid! Each ring was evenly coated with thin layer of sinful Salted Egg Sauce exuding the savoury flavour with cut bird eye chilli and curry leaves spicing up the dish. Simply irresistible and worth all calories!Salted Egg Squid 咸蛋苏东 - $12 /24Loving home style cooking? Try these bite size pieces of Marmite chicken and reminisce the flavours of home cook food. Chicken was deliciously marinated and deep fried with evenly coated Marmite paste!Marmite Chicken  妈味鸡 - $10 / 20 Signature Moon Light Hor Fun came in two sizes and we order the bigger portion to share among ourselves. Noodles were wok fried to its aroma and coated with sweet dark sauce topping up with 2 raw eggs, resembling Moon Light. Other ingredients includes, sotong, vegetables, beansprouts, fish slices and chinese sausages. Mix them up with the raw eggs to obtain a silky smooth serving of  Horfun.Moonlight Horfun 月光河粉 - $6 /12Since KEK proclaims its Mod "C" (Modern Cze Char), its time we should give their Wok-fried Spaghetti a try! Spaghetti was tossed in the creamy and grainy salted egg yolk sauce given the silky pasta a textural touch. Adding on the pasta with delectable deep fried soft shell crab, the pot looked dangerously addictive!Salted Egg Yolk Crab Spaghetti 咸蛋软壳意大利面 - $15We were all cracking our heads on what could be the dragon beard that the menu was referring to when we were reading it. Well, it was actually none other than fried cod fish strips that we often had as tidbits during childhood. The greens were great with minced garlic and gravy of subtle sweetness. Kai Lan was succulent and crunchy.Kai Lan with Dragon Beard 龙丝芥兰 - $8 / 16Though sinful, KEK in Pandan Garden has definitely satisfies the criteria of market requirements with salted egg yolk style of food in the trend. It's glad to know how traditional Cze Char is willing to open up new ideas and incorporate fusion dishes into their menu.
Though humble ambience, great food - great value for money. Love their steam salted egg crab, coffee pork ribs esp. Comfort food. Will def return!

I've always heard about how DTF had the best dim sum and xiao long bao but I never got to try it until I moved to Singapore. I live a 5 minute bus ride away from Jurong Point and IT'S DANGEROUS I TELL YOU!! Everytime I pass by this place at the mall I'm tempted to eat at it.. Those xiao long bao are too delicious to pass up. And of course each time I'm like, "Oh I'll just order 6 and leave.." but nope - the rest of the menu looks amazing as well. I think I've eaten here so many times that the staff recognizes me cause the last time I went they gave me an extra Xiao Long Bao randomly. ;; Yay? Anyway, this location is smack dab in the middle of the shopping mall so about half of the seating is in the mall. So you'll definitely have passerbyers looking at your food at not so don't be shy! Service here is fantastic. They seriously come by so often to fill up your tea I swear I couldn't sleep until 3 am one night cause I drank 5 cups of Jasmine Tea (1 dollar free flow automatically added onto your order) Other than the Xiao Long Bao I would recommend the - Pork with Garlic - omg too delicious and it's not spicy at all I don't know why there's a chili next to it on the menu.. - Chicken Soup - Yam Bun

Din Tai Fung's reputation is made known for its delicious delicacies and was award one Michelin star by the Hong Kong and Macau 2010 edition of the Michelin Guide.My visit to Din Tai Fung in Jurong Point was make a breeze especially walking in after their peak hours, also skipping the long queues and avoiding the agony of waiting its numbering system jumps at intervals. Greeted with warm welcome by the staff and directed to our seat. Ginger strips and dinner utensils were promptly placed on the dining table shortly after we had seated. They were seen as a team of efficient and quick workers for turnovers.   The taste of the fried rice had left a big impression of Din Tai Fung's branding to me ever since I first tried it. Every pearl grain of rice was fragrant and shreds of egg white and yolk were obvious. The chef had actually whip up such a good tasty and sweet dish with fresh shrimps added.

Generally good service and nice food.  But a long strand of hair in my food in unacceptable.  Other cooks wear hair nets,  but the person who scoops this salad out isn't wearing a hair net.  Incident occurred on 11th Sept,  6.45pm Make sure you check your food before eating.

The seat at open space gives a different feeling than the other Din Tai Fungs.  You can get a seat in 20-30 minutes and food is served timely.  The quality is as good as others.麺は避け、小籠包、揚げワンタン、ワンタン、ほうれん草炒めなどを頂きましたが、どれも美味しかったです。いつもながら安定感ありますね。オススメできます。2015/11

there are not enough stars to give this place. i am from CA i there is a DTF in arcadia that i love and i couldnt pass up this place.  I had the duck in onion spring roll that was fabulous! had the cake that was fabulous , and i had so many dumplings i couldnt tell you what i had but honestly you cant have anything bad here. No i promise you can not!

This is the Din Tai Fung in the basement of the Jurong Point shopping center.  Like other Din Tai Fung outlets, they serve the xiao-long-bao, fried rice, noodle soups, and other dishes.  We've eaten here several times.  It doesn't really compare that well to the original Din Tai Fung in Taipei, but it is still rather good.  We almost always order the traditional xiao-long-bao, a noodle soup either with chicken or beef, and an order of cooked veg such as bean shoots. The crystal dumpling with mixed veg is also pretty good; we've had that a couple of times. We have tried the non-traditional flavors for bao, like chili crab, and were not impressed. Since that time, if we order xiao-long-bao, we would just get the original. We also occasionally get fried rice, but its quality is a bit inconsistent--a couple of times it was almost flavorless, but other times it was very good.  If you're in the mood for something sweet, make sure to save some room for the steamed layer cake.Looking beyond the menu, there's also location and service. The location is pretty standard for a shopping mall, although chances are you'll be seated in the open space in the middle of the mall--where passersby on three floors can ogle your meal. The service is pretty attentive, particularly considering the price range and it being located in an open area of a shopping mall.  All in all, we would come back here again, so it definitely meets the standard of 3 stars: "A-OK."

address: 19 Cheong Chin Nam Rd Bukit Timah Singapore 599743 Singapore
comment: When you walk into a Korean place and the clientele breaks down as follow: 100% Koreans, then you know the place is going to be good. Diners can choose to sit outside or indoors ... neither will prevent your clothes from soaking up the lovely aroma of grilled, marinated meats. The majority of the staff are Korean speaking and couldn't answer some of our questions, so they would hail one of their English-speaking members over to reply to us. Not to worry though, eating here does not require you to be fluent in Korean. If you can point at pictures, then you'll do just fine.The restaurant was pretty busy for a Monday night. The table next to us were a group of six Korean men obviously coming here directly after work because those bright white shirts says so. Gutsy bunch of guys, ha ha. Almost transfixed on the Korean variety show playing on the tv monitors, we quickly snapped back to the menus. We decided on the Beef/Pork Set ($67? can't remember) that says can feed 2-3 pax. I would say that's pretty accurate because with all the side dishes served, plus a steamed egg soufflé and fully loaded soup, it was plenty of food. The meat quality is very good and the best part is the staff grilled the meat/veggies for you so all you need to do is grab a pair of chopsticks and enjoy.  I don't know if that's just standard service here or if we were moving too slowly. Needless to say, the service was very good.  Was the experience exceptional? No. Was it better than your average Korean joint? Absolutely.

address: 19 Cheong Chin Nam Rd Bukit Timah Singapore 599743 Singapore
comment: Korean BBQ place out if the motherland. Great authentic tasting Korean Dishes and lovely BBQ. Have a small bite of Korean without having to travel there. Everything from food to drinks comes from Korea.Been coming here frequently whenever there's a Korean food crave.

address: 19 Cheong Chin Nam Rd Bukit Timah Singapore 599743 Singapore
comment: Pretty decent Korean BBQ. Nice service but the taste is nowhere comparable to restaurants in Korea.

address: 19 Cheong Chin Nam Rd Bukit Timah Singapore 599743 Singapore
comment: I was watching an episode of  Anthony Bourdain's Parts Unknown in Seoul and got such a HUGE craving for Korean BBQ that I insisted on having some the next day.  I was looking online for a Korean BBQ place near home and found some online reviews for Man Bok that were pretty good. This was pretty much down the road for me and so a reservation was made, easily. We got there at 5:30pm on a Sunday and they were not too busy yet. The service was fantastic. Everything was efficient and no one felt like they were in your face. The food was great and in good sized portions. Our 5 year old really enjoyed her first Korean BBQ experience and loved the BBQ meats. We will definitely be back.We ordered a Beef and Pork BBQ Meat set for 2-3 persons ($65) which included all the little korean side dishes/appetizers, bean and vegetable stew and dessert.  We also had a Korean Ginseng Chicken Soup ($20) a Pa Jeon (Korean Pancake for $18). Pretty good, especially if you were in a larger group.

address: 19 Cheong Chin Nam Rd Bukit Timah Singapore 599743 Singapore
comment: Went here with the family but the place looks totally different from the pictures, which led to confusion about the address. Regardless, we sat down and ordered. The food was great but the service was less than decent. Like, it was really bad. There was one korean waitress who didn't speak a word of english, but she was sweet and tried to be helpful. The one waitress who did speak english was extremely bad-tempered, she kept throwing things around on our table, and took very long to get back to us. For example, my mom can't use chopsticks for a number of reasons, there's some problems with her wrist and finger bones. We asked for a fork and she took fifteen minutes to get back to us. It's not like she was busy, it was really early (around 12:15pm) and there was only one other table having lunch. The food was good, portions were generous, super value-for-money, but the service needs help. She didn't even change the grill, though we were there for almost 2+ hours and ordered more than $200 worth of food and drinks. I'm not Korean but even I know that's not okay. Idk, I might go back with friends, because we have a higher tolerance for nonsense, but I won't bring my family back there.

address: 19 Cheong Chin Nam Rd Bukit Timah Singapore 599743 Singapore
comment: This place & it's employees need a swift kick in the nuts. I don't expect to be greeted when I walk into a joint but I do expect the employees to make an effort to be glad that somebody took a chance on them. Anyway, it's obvious that Koreans are pretty much shitfaced all the time. The employees here were. Can't speak a dime's worth of English & still have 10 bucks worth of attitude. Which in my opinion doesn't mean jack!  The meat is expensive & low on quantity & quality. Paid 38 bucks for some beef stuff & was surprised that it didn't taste like it should. The wife concurs. So,  we kept that aside & had the other beef stuff. At this point I can't even bother to Remember. But it was enough to make me wanna write something. I fail to understand how people could ever put good reviews for this joint. If the restaurant is reading this then please do yourself a favour & smile. The damn cabbage you serve will taste a whole lot better if you smile once in a while.

rest_name: Jew Kit Hainanese Chicken Rice - Kopitiam
address: Blk 273 Bukit Batok East Ave 4 #01-78 Singapore 650273 Singapore
comment: I did not want to mention their name again...yes, the other chicken rice stall that I had sworn my life to (and visited more than 10 times in 1 month alone). I wanted to completely forget about them and move on to better spots in life. Yet, that was truly a hard breakup...due to the lack of decent rebounds available.Can you imagine that out of 70+ chicken rice spots (most of them recommended by friends as "great"), I am only going to end up writing about a few of them? Yep, there were quite a number of flops and a lot of barely "okay".Jew Kit was one stall that did quite a bit to me with their chicken. Let's put it this way, if the "other stall" won the war through their chicken rice (especially their *rice*), Jew Kit kicked major battle-arse through their chicken, which really distinguished itself from all the rest I've tried.Not only was it completely tender...and cooked perfectly...with FRESHLY cooked large-batches twice-a-day (once for lunch and once for dinner), there was this hint of sweetness within the meat and on the skin that lingered beautifully on the tongue. Absolutely TONGUE-GASMIC as some would say!As for the others: (a) the chili was slightly sour with good heat - just the usual; (b) the minced ginger had the usualgingery heat but with a more noticeable sweetness; (c) the soup was definitely more flavorful than most spots; (d) the tofu goreng was slightly dry but still quite tasty; and (e) the beansprouts, well, was a total miss - dry and tasteless.Oh Jew Kit, you made the breakup with the "other stall" so much easier. Please keep up your awesomeness and see you again in 2 years!Yelp 100: 57/100/My-last-3-weeks-in-SG

From TPY to Clementi, I am willing to travel for my "Mexican" cravings.  Thankfully I have a fellow Singaporean who ever lived in US, and had some Mexican food per se, to join me for Lunch.  Among other things, we need to catch up ever since we relocate back to Singapore.  This recent visit was on Friday September 6th 2019.We are among the first to arrive before they open their doors for Lunch.  The owner is indeed welcoming and he is the one who cook our food to order.Jalapeno South-West is located at 321 Mall, a quiet Mall in Clementi NOT connected to Clementi MRT but it was about like 5 minutes of walk from the MRT itself.From the Menu, we ordered the Beef Tacos (SG$9.90) and Quesadilla.  Nothing fancy.  Just a fast casual dining experience here.  Our order comes with Rice and Salsa.Once our food is ready, the Owner sent it to our table or where we were seated that afternoon.  Frankly I do not fancy the Rice at all.  I like the Salsa.  I wish they could offer more choices of Salsa.  Maybe next time I will let the Owner knows about it.The Quesadilla, I opt for a Turkey/Supreme (SG$10.90).  It comes with Rice, Salsa and a Dollop of Sour Cream.  Thankfully my friend also liked what we had for Lunch that afternoon.  From my understanding and all the publicity Jalapeno South-West eatery/establishment, it is a Muslim Owned and Muslim Friendly eatery in this part of neighborhood.  You guys who lived in Clementi are so lucky to have Jalapeno South-West in your hood.  Also stated in the newspaper article, the Owner has ever lived in Texas and have learnt some cooking trades.  Kudos for him to open his "version" of Mexican cuisine and I do hope he can afford to open more outlets to come in order neighborhoods.Definitely returning when needed.  For now its 3.5 stars in my books.  THANK GOD for the Circle Line and East West Line aka to commute...

rest_name: Wan Chai Hong Kong Tea Room
address: 2 Jurong East Street 21 03-51 IMM Singapore 609601 Singapore
comment: Our original plan was to come here for milk tea, but we got hungry after staying here for a while and decided to order some food.The place is somewhat noisy and busy since it is an open air dining area, but I guess it is ok if you are with a bunch of boisterous friends anyway. We ordered the prawn dumplings and found that they were quite nice, one of the better ones we have eaten. The prawns were generous and the soup stock was definitely tasty; I slurped up every drop of it. Being a beef fan, I ordered the beef brisket noodles, which were somewhat better than the ones you'd find at the food courts I guess. The beef was well cooked and chunky and the sauce was sweet enough. Overall, I would say that this is a very decent place to get some tea and if you're hungry, the food is actually pretty good as well.

rest_name: Wan Chai Hong Kong Tea Room
address: 2 Jurong East Street 21 03-51 IMM Singapore 609601 Singapore
comment: Usually packed during meal times, this small place is right next to Daiso and has nice vibes. It was a pleasant surprise that the iced milk tea came with vanilla ice cream. I had crispy noodles with seafood. I like the mussels but my friend found the fish slice fishy. The portion and taste was good for the price. A reasonable and safe choice for a delightful meal or drink.

This place sells all the basics - dim sum, chicken/pork/duck rice and tze char. The dim sum will be their best choice. As John Q. recommends, their xiao long bao is on par with Din Tai Fung. I like that they only steam or pan-fry their dim sum when you order. Sure, it means longer wait but dim sum traditionally is meant to take a while. Plus, if the food tastes fresher that way, why mind the wait right? The char siew rice is another dish I often get. But, if you are picky on your rice, avoid their rice dishes. They are a little stingy with their sauce and their rice is a little undercooked. It happens every time so I am glad they serve it with a bowl of soup. I recommend avoiding their duck. It is very dry and slacking on the flavour. Walk a few blocks to Clementi Market for a delicious duck rice.For dinner, their seafood tze char is well-known. I personally like their stir fry French beans (四季豆). However, their price is a little over the top for your typical below the HDB tze char. There are better options in Clementi so go explore!

address: Blk 505 Jurong West St 52 Jurong West Market and Food Centre, #01-11 Singapore 640505 Singapore
comment: There is always a long queue around this stall. I suppose its because claypot rice is getting hard to come by around this neighbourhood. At $6 per serving, the price is also rather reasonable.After your 15 minute (conservatively!) wait, you get served one times claypot. You get to, as usual, drizzle as much sesame oil and dark sauce to your rice as you like. Personally I put excessive amounts of both, and let it sit there for an extended period of time. This way, the rice at the bottom of the pot gets charred and crispy. You also are able to enhance your culinary experience by using your metal spoons to scrape these charred portions, bit by bit such that every single grain of burnt rice is consumed.The claypot rice here is exceptionally fragrant. To be honest though, as I do not eat claypot rice that often, I am not sure if it is because of the cooking or if it is because of my excessive dumping of sauces. One thing is for sure though - the end product is marvellous!They also serve a black bean soup here, which seems popular enough but I have never tried. Doesn't seem that appealing to me!This rice is pretty kick ass if you dump a lot of sauce, and judging by the queues, the cooking must also be excellent!

address: 2 College Ave West #01-07Stephen Riady Centre Singapore 138607 Singapore
comment: Best breakfast I've ever ate. Better than any American cafe I've ever been to; new favorite spot on NUS campus. Can eat anything here, and so inexpensive!

address: 2 College Ave West #01-07Stephen Riady Centre Singapore 138607 Singapore
comment: The waffles are nice so is the tea the macaroni is pretty bad ! The ambience is nice as its inside the NUS premise it's nice to try it rather than go to the usual starbucks cafe

address: 1 Woodlands Square #04-01/04, Causeway Point Singapore 738099 Singapore
comment: Whenever I'm in the vicinity I craved to have a meal here whether it's for lunch or dinner or to takeaway. Good options of rice, roti, naan, and dishes but I always go for their Briyani rice with Tandoori chicken and Assam soup. Sometime with  hot masala tea. All very well cooked and delicious. A good meal in a nice comfortable and clean setting :-)

address: 1 Woodlands Square #04-01/04, Causeway Point Singapore 738099 Singapore
comment: One of my favourite Indian food outlets to enjoy decent Indian cuisine. This outlet is located inside Food Republic at Causeway Point. The good thing is the seats inside is only catered for those eating at this outlet, so even if it's crowded elsewhere, you can find a place or two usually.This is the order-from-counter style so you have to queue up to make your order. What I recommend is the "Nasi Briyani" - choose the popular Indian style rice and you get to choose your vegetable and meat. There are also other side dishes you can choose but do note they are slightly expensive. For example: 80 cents for an egg. If you can't take spice, I recommend the lime juice which goes well with the spiciness. I won't say it's spicy, in fact it's pretty tame compared to others but what I like most is the chicken - how they so it with the sauce and all that. To TOP it up, you will get a rice cracker. For a meal like this, it cost around $10 including a drink. Overall, I enjoy coming here to enjoy decent Indian food. Helps a lot especially when you are hungry! Give this a try if you see this either here or Northpoint.

Nearby the Zoo. Maybe that's the reason why there are so many animal decor. I was greeted by an overhanging T-Rex; that's how hungry you can get right? I initially thought this would've a pretty western styled eatery. This cafe turns out to be a Chinese restaurant serving pretty nice Chinese food fare. There are about 20 plus table of which some are able to seat 12 comfortably. They also have a table that could possible serve 20 pax and features an automatic lazy suzy. I thought something was left over from the Chinese Ghost festival when I saw the table circling on its own at one corner of the room !Overall the dishes were pretty okay. More than edible with some delightful dishes like the cereal prawns, the salted egg yolk crab, the XO drunken Fried Chicken (I'm sure that's the reason why it got fried ). The crabs are priced at S$45 PER CRAB and do ask for the female crabs that has loads of eggs in them! (Yummy!!) and the crabs are pretty big, like those huge Sri Lankan crabby friends. The meat of the Crab I had though was a little on the tough side but was still okay. The food serving was pretty fast.I would come back again some other day when I have to host a dinner with greater than 10 as this place offers the seating arrangements I need.

address: 221B Boon Lay Place Boon Lay Place Food Village #01-96 Singapore 642221 Singapore
comment: I'll be honest. I am a carnivore and I don't like to eat vegetables at all.This however means that I am not left with much choice when I go back to my grandmother's house to eat. You see, she is Hakka, and she eats lei cha almost every day. Lei cha, for the clueless, is a bowl of white rice, 5 different sorts of chopped up vegetables, some dried radish and roasted peanuts, topped off with a bowl of soup which is apparently some sort of tea - hence, the 'cha' in 'lei cha'.My grandmother attributes her old age to this diet. At 96, she is a ferocious character. She is able to hold a cane and chase her great grandchildren around the house, nag at her grandchildren for anything and everything.Her lei cha is the traditional sort, which I have never liked.I must however say that this lei cha here is pretty good! The vegetables are less sparsely salted, they are more generous with the peanuts, and the dried radish sends a piquant kick to the back of your throat. Best of all, the tea (i.e. the soup) is less overpowering than traditional versions.In short, this version is more suitable to the tastebuds of the younger generation. For me, it was the stepping stone to accepting my grandmother's version of lei cha.If it helps kickstart a habit that could help you live until a ripe old age, why not?

address: 221B Boon Lay Place Boon Lay Place Food Village #01-96 Singapore 642221 Singapore
comment: One of the best Hakka Thunder Tea Rice (Lei Cha or Lui Cha) that I have ever eaten in Singapore. Forget about the chains in Food Republic, those are frauds compared to the authenticity of this stall in Boon Lay. They have since started to franchise but this is the original stall. They only open for breakfast and lunch (6am-2pm), a testament to their popularity. Working folks from around the area will drive here just to eat this. The queue can get pretty long but thunder tea rice. It is also healthy, not too oily and their home made tea is just the right flavour. You can choose white rice or wholemeal rice, to have it as a porridge, or have your tea in a separate bowl. Some like to mix it all in while some like to drink it like a soup. If you want to beat the long queue, call in advance to order and go pick it up at the agreed time.

address: 1 Cleantech Loop CleanTech One Western Water Catchment, Singapore Singapore
comment: If you have seen their ad or visited their website, you will be utterly disappointed when visiting their outlet at the Cleantech Park. It really is nothing more than your typical office canteen or the small food court below your HDB. They have great concept to try to get people to take a break from work or be social. However, their food is likely what drives the social aspect because everyone will have something to complain about. The ambiance is reasonable with bright green fake flowers on the table and clean environment. There are plenty of seating area both inside and outside the restaurant. BUT, their food is terrible. They have the typical mixed rice line - one Chinese style and one Indian style. The Indian one is slightly better although at a much higher price ($6 for a plate of chicken briyani). The Chinese one is reasonable but you will often get undercooked rice or very oily stir fry vegetables. They also have very bad meat selections that has more bones than meat in them. They also have a noodle station that alternates between prawn noodle, lor mee, laksa or fish noodle. The lor mee is decent but for $4, it is not worth getting. Next to that is a chicken rice stall with edible chicken or char siew rice. Again, for $4 a plate, they don't give you enough meat and way too much rice that is not sufficiently flavored by Singapore standard.Besides the stalls, they also have daily specials that are made to order. I have yet to try any of it. This place really tries to take advantage of working crowd with no car or are too busy since there is basically nothing else to eat within a 10-15 mins walk vicinity. I would have given it 1 star but considering that I do return to it quite often, and the occasional tasty fried fish from the Indian stall, 2 stars is about as much as I can give it.If you are visiting this area, make sure to get some good food at Pioneer or NTU before coming over here.

address: Blk 505 Jurong West Food Centre #01-40 Singapore 640505 Singapore
comment: Famous for it's smooth, tendered thick and fresh sliced pieces of fish, one could not even resist to order the biggest portion. Sliced Sliced are well handled with every order individually cooked. The tasty soup with fried onion oil, chopped garlic, small dried shrimps fragrance had gained the applause of the neighborhood residents. They had also added the steamboat vegetable "tang o" which blends well with the rest of the combination.Be prepared the raindrops coming down from your head after grabbing these sambal chillis even though the hawker centre is well ventilated and with fans installed and mounted on the pillars. Do get some packets of tissue with you. Tables around the stall are mostly occupied, sitting away from the stall may help. The stretch of stalls where 128 Fish is situated is known for its Bak Kut Teh and Fish/Chicken Porridge, well liked by the neighbourhood therefore seatings around that area may be harder to find.Price is reasonable and quality of food is definitely there.

address: 283 Bukit Batok East Ave 3 #01-285 Singapore 650283 Singapore
comment: Great place for claypot rice. The waiting time is 20 minutes and the good news is that they take advance orders by phone so you can call ahead and when you reach, voila! You can start digging into your piping hot rice. My friend and I shared a pot for two people at only $10. It comes with dark sauce by the side and you decide how much you want to pour before stirring yourself. I would say just a bit would be enough or it might be too salty. Scrumptious, fragrant and generous with ingredients!

address: Jurong Point Shopping Centre #01-31, 63 Jurong West Central 3 Singapore 648331 Singapore
comment: Auntie Anne's signature pretzels paired with cold lemonade are a great snack to have on-the-go, perhaps if you are feeling peckish in the afternoon in between lunch and dinner. Pretzels are prepared fresh at the shop and come in a variety of flavours that you can choose from. The original is close to what you get from the street carts of New York City. I personally prefer savoury food so my top choice is the sour cream and onion, although it isn't the healthiest. Or try the cinnamon sugar one as well, it's quite the delight.

address: Jurong Point Shopping Centre #01-31, 63 Jurong West Central 3 Singapore 648331 Singapore
comment: Auntie Anne's-my instant go-to comfort food. Easy to carry around, and best enjoyed with a glass of ice cold lemonade. A variety of sweet and savory pretzels that you can enjoy with a dip of your choice. They take pride in serving freshly made pretzels-and I take pride on eating them whenever I can. This is one treat I will never scrimp on. Their price is quite affordable and their pretzels are just really delicious with their dips. Sometimes, I pass on the dip and enjoy the pretzel on it's own because it's really flavourful. I did try their sweet variant with coffee, definitely beat the coffee-donut partnership.If you're looking for a pick-me-up or just a simply delicious treat, head over to your Auntie Anne's.

address: Jurong Point Shopping Centre #01-31, 63 Jurong West Central 3 Singapore 648331 Singapore
comment: Pretzels are the perfect all-time snack. They're not that unhealthy and are easy to carry around if you wanna enjoy yours on the go and Auntie Anne's does have a good selection of flavours. Baked fresh daily and the toppings are only added on after you place your orders. I recommend their sour cream and onion flavour.
My wife and I patronise their yong tau foo on a weekly basis. A healthy food choice if you're health conscious.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green 02-14/15, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Food:I tried the brown rice with seared salmon and with an onsen egg added. The salmon piece is  decently sized, and pretty well cooked! There was no fishy taste/smell and the meat wasn't tough, it was enjoyable to eat it. The only disappointing thing was that it could have been bigger, but then again we would always liked 200g steaks for the price of a 100g one right?The brown rice is pretty filling but quite dry. But fret not, because you can add sauces and/or break the egg which would help to moisten the rice, and whoa the rice is now actually quite nice. And again, the only disappointing thing was why couldn't I have more D:They offer a variety of food, but I've only eaten twice, and I chose the same type both time (accidentally). Price:For ~$10 you can get a bowl of their creation (unagi is real expensive though, your bowl can potentially reach $15). And they do spend some effort in their presentation, so for the price, it seems like they ain't overcharging ylj for the initial visual feast. Overall it's quite filling (if you choose brown rice) so it's quite value for money. Location:It's pretty accessible from the MRT. In fact it's one of the first few shops you'll see once you take the escalator from the connector to/from Bouna Vista MRT. Yep, it has "alfresco" (outdoor) seating. Only concern is that they don't accept reservations, but you can take a gamble and come in groups for dinner - sometimes it's quite empty. Just don't come in like groups of 20+.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green 02-14/15, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Thursday JULY 12th 2018Time : 12:08hrs - arrived and made the order.QUEUE Number : 931Ohhh OmoOmoDon..... we travelled far, we ordered, we ate...  They offer Japanese-ish and Korean-ish food, though NOT so authentic in their Menu.Managed to grab a seat outside aka "The Patio".... a little too warm to my liking, but I just go with the flow.  You ordered at the Automated Kiosk, made your payment.  MAKE sure you take and keep your receipt.  Our order indeed took awhile to be ready.  Once your order is ready, since we are seated outside aka the Patio, our QUEUE Number is being "flashed" on the big inverted monitor.  Time was about 12:28hrs ish.Okies for one, please do try your very best NOT to visit this establishment during the PEAK LUNCH hour.  That is what we did.  Well actually I wanted to arrive early before the PEAK HOUR Lunch rush, but my cousin has something on to attend to before our meeting.Anyhoos, in terms of the bowl, or what ever you order... it definitely adds up.  Hence can be EXPENSIVE to some.  In terms of portion size, a little to small for my liking - but I guess that is the "standard" of Singapore portions nowadays.I opt to Build My Own Don, with Korean White Rice ($1), Spicy Octopus ($6.50), Onsen and Tobiko ($2), Takoyaki ($4), with Soft Drink ($1).  My cousin opt to have the Ji-Ji Don ($10), Vegan Tofu $4 and Soft Drink ($1).For Lunch that day, with appertizers aka ala carte sides and drinks it was almost SGD30 aka $30 to boot!  The exact cost was ($29.50).  Flavor wise, OK-lah...  What I had ordered DID NOT blow me away with the flavor let alone, portions are tiny especially the Takoyaki I ordered as a separate dish.The plating or the bowl, they used are huge, but portions given or portions you received, is indeed small.  Maybe for the Lunch crowd who works around this area, is doable.  Though I cannot deny, this establishment is indeed PACKED to the Brim during Lunch Peak hour.At least I have tried, ordered and ate from this establishment.  The ONLY good thing to note, in my books, this establishment is Halal Certified.  Hence this GENEROUS 3 stars review.  Nevertheless, I do hope this Restaurant concept can grow in which they did when I found out they have been opening several locations in other parts of town.For this lunch alone, I was a little hungry after eating, maybe due to the fact what I had was on the smaller size than I am used to.  From my cousin's feedback, her lunch was "SO-SO" aka Semi-OK.I may return perhaps to try other outlets such as the ones at Kallang Wave or Yishun North Point.  Maybe what I ordered from here is an isolated incident.  Perhaps from there, once I try all the locations in town perhaps my review may differ.OmoOmoDonThe Star Vista #02-14/15,Vista Exchange GreenSingapore 138617Tel : 67341863

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green 02-14/15, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: A healthy but flavourful food option at Star Vista. Located near the escalator  adjacent to the east west line at Buona Vista, al fresco and indoor seats are available at this eatery.Automatic stations are available for making orders and payment, I.e. Self-service. You can select from preselected choices or make your own bowls. In the preselected flavours available, you get a staple, a protein, a sauce and a garnish in each dish.I tried yes sir yes sir - teriyaki beef with kimchi omelette and multigrain rice. I could get medium rare steak, it was decent meat but not the freshest. The kimchi omelette is really flavourful but rather spicy. I also tried the tako don - small octopus with kimchi omelette, bibimbap sauce and white rice. The small octopus were very tasty and perfect in shape. Kimchi and the bibimbap sauce was especially spicy in this dish. There are some vegetarian options like vegan prawn and fried mushrooms. You are given a number upon ordering and the number will show up on the screen once your order is ready. However, you might not be able to see the number, depending on where your seat is located. The wait might be long, even when there were only 3 or 4 orders ahead, it took about 10 minutes before my food was ready. I'm glad a new option is available at Star Vista! I will be back and $9.50 for a tasty and healthy meal is a good option.

When I lived over seas in Singapore I visited my local Sky Thai on such a regular basis that when I joined the queue they would already begin making my order for me. They were friendly and the chicken curry with bok choy was my go to! I miss it all the time but this is the place that started my love with curry and all things spicy. I'll be back in a few years :)
Great place for excellent local food at a good price. Very new and very clean.Wet market has a large variety of fresh seafood, fruits and snacks as well.

As of September 2018, with the recent visit, this Market is known as Ghim Moh Road Market and Food Centre.  It is located at 20 Ghim Moh Road, Singapore 270020.I went here with my fellow Singaporean friend, since the Appam vendor is located at this market.  Among other things, I also want to check out another Indian food vendor or stall..  On that faithful Thursday, the Appam vendor known as Heavens is opened.Unfortunately, the other Indian Food vendor known as Mohamed Faisal Seeni Eating House is closed.  **SIGH**  I will return on another day other than Thursday in order to try what Mohamed Faisal Seeni Eating House has to offer.  Coz they offer things like Prata or Biryani in which I do not mind ordering too.For the Muslim patrons, at most there are 5 Muslims vendors which offer Malay or Indian cuisine, at this Ghim Moh Road Market and Food Centre.  Its kind of limited, but I know this Market and Food Centre is NOT known with the Muslim crowd as compared to Geylang Serai or Ayer Rajah Food Centre.Yes like any other markets, usually its very busy. Mostly the locals or those who are working near the vicinity in the mornings and during the Lunch PEAK Hour.  From my observations there are other "famous" food stall or vendors, at this market and food centre coz of the LONG QUEUE Lines.  Unfortunately most are the Chinese Food Vendors.  **DOUBLE SIGH**From Buona Vista MRT Station (EW21/CC22), it is about 10 to 15 minutes walk depending on each individual pace, hence plan accordingly.

Love the $2.50 laksa here, the long queue curry rice, the closed-early duck rice, the long queue but worthwhile beef hor fun, the stingy chai-pok chwee kweh, the freshly-fried chicken cutlet curry rice, the healthy wheat noodles bak chor mee, the atmosphere the heat and warm atmosphere of a market fast diminishing.Sunday mornings are at its most glorious but peak periods.
