If you live nearby, you should cherish this bliss.

It's been about 2 years since I last set foot to this place but I must admit I do miss it. I was looking forward to having some vermicelli noodles from Economical Bee Hoon (yum) but they were closed on sundays. Still I found their competitor and it was still pretty good for about US$2. I then had some homemade soya bean drink with almond essence and it was good for about US$1.80. Just can't beat it...Another morning another visit. Tried the char siew pau and loh mai kai from Keng Kee Dian Xing place. It was good but not impressive 20 years ago. The pau was nice but did not feel hand made. Will try more over the next few days.

VIETNAMESE FOOD ! We love to eat here for authentic VIET home cooking CUISINE Do try CHICKEN PH and BÚN THT NNG , both are our favorites! Love the fish sauce too :)!Open everyday from 10 :00 AM until 9;00 PM.HIGHLY  RECOMMENDED !

Small local hawker's center.Highlights:- Most stalls open even at 10:30 on a weekday - Carrot cake: still like this rice soy combo, 4 stars - Almond tofu: hint of almond in this silly tofu did the trick. 5 starsLowlights:- Duck and cha sui with rice: dry and not much flavor. 2 stars - Didn't have to rojak even though was on the booth sign - Not as much variety as the bigger onesI'd be happy eating at most any Hawker's center in Singapore so I was happy to fit another one in.

Strawberry soursop juice with less ice ($2.50) from Alexandra Village Avocado Juice - 5 stars!Not too sweet - the lady said they don't add sugar and the strawberry juice added was fresh. The strawberry soursop combination was fantastic!Egg cheese appam from Heavens ($3) - 3.5 starsKind of average - the appam wasn't very fluffy or very crispy even though I ate it on the spot.Tom's City ZoomDa baoed the mee pok and the handmade fish noodles. I'm not big on pork and loved that this came with fishcakes and fishballs rather than pork. It was really good. I'll have to try it some time on the spot!

Ghim Moh market is shut down for renovations so they are relocated to a temporary market. I grew up eating the food at Ghim Moh market, so there is definitely a sense of nostalgia here.I love love love the ipoh hor fun, char kueh teow, yong tau foo, carrot cake, and economical bee hoon here! Apparently they have a branch of lao ban soy beancurd here as well. Definitely a food centre worth visiting for breakfast/ lunch!

This place has great food. Period. Amongst the many stalls here, my favorites are the carrot cake, char kway teow, Hakka yong tau foo, kway chap. The prices are cheap compared to many other places. The only thing I would say is that it's packed! Getting a table on the weekends requires you to hunt down someone who looks like they are almost done, then stare them down so they feel uncomfortable and don't linger! The carrot cake is wonderfully fried with crispy egg and soft fluffy carrot cake. The white one is much more popular than the black at this stall. Hakka yong tau foo requires extreme patience. You need to pick your goodies then wait for them to cook your order. At times it can be almost 45mins! Char kway teow also takes some time. The uncle there cooks each plate to order, giving each some tlc. It's got crispy bits of lard, perfectly seasoned with wonderful wok hei. Go try some of the stalls for yourself before they shut down for renovations!

Food market in Western Singapore - lots of food options and popular among locals. Some of the highlights are the hor fun (Singaporean rice noodle in savory sauce) - which has a strong burnt / wok smell, curry rice, and duck rice. In general, would suggest just checking out the stalls with long lines.

Alexandra Village Hawker Centre is what you think of when it comes to local food and dining. Many stalls and vendors to choose from. You can get any of the local favorite and the prices are very reasonable for the quality and quantity you pay for.

My absolute favourite place to go for Hainanese Chicken Rice. The Tong Fong Fatt Hainanese Boneless Chicken Rice stall does it to what I consider, perfection. Great Chicken Rice for a good price. Often times, I pair this meal with Teh Bing (Iced Tea with condensed milk + sugar) from any of the drink stalls in the market. Refreshing and delightful, I enjoy a good mix of sweet & salty between the Chicken Rice and the Teh Bing. Ghim Moh Market is generally a good place for local food and meeting up with friends, family or colleagues for a meal.

The temporary market may not feel as homey as the good ol' days, but the stalls that have chosen to remain still offer the best, cheap local eats among any market in the area. The lines and lunchtime crowds here are for good reason. My favorites -- kway teow, carrot cake, and soy beancurd. But above all, you can never go wrong with a piping hot plate of sliced fish hor fun or duck rice and a cold glass of sugar cane.For drivers, unfortunately, parking charges for the lot behind the temporary market are exorbitant compared to the one across the street.

Quiet quaint but dynamic food centre that will never lose its charms. While the hype of brunches continues around the island, there is nothing more comforting that a plate of cheew kueh (steamed rice cake) with sautéed radish or a plate of rojak or nasi lemak or noodles. The lines are often long enough to make you feel unadulteratedly silly but I assure you it is so worth it. The roasted pork rice is very famous and so is the chai dao kueh (fried radish with eggs). Dessert soups at the corner is nice but prepared to have more than just one. Laksa is also delicious but op for the dry mushroom noodles or porridge if you can. I find the market rather expensive but the food/ingredients are always fresh. Plus it helps to know they get from the suppliers from the wet market and cook the very day.

If you're wondering where the old people in the Holland Village Hawker Centre have disappeared to, you'll most likely find them smiling over Kopi O here.I've known about the existence of this place for years but never brought myself to go here - until my friend suggested heading here for lunch one day (he drove - can't say no to that!). I was vegetarian when I came here so I missed out on the Chwee Kueh, Chicken Rice, Yong Tau Foo... but the vegetarian noodles I had were absolutely delicious! Now that I'm back to meat... I'll be back...

address: 1 Venture Ave #01-13, Big Box Singapore 608521 Singapore
comment: A gem hidden next to Big Box in Jurong East! I wouldn't have known this place existed if not for my friend who brought me there. We went for late lunch on a Sunday and the place was quite empty. My friend said that it's usually crowded at night with people watching football matches. Anyway, the food and service are of good quality. I ordered baked red snapper with potato gratin. The menu price was $22 and there was a 20% discount for ala carte dishes. I was pleasantly surprised that they provide warm bread with olive oil before the main dish.

address: 1 Venture Ave #01-13, Big Box Singapore 608521 Singapore
comment: When you first walk into the place,the ambience gives you that seductive indulging vibe. A great place to spend the family afternoon! As for the good..well it explains itself. The Oven Roasted Pork Knuckle was crispy crackling and moist,the Caviar and Avocado Salad was a whirlwind of flavours and the Ribeye Steak was just out of this world and packs a punch of flavours with its spectrum of spices. Overall the experience was fantastic,the food was enjoyable and price was worth every bite!

First time there. Very friendly people. Seems to know most of the customers.$30 for their "招牌" cod fish steamboat. Soup is better than all other steamboat stalls that I patronized - it was not saltish or laden with MSG. I haven't come across any steamboat stall for years that ask "要不要加汤?". Hope to see more vegetables in the soup on next visit.There are many of the Heng Hua dishes. Yes, I zoomed in on the la-la ($10). Shiok. Wished I could try them all. Kangkong's ($8) cooking is nice but the kangkong itself is not "young" type. The ba-long-long ($2) drink is refreshing.

I only order the negitoro don and satsuma aged cheese (2 times every month)because it's so (consistently) good that I don't want to try anything else . It's fresh and really good quality (I actually wouldn't mind paying more) There is also the lunch set from i think 11-4 which actually makes it even more worth it  because there is soup, appetiser and ice cream.(The whole lunch set is cheaper than the ala carte main course ...they also don't give me less because it's lunch set) The service staff are great and really accommodating

A Japanese Gem in JEMWith the number of food establishments located between the 3 malls in Jurong East, it takes a lot to stand out from the crowd and stand out En Sakaba does. From the outside, the restaurant doesn't look any different from an Ajisan or a "nothing fancy nothing spectacular" Japanese restaurant but a glance at En Sakaba's menu made us change our minds First impressions, reasonable. With an Asari Miso soup going at $3.00 and some of the starters at $5.00, it had to be one of the most reasonable Izakaya restaurants in Singapore. Being a beef and foie gras fan, the wife had to try their Foie Gras Yakiniku Onsen Tamago Don. At $22.00, the Don came with a rice, premium beef tataki, a slice of foie gras and an onsen egg. The rice was well cooked and came in a pretty generous portion. The beef was excellent. Well seasoned and beautifully cooked, the beef was almost melt in your mouth tender. The wife, who's tried other beef tatakis, didn't quite like the rawness, had no issues with the ones here as the quality of the beef, along with seasoning and the sauce helped cut the rawness. Foie gras was good too, rich and well seasoned and with the sauce being slightly sweet, the onsen egg helped cut the sweetness, at the same time, binding and harmonizing the different flavours of the dish together beautifully.  Being a huge sashimi fan, I had to go with the En Kaisen Chirashi Don and what a don it was! At a glance, $28 for a chirashi don may seem steep but the chirashi here was an indulgent. It came with 15.....yes... FIFTEEN different piece of sashimi and was served on their speciality pink rice (rice... the rice was pink). I did initially feel that the rice was on the gimmicky side but turns out, it was pretty darn good! The sashimi was fresh and they were very generous with the tobiko, ikura and caviar. This indulging bowl came with: Zawai kani (crab claw), Uni, Caviar, Tobiko, Ikura, Negitoro, Maguro, Salmon, Aburi Salmon, Hotate, Unagi, Anago, Aka Ebi, Hamachi and Tamago Yaki. Monkfish Liver Tofu is something you don't always see and it was delicious! There's a slight hint of the liver taste but the monkfish liver was firm yet very smooth and the ikura and caviar not only added the saltiness to the dish while the uni added a whole new dimension and elevating the flavours of the tofu, offering a rich umami flavour. Zuwai Kani Miso Kourayaki.A very rich and very wholesome dish. Crab meat and guts (it's better than it sounds) grilled in the shell and topped with ikura and a quail egg, the perfect combination of rich, pungent, sweet and salty. For those who enjoy picking the inside of the crab head, this dish is perfect. The richness of the gut complimented the sweetness of the crab beautiful while the ikura offered the saltiness and the quail egg brought the dish together. One of the most unique but delicious dishes I've ever had. Overall the food here is very good. Service though leaves much to be desired. They can be a little slow and often not sure what some of the items on their own menu are but, that aside, this is definitely a must visit place. Service may be average but the food more than makes up for it!

En Sakaba is a new shop front housed in JEM in recent months when the mall had expended more into their F&B. En Sakaba is located at the 1st floor, taking over MADO Cafe, just right beside Marche.Miso soup is never boring if you order Kani (Crab) Miso Shiru. The usual Soy Bean Paste soup is coupled with little tofu cubes and Queen crab, delighting your taste buds.Kani Miso Shiru - $5If you love Japanese rolled omelette, there is no reason why you won't fall for this! These 4 pieces of rolled omelette were prepared well with yellow consistency in colors and if you draw your eyes nearer to the food, you will see the uniform thickness of its layer, making up this yummy food. What's more, feel the cool temperature of these chilled Tamago, they will never go wrong dabbing with the seaweed sauce. Recommended!Isobe Tamago Yaki - $5 (4 pcs)Another recommended item on the menu that worth your calories would be these grilled braised black pork cheek on the rice served with Onsen egg. Basically, seasonings in the bowl played a good importance here. Food may not be fanciful as it seems, but the harmony of sweet grilled sauce and tender Kurobuta (Black Pork) was perfectKurobuta Niku No Hono Don - $18Initially, I was quite disappointed as we did not order the recommended side, Beef Truffle Carpaccio, Nonetheless, I did also order a recommended Choice of the Foie Gras & Yakiniku. A strong wave of truffle hit me as the bowl was placed on my table. Just can't describe further how it kind of "lure" me into them but the egg was runny, cooler than other food items in the bowl. The thinly sliced premium beef was served using tataki method, where the meat were seared over hot flame and marinated well in its seasoning like soy sauce. The initial sight of it may be a turn off for someone who only takes medium well done beef like me but its really worth the try!Foie Gras Yakiniku Onsen Tamago Don - $22Menu is quite limited for its dishes but if you are there for Sake, their sake menu is considered extensive and this place can be a heaven. Anyway, being bored by those mainstream Japanese food in the malls, it was a good visit to En Sakaba, however as of now, I have not seen any noodle dishes on the menu yet.

The row of eateries along Clementi Road is the common meet up place among the NUS students who are studying nearby and also used to be one of my hang outs for Cheese Prata. Just today when we were there for our lunch we realize that Formosa Delights do have a shop space just beside the popular chain Wanton Mee, Fei Fei.I know of Formosa Delights through their outlet in West Coast Plaza for their handmade noodle but unfortunately they had shut down their premises about a year ago and we were quite disappointed to lose a lunch alternative during then.The interior over here looked rather upscale with bars available. Interior was air-conditioned as compared to the neighboring eateries and with a disco kind of ambiance.There was another menu which serves promotional dishes especially for Rush Hour Special apart from the usual menu.Even though we ordered sides, the main courses came first and this portion of Handmade Noodle in Taiwanese Stir Fried Sauce was big even though we had it at discounted rate (usual price $7.90). The bowl was filled with handful of noodle covered by minced meat with mixed vegetables and little toufu cubes as well as shredded cucumbers by the side.Handmade Noodle in Taiwanese Stir Fried Sauce - $6.90Similar to the former dish, Traditional Braised Meat Noodle cost $7.90 at its usual pricing. Ingredients serving of braised meat was unexpectedly huge and on a oily side. However the taste was good with a thoroughly braised hard boiled egg and preserved vegetables.Traditional Braised Meat Noodle - $6.90Since I first known Formosa for its handmade noodle, I'm tempted to have this finest handmade noodle on their menu with a choice of thick or thin noodle. The entire portion was quite big for a pax with 3 prawns, 2 delicious meat balls, mocked abalone pieces, vegetables and mushrooms. The broth of the noodle was definitely a good one, going well with the chinese parsley which elevates the dish. A thoughtful gesture seen was that these parsley was served separately from the dish and diner may choose to add or skip them.Formosa Finest Handmade Noodle - $12.40Though it was not the best  Taiwanese Fried Rice I ever had, the quality was there. Rice grains were relatively short and plum. Eggs and vegetables were the only main ingredients here. Even without the use of meat the dish was fragrant and scrumptious, most importantly, not greasy. Recommended.Vegetarian Fried Rice - $7.90The layers of the crepe was not very even and you can feel as if you are still biting on the dough. Also, there was not much taste of green onion even though hints of green onion can be seen on its top layer.Taiwan Green Onion Crepe  Handmade Dumpling was paired with ginger strips and vinegar. Elongated and with a thin layer of dumpling skin, the fillings were made up of fine minced meat but was not to my liking.Pan Fried Handmade Dumpling - $6.40Don't judge the book by its cover. These little white baos may look unappetizing and boring without its usual pleats and guidelines, the taste of them were simply above an average fare. Trust me.Xiao Long Bao - $5.90The overall menu seems to differ from the Formosa Delights we used to have and had kind of enlightened us. Food that we ordered were generous in portion, however on the greasy side.

The staff was quite friendly, but has some difficulty communicating clearly in English. And started preparing the food before we could confirm and pay for items picked. Very average taste, quite pricey for the taste and ambience. One time try.

We have always passed by this eatery that is located up on the hill but had never been there. Previously before the vegetarian took over, I remembered it was a Cze Char place and till one day it was never there, we still yet to visit the place. However thanks to the Vegetarian colleague who gets hook to the Mala there and thus giving me a chance to visit this place.The place looks modern than I have expected. The place was neatly furnished with round tables and since it is on top of a hill, its rather airy.Besides having Mala Pot, there are other varieties of food available like claypot rice and steam boat.It was my first time having vegetarian Mala, the items displayed may seems ordinary but overall, the Mala Pot depends on the spicy blend we had.Unlike for Yong Tou Foo, for Mala, everything goes by weight. The heavier it gets, the more you have to pay for it. Selection here includes mushroom, black fungus, Tofu, Brocolli , Cauliflower, Button Mushroom, Mock Meat Balls, Crab Meat and others.Interior was pretty simple and plain, without fanciful decorations which kind of illustrate the nature environment.There are a plenty of seating to choose, from inside the shop, to dinning on the wooden planks and the concrete. It was kind of laid back to dine in "nature".I'm not very use to dining on top of wooden planks as it is kind of disturbing when someone walks pass with all the squeaking noises produced by the planks. Luckily the place was not too crowded on a week day and there was not much customers sitting closer to our tables.Before having the spicy food, we had prepared ourselves with some icy cooling drinks.Finally our Mala Xiang Guo is ready to served with rice. There is a choice of white or brown rice and the spicy level. Chilli, together with roasted peanuts, pepper corns and coriander enhance the taste. However if you are talking about numbness in the dish, I would say its still within our capacity.The healthier choice of having brown rice. Luckily it was well cooked and hardness was medium without being too grainy.Having the fried mushroom as sides was in fact a very good choice. The batter coated over the mushroom was thin and crispy and the bite into the soft mushroom was heavenly. The taste of these were enhanced by the paprika powder.  Addictive!With the friendly service and variety of food, it is most likely I will be back again for other kinds of vegetarian selection.

Parking: Yes, small lot.The restaurant is in the corner, it's a completely vegetarian restaurant. They have options of laksa, sichuan noodles, mala hot pots, etc. I got the vegetarian laksa, it came in a clay pot. My other friends ordered a huge dish of the mala hotpot - basically stir fried sichuan vegetables. For the hotpot, you basically pick out the vegetables you like in a bowl and hand it over to the chef, they will weigh it and stir fry whatever you pick out. The food here was REALLY good, the laksa was very rich in flavor. The mala hotpot was very hot, so make sure you get mild if you cannot handle heat. I would highly recommend this place, the owner Agnes was very kind. She invited us back the following weekend for their 1 year anniversary. This restaurant also does parties and buffets.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: The XO doesn't stand for XO sauce but XO cognac. With each inhale of soup, you will experience not only the heat of the soup, but also the alcohol. The cognac flavor can't be missed and dare I say I felt lightly buzzed afterwards. Authentic XO milky fish soup located in front of an HDB complex, this stall is filled with locals. The soup is sold by the person, and it's currently $6 for one person and $10 for two (bigger bowl). I got lots of fish meat in my individual bowl; must have been at least 5-6 chunks, which was quite worth it. There was also some token cabbage, but the highlight was the fish and the soup. Don't expect too much from the service -- the uncle doesn't speak much english, but you won't be disappointed by the food. They take orders at a table in front of a coffee shop, and the menu is almost entirely in Chinese. Usually one of the aunties will step in to help if there are communication issues, so just order swiftly and be on your way.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: Poor service and the packing fee is very expensive. 2 S$ for one normal take-out box. Incredible. Never come again.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: If you can put up with crappy attitude in search of good food, then this stall is ok with you. Male boss usually takes orders and collects money from a table at the front of the Coffeeshop. When ordering, he makes you feel like he's doing you a favour by taking your orders. Oh well. I put up with his unsmiling face to enjoy a big bowl of yummy fish meat Beehoon soup. The soup is milky and tasty, with strong hints of cooking wine and the fish chunks are fresh too. Yes, I will return to endure fowl face for good food.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: Their menu is Chinese only, so if you are not a Chinese speaker you have hard time ordering food here. They give you a lot of fish in the soup so quite authentic. The soup is milky but I found it a bit weird that they also put XO alcohol inside. I've tried fish soup noodle in San Francisco Chinese restaurant before but I like the one there better.  $6 you get a normal bowl and $7 dollar add some extra crab sauce or something. I especially like the Chili that came with the soup, it was a good kick in flavour add on. The environment though was quite poor and dirty, but the fan was big enough so you don't feel sweaty. This place is behind Dover Parkview at common wealth.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: Love the xo fish soup. And the prawn paste chicken is also a must order. Been visiting this place more than 10 times and food is still as good. Highly  recommend to all

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: Update: it's open for lunch as well. Expect to have to wait around for seats during peak hours. $6 for the fish head and it's still good!

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: Formerly located at Blk 46 Holland Drive, they have since relocated to block 19A Dover Crescent. The only thing that did not change is the surly service.This place is famous for three main dishes. "San lao hor fun" (stir fried rice noodles and fish slices), XO bee hoon (fish slices and rice noodles in soup laced with Cognac), and "har cheong gai" (fried chicken with shrimp paste).The soup version of the rice noodle dish comes in a broth that is thick and fragrant, and their version of the fried chicken is rather crunchy and very tasty. (The fried chicken with shrimp paste is a bit of an acquired taste if you have not had it before). It is $1 less if you decide not to have alcohol added to your soup. However, I notice that the soup does not taste as good as before when it was at the old location. I used to be a frequent visitor to the old location at Holland Drive.Price is reasonable, but it's a typical coffeeshop in Singapore which means no AC and brusque service. There's a huge lunch crowd but that means freshly prepared dishes and better food. The number of people there for dinner is significantly less. There's a parking deck behind the coffeeshop, which makes it convenient if you drive. There are plenty of lots on the upper levels.Not as good as it used to be, but still a top choice if you happen to be in the area.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: Food is still not bad, however standards and portions are dropping. Service is still a tad unfriendly (ok maybe that's an understatement), but I'll be honest, I'd still eat there because I really like XO Fish Bee Hun Soup if I was around the area.It's not more somewhere I'll travel for just to eat anymore if im not around the place.The soup is tasty with XO (but little) and the prawn paste chicken is not too shabby either.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: There's nothing to complain about here. Okay, maybe the service is slightly erratic. You might get an angsty Uncle sometimes. Other times, you'll get an extremely friendly one who is super restaurant-proud. BUT the food is exactly how our hungry minds imagine it to be. It never disappoints. And it's affordable. We always overorder and yet the bill is relatively tiny. The last time we went, we ordered fish slice bee hoon soup, fish slice hor fun, ngor hiang, prawn paste chicken and one veg for four of us. All for about 50 bucks and it was way too much food! If not for the sake of variety and the less accessible location, I'd even bring every visiting friend from overseas there! It's a great experience given its at an HDB kopitiam.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: Disappointment. The standard of the well known xo been hoon and hor fan have dipped south. Even the prawn paste fried chicken wasn't as for good. The only palatable one was the HK kai-lan, though it was on the salty side. I doubt I'll return again.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: There's nothing to complain about here. Okay, maybe the service is slightly erratic. You might get an angsty Uncle sometimes. Other times, you'll get an extremely friendly one who is super restaurant-proud. BUT the food is exactly how our hungry minds imagine it to be. It never disappoints. And it's affordable. We always overorder and yet the bill is relatively tiny. The last time we went, we ordered fish slice bee hoon soup, fish slice hor fun, ngor hiang, prawn paste chicken and one veg for four of us. All for about 50 bucks and it was way too much food! If not for the sake of variety and the less accessible location, I'd even bring every visiting friend from overseas there! It's a great experience given its at an HDB kopitiam.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: Singaporeans do eat out quite a bit and folks rarely bat an eyelid for meals costing $30 and upwards at restaurants...but why pay $30 when you can have a bowl of absolutely scrumptious XO fish bee hoon for 6 bucks??! It's so so good... They're really generous with their chunks of sliced fish and it's definitely fresh and firm and they don't scrimp on the XO either!

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: Finding great fish soup means finding great broth for me since 80% of the taste is in the broth, imho. This place has such creamy and tasty xo broth combined with big chunks of fish head that will leave a heap of bones on the table after you finish the whole huge bowl (which I can barely finish). Add the prawn paste chicken wing to your order and you won't feel the pain of travelling all the way here just to get a bowl of great fish soup - after all, you'll be most likely to take a long lunch to eat a fish soup anyway, unless you want to get choked on the bones.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: This is a MUST-STOP for me when i visit Singapore for 1 thing: Shrimp-paste Fried Chicken. It's the BEST fried Chicken i've ever had, bar none. Forget the fried chicken of the South (US), forget Korean Fried Chicken. This shrimp-paste chicken is juicy, flavorful, crispy and amazing. My sister's mouth literally Waters when we talk about this eatery. It's almost comicalEverything else here is good too:- XO Fish head bee hon ( i personally don't eat cooked fish but the noodles + broth is awesome)- Ngoh Hiang: crispy and delicious- Cereal Prawns: yummyDon't get put off by the owner's grumpiness; he's actually super nice. he just doesn't suffer fools gladly. So don't be a foolHIGHLY recommended

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: Food is still not bad, however standards and portions are dropping. Service is still a tad unfriendly (ok maybe that's an understatement), but I'll be honest, I'd still eat there because I really like XO Fish Bee Hun Soup if I was around the area.It's not more somewhere I'll travel for just to eat anymore if im not around the place.The soup is tasty with XO (but little) and the prawn paste chicken is not too shabby either.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: Definitely one of the best, if not the best XO bee hoon in Singapore. You can actually taste the XO properly. The soup is lemak and fragrant, the fish slices super thick, the bee hoon soft but not soggy. The San Lao Hor Fun and Prawn Paste Chicken are famous too so it's good to go in a big group so you can try a bit of everything. The Prawn Paste Chicken, in particular, is quite unique as it has a crispy batter that has the distinctive flavour of hei bi. Parking is pretty convenient, there's a multi-storey carpark right next to the coffeeshop the stall is located in.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: It's ridiculous how much I love this dish for its indulgence. The inclusion of XO into typically milky-to-taste fish beehoon gives a dimension to it and pairs perfectly with the sharpness of ginger in the soup. So good!But what I really like is the Ipoh Fried Hor Fun and Prawn Paste Chicken that you'll find on the tables of everyone having the XO bee hun. The Ipoh Fried Hor Fun is stir-fried with loads of beansprouts, fresh fish slices and soft kway teow (rice noodles). So good and so fragrant. The Prawn Paste Chicken is a pretty acquired thing for some because of the "Hei Bi" (dried prawn) taste. Acquired in the way much like Smelly Tofu is acquired. The version here is good, I like that it is not artificially red and has the aroma of the dried prawn in every crispy bite.

rest_name: Holland Village XO Fish Head Bee Hun Restaurant
comment: This has to be my favorite fish slice bee hoon in Singapore! I love this to bits, really.Although the boss is kind of infamous for being a bit snobbish and 'attitude', it really didn't bother me much because the food is too good to miss out! I like how the fish is so fresh and nice, and the soup is sweet and rich in flavor (from both the milk and the xo). The wait can be a little long when it gets crowded, but trust me it's really going to be worth the wait because you would want your food to be served hot! Other than their xo fish slice bee hoon, their sum lo hor fun and prawn paste chicken is also worth a try. Last but no least just a tip, it is more value for money if you order individual bowls instead of a big bowl for sharing (because there's more soup and more fish slice!).

Open only at night,628 Seafood offers inexpensive but good "tze char" food. The food usually takes a while due to the long list of orders (waiting time is about 15-20mins on average). If you're staying nearby and want to do takeaway, calling beforehand to place your order is advised. Try the sambal fried rice and the black pepper dishes. I haven't tried the fish dishes but I've seen plenty of families digging into fish with dishes by the side to share, so I reckon it should be pretty good.

Great family restaurant with classic Peranakan dishes at an affordable price. Came here with a Singaporean friend - she went to high school around here and would frequent the restaurant back in the day. We ordered the ayam rendang, honey pork, and some vegetable I didn't remember. The ayam rendang was delicious; the honey pork was good but not generally my style (not a big fan of pork strips). It also tried bandong (with chin chow) for the first time and it also wasn't my favorite. Finished with a buboh cha cha which was high in ice content and low in starchy tuber variety but it hit the spot and I guess you can't expect that much for $1.40. The restaurant also sells kueh to go, so I picked up a kueh lapis which I remember being yummy.

Like a cosy family restaurant in a GCB enclave, this place serves its place as a F&B in the area really well. It is also surprisingly unbelievably affordable for a nyonya restaurant in this neighbourhood as well. Ordered a Ayam Buah Keluak which is chicken with the beluak nut in a rich tamarind gravy. It is a stunning winner and for this dish alone, I will come here again!The red snapper in spicy tamarind gravy and curry is also rich and very nyonya in flavour. The chap chye (mixed vegetables) is good enough but nothing to shout out about. This place is superb! Gotta come here especially if you have time out for a weekday lunch when its not so crowded.

Great Peranakan restaurant, full only with locals and expats that love the Peranakan cuisine. There were 6 of us so we sampled several dishes, all delicious and full of flavour, The price is quite low, as you would expect from an establishment such as this one, service is not that great but the place was literally stormed and waiting is quite normal apparently. Certainly recommended if you are into new experiences or you love local Peranakan food.

WOW. The food here is absolutely delicious! The caveat is that it's like a tapas place and every dish is kinda small, so it can get expensive fast. We tried a little bit of everything: beef rendang, fish curry, the signature chicken curry, some veggies, honey fried pork, etc. All really tasty; I'd totally come back here if it wasn't so far out of the way of downtown Singapore. Definitely worth checking out!

Being a Peranankan myself, I have refrained from dining at Peranankan restaurants as the food is never always as good as the those whipped up by my Grandma and Mum.I was skeptical when my partner suggested we had dinner here but... I was amazed at the quality of the food.What we ordered:1. Ayam Tempra - Not bad but the portion is a tad small. Chicken is succulent and tasty.2. Bakwan Kepiting - Meatballs are soft and soup is tasty. Not enough for 6 adults unless you cut the meatballs in half and share.3. Sayur Lodeh - My favourite dish of all. Standard was up to par.4. Babi Pongteh - Portion is the smallest of all with about 5 big pieces of meat and we had to share. However, the gravy is delicious enough to make up for the lack in portion.5. Udang Assam Goreng - I didn't try this dish as I do not eat seafood but my dinner companions said it was good so I'll take their word for it.6. Honey Pork - Very minute pieces of fried pork in very dark sauce that looks black. Doesn't look appealing but it fared 'ok' in taste.7. Fuyong Egg - The usual egg, scrambled and fried with bean sprouts and peas. Nothing can go wrong here.8. Sayur Lemak - Vegetables were not soft enough, coconut gravy was too diluted and the sweet potatoes gave the appearance of being too hard on first prod with a fork but was soft enough to chew.9. Hee Piow Soup - Soup was delicious and fish balls were soft. Will order this again.10. Nasi Kuning x 6 - Very fragrant rice!11. Dessert: Chendol, Gula Melaka Sago - Skip the dessert if you can as there is nothing to shout about. Very small portion. Chendol was too sweet while the Gula Melaka Sago has too much ice. Wanted to order Bubur Trigur but it was sold out. Since it was sold out, it probably means that it's good!Nothing to complain except that the portion is small and is a good trait of theirs if you'd like to order more dishes to taste and share. Price-wise, it cost an average of S$4++ per dish.In total, we paid S$63 for 6 adults and 1 child and is considered quite affordable!Will dine here again but probably at the Heartland Mall branch. If you are dining at the Bukit Timah branch, suggest to make a reservation beforehand as it gets pretty packed, especially on weekends and on public holidays.p.s. I was too hungry and only realized that I didn't take any pictures until the meal was over!

If you have friend's from out of town who are slightly on a budget , Ivin's is a great place to bring them to - everyone I've brought here has loved it - there are dishes to suit everyone, although options -may- be slightly limited for vegetarians (I realised this a little too late as someone in my party was vegetarian... I forgot, brought them here and we ended up ordering every single veggie dish we could find on the menu, which isn't much... oops).Anyway apart from that, this is what I always order at Ivin's:- Honey Pork (!!!)- Ayam buah keluak- Tahu Goreng - Gado gado - Beef rendang - The fried fish promfet - Nasi kuningOrder those dises above and you can't go wrong. Everything is quite cheap, below $10 except for the fish , which costs around $15. The desserts are cheap. The cold bo bo char char is damn disappointing cos they give it to you warm with a heap of ice that melts immediately, leaving you with a luke warm mess.The homemade iced-lemon tea is also pretty good!Cons: Smelly and crowded so service can be quite slow

Situated in a quiet neighborhood, prices were pretty reasonable for the portion served. The restaurant environment was spacious and quiet and is a extremely good place for gatherings and catch ups. Would visit again!

I hear this place is pretty much an institution, and when you step in, you'll know why... you see nonya aunties eating here. And they're dressed in their kebayas. Do you need more validation?There's so much to pick from, they've gone ahead and printed their menu on your placemat, and with the font size, you soon realise that there's a lot of a menu to navigate through, and you'll feel like you want to try all of it. I know, that's a lot of ANDs.You'll read al the other reviews for their selections, but I suggest just one thing. Try the sambal petai with prawns. I'd never liked petai before, and I may never eat it anywhere else, but here, and with that sambal? I'll get it every time.It stays at three stars because I'm not sure about the price to food ratio... but others love it, so come and try it out anyway.

Best value proposition in town.  Super tasty.  Dishes can be on the small side. Tough to find parking during peak hours.  MTR station just opened a block away however. Order : honey pork, chai poh omelette, sambal kangkong and otah.

It is difficult not to like Ivins- absolutely satisfying food, great service, spacious restaurant. I've never been properly introduced to peranakan food until I have been to Ivins, because the low prices make it absolutely possible to order more than what I usually would. I especially love the beef rendang- the beef is melt-in-your-mouth delicious, the sauce is not too thick but packed with all the spices, and the portion is just right so you dont feel too gelat after just one dish. The egg omelette is also pretty popular especially with my two nephews, and its not hard to see why. Not only is the egg fluffy, they are also extremely generous with the ingredients (chai po etc). Another classic would be the honey pork, which consists of small thin chunks of pork carefully marinated with honey and cooked in dark sauce (even though I've always been puzzle why they serve it with boiled green peas because no one seems to eat them!). On days when I crave for something light, I always go for the chicken macaroni which is simply macaroni cooked in clear soup. I also have a super sweet tooth, so I never give the desserts a miss no matter how full I am for lunch. My favourite has to be the bo bo cha cha- the yam is cooked to perfection (crumbles when eaten but firm upon serving), the starchy balls give great texture to dish, and the milk is light and creamy. Their tau suan is also especially well done, not too sweet with just the right amount of starch. A caveat is that the place is not especially well ventilated, so for the office workers who want to avoid smelling like food for the rest of the day, it would be best to visit for dinner.

I got introduced to Ivin's a couple of years back by my peranakan friend who has a bad habit of dismissing anything that doesn't come from her grandmother's wok. So when she grudgingly rated Ivin's as the place to have decent pernakan food at extremely affordable prices, I knew I had to give it a shot.Since then, I have returned to the restaurant many, many time and I always end up over-ordering because I can never make up my mind about what I want. A must-try is the ayam buah keluak - a dish that is so damn good with rice but an absolute nightmare to cook. If you don't know why, go google the recipe. Other than that, the sambal that comes with the lady's finger dish is extremely tasty without being overly spicy. One last dish that you should order is the sotong/fish hitam - chopped onions along with sliced green and red chilli are lightly fried in delicious dark sauce before being slathered on seafood. A great place for a pleasant surprise in terms of food and price. Thumbs up!

Not having been here in a long while, we were pleasantly surprised that the reasonable prices had not changed. The food was also good and well reflected in the long lines waiting to be seated on a weekend evening. They could certainly do with more staff though as it seemed like there were only 1-2 persons taking orders, serving and checking out customers all at the same time.

I recommend coming here with a huge group of people because each individual dish is ridiculously small, but the delight comes when you're able to get a taste of multiple items at a great price (think what happens with dim sum, the more the merrier and things doesn't quite work as well with small groups). Now I don't know my Peranakan food at all, so unfortunately I can't tell you what I ate (other than the ayam fish head and mince meatball soup which were divine), but what I can tell you is that every dish was awesome. We ended up paying $12 per person for more than 10 dishes to share and each of us ordered our own dessert.
Good food. Very tasty. Prices are very affordable. Pork rib was superb. Quantities are small and service is slow. Anyhow, for price you pay it is highly recommended. I will go again & again.

Wow where do I even start? Our family has been going to Ivins for as long as I can remember, and it's one of the best and most affordable places for Peranakan food outside of Mum and Grandma's kitchen.Food : I come here solely for the pong tau hu ... the broth is out of this world as are the pork-tauhu-prawn meatballs. Perfectly proportioned with excellent texture ... gotta love it! One of my chief comfort food dishes. We also really like the ayam curry ... I much prefer my curry chicken Nyonya-style than any other style as the complexity of the spices and herbs used really come through. Love the egg fuyong as well ... not really an authentic Peranakan dish ... I always thought of it as more of a Cantonese dish as we always used to see it on the cold dish platter at Chinese wedding banquets. Parents love the sting ray but we all feel the babi pongteh was a bit too lean. We quite like the sambal udang as well. The honey pork was really crisp and addictive and I quite like the ayam buah keluak as well ... half the fun is digging out the paste in the buah keluak, mixing with the rice and ayam and exclaiming "sedap"! Chendol and gula melaka sago could be better if they crushed the ice to a finer texture.Ambience : Simple family friendly bustling atmosphere.Service : Efficient and no frills. Very good food especially for the prices and the amount of work one would have to put in if cooking even one of those dishes at home. I highly recommend it! Might be a bit hard to find parking so either go early or very late.

As Singaporeans we all love home-style cooking and one such great place to find great home-style food is at Ivins. Although predominantly Peranakan, the food is similar to what we eat at home on a daily basis. Best of all, this home style restaurant is reasonably priced hence the immense crowd as well. Local favorites include Fish Head Curry, Sweet Pork with Peas, Mince Meatball soup , Sambal Kangkong and many more. I can't pick personal favorites here as every individual dish is wonderful so I recommend going in a group of 3 or more so you can share an array of dishes and truly experience the exciting flavours Peranakan cuisine has to offer. Despite the crowd, food does come quick which is a huge plus!

I love this place! Had a great meal with 3 other friends. I do think it is better if you go in a group. if only 1-2 pax the portion is too big... Maybe can try the ala-carte then.The food is yummy  ( we ordered the baby octopus andpork belly with a free topping of rice cake, bingsu comes free as well with the set.) and the price is very reasonable. The server knows what she is selling and gave us good recommendations. Will definitely go again!

Super excited to have a more budget friendly Korean restaurant to go to at Star Vista.i think because it's so new to the mall and hidden in a corner, it was not crowded at all on a Friday evening. there were 5 of us so we ordered 2 main dishes (min 2 servings required for each main dish) - Zzu Sam and Hot Dak. these main dishes came with a serving each of steamed egg and it was a great appetizer to have on a rainy day. they came bubbling and steaming hot so be careful not to burn yourself. my favourite of the two was Zzu Sam - small octopus with pork belly. we also ordered additional sides of mozzarella cheese, rice cake and instant noodle to be cooked together. the frying action was all done on the table before your eyes; think Yooganae. the pork belly was juicy thick and the octopus were fresh and chewy. totally love this dish! sure wish i can bring my own packet of mozzarella cheese because what they served ($3.90 per portion) was not enough for me. the Hot Dak wasn't bad in any way, just that i like octopus better than chicken. the chicken pieces were juicy and tender so if you are a chicken fan, you're in for some yumminess. the staff were friendly, responsive and attentive. i do have to point out that it's a shame that one of the servers didn't know the technique to serving beer out of the bottle. i feel bad for the folks who had to gush down foam before getting to the half filled glass of beer. i didn't have any alcohol but a citron smoothie - it was refreshing and great with my meal. a friend who ordered strawberry smoothie said hers was a tad too sweet. currently Chi-bing is having a promotion. You just have to tag them on facebook or instagram to get a free portion of fried rice for whatever main dish you order.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-24 The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Beauty in The Pot is one of my favourite hot pot restaurant. This is the fifth and newest outlet in the west at Star Vista. I especially love the signature beauty collagen broth and I would suggest everyone to order that on their first visit. As part of the opening promotion, the Star Vista outlet is offering a new shrimp both for the month of July 2019. If you enjoy the ramen soup at their sister company, Le Shrimp Ramen, then you would love the new shrimp both too.Excellent service by all staff and extremely fresh ingredients for the hot pot. Highly recommended.

This restaurant is actually part of the Night Safari, the place where you fill up on food before joining the hideously long line to jump on the tram. I came here because my tour group had booked up some of the tables for us, and also because it is a buffet restaurant (which seems to be common with tours - you can tell I haven't been on many). The food is all Chinese, which is sort of odd because the name is African. Also they didn't have chop-sticks, though they do sell reasonably priced drinks, including Singapore Slings that don't break the bank.

Was seeking out places to eat vegetarian food when I heard about this online. Apparently this is one of the outlets of this chain. This is my first time eating here so here's my review:Food:My friends and I ordered the hot plate brinjal, herbal mushroom and "three cups tofu". I usually hear of "three cups chicken" (三杯鸡) but never heard of tofu, hence that piqued my interest. Food arrived quite quickly, and the dishes were surprisingly good. The hot plate brinjal came wrapped in aluminium foil, the herbal mushroom came as a soup and the tofu came as stir fried (you can see my picture). They were flavourful, and pretty well cooked. The brinjal wasn't cooked too much till it's pulpy, and the tofu still had a spring to it. However, the tofu isn't the standard tofu u get on the market - it's some processed tofu with extra ingredients inside (I wanted to see how the plain tofu could be cooked with 三杯). In addition, I think we were having a relatively drier batch of rice (lucky there was soup and gravy from the food) The soup was actually relatively thick compared to most soups outside, however some of the herbs were evidently not boiled long enough (it's one of the roots, I forgot what it's called). Oh, and I ordered the homemade barley drink, and it's good! Thick and good. You should really try it. Ambience:Tucked away in a quiet neighbourhood in Jurong West, this shop is surprisingly accessible to the bus stop (that's if you know how to walk there). Just cross 1, 2 blocks and you've reached either place - and buses 99 (to Clementi) and 187 (to Woodlands) both reach the place. I went on a Wednesday night and the place was still relatively crowded, definitely showing how popular this place is. Nevertheless, we reached at about 7pm and could still comfortably get seats for 4 of us. There's a slightly hipster feel, and the place seems to be run by young people. Definitely a decent place yo chitchat after a day at work (provided you ain't exhausted from work) Overall rating:Food was decent, though I wouldn't say very impressive. Place is good and conducive to eat and talk at. Pricing can reach more than $10 (but below $20) per person to be decently full. I would definitely come again to try the other menu items, and then I'll reflect my review accordingly.

address: 1 Jurong West Central 2, #03-34 Jurong Point Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: With Fish and Co., it's best to go old school with Fish and Chips. Enjoy a delicious plate of deep fried battered dory fish and hugely cut fries with sauce that you can keep on coming.There will be times that we go old school and this is the place with their Fish and Chips. Sometimes, we order a salad to add some leafy balance to the meal. But trust me, a plate of fish and chips is definitely filling with all that protein and carbs. I also love how comfortable I am whenever I dine there-enough space for me to enjoy my food without worrying that I'l bump my knee under the table or kick the one in front of me. It is priced affordable with a hint of pricey-ness.Definitely best enjoyed with family or friends. Come to think of it, would you rather enjoy that feast all to yourself?

address: 1 Jurong West Central 2, #03-34 Jurong Point Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: Fish and Co is no doubt my favorite hangout in the west when it comes to having a good plate of fish and chips with friends in a comfortable setting.The menu shows 2 pages of fish and chips with many different styles; the difference probably lies in the types of sauce or toppings. I ordered the American style fish and chips, which came with some sort of cheese toppings. The one thing that I really like about fish and co is that the quality is very consistent; I don't recall having a single bad plate of fish and chips ever. The servings are always big and the fries are always crispy and satisfying. The only thing is that the price seems to have gone up a little, but other than that, this particular outlet remains my favorite for its location, atmosphere and consistently good food at reasonable prices.

address: 1 Jurong West Central 2, #03-34 Jurong Point Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: I've really only ever eaten two things here: the fish and chips (ask for more sauce!) and their seafood platter. OMNOMNOM I really like the seafood platter because I like variety--you get prawns, calamari (fried or grilled--I like grilled), fish and rice or fries. Unless you're super hungry, a platter for one can comfortably feed two, and so on, so it is great food for sharing. Their desserts look good too, though with such doorstop sized cheesecakes I am intimidated!

address: 1 Jurong West Central 2 #B1-62-63 Jurong Point Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: I visited this restaurant and was somewhat disappointed with the quality of the food here, and the service was only so-so as well.First of all, we had the baked potato with corn beef and cheese, which was just okay actually.Next, we had the seafood platter, but this platter was a far cry from what the other restaurants were offering. We felt that the fish was too oily and just didn't taste that good at all. The prawns were also not very fresh because I could feel the "bite" that fresh prawns had. Lastly, we found that the fries were somewhat soggy as well.We also had pasta, but it just wasn't anywhere near satisfying. The taste and presentation was just not there, and my friend was actually complaining the whole time.I guess the only saving grace is the fish melted cheese, which is pretty good, but the other dishes are a let down.

We came here on Sunday, which was a great day to come - if you have your own transport. since this place isn't that accessible.Being in the Science Park, the industrial decor was kind of appropriate, and the advantage of this being an ulu (remote) place was that prices were lower than they'd be in a better connected place.That said, the food wasn't very good.The buffalo wings were too lightly coated in the sauce. The sauce didn't quite taste right, though it was on the way to the right destination. The blue cheese dressing also wasn't watered down, which was nice. However there was too much batter on the wings, so the texture of the skin was off.The Italian Four Cheese wings also suffered from too much batter, as you might expect given that they probably started out done the same way. The cheese on top was nice but rather uneven - one piece had a lot more cheese than the others. And though it was Four Cheese wings I could only detect Mozzarella.The German BBQ Pork Rib Croissant was mediocre. The croissant was stale and not buttery; its pseudo flakiness was the sort of flaking you get when you toast a stale croissant. And the wedges were rather overcooked, with one of the smaller pieces being impenetrable (at least to our forks).As for the cod charcoal fish and chips, while the batter was not too thick it was very hard. I'm not sure if that was due to the charcoal or the over frying, but from the other dishes, probably the latter. Meanwhile the fish was on the soft side and fell apart easily. This was one of the least firm cod dishes I've had. And the fries were definitely overcooked - much more so than the wedges.The iced lemon tea was quite normal, but they had Avengers-themed milkshakes. The Hulk (Green tea) milkshake was so-so. It wasn't that thick and was not evenly blended, with a few ice cubes that were quite large. The green tea taste wasn't very strong either. They get props for originality though - the milkshake had a marshmallow and 2 green tea rolls inside, and the plate it was served on was dusted with green tea powder. And the other milkshakes were Oreo, caramel latte and chocolate, which is different from the usual vanilla, chocolate and strawberry.While the food here is rather creatively conceived, things really fall apart in the execution.

address: 1 Jelebu Rd # 02-19, Bukit Panjang Plaza Singapore 677743 Singapore
comment: I would say this is the best 18 Chefs in the entire Singapore. As a student, I always come here to eat the spicy garlic baked rice with chicken sausage and it has never disappointed. The portions are quite generous and very filling.A great and satisfying dining experience! Service was decent as well. Looking forward to coming here again!

address: 1 Jelebu Rd # 02-19, Bukit Panjang Plaza Singapore 677743 Singapore
comment: I came here with an expectation and also with an almost empty stomach. It's different from my last visit over here as the way of ordering is different. We have to fill up the order chit and make our payment at the counter. Taking culinary and water are self service, so the staff (quite a number of them) have lesser things to do. I don't think they need that many in fact. Well, there is another story.I ordered the Heart Attack Fried rice with steak but was disappointed to see my plate. There was more fats than meat, while the miserable portion of the rice was just so-so. For the price I paid, I didn't feel it was worth it. You have options to add on if you want and I chose to add on a soup and drink. The mushroom soup (soup of the day) was ok. Overall, I felt underwhelmed by my experience. Customer service as some of you viewers know how particular I am, is normal, nothing special. Main issue is the quality of the food, average is the best I can give for the quality and the fact I had more fats than meat for my steak is a disappointment.

address: 1 Jelebu Rd # 02-19, Bukit Panjang Plaza Singapore 677743 Singapore
comment: Love the food and the atmosphere of this place! The heart attack Fried rice with steak is definitely a must try as well. But do make a reservation or come early as it gets pretty crowded during peak hours.

address: 2 Jurong East St 21 #01-47/48 IMM Building Singapore 609601 Singapore
comment: My friend recommended this place and I might not have noticed it in the blur of various food places available. The menu serves typical Taiwanese dishes and the food reminds me of home-cooked food. The portion was filling and the set meal was a good bargain. I was worried that we could not decide on the sugar level of the bubble tea and it might be too sweet but the standard one that they have tasted great. Thumbs up!

address: 2 Jurong East St 21 #01-47/48 IMM Building Singapore 609601 Singapore
comment: The place was decorated in simple wooden style with a open look. The restaurant offered taiwanese food. The food was priced reasonable with none above $10. There was no GST and service charge.3-Cup Chicken 三杯鸡 ($7.90)Served hot in a claypot. The chicken cubes were well braised with basil leaves and garlic. The garlic was very soft with melt in the mouth texture.Kai Lan in Oyster Sauce ($6)The green leafy vegetables was crunchy.Salt and Pepper Chicken 鹹酥鸡 ($6)The chicken was crispy outside, while meaty and well flavoured inside.Oyster Mee Sua 蚵仔麵線 ($5.90)The oyster was plump and juicy which was rare in Singapore. The dish was served with pig's intestine which did not have stinking taste. It tasted not bad except a tab salty.Braised Pork Rice ($2.50)It tasted not bad except I wish there was more minced meat.Pearl Milk Tea 珍珠奶茶 ($2.20)The milk tea was a bit too sweet. Sorry cannot choose the sugar level here.Winter Melon Tea ($1.60)It did not taste too sweet for the warm version and there was dried longans in it too.The food was priced reasonable, tasted not bad but slightly more on the salty side. Great with rice.

rest_name: Hong Kong Street Chun Tat Kee
comment: An excellent exemplar of a tze char establishment if there ever was one!  In true tze char tradition, it occupies space in and is a cornerstone of a neighborhood coffeeshop.  Business is a boomin' at HK Street Chun Tat Kee and despite all this custom, the service is responsive and food arrives piping hot, having quite literally jumped out of the wok into a bowl in front of you.  The atmosphere is garishly authentic and a pastiche of Singapore heartland life, gregariously gathered around dishes of rojak, Thai beef noodle soup, ayam penyet and strangely not out of of place at all, pasta and steaks.  The food is the draw here and the evidence is the purposeful intent with which each morsel is fastidiously devoured.  When you choose to order from HK Street Chun Tat Kee, please take some time to pay homage to the sifu, the head cook, the chef.  He is the guy who ignominiously labors over that virtual forge of Vulcan to infuse every noodle, every crispy sweet sour shrimp and every steaming dish of savory fish head currywith wok hei, that elusive quality that home cooks can never hope to replicate, the love child of an instantaneous mating between superheated steel and farm-fresh ingredients. I recommend spending some time standing by the pickup counter, unobtrusively observing this master artisan at work.   One after another the orders stream in, pegged to take cardboard takeout containers or melamine serviceware and methodically and in a trance-like state, his hands are a continuous blur of industry.  There are no fancy sautee pans or copper-bottomed kettles or pots, only the wok and the long-handled bowl ladle that are in constant motion, a mesmerizing tango that produces dish after dish of steaming heavenly goodness.  Ingredients are almost carelessly tossed into a glowing wok to sauté airily once, twice and finish with a pirouette into a waiting bowl.  Few spectacles are quite as beautiful or as full of mastery as this fiery dance, a steaming chanson, a culinary ode to Singapore institution.I recommend the house special, the sam loh hor fun which is wok fried flat rice noodles (kway teow), thinly-sliced fish and bean sprouts bathed in a deceptively subtle sauce with some real depth, boasting a coy umami swaddled in the rich smokiness of scorched rice noodle.  Try to resist the urge to add soy or other condiment to this dish.  Luxuriate in the aroma and just let your eyes roll back into your head while your senses try in vain to capture each enticingly elusive scent in the cacophony of sensory signals rapidly flooding your brain.  Savor the sauce before exploring what fresh-cut mouse chilies or light soy might do change the tempo of the experience.Other honorable mentions:  the yang chow fried rice, smoky grains of glistening jasmine rice with egg, pork, scallions and shrimp..just gorgeous, and the fish meat noodle soup which is a bowl of near-perfect harmony of creamy, umami, spicy and interesting textures.  As is the custom for me now, I end this review with an earnest admonition to go out and try HK Street Chun Tat Kee for yourself.  I've never been much of a voyeur and neither should you.  Life is too short and too full of unexpected epiphanies for you to be reading about this rather than experiencing it for yourself!

rest_name: Hong Kong Street Chun Tat Kee
comment: Hong Kong Street Chun Tat Kee has been a favourite for the GF for many years, and looking at the popularity of the place , I can see how they've built their reputation. However... like most XO Fish Head Bee Hoon places who received rave reviews, they too are on a downward spiral and judging by what we had last night? A very quick spiral.Maybe once I get try the fish head Bee Hoon, my impression of this place might change, but for this review, I'm concentrating on the Tze Char that we had ordered. Baby KailanI love Baby Kailan. As long as it's not cooked to death, I'm usually not too fussy with the dish. The initial impression was great! Bright green, it showed that the Kailan's were well cooked, however, one taste and all that happiness went out the window. Completely tasteless, the dish barely tasted of anything. Clearly the dish had a sauce but it tasted like starchy water. Even the taste of garlic was absent. Hotplate VenisonProbably the only dish we had that decent, except for the fact that the Sizzling Hot Plate... wasn't sizzling. Venison itself was properly cooked and the sauce was tasty but there wasn't really an oomph about it. Cereal PrawnsI'm at a complete lost for words... And not in a good way. There was minimal Cereal. Cereal was soaked in oil and resembled wet sand. The portion had shrunk drastically and the price had been jacked up ($16 for 6 prawns). Although the flavour was decent... The oil made it feel like a heart attack on a plate. It was disappointing that their standards had dropped so drastically, especially since they raised prices ($18 for venison, $16 for prawn and $7 for kailan) . The saving grace of our dinner? Brother (兄弟) Rojak. But that's another review for another day.  Although not the worst Tze Char, it certainly missed the mark in terms of tze char satisfaction.

rest_name: Hong Kong Street Chun Tat Kee
comment: The wait was long but totally worth it. I ordered the fish meat thick bee hoon soup. The milk in the soup wasn't overpowering and it was sweet to the taste. The fish meat was also very thick and tender. The noodles were al dente and easy to eat. Good buy for $6!

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-05, The Star Vista Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: Stellar quality food for the price. If you're in the mood for some rolls or Hawaiian style poke, this store has many tasty options at an approachable decision set.Very nice staff, lots of natural lighting, a fine place to eat with a friend or just chill by yourself.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-05, The Star Vista Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: Salmon ($16.95) - 3.5 starsI was craving a sushi roll - those massive specialty ones with grilled eel and ebi tempura and other fancy things inside - but wasn't impressed by the ones at Sushi Tei so this was the nearest I found. It's alright but too bastardized for my liking. They serve it with different types of mayo instead of soy sauce for instance. (Not that I'm the authority on these things.) I tried all the mayos and they're not bad - yuzu is my least favorite as I expected. Otherwise, it was tasty enough with less mayo and actually tasted better when I didn't dip it in additional mayos.Still looking for other better sushi places (I'm not a big fan of sashimi though - I know and there I was trying to talk about authenticity) in the West so let me know!

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-05, The Star Vista Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: I must say that the sushi roll that I paid for was not cheap but the ingredients were fresh and very delightful in my mouth. So I guess it can be described as a value-for -money meal. I opt for seared Salmon with avocado and something something nice roll. I don't remember what went into my sushi roll but the product was yummy, refreshing, and generally filling (I'm a big eater). The system works like this. You can choose to order outside the shop using their iPads on their walls or order inside with the staff. You pay and they will give you a beeping device when your food is ready. You look for seats and get your dipping sauce and water. Collect food at the counter and enjoy your meal. They have limited seating so it's more like a eat-and-scoot-off place. It's too expensive a place to have daily lunch but definitely a nice treat for myself every 2 weeks.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-05, The Star Vista Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: The menu for this place screams modern west coast fusion sushi. The space is a lofty, light-filled glass enclosure. Furniture in the curvy modern Japanese style. Very classy, although it's still semi self-service: you order at the iPad outside or at the counter and they deliver. I had the Bollywood roll, which is fried ebi sushi with avocado and bits of egg topped with curry mayo and a blanket of crispy tempura dough bits. Very textural and interesting flavour-wise due to the curry mayo. But probably not worth $17. Would I have it again? Maybe not.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-05, The Star Vista Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: This is the best sushi I have had in Singapore!  And when you factor in the price with the serving size, it's a great deal!  The presentation it TOP notch!

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-05, The Star Vista Singapore 648886 Singapore
comment: I love their poke bowls! They are both photogenic and delicious. The atmosphere is cute and they do nice takeout service. I like the ability to order outside to free up the queue, but I wish you could pay there as well. Cons: The staff is not always the best and it can get pricey quickly. Also, the mall wifi doesn't work well there.

rest_name: New Hong Kong Street Chun Kee Restaurant
address: 20 Cheong Chin Nam Rd Singapore 599744 Singapore
comment: One of the options in a row of shophouses, the picture of white bee hoon caught my attention. The ingredients are fresh but I would prefer the gravy to be thicker. My friend had fish bee hoon. She was surprised that there were fish bones but impressed with the generous serving of fish. I tried the home made drink- Buah Kedondong which was a bit sour but refreshing. Service was prompt and there was no gst/service charge!

*Coffee Snob Intro*When you're let go from a company the locations you frequent many many coffee shops.These wonderful roasteries provide the perfect balance of professional attitude, casual attire, and passionate delivery to aid you in your job search.I'm going to rate a bunch of coffee shops based on this metric and a few others and provide an overall rating for the experience.----------------------------------OVERALL: 4 starsAmbience: 5Coffee: 3Food: N/A (did not try)Meeting Place: 4Working Space: 4----------------------------------*Coffee Review*Quaint. Quirky. Quizzical. This space has it all, and I've run out of Q's.Adorning the walls are assorted bric-à-brac that wouldn't be out of place in your Grandma's kitchen.I had 2 Long Blacks and a Soy Latte. The coffee was good, but not great.However, the ambience really excels here and gives you a boost. In addition to the attractive art deco style, is the interesting plethora of people coming-going-and-enjoying the space. There were friends catching up for coffee and a chat; business people interviewing potential hires; young mothers grabbing a coffee on-the-go; fit people getting their java buzz after a workout; and myself looking for somewhere to chill and sip a coffee whilst working on the mundaneness of a LinkedIn profile.I didn't try the food, so cannot comment on that.As a place to meet, greet and have a quick laptop lurk, this cute little cafe in Lor Kilat (near Bukit Timah) cannot be beat.
Good tarts. The raspberry cake is also very nice. Probably one of the better bakeries in this part of bukit timah

The cafe was located across the road from the MRT station. The place looked cozy and warm especially when outside was raining. The drink menu was listed on the board, with assorted cakes and pastries on the display shelf.Lemon Drizzle Loaf Cake (S$5.20)The cake was heated when served. It was soft and not too sweet or sour.Merry Trio Latte (S$7)Vanilla, Hazelnut, CaramelI had the iced version, which was served in a jar. Refreshing drink but could not really taste the distinct flavours in it. There was free wifi in the cafe. I was sitting at a table by the wall, which had a row of power points. There was a note paste on top which allowed customers to use the power point but limited to 15 minutes.

This afternoon i went to try the dessert set n it is wuite worth it. The food is fresh made n nice but lack of varieties. It will be good to hv pastries with drunk set instead of mini tarts n drink set only. Friendly service!

I have heard lots about Carpenter and Cook, though I don't remember exactly what it is I am supposed to try. I guess with the flurry of small cafes, bakeries, patisseries sprouting up in recent months (or is it years already?), it is hard to keep track. After a while, they really do seem to serve the same old stuff, taste about the same, cost also about the same, that most are pretty forgettable. I may like a pretty thing but what will leave an indelible impression will be the taste. Taste over appearance for me. The first impression of Carpenter and Cook is the darkness and seemingly messiness. It is not really messy, but it has a lot of things (antique or old stuff) crammed into the shop. And many wooden furniture inside also makes the place look darker than it actually is. I do quite like the vibe. Almost indie to me. Everything sort of work together even though everything is so mis-matched. That adds to the charm. You just share a big table if there are no smaller tables available. Quite nice actually. Everyone talks in a normal/soft tone so it is just a low hum of conversation, nothing jarring to the ears. And so you won't be an unwilling eavesdropper at all, even if you are sharing a table with strangers. After checking reviews on what was the recommended food (i.e. passionfruit meringue tart and lemon cream tart - isn't that wonderful of having a smartphone and internet and google and yelp and blogs?), I went to place my order. While there, I was very taken with the lemon meringue cake and the banoffee tart. They looked very tempting. I decided to just try the lemon meringue cake. It is quite rare to find a meringue cake and even rarer to find one which does it well. I love the lemon meringue cake which has 2 layers of sponge cake with a thin layer of  lemon curd and topped with meringue all around. The cake was moist and you could really taste the freshness of it. No day-old cake at all. The tartness of the lemon made a perfect foil against the slight sweetness of the cake and the sweeter meringue which was also very nicely done.  I liked that the meringue was not the typical hard type when served on its own but was a bit foamy soft and yet could stand on its own. You could just taste the egg white and sugar whipped until stiff and then browned a little in the heat. The sea salt chocolate caramel tart was nice but nothing memorable. For a chocolate lover, it is saying a lot when I actually prefer the tart instead of the sweet.P.S. I like the placement of lemons scattered all over the place. It does create a pop of color and cheer in the brownness of the place.

Uh oh... Is Success and popularity getting to Carpenter and cook's head? Ever since I first tried the place... I've seen and tasted a steady decline amongst the sweet cakes and tarts. So far, some of the crew's greetings resembles somewhere between a frost bite and an eclipse. The food itself seems..well...it taste and feels like the love that was poured into the making of those tarts... Have left. What was once raved as one of the best, if not the best place to have fantastic tarts, has now slowly started fading.From our last 3 visits, we've experienced overcooked and slightly burnt pastry, followed by undercooked pastry and finally today, salad with arugula that looks like it's been sitting in the bowl since this morning. Although the lettuce seemed fresher, it really looked like all they did was top up and left the bottom as it was, soaking in whatever dressing was there and turning into a dead mush in the process. It really feels like the basics have gone out the window. That said, we'll still be back and I just hope it doesn't decline any further that it already has.
My favourite secret spot for Sunday brunch and a delectable piece of passion fruit meringue tart

Lots has been said about Carpenter & Cook so I believe the average yelper (or any foodie worth her salt) would have heard about it this place. First off, the positives: the ladies at the counter were friendly, the decor of the place gives a feel of something found if Old-school and Indie got married. I'm a bit biased when it comes to arty decor and the ambience of this place just hit it off with me so very well. Now, the not-so-good stuff: Despite all the praises sung about the pastries, I honestly felt I could find much better alternatives elsewhere. I found the lemon meringue to be average at best, and the sea salt choc tart... well... something I'd try once and only once. And now where I get really picky: I've tried Liberty coffee - and while I immensely enjoyed the latter, I found the coffee at C&C to be rather weak. So.... I'd have to say I differ in my opinion from what seems to be everybody else when I say that the coffee was rather disappointing. All in all, though I really loved the design of the place, I don't think I'd come back. The food was decent, but nothing particularly noteworthy for me; and if you're as picky about coffee as I am, you'd know there are plenty of other places to go to get a good dose.

I admit my friend is one of the 3 owners but why I came 3 times in 2 weeks starting with a private soft-launch (even though this is out of my way) is because I love the lemon meringue tart (it's very tarty you might say which suits me to a T-for-Tart), the brioche is full of yums (yes I brought my saturday brunch mate friend as soon as we could find the time so she could try it) and the coffee is very respectable despite the lack of latte art. It's roasted by Liberty and drinking the coffee there a few times made me want to go checkout Liberty (but they're always closed and I only have so much time on weekends anyway).Love how all the furniture is so unique and while I am a modernist at heart, the place has a real character and comfy quirky vibe without looking old-fashioned.

always wanted to try it out and headed down for brunch on Sunday with my friend. We were both raving about the Passionfruit meringue tart - refreshingly savory. The bacon quiche was delicious as well and I'm not a salad person, but their side salad was really good. We also tried the Raspberry brownie but the flavor was too dark chocolatey for our liking. Gets rather gelat after a while. Still, nothing like enjoying a nice meal with their quaint ambience, and sipping tea and coffee. Will come back next time for their tarts!
Beautiful cafe! Has the most amazing, delicious desserts! I absolutely looooooved the desserts at this cafe. Highly recommend this place to everyone :) a must try !

Headed down for a quick lunch meeting so I didn't get to try much other than the tea.I have to say the decor for the place is absolutely spiffing and probably the thing Enid Blyton novels are made up of. Love the bits and pieces on display and for sale. Pick up some tea cups if you even want an extra quality in your life. You can just start with your first special tea cup, even if you don't want to pick up the entire set. Trust me when I saw tea works better in special teacups.I've heard amazing things about their quiche and passionfruit meringue tart.
