comment: Greendot is my favourite healthy vegetarian go-to place for a meal! Tried their Lion Mane Mushroom Rendang and it was SOOOO GOOD. Bento set costs about $7.90 and add another extra $1 for premium meat like the Lion Mane. It's full of flavour and tasty! Their Laksa noodles taste equally good as well!

address: 3 Gateway Dr #01-08, Westgate Mall Singapore 608532 Singapore
comment: Good food. Sometimes the brown rice is not boiled properly and could be raw. There tofu and potato curry is really nice. It's quite an affordable and good restaurant. It's in the ground floor of Westgate. Evenings around 6:30 pm is really crowded and has long queues.

address: 3 Gateway Dr #01-08, Westgate Mall Singapore 608532 Singapore
comment: I've been waiting for a place like this for a while! I have a few friends who are vegan, or are allergic to things like seafood which means they are unable to eat a lot of local delights such as laksa. Introducing Greendot, the solution to all seafood related allergies. I had the Laksa, which is completely vegan, with veggie prawn balls and straw mushrooms topped on the glorious dish. This tasted pretty much like the real thing, albeit with no grainy bits in the soup that is the by product of the seafood broth. My friend was just amazingly thrilled at the prospect of being about to eat laksa again. The prawn balls completely threw me off, as they were had such a similar texture to real prawns, i found it hard to believe it wasn'.t I also got to the try the rendang option with the bento. For the bento, you get one "meat" option, an 2 veggie sides which for me usually consists of pumpkin and broccoli. I came in with no expectations of this, having a lot of vegetarian meats that tasted like nothing, or had a texture that was more like a sponge. This flaked much like real meat, and I'm actually not sure of what the fake meat is, but there's probably mushrooms in it.This is definitely a must-try, a vegetarian version of local delights for anyone trying to be a little healthier or can't eat meat. The constant line-up doesn't lie!

address: 3 Gateway Dr #01-08, Westgate Mall Singapore 608532 Singapore
comment: Healthy and affordable place which usually has a queue! Service is quite well-organized. Some snacks were not available and it would have been nice if there was a notice on the display board. The fake meat or seafood tasted similar to the real stuff. Ironic I know but I am one of those people who like vegetarian food which resembles meat. A good start for people who want to have vegetarian meals regularly. Many people ordered the mixed rice which looked pretty normal to me but maybe it tasted better it looked. I was happy with my noodle soup.

address: 3 Gateway Dr #01-08, Westgate Mall Singapore 608532 Singapore
comment: This shop is what I feel most vegetarian stalls could emulate. Relatively cheap (for the air con, ambience and service) and decent food, showing what vegetarian food can taste like without having to show how vegetarian food can emulate meat dishes. Dishes are flavorful, colorful, and actually filling - and not because they added lots of additional starch. I got their bento set, which is $7.90 with soup (check out the photo), and they offer noodle and other soup variants. There's nothing else to add other than: please go and eat there. I'm not vegetarian myself, but I'd say this shop would still give other shops a run for their money.And guess what, they shifted their premises to be slightly nearer to the MRT too! (They used to be at the link way between West gate and JEM)

address: 3 Gateway Dr #01-08, Westgate Mall Singapore 608532 Singapore
comment: Rarely find a waiting line outside a veg healthy place but there was... good was good , service good and the place v good. Bento box and laksa were good. My meat eating son loved the veg laksa.the tom yum noodle soup was good but lacked the punch. Jelly dessert n teas were excellent. V good value for money and good option. Highly recommend.

rest_name: Seng Huat Homemade Fried Carrot Cake
address: Blk 254, Jurong East Street 24 #01-48 Singapore 600254 Singapore
comment: A common thread runs through my reviews of hawker fare, the slow death of Singaporean roots cuisine as the practitioners of this arcane art slowly retire  like stars dying and winking out of the firmament of Singaporean culture.   Hope as it turns out, does spring eternal and every now and then we devotees are given some good news, a reason to smile and keep that candle we're holding for Singaporean hawker cuisine burning bright, and yes, as the song goes, we'll keep that light on.Seng Huat is just such a story of hope.  Master Koh started hawking traditional fried carrot cake in the 1960s and perfected his craft over 40 years.  His is the story of the Singaporean street food master hawker.  One specialty, done perfectly and consistently over decades.  He retired from the wok in 2000 when his son, the younger Master Koh took over as  Master of the Wok.   He still takes orders and keeps the quality consistent, his demeanor little different than Daisho Jiro Ono's as portrayed in the food porn classic, Jiro Dreams of Sushi.  Yes, that's him in the photo.  The result  of course, is as good as it's always been, maybe even a little better than in the latter years just before the Senior Master Koh retired.  I can only begin to guess at the reason, but frying up a good sticky, almost carmelized homemade carrot cake is a game played most successfully with a straight back and strong arms.   I have the utmost respect for Master Koh's integrity as a craftsman.  You see, for him, it's all about the prouct at the end of the day and the Seng Huat reputation and less about his stature as the producer of that product.  No chefly ego that needs constant stroking and tuning,  just taking an honest pride in knowing that you've poured all your skill and experience into a dish that you can present as your very own with a clear conscience.  And being rewarded in turn with the appreciation and loyalty of your customers and their families who continue to rely on your fine product generation after generation.The carrot is not a red carrot, but something closer to the daikon.  The cake is steamed and then held as the basic ingredient for the final act of stir-frying, which is  an inadequate description for what happens in the hybrid wok-griddle.  The resultant dish resembles a stiffened congee more than any kind of cake.  When you spoon your first mouthful, you are walloped by a garlic fist, then stroked with the satiny smooth glove of egg, sweet soy, chye poh.  You immediately go back for seconds.  Add healthy doses of nostalgia and this simple dish of peasant food rapidly turns into a ride on the back of a wild tiger.With the younger Mr Koh at the wok, this ride helter-skelter into blissful oblivion need not end anytime soon....

address: 10 Kent Ridge Crescent #01-05, Yusof Ishak House Singapore 119260 Singapore
comment: There's nothing like a piece or two of piping hot curry puffs to perk you up in between classes! Old Chang Kee is definitely a favourite among students for its deep-fried snacks. On top of the aforementioned curry puff, you can find chicken nuggets, fishballs, sotong balls, and more!Best of all, the prices are cheap, and most snacks go for under S$2 per piece. My all-time favourite combination has to be the spring roll, sotong ball, and curry puff.  But I have to admit the curry puff, while delicious, isn't suitable for all occasions. Sometimes the craving just isn't there, and the curry puffs can be a turn off instead.The stall is conveniently located at Yusof Ishak House, a central location on campus. On the downside, it doesn't serve drinks, but you can always hop over to Ya Kun just next to it for some silky barley drinks.

address: 1 Jelebu Road #01-48/49/50, Bukit Panjang Plaza Singapore 677743 Singapore
comment: Ordered laksa Yong tau foo and hk style fried beancurd. The waiting was pretty long as it was new and due to the weekend crowd. Food was pretty good and will give the nearby San Cheng a run for its money. The space was pretty small (similar to the wang cafe opposite. Will go again after the hype dies down.
This place serves great pancakes. The owners are Korean themselves and they are warm and welcoming too. Good lunch deals so we always try to make it for lunch there.

Was craving Korean in my neighbourhood and decided to give this place a shot after reading mixed reviews.We ordered a Beef Bulgogi, a Tofu soup and a seafood pancake. The seafood pancake was deep fried and it was too chewy, the prawns and squid inside were way over cooked and it was a challenge to Chew and hard to swallow.The Tofu soup was average and I think I can cook a better tasting soup with a packet of instant kimchi ramen paste.The Bulgogi was the only decent tasting dish but it is far from being great. This average tasting meal does not warrant a return visit from me. I am deeply disappointed at the poor standard of the dishes. I give this place a generous 2 star
Consistently awesome home cooked Korean food with lovey banchan! Fabulous deals during lunch - ordered a bbq beef with tofu seafood soup for just $19Stuffed but so so happy

Was craving Korean food after visiting Charles Classic Cakes.  This hidden restaurant was fantastic.  The staff were very friendly.I always order spicy rice cakes (ddoboki) whenever I go to Korean restaurants.  We ordered three dishes - spicy rice cakes, spicy tofu soup (soontofu), and rice with pan fried beef (bulgolgi).As with any Korean restaurant, they had complimentary side dishes.  I particularly enjoyed the potato, fish cake, and green bean ones.  The spicy rice cake was super satisfying and the sauce was perfect.  Do eat it first though as rice cakes tend to harden if left for a while. The other two dishes reminded me of home cooked meals my Korean friend's mom used to make.  Definitely check it out if you want a non-pretentious meal.

Located in Sunset Way, this is one of the few restaurants which is lively during lunch. I had zhajiangmian which was made up of chewy noodles. The gravy had too much onions for my liking though and I could hardly find any minced pork. A friend who had soup felt that the taste was good but there were not many ingredients. There was a nice variety of side dishes for free with a limit to top up only once. They can adjust the spiciness of dishes according to your preference.

Came after lunch hour around 2pm, we ordered kimchi soup lunch set and beef stew a la carte.Kimchi soup comes with very little ingredients. There were only 6 tiny bites of pork inside. The $9.90 set was really overpriced as the amount of the ingredients inside didn't value for the money at all.The beef stew that we ordered cost $16. We ordered this instead of $9 promo set just to be safe, afraid the portion was too small. The soup tasted sugary sweet, and came with insignificant amount of beef. Sad to say, the food here didn't worth the price that we paid. We can get better taste food with fairer amount of ingredients at any other food court.

Great food and great friendly service. Small and cosy ambience. Definitely recommended. Have been coming here with my whole family so quite some time. My mom is quite the foodie and even she likes the food here- she is hard to please.

Perfect home cooked food and friendly owner. The green onion seafood pancake with crispy on outer layer and soft inside. The jajiangmeon and the spicy cold noodle are one of the best that we ever come across. Super delicious!

address: Blk 155 Bukit Batok St 11 Singapore 650155 Singapore
comment: Best tasting Nasi Lemak in my area IMHO! That Sambal is delicious! Tucked away in a old style open air food court with multiple food stalls - this place serves great Malay food.

address: 20 Ghim Moh Road, #01-45 Ghim Moh Food Centre Singapore 270020 Singapore
comment: You only understand the queue after you've eaten your first bite of the char Siew and roasted pork. You know it's special because it's not your usual bright red colour. It's darker brown and that's because of the marinate that they done in-house.It's sweet yet savoury, and together with the charred parts of the meat, each mouthful is delightful! Definitely a stall to return to again and again. Yumz!

address: 20 Ghim Moh Road, #01-45 Ghim Moh Food Centre Singapore 270020 Singapore
comment: One of the best store remaining here. Ask for fat char siew and roast pork for best experience

rest_name: West Coast Market And Food Centre
comment: Breakke time!! Love the carrot cake which u can have it either white or black!! He sells everyday!! Usually long queue on weekends!!

rest_name: West Coast Market And Food Centre
comment: Renovated once in five years, and another renovation is schedule later this year. So generally a good place where local comfort food is found and great value is expected. Locals know exactly what they want and like, see the Qs. Foreigners are not taking much risk eating here. If you join the Qs then you just order whatever those people ahead orders and you can't go wrong.Dress down in t-shirts and slippers.

address: 1 Jelebu Rd #02-16, Bukit Panjang Plaza Singapore 677743 Singapore
comment: Price is per-pax ($26 on weekday evenings) plus tax and service charge. Additional $3 on public holidays. Unless you're ordering expensive meats (e.g. beef), this buffet is probably on the pricey side. Lots of choices to dunk in the broth, though, such as lobster and salmon meatballs.

address: 144 Upper Bukit Timah Road #04-01 Beauty World Centre Singapore 588177 Singapore
comment: I love the food with a home cooked flavour. price is reasonable and service so fast. appreciate when we are hungry. will go back again and again.

address: 144 Upper Bukit Timah Road #04-01 Beauty World Centre Singapore 588177 Singapore
comment: This Korean place is rather packed for lunch and they have just added suction pipes on each table, implying they are quite good on bbq food? I haven't tried.However, their seafood pancake and sundulbu are good. Wholesomely, authentic kind of good. The portions are humongous. I saw the jajiangmian seems to be able to feed 4 women. I had the ramen tolbuki which was just average & the tolbuki wasn't chewy.

address: 144 Upper Bukit Timah Road #04-01 Beauty World Centre Singapore 588177 Singapore
comment: The girlfriend and I were in the area thinking of what to have for lunch when a brainwave hit - why not Korean food? Normally, that'd be an easy pick with the options available along Lorong Kilat, but then I remembered seeing Keiko's review a couple weeks ago... and BAM. Decision made. We swung the car around into the back parking lot (now there's a tip, especially since the front one only lets season parkers get in, and you look like a fool waiting for someone to get out - yes we were those people for a while).Anyhow, entering Beauty World is like a massive blast from the past - we both had gone to school in the area, albeit at very different stages of our school lives, and it really doesn't look like this place has changed one bit since then. In fact, I don't think it's changed since it was built in... the 70s? I may be exaggerating, but not by much, I assure you.Back to the matter at hand, and this little Korean restaurant. So it's on the fourth floor, and as we take the escalator up, I was looking around for it, and I discovered the hawker centre. I kid you not, a hawker centre, on the rooftop kind of level, and its old school. And I digress. We hunt for a bit, gawk at the hawker centre a little more, then we find Joo Mak, plastered with pictures of bulgogi and other tasty delights, which only made me want to go in even more.We open the doors, and there's a counter, and one other table of two Korean ladies chatting super animatedly. Good sign that they're Korean, bad sign that it's just one other table?The owner-type lady comes out from behind her counter, hands us some menus, and we flip excitedly, and pick out the seafood pancake, and the classic bibimbap, but of course we are distracted by the other four pages of beautiful, beautiful food.Orders go in, and food comes out! Thank goodness there weren't that many other people here, otherwise I might have passed out from a mixture of jealousy from looking over at the two ajunmas.The lady brings out six appetisers, and they taste ZOMGAMAZING. Clean, simple flavours, and those crunchy pickles!? Woah. Next comes the hot stone bibimbap, with many a joyous crackle and pop, to which I quickly squeeze out that spicy sweet sauce and stir up that egg, and see it sizzle, and spoon some into my hungry face-hole, and of course, burning my tongue. Worth it? YES MA'AM EVERYTIME MA'AM. Okay so I stopped for a little and let it cool down to I might at least enjoy the flavours, instead of scalding every tastebud I had.That seafood pancake emerged, and it was more like a 12 inch pan pizza. HELLO. and it was DEEEEELIGHTFUL. Crisp and the bottom, without too much oil, and made even more amazing by that soy concoction the lady supplied... Wow. Just. Wow.We washed it down with some rice punch, and for a fleeting moment, I was in K-town para-para-paradise...Meal's done, and time to pay - to my very pleasant surprise, my wallet was as satisfied as our bellies and tastebuds were. We'd enjoyed great tasting Korean food, at a very reasonable price, and I'd gladly come back again with friends... just not too many, lest we get cross looks from the ajunmas whose seats we might have taken!

address: 1 Create Way #01-06, NUS University Town Singapore 138602 Singapore
comment: I came here really only expecting to have a nice cold pint with a few friends, but made the mistake of looking at their extensive, picture-filled menu. I really cannot remember the name of the dish I ordered, but it was this incredible Italian bean and vegetable soup (not Minestrone though.) The soup was served hot and came with crispy slices of toasted garlic bread. I can't really say if this was authentic Italian, but it was pretty freaking delicious.We sat outside because our group was too large to fit inside, but there was nice ambiance nonetheless. The waitress was was friendly and helpful, and handled our large table of university students quite well.Also, get teh gelato here. Just do it. You know you want it! Its only $S 2 per scoop, much cheaper than I've seen anywhere else in Singapore, and its made in-house. The Hazelnut and Amaretto are both really good! I'll definitely be back for more.

address: 1 Create Way #01-06, NUS University Town Singapore 138602 Singapore
comment: This Italian restaurant has really decent pasta!Had the $10.90 set- fettuccine with smoked salmonGenerous serving, good enough for 2 to share. It is also reassuring to witness an Italian chef to cook and present it to you. It makes you feel this is a more genuine experience.Learned something new that day too. Ordered pepperoni pizza but when it came, it was bell peppers!Did a quick Google search and realized that pepperoni refers to bell peppers n salami would be sausages/pepperoni. Ahhhh~Sapore has both indoor and outdoor seating. When I was there, there were a good mix of Caucasians and locals lapping it up with a Tiger Beer Tower.

address: 1 Create Way #01-06, NUS University Town Singapore 138602 Singapore
comment: This place was started by Italian chefs which was a promising sign for the quality of the food. In reality, the dishes were hits and misses. Pizza came in thin crust and pasta had a variety of choices. The pesto sauce was good. One friend ordered pesto pasta with chicken slices but there were only a few chicken slices. I ordered potato gnocchi which was satisfying but could do with more flavors. Other friends ordered fried mozzarella to share and were pleasantly surprised by how addictive it was.

address: 1 Create Way #01-06, NUS University Town Singapore 138602 Singapore
comment: Sapore is incredibly average. I have never been blown away by the food, and only eat here when I am too lazy to leave campus. To me it only seems excellent in comparison to the atrocious dining hall food we are fed on a daily basis.My issue is that almost all of the pasta dishes seem to be frozen and re-heated - or at least that it was it tastes like. Perhaps they make their own sauces, but I doubt it. The pizza is average, and the gnocchi is not up to snuff. It would be a fair choice it the dishes were not over-priced for their quality. A pizza can run you up to $15 here, and nothing of the entrées will be below $10! The servings are also relatively small.The service is friendly, and the decor is nice. Get a booth if you can, and try to go a little before peak hours if you can as it does get busy in the evenings. If you have a choice and the time though, you can get far better Italian elsewhere.

address: 1 Create Way #01-06, NUS University Town Singapore 138602 Singapore
comment: This is one of the best Italian food I've ever had in Singapore, hands down. The food is cooked by actual Italian chefs who came to Singapore, and the pasta and pizza are all fantastic! You might feel a little intimidated at first, as the Italians are pretty big and loud! But they're quite friendly, and you'll be able to strike up a conversation upon second or third visit.It's my habit to first try the margherita pizza whenever I go to a new Italian restaurant. It's the simplest pizza one can make, and the standard will tell volumes about the rest of the dishes. I wasn't disappointed at all! Not going to spoil the surprise for you, so go ahead and try it out! The decor is pleasant, although the interior feels a bit warm if it gets too crowded. I'd recommend you sit alfresco anyway. The cool evening breeze and the soft lapping of the fountain is relaxing.It's the only place on campus that overtly sells beer! So this is a must-visit if you're craving a pint or two after a long day of lectures.

The long, slow-moving queue almost made me give up on this unassuming stall. Sheer determination and curiosity about how good this rojak could be was the only thing that kept me going.Pretty damn good, it turns out. The stall is run by two brothers working together in tandem - one snipping all the ingredients and the other mixing them all together with their signature sauce. You can choose to add extras like cuttlefish fish or century egg but we went with the basics. The shrimp sauce is perfectly balanced - sweet yet delivering a slight spicy note. They are also very generous with the taupok and youtiao which is my favourite part. I also loved that the uncle asked me if I wanted the sauce separately for my takeaway order to keep the rojak fresher. These little touches despite the long queues they must work through really make the place. One of the best fruit rojaks I've had (I still prefer Indian rojak a bit more). If you go, prepare yourself for a queue but know there is something worth it at the end.

Brothers Rojak @ CLEMENTI.Clementi Brothers Rojak 金文泰兄弟罗惹Hmm..  I wonder if Brothers Rojak @ Clementi and Clementi Brothers Rojak @ Zion Road is the same or NOT??  Maybe my Singaporean Chinese Friends can enlightened me or give an explanation.I have been to this Chinese Rojak vendor way before I left Singapore and now I am back since one of my Singaporean friends has been craving for their Chinese Rojak.  If I am NOT mistaken the day/date I return with her and her kids was on Monday late afternoon at about 16:10hrs ish.Thankfully we managed to be in a short queue in order to order their Chinese Rojak.  This time around, my friend ordered the Chinese Rojak without the Squid pieces or Dried Cuttlefish pieces.The line/queue went fast enough say about 5 minutes in waiting.  As usual both Uncles aka they are Brothers hence the name of this Vendor, are always smiling and so welcoming.I want to love their Chinese Rojak, but for now they received the 3.25 stars in my books coz maybe that late afternoon, the Chinese Rojak I had was without the Squid/Dried Cuttlefish pieces aka "essential" for my kind of Chinese Rojak.  With regards to the The Chinese Rojak, that my late grandma and late Aunt had made usually it consists of a salad of "vegetables" mainly pineapple, cucumber, turnip, tau pok (fried beancurd) and you zhar kway aka Youtiao (deep-fried dough sticks) freshly mixed in dark prawn paste with some sugar.  The prawn paste are sometimes pre mixed with a sprinkle of crushed peanuts and spice aka chili.Even though Uncle ask us, if we want our Chinese Rojak to be "spicy", my friend wants it to be less spicy, hence what we ate was the lack of "shiok-ness", less "spicy" = no "kick".Different people makes it differently but this is how I like my Chinese Rojak to be aka with some spice aka spicy.  Anyways, I do not mind returning to the Brothers Rojak for their Chinese Rojak in a heartbeat.  More Chinese Rojak haunts in the future when needed all across Singapore.449 clementi aveune 3Clementi, Singapore 1204499710 2700

One the best rojak ever!I love rojak, so I think I am justified to say that this uncle had the best balance of the prawn paste down pat. The ingredients are well soaked and fresh! The sweetness is just right, the sauce is just right.I forgot the photo. But you need the palate not the photo to tell you this is good stuff. Magic

One of only 2 Rojak joints worth anyone's time and effort in Singapore.  The other is in Hougang Ave 10.  Joints like Brothers Rojak are what make living in Singapore worth the climate, stiff fines, and the nosebleed expensive cost of living. Ok brass tacks:There's always a line.  Lunch line 10 mins or so, dinner line about 20 mins.  Service is honest and friendly.  These guys are always smiling no matter how demanding the crowd.  Consistency. These guys have been serving the very same dish the same way since forever.  The secret?   They stick with one recipe and one way of completing the dish.  No matter the line or the time of day, they just hunker down and do the dish right.  Corners are never cut to get customers through faster. That's my opinion at least after having seen these guys churn out Rojak for me thousands of times. You can get your Rojak to go in a "kit" with sauce on the side.  You can get fixin's. Codfish crisp, cuttlefish, sun dried crispy fish bones, century eggs. They also serve tau kwa pau.My recommended food crawl:Brothers Rojak.  Chai Ho satay (have the chicken). 51 Old AirportRoad Bean Curd.  Washed down with Sour Plum tea from Koi Cafe. Clementi rules!

Located in a small shop space in a corner of the See Lam Hern kopitiam, this unassuming stall serves up a tasty plate of rojak. The fruits used are always fresh and crisp, lending the dish an extra oomph. The quality of the youtiao varies, and I've had good days and bad days with this stall but I'm not sure what they put in their paste as it always seems tastier than your average plate of rojak. It is not yet a very established, well-known rojak stall like those in toa payoh or kallang airport where you have to wait for ridiculous amounts of time to get your food but it is pretty known in the area. So if you happen to be around clementi and feel like having a decent plate of rojak, this is quite a good place to head to.

I lived in Clementi with my mum's family the first ten years of my life and Brothers Rojak formed a significant part of my childhood. My whole family loves their rojak so much, we ordered at least one every week!This unassuming stall is tucked away next to the drinks stall and they hold the greatest market share in the whole coffee shop. Two very affable brothers man the stall for 11 hours daily. There always is a long queue but it hasn't entirely taken its toll on the two uncles. They do look visibly weary these days but they can still deftly chop up the fresh ingredients and whip up a mean salad for you in a jiffy.  Despite being tired from operating the stall the entire day, the friendly brothers greet every customer with a smile.If you're doing take-out, they are even thoughtful enough to ask if you wanna separate the sauce so the dish stays fresh longer.

As a less-than-wealthy college student living in the southwest of Singapore, I can attest to the lack of both cheap and delicious restaurants in the vicinity. However Din Tai Fung is one of the few that fits that bill perfectly. With just $10 one can get a whole tray of Xiao Log Baos, delicious soup-filled dumplings, easy to share, but just as easy to devour without said sharing. To be honest these mere  words do not do this dish justice. Not in the least. These are hot heaven in a soft noodle wrapping. They are delectable savory soup with a surprise pork treasure. I've been to this location many a time to do just that with several friends, each of us ordering a tray (at least) for ourselves, leaving with happy stomachs and happy wallets. Without a doubt one of my favorite restaurants in all of Singapore. Enjoy!

Having been to the original store in Taiwan, the one stark contrast is the level of customer service. Not that the service experienced here was bad, it was still really good but the level in Taiwan was excellent. Well, it is a popular tourist destination in Taiwan, with bus loads of tourists visiting that place daily. Food wise, the standard here remains constant with the original. I must say that the management has done a fantastic job in ensuring quality. Now the remaining question is, how is one supposed to eat the xiao long baos?

This place is already very well known and my review of specific to the branch in JEM. I was deterred by the number of people standing outside the restaurant but decided to take a queue number and was surprised that the wait is just 20 minutes which can be spent easily by window shopping. The famous dish here is the xiao long bao. The skin has the right thickness and the meat is tender. My friends and I had vermicelli, fried rice and noodle soup respectively. We were all happy with our orders. We didn't realize from the photo in the menu that there was vermicelli and it was a pleasant discovery when the dish got served. The pork chop that came with my fried rice came with the ideal softness and flavor. Even though the fried rice only had eggs, it was very flavorful. The waitress was prompt but spoke a bit too curtly. Still, it is impressive that the turnover is prompt and efficient.

I really loved this place. I always take the spicy noodles and I have never seen service this good! I recommend this place, very cheap and clean as well. As a Swedish student who currently lives in Singapore, I often go to this place. I also tried their dumplings and I think that if you like those stuff then you should definitely go to this place! However for me I didn't quite appreciate it so much. However that is the only negative aspect of this place. What are you guys waiting for? Go, go, go!

I've updated my rating to 5-stars. My most recent experience here was phenomenal. Pork steamed dumplings were incredible as always and I tried the shrimp steamed dumplings for the first time, which were equally superb.

rest_name: He Jia Huan Ban Mian Mee Hoon Kway
address: 496 Jurong West St 41 Coffee United Singapore 640496 Singapore
comment: When my brother told me about this place, and how they were known for the dry ban mian and mee hoon kway, boy was I skeptical. Being a lover and strong advocate of broth I knew I had to try it. And guess what? I'm a convert. I get cravings for this now all the time and I'm happy there's a branch in Jurong West. It comes with a generous amount of sauce on the bottom, topped with minced meat, ikan bilis, and an egg. Give it a good mix and today!This Is definitely a my new favourite ban mian place, and if you're a purist, they do have the soupy servings of ban mian as well. Also, if you eat there, you can get some of their soup on the side as well, which I highly recommend -trying their stellar fish broth.

address: 107 Clementi St 12 Sunset Way Singapore 120107 Singapore
comment: A nice cozy place to dine without the crowds but this place will die soon with the ridiculous rentals imposed on the stall operators. My favourite mee pok aunty is leaving this month as she has to pay $7K a month in rental. What a shame.

address: 107 Clementi St 12 Sunset Way Singapore 120107 Singapore
comment: I didn't specially come to this hawker centre but dropped by as my friend wanted to check out the well-stocked pet shop nearby. I was drawn to the display of the roasted meat stall. I had both roasted pork and char siew. The portion was decent and I preferred the roasted pork. The fish ball soup stall next to it highlighted that there's no MSG in their soup. Indeed, it tasted like home-made soup. The tzi char stall is open for lunch and the mixed rice stall had the longest queue.

Ever since my first taste of soufflés in Paris, I dreamt of reliving the taste here in Singapore.  Of course, with the myriad of hotels and top restaurants, thats not difficult to do. But to find a good one at affordable prices is close to impossible. I am glad to discover that Miam Miam @ Westgate is such a place.Honestly, I love the fact that everything is made from scratch on order. Good things come to those who wait. And for a good soufflé, it is definitely worth the wait.We had the 'soufflé de nuage' - which is tomato sauteed rice with mushrooms and ham. And it is topped with a superbly fluffy egg and cheese cloud. Yes, you read correctly, not a typo. The egg and cheese on top really is a heavenly cloud of fluffyness. Most important, all the flavours were not overpowering, just the right amount of lightness marry into a perfect blend.Next up was the complimentary soufflé pancake since it was my birthday. Of course, compared to the de nuage, it may be a little ordinary. Nonetheless, it was a very well made thick pancake with soufflé fluffyness on the inside.Finally, we came to the real soufflé soufflé. The hardest things to do make well are often the simplest. And I'm glad to say the vanilla soufflé pass the test with flying colours. Not too sweet not too creamy, just the right amount of fluffyness (i cant help it, no other words describe it better). As it sat there and began its slow collapse, you are instantly reminded to eat it while its warm. For soufflé lovers, this place is a definitely worth a visit. Best of all, they have 4 outlets in all every corner of our island.Aside: Thusfar, one of my favourite soufflé in Singapore is Laurent Bernard's rum and raisin soufflé @ Robertson Quay. This is definitely almost as good.

Nice place with good taste and decent portions. I had mac and cheese with the right amount of richness. It would have been even better if there's more meat. There's a variety of options for pasta and my three friends each ordered something different. Everyone was happy with their choices. The dessert ended the meal on a great note. We had chocolate soufflé which was fluffy outside and moist inside. It was also not too sweet. The service crew in the West gate seemed a bit flustered at times but overall we had a pleasant experience.

Went to Miam Miam @ Westgate after 2.30pm and caught the promotion period whereby selected drinks are only $2 each! :-)Tried the {Riz Au Curry Rice - $15.50}, {Famous French Toast - $9.80}, {Caramelised Banana Pancakes with Vanilla Softee - $12.80} & {Matcha Souffle - $10.80} *Note: Prices are excluding GST & service charge. Dessert takes minimally ~20mins to be served! IMO the curry rice tasted the best, prolly bcos I was a little sick of the sweet stuff at the end. Overall I feel that the service is good, waiters walking around in the café to see if you need help. But perhaps it was due to the fact I visited on a weekday at non-peak hour, where there were few customers in the house!3.5/5 stars because the food was not bad (kinda expected a lil more from the desserts) plus service was good :-)

Eating at Miam Miam was an interesting experience. I'll start with the good stuff. The dude and I needed a place to eat at the Jurong mall area that could be done in an hour since we had an appointment. We were headed for a brunch place we remembered on the 2nd floor of Westgate (I think), but then  saw Miam Miam and it's "made from scratch" headlines and decided to pop by. We ordered the curry rice and teriyaki chicken pasta since we didn't have time for souffles and then proceeded to wait, since the waitress said the food would take "20 minutes because its made from scratch". I was all happy thinking wow we finally found a restaurant that makes food from scratch and doesn't pass off Angliss stuff for $15/serving.Well we waited. We found our seats a little cold so we moved to a table outside and continued to wait. I literally thought I'd give them the benefit of the doubt with the longer than usual cooking time because they were making the effort to cook  something good. 45 minutes later....yes sir, I actually waited 45 minutes before saying anything, I asked a young female waitress to check on our food. She went inside the restaurant and didn't come back. Great, that's fine, I'm used to unprofessional service. I went inside and looked for a waitress that appeared to at least have cleared teenage hood. She said she would check on our order.We waited again. Finally I buzzed for service the said lady came out and apologized. Our orders were keyed into their "new" electronic order system and they didn't go through to the kitchen. Yea I was kind of pissed. I did however manage to ask, somewhat incredulously, how a restaurant service team can rely solely on technology to wait tables. It's totally possible in Singapore because waiters don't bus a certain section but man, it takes really really bad staff management to not have a waiter realize the order you put in 45 mins ago hadn't come through.To the lady's credit (I think she was the manager), she apologized, gave us free minestrone soup (don't pay for it, your mama makes better soup I promise), comped our drink order and watched our table like a hawk. My pasta came pretty quickly after the error was realized but the dude's curry took a good 10 mins more to arrive. The teriyaki chicken pasta was tasty though a little too saucy for my book, while the curry in a hot pan was delicious. But then we could've just been really, really hungry at that point.Moral of the story? Uh... budget an hour and a half for a 1 course meal.

address: 1 Bukit Batok Central Link, #02-04 West Mall Singapore 247933 Singapore
comment: I used to love this place three years ago. Now it feels like a really shit place with crap food and bad service.

address: 1 Bukit Batok Central Link, #02-04 West Mall Singapore 247933 Singapore
comment: The "Xiao long bao" here is bigger than your usual ones and they come in mini trays. Flavor wise, it is one of the best I've had but I wish it was smaller like the ones you get at Din Tai Fung. Another great treat would be their fried dumplings, XL on size yet again with this one. Careful when you bite into this or you might get some sauce squirting into your eyes. Overall, a great place for lunch or dinner and best of all, it is not too expensive as compared to Crystal Jade.

address: 1 Bukit Batok Central Link, #02-04 West Mall Singapore 247933 Singapore
comment: Mayim felt like a very family oriented restaurant as we saw lots of families in there. The service staff were very courteous and prompt to respond when we called for their attention.I went for the stewed beef la mian, and I really liked it. The texture of the handmade noodles was really great, and the portion was more than sufficient as well. However, the beef was just average. I also sprinkled garlic bits liberally over my noodles just for the extra kick.We ordered a few other stuff such as the pig trotters and the cod fish. The pig trotters (cooked in vinegar were really wow! Very tender and satisfying; it's no doubt one of the better pig trotters that I've come across. The cod fish (cooked into bits with an almost-uncooked raw egg yolk on top of it) was spectacular as well: creamy and satisfying. Overall, Mayim's a really nice place for a family dinner but be prepared to queue if you do not have a reservation.

address: 154 West Coast Road #02-23 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: I hadn't been here in a while, but in recent months I got to visit a few times. Unfortunately it seems that their standards have fallen greatly and the curry fish head is more watery and is in a smaller portion. Their service is very poor, particularly during peak hours.

address: 154 West Coast Road #02-23 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: The server made a mistake by serving me a lychee drink. I thought it was plain water and had a sip.Much to my astonishment, thereafter they wanted to charge me for the drink. There was a little argument and I refused to pay for the drink.They are incredibly calculative and wanted to charge me for their mistake. There is no knowing what other penny-pinching tricks they may be up to in the kitchen.I will never be returning.

address: 154 West Coast Road #02-23 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: Good sze-char. Their specialty is the fish head curry. Other dishes are good too. Reasonable prices and comfortable environment (air-conditioned).

address: 154 West Coast Road #02-23 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: Yes. The Fish Head curry is consistently good.Much like a Zhi Cha place, they serve a variety of dishes, but the most popular is the curry fish head. I like both the signature and the asam version.Not the cheapest, but sits in airconditioned comfort eating spicy food. Nicer then Al fresco.

address: 154 West Coast Road #02-23 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: West Co'z Cafe serves amazing food options for westies, and is particularly a great option when you have a group of at least 6 people. They are well known for their fish head curry, which lives up to its hype. The seating here is great because they have plenty of round tables which can seat around 8 people. I came here for lunch during the week and found the group of 8 to be perfect in trying their set menu + few add on items ala carte from the menu.The restaurant is clean, well ventilated, and easy to find. Highly recommend!

address: 154 West Coast Road #02-23 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: Signature fish curry head is worth to try, i do not like curry at all normally but fish curry head is good and acceptable curry taste. this cafe is in west coast plaza

address: 154 West Coast Road #02-23 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: So I finally got the chance to eat here!!Assam Fish - we opted for fish slices version with Assam curry. The fish slice was the deep fried type you eat in fish soup. I thought its a little queer but still tasted good as the curry is good. It's not super Assam as it's lemak too. Kinda the best of both worlds. :)Golden Claypot Chicken - another awesome dish. Pre-fried chicken pieces coated wiTom Yum Soup - not great. Taste like it's made with instant paste. Can skip the next time. Sambal Lady's Fingers and Sambal French Beans with Prawns - both very good. Vege were stir-fried with good wok-Hei. Cannot stop eating. A meal here cost is $80 so while it's not cheap, it's very affordable. Will be back again for the nice and affordable fish head curry.

address: 154 West Coast Road #02-23 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: I'm a resident of the West Coast area and when it comes to great food around here, it's pretty hard to match West Co'z Cafe. As other posters have pointed out, it's a venue that specialises in Halal "zi char" (stir-fry), so you get the usual dishes like sambal kangkong, hot plate tofu, shrimp paste chicken wings, cereal prawns, etc etc...basically the zi char experience in an air-conditioned mall (very similar to what you get at Far East Plaza), with a strong consistency across dishes.The specialty of this place is Curry Fish Head. Seriously, if you come here, just get this, otherwise you're just wasting your time here. It costs $16 and comes in a generous portion that feeds 4 (I get aggressive sometimes and order this even when there's only 2 of us here). You'll notice that every table has one of this and they do both the Nonya and Assam style, so pick your poison. They do enough quantities on a daily basis that it's fresh and cheap.One thing to note is that this place generally gets very crowded during mealtimes, but they do take your number and ask you to take a walk around the mall. Turnover is pretty quick, usually a 10-20mins wait, so don't get frightened off if they ask you to come back later!And oh, did I mention, a zi char place that takes American Express cards in Singapore? Yeah, this place is weird like that but so convenient!

address: 154 West Coast Road #02-23 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: A gotta-try someday halal zi-char cafe.Like many other zi char stalls, their dishes are available in three different sizes and they have set meals for groups of people at reasonable prices as well. I also absolutely LOVE their lemon chicken rice! The cafe is located on the third storey of West Coast Plaza. The wait staff have always been very polite and attentive even when they're busy (which is almost always).The cafe offers a satisfying meal and I have not been disappointed with their food or service so far.

address: 154 West Coast Road #02-23 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: Cheap and cheerful "zi char" place transplanted into a mall.It shouldn't work, but it does.A big plus: it's halal.It's also pretty good. The curry chicken, Assam fish head, golden claypot chicken and other signature dishes are winners. The fried rice dishes also have the requisite 'wok hei' flavour. I think it's way better than most of the "zi char' places around here.

address: #01-171 Blk 726 Clementi West Street 2 Singapore 120726 Singapore
comment: Visit umakemehungry blog for more reviews.The sprawling queues at Heng Heng Boneless Duck Rice during lunch times has spoken.The Duck Kway Tiao Dry, served in S$2.50 (Small) or S$3.00 (Big) are great. Slices of braised duck meat were placed on top of the kway tiao. These duck meats are fork tender and chewy without too much of fats seen.Generous amount of oil together with Kway Teow Kia (Kway Teow that is smaller in width ) was used, lending an unctuous essence to the dish, my colleagues and I had a hard time grabbing them up with our chopsticks as they were silky smooth. I love their "Lor" (Braised Gravy) as it was sweet and watery typ, giving the unami taste. There is only 2 Braised Duck Stall located in Clementi West Market and Food Centre, personally I prefer Heng Heng's as their soup is not as peppery. Although the queue is long but the wait is worthwhile.

mi Casa is actually an upgrade from a nearby hawker stall in Bukit Timah market and food Centre. They have transformed from a kitchen into kitchen and bar now. On top of that, the upper level of miCasa provides a different type of ambiance.While waiting for the food, we had some Australian Juices to accompany us. They are cranberry and lime juice.Juices - $7Ciabatta was lightly toasted and served warm with mushrooms.Ciabatta with Mushroom - $9Glistering top layer of pork cheek is crispy and definitely addictive with its melting texture. Put the cube into your mouth and gently press it down with your tongue and enjoy it. It may look the our Chinese version of "Sio Bak" but this is way healthier as these cheeks are less fatty, tender and richer in flavor. Try and you may like it!Pork Cheek - $16Live clams in white wine sauce was their Local Fresh Catch and nicely done up consisting buttery flavours of wine with garnishing like garlic, spring onions and cut chilli.Live Clams in White Wine - $18With the natural sweetness from the clams, the stock was made delicious and I cant stop at the first helping.It must be crazy to order Clam Pasta after ordering the live clams but the love of having clam just didnt stop us. Pasta was cooked to Al Dente perfection and in light stock. However we would prefer the stock of the pasta from the white wine above. Perhaps so, the dish will be made perfect.Clam Pasta - $16The thing about ordering striplion here is base strictly on its weight. If not for the wait on Tomahawks that will take about 45 minutes, we would have skipped the striploin. Nonetheless, having striploin also means that we may be back for the 1kg of Tomahawks. With the good crowd at night, if you want to order Tomahawks, it would be best to order in advance.Striplion - $42.84Striploin in medium rare doneness as requested was pretty well prepared as seen from the pinkish layer of meat in between, acommpanied by mashed potatoes and some garden greens. Meat was tender and awesomely done.This is not the usual carbonara that get soaked in a pool of cream (even though I prefer that style). One of the perks of this dish is the generous use of sausage as well as pork meat.Carbonara - $14Given the homely ambiance and relaxing environment, its hard not to be back again. Food might not be the most authentic Spanish or Italian ones but at least it somewhere we know that will not hurt your pocket in terms of such cuisine.

Distasteful and arrogant owner. I made a reservation for NYE for 2 to be seated outside but was told that they prioritised other reservations over mine so I had to be seated right in front of the kitchen where the fumes would be blowing over my partner and I. Although reservations were made a day before where the restaurant staff had OFFERED us a choice of seats, I was told that the restaurant would not be honouring their promises to us to give us the seat offered and promised to us. They would rather prioritise other bookings and ensure that they are kept over ours. This is not in the spirit of the new year at all. Not only did the owner not admit to the mistake, he insisted that I was had a point and that it was subservient to his. It is absurd to overpromise and underdeliver. Poor communication between staff and owner was clearly present. Owner flipflopped on agreement and said that what was noted down in the shop's notebook was merely a 'request' that is subject to the shop's discretion to accede despite it being offered and promised by the staff.

address: 17 Jalan Dhoby 80000 Johor Bahru, Johor Malaysia
comment: In the heart of Johor Baru downtown, it serves the best chicken chop in town - authentic and delicious. Love the outdoor seats tasting the old faces of the old town with breezes from the sea. Uniqueness: 9/10Food: 9/10Value: 9/10

address: 17 Jalan Dhoby 80000 Johor Bahru, Johor Malaysia
comment: One of the few cafes in the neighborhood that is open. I had the chicken chop with 2 eggs and mushroom gravy and a root beer float . It was fantastic. Wife has the same but with black pepper sauce. Also yummy. Son had the fish and chips. He gave it good reviews as well. Service was prompt and friendly.

address: 17 Jalan Dhoby 80000 Johor Bahru, Johor Malaysia
comment: Famous as this place goes, we had to come check it out. Supposedly one of the best chicken chop places around, we got the fried chicken chop with mushroom and pepper sauces respectively. Came here on a Sunday afternoon at 12pm, and did not have to wait for seats. Service is prompt here, and the place itself is quaint and dated. We ordered a latte and iced barley, and were disappointed to find out the coffee was instant, and the barley from a syrup, not homemade. The chicken chop was soso, with a light crust, and a tender inside, the seasoning didn't stand out, and the mushroom sauce was essentially a tasteless brown gravy with canned mushrooms. The pepper sauce fared better, with a bit more punch. The sides were coleslaw and fried potato wedges. The coleslaw was your run-of-the-mill mayonnaise-laden cabbage, but I really liked the potato wedges, which were freshly fried and not from a packet, but cut potatoes. I am unsure if this place is halal, but did see many Muslim waitstaff here. Rm 40 for the whole meal.

address: 17 Jalan Dhoby 80000 Johor Bahru, Johor Malaysia
comment: As one of the oldest established Hainanese Restaurants in Johor Bahru and located at the intersection of Jalan Dhoby and Jalan Pahang, It Roo proudly dons a sign boasting "the best chicken chop in town" and being awarded the title of "The Best Chicken Chop In Malaysia" by the Star Newspaper in 2003, It Roo certainly has a much hyped up name to live up to in patronizing a contingent of Chicken Chop devotees, myself included. Despite being given the luxury of numerous options on the menu, I'd be the biggest fool in the southern hemisphere to not order the Chicken Chop and so I did. The chicken chop choices vary between fried or grilled with either a mushroom or black pepper sauce. Starving as always, I gobbled it down in mere minutes, the batter wasn't too thick and the meat was tender and moist. As delicious as it was, I wouldn't jump on the tagline of BEST chicken chop I've ever had in Malaysia but it undoubtedly ranks up there

rest_name: Ah Kow Mushroom Minced Pork Mee
address: 359 Bukit Batok Street 31 #01-401 Meng Soon Huat Food Centre Singapore 650359 Singapore
comment: If you love BCM (Bah Chor Mee) you would have probably heard of Ah Kow Mushroom Minced Pork Mee which was previously located in Hong Lim food Center. The stall has been around since 1945, passing recipe from the original owner to his sons.Everytime, without fail, I will get to Ah Kow's Die Hard Supporters adding to its long snaking queues. What's so great about the bowls of noodle, let's check it out.Our frequent order from the stall will be Bee Tai Mak Dry in its smallest available portion at $4 per bowl.  For those who prefer more vinegar in their minced meat noodle will definitely appreciate the "uncontrolled" use of black vinegar in their noodles.Minced Meat Noodle (Dry) - $4 (Small)Noodles were springy and complemented well with the sauce. Ingredients were generous in its thick cut braised mushrooms, handful of minced meat and noodles stand up with its fragrant fried sole fish.Minced Meat Noodle (Dry) - $6 (Big)Overall, Ah Kow's noodle is some food that we will return for its taste and generous portion.Apart from food, I notice that the stall owner has passion in running the business. On several occasions, I noticed that his white shirt was totally drenched either in his sweat or most probably from the steaming vapour of his soup, but such thing has never stop him from serving out more delicious bowls of Minced Meat Noodle!

address: 80 Mandai Lake Rd Singapore Zoo Singapore 729826 Singapore
comment: Inuka Cafe offers great treats to have when visiting the Singapore Zoo. I got a Bo Bo Cha Cha while I waited to go to the Night Safari. It was about 8:45 pm, and they ran out of jelly for the chendol and bo bo cha cha. The service was very quick! I waited about two minutes to get my dessert. The bo bo cha cha was great. Even though it was missing the jelly it still tasted amazing.

If you are on a budget and looking for a satisfying buffet experience, look no further and head down to Sakura International Buffet at Admiralty park. Buffet cost $23+ for a weekday lunch and $31+ for dinner, $29+ for weekend lunch and $34+ for dinner. Operating hours are 11am to 3pm for lunch and 5.30pm to 10pm for dinner.Sakura serves a wide variety of food from Western, Japanese and Oriental food. For those who have been to a Sakura buffet in other branches, you will probably find no difference in the offerings from Admiralty park. The dining experience is, however, one of the best that the chain has to offer. Customer service is certainly one of the best I have experienced, with friendly staff and fast topping up of empty food trays. As an international buffet there will be many different food to accommodate to various taste such as japanese sushi , asian delicacies and lots of different desserts ranging from cakes to puddings. Drinks are free flow and the variety is just a vast, from different kinds of soft drinks to coffee and tea.What really set this branch apart is the environment and ambience. It offers an outdoor alfresco dining, overlooking a lotus pond in Admiralty Park. For those who dislike outdoor dining, fear not as there is also indoor dining where air conditioning is available.Overall, it is a value for money dining experience and certain not to disappoint.

It's not easy to find good American style pizza (by which I mean the generic sort, rather than regional variations like New York, Chicago or Sicilian) in Singapore.Sure, pizza chains are a dime a dozen, but most of them suck and almost all of them are Halal (which means you don't get the goodness of real [i.e. pork] bacon, ham, pepperoni etc).And yes, there're lots of places serving good Italian style pizza (thinner crusts, wood fire ovens, toppings like prosciutto and the like).But sometimes you don't need the delicacy, artistry and (relative) simplicity of an Italian style pizza, but just something hearty, messy and rich to sink your teeth into.Well, good news. Papa John's, which has been in Singapore since 2015, is no longer Halal certified as of late 2015 (or early 2016).We had the Sausage and Bacon pizza.The first thing I noticed on biting into a slice was the crispy bacon on top, adding a hearty crunch to the slice. The cheese, meat and ingredients in general were of good quality - a definite cut above the other American pizza chains (even Domino's, which is the best of the rest).In particular, the mozzarella was very generously scattered and was of very good quality, and the tomato sauce was really intense with a strong tomato flavour (which you don't find even at the good Italian pizza places here).Everything combined in a savory, gooey explosion in my mouth.We topped up to get a stuffed cheese crust at only 3 bucks for a large pizza, and there was a lot of (good) cheese inside.I wasn't hot about the garlic dipping sauce though, as it didn't really go with the pizza. But the pizza is awesome enough as it is so that isn't a problem.This outlet feels rather remote, but even though it's within walking distance of an MRT stop, the crowds don't seem to think it's worth it (Singaporeans like their shopping centres to be linked directly to their MRT stations). So during a late Saturday lunch there weren't many people in either the shopping centre or the restaurant. There weren't so few people that the area was deserted but just enough to give it a relaxed suburban feel (and in my other visits to this shopping centre I've found the same). So this outlet's location is actually a plus (at least once you get there).There are some minor downsides though.If you're intending to order this for delivery, their only outlets (as of the time of writing) are in Hillview and Tampines so coverage is limited.Their largest pizza, appropriately titled the large pizza, at 12 inches isn't that large, so if you're feeding large groups, take that into account.Finally, the pizza is also a bit pricier than at other American pizza places. But oh, is it worth it.
Portions are huge here. The smoked duck pizza was nice and good to share amongst 3 ladies. Nutella and banana crepe was delicious and huge as well. Come to this place to share (or u will be stuffed).

Extremely expensive menu for the quality it has. And the specials are the same almost through out the year. Some food are good but meats are generally dry and not fresh. A glass of water is needed to gulp down the food. Pizza and breakfast menu r considerably better.  The photo attached is that of grilled chicken wrap. Dry as hell. The order was served considerably very fast. Not fresh!The restaurant looks modern has both outdoor and indoor setting arrangement.The ice cream was very old hard and tasted funny.

Awesome spot for breakfast and brunch.I love the coffee here.  I do miss a real good cup of coffee and no amount of local 'kopi' satisfies like a real robust brew from quality grounds.Stopped by for a very quick breakfast and was served quickly and efficiently.Portions are generous and made from scratch. I enjoyed their crepe with ham. I thought it would be kinda foo-foo, but that plate was yuge. The crepe was like a ginormous burrito.. The cheese was delicious, the crepe was eggy good.. yeah.. just get the crepe.. so good.Servers were fast and professional.  Would definitely return if I am in the area.

I am a regular at this place because of the prices.. A nice margarita or roasted chicken pizza for S$18.. Very fresh ingredients, very flavourful, light and crispy dough. Good salads and good pastas as well. Very good sized servings. Sandwiches are tasty but not fantastic. There are always good promotions going on here. The 1-for-1 breakfast deal on weekdays at this outlet is a real steal. My family's favourite pizza place. Only regret is that they should have a kids menu

This was reasonably good food and a good deal.While not adhering to the real Italian recipe which uses no cream, their carbonara was a huge portion and it was quite good. The bolognese was nice and had thin straws of carrot. Both pastas were about $16, and significantly better than the pastas at Jamie's Italian, for example. The salad was good also, and the Mövenpick ice cream is reliably fantastic. They were out of tiramisu though. I wasn't crazy about the raspberry smoothie as it was too sweet.

address: River Safari 80 Mandai Lake Road Singapore 729826 Singapore
comment: obviously, this kitchen is neither run by a mama panda nor is it one that sells panda friendly food.it's mere existence suggests that they are capitalizing on the popularity of jia jia and kai kai, the two main attractions residing within the giant panda forest of river safari.seriously, who can resist coming in here for cutesy panda themed fast food?well, you can't, especially not when it is your only air conditioned f&b option once you have passed through those turnstiles.thus a very captive audience they have indeed and therefore it gets really crowded here.furthermore, it is strategically located at the somewhat half way point of the park where a rest stop would seem more than prudent.and it is also a good place to while away the time as you patiently await that amazon river quest boat ride you reserved earlier.panda cookies, panda pineapple shortcakes and panda souvenir cup with any soft drink purchase, all perfectly touristy gifts. panda cappuccino art and panda shaped custard buns, who can say no?their other snacks however are more for sustenance rather than gourmet gastronomy.one probably would not travel to river safari just to visit mama panda kitchen but if you do then perhaps your visit might help you answer these questions: how do you say black and white horse in mandarin?斑马(zebra)how do you say black and white cat in mandarin?熊猫(panda)

address: River Safari 80 Mandai Lake Road Singapore 729826 Singapore
comment: Not as bad as i expected. About the only option to dine at though :/Pricey for the quality of food and it was just mediocre taste. They have cute panda shaped dim sum and panda drawn on their frappucino though xD

address: River Safari 80 Mandai Lake Road Singapore 729826 Singapore
comment: good lord they have capitalized on the pandas here. Panda everything!!!! We wanted a snack after going through the whole zoo and then part of the river safari so this was a logical stop. We shared spicy tofu and steamed dumplings. It wasn't anything impressive but it wasn't awful. I did get a cute souvenir kai kai and jia jia cup because I'm a sucker.

address: River Safari 80 Mandai Lake Road Singapore 729826 Singapore
comment: Not that great. But this is pretty much your own option once you entered the park. It's located right past the pandas and by the polar bear exhibit, halfway through the park. They pretty much have a captive audience, since the nearest place to get a full meal is the Tea House, which is a walk back across the entire park and outside the turnstiles. And it's air conditioned, so a decently place to wait for either the polar bear feeding (which doesn't actually seem to always happen on time???) or the Amazon River Quest that you booked.It's a Chinese restaurant with pretty limited selection, but with a lot of panda themed items.I got the spicy beef noodle soup, which was supposed to come with mango pudding, but they were out for some reason, so they gave me a tapioca pudding instead, which was okay, but I wanted my mango! The beef noodle soup was acceptable. The picture on the menu shows that it is supposed to come with a decent amount of lotus root chips as well, but it only came with like 4. Sad beans. Overall it was pretty pricey as well, coming out to something like 16.5 Singaporean dollars.My companion did not seem to like her braised pot dish. At least the soda came with a touristy souvenir cup!Anyways, maybe it's better to bring your own food. But I guess if there was no other choice, this place suffices.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-03, Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Very very aromatic coffee! Consistently thick and just so goood! The lurking chocolately-ness of the coffee is almost waiting to pounce on you as you have your sip. This place makes magic local Singapore coffee or what we call 'kopi'. Must-try!!

I love the prata here. It is nice, soft, and chewy without being too soft and the curry that accompanies the pratas is always on par. My favorites are the marsala prata, the egg onion prata, and the cheese egg prata. Yum!!The thosai (or dosa) here is nice but not nearly as good as the prata. Although, that is my general preference anyways so maybe I'm just being biased. I had the marsala thosai and it was good, but not as flavorful as I would have preferred. There was a really delicious tomato sauce that came with it though and it was really refreshing.The mutton curry biryani that I had here was one of the best biryanis that I've had. The mutton was just perfectly cooked and they give you a good size portion of it too. I feel like I could eat this biryani for the rest of my life... Definitely a must try if you're here.I've also tried the butter chicken here, but this dish didn't really stand out to me. It was a little bland and didn't have a lot going on. I couldn't really taste the butter that I usually do and it was kind of off, in my opinion. I would skip on this dish and try the others.

My favourite Indian food! They have Roti Prata including Italian Prata, murtabak (Turk-tabak is stuffed with turkey), Oreo Roti Boom is a set of 2 pratas and Oreos and ice cream.They also have Mee/nasi/kway teow goreng, fish head curry, kambing (lamb) soup, tulang (bone marrow) soup/merah, tandoori.There is an air con area but with the passage door open, it isn't cold enough. Maybe it is real Low air con and that's why they have fans.The roti Prata is better than the one at the other end of Clementi Road (near Pasir Panjang). Texture is much better and it is a little crispy.Had half a piece of fish too and curry was slightly warm.Overall a good place for prata.Free wifi too!

Terrible terrible service. I think I was doing the waiter a favor by eating here. I felt like I had to apologize for not ordering a drink. Food was all right, but nothing to really rave about. The chicken in the curry was very tender and nice. Didn't sense much passion in the cooking though. At least it's indoors with air-conditioning and wi-fi (to encourage more people to come in?)

Decent North Indian and South Indian food. Tandoor is only open for dinner and not lunch. South Indian is better. Range of Prata is enormous, almost ever type of Prata under the sun.Also, has Asian delights out of which I personally like the Maggi Goreng!

The food used to be better. The service fluctuates here but mostly on the bad side which wouldn't be such a big deal since it's located at the bottom of an HDB flat but when you're paying $8 for a chicken briyani, you kind of expect service to be just a bit better when the food isn't what it used to be.

This is a revisit after more than a year. I ordered a fresh  coconut juice and prawn biryani. But was pushed to order fish with prawn biryani instead. When the coconut drink came, it was floated with coconut fiber. So I sent it back but have to ensure that I didn't drink it. The prawn biryani was so so. The rice was on the sticky side. The amount of prawn was surprisingly generous with one slice of fish. When come to paying, the dish was named food item and cost $15 which is almost double the price of prawn biryani  as listed on the menu. Lesson learnt, never order what the waiter is pushing. I felt cheated.

Prata Planet offers a wide variety of pratas, both savory and sweet, alongside roti, murtabak, thosai and ala carte South Indian dishes. The kosong (plain) prata was perfect: the fluffy, crispy and flaky layers that were the result of folding the dough over several times. Also, I just loved the taste of freshly-made dough, which had a hint of sweetness to it.I also tried the Cheese and Mushroom Prata. The Prata was fluffy and not oily. It was filled with melting cheese and button mushrooms. Besides Prata, the restaurant also sells Mutton Soup, Thosai and Biryani. I also tried the Chicken Biryani which I thought was pretty decent. Long thin grain rice was used for the Biryani rice. The curry was not too spicy and the chicken was very tender.Overall, I'd highly recommend this place for its amazing pratas!

This is a good place to go if you are wanting supper after most of the shops have closed. Located near Clementi MRT Station, this prata place is not the place to come if you want to have the best prata but to be able to eat some junk in order to wind down and end a stressful day. Have visited this place many times with my best friend, who usually goes for the pratas while I always choose to have the maggie goreng ($3.50). Both of us agree that the portion is not enough for us, but then again, it might be doing us much good by limiting how much we ate at that time of the night. Opening hours: Daily: 630am - 11pm

Quint little home styled peranakan dishes.Babi Buah Keluak is their famous dish. Basically stewed pork with Buah Keluak nut. Tender melts, slight chewiness and unforgettable. I like.Ngoh Hiang. Bite-sized prawn stuff fritter balls! The fragrance is well balance and freshness of the prawn comes thru. YumSoup Bakwan Kepiting and Itek Tim tastes homely, exactly what my mom cooking! If they come in bigger bowls that would be lovely.Bobo ChaCha is a very common local dessert. Here at $3 is pricey, the softness of the sweet potato and yum cubes and sweetness is just right.

This restaurant is a little off the beaten path - it used to be in West Coast but has since moved to Rifle Range Road where parking is not a problem at all.Unfortunately, the food left me wanting. The dishes were not served very hot, taste-wise I felt like there wasn't enough punch or umami, and the prices were high - we ended up spending a LOT just for what we thought would be a regular dinner.The rendang was stone cold when served, the assam pomfret was fresh but the sauce didn't have a good oomph. The kailan we got was ordinary, the chap chye nothing to write home about, but the babi buah keluak was pretty good because they used soft bone which was nice and tender. The two things I really liked were the ngoh hiang - good texture and flavor, as well as the bakwan kepiting - the soup was delicious and the meatballs had good flavor!I'll probably go back to Joo Chiat for my Peranakan fix. I'm a loyal customer at heart I suppose!

rest_name: Treasures by Imperial Treasure Yi Dian Xin
address: 252 North Bridge Rd #B1-37, Raffles City Shopping Centre Singapore 179103 Singapore
comment: This was some of the best Chinese food I had while in Singapore. They have many locations throughout Singapore. The servers are very nice and fast. The menu is very extensive. You can have anything from dim sum, to congee & noodles, to traditional entrees. I had congee and dim sum. All of it was excellent and fresh. This particular location is in a mall which is convenient. It's well lit and very clean.

rest_name: Treasures by Imperial Treasure Yi Dian Xin
address: 252 North Bridge Rd #B1-37, Raffles City Shopping Centre Singapore 179103 Singapore
comment: Still my favourite Chinese food restaurant since I tried their 100am outlet. Food was served fast on a Saturday afternoon and service was efficient and pleasant. There is the option of which part of the duck/chicken you'd like should you order their roasted specials, and an additional $2 for the leg. I would recommend choosing the duck leg when ordering the roasted duck noodles-it's extremely flavourful and the duck meat is served in a generous portion. Other dim sum dishes I usually order include their chicken feet and fried shrimp in bean curd skin. Absolutely love them!

rest_name: Treasures by Imperial Treasure Yi Dian Xin
address: 252 North Bridge Rd #B1-37, Raffles City Shopping Centre Singapore 179103 Singapore
comment: Had the #16, #21, #78, #89 (with duck and pork), and another #78.  Every single thing was delicious and brought out quickly.  Friendly waitresses and good prices.  Highly recommend!!

Despite the uneven reviews, we went for brunch...and are so glad we did!The building and the entire Cjimes complex are visually appealing and harken back to times long past. The room is well spaced, with a comfortable feeling (see pic).The food was absolutely delicious.We had a half Peking duck which yielded ten little pancakes in which slivers of the skin and meat were nestled. As with most purveyors, the remaining meat was then taken back to the kitchen to turn into a polished fried rice dish (we could have opted for noodles).We also enjoyed:- Roasted crispy pork. These crispy little cubes were absolute heaven! I ordered the same thing later that day at another well known restaurant...no where near as good as these were. I could easily opt for a big plate of these for my last supper- Fried silver fish. If it weren't for their tiny black eyes, you would assume a plate of Mickey D's fries!- Flaky pastry with shredded turnip in a crazily shaped dough- Steamed Shanghainese dumplings (nearly impossible to coral onto the serving spoon or grab with the sticks...you might ask for a fork, particularly if you're in a hurry)- Panfried stuffed red chili, green chili and eggplant ...There was NOT a miss in the bunch!While I feel we were well served, I can appreciate some of the service related comments offered by other yelpers. While hard working, staff could be a bit "smoother around the edges," and interactions were sometimes abrupt. They were constantly ensuring our tea cups were full...if I were a bit more jet lagged I might had minded the frequency. Language was uneven across the staff, such using the wrong word or our needing to repeat..but, again, we really didn't mind.To the contrary one of our many servers was very polished and extremely customer focused, having done a great job. Among a myriad of duties (including rolling a table through the dining room), he was on point for the Peking duck experience!I can only speak to the midday dim sum experience, but we feel this was a home run and a memorable experience...a definite recommend.
My friends took me to eat dim sum here.Love this place!!! Yummy Pecking duck! Yummy winter melon soup(not on the menu)! Yummy all the different type of dumplings. This restaurant is a keeper!!!

Peking Duck is delicious , truffle fried rice and fish must try !   Escalopes and veggies are fresh !  My favorite is side cucumber dish too.Love the pomelo mangoes dessert  ! We had a big table but NO ROTATING TRAY ! The service is good . HAPPY to have the toilet on the same floor !Shall be back !

Michelin star restaurant #2.The good first:Excellent selection of Cantonese food which you will not find in usual Chinese restaurants. A large dining area which means you can actually get a seat here (as opposed to most 10-15 seater places with stars which are booked out months ahead). Loved the braised pork in chinese wine, and the braised vegetables which included some unknown to me veggies but with excellent texture. Also got the crab dumplings which were ok.The bad:The service wasn't up to the standards I was expecting from a Michelin star place. Very unattentive, not refilling your water, taking forever to give the drinks, also they were not able to explain a lot of the dishes very well.

Very good Chinese food with excellent service.I came here one night for business dinner and really enjoyed their food and service.My business partner pre-ordered dinner so I don't know how much it was but it seemed high end Chinese restaurant.Great selection of wine by bottle, wide variety, it was easy to find what I liked.Everything chosen for me that night was excellent. Peking duck was crisp with great flavor, pork, tofu, soup... all was excellent. I didn't see the menu and the server spoke mostly in Chinese so I didn't quite get the name of food.Service was excellent, she was attentive, served next food just when we were finishing one, kept coming back to pour more wine, changed a plate for each dish served.I likes they prepared two chopsticks, black one is to pick food from shared plate and white one to eat from your plate. It was a pleasant evening with great food. Highly recommend for business dinner.
Soup prepared to the finest taste. Simply love the milky texture and sweet taste after long hours of cooking

3.5 stars. Upscale 1-michelin star Chinese cuisine in Singapore. We went there for Chinese New Year and went for their Chinese New Year set dinner. Experience was solid good. Food was overall quite good but not spectacular. Favorite dishes were the chicken, Lo Hei, and the fish. Quality of ingredients and excellent and the food was well-cooked but don't' think it was worth the $200/pax given the lack of wow factor. Set was quite big and we were all stuffed by the end of the meal

This place is exquisite! I can definitely understand why it is a Michelin-starred restaurant. It is within walking distance from city hall/raffles city areas. It is located in a little "restaurant village" called the chijmes. The outside area is a beautiful garden theme. You will walk in to an elegant building where they will escort you to your table either downstairs or upstairs. There are very many exotic yet edible sea creatures in tanks stacked in three rows towards the end of the downstairs dining room. The servers are a little familiar with the English language; however, most items in the menu are pictured as well so ordering isn't too bad of a task. Food was wonderful- each dish was refreshingly tasty. They also have an in-house restroom, which is also a perk. I would definitely try this restaurant again!

I had a satisfying meal at Lei Garden in Shanghai just a week ago. Looking forward to experience the same, I brought my family at Lei Garden in Singapore. Unfortunately, i was quite disappointed. Taste is different for the bbq honey pork. Very little serving for the crispy pork. Overpriced fried rice. Only the Chicken in Abalone was the same. The 3-star rating is limited to the dishes we ordered tonight vs same dishes I had in Shanghai.
Good food, in smallish costly portions though. The drinks are pretty good but very expensive. I would give it 4 stars with prices 20% lowerz

Not the best place if you looking for good service. The waiter offered to portion out the fish for our table of 10 diners but he obviously has a problem dividing the portions equally.
