Overall, Tess Bar & Kitchen is a solid place for food, and also can be for cocktails.  The talents and influence of the french trained (Rubuchon) chef really shows, and is a pleasant surprise.  The wine lists looks fairly short but well priced, but the cocktails we ordered seemed to go along with the food just as well.  So when you want to go to a place for cocktails and for a more substantial meal, Tess Kitchen and Bar works very nicely!

hipster clusterfuck. pisco sour was pretty weak. oysters were $12 for 6, but oysters were on the anoroxic side. i was lazy or i would have gone to allswell, bought fat juicy plump oysters at $2 each and shucked them myself. this was an appropriate punishment for my laziness.

It's one of those nights where you just finished watching a performance in town, it's close to 10pm..where can you go to get some decent food?Since Chijmes was nearby, my friend and I ventured in search of a restaurant that will catch our eyes and fill our hungry tummies with great food. So we walked past many diners and finally landed ourselves at Pizzeria Giardino, located at the Lawn area of Chijmes, cos we were attracted to the authentic wood-fired oven where they cook all their signature pizzas.We ordered the Pollo Chicken Pizza and the Ruccola Salad. The pizza was filled with fillings loads of cheese and the thin pizza crust was great. The salad was also great with generous servings of parma ham. The portions, add together, is a little too much for 2 pax to share on such a late night, but it's not overwhelmingly excessive. If you enjoy sitting out on the lawn on a cool evening and enjoy some italian classics, Pizzeria Giardino is a great place to be. Really frustrated I cant share any of the images of the wonderful meal (My phone got reset and my pictures disappeared!), but hey, go there and try it out yourself instead!

Amazing location, Great plates, ok drinks, not so great dessert. Decided to try a place at Chijmes since it was a block from our hotel.  The restored convent, chapel and school is stunning. We decided to share a bunch of plates and found a few surprises. The seafood stew, foie gras and beef cheeks were delightful while the potatoes cooked in duck fat were disappointing. How can you mess up potatoes in duck fat?!?The Giardino crush had lime cordial which gave it a sickly sweet flavour and didn't meet expectations. They messed up the tiramisu by covering it in ground coffee and barely soaking the biscuits. All up great location with great tapas style plates for sharing but doesn't have all the elements.

Pizzeria Giardino has a primo spot in Chijmes, facing the courtyard inside.  There is actually a fairly extensive menu despite the name, but we mainly stuck to pizza and a couple of plates.  The kids seemed happy with the pasta, but the seafood casserole was actually quite decent - a bit light but also full of shellfish and flavor.  As for the pizza, there are some interesting topping choices for thin crust version here such as squid ink and the prices are reasonable, between $20-30.  But the pizzas themselves are just ok - the crust didn't have much flavor or texture but the toppings seem to have the right balance between cheese, meats, and veggies.  I definitely enjoyed the drink specials all day, where you can get wine, house pour, or beer for $8.  There are many choices at Chijmes, and while Pizzeria Giardino doesn't seem to jump to the top of the list, it's still a decent place for some food and drinks, while being in a nice open spot.

The pizza was very generic and looked hastily prepared with no care/love.  For example, ingredients that were meant to cover the whole pizza would be clumped over a few slices - obviously they aren't that concerned about presentation.    Interesting too as the place was not busy - so it's not like it was a rush to get our order out!So - the 2* is because this places charges ridiculous price for the quality they provide...   back in Australia there was a place that charged $30 for a pizza, but wow, was it amazing, packed with ingredients and such variation in flavour!  But this place?  Charging over $20 for a generic run-of-the-mill pizza that any outlet, any takeaway could offer for less.   If pizzas were $10-15 and treated more as a 'side' for drinks...  then it could be nice place to have a few beers with generic food. There's a lot of choice in singpaore for food - these guys offer nothing beyond generic and are most likely living off the 'novelty/tourist' factor of Chjimes.

Horrible service... Staff was blur and we needed to repeat our order after the waiter left... We also Waited for about 1h for my food and bill took another 30 minutes to divide between my friends...The food was good but the service needs much improving...

I've only been there once and it was a couple of years ago. I usually go back to pizza places I enjoy so I don't know if I really enjoyed the pizza there. I ordered the pepperoni pizza and its was okayyy lah. The pepperoni was a little oily but I guess that's not their fault since all pepperoni oozes oil after they're baked.  The overall flavor also didn't blow me away. It's okay pizza and quite generic.Their fried calamari is good though. Could be worth a shot.

For a full review, please visit: urbanjourney.com/food-an…While we have tried quite a few pizza places here in Singapore in search of the perfect fit for our seasoned, pizza-eating taste buds, we've often been left wanting more.  So when we first happened upon Pizzeria Giardino, we had high hopes but feared being disappointed yet again. However, even before we took our first bite, we couldn't help but be drawn in by their al fresco dining area amidst the lush green trees of the charming, Chijmes convent complex.Cheese lovers, opt in for the Quattro Formaggi pizza, adorned with an extremely generous portion of mozzarella, gorgonzola, parmesan, and scamarza. Taking a bite of this pizza is like you imagine a pizza should be, as the chewy, doughy crust pulls away from the main slice, while the thick, hot, cheesy layer hangs on a bit longer, stretching and stretching as you try to get it all in your mouth.  Best of all, with all the cheese packed on, this ritualistic process happily continues until the very last bite is in your mouth.For those Tiramisu fans, you can't go wrong by ordering their take on this fan favorite, but we personally are suckers for their Profiteroles, the puff pastries filled with creamy ricotta cheese and drizzled with warm, rich chocolate sauce.

address: 11 Stamford Rd #01-83, Capitol Piazza Singapore 178906 Singapore
comment: Another Breadtalk concept which poshes up the old kopitiam cafe concept. There's hipster tisanes and brew coffees to go with your chicken rice and chicken curry. Clever twists on presentation. The chicken curry comes in a bread bowl. The Raffles blend coffee is a filter coffee that comes with a mini sock in a fancy glass filter. The desserts are all plated with fancy finesse - think sauces brushed on plates, quenelles of ice creams, strategically placed fruits. Despite the hipster presentation, the food is nicely done. The chicken rice has silky chicken and good broth. The chicken curry has good rempah but the bread bowl is huge. Prices are of course on the high side to match the table service and fancy ambience. But it's a nice quiet corner to hang out for dinner and coffee.

address: 11 Stamford Rd #01-83, Capitol Piazza Singapore 178906 Singapore
comment: 1933 is a cafe which is opened by BreadTalk. To most, it feels like an atas version of ToastBox. The cafe offers local cuisine, priced reasonable, considering the high class shopping mall.Tea Set ($10.90++)The cafe offers a reasonable priced tea set during the afternoon. It is pandan chiffon cake served with a choice of tea or coffee. As the coffee machine was down, the choices were limited to mostly tea.Gula Melaka Pandan Chiffon 香兰椰糖蛋糕 ($8.90)Childhood favourite soft pandan chiffon is baked with bits of palm sugar for that extra Nyonya flavour and served with delightful Gula Melaka syrup.Interesting chiffon cake with a layer of Gula Melaka filling in it. If not enough, there's a serving of rich Gula Melaka syrup to dip with. The cake was light and fluffy. Although it looked like there was lots of cream with dessicated coconut on top of the cake, I felt that it gave the cake a kind of moist feel.Served with Green Mango Peach fruit tea 有机芒果桃味茶 ($8)The tea was light and fruity in taste.Overall the tea set was enjoyable. The service was great with the staff refilling the tea without being asked to.

address: 11 Stamford Rd #01-83, Capitol Piazza Singapore 178906 Singapore
comment: Nice air-conditioned environment within the Capitol Piazza overlooking the Atrium. Try the Asian fusion baked goods (on display the front) and the Eggs Royale - the smoothies have no added sugar. Nice and quiet during brunch. Lunch menu starts at 11:30am and yes there's chicken rice if you need it.It's not big, it doesn't try to be too clever, and gets the job done nicely!

address: 109 North Bridge Road #01-15, Funan DigitalLife Mall Singapore 179097 Singapore
comment: Being a big fan of ba kut teh, I must say that this joint is a good contender against Songfa which is a little farther down the road.The location not too bad, at Funan digital mall and the place looks clean and bright, which makes you feel pretty comfortable and happy somehow. The layout is pretty standard, with squarish tables and as Jessica pointed out, the table is quite multi funtional, with a drawer for spoons and chopsticks, electronic tablet for ordering and also an electronic stove which I reckon is for heating up water for tea (maybe).Now to the main point the soup. This is the Singaporean meaty and peppery type of soup. The spice and meat taste came out pretty nicely in the soup. They are very generous with their meat portions (I guess proportional to the price) and I was pretty impressed that the meat was tender and tasty. They do give some garlic as well, but the setback is that the garlic wasnt boiled long enough, hence it was still a little hard. The other important component is the rice. Typically the rice tends to be hard and dry, but over here, the rice is cooked just right and still fluffy when I ate it.Service was good, before I could request for more soup, my soup was topped up with more piping hot and tasty soup. It wasn't really diluted like some joints. The condiments counter had freshly minced garlic and chilli padi.I would recommend a try if you are looking for tasty peppery soup in the CBD area and do not want to perspire when having piping hot soup.

address: 109 North Bridge Road #01-15, Funan DigitalLife Mall Singapore 179097 Singapore
comment: The restaurant has multi-function tables with drawers that put out to become ipad (menu), panels to connect adjacent tables to become a long table. Kids were super excited to open all the drawers. They also have a counter with bowls of condiments that you can self-help in tiny saucer bowls! Too cute!!The soup is nice but I prefer it to be more peppery. I ordered lean meat slices and the portion is generous! One other dish is preserved Vege which was also good. However, I did find the braised peanuts a little weird tasting. The whole meal is not cheap but to eat in Aircon comfort and with good flavours, I can't complain. Likely to return.

Been coming here for the past 5 years now and I love it. It has good ambiance, staff are friendly, food is good, cheap, portions are huge. Like seriously, what more could I ask for? :)What I Love: Love the style of the place. It's very chill, there are couches, pillows and magazines. Games are put in a corner - just in case you're in the mood for some. Staff are really friendly and sweet - they know me and are very accommodating. The food is gooooooood. I don't think you can go wrong with anything.Try their Summer Rolls. Portions are insane. Plate of 2 (which is cut into 4 pieces) is big enough of a starter for 2 people.Their Fried Spring Rolls are yummy too. Not as big as the Summer ones, but good to share as well.I've tried their salads which are to die for. There's a Morning Glory Salad with Chicken that's yummmy. And a Watercress Salad that's good too. You can order it with Chicken or Beef - but I usually get chicken with this. Their Beef Stew is yummmy. I've tried their Beef Combo, Beef Brisket and Beef Noodles, all yummy. My fave is the Dry Noodle with Grilled Pork. The pork is served in quite a large portion!Fave Fave Dish: Crispy Noodle with Beef on it. It's really to die for. Portion is huge! So prepare to stuff yourself.Drinks: Love their Plum Lime Soda, Calamansi Soda and Vietnamese Coffee. I also like their new teas, Pandan and Lemongrass. Their Lemongrass drink is really yummy too.Dessert: Try their Gula Melaka Sago with Coconut Ice-Cream. Yummmmmmy!!!!What I Don't Love: That I can't eat here everyday! There's nothing to not love about this place! ;D

I'm a big fan of Vietnamese cuisine and, having lived in northern Vietnam for a while, I can be picky when trying Vietnamese food elsewhere. Va Va Voom is average and doesn't serve anything close to what you can get in Vietnam, but it's reasonably priced and the portions are well-sized. One of the reasons behind my love affair with Vietnam's cuisine are the herbs used to heighten flavours in their dishes, and Va Va Voom really falls flat on this one. The pho bo is distinctly lacking in these, as is their fresh spring roll. However, I was quite pleased with their bun with fried spring rolls, and I think I'll stick with this one the next time I go. They have great deals at lunchtime - SGD 9 for a main, drink and ice-cream - and happy hour on their beers and ciders in the early evenings. Because of these aspects, I would say that Va Va Voom is a good choice if you're on a budget, but don't expect to be transported to Vietnam with this experience.

Don't expect traditional Japanese dishes here, these dishes are more for those who fancy a little bit of fusion, and more refined. No large rice or ramen bowls, rather, small adequate portions of the dishes so you can sample the various items on the menu. A little pricey, but at that location, it comes as no surprise. The only dish I didn't like is the wagon with miso, was too salty and strange for my taste. Loved the scallops, seared Salmon and tuna dishes, couldn't get enough of them. They serve delicious cocktail drinks also, and at one side of the restaurant, there's a bar where you CA just sit by and enjoy the bartenders' antics, while people watching. Nice place to enjoy good dishes after a show!

You know what? I've come here enough throughout the past year that they deserve an extra star from me.This remains my go-to place for when I need free wifi and a central location to work out of for an hour or 2, on a whim without reservations. The staff has been nothing but accommodating to me and my laptop. I've even used their power outlets to recharge my phone, further mooching off their amenities. And usually I just order an iced tea or non-alcoholic beverage.They let me stay as long as I want, even though I'm one of those annoying, cheap bastard, moochers. For that, 4 stars well deserved.

We didn't have high hopes for the mushroom soup as it was quite watery. However it was tasty and mushroom-y (without being overpoweringly so). It also came in a big bowl, and was served with quite a lot of baguette, instead of the token one or two slices that most places give you. The baguette was reasonably crusty too.The chicken genovese pasta (the type with pesto) was alright - nothing noteworthy either way.The Grilled Furikake Salmon on Potato Risotto was really interesting. It was salmon with a crispy seaweed and sesame seed crust, served on a bed of mashed potato (yeah, that's what the potato risotto essentially was). This was a pretty unusual dish, with the salmon having a crispy crust, and a pleasantly intense umami flavour permeating the flesh. It is rare for salmon to be non-generic tasting and this combination was a winner.Dimbulah is very cheap for the area (this is the heart of Yuppie-land), with the pastas and the fish and chips going for $14. And prices are nett prices too (no 7-17% surcharge).Service was a little slow though, and they mixed up our order.

This review is based solely of their coffee. It was great. I had the cappuccino ice-blended "spin" and the picture is of their signature Dimbulah coffee, both of which were excellent. Solid Wifi, good prices, & tasty coffee. I'll be back!

Perfect ambience as they are located in a quiet corner within chijmes. Kudos to the nett price for everything on the menu. Hence the 2 stars for this review. Coffee, needs improvement. The flat white was bland. I also spotted a tiny crack on my coffee cup, not acceptable.
For a $5.50 cup of flat white, I don't recommend that you come here for it.

address: 26 Beach Rd #01-18 South Beach Tower Singapore 189768 Singapore
comment: Real Food is located at South Beach next to the entrance to the Esplanade MRT Station. I went for a quick lunch and the big attraction for me was being able to sit outside and eat al fresco.The menu is quite diverse and offers both Asian and Western options, the main focus being wholesome, natural ingredients. I started with the vegetarian spring rolls which were nothing short of amazing. No dipping sauce required and I would go back just for the Spring rolls. For my main I went western as I wanted to try their thin crust pizza. It was light and tasty and while not of the same genre as artisan pizzas, it certainly held its own. They could probably add more spices to it, but you could tell the ingredients were fresh.I was pleasantly surprised with Real Food and I would definitely go back for the Spring Rolls and the great service.

address: 26 Beach Rd #01-18 South Beach Tower Singapore 189768 Singapore
comment: Great lentils burger! And an extensive menu full of healthy options.... My fav lunch option in the hood. Especially after they change the model and now it's full service instead of ordering yourself.

My review is solely based on their wonderfully crafted drinks, classic bruschetta appetizer and great service!!The lady and I were bar hopping and stopped here for a round... so glad we did!! I forgot the names of the drinks we ordered but I included a picture.  The bartender took his time to craft the drinks and upon completion, we felt the drinks looked way too nice to drink, but of course we did drink them!Everything was perfect and I recommend you stop by for a quick drink!  By the way, they have great drink specials and we took advantage of their "2 for 1"!

I can't believe this place has yet to have a review! Guys, if you haven't, please just try this when you are at the Capitol. And if you are here on a weekday during lunch time, it's really no excuse not to cos of their extremely value for money set lunches at $13.90++ or $16.90++. It comes with a serving of appetizer and a main that is of a generous portion! To round up the meal with a nice fresh breath, choose from their wide selection of tea at $9.90++ per pot that comes with a nice little mini biscuit and muffin too.The food here is really good! From pastas to mains (chicken or fish) to pizzas, you can have no fear that you will not have enough options. If you have a birthday, come and get their chocolate cake with the sparkle. You'll not regret it. Though I'm not so sure about their deconstructed tiramisu cos I still prefer tiramisu as one whole cake then broken down in pieces. All in all, a great place to chill and hangout. Come come come!!
The lunch set meal is a really good bargain. The pasta bolognese was well portioned and the flavor rich and satisfying. The espresso pairs well with their gelato.
Food is tasty.But I had a sharp piece of plastic in my pasta which cut the roof of my mouth. Completely unacceptable for a nice restaurant like this one. Would not go back !

Ate here by chance; many vegetarian options and pretty reasonable prices. They had the appetizer + main set for 24.90. Enjoyed my vegetarian risotto with the Asian flair sauce - a hint of tom yum was a nice surprise from the usual cream risotto flavors. Ambience was great; I loved the open layout of the restaurants at the Capitol.

Very underwhelmed by this place, website oversells it. Food decidedly average, service cheerless, ambience nothing special. Worst of all, I had a salmon dish that didn't smell great - then woke up with mild food poisoning. I would not go back under any circumstances.

address: 3 Punggol Point Road #01-03~05 S Singapore 828694 Singapore
comment: Good offer (50% off for crabs till 31-Jan) and the food tastes great too!Ambiance - seated outdoors facing the sea, nice cool breeze while the building blocks the evening sun. Nice! Food - Fried bee hoon looks different from menu.  Looks bland but surprisingly taste pretty nice.  The spicy milky crabs appear to be butter fried and it blends well with the spicy (not very to me) milky sauce.  Initially thought that it is going to be average with the current promotion and this does not disappoint too.  Thumbs up!

address: 681 Punggol Dr #01-06 Oasis Terraces Singapore 820681 Singapore
comment: Rise & Grind serves absolutely delicious coffees, teas and also western foods. Their chicken chops is succulent and very tender. There is quality and care in what they do. People are chilling here on a weekday afternoon in ulu punggol!Dinners and weekends are really crowded. It's got a chill vibe, cusions are laid on the benches to give a more cosy feel. And with quality food, this is a place great to be at with a book or with friends.

Tucked away in a cozy corner right by an entrance to the Punggol Riverside Walk, Frienzie Bar & Bistro is a perfectly fine place to pop by after an evening stroll along the river for some ice cold brewskis as day turns to night. Folks are really friendly here and it's a popular spot with locals. Happy hour's a plus but they also have other monthly drinks specials plus it's a full bar if beers aren't to your liking. If they are, feel free to grab a whole tower of it. The vibe is totally relaxed and you get a gentle breeze as you drink/dine alfresco. Totally a neighborhood spot, but a good one at that. Also means it can fill up fast with the limited options around.

Ambience is relaxed and great for friends to catch up over drinks. It's been a while since I visited ever since moving away from Punggol. Food wise Frienzie has a great selection of local and western dishes. It's not strange in Singapore to find harcheong chicken next to pizza or steak
Located along the riverfront. Pretty gd selection of alcohol. Chicken and ribs were underwhelming. The smoked duck was pretty awesome

From the looks of the place from the outside, it looked pretty classy and a nice place to chill out. They had a small bar at the side so people could order drinks while they ate their meals. I did not like their service though, me and a group of friends had stood there for awhile before any of the staff decided to seat us.The unpleasant service aside, we ordered some of the dishes including this huge sausage with mash potato and also the aglio olio. I remember that the sausage was quite a turn off as it was not tasty at all and a tad too rubbery. The oglio olio was also pretty dry and not tasty at all. We had ordered the side dish of chicken wings and it came to our table but it did not look appetizing at all, and not tasty too.I think the only thing that saved the meal was the average tasting brownie topped with ice cream. Though it tasted pretty average but it still managed to refresh my taste buds and i felt better after that. Aside from the bad food and service the price came up to be about $40 per pax too and it was a little pricey for me. Overall a very bad experience and i would never go back there again.

I love this place. Been here a few times. Greasy finger foods with fresh ingredients.Freshly squeezed lemonade, fresh cabbages and carrots for the cole slaw, great textured fish.The sauces are fantastic, and especially the xo mayo. Super bomb.The side dishes that you must try is the shishamo. Fatass pregnant fishies. The only gripe I have is that the food is greasy, obviously because they are dunked in oil and deep fried.The sandwiches are super value for money. You get a whole slab of fish fillet, and the whole sandwich get up is only $1 more (including the bread and veggies already).The crisps are amazeballs crispy, but you gotta eat them hot. If they're cold, they'll be soggy and it would be half the fun.Everything is self service, and the cutleries are placed where the sauces are.Easy to navigate order machines, automated queue calling for the food, and fun dips stand. I hope they stay this way, and don't reduce the sizes of their fish over time.

Few facts:On the top of the Bugis Junction shopping mall. Food is on the pricy side, but it's another alternative if you don't want typical local food.Most items are deep fired. Including Asian Fish, such as ShishamoYou can order from the machine and just wait them to call your numbers.Will it return-probably not
Fish ok. Crisps ok. salted egg sauce ok. But u gotta have some lemon or lime for the fish. fish n chips woulda been perfect w lemon on d side

Ministry of Food has set up 2 buffet concepts at the corner of level 1 at Punggol Waterway Point. We've visited Daessiksin (大食神) Korean BBQ Buffet previously and thought it was not worth a review. This time, we visited Danro Collagen Hotpot Buffet Punggol Waterway Point to try out its 美人锅 (Beauty Hotpot) and thought it was well worth it.The price of Danro Collagen Hotpot Buffet Punggol Waterway Point is actually pretty inexpensive. At $24.90++ for adults (and $13.90++ for kids) for dinners and weekends, it's not too bad. But if you're able to make it for lunch during weekdays, prices goes as low as $15.90++ for adults and $11.90++ for kids! Now, that's a steal! Do note that you'll have to top up $5, if you'd like to try the collagen soup base.Read the full review on 2bearbear!
the oyster omelette is my favourite thus far! crispy and flavourful! but sinfully oily.

If you're a fan of Orh Luak, then you'll probably love Hougang Fried Oyster. The fried oyster here is really delicious. The oysters are plump and large but the uncle also has perfected the balance between the gooeyness from the starch, while also frying everything till it's nice and crispy. Top if off with the sour and spicy chili sauce and the whole dish just works. So indulgent but so satisfying.They also do a wonderful oyster omelet that is light and fluffy with the same plump oysters. It also goes really well with some curry fish head and rice from another store in the same coffeeshop. Good crispy fried oysters + cold beer. Win.

Buffet's and I have a love/hate relationship. I used to go quite often to buffets, and as father time catches up to you, well, not so much anymore. But after a day of wakeboarding, you're stomach is growling and a buffet seems like a great idea. And if you're a fan of seafood, Sakura is a pretty decent choice. It's a grill + Shabu Shabu buffet which offers a large selection of seafood (prawns, salmon, dory, shrimp, scallop, squid, etc. - some is frozen mind you), pork, beef, chicken which are all delicious when thrown on the grill. A lot of the food is pre-marinated as well, so you can try a bunch of different things without getting bored. They also have veggies and fishballs for shabu shabu, and a small selection of cooked food as well.Some stuff is better than others, for instance the sushi is terrible, but all in all it's worth the $30 you'll pay for an all you can eat dinner on a weekend.I wouldn't say it's amazing, but for the value, it's pretty good, especially given that there is quite a good seafood selection.

Although this place is situated at quite an 'ulu' place, right at the end of punggol. It is about a 8 minute drive from punggol mrt and i suggest that it would be better to get somebody who is driving to bring you in as it is quite inconvenient to walk.Once you reach Punggol marina, there will be a lot of carpark lots available but if you go on the weekends you might end up parking outside along the road. The restaurant is quite big with 2 sections, 1 towards the carpark and 1 towards the sea. Be prepared to get your hair and clothes smoked up as the whole environment will be very smoky due to the bbq.The price is quite affordable at $26++ par adult and the range of food there is not bad as well. Alot of meat varieties and marinates that come along with it. There are other food to choose from like sushi and desserts with quite a variety. Each table will have their individual hot pot cum mini bbq pit to bbq their meat. A good place to hang out with friends or colleagues.

rest_name: Bedok North 85 Carrot Cake and Fried Oyster
comment: My "go to" place when I need to satisfy my cravings for carrot cake and fried oyster omelette. They serve the carrot cake in two versions, black and white. I usually order the black one and I think so far, it's the best I've had. The amount of black sauce they use is just right - not too sweet, not too salty. And the carrot cake is cut up to just the right size, which makes it easy to eat spoonfuls of it.Their fried oyster omelette is also worth checking out. Loads of starchy goodness mixed with crispy fried egg and oysters and some killer chilli sauce to go with it. This place gets my vote!

I don't know about the other guy but I have been eating here a lot and so far, there are stalls that are tasty. Its cheap and is very convinient for tourists like me who is on a tight budget. There are also hawkers around this area but the review is for this kopitiam :)The place is accesible and some of the stalls are open until 12mn. You can grab a quick bite before going to the mrt or going home. In conclusion, there are stalls that are needs to add more flavors but there are also a lot that tastes good. :)

Ate here with the company of 20 others and got to sample from most of the stalls open that day. Generally, the food is pretty "meh" - tastes just like generic food court food without any notable elements whatsoever. Even the Old Bugis Kway Chap promoted by Seth Lui was mediocre at best. The innards and pig skin were fresh but somehow, the bland gravy and side dishes failed to pack the much-needed punch! At least the portion size is big and there's enough variety in this place to sate your hunger. This is one of the few kopitiams in existence with no air conditioning, so come prepared to perspire!

Super big variety of food to choose from. There is also a market within should you need to get groceries instead of heading to NTUC and the likes. Prices here are pretty cheap and there is also a car park above the eatery. Came here as there is a laundromat services and I could while my time away drinking coffee or tea waiting for my laundry to wash and dry. How nice is this? Just make sure you choose the seats closer to the roadside as I feel the ventilation is definitely better!
blech the food here tastes so bad that I almost went berserk. Some of the food tastes like something you feed a dog.

I went here with my Cousin and his wife on a Saturday afternoon.  We went here for a super very late Lunch.  The staffs are efficient.  In terms of the menu, it's okay though I wish they could offer more dishes, since HALAL DIM SUM in Singapore it's NOT that many.  The pictures of the dishes in the Menu helps, though I wish they could have further descriptions of each item.  Since my cousins have been there, they did the ordering and I select some items that are calling my name.  The food/dishes comes out at periodically aka timely manner.We ordered the following items :*  Har Kow ($4.50)*  Lobster Mai ($6.50)*  Golden Pau ($4.80)*  Shrimp Chives Dumpling ($4.50)*  Pan Fried Chicken Dumpling  ($4.70)*  Steam Bean curd Roll in Thai Sauce ($4.70)*  Vietnam Crispy Rolls ($5.60)*  Chicken Crispy Rolls ($5.40)*  Deep Fried Prawn Roll ($11)*  Seafood Roll (Ngoh Hiang) ($11)My cousins opt for (HOT) ICE Limau @ $1.50 each, hence it was $3 for 2 orders as part of their beverages.  I opt to have (COLD) water @ $0.50.All in all, YES, all the food that we ordered and the dim sum dishes comes out piping hot from the steamers or the fryer.  That is good in my books.  But there are some items which is a hit or a miss in terms of flavor and execution wise.  Those items which are prepared with the Thai Spicy Sweet sauce, is either drenched with the Thai Spicy Sweet Sauce or has Thai Spicy Sweet Sauce as part of the condiment.  Hence everything which has the Thai Spicy Sweet Sauce tasted like the Thai Spicy Sweet Sauce.  *MEGA SIGH*If you are in the neighborhood, with a vehicle/a car this establishment is Ok to drive to..  but is it worth coming all the way here...  that is up to you... At least try if you have Muslim friends who wants to eat HALAL Dim Sum else you need to drive all the way to BEDOK area, which also has another outlet by the same name.  Do take note if you decide to dine here during the evenings or at night, prepare to wait with long queues and parking at the allocated parking spots can be a nightmare.  Hence DO PLAN Accordingly.TANG TEA HOUSE HONG KONG CAFE JALAN KAYUNo. 242 Jalan KayuSingapore 799466Tel : 6483 2298/ 6483 2284Fax : 6483 2291

Tasty crab bee hoon! This neighborhood cze char stall specializing in crabs was recommended to me by a friend who lives near it. She bought a number of dishes to takeaway to my place on one of our girls gathering that got me rather impressed. We didn't have crab that time though. Noteworthy dishes were the fried rice,  beancurd seafood roll and prawn paste chicken. The second and third time I ate from Master Crab (also takeaway), we had crab beehoon. They were consistently good both times though the crab on the first account was better, like, really really mind blowing good -- fresh, fleshy and sweet. Funny thing was, the quantity of crab beehoon we got was the same both times though the first time we ordered for two pax ($39, which I thought was incredibly cheap for such a good crab!) and the second time we did for four pax! ($54) We even asked for more beehoon!   I think the price difference could just be reflecting the difference in the weight of the two crabs, so fair enough. But the amount of beehoon we got couldn't feed two pax, much less four! I suspect it was because they only have one takeaway box size and make the dish to fit into it. But still... So yeah this episode made me a little wary of getting takeaway crab dishes from them. I will, however, return to try more crab dishes at the restaurant, especially their specialty -- salty egg crabs, heard it's awesome!
Common Zi char stall. Very crowded on weekends due to not much options around the punggol region. Dishes are very common also.

address: 60 Yishun Avenue 4 SAFRA Yishun Country Club Singapore 769027 Singapore
comment: This is a restaurant that serves mainly western fare. The décor of the place was pretty standard, and the service was attentive.We sat down, made our orders, and the food came pretty quickly.I had the ribeye steak, which was served with a baked potato with sour cream, bacon bits, spring onions and a few other side fishes. Brown mushroom sauce was poured over the beef. I found that the meat was succulent and sweet, definitely one of the better steaks I have eaten. The sauce was rather disappointing however; I found that it lacked flavor. Fortunately, the meat was good enough on its own.My friend had lamb chop, which came with fries and salad. The fries were thick and very nice. I asked to try a piece of the lamb chop and I was quite surprised to find that it was really tender. It's safe to say that the lamb chop here is really good and easily a cut above the usual lamb chops that you will have at the usual restaurants.   Overall, a great place to dine in, particularly if you happen to be in the area.

address: 60 Yishun Avenue 4 SAFRA Yishun Country Club Singapore 769027 Singapore
comment: The place was located by the swimming pool in the club. Although the place was not crowded (just a couple of tables occupied), there was no one to welcome me at the door. One had to walk all the way into the centre before managing to get the attention of the staffs. I ordered the Great Value Chicken Meal which cost $9.90++, which was available from 14 Nov to 15 Dec (Mon to Fri). The set meal came with Soup of the Day, the grilled chicken, Day's Dessert & Coffee/Tea.Soup of the DayThe soup was potato soup, topped with sliced of browned onions. It was served with a crusty garlic toast. Simple but savoury.Grilled ChickenThe chicken was tender and sliced easily. It was served with mushroom brown sauce, mashed potato and coleslaw. The coleslaw was interesting as it came with slices of crunchy apple.Day's Dessert The dessert was fruit pie, topped with custard sauce. The custard sauce was quite powdery in taste which the pie could do better without it. The pie was covered with a buttery flaky crust, with juicy cubes of fruit in it.Overall the food was not bad and it was a great deal.

address: 168 Punggol Field #01-01 Punggol Plaza Singapore 820168 Singapore
comment: This sze char stall is affordable and very scrumptious. Opens from 2pm on weekdays and it is mostly crowded at night for dinner. The famous dishes are the coffee pork ribs which are still juicy with a hinge of coffee taste. It is quite sweet and also flavorful at the same time. It looks like any ordinary sze char stall but do be amazed by the quality of food they serve.Other dishes that i would recommend are the basic sze char dishes like shen mee, mee goreng, hor fun, beef hor fun. One dish that other stalls might not have is the fried hor fun which tastes similar to char kway teow and also the sin chow bee hoon which is simply just yummy. I have tried other sin chow bee hoon else where but till date this is the best i can find.Other dishes to try that goes along with white rice are the sambal kang kong, salted egg prawn (which is the best because they de-shell it for you! Alot of places do not do that). Also a must try is the chicken essence frog leg soup just yummy.

address: Leong Ji Signatures Seafood Restaurant #02-10 Singapore 828694 Singapore
comment: Tried both the horfun and homemade tofu and it was nice. The "chaipoh" horfun consist of thin white noodles and it has a slight burnt aftertaste which liners in my mouth for a long time.  The sliced fish is fresh without the usual "disguising" staleness that I hv encountered elsewhere. Definitely worth trying! The homemade tofu with minced meat has a complex taste.  Tofu, slightly fried, blended well with sesame oil and soya source to give a very oriental taste and it is topped with salted minced meat. It taste great if eaten together. Will be back to try other dishes!

address: Leong Ji Signatures Seafood Restaurant #02-10 Singapore 828694 Singapore
comment: Ok the white bee hoon is better at other place but you won't have to wait on a line that goes out to be parking lot. Nothing bad. Service is good. Nice view from level 2.

address: Leong Ji Signatures Seafood Restaurant #02-10 Singapore 828694 Singapore
comment: Was looking for White Bee Hoon at the popular White Restaurant at The Punggol Settlement. Then again, the long queue daunted me. I don't feel that the White Bee Hoon there deserves such a long queue (personal feeling though) and so decided to roam around to source for alternate dinner. Walked through an almost dead dining town on a Monday night and saw an eatery called Leong Ji Signature on level 2. They were selling Zi Char and decided to see what they offered. Was surprised they offered the White Bee Hoon too and decided to order a plate to try plus the Prawn Paste Chicken aka Har Cheong Kai. The White Bee Hoon was pretty moist with good amount of sauce to go with and I personally felt that it was just as good as the other outlet. But the Har Cheong Kai was not as good due to the paste they use to marinate it in. It tastes pretty hard rather than crispy. Was leaving when I over heard another table order the Chao Ta Bee Hoon. Hmmm... Think I am going back again to try their other dishes.

Excellent place for crab. The Chinese name is House of Crab. They have several store. But my friend said the Punggol Settlement is the best. It is long drive but the highway make it easy. The place is pack at the time we have visited. We got their award winning Pepper Crab and the Creamy Butter Crab. To eat crab, you need your two hands. They provide a bowl water with lemon for hand cleaning. The Butter Crab need to come out first. It has the sweet butter taste. If the pepper crab come out first, the taste will over shadow the butter crab. The crab meat is abundant. The crawl is huge. They have a mechanical machine to crack the crawl. I like pepper crab the best. If you can handle some spicy sauce, I would recommend the pepper crab. We also got the Golden Egg three color amaranth veggies. It was good. We also got the white rice noodle. It has shrimp and fish meat. Good combo. Service is great.

We have always had really tasty black pepper crab here in this House of Seafood over the years! Always always very fresh, juicy, cooked to perfection black pepper crabs! Red chili crabs are also very tasty, while the black pepper crabs sauce is very peppery, tangy and savory!! Yummy goodness! We also love the veggie, fish meow soup, and fried noodles with crab meat!

Once or if we're lucky, twice every year we get to fly to the Food Paradise that is Singapore. I'd not been to Punggol in at least 30 or so years and upon arrival it was a stark difference from the dark, dusty village street I remember and was now a modern restaurant with bright lights and all the amenities and conveniences including tv screens.There's a bit of an unspoken tradition within our family in Singapore, in that everyone will always try to shout the other person's meal. With Dad being one of 14 children to his parents, there is certainly a rush to pay the bill, when it gets near the end of the meal and at times, there can be a bit of jostling between cousins, uncles and aunties to take care of the payment. Sometime I even go to the extreme where I'll pretend to go to the restrooms and sneakily pay before anyone else has had the chance.If it's not lines that tell you whether a restaurant is any good or not, you'll see photos of celebrities, certificates of awards and merit and newspaper clippings that adorn the facade and exterior of the restaurant and this one is famed for its crab.I must agree with other advisors in that the serving sizes were a bit on the small side but the taste and balance of flavours were near on perfect and the best crab I've ever had in my 30 plus years of heading to Singapore.Disregarding the portion size, the crabs were juicy and full of meat which isn't often the case and at other establishments I'm forever feeling for crab shell in my mouth with the claws shell shattered by the chef but I found the crab here to not have that issue and can only put it down to being carefully cracked open.The sauce was awesomely balanced and not too sweet with just a hint of chill and the black pepper crab sauce was head and shoulders above any other I'd tried and not too peppery, just right.The menu was massive and one of the most beautiful photographically to look and all the other dishes were superb and included deep fried, crispy squid aka Sotong Goreng, sizzling deer, sambal kang kong, seafood bee hoon, spicy and sweet pork ribs.All in all we had a great night and stayed until we were the last ones there and they made no mention of it.Cheers!Dave.

We had a big group of 12, the restaurant was packed really tightly to squeeze any livin available space to accommodate tables -.-In an attempt to soothen the hungry crowd, instrumental music was played, the servers are dressed in a Hawaiian shirt and they are plentiful around, so no worries!We ordered 3 kinds of crabs-Crab Beehoon-Chilli Crab-Pumpkin Crab It was my first time having crab beehoon and the broth was extremely tasty! I love it, the essence of crab,ginger and the milky finish was very refreshing.The chili crab lacked gusto, I had far better ones in hawker zichar. Could do better with more spice!Pumpkin Crab is quite an acquired taste, the sauce was thick and I don't think it was a popular choice. Huge pincers btw.We also ordered a couple of side dishes and 2 main carbs. worth mentioning are-yi mee ( we had seconds of, not the exact dish name but tasty!)The rest were pretty mediocre imho. parking here is v challenging. carparks get full too easily, there's also parking space near outward bound and side of road (not legal but everyone's desperate to unload)At around 7.30, Fatimah came to do her summons so beware.Overall, house of seafood is not mind blowing but very acceptable to big dining crowds.Families, there is a sand playground equipped with swings and slides. good way to tire out the little ones!

opening: [('Mon', ['Closed']), ('Tue', ['5:00 PM - 2:30 AM (Next day)']), ('Wed', ['5:00 PM - 2:30 AM (Next day)']), ('Thu', ['5:00 PM - 2:30 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['5:00 PM - 2:30 AM (Next day)']), ('Sat', ['5:00 PM - 2:30 AM (Next day)']), ('Sun', ['5:00 PM - 2:30 AM (Next day)'])]
comment: This place is not really a convenient location. Parking is atrocious and can cause quite a jam. I suggest you park at the housing estate nearby. This place is famous for their sambal fish and frog legs. Just the frog legs alone is worth your visit. The sauce is kick-ass! My first time using that word on Yelp. The sauce just coats perfectly on your porridge. Mike Chen, you gotta try this place. *Be glad to show you this place.* The spicy version is rather hot. I suggest ordering the non-spicy version and add chillies yourself. Their condiments is amazing. The chopped onions with lime/citrusy juice is just so perfect for the spicy frog legs. The smooth legs of the frogs is just even more tender than any chicken. Its a rather worthwhile death for the frogs if you lick em clean.Very clean eatery. Can be quite busy but service is efficient. Do be patient with them ya. Come slightly before dinner time like 5/6pm to avoid the crowds.3 frog legs for $16 while 2 frog legs for $13. It seems more value to get the 3 legs dish. Porridge is $2 or $3 for a pot and the $3 pot is really huge for groups of 3 or more. Even their vegetables like potato leaves, kailan is just so amazing! You can treat this as a semi chi-char place. This place is just the hush word for great food in this area. I'm just afraid this place be swarmed when the Michelin inspectors head over here.

opening: [('Mon', ['Closed']), ('Tue', ['5:00 PM - 2:30 AM (Next day)']), ('Wed', ['5:00 PM - 2:30 AM (Next day)']), ('Thu', ['5:00 PM - 2:30 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['5:00 PM - 2:30 AM (Next day)']), ('Sat', ['5:00 PM - 2:30 AM (Next day)']), ('Sun', ['5:00 PM - 2:30 AM (Next day)'])]
comment: The stingray's sambal never disappoints. Pair it with a bowl of kong pow frog legs and you in for an incredible food coma. 10/10 would grab to this secluded-ass place for more!

we were there on 20/5/2016, served by 3 pink poney tail waitresses. It was our first visit, therefore we asked questions abt the different flavors and prices. One of the waitress looked at us like aliens and told us she's very busy, but she instead went next table for drinks and smoke. Before we left, we requested for some iced water, and a thin guy at the bar gave us another alien look for a few seconds, then he slowly brought out 2 glasses of water for 10 of us. we don't mind paying for the water if it's needed, but don't stared at us. His behavior was annoying.We felt that all the staff there were very rude not friendly, they only concentrate on their own friends that were there that night. This will be my first and last time to visit there

Very bad behavior of their staff and manager. We ordered for a dish while confirming 2 times (with staff as well as chef) that they can serve it without any meat or chicken. But they served it with chicken. Due to low light outside in evening, I happened to eat chicken which is against my religion. When we highlighted to manager, he turned out to be more rude and arrogant.My advice- you better starve than eating at this place.

address: 3 Punggol Point Rd #01-11/12 The Punggol Settlement Singapore 828694 Singapore
comment: Looking for unique dining experience to celebrate birthday with the kids. We were the first table & warmly welcomed by staff who explained different sets & recommended few ala carte items. That's all for service. The ribeye, fish tofu & fishball with roe egg came deep deep frozen. The slices of beef stuck together you could not separate them without tearing them into smaller pieces. The fish tofu were hard as ice & took ages to defrost & warmed up in the broth. Extremely disappointed that the frozen food were not defrosted before serving. It was indeed an uniquely bad mookata dining experience for us. Only three tables on a Friday night. Could easily understand why.

address: 60 Yishun Ave 4, #02-VI Safra Yishun Country Club Singapore 769027 Singapore
comment: If you are looking for a good and affordable Chinese Restaurant, Pin Shi will definitely be my number one choice. I brought my entire family to this restaurant when I received my first pay check. I would like to comment on their steamed salted kampong chicken.  They come with a really big portion costing only $8.80 to dine there and $6.80  for take-away. Smooth chicken! My family totally loves it. Not forgetting to mention on their fish maw soup and shark fin soup. For the price you are paying, I would expect lesser ingredient and more soup. But that is definitely not the case at Pin Shi. They are really generous in their portion of fish maw. Love it to the max.So I would definitely suggest to people who are looking for good food at affordable prices.

address: 60 Yishun Ave 4, #02-VI Safra Yishun Country Club Singapore 769027 Singapore
comment: Impromptu visit as I was craving for Dim Sum today. Search around and was lazy to leave my hometown Yishun and found this place. There is public car park in Yishun Safra and lots of spaces.Restaurant servers are courteous and inviting  the atmosphere was what strike me the most as compared to other Dim Sum outlets. Due to Covid-19, the tables were well spaced out with soft music playing in the background.The food are as good as other Dim Sum outlet. Not losing in quality and quantity. The Crispy Beancurd Skin with Prawns were well stuffed with Prawns. The Chicken Claw with Black Pepper Sauce was not too spicy and tasted really good.Would definitely come back for another round once my craving hits me.

address: 60 Yishun Ave 4, #02-VI Safra Yishun Country Club Singapore 769027 Singapore
comment: Our family of 4 adults and 3 children made reservations at Pin Si for our pre-Christmas dinner. We appreciated the fact that we were informed beforehand that the restaurant was booked for a wedding event and we would be dining at the SAFRA Ballroom (next to restaurant) instead. When we arrived, we were shown to the Ballroom which looked like a makeshift room with tables and chairs. The air-con wasn't turned on. We realized it's stuffy and had to tell the service staff to turn it on. When the dishes were served, we were very disappointed with the portion. The pieces of pork ribs weren't enough to go round the table. The rice bowls resemble those toy bowls that my kids play at home. So, we had to order additional bowls of rice (maybe that's the whole idea!). It doesn't help make us feel any better, with the slow service on that day. I guess the service staff would have to go over next door to pick up the dishes and collect bowls of rice to bring over to the Ballroom. The price may seem reasonable on the menu, but we don't find much value-for-money, judging the petite portions. The quality of the dishes didn't disappoint us, at the very least. The pork ribs 京都排骨 dish was nicely done, though could be better if it's slightly more tender; the sweet and sour grouper fish 酸甜鱼 is wonderful to the palate of kids. To add to the enjoyment, the crispy skin roasted chicken 脆皮鸡was excellent - crispy on the skin, tender on the meat. Not to forget the crispy salted egg salmon skin 咸蛋炸鱼皮 as starter.  Perhaps, I may consider returning, when the restaurant is available for dining.

address: 60 Yishun Ave 4, #02-VI Safra Yishun Country Club Singapore 769027 Singapore
comment: Located at a secluded corner in yishun safra. It would be pretty inconvenient to reach this place without a car.Food to try, their kampong chicken and the fish maw soup. You wouldnt want to miss the shen mien (crispy noodle) and the XO fried rice. Price is value for money and definitely they serve food that is restaurant level.However you might be perplexed by the pricing system of the kampong chicken. Take away is $2 cheaper than dine in and you would not be able to eat the take away else you will be charge as dining in.Great place to hang out, cheap and good !

address: 60 Yishun Ave 4, #02-VI Safra Yishun Country Club Singapore 769027 Singapore
comment: One of the best restaurant in Yishun. The food is good and ambience ok. What I don't like is the glass windows, looks very dirty.

address: 60 Yishun Ave 4, #02-VI Safra Yishun Country Club Singapore 769027 Singapore
comment: I came to Safra Yishun for an event and went to this restaurant with some of the friends that I had made there.Turns out that this was the right decision, and indeed it is actually somewhat surprising to find a good restaurant here in Safra Yishun.We had the deep fried beancurd with pork floss, which looked but more importantly, tasted fantastic. The beancurd Is crispy on the outside and smooth in the inside.We also had the peking duck skin with crepe. Usually, this dish is not my favorite and the peking duck skin here did not change my opinion. I felt that the duck skin had lost its texture. The noodles cooked with duck meat was really good though. Next, we had the salted egg prawn, which came with a coating of salted egg around the prawn. This is my first time eating this dish and I really liked it as well.Overall, this is a good place to come for good food, although the prices could be slightly lower.
Simple menu with traditional recipe full flavour. If you are looking for something healthy, full flavour, fast and cheap, you have found your place. Very friendly staff. Come over!
Stall owners smoke disgustingly even though there's a "No Smoking" signs. Very ignorant and didn't care about other patrons. Won't be goin there anymore.

Some pretty good "meat bone tea" here at Olden Street Bak Kut Teh. The herbal soup is light but deep and flavorful with a nice balance of pepper and garlic. In addition, the meat is fall off the bone tender. Much joy to eat when dipped in some dark soy and sliced chili. You should also order some of the side dishes. I really liked the braised tau kee and tau pok but the preserved veg is pretty good too.The space looks newly renovated and was a comfortable spot for lunch even in the afternoon. Surprisingly it wasn't crowded when we arrived for lunch but it filled up shortly after and for good reason. That soup really hits the spot but they have other dishes like braised pork that look real good too.

address: 3004 Ubi Ave 3 #01-124 Kampong Ubi Industrial Estate Singapore 408860 Singapore
comment: This place is also known as Wong poh cafe, and has a variety of food including chinese mixed rice, malay food and chicken rice that starts at $2.50. The scissor cut rice is served by an uncle who is quite comical. He dances as he cuts the food up and serves it to you, drown in curry sauces. The curry is just right, not too spicy to or too sweet. The pork chop is crispy and meaty. I got it with veggies which were very wet and sweet. All in all, a simple meal for $3. The coffee shop can be quite hot, so do find a seat that has a fan blowing it.

address: 3004 Ubi Ave 3 #01-124 Kampong Ubi Industrial Estate Singapore 408860 Singapore
comment: Yong tau foo is a must try!! Traditional style comes w a set of standard ingredients, definitely saves the hassle of picking your own. If you order dry noodles, it coms with bar chor(minced pork) and a bit of garlic. The lady taking orders is really nice and sweet as well.

We read some reviews on Shan Cheng and thought we would give it a try. After all it offered food from Ipoh that I am familiar with. "Par Lor Sha Hor Fun," was a motivation. I order the Char Siew Hor Fun and my wife order the Ipoh Hor Fun. When we picked out our orders we took some pickled green chillies and sambal.   We were disappointed with the Ipoh Hor Fun. It was a poor representation of the Ipoh Hor Fun that I knew and loved. The soup was overwhelmed with the chilli oil. There were only a few strips of chives. The Char Siew Hor Fun was okay but nothing to shout about.    I wouldn't recommend it for those who have tasted genuine Ipoh Hor Fun.   The only consolation was the sambal. It was very good. For that I gave it 2 stars.

address: 83 Punggol Central #B1-21, Waterway Point Singapore 828835 Singapore
comment: This restaurant is located in the East wing of the mall at basement one. If you are lost, look for fish & company or breadtalk. It is in that same block just walk for the in and you will find it in the left corner of the building.Parking was easy and abundant. We parked in basement one which was perfect for us because my grandmother needed wheelchair assistance and it was a very straight shot to the basement one of the mall.As it was lunchtime the mall was rather crowded but the restaurant which we went to, Uncle Leong, is a seafood restaurant. It was quite empty. Initially when we sat down, I thought we were not going to enjoy our lunch.after we were seated, we were given a rather sick menu, I went straight for the lunch set for 4 people. We also added a few dishes in case the four was not enough for the five of us.I was set lunch for four plus one included seafood hor fun, lemon chicken, drunken prawn, abalone spinach, tri-egg spinach, fried tofu, Ginger and scallion sliced fish. All the dishes that came taste it great. There was just the right amount of flavor and as of now I am reviewing this one hour after we finish our lunch I don't feel thirsty which usually is the case with Cantonese/Chinese restaurants where they add a lot of monosodium glutamate to the food.The server told us that for lunch we are entitled to 30% discount which does not apply to sets. So we got out 30% off on a la carte dishes.Overall, this restaurant was a surprise. And we receive attentive service from the servers as it was very empty at lunch time.

address: 83 Punggol Central #B1-21, Waterway Point Singapore 828835 Singapore
comment: Uncle Leong Seafood has a new branch at Waterway Point located at the East Wing Basement 1 near all the Telco shops. LOCATION  4/5Not being located at the central atriums doesn't really impact on it much. There is usually a long queue at the entrance, waiting for be seated.  AMBIENCE  3/5Its a slightly above average ambience. About 3-5 waiters/ waitresses staff are servicing the entire restaurant. The tables are situated quite closed to each other so it might be a bit inconvenient moving around the tables if people sit a bit away from the tables.FOOD   4/5The sweet sour fish, signature tofu, salted egg with fish slices and stir fried deer meat were good. The stir fried kang kong with garlic was a bit bland. COST  3.5/5At about $20/head, so it would make more sense to have a larger group to dine in if you would like to try out more dishes.

address: 83 Punggol Central #B1-21, Waterway Point Singapore 828835 Singapore
comment: When comes to crabs, Uncle Leong Seafood wasn't any stranger to Singaporeans nor tourists. Being one of the big players in our local cze char market now, Uncle Leong Seafood started off humbly at a coffeeshop in Ang Mo Kio district. Their shimmering crabs won the hearts of many when it was first introduced to the market in Year 2003 and was since one of their signature dish even till today. Although Ang Mo Kio stall was no longer around, but you could still enjoy their delicacies at Jurong East and Toa Payoh branches. Not forgetting the newly opened Uncle Leong Signatures at Punggol district new Waterway Point shopping mall.Uncle Leong Signatures, this newly additional arm, was up featuring all Uncle Leong's signature dishes and also new modern fusion creations. Although called "Signatures" but settings were simple and casual. This night, we tried out many dishes, some were newly introduced to the menu, some dishes were specially featured for this upcoming Father's Day in June. Father's Day menu (FDM) available now till 19 June 2016.1* Treasure Box Beancurd 宝盒豆腐 $16.90 [New]- Tofu, a common ingredient that we see's everyday, Uncle Leong recreated them into an exquisite dish filled with goodness from the sea. By making an opening in every piece, filled them up with fresh scallops and prawn cubes, they transformed into many treasure boxes filled with "gold"! Although the overall taste of tofu can be rather bland, but the seafood were definitely fresh! Not forgetting the crispy shredded scallops placed on top helped to enhanced the taste too! Rating 3/52* Nescafé Pork Ribs 传统咖啡排骨 $16.90 (FDM)- Love the taste of the sweet sauce coated on the ribs which carries hints of bitterness derived from Nescafé coffee infusion. Coffee fragrance was captivating too! Fans of coffee definitely love this dish! As told by the chef, these generous chunky pieces of ribs were individually wrapped in aluminum foil, then marinated for more than 4hours before stew! I couldn't tell you how tender and fragrant was the pork, you gotta try it to experience it yourself! Rating 5/53* Twin Taste Kai Lan 双味芥兰 $15.90- Glad to see that Uncle Leong made changes to our usual plain ordinary Kai lan vegetables but there's more room for improvement in this dish. Deep fried kailan leaves were tasteless and the chicken floss accompanying them tasted too ordinary. Maybe using Chinese sausages or bacon bits would worked better than this combi, or at least use crispy floss instead. Lucky the stems wasn't overly blanched, crunchiness still remains. Rating 1/54* Crispy Milk Granules Marble Goby 奶沙顺壳 $48.00 (FDM)- This marble goby was deep fried till crispy you could even swallow the bones. The sauce for this goby was pretty impressive too. It tasted like a combi of thai tom yum sauce plus assam and bit of sweet chilli. The tangy sourish aftertaste made the whole dish really appetizing and made me go for more!! Rating 5/55* Cereal Chicken 麦片鸡 $16.90 [New]- Chicken pieces deep fried till crispy on the exterior, locking juicy meat on the inside. The zesty lemony sauce drizzled on top did add more flavours to the dish but it tends to turn the chicken soggy after awhile. My most love part towards this dish was the buttery cereals crunchies scattered on top! Rating 3/56* XO Sauce Scallops XO酱带子 $19.90 [New]- I'm actually a fan of juicy fat plump scallops but those here were way too tiny. The size was more of like those you accompanied with broccoli rather than a stand alone dish. Texture was good but disappointed I couldn't taste that umami scallop taste! The XO sauce used was the only memorable moment. Rating 2/57* Pan-fried Prawns w/ Tomato Soya Sauce 干煎虾䘵 $19.90 [New]- Expected "Wok hei" taste for these pan-fried prawns but was again disappointed. Prawn texture wasn't firm and my piece was a little mushy at head portion, I reckon that prawns wasn't very fresh. Soya sauce base  was rather sweet but I like, pretty good to "下饭". Rating 2/58* Chilli Crabs 辣椒螃蟹 and Butter Cheesy Crab 牛油芝士螃蟹 $70.00 each crab-  Crabs were priced at $70.00 each, applied to any style of cooking. This plate of Chilli crab we had, the gravy was thick and packed w/ lotsa eggs! Taste was quite good, I definitely had better ones elsewhere, but I love the spicy kick it gave me :) I had my deep fried "man tou" soaked in the gravy before I ate it, so shiok!! Crab meat was firm and sweet too, I just wished that the crab they used was bigger in size. Rating 4/5- Butter Cheesy crab, the appearance of it already puzzled us. What were the loads of brown bits scattered everywhere? After we tasted it, we were quite turned off. Those brown bits were deep fried garlic. So much, so charred, we only tasted "chao tah" bitterness and 0% cheesy butter taste. The garlic totally spoilt the sweetness of seafood. I guess this dish needed quite abit of fine tuning. Rating 1/5

Bought bread here, a whole meal loaf and sourdough. For some reason they wouldn't slice the bread in the bread slicer, so we ended up with giant slices. Other bakeries who sell sourdough will slice it for you in the bread slicer so you can use it for sandwiches. The taste was great, but I would prefer it if they would use the machine to slice. My whole meal loaf got all smashed from the hand slicing.

Great sandwiches, and amazing bread to take home. If you decide to eat there, just be sure to have no plans afterwards. As amazing as the sandwiches are, something about them requires somewhere between 30-45 mins to make them. Its mystifying how sandwiches could take that long, but you'll see for yourself.

address: 205 Hougang St 21 #02-00, Heartland Mall Singapore 530205 Singapore
comment: The casual restaurant is located at the second level of the mall. The place is decorated in peranakan traditional style with pottery around the walls. Although we are the first customers of the day, certain dishes such as the five spice roll is not available as still have not delivered from the central kitchen. At the counter, sauces and assorted kuehs are available for sale.Ayam Buah Keluak ($7.90)Chicken braised in thick tamarind gravy with buah keluak nuts.I feel that the gravy is too watered down. The chicken is tender and flavourful.Bakwan Kepeting ($6.90)Minced pork and crabmeat meatballs with bamboo shoots in a clear soup.I could not taste the crabmeat in the meatballs, although the meatballs are juicy. Quite plain looking.Nyonya Chap Chye ($6.50)Stew mixed vegetables with prawns in a soy bean sauce.I could not find any trace of the prawns in this dish although the vegetables is well braised. Hor Pow ($4.50)Stuffed beancurd, served with chilli chukkaThe stuffed beancurd tastes quite plain on its own but with the tangy sweet it adds a spark to the dish.Home-made Ang Cho Teh ($2.20) & Bandong with ChinChow ($2.80)Refreshing and rich in taste.Gula Melaka Sago ($2.50)I like that the gula melaka used here has been filtered off the impurities. It tastes smooth and rich except that the coconut milk is a bit lumpy.We also try 3 of the kuehs which costs $2. They are taste not bad except a bit too soft.Overall the food is not bad. The service is a bit slow even when there is no other customer. The place is packed when it hits the lunch hour, especially with the older generation.

address: Block 340 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Singapore 560340 Singapore
comment: Located in a coffee shop in the matured estate of Ang Mo Kio is Chok Chai Mookata. Just opened 3 months ago by Len and Jon, these young and energetic duo have tasted the goodness of authentic Thai Mookata in Thailand. They then decided to bring back this delicious family sharing style of food to Singapore. They spent time learning the authentic marinating methods and tweaked their recipe to suit Singaporean taste buds.Their menu seemed very reasonable for a HDB coffeeshop. $28 for 2-3 pax and $45 for 4-5pax for a mookata set. Ala carte add-ons start at $3 for thai black pepper chicken, farlic lean meat and pork belly!Mookata Set for 4-5 pax - Lots of varietyFor the set menu, here's what you get1. Thai Black Pepper Chicken2. Thai Garlic Lean Meat3. Prawns4. Sotong5. Scallops6. Pork Ball7. Crab Stick8. Fish Ball10. Hot dog11. Xiao Bai Cai12. Cabbage13. Golden Mushroom14. Sweet Corn15. Carrot16. Tang Hoon17. EggLooking at the amount of ingredients for the price, I must say, this is probably the most bang for the buck mookata I've seen. There's a huge variation of ingredients at about $10 per pax. There is no beef in the set but you can order beef slices from the ala carte menu.Owner Len explained that here at Chok Chai, they strongly believe in providing you with the authentic Thai experience, so much so that they import chilli from Thailand. They have invested in their own grinding techniques to make their own in-house chilli. He shared that the chilli had coriander, garlic and a mix of "secret" ingredients to give it the wow factor.The bacon strips had a good ratio of fats to meat and it was extremely juicy and oily after grilling for some time.A mookata experience is all about sharing food with your friends and family and cooking food together and for one another. It's a great opportunity for bonding.The lean meat was very well marinated with a somewhat sweeter marinate in comparison to the other meats. It was very tasty and slightly chewy with every bite. It was definitely one of my favourite choice of meats during the meal.The liver cooked very quickly in the hot boiling soup surrounding the grill iron. It was very tasty and definitely pretty fresh.The mookata broth was made with pork bone, white radish, pandan leaves and more "secret" ingredients. This according to owner Len was the "authentic" soup broth he had learnt from his trips to Thailand. So there's basically only one soup broth available here and there's no tom yum options either. The maggie noodles were seriously awesome as they could really absorb all the soup essence in one go. After we cooked the noodles, we had to repeatedly top up the soup. The Thai speaking staff were also very attentive and noticed the soup levels going down each time we cooked the noodles and volunteered to top up the soup for us, despite having a kettle of soup placed next to the mookata.There's also a separate dish of vegetables. I'm no rabbit so vegetables aren't for me, but I did love their generous serving of enoki mushrooms.Som Tam (Papaya Salad) with Fresh PrawnA famous Thai appetizer for any Thai meal be it mookata or not is Som Tam. But as I don't eat spicy foods, I've never actually been able to gobble down a Som Tam myself. According to my friends who tried it, they all said it was spicy! But looking at the generousity of the prawns, I can tell Chok Chai is pretty game to deliver an appetizer to whet your appetite.Overall : Hidden gem in Ang Mo Kio, very reasonable prices for mookata with quality ingredients accompanied with great service.Now, if only they served Thai iced milk tea! I would have a complete thai dinner!

address: 1002 Toa Payoh Industrial Park #01-1407 Singapore 319074 Singapore
comment: More detailed review available on my blog: lynnechua.blogspot.com/2…Been to this restaurant several times with family and relatives. Love their dishes, especially chilli crab and black pepper venison!

address: 1002 Toa Payoh Industrial Park #01-1407 Singapore 319074 Singapore
comment: The location is in one secluded industrial park but this restaurant is one of the best kept secret in the tze cha scene. The place is air conditioned with table cloth settings, but priced just slightly above across the street.Food is above average I would say. I particularly like tge sweet and sour pork. Unlike most places where the prok is soggy after the gravy is poured onto the meat, this place managed to maintain the crispness of the pork. No service charge and gst is a real plus at this place.

rest_name: Nam Hwa Chiang Fish Head Steamboat
comment: Your regular zhichar place, with fish steamboat on the menu. They have a few types of fish for you to choose, and we picked the 2 people portion, for 3 people, and added on shrimp paste wings and sambal kangkong.I really liked the kangkong here, but the shrimp paste wings just had a hint of shrimp paste, which was a bit of a letdown. The steamboat was not too bad, and the soup wasn't too salty. They top up the soup liberally, and it comes in an old-fashioned sort of charcoal hotpot. Would I come back?  I guess so.

rest_name: Nam Hwa Chiang Fish Head Steamboat
comment: I have been hearing from others, that Nam Hwa Chiang Fish Head Steamboat is nice and tasty. Finally, I can try out today. You can go there by MRT and bus, the queue is sometime  horrible, in order to save your time, you can make your reservation before going.But it really disappointed me. Six of us order fish head steamboat, oyster eggs, salted egg pork ribs and one vegetable. These dishes cost us $15 per person. The food is not fantastic at all. The steamboat soup is salty as it included salted fish. The service is bad as well, we try to order drinks after drinking the salty soup for at least 3 times, but end up, they didn't serve the drinks at all.

Don't let the hippy jazz / lounge music intimidate you. Tachinomiya invaded the Kovan neighbourhood about 6 months ago and it's located a couple of doors down from Hatter Street cafe. This restro-bar serves Japanese food, a great variety of sakes and whiskies at crazy affordable prices. There's a weekday lunch set available (with 4 options to choose from) reasonably priced at $8.90 only. If you're going in a group, you might wanna add on to that order with a side of Yakitori (they're good for this). Wash it down with a nice 500ml pint of Asahi beer on a hot afternoon (there's black Asahi available too!) & the bill per person amounts to less than $20. Didn't fancy the disposable utensils but it keeps serving & clearing more efficient. It gets crowded in the evenings when people knock off work & come by for drinks & bites. Nice, laid-back place. You would expect service to be slack since there's NO service  & GST charge, but No. it's personal & quite attentive. drop a tip for the server(s) if you appreciate the servic If you enjoy good bites, drinks set in a casual neighbourhood, you should check out Tachinomiya. This little shop deserves a little more awareness:)

4 set lunch choice to choose from. The katsu curry seem popular and the Gyu Beef set too. Presentation of the meal was in take out boxes. If you are familiar with the popular Tori Tori yakitori seen in malls, the take out box is like that. While there's a Japanese feel of efficiency, it does take away the presentation. The Katsu curry rice is reasonable in taste but the Gyu beef in soy sauce was somewhat too saltish for my preference. For the price of the lunch set with miso and Ocha is reasonable. The yakitori was a bit of disappointment. It was dry and tough. From the open kitchen, I noticed that the yakitori was partially prepared in oven instead of the traditional grill.It is worth to give it a try and hopefully they have fine tune the recipe the next time I visit.

I've always been curious about their sizzling pasta dishes. It is self-service, like MOS burger. I got the tomato cream seafood pasta dish. The board says tomato cream, but it wrote "spicy tomato" on my receipt. Hmm. The pasta sauce was definitely spicier than I had expected. It's not bad, tangy and spicy. The only thing I would criticize is that the pasta serving is too small, and if you are someone who doesn't like to DIY, don't try this place out. The shrimps were small and unfresh, and I would expect something more out of a 11.90 meal. The beef entrees are probably much better, since they are the most popular entrees.

Do-It-Yourself food involves an enjoyable and fulfilling process. It also comes with a guarantee that your food will always be served hot before consumption. Pepper Lunch still maintains its popularity after all these years and I'm happy to say that the franchise deserves such a rep. The Pepper Lunch outlet at Hougang Mall was where I had my first DIY Japanese food experience.Service is usually quick at the outlet and the food doesn't disappoint either. As I'm a fan of sticky rice and gravy, my usual dish of choice is the Curry Beef Pepper Rice with Cheese. Firstly, the food proportions are normally quite ample. Secondly, it tastes pretty fantastic. Mixing in the curry rice with cheese just brings warmth and comfort to my taste buds. One of the best combinations ever!I also have to commend on how tender the beef strips are, which come in quite a generous portion too.  If you're a student then it's double whammy for you because the eatery provides really good student discounts. Don't forget to end your meal with their signature (extremely) soft and smooth ice cream!

rest_name: Yi Jia South Village Seafood Restaurant
comment: There are both indoor & outdoor seating available. They own 2 units next to each other so don't be too alarmed to see only 5 tables when you walk into the restaurant. Almost all the dishes we ordered were tasty! Only the deep fried pork knuckle was a bit dry & tough. Rating 2/5The prawn paste chicken (har cheong gai) was light & crispy on the outside & juicy on the inside. Rating 5/5The deep fried sotong (squid) with salted egg yolk was not too over powering & still soft & chewy. Rating 4/5The deep fried fish skin was also very light & crispy. Rating 4/5The Mongolian tofu was something I've never tried before. It's like a tofu ring (similar to yam ring/basket) with seafood ingredients in the middle. The steamed tofu had a tangy taste to it. Rating 3/5The "green dragon" stir fried vegetable with shaved almonds has a unique taste to it. Very nice! Not sure what is the English name for it though. Rating 5/5

rest_name: Yi Jia South Village Seafood Restaurant
comment: Went there for reunion dinner. Appointment was at 5pm and the restaurant informed us that we will need to leave by 630pm as it would be time for the next session. We arrived at 445pm, had lohei at 505pm, and the first dish arrived only at 545pm (yes, 45mins waiting time for the first dish). It is puzzling why all the dishes that came out in the interim went to other tables. Perhaps we ordered a less expensive set meal? When the dishes came, the broccoli was overcooked, and the sharks fin soup was the saltiest that I have ever had. By the time the third dish came at 605pm, I had to leave for my next reunion dinner. Hence, I am unable to comment on the quality of the rest of the dishes. I can understand that business is brisk on the eve of cny. That said, the restaurant should have minimally ensured satisfactory service standard and food quality, both of which were totally absent during my stay there. If you would like to visit this restaurant, I would suggest that you visit at non-peak seasons. Hopefully, the waiting time is bearable and the food is edible.

Nice neighborhood spot in Braddell Heights serving Kerala cuisine. Been searching for an authentic Indian restaurant in town and was so glad to stumble upon this place! Ordered the Chicken Peratal, Kerala Beef Roast, and Kerala paratha to share. The beef roast was recommended by the server and the highlight of the meal. Both dishes were slightly too spicy for me, but went well with the paratha and mango lassi. Don't expect much from the ambience and service, but the authentic food and wide selection makes this place worth a visit.

Went to Curry Magic for lunch as it was recommended by a friend. The restaurant is located within a private housing estate and is in an area where parking options aren't plenty and if you're going there via public transportation, all the best. The restaurant has ample seating and isn't too crowded even during lunch on a Friday. There were 6 of us in total.
